Image_title: [Title page]
Description: A king sits on his throne. Through the windows may be seen pineapple plants or cacti.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a] Carta de relacio[n] e[m]biada a Su. S. Majestad del e[m]p[er]ador n[uest]ro señor por el capita[n] general dela Nueua Spaña: llamado Ferna[n]do Cortes. ; enla q[ua]l haze relacio[n] d'las tierras y proui[n]cias sin cue[n]to q[ue] hã descubierto nueuame[n]te enel Yucata[n] del an[n]o de. xix. a esta p[ar]te: y ha sometido ala corona real de Su S.M. ..
Source_publisher: Por Jacobo Cromberger aleman
notes: Imprint from colophon. Cortés (1485-1547) sent five long reports (also known as "letters of relation") to Emperor Charles V detailing his progress in the conquest of Mexico. This is the second one, in which Cortés narrates the wars and alliances that took place on the way to Tenochtitlan, and provides vivid descriptions of the land and the peoples he encounters which he calls New Spain. This letter was the first time the name of a European nation was used with the adjective "new" to name an American territory.
References_exhibitions: http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/John_Carter_Brown_Library/spHistorical/index.html (July 2013)

Image_title: [De las costumbres destos Indios, y de las armas que vsan, y de las cerimonias que lienen, y quien fue el fundador dela ciudad de Antiocha]
Description: Masons build a wall while an overseer directs their work.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Parte Primera dela chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin de Montesdoca
notes: Text here refers to the city of Antiocha [Antioquia, Colombia?], but this is a generic image of masons probably intended to represent native American workers. The same woodcut is used many times in book to illustrate the building of other towns. Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [De los ritos y sacrificios q estos Indios tiene: y quan gra des carniceros fonde comer carne humana]
Description: Human sacrifice. Native American plunges a knife into another's chest. Two bodies hang, a statue of an idol or devil on a pillar stands at left.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Parte Primera dela chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin de Montesdoca
notes: Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [De los carneros, ouejas, Buanacos, y Vicunias que ay en toda la mayor parte de la serrania del Peru]
Description: Llamas or vicuñas.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Parte Primera dela chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin de Montesdoca
notes: Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: Cerro de Potosi
Description: Town and mountain of Potosí. Includes a view of the churches, dwellings, and town square (with decapitated head on a pike) of the settlement. Also includes river and paths up the mountain along with an indication of the different veins of silver.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Parte Primera dela chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin de Montesdoca
notes: The mines at Potosí in Peru were discovered by Diego Hualca in 1544. The silver mines there were among the richest in the world.

Image_title: [En que se trata quien fueron los reyes Incas, y lo q[ue] mandaron en el peru]

Image_title: [Como antiguamente tuuiero vna esmeralda por dios en que dorauan los Indios de Manta: y otras cosas q ay q dezir destos indios]
Description: Sacred stone of the native Americans of Manta, Ecuador, worshipped by a priest and supplicants.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Parte Primera dela chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin de Montesdoca
notes: Cieza de Leon writes of the leader of Manta having an emerald of great size and value which the people worshipped. Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [De los pozos que ay en la punta de sancta Elena: y de lo que cuentan de la venida que hiziero[n] los gigantes en aquella parte: y del ojo de alquitran que en ella esta]
Description: Native Americans run from flames which come down from the sky.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Parte Primera dela chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin de Montesdoca
notes: Illustrates the native American legend of the giants who lived on the Santa Elena peninsula, Peru, who were driven off by a youth shining like the sun who descended from the sky and threw flames of fire at the giants. Image title taken from chapter title.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Cuzco [De la manera y traça con que esta fundada la ciudad del Cuzco: y de los quatro caminos reales que de ella salen: y de los grades edisicios que tuuo: y quie fue el fundador]
Description: Incan ruler, possibly symbolizing Manco Capac (adorned with the royal fringe [llautu] or crown), gesturing toward Cuzco to Francisco Pizarro.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Parte Primera dela chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin de Montesdoca
notes: Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [De la gran laguna que esta en esta comarca del Collao: y quan honda es: y del te[m]plo de Titicaca]
Description: Boatmen on Lake Titicaca with city in background.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Parte Primera dela chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin de Montesdoca
notes: Cieza de León's description of Lake Titicaca is the first published account and depiction of it. Two other Spaniards reported seeing it in 1533.Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: Effigies Nicolai Monardis Medici Hispalensis: Aetatis sive anno
Description: Title page with portrait of Nicolás Mondardes holding an open book. Also includes a coat of arms.
Source_Title: Dos libros, el vno que trata de todas las cosas que traen de nuestras Indias Occidentales, que siruen al vso de la medicina, y el otro que trata de la piedra bezaar. y de la yerua escuerçonera
Source_publisher: en casa de Hernando Diaz, en la Calle de la Sierpe

Image_title: [Ten commandments]
Description: Two left hands with each finger labeled twice with the ten commandments. The hand on leaf 14 verso is labeled in Spanish; the hand on leaf 15 recto is labeled in Huastec.
Source_Title: Doctrina christiana en la lengua Guasteca co[n] la lengua castellana ...
Source_publisher: En casa de Pedro Ocharte
notes: These woodcuts of hands with type-printed labels were used as mnemonic devices to teach the concept of the Ten Commandments. The Huastec or Guasteca people of the province of Vera Cruz are tribes of Maya stock who were isolated from the rest of the Maya before the coming of the Spanish and whose language and culture developed separately from the Maya.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1927, p. 9-10; http://www.vjf.cnrs.fr/celia/FichExt/Am/A_19-20_09.htm (Feb. 2004)

Image_title: [Carlo Sancto]
Description: Saint Charles's root from New Spain.
Source_Title: [Historia medicinal. English] Ioyfull nevves out of the newe founde worlde, wherein is declared the rare and singular vertues of diuerse and sundrie hearbes, trees, oyles, plantes and stones
Source_publisher: Poules Churche-yearde, by Willyam Norton
notes: Text describes this plant as having bark, a decoction from which cures headache, the pox, and toothache and is from Mechoacán [Michoacán], Mexico. This may be Mechocán root (similar to rhubarb) which had purgative effects, but see 01798-7. Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: [Of a certayne kinde of Barley.]
Description: Wild barley.
Source_Title: [Historia medicinal. English] Ioyfull nevves out of the newe founde worlde, wherein is declared the rare and singular vertues of diuerse and sundrie hearbes, trees, oyles, plantes and stones
Source_publisher: Poules Churche-yearde, by Willyam Norton
notes: Text describes the plant as being a kind of wild barley [cebadilla] found in New Spain and somewhat poisonous, useful for treating worms, canker, and necrotic flesh. Known as green gentian or monument plant, cebadilla (Swertia radiata) was used as a laxative, febrifuge, contraceptive, and tonic. Image title from chapter title.
References: Pardo Tomas, J. Two glimpses of America, p. 178-179

Image_title: [The Armadilio.]
Description: Armadillo.
Source_Title: [Historia medicinal. English] Ioyfull nevves out of the newe founde worlde, wherein is declared the rare and singular vertues of diuerse and sundrie hearbes, trees, oyles, plantes and stones
Source_publisher: Poules Churche-yearde, by Willyam Norton
notes: Text describes the uses for powdered tail of the armadillo, chiefly for curing deafness, tinnitus, and earache.Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: [The Flower of Mechoacan.]
Description: The flower of Mechoacan.
Source_Title: [Historia medicinal. English] Ioyfull nevves out of the newe founde worlde, wherein is declared the rare and singular vertues of diuerse and sundrie hearbes, trees, oyles, plantes and stones
Source_publisher: Poules Churche-yearde, by Willyam Norton
notes: Text describes the discovery of Mechoacan [Michoacan] root in Nicaragua and Quito which is used as a purgative. The variety (called escamonea) found on the Cape of Santa Elena, present-day Ecuador, is so strong that it poisoned as often as cured a patient. This is probably a variety or perceived variety of Convolvulus or kind of bindweed used in Europe as a purgative and anthelmintic. Known as white rhubarb, scammony, or briony of America, the root was dried and powdered for use (see Pierre Pomet, Histoire generale des drogues, Paris, 1694).Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: [The fruite of Balsamo.]
Description: The fruit of the balsam of Peru.
Source_Title: [Historia medicinal. English] Ioyfull nevves out of the newe founde worlde, wherein is declared the rare and singular vertues of diuerse and sundrie hearbes, trees, oyles, plantes and stones
Source_publisher: Poules Churche-yearde, by Willyam Norton
notes: Text describes the production of balsam resin (Balsamum peruvianum) in New Spain and its use as a remedy for head ailments. The tree (Myroxylon toluifera) is incised and the resin is collected and extracted.Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: [Long Peper.]
Description: Long pepper or chili pepper.
Source_Title: [Historia medicinal. English] Ioyfull nevves out of the newe founde worlde, wherein is declared the rare and singular vertues of diuerse and sundrie hearbes, trees, oyles, plantes and stones
Source_publisher: Poules Churche-yearde, by Willyam Norton
notes: Text describes the biting taste of the long or chili pepper (Capsicum annum) from Cartagena, Colombia.Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: Hispaniae novae sivae magnae, recens et vera descriptio. 1579.
Description: Map of New Spain showing part of Mexico. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude, location of rivers and some settlements. Decorative elements include ships, birds, and angels. Images are lettered for identification in table at bottom right.
Source_Title: [Theatrum orbis terrarum. French] Theatre de l'univers, contenant les cartes de tout le monde
Source_publisher: de l'Imprimerie Plantienne, pour Abraham Ortel autheur mesme de ce liure
notes: Ortelius was the creator of the first true atlas (defined as a collection of uniform map sheets and sustaining text bound to form a book for which copper printing plates were specifically engraved). Frequently revised, this atlas was the last one to be printed during Ortelius's lifetime. The sources of this map are unclear.
References: Broecke, M.P.R. van den Ortelius Atlas Maps, No. 13; Cline, H.H. "Ortelius maps of New Spain," Imago Mundi XVI, p. 98-115; Koeman, C. Atlantes neerlandici, Ort. 36; Skelton, R.A. Bib. note, in Facsimile ed. of Ortelius, A. Theatrum orbis terrarum, p. ix
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page showing Atahualpa [or Atabalipa] adorned with jewelry and carrying a sceptre being carried on a litter by native Americans. Includes scenes of mining by native Americans. Also includes musical instruments such as drum, pipes, and trumpet, swords, scene of warfare, baskets, winches, hoes, shovels, bows, arrows, ships, and boat.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 6. Latin] Americae pars sexta, sive Historiae ab Hieronymo Be[n]sono Mediolane[s]se scriptae, section tertia
Source_publisher: Theodoro de Bry
notes: Illustrating the conquest of the Incas, this part of Benzoni's work describes the Spanish attempt to control Peru. The mining scene may be of silver mining at Potosí.This work was published by Theodor de Bry and is derived from the third part of Girolamo Benzoni, Historia del mondo nuovo, Venice, 1565. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 6. Latin. Imprint information from colophon.
References_exhibitions: Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Fig. 30

Image_title: [Soldier of Peru]
Description: Native American soldier from Peru. He holds a stone in one hand. Includes padded vest over a tunic, helmet, sword, and a slingshot with stone.
Source_Title: [De gli habiti antichi et moderni] Habiti antichi et moderni di tutto il mondo
Source_publisher: Appresso i Sessa
notes: The text describes the helmet and tunic as being made of quilted cotton. The tunic was made of cloth of many colors.Vecellio's popular book on costumes included not only the dress of his native Venice, but clothing from ancient times and from the Americas along with social commentary about the illustrated people and their attire. The woodcuts for this book were created by Christoph Krieger. Image title taken from text.

Image_title: [Women of Peru]
Description: Native American women from Peru. Clothed in a dress of striped woven cotton with a wide belt of striped cotton around her waist, one woman holds a drop spindle in one hand and makes yarn. Another woman wearing a cloak stands in the background.
Source_Title: [De gli habiti antichi et moderni] Habiti antichi et moderni di tutto il mondo
Source_publisher: Appresso i Sessa
notes: The text decribes the striped and multi-colored material used to clothe the women.Vecellio's popular book on costumes included not only the dress of his native Venice, but clothing from ancient times and from the Americas along with social commentary about the illustrated people and their attire. The woodcuts for this book were created by Christoph Krieger.Image title taken from text.

Image_title: [Mexican youth]
Description: Native American youth or young man from Mexico holds flowers in one hand and a mirror in the other. He wears a flowered tunic. Behind him another young man holds a bow and wears a feathered headdress.
Source_Title: [De gli habiti antichi et moderni] Habiti antichi et moderni di tutto il mondo
Source_publisher: Appresso i Sessa
notes: The text describes the clothing from Mexico as being very delicate and made out of flowers [perhaps the author is describing ayate or a cloth that is woven from fiber from an agave plant]. In the province named Chichenecha [of the Chichimecs], the inhabitants go about practically naked because of the great heat.Vecellio's popular book on costumes included not only the dress of his native Venice, but clothing from ancient times and from the Americas along with social commentary about the illustrated people and their attire. The woodcuts for this book were created by Christoph Krieger.Image title taken from text.

Image_title: [Nobleman of Mexico]

Source_Title: [De gli habiti antichi et moderni] Habiti antichi et moderni di tutto il mondo
Source_publisher: Appresso i Sessa
notes: The text describes the clothing of the noblemen of Mexico. They wore a striped mantle or cloak over tunics made from flowers [perhaps the author is describing ayate or a cloth that is woven from fiber from an agave plant]. Their hats were adorned with images of the sun and moon.Vecellio's popular book on costumes included not only the dress of his native Venice, but clothing from ancient times and from the Americas along with social commentary about the illustrated people and their attire. Image_title: [King of Florida]
Description: Native American king or leader of Florida. He wears a crown, richly decorated robe, tattoos, and carries a scepter or baton.
Source_Title: [De gli habiti antichi et moderni] Habiti antichi et moderni di tutto il mondo
Source_publisher: Appresso i Sessa
notes: The text describes the leader or chief of the Indians of the island of Florida. His robe was made of linen and silver. His baton was topped with beautiful quills or feathers. This image is derived from the account of the Timucua Indians of Florida and their leader, Holata Outina, in Theodor de Bry, America, part 2. Vecellio's popular book on costumes included not only the dress of his native Venice, but clothing from ancient times and from the Americas along with social commentary about the illustrated people and their attire. The woodcuts for this book were created by Christoph Krieger. Image title taken from text.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Man on a llama with two native Americans. Decorative elements include guns, parrot, sword, bows and arrows.
Source_Title: Vera historia, admirandae cuiusdam nauigationis [Part 4]
Source_publisher: Impensis Levini Hulsii
notes: Text concerns Schmidel's travels on the Rio de la Plata, Argentina. This acccount is one of a series of accounts of voyages selected, edited, and translated by Levinus Hulsius and others, and known as the Erste-[XXVI] Schiffart or the Sammlung von Sechs und Zwanzig Schiffahrten.

Image_title: [Title page]

Source_publisher: Impensis Levini Hulsii
notes: Text concerns Schmidel's travels on the Rio de la Plata, Argentina Constitutes the fourth part of Sammlung von sechs und zwanzig Schiffahrten in verschiedene fremde Länder durch Levinus Hulsius und einige Andere, aus dem Holländischen ins Deutsche übersetzt und mit allerhand Anmerrkungen versehen, compiled by Levinus Hulsius, and printed in 26 parts in Nuremberg, Frankfurt am Main, Oppenheim, and Hanau from 1598 to 1663

Image_title: Legendo Simulque Per Agrando.
Description: Portrait of Mateo Alemán. Decorative elements include the coat of arms of the Holy Roman Empire (with a double-headed Hapsburg eagle) and Alemán's motto," ab insidiis non est prudentia" (taken from Pliny), under a shield with a snake and spider hanging from a web.
Source_Title: Sucesos de D. frai García Gera arcobispo de Mejico, a cuyo cargo estuvo el govierno de la Neuva España
Source_publisher: En la enprenta de la Viuda de Pedro Balli. Por C. Adriano Cesar
notes: Alemán, author of the picaresque novel Guzmán de Alfarache, wrote this account of the short tenure of Fray García Guerra (1560-1612) as archbishop and viceroy of New Spain.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Item 19, Fig. 26

Image_title: Contrafactur Ulrichs Schmidels.
Description: Portrait of Ulrich Schmidel with a wild cat, cougar, or panther, a coiled snake, and a coat of arms.
Source_Title: [Neue Welt. Latin] Vera historia, admirandae cuiusdam nauigationis, quam Huldericus Schmidel, Straubingensis, ab anno 1534. usque ad annum 1554. in Americam vel nouum mundum, iuxta Brasiliam & Rio della Plata
Source_publisher: Impensis Levini Hulsii
notes: Schmidel, from Straubingen near Regensburg, set out with 80 other Germans on the expedition of Pedro de Mendoza to Rio de la Plata in 1535. He spent 18 years on Spanish explorations of what is now Argentina and Paraguay, and his account, first published in Frankfurt in 1567, is one of the few records of early exploration in Paraguay. During his career in Spanish service, he traveled with expeditions of Juan de Ayolas, Gonzalo de Mendoza, Cabeza de Vaca, and Martinez de Irala. Here the explorer is portrayed, across from an image of new world creatures. His narrative of the Surukusis seems to be the only record of that lost people of South America.
References_exhibitions: http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/John_Carter_Brown_Library/exhibitions/german/pages/engagingnew.html (July 2015)

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with four portrait medaillons--Hernán Cortés, Ferdinand Magellan, Christoval de Olid, Gonzalo de Sandoval--and ten vignettes showing on the left scenes from the Spanish conquest of Mexico, including scenes of warfare or execution and Mexican or Aztec kings being carried on litters, and views of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán. On the right are scenes of the Strait of Magellan, the murder of Magellan, and the triumphant homecoming to Seville, as well as a scene showing the partition of the world on a bridge over a river. Includes native Americans fighting and boating, canoes, ships, cannons, gallows, dwellings, and navigational instruments such as dividers, globes, and compass. In the center is the Spanish royal coat of arms (of Castile and Leon).
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellano en las Islas y tierra firme del mar oceano ... Decada terzera
Source_publisher: en la emplenta Real
notes: In 1494, Spain and Portugal signed a treaty, known as the Treaty of Tordesillas, agreeing to a demarcation line whereby the pope divided the lands of the new world between the two countries. Only when the Spanish discovered the riches of Mexico was the treaty seen to be so advantageous to Spain.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with four portrait medallions--Diego de Almagro, Francisco Pizarro, Pedro de Alvarado, Diego de Ordás. Includes scenes of the flight of Pizarro to the Isla Gongora off of the present-day Colombian coast, rafting of Pizarro from Tumbez to Isla Puna in the Gulf of Guayaquil in present-day Ecuador, sailing in the bay of San Mateo, scenes of warfare with native Americans fighting Hernando de Soto at San Miguel. Also includes scenes of the battle of Utlatlanguez [?] with Pedro de Alvardo and scene of Diego de Ordas at the volcano of Tlascala. Includes ships, boats, rafts, dwellings, horse, dogs, fortifications, churches, and cannons.In the center is the Spanish royal coat of arms (of Castile and Leon).
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellano en las Islas y tierra firme del mar oceano ... Decada quarta
Source_publisher: en la emplenta Real
notes: The portraits are of conquistadors associated with the conquest of Peru.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with four portrait medallions--Don Hernando V el Catolico Rey de Castilla y de Leon [King Ferdinand], La cat[olic]a d[on]a Ysabel Rey [Queen Isabella] ... , Don xponual Colon [Christopher Columbus] primeros Almirante de la Indias, and Don Bart[olo]me Colon [Barthomew Columbus] Hernando Alm[iran]te prim[e]ro Adelantado d[e] las indias. Also shows four scenes of the conquest of and Spanish settlement of La Navidad, the first European settlement in the Caribbean. Also shown are the discovery of Trinidad and the coast of Veragua, present-day Venezuela. Includes scenes of warfare (including the battle of Vega Real led by native American chief, Guarinoex), map of the western hemisphere, fortified city, building of the tower of La Navidad and its destruction, ships, boats, dwellings, bows and arrows, dogs, horses, and king (the local chief, Guacanagari) carried on a litter. In the center is the Spanish royal coat of arms (of Castile and Leon).
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellano en las Islas y tierra firme del mar oceano ... [Volume 1]
Source_publisher: en la emplenta Real
notes: Christopher Columbus landed at La Navidad, Hispaniola, on Christmas eve in 1492, wrecking his flagship, the Santa Maria. Using the wreckage to build a fort and leaving 40 of his men behind, he sailed for Spain. He returned a year later to find the fort destroyed. On his third voyage, Columbus left his brother, Bartholomew, known as the Adelantado, in charge at the new settlement of Isabella. Columbus landed at Trinidad and traveled to the mouth of the Orinoco River but was discouraged from exploring because of the dangerous water. He, nonetheless, became the first European to set foot in South America.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings1: First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners

Image_title: [Map of southern South Ameica and Tierra del Fuego]
Description: Map of southern South America, especially Patagonia and Tierra del Fuego, inluding the Strait of Magellan. Cartographic elements include degrees of longitude and latitude and names of rivers and settlements. Includes a Patagonian "giant" holding a bow and swallowing something next to a European, a native American holding a bow handing an arrow to another native American carrying a war club, and a native American with bow and arrow chasing another. Also includes fish or sea monsters and ships.
Source_Title: Sechster Theil, kurtze, warhafftige Relation vnnd Beschreibung der wunderbarsten vier Schiffahrten, so jemals verricht worden. ...
Source_publisher: Bey Hartmanno Palthenio, in Verlegung der Hulsischen
notes: Thomas Cavendish left London in June of 1586 intending to circumnavigate the globe.Hulsius was a maker of fine instruments, an art about which he wrote, and also a publisher and printer.Number 6 in "Sammlung von sechs und zwanzig Schiffahrten" a collection (with a title invented by bibliographers) of 26 numbered pamphlets, compiled by Levinus Hulsius.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title is flanked by a native American man and woman. At bottom is a llama and at top a figure wearing a pointed hat with his feet on a skin rug. Includes feathered headdress and garment, cloak, and penguins.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 9. Latin] Americae nona & postrema pars ...
Source_publisher: Apud Matth. Beckerum
notes: The native American figures are taken from an illustration in this book and represent the people of Patagonia. A similar figure with a pointed hat also appears later in this same book to illustrate a Dutch visit to the Congo. This work contains three different voyages; Pt. 1 is José de Acosta, Historie naturael ende morael van de Westersche Indien, Haarlem, 1598; Pt. 2 is Barent Janszoon Potgieter, Wijdtloopigh verhael van tgene de vijf schepen, Amsterdam, 1600, here entitled Relatio historica; the appendix and Pt. 3 is Olivier van Noort, Beschryvinghe van de voyagie, Rotterdam & Amsterdam, 1602, here entitled Additamentum nonae partis Americae. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9. Latin.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Allegorical figure of America as a native American woman with feathered headdress seated on an armadillo and holding a bow and arrow. In the background are llamas [?] and scene of men hunting a deer or stag.
Source_Title: Warhafftige Beschreibung der unglückhafften Schiffarht eines Schiffs von Ambsterdam, die Silberne Welt genannt ... nach Rio de Plata
Source_publisher: bey Wolff Richtern
notes: One of Theodore de Bry's quarto series of America, this volume recounts the 1598 to 1601 voyage of the Dutch navigator, Hendrick Ottsen, to Rio de la Plata and Buenos Aires. This iconic image of America as a native American woman seated on an armadillo is credited to Marten de Vos, a Flemish Mannerist artist.
References: Glaser, L. America on Paper, preceding p. 1

Image_title: Cerro de Potosi
Image_publisher: Cornelis Claesz, op't water, in't schrijf-boeck
Description: View of the mountain of Potosí with a view of the town at the base of the mountain. Includes church and miners walking up the mountain with their pickaxes. Includes dwellings and a river. In the distance is the Villa de Plata.
Source_Title: Hand-boeck; of cort begrijp der caerten ende beschoyvinghen van alle landen des werelds. Van nieuvvs oversien ende vermeerdert.
Source_publisher: By Cornelis Claesz, op't water, in't schrijf-boeck
notes: The mines at Potosí were discovered by Diego Hualca in 1544. The silver mines there were among the richest in the world.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Spanish missionary instructing native Americans. Decorative elements include scenes of the passion, plus images of St. Francis and another saint, probably St. Thomas.
Source_Title: [Monarquía indiana] IIa parte de los veynte y vn libros rituales y monarchia yndiana: con el origen y guerras de los Yndias occidentales de sus poblaçones descubrimiento conquista conuersion y otras cosas marauillosas de la mesma tierra
Source_publisher: Por Matthias Clauijo
notes: A priest instructs native Mexican men and women in Christian doctrine using five images--the mocking of Christ; Christ carrying the cross; the crucifixion; the harrowing of hell; and the resurrection.
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, Fig. 28.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Spanish missionary instructing native Americans. Decorative elements include scenes of the passion, plus images of Saint Francis and another saint, probably Saint Thomas.
Source_Title: [Monarquía indiana] IIa parte de los veynte y vn libros rituales y monarchia yndiana: con el origen y guerras de los Yndias occidentales de sus poblaçones descubrimiento conquista conuersion y otras cosas marauillosas de la mesma tierra
Source_publisher: Por Matthias Clauijo
notes: A priest instructs native Mexican men and women in Christian doctrine using five images--the mocking of Christ; Christ carrying the cross; the crucifixion; the harrowing of hell; and the resurrection.
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, Fig. 28.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Imprinted by T.D. for Nathanaell Newbery ...
Description: Map of the Strait of Magellan showing the voyage of William Corneliszoon Schouten. Includes Tierra del Fuego, Staten Island, Patagonia, and ships.
Source_Title: [Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse. English] The Relation of a wonderfull voiage made by William Cornelison Schouten of Horne ...
Source_publisher: Imprinted by T.D. for Nathanaell Nevvbery, and are to be sold at the signe of the Starre, vnder S. Peters in Corne-hill, and in Pope-head Alley
notes: Schouten circumnavigated the world in 1615. His discovery of the way round Cape Horn was important because the Dutch East India Company [VOC] had the monopoly on using the Strait of Magellan. He named the cape after the town of Hoorn from which he came, and the way was kept secret by the Dutch until the middle of 1618, making this map one of the earliest to show his journey.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Payta
Description: View of Paita, Peru, iwth ships in the harbor,a balsa raft in the foreground with an enormous bird on it. Also includes scene of warfare with battalions carrying the Dutch flag, houses on fire and three crosses on a hill. Also includes boats
Source_Title: Oost ende West-Indische spiegel : der 2. leste navigatien, ghedaen inden jaeren 1614.15.16.17. ende 18. daer in vertoont woort, in wat gestalt Ioris van Speilbergen door de Magellanes de werelt rontom geseylt heeft, met eenighe battalien so te water also te lant, ende 2. historien de een van Oost ende de ander van West-Indien, her ghetal der forten, soldaten, schepen, ende gheschut ...
Source_publisher: By Nicolaes van Geelkerchen
notes: The Dutch fleet under Spilbergen attacked Paita on Aug. 8, 1615, and captured the town. The items in the image are lettered and identified in the adjoining text. The extraordinary bird on the raft, caught on the "Island of Loubes" [Lobos de Tierra], was likely an Andean condor which has a neck like a sheep (as described in the text) and a comb on its head like a rooster. In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Six heavily-armed ships and about 700 men left the Netherlands on a voyage to circumnavigate the world; one ship deserted before the Strait was passed. The fleet then sailed west to the Moluccas which it reached in March 1616.
References: Spilbergen, J. van East and West India Mirror, Hakluyt Society, 2nd ser., no. 18
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page showing two monks standing within an aedicule or classical architectural element, one with a star on his forehead holding a church, crucifix and lily accomanied by a dog holding a flaming torch [Saint Dominic], the other holding a flower and a book. The element is surmounted by two globes of the world and the Spanish royal coat of arms.
Source_Title: Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales, y particular de la gouernacion de Chiapa, y Guatemala. Escriuese juntamente los principios de la religion de nuestro glorioso padre Santo Domingo, y de las demas religiones
Source_publisher: Por Francisco de Abarca
notes: Remesal was a Dominican who while living in Guatemala wrote a history of Chiapas, Guatemala, Oaxaca, Peru. and the Philippines. Ramesal's book was banned by the Inquisition because he wrote of the conquistadors, especially Pedro de Alvarado, as well as Bartolome de las Casas.

Image_title: [Natives of Chile]
Description: Native Americans stand in a group on shore while others open mollusk shells, canoe, and shoot arrows at European men whose ships ride in the background. Includes birds, short fur cloaks, bows, spears, knives, and dwellings. Includes scene of warfare with bodies being mutilated on the beach.
Source_Title: [Journael vande nassausche vloot. German] Diurnal der nassawischen Flotta, oder Tagregister, vnd historische, ordentliche Beschreibung einer gewaltigen mächtigen Schiffahrt, vmb die gantze Erdkugel rund vmbhr ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung Eberhard Zetzners
notes: The native American or aboriginal people shown here may be Alakaluf or Yamana or Yaghanes. This expedition was probably the first European contact for those peoples. Prince Maurice of Nassau ordered the voyage, commanded by Admiral Jacob L'Hermite (or Jacques L'Hermite), as an expedition against Spain. The fleet circumnavigated the globe. See also the image at 08299-2.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Bey Hartmanno Palthenio, in Verlegung der Hulsischen H. Palthenius, for the Hulsiuses
Description: A ship named the Victoria with many men on board fires its cannons. At the bow of the ship is an angel holding a palm branch and a laurel wreath. Roundels on either side of the image contain portraits of navigators Ferdinand Magellan, Juan Sebastián de Elcano, Sir Francis Drake, and Olivier van Noort. Also includes a shield showing Magellan's Strait and another shield showing a globe and the Latin motto Primus me circumdedisti.
Source_Title: Sechster Theil, kurtze, warhafftige Relation vnnd Beschreibung der wunderbarsten vier Schiffahrten, so jemals verricht worden. ...
Source_publisher: Bey Hartmanno Palthenio, in Verlegung der Hulsischen
notes: Magellan's circumnavigation began with five ships, but only the Victoria under the command of Elcano completed it after Magellan's death. Drake was the first to circumnavigate the globe after Magellan. Van Noort completed his circumnavigation in 1601.Hulsius was a maker of fine instruments, an art about which he wrote, and also a publisher and printer.Number 6 in "Sammlung von sechs und zwanzig Schiffahrten" a collection (with a title supplied by bibliographers) of 26 numbered pamphlets, compiled by Levinus Hulsius.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: An allegorical image of America as a kneeling young woman with a bow and an axe looking at an eagle. Decorative elements include three coats of arms (at top, the royal coat of arms of Leon and Castile), the chain of the Order of the Golden Fleece, the old and new hemispheres.
Source_Title: Memorial discursivo sobre el oficio de protector general de los Indios del Piru
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta Real

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: En casa de Domingo de la Yglesia
Description: Kneeling man in armor offers a crown and the Indies to the pope. Decorative elements include two medallions of St. Francis and [another saint], two coats of arms (one of the Franciscan order, the other showing the five wounds of Christ), the dome of St. Peter's Basilica. The pope holds the triple-tiered crown of the papacy. The soldier says, "Quantum offero pro Indies."
Source_Title: [Noticias historiales. 1. Parte] Primera parte de las noticias historiales de las conquistas de tierra firme en las Indias occidentales
Source_publisher: En casa de Domingo de la Yglesia

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page showing Faith and Religion as pillars upholding the Spanish monarchy within an aedicule or classical architectural element. The Spanish king sits holding a sword and scepter with his foot on the globe between America and Spain. Two figures representing allegorical representations of Spain (a soldier in armor holding a sheaf of wheat) and America (with feathered headdress and holding a sheaf of corn or maize) flank him. Two vignettes at the bottom of the pillars show a man battling a many-headed snake with the motto: "Domat omnia virtus," and a beehive with the motto: "Omnia nos itidem." Also includes the royal Spanish coat of arms and a parrot. The globe is held by Neptune or Poseidon with his trident resting on a shell in the ocean. The figure of Faith holds a cross, chalice and host; the figure of Religion holds a pelican feeding its chicks from its breast.
Source_Title: [De Indiarum jure] Ioannes de Solorzano Pereira I.V.D. ... Disputationem de Indiarum iure, sive De iusta Indiarum Occidentalium inquisitione, acquisitione, et retentione tribus libris comprehensam, D.E.C.
Source_publisher: Ex typographia Francisci Martinez
notes: In 1609 Solorzano was appointed judge of the audience of Lima and became the leading Spanish colonial jurist in the seventeenth century, instituting a number of reforms and improvements to the administration and tribunals.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with title flanked by allegorical female figures representing the west (shown as a native American wearing a feathered headdress holding a bow and arrow and standing on an alligator) and the east (shown wearing a turban, holding a scimitar or sword and cornucopia, and standing next to an elephant). Above their heads are books representing Spanish possessions and (over the figure for the east) the astrological symbol for Virgo with an image of a woman holding a sheaf of grain and (over the figure for the west) the symbol for Cancer with a lobster or crab. Decorative elements also include royal coat of arms of Spain [Leon] surrounded by the chain of the Order of the Golden Fleece and [Medina?] coat of arms, navigational instruments such as an astrolabe, armillary sphere, and globe, personifications of geography and navigation accompanied by the names of important geographers and navigators.
Source_Title: Epitome de la biblioteca oriental i occidental, nautica i geografica ...
Source_publisher: Por Iuan Gonzalez
notes: Leon Pinelo, a Peruvian historian, is known for his compilation of the ordinances and decrees issued relating to South America and a bibliography of printed or manuscript works relating to South America.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with title flanked by two female figures representing Peru and New Spain. Includes coats of arms of Peru (with snakes, sun, and moon), New Spain (with eagle wearing a crown on a cactus growing on an island in a lake), and the royal arms of Spain as established by Philip II. Also includes feathered headdress, ship, angels, pillars of Hercules with "plus ultra," a sheep or llama, and helmets. The native American figure identified as Peru holds a mountain [Potosí] with a cross on top in one hand and a spear or pike in the other. The native American woman identified as New Spain holds a spear and flowers from which a bird [hummingbird] sips nectar.
Source_Title: Tratado de confirmaciones reales de encomiendas, oficios i casos, en que se requieren para las Indias Occidentales
Source_publisher: Por Iuan Gonzalez
notes: Leon Pinelo, a Peruvian historian, is known for his compilation of the ordinances and decrees issued relating to South America and also for his bibliography of printed or manuscript works relating to South America. The coat of arms above the heads of Peru and New Spain is probably that of Lorenço Ramirez de Prado.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Por la viuda de Iuan Gon�alez
Description: Native American in feathered headdress stands holding a branch of the cocoa tree. Decorative elements include royal Spanish coat of arms [?] and portrait of the author [?] with a helmet and lion.
Source_Title: Question moral si el chocolate quebranta el ayuno eclesiastico
Source_publisher: Por la viuda de Iuan Gon�alez
notes: Leon Pinelo, a Peruvian historian, is known for his compilation of the ordinances and decrees issued relating to South America and also for his bibliography of printed or manuscript works relating to South America.
References_exhibitions: Landis, D.C. Literature of the Encounter, No. 13, Fig. II.3

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page within an aedicule or classical architectural element which includes a mission church. Also includes representations of Saints Peter and Paul. At bottom are portraits of Fra Martin and Fra Jacob Dacian with a representation of the Virgin Mary on a crescent moon.
Source_Title: Chronica de la Orden de N. seraphico P.S. Francisco, prouincia de S. Pedro. y S. Pablo de Mechoacan en la Nueua España ...
Source_publisher: Por la Viuda de Bernardo Calderon
notes: The Franciscan province of San Pedro y San Pablo de Michoacán was established in 1565. Brother Jacob Dacian, Jacob the Dane, or, in Latin, Jacobus de Dacia was a Danish Franciscan monk who was sent to Mexico where he learned several indigenous languages and founded several convents. He spent three years at the Colegio de Santa Cruz de Tlatelolco studying Nahuatl before being sent to Michoacán to work among the P'urhépecha Indians, where the bulk of his missionary work was done. Fra Martin on the title page may refer to Martin de la Coruña, one of the "twelve Franciscan apostles of Mexico."
SubjectHeadings4: Franciscans. Provincia de San Pedro y San Pablo de Michoacán

Image_title: Tabula Geographica Regni Chile
Description: Map of the coastline of Chile. Cartographic elements include sea banks or shoals, compass rose, location of rivers and settlements. Also includes the dividing line established between the Mapuche and Spanish at the Bio Bio River. Decorative elements include lion, llamas, parrot, penguin [?], rheas, armadillo, sea monsters, mermaid, ships, Patagonian giants, stag or deer, coat of arms of Innocent X and the royal Spanish coat of arms, men with tails, altar with cross, native Americans with bows and arrows, hunting birds, plowing. Inset of vignette showing the treaty between the Spanish and the native Chileans in 1641 between the marchio de Vaydes and the chief Antesignanus. Another inset shows vignette of warfare between the Spanish and native Americans with cannons, clubs, shields, and spears. Also includes two insets with plans of San Jacob and of Valdivia.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: This map is greatly enlarged from the version commonly found in this edition; this copy may be unique. See Lawrence C. Wroth's article in Imago Mundi.This map contains extensive Latin commentary by Ovalle to explain native American ethnography and the history of the conquest. After about a century of struggle with the Spaniards, the Treaty of Quilin was signed in 1641, recognizing the independence of the Mapuche Indians but forcing them to an area south of the Bio Bio River.
References: Wroth, L.C. "Alonso de Ovalle's large map of Chile, 1646" Imago Mundi XIV (1959), 90-95
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writings about the New World, Fig. 20
SubjectArea3: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe standing on a crescent moon with a cactus, two kneeling angels, and crown. Behind her is the double-headed Hapsburg eagle and crossed keys.
Source_Title: Imagen de la Virgen Maria madre de Dios de Guadalupe, milagrosamente aparecida en la ciudad de Mexico ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de la Viuda de Bernardo Calderon. Vendese en su tienda en la calle de San Augustin.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. The cactus is the symbol of the Aztecs and marked the place where they built Tenochtitlan.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Engraved title page showing a classical aedicula populated by allegorical figures and portraits. Two figures (one representing future virtue, the other permanent strength) support a portrait of the conde de Castrillo, García de Haro y Avellaneda beneath which is his coat of arms. Below them are a female figure in armor holding a spear and a cornucopia representing Spain and a female native American holding ears of corn and a bow and wearing a quiver and a feathered headdress. Below them is another cartouche holding a portrait of the author with a coat of arms below it. Includes Latin mottoes, sword, and mirror with snakes.
Source_Title: Doctoris Francisci Carasco del Saz regij Panamensis senatoris ... opera ...
Source_publisher: Per Iulianum de Paredes
notes: Francisco Carrasco del Saz was a lawyer in Lima and rector of the University of San Marcos in 1613. He later went to Panama as a judge of the audiencia. García de Haro y Avellaneda lived from 1588 to 1670 and held important political offices in Spain. This engraved title page serves for a collection of works issued together.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: An image of Our Lady of Guadalupe.
Source_creator: Lasso de la Vega, Luis, 17th cent.
Source_Title: Huei Tlamahuiçoltica omonexiti in ilhvicac tlatóca çihvapilli Santa Maria Totlaçonantzin Guadalupe ...
Source_publisher: en la Imprenta de Iuan Ruyz
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the truth of the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it filled with out-of-season roses. This book, written in Nahuatl by the vicar of the chapel of Guadalupe, is the second known retelling of the Guadalupe story. The first was written in 1648 by Lasso de la Vega's friend, the priest, Miguel Sanchez. According to Medina, this account was probably written by a native Mexican, Antonio Valeriano, and edited, with a preface by Lasso de la Vega.

Image_title: [Title page] Rerum medicarum Novae Hispaniae thesaurus
Description: Six native Americans flank title surmounted by the royal Spanish coat of arms of Philip II, III, and IV surrounded by the chain of the Order of the Golden Fleece. At base of the title is a map of Mexico. Decorative elements include cornucopia, sphere, feathered headdresses and garments, wildcat, coral, sack of coins, ceremonial staffs, and various plants and fruits.
Source_Title: Novum plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi

Image_title: [De Copalli Quahuitl, seu Arbore Gummifera Copalifera I.]

Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi

Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: It has not been possible to identify this plant. Tlacote is a place in present-day Mexico.Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him. Hernández linked each plant with one or more of the humors of the body.Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Fran. Boude. Imprimeur a l'enseigne de S. Thomas. F. Boude
Description: Title surrounded by images of Augustinian friars preaching to and baptizing native Americans. Each scene is surrounded by a Biblical verse. At the top is a flaming heart, the symbol of the Augustinian order. It is surmounted by a bishop's mitre, crozier, and a galero with six fiocchi. At the bottom are the arms of the Augustinian Prior General Philip Visconti.
Source_Title: [Crónica moralizada. French. Selections] Histoire du Peru, partie principale des Antipodes, ou Nouueau Monde. ...
Source_publisher: F. Boude
notes: Philip Visconti was Augustinian Prior General from 1649 to 1655. Generals of orders are allowed six fiocchi or tassels.

Image_title: El illmo. Yrmo. S. D. Iuan de Palafox y Mendoca. Obispo de Osma.
Description: Portrait of Juan de Palafox y Mendoza writing in a book with a quill on a desk. Includes a crucifix, inkwell, bell, and chair.
Source_Title: Luz a los vivos, y escarmiento en los muertos ....
Source_publisher: Por Maria de Quiñones
notes: Appointed "visitator general" of Mexico in 1639, Palafox y Mendoza served as the bishop of Puebla of Los Angeles until 1649. His appointment to the uncelebrated bishopric of Osma in Spain in 1655 was the equivalent of enforced retirement and public humiliation. The process of his canonization was begun in 1726, but a final decision was suspended in 1777.

Image_title: V. Efigies Vener. P. Fr. Petri Vrraca, Ord. B.V.M. de Mercede. Redempt. Captiv. Virtutibus, ...
Description: Portrait of Pedro Urraca, member of the Mercedarian Order. He wears the shield of his order, holds a heart in his left hand and points to three stars with his right hand. Includes an angel.
Source_Title: El Iob de la ley de gracia, retrato en la admirable vida del siervo de Dios, venerable padre fray Pedro Vrraca, ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta Real
notes: Urraca was born in Spain and was brought to South America by his brother. He was ordained as a priest in Lima in 1610, and he died in Lima in 1657. The stars in the portrait refer to a miraculous appearance of three stars in this configuration when Urrace was nine years old.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Native Americans [?] sacrifice children on an altar. Includes priests with knives who place the infants on a pyre. Also includes snakes, skulls, and dog [?]. In the background is a funeral scene with bodies being buried in graves.
Source_Title: [Neu-augirte Welt-Beschreibung. Dutch] De nieuwe bereysde wereldt
Source_publisher: by Iohannes Tongerloo
notes: This book describes the religious practices of the Indians of Mexico, as well as the natives of the East Indies.

Image_title: [Port Desire]
Description: View of Port Desire in present-day Argentina. Men use spears and axes to kill sea lions, dig up graves and discover skeletons, and carry water back to two ships, one of which is on fire. Includes compass rose, llamas (?), rheas, and penguins. Items in the image are lettered for identification.
Source_Title: [Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse. Latin] Diarium vel descriptio laboriosissimi, & molestissimi itineris, factià [sic] Guilielmo Cornelii Schoutenio Hornano. Annis 1615. 1616. & 1617. ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Ludovici Vlas-blom
notes: At Port Desire or Puerto Deseado the two ships Eendracht and Hoorn stopped for fresh water and to be careened. In the process, the Hoorn caught fire, and the expedition had to continue in the Eendracht. Members of the expedition claimed that the native American skeletons they dug up were ten to twelve feet tall with heads large enough to fit over their own.Jacob Le Maire and Willem Corneliszoon Schouten set out in 1615 from the Dutch city of Hoorn to discover a way around South America without using the Magellan Strait that was monopolized by the Dutch East India Company or VOC. They succeeded in finding another strait that they named for Isaac Le Maire, Jacob's father, and proved that Tierra del Fuego was an island.Generally referred to as Schouten's journal, the author being unknown.Cf. 03458-1, Le Maire, Speighel der Australische ... Amsterdam, 1622 and 02470-2, Schouten, [Jounael ofte beschryving...], Amsterdam, 1618.
SubjectArea3: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: The Virgin Mary holds the Christ Child surrounded by some of the miracles ascribed to her, a dog leans a horse away from a unseated man, the Virgin saves a man upon whom a pillar has fallen, she guides a ship away from rocky shores, and a man takes out a statue of the Virgin and Child from a chest. Also includes the eagle perched on a cactus (symbol of the Aztec or Mexica people).
Source_Title: Amoroso canto, que con reverentes afectos, continuando su devocion ...
Source_publisher: Por la Viuda de Bernardo Calderon
notes: The eagle perched on a cactus was a sign to the wandering Mexica or Aztec tribe of the site where they were to build their city of Tenochtitlan, now Mexico City.

Image_title: Ill.ac R. D. D. F. Christophorus de Torres, ordinis praedicatorum, Philippi III ... Rosarii beatissimae Virginis Mariae ardentissimus Promotor ...
Description: Portrait of Cristóbal de Torres, archbishop of Nueva Granada. Includes angels holding a bishop's miter, cross, royal coats of arms of Spain and Castile. Also includes the Virgin Mary and child with a rosary, eagle, a glove, pectoral cross, and book.
Source_creator: Colegio Mayor de Nuestra Señora del Rosario (Bogotá, Colombia)
Source_Title: Constituciones del Colegio Mayor de Nuestra Señora del Rosario, en la Ciudad de Santa Fè de Bogotâ, hechas, y ajustadas por su insigne fundador, y patrono. El ilustrissimo señor maestro D. Fr. Christoval de Torres...
Source_publisher: Por Iuan Noguès
notes: Torres, a Dominican priest and archbishop of Bogota, Colombia, was one of the first priests to admit native Americans to communion in 1636 and was the founder of Colegio Mayor de Nuestra Señora del Rosario.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title is enclosed within an aedicule or classical architectural element. Includes allegorical figures (of peace and justice), figures representing Philip IV (1621-1665) and his successor, Charles II, the double-headed Hapsburg eagle, the royal coat of arms of Spain, two globes showing the celestial and terrestrial worlds, angels, phoenix, palm tree, and crowns.
Source_Title: Solemnidad funebre y exequias a la muerte del catolico augustissimo Rey D. Felipe Quarto el grande N.S. ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de Iuan de Quevedo
notes: This title page for the funeral ceremonies of King Philip IV of Spain was published in Peru. Compiled, edited, and partially authored by Diego León Pinelo.

Image_title: [top] Sinischer Drachen = und Tiger Feltz [bottom] Das Sibler Bergwerct Potosi in Peru
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: [top] A fight between a dragon and a tiger on a mountain in China. [bottom] Silver mine in Potosi. Workers climb up ladders from the interior of a mine carrying ore on their backs.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben

Image_title: [top] Back=Palm Clusii Lavendel=Ast Hoitzxochitl Avaramo-Tem� [upper middle] Aroeira in Brasilien Aroeira oder Molle in Peru Ahate de Panucho [lower middle] Billing-bing West=Ind. Lace Baum Lace-zweig [bottom] Guytys [Guiti-iba]
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Various trees with their fruits and flowers including a lavender or cactus, a lance-leafed tree, trees of the Anacardiaceae family showing the Brazilian and Peruvian form, and Brazilian trees known as guititoroba, guiticoroya or guiti-iba.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: The Avaramo-Temó is described as being from Brazil. The billingbing is a tree from southeast Asia.

Image_title: [top] Die Baume Acacia - Egyptischer Mesopotamischer Mexicanischer [middle] Saam�una Umb� Drachen=Baum [bottom] Lance und Rampostan Xochicopalli Ietaib�
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Various trees with their fruits and flowers including acacia trees from Egypt, Mesopotamia, and Mexico, saamouna (a tree of the West Indies), the Brazil plum or umbu, a dracaena, a copal-bearing tree and an ietaiba.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: The Brazil plum or umbu (Spondias tuberosa). Copal is a name given to tree resin from the copal tree Protium copal (Burseraceae) that is particularly identified with the aromatic resins used by the cultures of pre-Columbian Mesoamerica as ceremonially burned incense and other purposes. ;

Image_title: [top] Hoaxacan Zweig von Guayaco Iaparandiba [top middle] Iacaranda Cuiet� Atitara [bottom middle] Mucun� Caaroba [bottom] Der Baum Trema� Ost=Indische Enche Ost=Ind: Nachen Baum Atexcal Quahoitl.
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Various trees with their fruits and flowers including lignum, guaiacum, jacaranda trees, and fruit of the mucuna.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: Hoaxacan Lignum vitae or Guajacum sanctum, native to the area around the Caribbean including Florida and the Yucatan. The Iaparandiba is a Brazilian fruit tree. The jacaranda is a variety of tree with fragrant flowers. Atitara is a genus of flowering plants in the Arecaceae family. Mucuna is a genus of around 100 accepted species of climbing vines and shrubs of the family Fabaceae, The tree grows pods and the name mucuna comes from a Tupi-Guarani word for this species. ;

Image_title: [top] Brasiliansche Pflante Ibati [bottom] Sinesische Kunst=Felser
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: [top] The Brazilian plant, ibati. [bottom] Chinese rock formations.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: These two images are derived from the image in Theodor de Bry, America, pt. 6, plate 23 (# 35379-24) and plate 24 (# 35379-25). ;The Urabá natives of the Atrato River in present-day Colombia built their houses in trees because the land was so swampy. According to the text, Balboa was the first to see them, and Oviedo wrote that one house was so big it was supported by 110 palm trees. The Spanish heard that they had gold and silver and tried to get them down. The Indians threw down stones, spears, and boiling water to prevent the Spaniards from cutting down the trees. The Spanish built wooden boards to protect them while they attempted to cut them down. This work was published by Theodor de Bry and is derived from the third part of Girolamo Benzoni, Historia del mondo nuovo, Venice, 1565.

Image_title: [Plants, buildings, and production of sugar. Also includes varieties of palm trees at bottom.]
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Sugar canes are shown at the top while illustrations of a sugar grinding mill, a sugar mill and blacks or slaves producing sugar are shown in the middle. Palm trees, a cocoanut, some carnauba trees [Copernicia prunifera], are also shown.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben
notes: The images of sugar production are derived from other images. Palm wax or Brazil wax comes from the leaves of the Copernicia prunifera palm grown only in Brazil.

Image_title: [Pineapples, bananas, and various cacti.]
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Fruits such as pineapples and bananas. Includes strangler figs. Also includes varieties of cacti such as the mandacaru.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben
notes: The mandacaru (Cereus jamacura) is native to Brazil and are also used for animal feed.

Image_title: [top] [Corals] [upper middle] [Sponges] [lower middle] Amacpatli Copaiba Cabureiba [bottom] Meeru Albara Paco-Çeroca Paco Caatinga
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: [top] Corals. [upper middle] Sponges [lower middle] Amacpatli (a coral), copaiba, cabureiba [bottom] Meeru Albara Paco-Çeroca Paco Caatinga.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben
notes: Copaiba (Copaifera officinalis) resin was first recorded in European medicine in 1625. Becuase it was brought back from South America by the Jesuits, it is often known as Jesuit’s balsam. Text describes the tree as being found in Brazil, Peru, and the Guianas. Cabureiba (Myrocarpus fastigiatus), a native of southern Brazil and northern Argentina yields a balsam resembling balsam of Peru. Text avers that both copaiba and cebureira will cure gonorrhea. Meera is a canna lily. Paco çeroca and paco cataagina are types of American lily native to Brazil.

Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Various fruit trees with their fruits and nuts. The bottom row of cinnamon trees includes a marmoset [?], along with details of the shoots and roots of the tree.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben
notes: Various guava trees and their fruits. Jacapucaio is a nut tree native to Brazil, perhaps a Brazil nut tree. Tatai-iba (Maclura tinctoria) or old fustic or dyer's mulberry. The bottom row includes cinnamon trees including the West Indian wild cassia or wild Senna (Cassia hebecarpa).

Image_title: [top] 1. Ost Indisches Tiger. [middle] 2. Mexicanishes Tiger. Brasiliasche Tiger 3. Iaguara 4. Iaguareté [bottom] 5. König von Java 6. Die Königin
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: [top] East Indian tiger. [middle] Mexican tiger or jaguar. Brazilian tiger or iaguara and iaguareté. [bottom] King and queen of Java.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben
notes: Yaguara and yaguareté are Guarani-Tupi words for jaquar.

Image_title: 1. Meer Mensch filier So bey Bragefanger Die Riepe Die abgefleischte hand 2. Schwimmende Firer
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: View of a sea creature swimming to shore. An insert provides an illustration of a merman with a drawing of the bones in the hand or flipper, a drawing of a rib, and the creature itself.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben
notes: Text describes a sea creature which washed ashore in Brazil and gives it the name "ipupiara" or "yupiapra" (etymology from Guarani-Tupi meaning "water dweller"). In 1654 Dutch anatomist Thomas Bartholin (mentioned here in this text) published an illustration of a skeletal forelimb and a rib from an animal that had been caught off the coast of Brazil. According to Senter and Snow, the morphology of the specimen matches that of a manatee (Trichechus sp.). See also other illustrations of a mysterious sea creature (# 01793-1 and # 73-36-2) from Brazil. This creature is described by Magalhães de Gandavo, Jean de Léry, Joannes de Laet, and Bartholin, among others.
References: https://archive.org/details/erasmifranciscio00fran (Sept. 2015); Senter P. and V.B. Snow, "Solution to a 300-year-old zoological mystery," Archives of natural history. Volume 40, Issue 2, Page 257-262

Image_title: [top] Brasiliansche Pflante Ibati [bottom] Sinesische Kunst=Felser
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: [top] The Brazilian plant, ibati. [bottom] Chinese rock formations.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: These two images are derived from the image in Theodor de Bry, America, pt. 6, plate 23 (# 35379-24) and plate 24 (# 35379-25). The Urabá natives of the Atrato River in present-day Colombia built their houses in trees because the land was so swampy. According to the text, Balboa was the first to see them, and Oviedo wrote that one house was so big it was supported by 110 palm trees. The Spanish heard that they had gold and silver and tried to get them down. The Indians threw down stones, spears, and boiling water to prevent the Spaniards from cutting down the trees. The Spanish built wooden boards to protect them while they attempted to cut them down. This work was published by Theodor de Bry and is derived from the third part of Girolamo Benzoni, Historia del mondo nuovo, Venice, 1565.

Image_title: [top] Hoaxacan Zweig von Guayaco Iaparandiba [top middle] Iacaranda Cuieté Atitara [bottom middle] Mucuná Caaroba [bottom] Der Baum Tremaé Ost=Indische Enche Ost=Ind: Nachen Baum Atexcal Quahoitl.
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Various trees with their fruits and flowers including lignum, guaiacum, jacaranda trees, and fruit of the mucuna.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: Hoaxacan Lignum vitae or Guajacum sanctum, native to the area around the Caribbean including Florida and the Yucatan. The Iaparandiba is a Brazilian fruit tree. The jacaranda is a variety of tree with fragrant flowers. Atitara is a genus of flowering plants in the Arecaceae family. Mucuna is a genus of around 100 accepted species of climbing vines and shrubs of the family Fabaceae, The tree grows pods and the name mucuna comes from a Tupi-Guarani word for this species.

Image_title: [top] Die Baume Acacia - Egyptischer Mesopotamischer Mexicanischer [middle] Saamóuna Umbú Drachen=Baum [bottom] Lance und Rampostan Xochicopalli Ietaibá
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Various trees with their fruits and flowers including acacia trees from Egypt, Mesopotamia, and Mexico, saamouna (a tree of the West Indies), the Brazil plum or umbu, a dracaena, a copal-bearing tree and an ietaiba.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: The Brazil plum or umbu (Spondias tuberosa). Copal is a name given to tree resin from the copal tree Protium copal (Burseraceae) that is particularly identified with the aromatic resins used by the cultures of pre-Columbian Mesoamerica as ceremonially burned incense and other purposes.

Image_title: [top] Back=Palm Clusii Lavendel=Ast Hoitzxochitl Avaramo-Temó [upper middle] Aroeira in Brasilien Aroeira oder Molle in Peru Ahate de Panucho [lower middle] Billing-bing West=Ind. Lace Baum Lace-zweig [bottom] Guytys [Guiti-iba]
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Various trees with their fruits and flowers including a lavender or cactus, a lance-leafed tree, trees of the Anacardiaceae family showing the Brazilian and Peruvian form, and Brazilian trees known as guititoroba, guiticoroya or guiti-iba.
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: The Avaramo-Temó is described as being from Brazil. The billingbing is a tree from southeast Asia.

Image_title: Le Paraguay Tiré des Relations les plus Recentes.
Description: Map of Paraguay and the watershed of the Rio de la Plata, showing also present-day Uruguay, Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, and Chile. Cartographic elements include degrees of latitude and longitude, topographical detail, names of cities and tributaries. The source of the Rio de la Plata is shown as Lake Xarayes. Decorative cartouche shows two female figures with vegetation.
References: Phillips, P.L. Atlases, 486, no. [33] & 3436, no. [39]; William L. Clements Library 2/333
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [top] 1. Americanische K�biss = Drucken 2. Uberfahrt Seil 3. Auf Sinken [bottom] Seilerne Br�ck.
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: [top] Native Americans cross a river with various modes of transportation. 1. on a gourd raft pulled across the river by a swimmer, 2. by sitting in a basket and pulling a rope across the river. 3. by binding together reeds and using the bundles to float across the river. [bottom] A band of soldiers crosses a river by means of a net which has bridged the river. Includes shields and spears.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: [top] These methods of crossing a river was also illustrated in Theodor de Bry, America, pt. 9, part 2, plate 25 (# 09187-2 ). [bottom] This bridge was illustrated in Theodor de Bry, America, pt. 6, plate 2 (# 35379-26), where a bridge the Inca king Huayna Capac had built over the Chiouo River (Rio Guayas) to conquer the people on the other side is described. While his men were crossing the bridge, the locals cut the bridge and most of Huayna Capac's men drowned. This work was published by Theodor de Bry and is derived from the third part of Girolamo Benzoni, Historia del mondo nuovo, Venice, 1565.

Image_title: [top] 1. Americanische Kübiss = Drucken 2. Uberfahrt Seil 3. Auf Sinken [bottom] Seilerne Brück.

Image_title: [Uses for trees in America]
Image_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreae Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
Description: Native Americans in trees drop stones, shoot with arrows, and pour water on Spanish soldiers who attack from the ground. One man chops at a tree trunk while two others hold boards over his head to protect him from the onslaught above.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Ost-und West-indischer wie auch sinesischer Lust-und Stats-Garten ...
Source_publisher: in Verlegung Johann Andreæ Endters, und Wolfgang dess jüngern sel. Erben
notes: These two images are derived from the image in Theodor de Bry, America, pt. 6, plate 23 (# 35379-24) and plate 24 (# 35379-25). The Spanish heard that they had gold and silver and tried to get them down. The Indians threw down stones, spears, and boiling water to prevent the Spaniards from cutting down the trees. The Spanish built wooden boards to protect them while they attempted to cut them down. This work was published by Theodor de Bry and is derived from the third part of Girolamo Benzoni, Historia del mondo nuovo, Venice, 1565.
