Image_title: [European soldiers are offered native American women]
Description: Spanish soldiers approach bound serpents or dragons. In the background, the creatures are grilled and native American women are being offered to the Spanish. Also includes scene of dancing and of first encounter with native Americans with natives fleeing into the woods.
Source_Title: Naaukeurige versameling der gedenk-waardigste zee en land-reysen na Oost en West-Indiën ... zedert het jaar 1524 tot 1526
Source_publisher: Door Pieter Vander Aa, boekverkoper in de St. Pieters Koor-steeg, in Plato.
notes: In 1499-1500, the Spanish, under Alonso de Ojeda and including Amerigo Vespucci, were reputed to have landed on the shore of Cabo de la Vela in present-day Colombia. Many natives fled into the woods when they landed. The Spanish followed them and came upon a settlement where many strange animals described as being horrible snakes with feet and wings (iguanas) were held and being prepared for a meal. The natives were very hospitable, even offering their women. See Theodor de Bry, America, part 10 (# 35312-5 ). This image follows the special title page for Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, Eerste zee-togt van Alonso d'Ojeda, en Amerikus Vesputius, ter nader ontdekking en bemagtiging van nieuwe landen, gedaan na de West-Indien, beneffens die van Christoffel Guerre, en Pero Alonso Nino, in 't jaar 1499 ... , Leiden, 1706. Excerpt and translation of the author's: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellanos, first printed Madrid, 1601. This collection of voyages consists of 127 parts, each having a special title page, separate pagination, and register. The voyages covering the period from 1246 to 1696 are arranged chronologically.
SubjectHeadings1: First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners

Image_title: [European soldiers are offered four native American women and three native American men]
Description: European soldiers are offered four native American women and three native American men. In the background a man is buried along with food. Also shown is a man being carried in a hammock and other men dancing.
Source_Title: Naaukeurige versameling der gedenk-waardigste zee en land-reysen na Oost en West-Indiën ... zedert het jaar 1524 tot 1526
Source_publisher: Door Pieter Vander Aa, boekverkoper in de St. Pieters Koor-steeg, in Plato.
notes: Text describes how the Spaniards fought with Indians who lost the engagement. The battle being lost, the Indians freely and joyfully gave the Spaniards the four women and three men. They danced and admired the Spanish victory. This image follows the special title page for Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, Eerste zee-togt van Alonso d'Ojeda, en Amerikus Vesputius, ter nader ontdekking en bemagtiging van nieuwe landen, gedaan na de West-Indien, beneffens die van Christoffel Guerre, en Pero Alonso Nino, in 't jaar 1499 ... , Leiden, 1706. Excerpt and translation of the author's: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellanos, first printed Madrid, 1601. This collection of voyages consists of 127 parts, each having a special title page, separate pagination, and register. The voyages covering the period from 1246 to 1696 are arranged chronologically.

Image_title: [Battle between native Americans and Europeans]
Description: Battle between native American and European soldiers. Europeans attack in boats with guns, swords, and pikes. Native Americans have feathered headdresses and tattoos. Also includes ship with cannons.
Source_Title: Naaukeurige versameling der gedenk-waardigste zee en land-reysen na Oost en West-Indiën ... zedert het jaar 1524 tot 1526
Source_publisher: Door Pieter Vander Aa, boekverkoper in de St. Pieters Koor-steeg, in Plato.
notes: Text describes how the Spaniards fought with Indians in presnt-day Venezuela.The battle being lost, the Indians freely and joyfully gave the Spaniards the four women and three men. They danced and admired the Spanish victory. This image follows the special title page for Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, Eerste zee-togt van Alonso d'Ojeda, en Amerikus Vesputius, ter nader ontdekking en bemagtiging van nieuwe landen, gedaan na de West-Indien, beneffens die van Christoffel Guerre, en Pero Alonso Nino, in 't jaar 1499 ... , Leiden, 1706. Image_title: [Continuation de la Bataile des Chupas; déroute des Almagres; victoire du Gouverneur; & suitte de Dom Diego]
Image_publisher: Chez Gerard Kuyper, Marchand Libraire à côté de la Maison de Ville
Description: Priest gives last rites to a dying man while a scene of warfare rages in the background. Includes a cross, sword. running man, and guns.
Source_Title: Histoire des guerres civiles des Espagnols, dans les Indes, entre les Piçarres & les Almagres, qui les avoient conquises. Traduite de l'espagnol de l'Ynca Garcillasso de la Vega, par J. Baudoin
Source_publisher: Chez Gerard Kuyper, Marchand Libraire à côté de la Maison de Ville
notes: Image title from chapter title. Diego de Almagro (1520-1542) attempted to solidify his title as the governor Peru in the desperate battle of Chupas on September 16, 1542. He escaped to Cuzco, but was arrested, condemned to death, and executed in town square. The artist may be Jan [or Joannes] Lamsveld, born ca. 1664.

Image_title: [Methods by which native Americans cured their sick]
Description: Native Americans put a sick man in the water to cure his fever, They wrap another sick person in a hammock. Another sick person the force to be near a fire, another is bled from his side. Also includes a woman and child. dwellings, and stream.
Source_Title: Naaukeurige versameling der gedenk-waardigste zee en land-reysen na Oost en West-Indiën ... zedert het jaar 1524 tot 1526
Source_publisher: Door Pieter Vander Aa, boekverkoper in de St. Pieters Koor-steeg, in Plato.
notes: Text describes how the sick were cured in what is present-day Venezuela. This image follows the special title page for Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, Eerste zee-togt van Alonso d'Ojeda, en Amerikus Vesputius, ter nader ontdekking en bemagtiging van nieuwe landen, gedaan na de West-Indien, beneffens die van Christoffel Guerre, en Pero Alonso Nino, in 't jaar 1499 ... , Leiden, 1706. Excerpt and translation of the author's: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellanos, first printed Madrid, 1601. Image_title: Fig. 1. A Shark drawn on his back, being the posture he in in when he takes his prey, his mouth not appearing in any other posture Fig. 2. Dophins
Description: Figure 1. Shark. Figure, 2. Dolphinfish or mahimahi. Image shown horizontally.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world. Containing an account of Captain Dampier's expedition into the south-seas in the ship St. George, in the years 1703 and 1704. With his various engagements, &c. And a particular and exact description of several islands in the Atlantick Ocean, the Brazilian coast, the passage round Cape Horn, and the coasts of Chili, Peru, and Mexico. Together with the author's voyage from Amapalla on the west coast of Mexico ...
Source_publisher: Printed by W. Botham, for James Knapton, at the Crown in St Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Scientific name of the mahimahi or common dolphinfish: Coryphaena hippurus. William Dampier, circumnavigator and privateer, commanded the ship St. George on his third voyage (1703-1707) around the world. He did not publish a description of this voyage although one of his officers, William Funnell, described it in this work. It was during this voyage that Alexander Selkirk, a model for Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe, was marooned on Juan Fernandez Island.

Image_title: Fig. 3. The Jelly Fish.
Description: Figure 3. The Jelly-fish perhaps a lizardfish or a marlin. Image shown horizontally.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world. Containing an account of Captain Dampier's expedition ... Together with the author's voyage from Amapalla on the west-coast of Mexico ...
Source_publisher: Printed by W. Botham, for James Knapton, at the Crown in St Paul's Church-Yard
notes: It is not clear what fish Funnell saw. William Dampier, circumnavigator and privateer, commanded the ship St. George on his third voyage (1703-1707) around the world. He did not publish a description of this voyage although one of his officers, William Funnell, described it in this work. It was during this voyage that Alexander Selkirk, a model for Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe, was marooned on Juan Fernandez Island.

Image_title: [Cabbage tree, fish, plan of Arica, Chile, and profiles of mountains]
Description: Various views of a cabbage tree, a fish, profiles of Gallo Island and the mountain of Sama, as well as a plan of the harbor of Arica, in present-day Chile.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world. Containing an account of Captain Dampier's expedition into the south-seas in the ship St. George, in the years 1703 and 1704. With his various engagements, &c. And a particular and exact description of several islands in the Atlantick Ocean, the Brazilian coast, the passage round Cape Horn, and the coasts of Chili, Peru, and Mexico. Together with the author's voyage from Amapalla on the west coast of Mexico ...
Source_publisher: Printed by W. Botham, for James Knapton, at the Crown in St Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text describes the cabbage trees on Juan Fernandez Island, a silver fish said to have a great bottle nose and delicious white flesh, and the port of Arica, including profiles of some mountains which surround it. William Dampier, circumnavigator and privateer, commanded the ship St. George on his third voyage (1703-1707) around the world. He did not publish a description of this voyage although one of his officers, William Funnell, described it in this work. It was during this voyage that Alexander Selkirk, a model for Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe, was marooned on Juan Fernandez Island.

Image_title: [Profiles of mountains, banana palm, a pelican, an albacore tuna, and an iguana]
Description: Various views of profiles of mountains of Point Garachina and Gallera Island in the Bay of Panama, a pelican, a banana palm tree, an albacore tuna, and an iguana.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world. Containing an account of Captain Dampier's expedition ... Together with the author's voyage from Amapalla on the west-coast of Mexico ...
Source_publisher: Printed by W. Botham, for James Knapton, at the Crown in St Paul's Church-Yard
notes: William Dampier, circumnavigator and privateer, commanded the ship St. George on his third voyage (1703-1707) around the world. He did not publish a description of this voyage although one of his officers, William Funnell, described it in this work. It was during this voyage that Alexander Selkirk, a model for Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe, was marooned on Juan Fernandez Island.

Image_title: Fig. 26. A Ceawau. Fig. 28. The Yellow Tayle. Fig. 29. [Island Magon]. Fig. 30. The form of ye Indian Proe with its outleaker
Description: Two fish, a ceaswau and a yellowtail amberjack, a profile of the island of Magon [?] seen from the north, and a view of an Indian proa or boat with outrigger.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world. Containing an account of Captain Dampier's expedition ... Together with the author's voyage from Amapalla on the west-coast of Mexico ...
Source_publisher: Printed by W. Botham, for James Knapton, at the Crown in St Paul's Church-Yard
notes: The ceawau [not identifiable] was a fish caught by Funnell near the island of Amapala, in present-day Honduras, with an oddly coiled body. The yellowtail amberjack; scientific name: Seriola lalandi. William Dampier, circumnavigator and privateer, commanded the ship St. George on his third voyage (1703-1707) around the world. He did not publish a description of this voyage although one of his officers, William Funnell, described it in this work. It was during this voyage that Alexander Selkirk, a model for Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe, was marooned on Juan Fernandez Island.

Image_title: Bedel en Slacht Papen Afgoden der Mexicane[s] | Prêtres mendians et Sacrifians aux Divinitez des Mexiquains.
Image_publisher: Chez Pierre van der Aa, marchand libraire
Description: Religious practices of the Japanese, Turks, and Mexicans. Priests make sacrifices to idols and gods. Includes Aztecs or Mexicans offering human sacrifices on altars and before a temples with an idol identified as Uitziaputsli [or Huitzilopochtli (the god of the sun and war)]. Japanese priests and mendicants or beggars are also shown. Also includes oxen carrying people in woven baskets, person being hung over a fire, how bramins [?] bathe, and shows the dervishes of Turkey. Items in the image are lettered for identification in a key above.
Source_Title: Les Indes Orientales et Occidentales, et autres lieux; : représentés en très-belles figures, qui montrent au naturel les peuples, moeurs, religions, fêtes, sacrifices, mosquées, idoles, richesses, cérémonies, festins, tribunaux, supplices et esclavages ... etc.
Source_publisher: Chez Pierre van der Aa, marchand libraire

Image_title: [left] Histoire de Perse | Persische Historie [right] Art de pendre ches les Mexiquains | Veder Schilder Konst.
Image_publisher: Chez Pierre van der Aa, marchand libraire
Description: [left] A man kneels before a king in court in Persia surrounded by a ruler in a turban and his courtiers. Includes a dog and sets of keys. [right] Various art forms of the ancient Mexicans or Aztecs are practiced. Includes telling of time by using a stone sun calendar, making or painting of idols, new year's celebrations, view of an aqueduct. Also includes depiction of the royal palace, breaking of vessels, a dog or jaguar [?], woven baskets, feathered garments and headdresses, musical instruments such as a trumpet and drums.
Source_Title: Les Indes Orientales et Occidentales, et autres lieux; : représentés en très-belles figures, qui montrent au naturel les peuples, moeurs, religions, fêtes, sacrifices, mosquées, idoles, richesses, cérémonies, festins, tribunaux, supplices et esclavages ... etc.
Source_publisher: Chez Pierre van der Aa, marchand libraire

Image_title: Santa Rosa de S. Maria natural de Lima y patrona de Peru
Description: St. Rose of Lima holds a representation of the city of Lima in one hand and a child circled in garlands in the other. A native American woman with feathered headdress, bow, and arrows kneels before her image which emerges from a rose. The author, a gentleman holding a book and quill with the cross of the Order of Santiago on his cloak, also looks up at St. Rose. Also includes sword, angels, anchor, and coat of arms of Lima.
Source_creator: Oviedo y Herrera, Luis Antonio de, Conde de la Granja, 1636-1717
Source_Title: Vida de Sta. Rosa de Santa Maria, natural de Lima, y patrona del Peru. Poema heroyco ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Garcia Infanzon
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first saint who was born in the Americas to be canonized, joined the secular order of the Dominicans.
SubjectHeadings2: Oviedo y Herrera, Luis Antonio de, Conde de la Granja, 1636-1717

Image_title: V. Me. Sor Maria de Jesus de Agreda ...
Creator1: Aciscio Antonio Palomino de Castro y Velasco
Description: Portrait of a nun writing in a book with quill and ink. Behind her stands a vision of the Virgin Mary standing on a crescent moon, her head encircled by stars.
Source_Title: Prologo y relacion de la vida de la Venerable Madre Sor Maria de Jesus de Agreda
Source_publisher: Por Blàs de Villa-Nueva
notes: Sor Maria de Jesus de Agreda wrote the work, The city of God, a history of the Virgin Mary. She also reported that she had a memory of over five hundred spiritual visits to the various tribes of the American southwest during which time she converted the whole Indian population to Christianity without physically leaving Spain.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles
SubjectHeadings2: María de Jesús, de Agreda, sor, 1602-1665

Image_title: Jnga Peruviana, Siliquâ quadrangula vulgo Pacay Pois Sucrins du Perou
Description: Peruvian inga plant showing leaves, legume or seed pod, flower, and branch. Includes details of pod and flower.
Source_Title: Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily et du Perou fait pendant les années 1712, 1713 & 1714.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean-Geoffroy Nyon ... Etienne Ganeau ... Jacque Quillau
notes: The Pacay is a South American legume tree, Inga feuillei. It is cultivated for its large, white, edible pods. Engraver is probably Nicolas Guerard, active 1680-1719.

Image_title: Le Perou dans l'Amerique meridionale, Dressé Sur les Divers Relations des Flibustiers et Nouveaux Voyageurs.
Image_publisher: Chez I.F. Benard gendre de l'Auteur dans l'Isle du Palais sur le Quay de l'Orloge a la Sphere Royale
Description: Map of Peru including parts of present-day Ecuador, Bolivia, and Brazil. Cartographic elements include location of native American settlements, rivers, lakes, and wetlands, some topographical details, compass rose, and degrees of latitude and longitude. Decorative cartouche includes llamas, scene of mining with miners carrying baskets on their backs and climbing ladders. Also includes native American man and woman with spear, shield, and basket.
References: Phillips, P.L. Atlases, 5962, n. [99] and 5979, no. [115]; British Museum Printed Maps 11/476
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Map of the wanderings of the ancient Mexicans]
Description: Conceptual map of the wanderings of the Mexicans on their search for a homeland. Significant places on their journey are given French and Nahuatl names and symbols. Includes location of Tenochtitlán marked by a cactus, Chapultépec [Hill of the Grasshopper], Chaco, Xaltzpozaulican, etc. Also includes native Americans or Mexicans, speaking bird, body parts, tzompantli or skull rack, and symbols of plants including maize and fruit trees.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Text states that image is a copy drawn by Charles Siguenza of an original drawn by native Americans.The Mexicans were told to search for a place that would be shown to them by the presence of an eagle standing on a cactus growing out of a rock. This place is Tenochtitlán or the present-day Mexico City. An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais. Cf. 08792-2, A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Ticocic V. Roy des Mexiquains
Description: Tizoc, here identified as the fifth Aztec king, wears a mantle or cloak and holds feathered scepters. His hair is dressed with a feathered ornament.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Tizoc (reigned 1481-1486), grandson of Moctezuma I and brother to Axayácatl, was a weak ruler who was probably poisoned by his own nobles. Cf. 08792-5, for A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: Mine
Description: Workers holding candles descend into a mine by means of climbing down a notched pole. Other workers dig underground with axes. Items in the image are lettered and identified in following text.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Text describes the silver mines mined by native Americans and the dangers they faced.Cf. 08792-5, for A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: [Aztec calendar]
Description: Aztec calendar showing the century and year surrounded by a snake. Includes symbols of the years, months, and days.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: The Aztec calendar consisted of a 365-day calendar cycle called xiuhpohualli (year count for the solar year) and a 260-day ritual cycle called tonalpohualli (day count). Together these two cycles together formed a 52 year "century," shown here. Cf. 08792-1, A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: Idole de la pluye
Description: Tlaloc, the idol of rain, is shown holding an obsidian knife, shield, and wearing a feather headdress.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Tlaloc, the Aztec god of rain, presided over the third era of the Mexica. His attributes include rimmed eyes, a crown of heron feathers, and a "netted" cloud dress. Cf. 08792-5, for A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage and 12806-1.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: Axaijacac VII. roy
Description: Axayácatl, here identified as the seventh king of the Aztecs, dressed in jaguar costume is shown with feathered shield (or chimalli) and obsidian sword (or macuahuitl).
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Axayácatl [reigned 1469-1481] was the sixth Aztec emperor. The elite fighting forces of the warrior society of the jaguars used the macuahuilt or a "hand-stick," a wooden blade with sharp obsidian blades embedded in its sides. Cf. 08792-5, for A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage and 12806-1.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: Quauhtimoc X. Roy
Description: Cuauhtémoc (also known as Cuauhtemotzin, Guatimozin or Guatemoc), here identified as the tenth king of the Aztecs, dressed in a mantle or cloak and holding a feather "scepter" and an arrow. Includes facial ornamentation.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Cuauhtémoc [reigned 1520-1521] was the Aztec ruler (tlatoani) of Tenochtitlán from 1520 to 1521. The nephew of Moctezuma II, he was married to one of Moctezuma's daughters. His reign coincided with a devastating epidemic of smallpox.Cf. 08792-4, for A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: Ahuitzotl VIII. Roy
Description: Ahuitzotl, here identified as the eighth king of the Aztecs, dressed in a mantle or cloak, holding a feather "scepter" and baton. Includes facial ornamentation.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Auitzotl, or Ahuitzotl (reigned 1486-1502), the eighth Aztec emperor, son of Moctezuma I and brother of Axayácatl and Tizoc, enlarged the Aztec empire to its greatest size. A ruthless military leader, he suppressed a Huastec rebellion and more than doubled the size of lands under Aztec dominance. He conquered the Mixtecs, Zapotecs, Tarascans, and others down to the western part of Guatemala. Under his rule the main temple at Tenochtitlán was completed. His symbol is of the ahuizotl, a water creature (perhaps mythical), which lived in the lakes around Tenochtitlán. The baton he holds in his hand may represent the water symbol of the ahuizotl.Cf. 08792-4, for A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: Monhtezuma roy et le II. du nom
Description: Moctezuma, here identified as the second king of the Aztecs of his name, dressed in a mantle or cloak and holding a spear, sits on a wicker throne. A glyph of his name is included along with a sword, skull, and wicker boxes.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Moctezuma II (or Montezuma II, reigned 1502-1520), the ninth Aztec emperor, whose surname was Xocoyotzin or bitter lord (or the youngest), was the son of Axayácatl and great grandson of Moctezuma I. He surrendered to the Spanish in 1520. Cf. 08792-4, for A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L. F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: Aguacate Avorat ou Persea
Description: Avocado pear is shown with branch, flowers, and fruit. Includes a cross section showing the seed or pit.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Scientific name: Persea lauraceae. Cf. 09519-19.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Image_title: Zapote sapotier
Description: Branch, fruit, flower, and cross-section of fruit of the sapote tree.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Black and white sapote (zapote in Spanish) trees are discussed in the text. White sapote is Casimiroa edulis, and black sapote, actually related to the persimmon, is Diospyros digna. Cf. 09519-17.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Image_title: Granadilla Fleur de la Passion

Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Passion fruit or Passiflora edulis, also known as granadilla, is indigenous to Central and South America. Image_title: Cacaotier Cacao
Description: Branch, leaf, seed pod, and flower of a cocoa tree. Includes a cross-section of the seed pod.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: The fruit of the cocoa tree, Theobroma cacao, grows from the trunk and major branches of the tree. Cf. 09519-17.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: Vanila Vanille
Description: Branch, flowers, and pods of the vanilla orchid.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: The vanilla orchid, native to South and Central America, was first brought to the attention of Europeans by Hernán Cortés who saw it at the Aztec court where it was called tlilxochitl. Due to the difficulty of its pollination, it was not successfully cultivated until the nineteenth century. Cf. 09519-18.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Image_title: Maghey Aloé
Description: Branch, flowers, root, and seed pod of the maguey or aloe plant.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin

Image_title: Description de Mexico et des Lagunes de ses Environs
Description: Map of Mexico City and the lakes in its environs. Cartographic elements include, scale, compass rose, and location of settlements, lakes, and volcanos.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Text states that image is a copy drawn by Charles Siguenza of an original drawn by native Americans.The Mexicans were told to search for a place that would be shown to them by the presence of an eagle standing on a cactus growing out of a rock. This place is Tenochtitlán or the present-day Mexico City. An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais. Cf. 08792-3, A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Soldat Mexiquain
Description: A Mexican or Aztec soldier holding an obsidian sword, shield, sling with stone in it, and the head of a warrior. Includes settlement in distance.
Source_Title: [Giro du mondo. French] Voyage du tour du monde ... Tome sixieme
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne Ganeau, Libraire rue S. Jacques, aux Armes de Dombes, vis-à-vis la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: The stone sling (tematlatl) was made from maguey fiber. The macuahuilt or a "hand-stick" was a wooden blade with sharp obsidian blades embedded in its sides. Cf. 08792-5, for A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704, which includes Gemelli Careri's voyage.An abridged translation, variously attributed to Eustache Le Noble (1643-1711) and to L.F. Dubois de Saint-Gelais.Gemelli Careri was a world traveler who went around the world starting with the Holy Land and ending in Mexico. His five-year journey which began in 1693 ended by taking the silver fleet back to Spain from Cuba.

Image_title: La Californie ou Nouvelle Caroline. Teatro de los trabajos, apostolicos de la Compa. e Jesus en la America, Sept.
Image_publisher: dans l'Isle du Palais a la Sphere Royale
Description: Map of California as an island and present-day Mexico. Cartographic elements include degrees of latitude and longitude. Decorative elements include scenes from native American life, including grating manioc and dancing, as well as animals such as an armadillo and birds.
References: Tooley, R.V. Mapping of America, no. 62; Wagner, H.R. Cartography of the Northwest coast of America, II, no. 517; British Museum Printed Maps 6/21
SubjectArea3: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Robinson Crusoe.
Description: Robinson Crusoe wearing fur clothes and hat and holding an umbrella or parasol made of fur. Includes gun or musket, basket, saw, ax or hatchet, turtle, dwelling, and palisade.
Source_Title: [Robinson Crusoe. Parts I-III. French. 1721] La vie et les avantures suprenantes de Robinson Crusoe ...
Source_publisher: Chez L'Honoré & Chatelain
notes: The story of Robinson Crusoe was based on the story of Alexander Selkirk who went to sea in 1704 with William Dampier and was put ashore on Juan Fernandez Island off of the coast of Chile where he survived until he was rescued in 1709 by Woodes Rogers.

Image_title: Maniere dont les prêtres Caribes souflent le Courage.
Description: Native Americans dance in a dwelling preparatory to war. Priest in feathered garments and headresses blow smoke from pipes on the faces of the dancers. Includes interior of council house, bows, quivers or arrows, feathered ornaments, necklaces, feathered headdresses, and religious objects or rattles.
Source_Title: Ceremonies et coutumes religieuses des peuples idolatres ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez J. F. Bernard
notes: Text describes the people of New Granada, or Cumana in present-day Venezuela. Published under the general editorship of the Amsterdam bookseller, Jean Frédéric Bernard.
References_exhibitions: Landis, D.C. Literature of the Encounter,no. 31, Fig. III.8.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Social life and customs

Image_title: [Our Lady of Guadalupe]
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe standing on a crescent moon with roses, starry cloak, and angel.
Source_Title: Conveniencia relativa entre el termino de vn templo apostolico, sujeto, que se dedica, y la imagen de Gvadalvpe, predicado, que se coloca ...
Source_publisher: Por Francisco de Rivera Calderon, en la Calle de San Augustin
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [top] Le Mercure des Mexicains adoré à Cholula sous le nom de Quetzalcouatl. [bottom] Divinité qui préside à la chasse.
Description: [top] Native Americans offer blood sacrifices to the statue of the deity, Quetzalcoatl. Priests offer birds and practice self-mutilation (cutting ear and piercing tongue at fire before the deity). [bottom] Native Americans hunt bear and deer or stags. In the background natives offer their catch to a statue of a deity. Includes feathered headdresses, whips, cage, bows and arrows, war club, and net.
Source_Title: Ceremonies et coutumes religieuses des peuples idolatres ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez J. F. Bernard
notes: Quetzalcoatl, whose name means feathered "quetzal" serpent, was the Aztec god of creation. Published under the general editorship of the Amsterdam bookseller, Jean Frédéric Bernard.
References_exhibitions: Landis, D.C. Literature of the Encounter,no. 31, Fig. III.8.

Image_title: [top] Honneurs funébres, rendus aux Grands, du Perou apres leur mort. [bottom] Maniere d'ensevelir les Grands, du Perou.
Description: [top] An Inca king is carried on a litter while a native American blows down his throat with a pipe. In the foreground, some of his subjects are buried alive. [bottom] A king is buried in a grave with golden objects. Includes feathered headdresses and garments, war club, shovels, dwellings, fortification, and canopy or parasol.
Source_Title: Ceremonies et coutumes religieuses des peuples idolatres ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez J. F. Bernard
notes: Text describes the funerary practices of the royalty of Peru. Published under the general editorship of the Amsterdam bookseller, Jean Frédéric Bernard.
References_exhibitions: Landis, D.C. Literature of the Encounter,no. 31, Fig. III.8.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Funeral customs and rites

Image_title: The great Temple of Mexico.
Image_publisher: T. Woodward ... J. Hooker ... J. Peele
Description: Bird's-eye view of the main temple [the Templo mayor] of Mexico City. The temple is encircled by a wall with serpents or snakes carved on it and two sanctuaries on the top before which priests sacrifice a victim. A body is tossed down the stairs. Dancers celebrate before the temple within the wall. In foreground is a skull rack or tzompantli and native Americans with bows and arrows wearing feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. English] ... Done into English ... By Thomas Townsend Esq;
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Woodward at the Half-Moon, and J. Hooker at the Flower-de-Luce, both against St. Dunstan's Church, in Fleet-Street; and J. Peele at Locke's-Head in Pater-Noster-Row.
notes: The great temple at Tenochtitlan was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc, the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli. Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. Tlaloc, the god of rain and agriculture, was of pre-Aztec, or Toltec, origin. A coatepantli or wall made of sculpted serpents often surrounds Aztec temples. The tzompantli would hold the skulls of sacrificial victims.

Image_title: [left] Myrtus parasy-litica, Mari folio, vulò Hitigu. [right] Myrtus Buxi folio, fructu rubro, vulgò Mortilla.
Description: [left] Myrtus parasy-litica tree with its leaves, flower, and fruit or berries. [right] Myrtus Buxi folio plant with its leaves, flower, and fruit or berries.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: The scientific name for Myrtus parasy-litica is Myrceugenia rufa; it is native to Chile. Myrtus buxifolia may be one of three species of the genus Eugenia native to Chile: E. darwinii, E. temu, or E. uniflora. It may also be Myrtus ugna. All have red fruits that are eaten.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725.

Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Parqui is Cestrum parqui; it is native to Chile. Myrtus folio subrotundo may be one of three species of the genus Eugenia native to Chile: E. darwinii, E. temu, or E. uniflora. All have red fruits that are eaten.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725.

Image_title: [left] Onagra Salicis angusto, dentatò que folio, vulgo Mithon. [center] Onagra Linarae folio, magno flore purpureo. [right] Onagra Hyssopi folia, flore amplo violaceo, vulgo Innil
Description: [left] Onagra Salicis angusto plant with its roots and leaves. [center] Onagra Linarae folio plant with its roots, leaves, bud, and flowers. [right] Onagra Hyssopi folia plant with its roots, leaves, and flower.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart

Image_title: [top] Opuntia herbariorum [bottom] Muscus Squamosus aquaticus elegantissimus.
Description: Opuntia ficus-indica or prickly pear cactus plant with its spines or thorns and flowers. Includes detail of the cochineal insect. [bottom] Muscus squamosus plant with its roots and "leaves."
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: The cochineal insect, from which red dye is made, is a parasite of the opuntia cactus. It has not been possible to identify the Muscus squamosus plant.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725.

Image_title: [left] Phascolus folio vario flore ex luteo virescente [right] Paclas aquatica, humifusa, Cotini folio.
Description: [left] Phascolus folio vario plant with its leaves, flower, and fruit or legume. [right] Paclas aquatica plant with its roots and leaves.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart

Image_title: [left] Chenopodium folio sinuato sature virente, vulgò Quinoa. [right] Congona
Description: [left] Chenopodium folio sinuato sature virente plant with its roots, leaves, flowers, and seeds. [right] Congona plant with its roots, leaves and flower or seed stalk.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: [left] This plant is quinoa or quinua, Chenopodium quinoa, native to the Andes Mountains of Bolivia, Chile, and Peru where its seeds have been eaten for 5,000 years. The leaves of the plant may also be eaten. Congona is probably Peperomia congona, native to Andean South America.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725.

Image_title: Convolvulus Indicus vulgo Patates dictus, ...

Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.

Image_title: [left] Coriaria Rusci-folia, vulgò Deu [right] Convolvulus, folio Subrotundo, floribus solitariis e foliorum alis.
Description: [left] Coriaria Rusci-folia plant with its leaves and flowers. [right] Convolvulus folio subrotundo plant with its root, leaves, flowers, and seed [?].
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Coriaria Rusci-folia is probably Coriaria ruscifolia, a poisonous plant native to South America. It has not been possible to identify which species of Convolvulus Feuillée's folio subrotundo is, but he found it in the valley of Lima.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Image_title: [left] Ficoides Peruviana, folio triangulari, amplo flore purpureo [right] Elichrysum Americanum latifolium, vulgò Vira-vira Ins. R. Herb.
Description: [left] Ficoides Peruviana plant with its roots, leaves, flowers, and fruit. [right] Elichrysum Americanum latifolium plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Ficoides Peruviana may be a member of the genus Carpobrotus, perhaps C. dimidiatus or C. chilensis, a genus believed to have been introduced to the west coast of the Americas (especially Chile) from southeastern Africa by the Portuguese in the 1500s. Elichrysum Americanum latifolium may be the native Chilean plant Gnaphalium viravira. Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725.

Image_title: [top] Eupatorioides Salicis folio trinervi, flore luteo, vulgò Contrahierba [bottom] Gentianoides flore luteo
Description: [top] Eupatorioides Salicis plant with its leaves and flowers. Includes details of flower and worm found inside the flower. [bottom] Gentianoides flore luteo plant with its root, leaf, and flower.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: It has not been possible to identify these plants, but Gentianoides is probably a member of the Gentianaceae family, the oldest members of which are found in Latin America. This specimen was found in Argentina. The specimen of Eupatorioides was found in Chile and was used as a yellow dye.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Description: [left] Gratiola latiore folio plant with its root, leaves, and flowers. [right] Guanabanus Perseae folio plant with its roots, leaves, fruit, and flower.

Image_title: [top] Ranunculus palustris echinatus [bottom] Herba purgationis flore violaceo
Description: [top] Ranunculus palustris plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers. [bottom] Herba purgationis plant with its leaves, seed head, and flowers. Includes detail of seed or petal.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Ranunculus palustris may be Ranunculus muricatus, a species native to Chile. Feuillée's specimen was collected in northwestern Argentina. Herba purgationis, which Feuillée says was used by the natives to cure venereal diseases, may be a member of the genus Boerhavia or the genus Commicarpus.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart

notes: Both of the bulbs shown are probably members of the genus Hippeastrum and native to South America. Image_title: [left] Llithi. [right] Lucuma.
Description: [left] Llithi tree with leaves and fruit. [right] Lucuma tree with its leaves.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Sir William Jackson Hooker in his The botany of Captain Beechey's voyage, London, 1841, p. 16 contends that much confusion has been caused by the engraving of the names of the species in this plate under the wrong images. The Llithi, litre, or Lithraea caustica tree causes extreme swelling of the skin when people allergic to its secretions are exposed to them. It is native to central Chile. Lucuma is probably Pouteria lucuma, a fruit tree native to the Andean region.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Image_title: [left] Oxis lutea, annua, floribus dentatis. [right] Lun.

Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Oxis lutea, described by Feuillée as being large with purple stripes on its yellow flowers, may be Oxalis spiralis or Oxalis herrerae, both from Peru where he gathered his sample. Lun is probably Escallonia revoluta, a tree native to Chile.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: [left] The Lycopersicum Pimpinellae plant is Lycopersicum pimpinellifolium or the currant tomato native to Brazil and Peru. [center] Lychnidaea Verbenae may be Verbena corymbosa. Feuillée collected this specimen in Chile.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725.

Image_title: Palillos
Description: Branch of the palillos tree with its leaves, flower, and fruit. Includes details of two insects.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: The palillos tree may be Campomanesia lineatifolia, native to Colombian, Peruvian, and Brazilian Amazonia.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725.

Image_title: [left] Palo-Negro. [right] Palquin
Description: [left] Palo-negro plant with its roots and flowers. [right] Branch of the palquin bush with its roots, leaves, and flower globe.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Palquin is probably Buddleia globosa or orange butterfly bush, native to the Andes of Chile, Peru, and Argentina. It has not been possible to identify Palo-negro, but Lindley has suggested that it is a member of the genus Euxenia, and it has also been identified as Podanthus ovatifolius or P. mitiqui. Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725

Image_title: [left] Papaya ramosa, fructu Pyriformi. [right] Renalmia ramosa lutea, foliis spinosis, vulgò Poya.
Description: [left] Papaya ramosa plant with its roots, leaves, fruit, and flowers. [right] Renalmia [Renealmia] plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Papaya ramosa is probably not Carica papaya, but may be Carica candicans from Peru, C. pyriformis or mountian papaya, C. pubescens with a pink flower which is synonymous with Vasconcellea cundinamarcensis, or it may be V. candicans. Renalmia [Renealmia] is probably a member of the genus Puya, either P. chilensis or P. gilmartinii, both native to Chile.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725

Image_title: [left] Percicaria Salicis folio ampliori utrinque acuto, flore purpureo, vulgo Duras-Nnillo. [right] Golondrina
Description: [left] Percicaria [Persicaria] plant with its roots, leaves, flowers, and a detail of its seed. [right] Golondrina plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Percicaria [Persicaria] is probably a member of the genus Polygonum which is synonymous with Persicaria. Considered a weed, some of its members are native to Chile and Peru. Golondrina may be a member of the Euphorbia genus, generally known as spurge, some members of which are native to South America.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. Image_title: [left] Urceolaria foliis carnosis scandens [right] Qued qued
Description: [left] Urceolaria vine with its leaves, flower, and roots growing on a tree stump. [right] Branch of the qued qued tree with its berries or fruit.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart

Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.

Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.

Image_title: [left] Calceolaria Salviae folio vulgo Chachaul [right] Calceolaria, foliis Scabiosae vulgaris.

Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.

notes: Both of these plants are probably from the genus Calceolaria whose members are native to South and Central America with most of its destribution in the Andean region. Image_title: [left] Cardamindum ampliori folio et majori flore. Inst. R. Herb. [right] Cardamindum minus et vulgare.
Description: Two nasturtium plants: [left] Cardamindum ampliori folio et majori flore plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers. [right] Cardamindum minus et vulgare plant with its root, leaves, and flowers.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Cardamindum ampliori folio et majori flore is probably Tropaeolum majus, and Cardamindum minus is probably Tropaeolum minus. Nasturtiums are native to South and Central America. All parts of the plant are edible. Feuillée collected both plants in Peru.Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile.Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: En la Imprenta de Angel Pasqual Rubio
Description: Portrait of Juana Inez de la Cruz holding a book and quill.
Source_creator: Juana Inés de la Cruz, Sister, 1651-1695
Source_Title: [Obras] Segundo tomo de las Obras ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de Angel Pasqual Rubio
notes: Known as the lyric poet of colonial Mexico, Juana Inés de la Cruz was a nun, scholar, intellectual prodigy, and writer of polemics and plays, as well as poetry.
SubjectHeadings1: Juana Inés de la Cruz, Sister, 1651-1695--Portraits

Image_title: Ein Paraquar
Description: Native American man from Paraguay holding a bow and an arrow. Includes skin garment and feather ear ornaments. Also includes a quiver with arrows.
Source_Title: De India, ejúsque gloriosa juventute; sermones habiti a rhetoribus viennensibus et honori illustrissimorum, perillusatrium, reverendorum, praenobilium, nobilium, excellentium, ac doctissimorum dominorum
Source_publisher: Typis Wolffgangi Schwendimann, univ. typogr.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page showing kneeling and chained native Americans. The decorative border also contains feathered headdresses, bows, arrows, suits of armor, cannon, flags, and a woman representing the Church. She sits upon a serpent and a fallen idol or devil and holds a cross and chalice and paten. Beside her is an incense burner, papal crown, and crozier. Also includes the Spanish royal coat of arms.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page includes the decorative border from the scenes of war from Cajamarca, Peru, in the illustration following p. 84 of this volume. Includes native Americans fighting Spanish soldiers, feathered headdresses, shields, war clubs, bows, arrows. Surmounted by angels of fame holding laurel wreaths and musical instruments such as trumpets. Also includes dogs, ship, dwelling, guns or muskets, and axes.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: The scene is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 6, plate 13, which shows the Inca attempt to retake Cuzco under the leadership of Atahualpa's brother, Manco.

Image_title: Ceremonies que les Incas observent en faisant Chevaliers les Princes de leur Sang. Liv. VI ch. XXVII
Description: The Inca king, enthroned in a Western (Classical) architectural setting, pierces the earlobe of one of his subjects. Other prospective "knights" await their turns and have sandals fitted on their feet. Decorative elements include statues in niches with reliefs of native birds, beasts, and insects.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard

Image_title: Neue Taffel Der Weitlauffigen Landschaft Paraguaria ...
Image_publisher: Heirs of Phillip, Martin & Johann Veith
Description: Map of the Jesuit missions in Paraguay showing the locations of the various tribes and settlements. Includes the Pacific Ocean east to the Parana River or parts of Peru, Bolivia, and Paraguay. Cartographic elements include degrees of latitude and longitude, compass rose, location of rivers and lakes (including Lake Titicaca [?] and Lake [Xareyes? with the island of Orejones in the middle]), scales, and some topographical details. Also includes a lion and jaguar.
Source_Title: Allerhand so lehr- als geist-reiche Brief Schrifften und Reis Beschreibungen, welche von denen Missionariis der Gesellschafft Jesu aus beyden Indien un andern ... Ländern ... Zweyter Bund
Source_publisher: In Verlag Philipp, Martin, und Johann Veiths seel. Erben
notes: This map accompanies an account of the Jesuit Paraguayan missions.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Die Landschaft nider=Paraguaria, Samt den Ländern Tucuman, Tscharvas, Tschaco, Mocobis, und einem Theil des Königreichs Tschili.
Image_publisher: Heirs of Phillip, Martin & Johann Veith
Description: Map of the Jesuit missions in Paraguay showing the locations of the various tribes and settlements, and showing the Rio de la Plata and Parana and Uruguay rivers. Includes parts of Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, and both the Atlantic and Pacific oceans. Cartographic elements include degrees of latitude and longitude, compass rose, location of rivers and lakes, scales, and some topographical details. Also includes a a rhea and an ox.
Source_Title: Allerhand so lehr- als geist-reiche Brief Schrifften und Reis Beschreibungen, welche von denen Missionariis der Gesellschafft Jesu aus beyden Indien un andern ... Ländern ... Zweyter Bund
Source_publisher: In Verlag Philipp, Martin, und Johann Veiths seel. Erben
notes: This map accompanies an account of the Jesuit Paraguayan missions.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: En la imprenta de Francisco Martinez Abad
Description: An angel guides shipwrecked men to a shore where native Americans wait.
Source_Title: Origen de los Indios de el Nuevo Mundo e Indias Occidentales ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Francisco Martinez Abad
notes: Garcia theorized that native Americans originated in Asia and he included native American origin accounts in his book.

Image_title: [Methods of obtaining metal]
Description: Different stages of mining and refining metal are shown. Men mine the ore from underground, shovel it into machines which grind it up, the ore is washed and refined in a furnace, smelted, and worked. Poem at the bottom of image asks why France never discovered gold in the New World.
Source_Title: Traité de l'art métalique extrait des oeuvres d'Alvare-Alfonse Barba, célébre artiste dans les Mines du Potozi, Auquel on a joint un Memoire concernant les mines de France
Source_publisher: Chez Guillaume Saugrain, au milieu du Quay de Gêvres, à la Croix blanche

Image_title: Captif Sacrifié par les Antis.
Description: Native Americans torture another by cutting him, collecting his blood, and eating his flesh (scene of cannibalism). Includes a temple in the background in which a skeleton hangs and before which people make an offering. Includes knives, shield, war club, arrows, and post at which the victim is tied.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: IHS Plano una parte del Orinoco, que comprehende desde el Caño de Guaruapo asta la Isla de Faxardo ...
Description: Plan of a part of the Orinoco River showing the missions of the Capuchins from Isla de Faxardo at the confluence of the Orinoco and Caroni rivers to the mouth of the Orinoco. Cartographic elements include scale.
Source_Title: Informe, que hace a Su Magestad, en su Real, y Supremo Consejo de las Indias, el padre Joseph Gumilla, de la Compañia de Jesus, missionero de las missiones de Casanáre, Meta, y Orinoco
notes: The original map from which this map was engraved is in the Archives of the Indies, Seville, Spain.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plano de la Ciudad de Cartagena de las Indias ...
Description: Plan of the city of Cartagena in present-day Colombia. Cartographic elements include scale and compass rose. Items are lettered and numbered for identification in key at lower left of image. Includes names of different bastions and religious structures. C
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo primero.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: An account of the expedition sent by the French Académie Royale des Sciences in 1735 to measure a degree of the meridian at the equator. The participants included the Frenchmen, La Condamine, Godin, and Bouguer, and the Spaniards, Ulloa and Juan y Santaci
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plano de la Baia y Ciud. de Portoveto. [Portobelo] ...
Description: Plan of the city and port of Portobelo in present-day Panama. Cartographic elements include soundings, names of bodies of water, scale, and compass rose. Items are lettered for identification in key at right of image.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo primero.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: An account of the expedition sent by the French Académie Royale des Sciences in 1735 to measure a degree of the meridian at the equator. The participants included the Frenchmen, La Condamine, Godin, and Bouguer, and the Spaniards, Ulloa and Juan y Santaci

Image_title: [Portrait of Juan Palafox y Mendoza]
Image_publisher: Ex Reg. Sum. Adm. Sacr. que Lib. Typ. apud D. Mariam de Rivera, in pub. via de Empedradillo
Description: Announcement of a thesis defense with a portrait of Juan Palafox y Mendoza.
Source_Title: Mirabilis oculus in capitis vertice firmo radiorum lumine circuncinctus cum totum corpus nitida collustraturus effet potestate; celsiorem juremerito arcem occupavit, speculatoris culmine strenua claritate munitus, tam validam reginimis illûmuniationem emisit; ut amico foedere membra colpulata in rectam viam illicò dirigi cereuerentur
Source_publisher: Ex Reg. Sum. Adm. Sacr. que Lib. Typ. apud D. Mariam de Rivera, in pub. via de Empedradillo
notes: This is a announcement for the thesis defense of Juan Francisco de Saavedra for August 3, 1738.

Source_publisher: Ex Reg. Sum. Adm. Sacr. que Lib. Typ. apud D. Mariam de Rivera, in pub. via de Empedradillo

Image_title: V. P. Fr. Petrus a S. Iosepho de Betanucr ob eximiam Nativitatis Domini devotionem, insignemque Charitatem erga pauperes, Ordinem Hospitalarium Bethleemitarum in Indijs Occidentalibus fundavit, ...
Description: Mary and Joseph place the baby Jesus in a manger. Includes a nativity scene with angels, shepherds, creche, lamb or sheep, and ox or cattle. Also includes a kneeling man who may represent Pedro de San José Bethencourt (Pedro de Betancourt).
Source_creator: José de la Madre de Dios
Source_Title: Storia della vita, virtu, doni, e grazie del venerabile servo di Dio p.f. Pietro di S. Giuseppe Betancur, fondatore dell'Ordine betlemitico nelle Indie Occidentali ...
Source_publisher: per Antonio de' Rossi, vicino alla Rotonda
notes: Pedro de Betancourt founded the hospitaler Bethlehemites or Belemites and worked for the poor in Guatemala. He is credited with introducing the custom of nacimiento in Guatemala, a custom of recreating the nativity scene with Mary, Joseph, the Christ child, and angels.The painter may be Fra Bartolomé de San Antonio (1708-1782) who was a member of the Trinitarios descalzos; he studied painting in Rome for six years and in 1740 returned to his native Spain.
References: Bryan, M. Bryan's dictionary of painters and engravers, vol. 2, p. 443

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Two angels point to a winged flaming heart. They are suspended over a globe with America, Guatemala and Mexico on it. Also includes a rising sun.
Source_creator: José de la Madre de Dios
Source_Title: Storia della vita, virtu, doni, e grazie del venerabile servo di Dio p.f. Pietro di S. Giuseppe Betancur, fondatore dell'Ordine betlemitico nelle Indie Occidentali ...
Source_publisher: per Antonio de' Rossi, vicino alla Rotonda
notes: The painter may be Fra Bartolomé de San Antonio (1708-1782) who was a member of the Trinitarios descalzos; he studied painting in Rome for six years and in 1740 returned to his native Spain. The engraver may be Gennaro Gutierrez, an Italian engraver, who flourished about the year 1760.
References: Bryan, M. Bryan's dictionary of painters and engravers, vol. 2, p. 443; Bryan, M. Bryan's dictionary of painters and engravers, vol. 1, p. 612
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Admiral Hosier's Ghost.
Description: Ship surrounded by ghosts in shrouds. Built environment includes fortification in harbor.
notes: "Admiral Hosier's Ghost" was a ballad written in 1740 by Richard Glover in an effort to rouse national feelings following Admiral Vernon's successful capture of Portobelo [in present-day Panama] in 1740 with only six ships and the loss of seven lives. Admiral Hosier's effort to blockade the port in 1726 led to his death and the death of many of his men by yellow fever.

Image_title: A Perspective View of ye Harbour, castles, & town of Porto Bello; with ye Disposition of ye Ships under ye Command of Vice Admiral Vernon ...
Image_publisher: Printed for Tho: Bowles in St. Paul's Church Yard & Iohn Bowles at the Black Horse in Cornhill
Description: View of the siege of Portobelo [in present-day Panama] by Admiral Edward Vernon. Built environment includes fortifications, castle, dwellings, churches, ships with British flags, and boats. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key below image.
notes: Vernon's siege of Portobelo was accomplished with only six ships and the loss of seven lives. Vernon's victory was greatly celebrated at the time; "God Save the King," as it is known today, was first sung at a dinner given in honor of Admiral Vernon's successful siege of Portobelo. "An Account of Admiral Vernon's taking Porto Bello," accompanies the image.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The taking of Porto Bello by Vice Admiral Vernon on the 22d. of Novr. 1739 with Six Men of War only.
Image_publisher: Published by F. West, 83, Fleet St.
Description: View of the siege of Porto Bello [in present-day Panama] by Admiral Edward Vernon. Built environment includes fortifications, castle, dwellings, churches, ships with British flags, and boats. Soldiers scale the walls of the fort.
notes: Vernon's siege of Porto Bello was accomplished with only six ships and the loss of seven lives. Vernon's victory was greatly celebrated at the time; "God Save the King," as it is known today, was first sung at a dinner given in honor of Admiral Vernon's successful siege of Porto Bello. This print was supposedly made from a painting by Peter Monamy shown at Vauxhall Gardens. Location of original painting is not known.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Catafalque]
Description: Catafalque erected for the funeral service of Diego Morcillo Rubio de Auñon in the chapel of the Immaculate Conception in the cathedral of Lima. Includes candlesticks, archbishop's miters, altar, bed, processional cross, crozier, footstool and scale.
Source_Title: Magnifica parentacion [sic], y funebre pompa, en la ocasion de trasladarse de la sepultura de los Sres. arzobispos ... ál sepulcro ... que se erigió en la Capilla ... de esta Sta. Iglesia Metropolitana de Lima, èl cuerpo de ... Dr. maestro D. Fr. Diego Morcillo Rubio de Auñon
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Gutierrez de Zeballos
notes: Auñon was a Spanish bishop in Peru and twice viceroy of the colony from Aug. 1716 to Oct. 1716 and Jan. 1720 to May 1724.This work is bound as the fourth item of ten in volume 2 of a 13-volume set entitled, Noticias del Peru.

Image_title: Laurentius eques Boturini Benaduci Dominus de Turre et Hono.
Description: Portrait of Lorenzo Boturini Benaducci holding an Aztec calendar and pointing to the Virgin of Guadalupe. Decorative element includes coat of arms.
Source_Title: Idea de una nueva historia general de la America Septentrionale
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de Juan de Zuñiga
notes: Boturini Benaducci, an Italian, went to Mexico to trace the historical origins of the veneration of Our Lady of Guadalupe. During the seven years he spent studying Aztec language, religion, and culture, he assembled the first important collection on Aztec civilization. Considered potentially dangerous by the church, the collection was confiscated and dispersed.
References_exhibitions: Hough, S.J. Italians and the creation of America, 65
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1859 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: Nueva y correcta carta del Mar Pacifico ó del sur ... el año de 1744.
Description: Map of the west and northwest coast of South America. Cartographic elements include degrees of longitude and latitude, compass rose, names of rivers and islands, location of equator and Tropic of Capricorn, sea shoals or shallows. Cartouche includes ship,
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Segunda parte, Tomo quarto.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: An account of the expedition sent by the French Académie Royale des Sciences in 1735 to measure a degree of the meridian at the equator. The participants included the Frenchmen, La Condamine, Godin, and Bouguer, and the Spaniards, Ulloa and Juan y Santaci
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [top] Cape Blanco bearing S.W. distant five leagues. [bottom] Cape Blanco on the coast of Patagonia: Bearing S b W 1/2 W distant 4 leagues.
Description: View of Cabo Blanco in Patagonia. Includes ships and schooner. A location on the cape is lettered for identification on previous page.
