Source_Title: A voyage round the world, in the years MDCCXL, I, II, III, IV. By George Anson ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the Author; By John and Paul Knapton, in Ludgate-Street
notes: George Anson, first baron Anson, a commodore in the British Royal Navy, set sail on a circumnavigation in 1740. Anson's orders were to raid Spanish possessions along the South American coast and to disrupt their trade.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Rulers of the Incas and Spain]
Creator2_role: sculpr. Regius invt. excudit, et Iconibus incidit.
Description: In front of a Baroque building, angels support oval medallions on which are portraits of Inca rulers from Manco-Capac to Atahualpa and Spanish rulers from Philip III to Ferdinand VI. In the center next to a flame, a female figure holds a cross, mirror (?)
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Segunda parte, Tomo quarto.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: The work by Garcilaso de la Vega, Resumen historico del origen, y sucession de los Incas, y demas soberanos del Perù ... , appears at the end of vol. 4 and is prefaced by this plate. Text discusses each ruler in turn.

Image_title: Une lionne marine. Un lion marin.
Description: Male and female elephant seals. Includes mollusks or shells.
Source_Title: [Voyage round the world. French] Voyage autour du monde, fait dans les années MDCCXL, I, II, III, IV. Par Georges Anson
Source_publisher: Chez Arkstée & Merkus
notes: Text describes the seals of Juan Fernandez Island. The engraver may be the Dutch engraver Franz van Bakker, fl. 1736-1765.

Image_title: Mapa y Tabla Geografica de Leguas comunes, que ai de unos à otros Lugares, y Ciudades principales de la America septentrional
Description: Map of New Spain and North America with a distance chart between principal cities of New Spain, the latitude and longitude of the major cities of New Spain, and zodiac sign for each city. Map of California, Mexico, Guatemala and North America from Virginia south to Florida is shown as an inset. At left, native American wearing a feathered headdress holds a staff and stands on a pot from which spill coins or wealth. At right an eagle with a snake in its talons sits on a cactus under the royal coat of arms of the viceroy of New Spain [?]. In the background is an idealized view of the area between Mexico City and Veracruz.
notes: This map is a presentation piece, dedicated to the Viceroy of New Spain, Agustín de Ahumada y Villalón (1755-58). The historical symbol of Mexico is the eagle and serpent on a cactus. The main purpose of this piece was to acquaint the new Viceroy with the extent of his empire and its relationship with the rest of North America.
References: Dios Fernandez de Sousa, J. de Carta consolatoria, p. 64
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Our Lady of Guadalupe]
Image_publisher: en la Imprenta de la Bibliotheca Mexicana
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe standing on a crescent moon with roses, starry cloak, and angel.
Source_Title: Alabado en lengua mexicana
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la Bibliotheca Mexicana.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, filled with out-of-season roses to the bishop.

Image_title: Lignum febrium
Description: Fever tree in the shape of a stylized cinchona plant.
Source_Title: Therapeutice specialis ad febres periodicas perniciosas, cui subnectuntur responsiones jatro-apologeticae ad clarissimum Ramazzinum ...
Source_publisher: In officina Fleischeriana
notes: Francesco Torti, an Italian physician, made a significant contribution to the development of anti-malarial therapies by establishing that the Peruvian bark was only effective against a particular group of diseases. His "Tree of Fevers" was a highly stylized representation of the cinchona plant, used to map out hierarchical distinctions between different pathological entities. This new way of categorizing and organizing information about disease would have a tremendous impact in the development of medical nosology (the classification of diseases). The notion that individual illnesses could be cured using specific remedies was a radical challenge to the humoral explanations that dominated the medical literature of the time. Cf. 70-582-1.
References_exhibitions: http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/John_Carter_Brown_Library/materia%20medica/index1.html (Feb. 2009)

Image_title: Verdadera Efigie del Siervo de Dios F. Franco. Camacho, que fallegio en este Con[vent]o de Sr. Sn. Diego de Lima ...
Description: Portrait of Francisco Camacho holding an image of St. Francis who holds a crucifix. He stands in front of a hospital room on the grounds of a convent. Includes beds, church, tiled floor, staff, and rosary.
Source_Title: Oracion funebre, que en las exequias del venerable siervo de Dios Fr. Francisco Camacho del Orden Hospitalario del patriarcha San Juan de Dios ...
Source_publisher: En la Calle del Tigre
notes: Camacho belonged to the Hospitaller Order of Saint John of God in Lima, Peru, and particularly venerated the image of the Virgin Mary.

Image_title: [left] El maiz. lamitad menor de loq[?] es segun su magno. natural. [right] Caña del maiz con su flor.
Description: [left] An ear of corn or maize with its silk or female flower. [right] Top of a cornstalk with its male flower or tassel.
Source_Title: [Spectacle de la nature. Spanish] Espectaculo de la naturaleza, o conversaciones acerca de las particularidades de la historia natural, ...
Source_publisher: En la Oficina de Joachin Ibarra, calle de las Urosas.
notes: Corn or maize, Zea mays, was domesticated in Central America.John Carter Library copy imperfect: all but vols. 4, 6-7 wanting. No date of imprint in vol. 4.
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 1961. Former collections: Diego Montero; Convento de S. Pedro de Alcantara, Guanajuato.

Image_title: Mapa de la California su Golfo, y Provincias fronteras en el Continente de Nueva España.
Description: Map of the Baja Peninsula of California and of part of Mexico surrounded by vignettes including gannets or birds, bighorn sheep, coyote, beaver, four scenes of native Americans hunting, fishing, curing sickness, and showing religious ceremonies. Also includes scenes of Spanish martyrdom, Lorenzo Carranco and Nicolas Tamaral, at the hands of native Americans. Cartographic elements include location of rivers and settlements and degrees of latitude and longitude. Decorative elements include the Jesuit symbol, feathered headdress and fans, bows, arrows, and fishing net.
Source_Title: Noticia de la California, y desu conquista temporal, y espiritual hasta el tiempo presente .. Tomo primero
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de la Viuda de Manuel Fernandez, y del Supremo Consejo de la Inquisicion
notes: Venegas, a prominent Mexican Jesuit, finished the manuscript of this book in 1739. It was extensively revised by Andrés Marcos Burriel. Considered the first history of California, it is notable for publishing the explorations of Father Consag which established that California was not an island and for publishing Torquemada' account of the Vizcaino expedition.Carranco and Tamaral were martyred at the beginning of Pericú revolt in 1734.
References: Wagner, H.R. Cartography of the Northwest coast of America, 587, vol. 1, p. 154-155; http://www.dsloan.com/Auctions/A12/78WebA12.htm (June 2004)
SubjectArea3: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Rto. del Illmo. Sr. Dr. Dn. Alfonzo de Cuebas Davalos ...
Image_publisher: Heirs of the Widow of Joseph Bernardo de Hogal
Description: Portrait of Alonso de Cuevas y Dávalos, archbishop of Mexico. Included in the portrait are four miters representing his four bishoprics. Also includes pectoral cross, coat of arms with galero and six fiocchi.
Source_Title: Resguardo contra el olvido, en el breve compendio de la vida admirable, y virtudes heroycas del Illmo. Sr. Dr. D. Alonso de Cuevas Davalos ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de los Herederos de la Viuda de D. Joseph Bernardo de Hogal.
notes: Juan Alonso de Cuevas Dávalos was first elected bishop of Oaxaca in 1657. Eventually he became archbishop of Mexico from 1664 to 1665.Moreno first worked at the Royal Mint in Mexico, but left for the more lucrative profession of private printing and publishing.
References: Donahue-Wallace, K. "Printmakers in Eighteenth-Century Mexico City," http://www.analesiie.unam.mx/pdf/78_221-234.pdf (Sept. 2009), p. 231
Provenance_Donor: Originally owned by the Convento de San Antonio de la Puebla, Mexico.

Image_title: Vo. Rto. de la R. M. Maria Anna Agueda de S. Igna[ci]o ... de la Puebla de los Angeles ...
Description: Portrait of Maria Anna Agueda de San Ignacio holding a book and quill or pen. Also includes rosary.
Source_Title: Vida de la V. M. R. M. Maria Anna Agueda de S. Ignacio, primera priora del religiosissimo Convento de Dominicas Recoletas de Santa Rosa de la Puebla de los Angeles ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la Bibliotheca Mexicana.
notes: Sor Maria Anna (16951756), a Dominican nun born the year Sor Juana de la Cruz died, was an important and (during her lifetime) popular colonial writer and theologian in Mexico. Her writings include constitutions for her convent, spiritual guidebooks for nuns, and four mystical theological treatises. Not much is known about the engraver of this portrait except that on the day the Inquisition arrived at his shop to inquire about printing protocols, he and his wife were out, involved in a duel.
References: Eich, J. The Other Mexican Muse; Donahue-Wallace, K. "Printmakers in Eighteenth-Century Mexico City," http://www.analesiie.unam.mx/pdf/78_221-234.pdf (Sept. 2009)
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 1941. Bookplate of Luis González Obregón.
SubjectHeadings1: Agueda de San Ignacio, Maria Anna, 1695-1756--Portraits

Image_title: [Jesuits in South America] Idololatria et feritas Deo et regi domitae
Description: Allegorical figures surround a map of the western hemisphere. Native Americans kneel at bottom with a figure holding aloft the Jesuit trigram [IHS] and an angel holding a plaque with the word "Guaira [Guarani]" on it. Other angels hold plaques with other geographical names on them, Chile, Paraguay, Parana Uruguay, Rio de la Plata, and Tucuman. Angels playing trumpets surround a portrait of Ignatius Loyola, founder of the Society of Jesus [Jesuit] order. Also includes royal coat of arms of Spain, feathered headdresses and garments, and a dragon [?].
Source_Title: Decades virorum illustrium Paraquariae Societas Jesu ex historia ejusdem provincae & aliunde depromptae & aliunde depromptae ... Pars prima
Source_publisher: typis academicis Societatis Jesu
notes: In 1608, the Jesuits were granted the right to establish missions or "reducciones" in South America. The members of the "reducciones" owned and worked land in common.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Pizarro entertain'd on Shore by a Peruvian lady.
Description: Pizarro and his men sit at a table set in an arbor. A native American woman in a throne-like chair is host. Includes plates of food and native Americans blowing horns.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. III.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Looking for gold, Pizarro and his men sailed along the west coast of South America until they came to Payta which they named Santa Cruz. There they landed and were entertained in some splendor by a native American woman.Volume three contains an account of the conquest of Peru and the settlement of Brazil by the Portuguese.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Pizarro Assassinated.
Description: Spanish soldiers in a room fight one another with swords. In the foreground one runs his sword into the chest of another.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. III.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Pizarro was killed by Diego Almagro whose father, also named Diego, had been ordered killed by Pizarro in a dispute over jurisdiction of Peruvian territory.Volume three contains an account of the conquest of Peru and the settlement of Brazil by the Portuguese.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: The Dutch defeat a Party of Spaniards.
Description: Men on horseback fight foot soldiers with guns or muskets in front of a city with a church. Includes swords, horses, drum, and standard or flag.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. III.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: In 1643 the Dutch decided to harrass the Spanish by looking for gold and making settlements in Chile. A fleet under the command of Hendrick Brouwer sailed around Cape Horn and explored the coast. When they landed at Carelmappa they engaged and defeated a party of about ninety Spaniards. The Dutch took possession of the town, but set fire to it when they left. Brouwer died around this time.Volume three contains an account of the conquest of Peru and the settlement of Brazil by the Portuguese.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Captn. Drake Seizes the Spanish Treasures near Rio Francisco.
Description: Soldiers in armor open chests full of silver and gold and load them into a wagon. Includes soldiers fleeing, mules, and distant city or town.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. IV.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Near the town of Nombre de Dios in present-day Panama, a major port for the Spanish treasure fleet, Sir Francis Drake and the French cartographer and privateer Guillaume Le Testu combined forces to ambush a Spanish mule convoy loaded with precious metals in 1573. The items were being transported to the port to be taken to Spain on the silver fleet.Volume four contains an account of the British discoveries in America.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: The English coming to their Boat find it in flames, while the Spaniards at a distance mock at their distress.
Description: A group of European men stand on a shore bewailing the loss of their boats that are on fire. Across the inlet, men look on and gesture to mock their distress.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: In 1683 while engaging in piracy, William Dampier's ships sailed north from the Juan Fernandez Islands to Cape Blanco in Mexico and landed to bury Captain John Cook (or Cooke). While they were ashore they were greeted by men described as Spanish Indians who told them of cattle that could be taken at will. One of the native Americans escorted the English to the place, and they remained there over night, intending to slaughter the cattle the next morning. In the morning, they were ambushed by a group of Spaniards and discovered that the Spanish had set fire to their boats so that escape was impossible. Many hours later, the English were rescued from a rock where they had taken refuge amidst a rising tide.Volume six contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to William Dampier.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: The English unload the Spanish Mules.
Description: Men unload mules in front of a dwelling. Includes guns or muskets, swords, vessels, and feed bags.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: In 1683 while engaging in piracy in South and Central America, William Dampier arrived at a village near Acapulco, Mexico, where a mulatto woman told his crew of a mule train loaded with flour and other goods that Dampier needed. The woman guided them to a farm house where the mules were found loaded with flour, cheese, chocolate, and earthenware.Volume six contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to William Dampier.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: A View of the Commodores Tent in the Island of Juan Fernandes.
Description: A European man holding a walking stick walks toward three tents set in a clearing in the woods.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Commodore George Anson was sent to attack Spanish possessions in South America as part of the War of Jenkins' Ear. The mission began with six ships and almost 1000 men, but by the time Anson reached the island of Juan Fernández in June, 1741, bad weather and scurvy had reduced the ships to three and the crews to about 335. The men sick with scurvy were disembarked and allowed to rest and recover in tents.Volume seven contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to Commodore George Anson's voyage between 1740 and 1744.Image placed horizontally on page.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: The burning the Town of Payta.
Description: View of ships with smoke rising from a burning town in the distance. Includes boats and sunken boats and ships.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Harrassing the Spanish while sailing up the west coast of South America, Anson set fire to the Peruvian port town of Payta or Paita.Commodore George Anson was sent to attack Spanish possessions in South America as part of the War of Jenkins' Ear. The mission began with six ships and almost 1000 men, but by the time Anson reached the island of Juan Fernández in June 1741, bad weather and scurvy had reduced the ships to three and the crews to about 335.Volume seven contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to Commodore George Anson's voyage between 1740 and 1744.Image placed horizontally on page.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Peregrino de sta Sagrada Vid Medita a cada passo, y con ferbor Logue en suspassos Jesus, y Maria Sigicron peregrinos por tu amor.
Description: Maria de Jesus de Agreda and Joachin de Ostina kneel before a cross with a sword and INRI symbol.
Source_Title: Peregrinacion christiana por el camino real de la celeste Jerusalen ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de la Bibliotheca mexicana, enfrente de San Augustin
notes: Sor Maria de Jesus de Agreda wrote the work, The city of God, a history of the Virgin Mary. She also reported that she had a memory of over five hundred spiritual visits to the various tribes of the American southwest during which time she converted the whole Indian population to Christianity without physically leaving Spain. INRI is an acronym of the Latin inscription which translates to English as "Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews."Not much is known about the engraver of this portrait except that on the day the Inquisition arrived at his shop to inquire about printing protocols, he and his wife were out, involved in a duel.
References: Eich, J. The Other Mexican Muse; Donahue-Wallace, K. "Printmakers in Eighteenth-Century Mexico City," http://www.analesiie.unam.mx/pdf/78_221-234.pdf (Sept. 2009)
SubjectHeadings1: María de Jesús, de Agreda, sor, 1602-1665

Image_title: [top] Prospect af øen Juan Fernandes naar man Kommer fra den Ostnordostlige side [bottom] Prospect af Cumberlands bayen
Description: [top] View of the island of Juan Fernandes or present-day Isla Róbinson Crusoe, Chile. Includes ship. Various landmarks are identified with letters on image. [bottom] View of Cumberland Bay with many ships.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Femtende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Isla Róbinson Crusoe, formerly known as Más a Tierra, is part of the Juan Fernandez Islands, Chile. Engraver may be Jean Haas. The story of Robinson Crusoe was based on the story of Alexander Selkirk who went to sea in 1704 with William Dampier and was put ashore on this island off of the coast of Chile where he survived until he was rescued in 1709 by Woodes Rogers.

Image_title: Alex[ande]r. Selkirk, found in the Isle of Juan Fernandez.
Description: A group of European men approach a hut and a man dressed in skins who is slaughtering a goat.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text states that Alexander Selkirk was left on Juan Fernández Island by Captain Stradling and remained there for four years and four months. In February 1709, Woodes Rogers rescued Selkirk.Woodes Rogers was an English privateer who during the War of the Spanish Succession harassed Spanish possessions in order to help protect English shipping. In the ships Duke and Duchess, he led a circumnavigation of the globe between 1708 and 1711. His pilot on this trip was William Dampier. The voyage was instrumental in the foundation of the South Sea Company. In 1717 Rogers was appointed first royal governor of the Bahamas after which time he helped to suppress piracy.Volume six contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to Woodes Rogers' voyage beginning in 1708.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Captn. Rogers attacked by a Seal.
Description: On a shore, a European man thrusts a spear into the chest of a seal.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text states that when Rogers' ships reached the Galapagos Islands off Ecuador, Captain Rogers was attacked by a seal that rushed out of the water toward him.Woodes Rogers was an English privateer who during the War of the Spanish Succession harassed Spanish possessions in order to help protect English shipping. In the ships Duke and Duchess, he led a circumnavigation of the globe between 1708 and 1711. His pilot on this trip was William Dampier. In February of 1709, he picked up Alexander Selkirk from Juan Fernández Island where he had been marooned for five years. The voyage was instrumental in the foundation of the South Sea Company. In 1717 Rogers was appointed first royal governor of the Bahamas after which time he helped to suppress piracy.Volume six contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to Woodes Rogers' voyage beginning in 1708.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: The Town of Guaiaquil plundered by Capt. Rogers.
Description: A group of men fires guns or muskets at another group of men who fire cannons at the first group. Includes churches, flag, horses, and bundles.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Rogers' party attacked Guayaquil, Ecuador, in April 1709. They first attempted to take the town by means of threats and bargaining, but used force when the leaders of the town proved to be bargaining treacherously. The town was plundered of its valuables which were then shared out as booty to the crews. Woodes Rogers was an English privateer who during the War of the Spanish Succession harassed Spanish possessions in order to help protect English shipping. In the ships Duke and Duchess, he led a circumnavigation of the globe between 1708 and 1711. His pilot on this trip was William Dampier. In February of 1709, he picked up Alexander Selkirk from Juan Fernández Island where he had been marooned for five years. The voyage was instrumental in the foundation of the South Sea Company. In 1717 Rogers was appointed first royal governor of the Bahamas after which time he helped to suppress piracy.Volume six contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to Woodes Rogers' voyage beginning in 1708.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Francis Pizarro with Six Spaniards attacked by 400 Indians under the Command of Zemaco.
Description: Scene of warfare in which seven Spanish soldiers, including Franciso Pizarro, fire guns or muskets at a large group of native Americans who shoot arrows at the Spaniards. The native Americans are led by their chief or cacique Zemaco.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. III.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text explains that Balboa sent Pizarro with six men from Darien to explore whether there was gold in the province of Coyba [perhaps Coiba on the west coast of present-day Panama] as had been reported. Pizarro killed about one hundred of the native Americans.Volume three contains an account of the conquest of Peru and the settlement of Brazil by the Portuguese.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: The Cacique Quarequa & his Indians fall upon Nunez & his Spaniards, but are defeated & great numbers torn to pieces by Dogs.
Description: Scene of warfare in which Spanish soldiers carrying swords and shields chase a large group of fleeing native Americans. A native American who has fallen is attacked by dogs. Includes bows and arrows and dwellings.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. III.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text explains that in this engagement the Spanish killed the cacique Quarequa and about six hundred other native Americans. While plundering the town for its gold, they discovered men wearing jewels like women. Concluding that they were sodomites, the Spanish set their dogs on them to kill them.Volume three contains an account of the conquest of Peru and the settlement of Brazil by the Portuguese.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Atabaliba Strangled.
Description: A native American wearing a feathered headdress is tied to a tree and strangled or garroted by two others. Spanish soldiers and a Catholic priest observe. Built environment includes dwellings and palisade.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. III.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: The Spaniards, headed by Pizarro, used the imprisoned Atabaliba's [Atabalipa's or Atahualpa's] order to execute his brother Huascar as an excuse to condemn him to death. The sentence was commuted from burning at the stake to death by garrote when Atabaliba consented to be baptized.Volume three contains an account of the conquest of Peru and the settlement of Brazil by the Portuguese.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Peru--Kings and rulers

Image_title: A Sea Lion and Lioness.
Description: Sea lion and sea lioness on a shore.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: These animals may also be elephant seals, from the genus Mirounga. Text notes the "large trunk or snout that hangs down five or six inches below the end of the upper jaw" on the males. While on Juan Fernández Island, the sailors in Anson's fleet ate goats and sea lions.Commodore George Anson was sent to attack Spanish possessions in South America as part of the War of Jenkins' Ear. The mission began with six ships and almost 1000 men, but by the time Anson reached the island of Juan Fernández in June 1741, bad weather and scurvy had reduced the ships to three and the crews to about 335. The men sick with scurvy were disembarked and allowed to rest and recover in tents.Volume seven contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to Commodore George Anson's voyage between 1740 and 1744.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Söe Lövinde Söe=Löve [Sea Lions]
Description: Sea lion and sea lioness on a shore.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Femtende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: These animals may also be elephant seals, from the genus Mirounga. Text notes the "large trunk or snout that hangs down five or six inches below the end of the upper jaw" on the males. While on Juan Fernández Island, the sailors in Anson's fleet ate goats and sea lions. Commodore George Anson was sent to attack Spanish possessions in South America as part of the War of Jenkins' Ear. The mission began with six ships and almost 1000 men, but by the time Anson reached the island of Juan Fernández in June 1741, bad weather and scurvy had reduced the ships to three and the crews to about 335. The men sick with scurvy were disembarked and allowed to rest and recover in tents. Image probably derived from Richard Walker, A voyage, London 1748 (see 32896-020).

Image_title: Prospect af den Plads paa Øen Iuan Fernandes huor Chesen for Esquadren havde sit Telt.
Description: View of the encampment of Commodore George Anson on Juan Fernandez Island. Includes tents, dog, and goat.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Femtende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Isla Róbinson Crusoe, formerly known as Más a Tierra, is part of the Juan Fernandez Islands, Chile. Engraver may be Jean Haas. The story of Robinson Crusoe was based on the story of Alexander Selkirk who went to sea in 1704 with William Dampier and was put ashore on this island off of the coast of Chile where he survived until he was rescued in 1709 by Woodes Rogers.

Image_title: Planta y descripcion de la ymperial ciudad de Mexico en la America
Image_publisher: Se hallera en la Libreria de Dn. Christoval de Zuñiga y Ontiveros
Description: Bird's-eye view of Mexico City. Built environment includes churches and dwellings. Also includes fields outside of the city walls. Items in image are lettered in a key above and below. Embellishments in woodcut are added to engraving. At top a scene of man presenting a cloak with the image of Our Lady of Guadalupe on it to a bishop. At bottom the royal coat of arms of Mexico with eagle holding a snake perched on a cactus.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it filled with out-of-season roses.
References: Atlas historico de la ciudad de Mexico, I: 322
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: A View of Masa Fuero Island.
Description: View of a wooded island with ship and boat in the foreground.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. VI.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Masa Fuero is now known as Alejandro Selkirk Island or Isla Más Afuera. It is part of the Juan Fernández archipelago belonging to Chile. Anson thought the presence of fresh water and goats there made it a good resting point.Commodore George Anson was sent to attack Spanish possessions in South America as part of the War of Jenkins' Ear. The mission began with six ships and almost 1000 men, but by the time Anson reached the island of Juan Fernández in June 1741, bad weather and scurvy had reduced the ships to three and the crews to about 335. The men sick with scurvy were disembarked and allowed to rest and recover in tents.Volume seven contains an account of voyages around the world. This section relates to Commodore George Anson's voyage between 1740 and 1744.Image placed horizontally on page.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Le Paraguay Tiré de la Carte de l'Amérique Mérionale de Mr. D'Anville
Description: Map of Paraguay and the watershed of the Rio de la Plata, showing present-day Uruguay, Bolivia, Argentina, and Chile. Cartographic elements include degrees of latitude and longitude, names of cities and tributaries, topographical detail, scales, and sea banks. The source of the Rio de la Plata is shown as Lake Xarayes.
Source_Title: [Cristianesimo felice nelle missioni de' padri della Compagnia di Gesù nel Paraguai. English] A relation of the missions of Paraguay
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Marmaduke in Long-Acre
notes: This map was removed from Muratori, A relation of the missions of Paraguay, and is held separately.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: A Man and Woman of the Island of Pasch.
Description: Native American man draped in cloth, carrying a staff, and wearing a broad-brimmed hat stands next to a seated native American woman wearing a European-style dress and a hat.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... Vol. IX.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: These native Americans were encountered by Roggeveen on Easter Island in 1722.Volume nine contains accounts of voyages to the East Indies and the southern Atlantic. This section relates to Jacob Roggeveen's voyage of 1721-1722 from Texel in the Netherlands to Batavia through the Le Maire Strait.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: The Caciques of Quiabislan & Zempoallo appear before Cortes carried on Mens Shoulders.
Description: Two native American caciques or chiefs sitting in chairs with parasols over their heads are carried toward Hernán Cortés. Groups of native American and Spanish soldiers surround their leaders. Includes buildings, feathered clothing and headdresses, spears, and shield.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Cortés was meeting with the caciques of Quiabislan and Zempoallo (Zempoala, or now Cempoala, near present-day Veracruz) in order to gain their support in the defeat of Moctezuma [Montezuma].Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernando Cortes.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: V. R. del Milagrosa Img. de Na. Seña. del Pueblito ...
Description: Monk or priest holds three balls. Includes a statue of Our Lady of Pueblito in a niche. Also includes two angels, vases of flowers, and the Christ Child.
Source_Title: Historico, y sagrado novenario la milagrosa imagen de nuestra Señora del Pueblito, dela santa provincia de religiosos observantes de San Pedro, y San Pablo de Michoacan
Source_publisher: en la Imprenta de la Bibliotheca Mexicana, junto á las Reverendas Madres Capuchinas
notes: In 1632, the Franciscan Fray Nicholas de Zamora placed a statue of Our Lady of Pueblito near a native place of worship in Querétaro, Mexico. The statue was said to miraculously convert native Americans to Christianity. The author was a captain in the Infantry Regiment of New Spain, and a member of the Florentine Academy and the Academy of Volterra. He was also the Count of Colombini.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: The meeting between Cortes & the Principal Cacique and Inhabitants of Cozumel.
Description: At a shore, a native American cacique or chief bows toward Hernán Cortés. Both leaders have groups of soldiers holding spears behind them. Includes native American spreading fruits from a basket, feathered headdresses, clothing, and cape, and a horse.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernán Cortés.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of Mexico--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: The Engagement between the Spaniards & people of Tabasco & their manner of fortifying themselves.
Description: Hernán Cortés leads his men through a swamp to attack the fortified native American settlement of Tabasco. Includes palisaded town, dwellings, feathered headdresses and clothing, swords, and spears.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernán Cortés.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Cortes receives Donna Marina w[i]th. other female Slaves as a present from the Cacique of Tabasco.
Description: A group of native American women followed by native Americans carrying burdens is presented to Hernán Cortés and his men. Includes feathered clothing and headdress, necklaces, earrings, leg ornaments, spears, shields, horses, dead animal and basket of food.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text explains that in order to make amends for having made war on the Spanish, the cacique or chief of Tabasco presented twenty women skilled in the making of bread from Indian corn and in other kinds of cooking to Cortés. The most beautiful of the women was baptised Marina and became Cortes' mistress.Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernán Cortés.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Cortes meets Motezuma at Mexico.
Description: Hernán Cortés and Moctezuma [Montezuma], each with his followers, greet one another in front of a city. Moctezuma has descended from a litter with a chair and canopy. Includes feathered headdresses and clothing, spears, and horses.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernán Cortés.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.
SubjectHeadings2: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Cortes orders Motezuma to be put in Irons.
Description: Hernán Cortés and his soldiers stand next to the seated Moctezuma [Montezuma] in a room with barred windows. Moctezuma's followers wring their hands in distress. Includes feathered headdresses and clothing, spears, and pikes.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernán Cortés.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.
SubjectHeadings2: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Motezuma slain by a Stone flung at him by the Mexicans as he stood upon the Wall of the Spanish Quarters.
Description: A native American [Moctezuma or Montezuma?] lies on the ground holding an arrow. Other native Americans shoot arrows and throw stones at Spanish soldiers and native Americans at the top of a fortification. Includes feathered headdresses and clothing, bows and arrows, shields, and spears.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: While the Spaniards held Moctezuma [Montezuma] prisoner, the other Mexicans chose another leader and determined to drive the Spanish out of Mexico. Cortés asked Moctezuma to speak to the Mexican nobles leading the attack, but as he was doing so, the Mexicans threw stones at him. One stone hit him on the temple and proved mortal.Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernán Cortés.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of Mexico--Kings and rulers--Death and burial
SubjectHeadings2: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: The Royal Standard of Mexico seiz'd, which ocasions the entire overthrow of the Indians.
Description: Native Americans and Spanish soldiers fight a battle. A Spaniard in armor takes a standard away from a native American. Includes dead native Americans, horses, litter [?] with canopy, swords, shields, and feathered headdresses and clothing.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: As Cortés retreated toward Tlaxcala after Moctezuma's [Montezuma's] death in Mexico City, he had to do battle with various native American groups, but he defeated them all. Here native Americans flee when they realize that their standard has been taken by the Spanish.Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernán Cortés.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: The Emperor Guatimozin, and the Empress seized on board a Piragua by Sandoval.
Description: Two Spanish soldiers who have boarded Guatimozin's boat grab him. Includes Spanish ship with soldiers aboard, other boats, and a city.
Source_Title: The world displayed; or, A curious collection of voyages and travels, selected from the writers of all nations. ... vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Newbery, at the Bible and Sun, in St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Cuauhtémoc [or Guatimozin] became emperor in 1520 on the death of Montezuma's [Moctezuma's] successor, Cuitláhuac. Hernán Cortés, with his Indian allies, was then marching on Tenochtitlán or Mexico City. Cuauhtémoc's forces were forced to retreat in 1521; but he defended his capital in a four-month siege, finally losing to the Spanish. Cuauhtémoc was later tortured to reveal the location of hidden Aztec wealth.Volume two contains an account of the conquest of Mexico by Hernán Cortés.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection William Holbech; acquired as a gift from the estate of Frederick Lippitt.

Image_title: Verdro. retto. de la sacratissima Portentosa Imagen de Nra. Sra. de los Lagos ...
Description: Image of the Virgin of San Juan of the Lakes. Includes crescent moon, crown, and halo. Also includes two angels holding lit candles, dove or Holy Spirit, flowers [lilies], and monogram.
Source_Title: Novena en honra de la milagrosissima imagen de Maria Santissima Nuestra Señora de S. Juan
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta del Superior Gobierno de los Herederos de Doña Maria de Rivera, en la calle de S. Bernardo
notes: The town of San Juan de los Lagos is located in the eastern part of the state of Jalisco in west central Mexico. In 1542, the Spanish priest, Father Miguel de Bologna, brought an image of the Virgin of the Immaculate Conception to the village. In 1632, a daughter of Indian parents fell gravely ill but was saved by praying to the Virgin. Her statue was venerated from that time.Not much is known about the engraver of this portrait except that on the day the Inquisition arrived at his shop to inquire about printing protocols, he and his wife were out, involved in a duel.
References: Donahue-Wallace, K. "Printmakers in Eighteenth-Century Mexico City," http://www.analesiie.unam.mx/pdf/78_221-234.pdf (Sept. 2009)
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico
SubjectHeadings2: Santuario de Nuestra Señora de San Juan (Guadalajara, Mexico)

Image_title: 1 Amsaleira; 2 Amsale; 3 Ananseira ell Ananas; 4 Anoneira; 5 Anona
Description: Three kinds of fruit: 1) and 2) the amsaleira, 3) the pineapple plant with its fruit, 4) and 5) the Anoneira shown whole with its leaves and cut open.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Anoneira's scientific name is Annona cherimola Mill. It was originally found in Colombia, Bolivia, and Ecuador. It is also known as cherimoya. Pineapple's scientific name is Ananas comosus; it is probably native to Brazil or Paraguay. ;Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. ;Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely.

Image_title: 1 Asafreira og dets Blomster.; 2 Ateira; 3 Ata; 4 Beteleira huis Blade er Betel.
Description: Three kinds of plants: 1) asafreira 2) Ateira, sugar apple, or sweet sop showing branch and fruit, and 3) branch of the betel plant with its catkin.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Ateira's scientific name is Annona squamosa; its origin is unknown, but it is cultivated in South America and the Caribbean. The betel plant is native to south Asia. ;Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. ;Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely. ;Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: 1 Bilimbeira; 2 Bilimbin; 3 Cajuijera; 4 Caju eller Acaju; 5 Keneel-Traeet
Description: Three kinds of plants: 1) branch and flowers of the bilimbeira, 2) fruit of the bilimbeira, 3) branch and flowers of the cashew, 4) fruit or drupe and peduncle or pseudofruit of the cashew, and 5) cinnamon tree.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Bilimbeira is known as bilimbi or belimbing asam; its scientific name is Averrhoa bilimbi, and it originated in the Moluccas. The cashew, Anacardium occidentale, is native to northeastern Brazil. Cinnamon, Cinnamomum verum, is native to Asia. ;Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. ;Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely. ;Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: 1. Jaqueira. 2. Iaqua. 3. Mangueira eller Manguier 4. Mangue 5. Mogoreira eller den dobbette Jasmin
Description: 1. Branch and seeds of the Jaqueira or jackfruit. 2. Jackfruit 3. Branch, flowers, and fruit of the Mangueira or mango. 4. Mango fruit. 5. Branch of the Mogoreira with buds and flowers, probably a kind of jasmine.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Jackfruit, Artocarpus heterophylla, is native to tropical Asia, but is grown in Brazil and Surinam. The mango, Anacardiaceae mangifera, is native to Brazil. Mogoreira (also spelled Mangoreira in text) is perhaps Jasminum sambac, a plant native to South Asia and Indonesia used to scent tea. ;Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. ;Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely. ;Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: 1 Papeyera. 2. Papaja, ell. Papaie. 3. Pereira, eller Guaiavier 4 Pero, ell. Guaiave. 5. Pimenteira, eller Pebertraeet.
Description: 1. Papaya tree with detail of flower. 2. Papaya fruit 3. Branch, flowers, and fruit of the guava. 4. Guava seeds and fruit. 5. Branch of the pepper tree with fruit or drupes.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: The papaya, Caricaceae Carica papaya, is native to southern Mexico, Central America, and northern South America. The guava, Myrtaceae Psidium, is native to the Caribbean, Central America, and northern South America. Pepper, Piper nigrum, is a vine native to southern India. ;Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. ;Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely. ;Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: 1. Figueira ell. Bananes Indianske Troe 2. Bananes 3. Jangomeira. 4. Jangomas 5. Brindeira 6. Brindons
Description: 1 & 2. Banana palms or trees. 3. Tropical fruit tree. 4. Flacourtia jangomas, Indian plum, coffee plum [?]. 5. & 6. Other trees.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Scientific name of banana: Musa. Scientific name of the Indian plum: Flacourtia jangomas ;Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. ;Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely. ;Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: 1. Jamboyera 2. Jamboya 3. Jambo 4. Dets aabne Blomster 5. Dets voxende Frugt 6. Jamoleira 7. Jambolon aaben
Description: 1 & 2. Banana palms or trees. 3. Tropical fruit tree. 4. Flacourtia jangomas, Indian plum, coffee plum [?]. 5. & 6. Other trees.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Scientific name of banana: Musa. Scientific name of the Indian plum: Flacourtia jangomas ;Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. ;Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely. ;Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: Ven. Ioannes de Palafox episc. angelop. postea oxom.
Description: Portrait of Juan de Palafox y Mendoza holding a book with a bishop's miter and crozier. He is surrounded by allegorical female figures representing instruction in esthetics, political and canonical thought, and civil duties. The women wear a papal crown and crowns. One wears a headdress shaped like a city or building. Also includes a skull, rake, scales of justice, a sword, angels, a torch, fasces, chalice and host.
Source_Title: [Works. 1762] Obras del ilustrissimo, excelentissimo, y venerable siervo de Dios don Juan de Palafox y Mendoza ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de don Gabriel Ramirez, criado de la Reyna Madre nuestra Señor, impresor de la Real Academia de San Fernando
notes: Appointed "visitador general" of Mexico in 1639, Palafox y Mendoza served as the bishop of Puebla of Los Angeles, a position he held until 1649. The process of his canonization was begun in 1726, but a final decision was suspended in 1777.The engraver may be Juan Benaré Palomino (1693-1777).

Image_title: S[an]ta. M[ar]ia Vn. D. Guadalupe D. Mex.
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe standing on a crescent moon with roses, starry cloak, and angel. She is surrounded by four vignettes showing her discovery, veneration, and revelation. Includes native American seeing the vision, revealing it to others, praying before it, and showing a cloak with her image on it to a kneeling man. Also includes an eagle wearing a crown and holding a snake in its beak sitting on a cactus.
Source_Title: Informe medico-moral de la penosissima, y rigorosa enfermedad de la epilepsia, que a pedimento de la M.R.M. Alexandra Beatriz de los dólores ....
Source_publisher: En la Oficina de Domingo Fernandez de Arrojo, Calle del Carmen
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Archbishop Zumárraga, the first archbishop of Mexico, accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it filled with out-of-season roses. The symbol of the eagle refers to the Aztecs, who looking for a homeland, were guided to a place where an eagle perched on a cactus ate a snake.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Catafalque for Maria Amalia de Saxonia, consort to Carlos III]
Description: Catafalque erected in the city of Santiago de los Caballeros in Guatemala. Includes candles, crown, skull, crossed bones, snake eating tail [ouroboros], and allegorical figures.
Source_Title: El pantheon real, funebre aparato a las exequias, que en la ciudad de Santiago de los Caballeros de Guatemala se hicieron por el alma, y â la piadosa memoria de nuestra catholica reina, y señora, doña Maria Amalia de Saxonia
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de Sebastian de Arebalo
notes: A catafalque, an elaborate funerary structure, was erected in the city of Santiago de los Caballeros (present-day Antigua Guatemala] in Guatemala for a funeral ceremony for Maria Amalia of Saxony (1724-1760), consort to Charles III.
SubjectHeadings2: María Amalia, consort of Carlos III, king of Spain, 1724-1760

Image_title: [Catafalque of Bishop Castañeda]
Description: A catafalque with lit candles. Decorative elements include the Castañeda coat of arms (with galero and six fiocchi), skeleton with scythe, and (symbolizing his office) mitres, crosier, scapular, mozetta.
Source_Title: Funebre pompa, magníficas exèquias, que a la justa memoria del Illmo. señor Doct. D. Juan de Castañeda Velazquez y Salazar, dignissimo obispo de las Santas Iglesias de Panamà, y el Cuzco; solemnizó, en la metropolitana de la ciudad de los Reyes, D. Joachin de Lamo y Zuñiga, conde de Castañeda y de los Lamos, teniente coronel del Regimiento de Infanterìa Española de Lima ...
Source_publisher: con licencia de los superiores. En la Oficina nueva de la Calle de la Coca
notes: This is the only known copy with added plate (folded) illustrating the catafalque of Bishop Juan de Castañeda Velazquez y Salazar, bishop of the dioceses of Panama and Cusco [Cuzco], Peru. Not included in Medina's description. Referred to but not seen by Vargas Ugarte: "Entre las págs. 28 y 29 del antelogio debe figurar, tal vez, un grabado del túmulo que falta en los ejemplares que hemos visto." John Carter Brown Library copy is no. 6 of 7 items bound together in vol. 3 of a 13 v. set with spine title: "Noticias del Peru." This engraving shows a catafalque, an elaborate funerary structure, which was erected in the cathedral of the archdiocese of Lima for the bishop's funeral service and later disassembled.

Image_title: V. P. Ignacio Raphael Coromina dela Comp[ani]a de Jesus Apostal de Guanajuato murio de 55. a[no]s en d[ic]ho Colegio
Description: Ignacio Raphael Coromina hands his rosary to seated and kneeling figures. He also blesses a kneeling man and preaches to a congregation in a church. Includes pulpit, biretta, crucifix with INRI, books, and altar.
Source_creator: Fernandez de Sousa, Juan de Dios
Source_Title: Carta consolatoria a la ciudad de Guanajuato en la sensible muerte de su zeloso apostol el padre rector Ignacio Raphael Coromina ... y analysis de su exemplar vida ...
Source_publisher: Impressa en el Real, y mas Antiguo Colegio de S. Ildefonso de Mexico
notes: Coromina was the rector of the Jesuit Antiguo Colegio de San Ildefonsos of Guanajuato founded by the Jesuits in 1588.

Image_title: [Catafalque]
Description: Catafalque of the Queen Mother, Isabel Farnesio. Allegorical figures representing faith (holding a cross), magnanimity (holding a compass), strength (holding a column), and fertility (holding a sheaf of wheat) are on the first tier. Figures stand on the second tier representing a native American and a European. Decorative elements include crowns, two coats of arms (one of the Farnese family, the other the Spanish royal coat of arms), crowns, pillars and urns bursting into flame, a skeleton with a bow and arrow, an orb. Figure at the top stands on a hemisphere.
Source_Title: Relacion de las reales exequias, que a la memoria de la reyna madre, neustra señora, Doña Isabel Farnesio, mando hacer en la ciudad de Los Reyes, capital de la América meridional
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta Real: Calle de Palacio, por Nicolas Urdin y Cevallos
notes: A catafalque, an elaborate funerary structure, was erected in the cathedral of Lima for a funeral ceremony for Queen Isabel Farnesio (1692-1766), born Elisabetta Farnese of Parma, who was the second wife of King Philip V of Spain (1683-1746). Bound as item 1 of 9 items in vol. 4 of a 15 v. set entitled, Noticias del Peru.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: En la Imprenta de el Superior Gobierno, de el Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal, en la Calle de Tiburcio
Description: An allegorical depiction of the spiritual conquest of Mexico. The church, shown as a blindfolded woman, carries a cross and a chalice with the host above it. Around her, native American men, women, and children kneel. Includes Christian church, owl [?], and native American sculptured objects. Also includes Biblical quotation in Latin, "Haec est Victoria, quae vincit Mundum Fides nostra. 1 Ioan. 5. v. 4."
Source_creator: Catholic Church. Province of Mexico City (Mexico). Concilio Provincial (1st : 1555)
Source_Title: Concilios provinciales primero, y segundo, celebrados en la muy noble, y muy leal Ciudad de México ...
Source_publisher: en la imprenta del Superior Gobierno, del Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal en la Calle de Tiburcio

Image_title: [El Grande Templo de Mexico]
Image_publisher: Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal
Description: Bird's eye view of the main temple of Mexico City. Parts are labeled in a key below image.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a-4a] Historia de la Nueva-España, ... aumentada con otros documentos, y notas, por el ilustrissimo señor don Francisco Antonio Lorenzana, ...
Source_publisher: en la imprenta del Superior Gobierno, del Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal en la Calle de Tiburcio
notes: Part of Francisco Antonio de Lorenzana's Historia de la Nueva-España (Mexico, 1770) which brought together historical documents relating to the civil and religious history of Mexico. Engraver is José Mariano Navarro. Two gods depicted at the top of the temple and to whom sacrifices are being made are Huitzilopochtli (god of the sun and war) and Tlaloc (god of rain).
References: cf. Solís, Antonio de, Historia de la conquista de Mexico, ... Brussels, 1741, plate following p. 114.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Item 26, fig. 37.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: V.S.D. Juan de Palafox obispo dela Puebla D Los Angeles y D Osma
Description: Portrait of Juan de Palafox y Mendoza wearing a cross around his neck and a skull cap and holding a book. Includes bishop's miter and crozier.
Source_Title: Breve tratado de la oracion ... con las meditaciones de san Pedro de Alcantara y fr. Luis de Granada ...
Source_publisher: Joseph Doblado
notes: Appointed "visitador general" of Mexico in 1639, Palafox y Mendoza served as the bishop of Puebla of Los Angeles until 1649. His appointment to the uncelebrated bishopric of Osma in Spain in 1655 was the equivalent of enforced retirement and public humiliation. The process of his canonization was begun in 1726, but a final decision was suspended in 1777.

Image_title: [Interior of a church]
Image_publisher: Oficina de la Calle de San Jacinto
Description: Interior of a church.
Source_creator: Colmenares Fernández de Córdoba, Felipe Urbano, marqués de Zelada de la Fuente, 1723-1807
Source_Title: El dia deseado
Source_publisher: en la Oficina de la Calle de San Jacinto
notes: This image is the frontispiece to Pablo de Laurnaga, Oracion panegirica, que en el dia deseado de la dedicacion y estreno del neuvo templo del Santo Cristo de los Milagros, Lima, 1771, published to consecrate the church of Santo Cristo de los Milagros (Our Lord of Miracles ). This baroque church, attached to the convent of the Nazarenes in Lima, contained an image of a black Jesus, painted by an African slave in the seventeenth century and venerated for protection against earthquakes. The oration was included, with title page, as a part of El dia deseado.

Image_title: [Carding machine for cotton]
Description: Man works a carding machine for cotton. Includes cotton fiber, treadle, wheel, and grinding mechanism. Items in the image are lettered for identification in following text.
Source_Title: Asuntos varios sobre ciencias, y artes. Obra periódica ... por D. Josef Antonio de Alzate, y Ramirez.
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de la Biblioteca Mexicana del Lic. D. Josef de Jauregui, en la Calle de San Bernardo
notes: Text, published by José Antonio de Alzate y Ramírez as the ninth part of a Mexican scientific periodical, describes the workings of a cotton carding machine.The engraver may be Manuel Villavico who engraved maps in Mexico in the 1780s.

Image_title: [The nations of Europe assemble]
Image_publisher: Chez T. R. Delorme, imprim. libr. Dover Street, Piccadilly
Description: Devils and fools dance in front of the entrance to Hell [?] and the entrance to Heaven [?]. A pig dressed as a priest stands before the fires of Hell while a procession led by another ecclesiastic carries a crucifix with "Nuestra Sonora, d'atocha" on it. Throngs of people, some nuns, some bishops, some royalty, some ordinary people, wait behind a portal. A figure representing Calvin, with a Bible under his arm, points the way to a garden [heave].
Source_Title: Congrès politique, ou Entretiens libres des puissances de l'Europe; sur le bal général prochain. Avec figures.
Source_publisher: Chez T. R. Delorme, imprim. libr. Dover Street, Piccadilly
notes: This book, a "satiric allegory on European wars" (according to Echeverria & Wilkie) was probably printed in Paris. Nuestra Se�ora de Atocha ("Our Lady of Atocha") was the most famous of a fleet of Spanish ships that sank in 1622 off the Florida Keys while carrying copper, silver, gold, tobacco, gems, jewels, jewelry, and indigo from Spanish ports at Cartagena and Porto Bello in New Granada (current Colombia and Panama, respectively) and Havana bound for Spain.

Image_title: A New Map of the Southern Parts of America taken from Manuscript Maps made in the Country and a Survey of the Eastern Coast made by Order of the King of Spain.
Description: Map of the southern part of South America from the Saint Gregory's Bay to the Strait of Magellan. Cartographic elements include a scale, lines of latitude and longitude, some topographical details, and location of islands and bays. Includes the Falkland Islands. Decorative cartouche includes a native American man and woman, volcano, dwellings or tents, pine trees, anteater, armadillo, skunk in the process of spraying, a rodent with three toes, spear, sword, bow, fur cloak, and ornaments.
Source_Title: [Description of Patagonia] A description of Patagonia, and the adjoining parts of South America ...
Source_publisher: Printed by C. Pugh; London and sold by T. Lewis, Russell-Street, London
notes: Thomas Falkner, a Jesuit missionary, was born in Manchester, England. After studying as a surgeon under Mead, he shipped out as surgeon on board the Assiento, a slave ship belonging to the South Sea Company. He sailed to the Guinea Coast circa 1731, then to Buenos Aires where he fell dangerously ill. He was received into the Society of Jesus in 1732 and afterwards spent 38 years as a missionary, first in Paraguay and Tucuman and then from 1740 among the native tribes between the Rio de la Plata and the Strait of Magellan. Biography taken from Lawrence Wroth's penciled note on end paper.
References: Cardiff, G. La personalidad y la obra de Tomás Falkner, 60
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Map of the Southern Parts of America]
Description: Map of the southern part of South America from the Rio de la Plata to Cape Saint Helen on the east coast and Chiloe to Point Male on the west. The southernmost portion of South America is included in 31195-2. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude, location of rivers, bays, lakes, salt flats, and a sand dessert. Also includes some topographical details and indications of a "Horse Road."
Source_Title: [Description of Patagonia] A description of Patagonia, and the adjoining parts of South America ...
Source_publisher: Printed by C. Pugh; London and sold by T. Lewis, Russell-Street, London
notes: Thomas Falkner, a Jesuit missionary, was born in Manchester, England. After studying as a surgeon under Mead, he shipped out as surgeon on board the Assiento, a slave ship belonging to the South Sea Company. He sailed to the Guinea Coast circa 1731, then to Buenos Aires where he fell dangerously ill. He was received into the Society of Jesus in 1732 and afterwards spent 38 years as a missionary, first in Paraguay and Tucuman and then from 1740 among the native tribes between the Rio de la Plata and the Strait of Magellan.Biography taken from Lawrence Wroth's penciled note on end paper.Creator taken from the part of map depicted in 31195-2.
References: Cardiff, G. La personalidad y la obra de Tomás Falkner, 60
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Mapa sacado con la ocasion de la Entrada qui hizo â su costa â los Fertiles y dilatados Paises del Gran Chaco Gualamba, el Governor del al Prov[inci]a del Tucamàn Dn. Geronimo Matorras ...
Description: Map of the interior of Argentina, Paraguay, and Bolivia. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude and path of the main route from Buenos Aires to Potosí (at the very top of the map). Decorative elements include native Americans meeting with Spanish soldiers, bird, horses, and military encampment. Items in the image are numbered and lettered for identification in a key above.
notes: This map was given as a presentation map and provided a record of the expedition of Geronimo Matorras, Governor of Tucumán, into the interior Indian country, or Gran Chaco Gualamba. The drawing memorializes the governor's meeting with "El famoso Indio Paykin." Another copy of this map is held by the Archivo General de Indias, Seville.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Neue Charte der Südlichern Theile von America ...
Description: Map of the southern part of South America from the Rio de la Plata to Cape Saint Helen on the east coast and Chiloe to Point Male on the west. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude, location of rivers, bays, lakes, salt flats, volcanos, and a sand dessert. Also includes some topographical details. Decorative details include armadillos, anteaters [?], native American man and woman, spear, bow, sword, dwelling or long house made of skins, erupting volcano, and pine tree.
Source_Title: [Description of Patagonia] Beschreibung von Patagonien und den angrenzenden Theilen von Südamerika ...
Source_publisher: bey Carl Wilhelm Ettinger
notes: Thomas Falkner, a Jesuit missionary, was born in Manchester, England. After studying as a surgeon under Mead, he shipped out as surgeon on board the Assiento, a slave ship belonging to the South Sea Company. He sailed to the Guinea Coast ca. 1731, then to Buenos Aires where he fell dangerously ill. He was received into the Society of Jesus in 1732 and afterwards spent 38 years as a missionary, first in Paraguay and Tucuman, and then from 1740 among the native tribes between the Rio de la Plata and the Strait of Magellan. This map was engraved by Thomas Kitchin.
References: Cardiff, G. La personalidad y la obra de Tomás Falkner, 60
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Catafalque of Pedro Antonio de Barroeta y Angel]
Image_publisher: En la Imprenta de los Niños Huérfanos
Description: Catafalque of Pedro Antonio de Barroeta y Angel, archbishop of Lima from 1751 to 1758 (when he was transferred to the see of Grenada). Decorative elements include allegorical figures, candlesticks, skeletons, and (symbolizing his office) mitres, pallium, and mozetta.
Source_Title: Lagrimas de Lima en las exequias del Ilmo. Sr. D.D. Pedro Antonio de Barroeta y Angel ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de los Niños Huérfanos
notes: A catafalque, an elaborate funerary structure, would have been erected in the cathedral for important persons and later disassembled. This engraving commemorated Pedro Antonio de Barroeta y Angel (ca. 1700-1775), who was archbishop of Lima from 1751 to 1758 (when he was transferred to the see of Grenada). He devoted himself to reforms among the clergy and church administration and to charity. Barroeta distributed all his revenues among the poor, so that his brother had to pay the expenses of his voyage back to Spain.

Image_title: Dama in abito da visita
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Woman in a visiting costume holds a rose in one hand.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.

Image_title: Dama in abito da casa
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Woman wears a costume worn in the house.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.

Image_title: Macello delle Vacche
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Manner of killing beasts or hunting in Chile. At top the cattle or bulls are kept within a fence while gauchos watch over them. A gaucho on horseback chases an escaping bull. In the middle a gaucho lassoes a bull and captures it by its horns. At bottom, the gaucho pins the bull to the ground and prepares to slit its throat while his horse holds the rope tight. Includes knife and lariat or boleadoras.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.

Image_title: Givoco la Chueca
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Native Americans play a game of chueca, a game similar to field hockey. Includes sticks, ball, feathered headdresses. A basket and laundry or clothing hang on tree.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously. The word "chueca" means curved stick in Mapuche and was played as a ritual celebration with prayer, dancing, and feasting. Europeans disapproved of the game; often it was followed by drinking of chincha and drunkenness.This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.

Image_title: Givoco il Cututumpeucu.
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Native Americans play a game of cututumpeucu, a circle game in which one player stands in the center while the others dance around him. Includes feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.

Image_title: Ballo degl' Indiani.
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Native Americans dance in a circle. In the center stand a musician or drummer and a man holding a flag or banner. Also includes gourds or bottles.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.

Image_title: [Birds of Chile]
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Penquin, hummingbird, jacana [here called a keltheau], nest of a building bird, flamingo, and an Andean condor.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: The penguin is perhaps the Humboldt penguin [Spheniscus humboldti] or the Gentoo penguin [Pygoscelis papua]. It is similar to the Magellanic penguin. The keltheu is probably a wattled jacana [Jacana jacana, a wading bird with huge feet and claws which allow them to walk on vegetation], a flamingo, and an Andean condor [Vultur gryphus].This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.

Image_title: [Animals of Chile]
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Guemul [llama], chillihueque [alpaca], vicogna [vicuña], huanaco, kirkinchio [perhaps an armadillo], leone marino [sea lion], lupi marini [sea wolf or seal], and chiñe [chinchilla].
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: Alpacas and vicuñas are in genus Vicugna. Huemul is a species of Andean deer, although the guemul shown here is a llama (a camelid). The chilliheuque is described in the text as an Araucanian camel.This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.

Image_title: S. Giacopo Capitale del Regno del Chile
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Plan of San Giacopo, or present-day Santiago, the capital of Chile. Includes a key with location of important buildings such as palaces, churches, convents, gardens, and university. Also includes the location of the Mapocho River, Mount Santa Lucia [Cerro Santa Lucía] and San Christoforo [Cerro San Cristóbal], compass rose, and scale.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Il Chile Regno dell'America Meridionale
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Map of Chile from Peru in the north [on left] to the archipelago of Chiloe in the south. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude, compass rose, scale, some topographical details, location of settlements, lakes, volcanoes, and native American lands. Decorative cartouche includes an Araucanian Indian with feathered headdress, spear, and poncho.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously, but is attributed to Molina.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Aztec glyphs]
