Image_publisher: W. Strahan, & T. Cadell, in the Strand
Description: Aztec glyphs or pictographs, perhaps depicting historical events and tribute.
Source_Title: The history of America. Vol. II.
Source_publisher: Printed for W. Strahan; T. Cadell, in the Strand; and J. Balfour, at Edinburgh.
notes: Robertson's history is one of the best known and most influential of the eighteenth century. Text discusses previously known Mexican (Aztec) paintings and their publication. Robertson has taken his example from eight paintings in the so-called Codex Mexicanus in the collection of the Imperial Library at Vienna. These paintings may have come originally from King Emmanuel of Portugal before 1533. Robertson identifies the lettered items in the text as targets or darts (AA), temples (BB), a bale of cloth (C), a numerical notation (DDD), and soldiers (EEE). Engraver is probably John Lodge, active in London ca. 1754-1794, d. 1796. Cf. Robertson, [History of America. Books 1-8. Greek], Vienna, [1792-1794] for the same image, reversed (04231-3).

Image_title: La milagrosa ymagen de Nuestra Señora de Copacabana ...
Image_publisher: en la Calle de Juan de Medina
Description: Representation of the Virgin standing on crescent moon and holding her infant, Jesus. She is flanked by two angels.
notes: The statue of our Lady of Copacabana, the patron saint of Bolivia, was made by a native Inca, Francisco Tito Yupanqui, descendant of Huayna Capac Inca, and was enthroned in Copacabana on the shore of Lake Titicaca in 1583. This broadside is the only known copy.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: Verdadero Retrato de la milagros Imagen de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe de Mexico
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe with roses, starry cloak, crescent moon, crown, and angel.
Source_Title: Vida de la madre de Dios y siempre Virgen Maria ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de Gregorio Biasini en la Ingsignia de Palas
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: Carte du Chili Méridional du Rio de la Plata, des Patagons, et du Détroit de Magellan; Ce qui fait l'extremité Australe de l'Amerique Merid[iona]le
Description: Map of the southern part of South America from the Rio de la Plata. Cartographic elements include lines of longitude and latitude, scales, and some topographical details. Decorative cartouche includes trees, flowering bush [camelia?], ships, golden coins, shells, and pearls [?].
notes: This map was one of three maps of South America produced by Anville.
References: Phillips, P. L. Atlases 647, no. 53; William L. Clements Library 1/37
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Josephus Ignatius Vellejus Mexicanus ...
Description: Portrait of José Ignacio Vallejo.
Source_Title: Vida de la madre de Dios y siempre Virgen Maria ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de Gregorio Biasini en la Ingsignia de Palas
notes: Vellejo was the bishop of Guadalajara, Mexico.

Image_title: [Our Lady of Guadalupe] Non fecit taliter omni nationi
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe with starry cloak, crescent moon, crown, and angel.
Source_Title: Felicidad de Mexico en la admirable aparicion de la Virgen Maria Nra. Sra. de Guadalupe ...
Source_publisher: Por D. Felipe de Zuñiga y Ontiveros, Calle de la Palma
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Diagram of electrical apparatus and of a mountain range in Peru]
Description: Figure 1 is an electrical apparatus. Figure 2 is a measured view of part of a mountain range in Peru.
Source_Title: [Works. German] Des Herrn D. Benjamin Franklin's, Mitglieds der Königlichen Londner und Göttinger Gesellschaften, ... Aus dem Englischen und Französischen übersetzt. ... Zweiter Band, mit kupfern.
Source_publisher: In der Waltherischen Hofbuchhandlung.
notes: Pierre Bouguer's La Figure de la Terre, déterminée par les observations de Messieurs Bouguer et de La Condamine ... envoyés au Pérou pour observer aux environs de l'Équateur. ... 1749 was based on his trip to Peru with La Condamine to measure a degree of the earth's meridian. The diagram in figure 2 may have to do with his attempt to measure the horizontal gravitational pull of mountains.Echeverria and Wilkie state that this translation is a combination of Barbeau-Dubourg's 1773 edition and Vaughn's 1779 edition of Franklin's works.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Les Espagnols se rendent maitre de Montezuma dans Mexico même.
Description: Moctezuma (Montezuma) II is carried on a litter by his Aztec subjects. Native Americans kneel before him and European soldiers escort him. Decorative elements include crowns, feathered headdresses, canopy, armor, and swords. Also includes fortifications.
Source_Title: Histoire philosophique et politique des établissemens et du commerce des Européens dans les deux Indes ... Tome second.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean-Leonard Pellet, Imprimeur de la Ville & de l'Académie
notes: Moctezuma II (reigned 1502-1520), ninth Aztec emperor, was the son of Axayácatl and the great grandson of Moctezuma I. He surrendered to the Spanish in 1520.
SubjectHeadings1: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: [Transfer of the see of Michoacán from Tzintzuntzan to Pátzcuaro]
Description: Fray Geronimo Alcala and Bishop Vasco de Quiroga face each other before a crowd of native Americans, many of whom are named and some of whom are bearded. To the left of the two men is a small tower with the profiles of men (who perhaps are dead) next to an image of a cross. In the background, five pyramids are shown. To the right are three bells and above the bells are two churches.
Source_creator: Beaumont, Pablo de la Purísima Concepción
Source_Title: [Crónica de Michoacán de Ocampo (Mexico)]
notes: This image, possibly copied in the late eighteenth century from an unknown sixteenth century original, relates to a disagreement between Bishop Vasco de Quiroga, the first bishop of Michoacán, and the native nobility over the bishop's decision to transfer the seat of his new diocese from the native capital of Tzintzuntzan to Pátzcuaro. Quiroga transferred the seat of his new see the day after he was consecrated on August 6, 1538. The Franciscan on the left is Fray Jerónimo de Alcalá, credited with being the first to write in Tarascan or Purépecha. Above the men are two natives named Francisco Tariyácuri and Antonio VItzimángari (also known as Tariácuri and Huitsiméngari), sons of the last native king of Michoacán, Cazonci Tzintzicha Tangazuan, who was executed in 1530 by the Spanish governor of New Spain, Nuño de Guzmán. The earliest Christian structure in the area was Santa Ana, shown at the upper right of the image. Below it is what seems to be a later church. The small tower is labeled "Alabentaro hatitacurini, cacntztiyo," (meaning in mixed Spanish and native language, "The ancient oratory now in ruins"). The pyramids in the background are labeled "Yrechequaro," (or 'the place of the kingdom"). In Tzintzuntzan five pyramids or "yácata" formed the center of their religious ceremonies.
References: Warren, J.B. Conquest of Michoacán, p. 87-90; www.ahila.nl/publicaciones/ cuadernos. html

Image_title: A View General of the City de Havana of Amerique. Vue Generalle de la Ville de Havanne en Amerique.
Image_publisher: chés Huquier fils rue St Jacques au dessus de celle des Mathurins au Gd. St. Remy
Description: View of Havana, Cuba. Ship in foreground unloads cargo and men onto a boat. Includes boats, fortifications, dwellings, churches, and chain across the mouth of the harbor.
notes: This fictitious perspective view of Havana, Cuba, a "vue d'optique," was a type of popular print published in Europe during the 18th century. These prints were viewed through a device called an "optical machine" or an "optique." Image title in French is also printed in reverse above image. This image is derived from Arnoldus Montanus, De nieuwe en onbekende Weereld, Amsterdam, 1671.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: In pace et aequitate ambularit. Malach. C.2.V.6
Description: Portrait of Diego Antonio de Parada, archbishop of Lima from 1762 to 1779 (when he died). Decorative elements include the archbishop's coat of arms (with galero and ten fiocchi or tassels), and (symbolizing his office) mitres, zucchetto, pallium, archiepiscopal ring and cross.
Source_Title: Relacion de las exequias del Illmo. or. D. D. Diego Antonio de Parada, arzobispo de Lima
Source_publisher: En los Niños Húerfanos
notes: This engraving is included with the "Relacion" and Joseph Antonio de Leon's "Orancio ufnebre [sic] del ... Diego Antonio de Parada," Lima, 1781, and is bound as vol. 5 of a 13 v. set entitled, Noticias del Peru.

Image_title: [Catafalque]
Description: Catafalque of Diego Antonio de Parada, archbishop of Lima from 1762 to 1779 (when he died). Decorative elements include allegorical figures, candlesticks, skeletons, and (symbolizing his office) mitres, pallium, mozetta.
Source_Title: Relacion de las exequias del illmo. Sor. D. D. Diego Antonio de Parada, arzobispo de Lima
Source_publisher: En los Niños Húerfanos
notes: A catafalque, an elaborate funerary structure, would have been erected in the cathedral for important persons and later disassembled. This engraving commemorated Archbishop Parada. The engraving is included with the "Relacion" and Joseph Antonio de Leon's "Orancio ufnebre [sic] del ... Diego Antonio de Parada," Lima, 1781, and is bound as vol. 5 of a 13 v. set entitled, Noticias del Peru.

Image_title: Verdao. Retro. del S. D. Pedro Romero de Terreros, Conde de Regla ...
Description: Portrait of Don Pedro Romero Terreros, conte de Regla. Includes coat of arms of the Regla family [?], medal of the Military Order of Calatrava, and laurel wreath.
Source_creator: Ruiz de Villa Franca y Cárdenas, José
Source_Title: Llanto de la religion, derramado en la muerte del señor don Pedro Romero Terreros ...
Source_publisher: por Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: Pedro Romero Terreros was possibly the richest man in the world in the eighteenth century. His wealth came from the ownership of an extremely successful and rich gold and silver mine near Querétaro in New Spain or Mexico.

Image_title: [Our Lady of the Rosary]
Description: Statue of the Virgin Mary. Includes crown and dove.
Source_Title: Ave Maria. Duodenario, o Exercicio devoto de la Immaculada Concepcion de Maria Santísima
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta Real; Calle de Concha
notes: This is an image of the Virgin of Miracles [Virgen del Milagro] venerated in the chapel at the Convento Maximo de Jesus in Lima, Peru.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Peru

Image_title: Indorum pietate vigil qui temperat iras, Auspicio Musis Jauregui totus adest.
Description: Portrait of Don Agustín de Jauregui, viceroy, governor, and captain general of Peru. Includes cannons, book, and flags.
Source_creator: Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos
Source_Title: Cartel del certamen Templo del honor, y la virtud. En el plausible triunfal recibimiento dei Ex.mo S.or don Agustin de Jaurequi y Aldecoa, caballero del orden de Santiago, teniente general de los reales exèrcitos, virrey, gobernador, y capitan general de estos Reynos de Perú, y Chile &c
Source_publisher: Imprenta de la Calle de Concha?
notes: Authorship attributed to Ramón José Argote y Gorostiza, according to Medina and Vargas Ugarte.

Image_title: V. R. del Santo Cristo de Amacueca
Description: Image of Christ Crucified [Cristo renovado] on an altar with two urns or vases [?] and stylized flowers.
Source_Title: Novena en honra de la milagrosisima imagen del Santo Christo de Amacueca ...
Source_publisher: por Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: This image of Christ Crucified was made by Father Joseph Ruiz in Michoacán. The image was credited with ending the drought which had afflicted the town of Tzacoalco.

Image_title: S. Maria Mater Guadalupana Mexici
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe with starry cloak, crescent moon, crown, and angels. She stands above a settlement or city with churches. Also includes an eagle standing on a plant [cactus] with a snake in its mouth and a crown.
Source_Title: Colección de obras y opusculos pertenecientes a la milagrosa aparicion de la bellisima imagen de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe
Source_publisher: en la imprenta de Lorenzo de San Martin, impresor de la secretaría de estado y del despacho universal de Indias, y de otras varias oficinas de S.M.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Fish and birds]
Description: Various birds and fish including: 1) the gold-fish, 2) the goldsinny, 3) the common goosander, 4) the red-breasted goosander, 5) the Antarctic white-winged goose, and 6) the Canada goose. Items are numbered for identification in key at bottom of image.
Source_Title: A new dictionary of natural history; or, Compleat universal display of animated nature... Volume the first
Source_publisher: Printed for Harrison and Co. No 18 Paternoster Row
notes: The Antarctic white-winged goose may be Chloephaga picta, the Magellan goose or upland goose, or C.p. leucoptera found on the Falkland Islands. The Canada goose, Branta canadensis, is found all over North America.

Image_title: [Hummingbirds]
Description: Nine South American hummingbirds. Images are numbered for identification in key at bottom.
Source_Title: A new dictionary of natural history; or, Compleat universal display of animated nature... Volume the first
Source_publisher: Printed for Harrison and Co. No 18 Paternoster Row
References_exhibitions: Been, A. Animals & Authors, Fig. VII: 8

Image_title: Gonzalo Pizarro Beheaded at Cuzco.
Description: Gonzalo Pizarro is beheaded with Spanish soldiers as onlookers. Includes executioner's sword, armor, and spears.
Source_Title: A new and complete collection of voyages and travels ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for the Proprietors: And Sold by Alexander Hogg, at No. 16, Pater-noster Row
notes: In 1548 the officially appointed governor of Peru, Pedro de la Gasca, and Gonzalo Pizarro met at the Apurimac River as Pizarro was advancing from Cuzco. The superior forces of Pedro de la Gasca caused many of Pizarro's men to defect, leading to Pizarro's surrender. The following day he was executed and his head taken to Lima to be placed on display.

Image_title: A View of the Pearl-Fishery.
Description: Native Americans or blacks [slaves] dive and collect pearl oysters from boats or canoes. In the background, a group of native Americans offer pearls and oysters to Europeans. Includes tents and boats.
Source_Title: A new and complete collection of voyages and travels ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for the Proprietors: And Sold by Alexander Hogg, at No. 16, Pater-noster Row
notes: Between 1513 and 1540, the number of pearls taken from the pearl islands off of the coast of Venezuela alone approached 120 million. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: The Rejoicings of the Mexicans, at the beginning of the Age.
Description: Native Americans dance before temples to the accompaniment of musical instruments such as drums, tambourines, and trumpet. Includes feathered headdresses and garments, astrological symbols or calendar, and priests giving offerings such as incense.
Source_Title: A new and complete collection of voyages and travels ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for the Proprietors: And Sold by Alexander Hogg, at No. 16, Pater-noster Row
notes: Text describes the temple of Huitzilopochtli, the Aztec god of the sun and war. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: A Patagonian Woman and Boy in Company with Commodore Byron.
Description: European man gives jewelry to a Patagonian giant and her son.
Source_Title: A new and complete collection of voyages and travels
Source_publisher: Printed for the Proprietors: And Sold by Alexander Hogg, at No. 16, Pater-noster Row
notes: In 1766, Commodore John Byron returned to London after circumnavigating the world. Word soon leaked out that the crew had discovered nine-foot tall Patagonian giants. Earlier explorers had also reported a race of giants in Patagonia. As early as the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America.

Image_title: Mr: Doughty beheaded by order of Sir Francis Drake, at Port St. Julian, on the Coast of Patagonia.
Description: Man holds the beheaded head of another, while six men look on. Includes hatchet or axe and ship.
Source_Title: A new and complete collection of voyages and travels
Source_publisher: Printed for the Proprietors: And Sold by Alexander Hogg, at No. 16, Pater-noster Row
notes: Thomas Doughty was given command of a Portuguese ship captured by Drake's fleet during Drake's voyage around the world of 1577 to 1580, but was beheaded at San Julian, in present-day Argentina, for suspicion of planning a mutiny.The artist may be Robert Dodd (1748-1815), English painter and engraver of naval action.

Image_title: Marriage-Ceremonies observed by the Indians of Panama.
Description: Native American marriage ceremony showing a woman with her head covered being led out of a dwelling. Includes hammock, baskets of grain and fruit, bows, arrow, and hatchets. In the background men chop wood.
Source_Title: A new and complete collection of voyages and travels
Source_publisher: Printed for the Proprietors: And Sold by Alexander Hogg, at No. 16, Pater-noster Row
notes: Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Social life and customs

Image_title: [Birds, lion, and leopard]
Description: Various birds, a lion, and a leopard including: 1) the lanner, 2) the red lark, 3) the hunting leopard, 4) the Angola linnet, 5) the black linnet, 6) the olive-colored linnet, 7) the yellow-headed linnet, and 8) the lion. Items are numbered for identification in key at bottom of image.
Source_Title: A new dictionary of natural history; or, Compleat universal display of animated nature... Volume the second
Source_publisher: Printed for Harrison and Co. No 18 Paternoster Row
notes: Text notes that the yellow-headed linnet was from Mexico; it may be the house finch, Carpodacus mexicanus, whose plumage is red or yellow depending upon its food. Its range was originally Mexico, but has now spread to all of the United States.

Image_title: Iosepho II. Avg. argentvm hydrargyro E. mineris primo extractvm Schemnizii Hvngariae Kal. Ian. MDCCLXXXVI
Description: Angels carve into a stone and lift a fire toward a statue or bust of Joseph II. In the background are the openings to underground mines.
Source_Title: Ueber das Anquicken der gold- und silberhältigen Erze, Rohsteine, Schwarzkupfer und Hüttenspeise
Source_publisher: Bey Christian Friederich Wappler

Image_title: [Beetles]
Description: Various kinds of beetles including the elephant, stag, brass, green tortoise, shield, lady-cow, capricorn, musk, unicorn, and dorr or chafer. Items are numbered for identification in key at bottom of image.
Source_Title: A new dictionary of natural history; or, Compleat universal display of animated nature... Volume the first
Source_publisher: Printed for Harrison and Co. No 18 Paternoster Row
notes: The elephant beetle, Megasoma elephas (1), is found in Central and South America. The brass or dung beetle (3) is found all over the world.

Image_title: [Mining machine]
Description: Machine to raise ore from a mine shaft. Includes a large spindle or winch around which mules or horses are driven to elevate ore from the ground. Includes ropes and men driving the horses with whips.
Source_Title: [Gazeta de México (Mexico City, Mexico)] Gazetas de Mexico, compedio de noticias de Nueva Espana que comprehenden los años de 1788, y 1789 ... Tomo tercera
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Don Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros
notes: This engraving is found in the issue for December 1788, volume 3, number 22, and accompanies an article about mining in Mexico.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Cae de un precipicio el Bto. Aparizio, y un Angel le favoreze para que no reciviese daño alguno
Description: An angel comes to the aid of Sebastian de Aparicio who has fallen from a precipice. At the top of the cliff is his cart or carriage and oxen. A man and a woman point toward the angel and Aparicio. Includes staff, rosary, dwelling, and stream.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Encuentra el Bto. Aparizio embarazado el camino para pasar con sus Carretas, y los Angeles se las pasan por el Aire, hasta la llanura
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio encounters difficulties with an overturned cart or carriage and angels aid him by flying the oxcart evenly over the gap in the road. Includes spilled bags of grain, a gentleman with a horse, people or peasants who attempt to load the cart, staff, rosary, settlement, and sea with a ship in the distance.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Caen del Puente al Rio la Carreta, y Bueyes invoca el Bto. Aparizio a su Patron Santiago, y no sucede desgracia
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio falls off a bridge into a river with his oxcart or carriage. His patron, Saint James of Santiago, comes to his aid. In the foreground Aparacio walks on water and drives the swimming oxen safely to shore. Includes bales or cargo in cart, staff, and the saint's banner.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.James of Compostela, also known as Santiago, patron saint of Spain, conquistadors, and the Spanish army, is shown with his attributes of cockle [scallop] shells and his sword cross on the banner. Saint James's body was said to have arrived in Spain after his death in Jerusalem by mysteriously being transported by sea.

Image_title: Deja libre la Nieve el sitio que occupavan el Bto. Aparizio, sus Bueyes, y sus Carretas
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio shelters with his oxen under his cart or carriage during a snow storm. In the background men, one on a horse, travel towards a shelter and a settlement. Includes rosary, yoke, dwellings, and staff.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Ve el Bto. Aparizio a un Joben, que caminando a Cavallo, llebava alas ancas al Demonio
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio sees a youth riding a horse with a devil or demon riding behind him. In the background a youth lies on the ground crushed by a rock which has fallen from a cliff. A grazing horse and two dogs run beside the prostrate body. Also includes a settlement.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Estando en Oracion el Bto. Aparizio, vio caminar al Cielo la Alma de una Donzella

Image_title: Acuden los demas Labradores al Bto. Aparizio, y lepiden su voto, y consejo para su aciertó
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio advises his workers. He sits holding his rosary while the workers who hold pitchforks and staffs listen to him. In the background he is seen showing an ox to a worker, watching over a man pouring grain into a vessel, and speaking with a man sitting on a rock. Includes astrological signs across the sky, moon, dwellings, mill, teams of oxen, spears, laurel wreath, skull, flail or whip, cross, and book.

Image_title: Consique el Bto. Aparizio, que la Justizia de libertad a un preso, pagando por el tres mil pesos
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio leans out of a carriage to speak with a man leading another who is tied with rope at his wrists. The carriage is followed by black servants [slaves]. In the background is a square with a town government building or courthouse. Also includes people carrying trays of food, clock, and dwellings.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Exercita el Bto. Aparizio con los probes, las siete obras corporales de misericordia
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio practices the seven Corporal Works of Mercy with the poor of Mexico. He offers food and drink to the hungry and thirsty. He offers hospitality to a traveler, he visits a prisoner, helps clothe a poor man, he cares for the sick, and, in the distance, buries a body in a grave marked by a cross. Also includes dwellings, jail, hospital, bottle, cup, bread, staff, pulley, and rope.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: The seven corporal works of mercy are (1) the burial of the dead, (2) visiting prisoners, (3) feeding the hungry, 4) dressing the naked, (5) offering of hospitality to pilgrims, (6) relieving the thirsty, and (7) caring for the sick.Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Intenta un Fidalgo de Mexico casar al Bto. Aparizio con una Hija suia, y no lo consigue
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio stands before a young noblewoman and proposes marriage. He holds a piece of paper in his hand. The young woman is attended by another woman in a well-appointed salon with mirror and wallpaper. Women servants serve drinks on a tray. Includes a painting which shows a man on horseback being welcomed into a doorway. Also includes a small dog, chairs, curtains, fans, and dwellings.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Sebastián de Aparicio lived in Atzcapotzalco, where a nobleman tried to get a rich man to marry his daughter. Aparicio paid the 600 pesos needed by the nobleman to provide a dowry for his daughter.Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Medita, y resuelve el Bto. Aparizio Casarse, pero con intencion de conservarse Virgen, si le fuese posibile
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio kneels before an altar with candlesticks, a crucifix, and flails or whips. He meditates on his intention to remain a virgin after his marriage. Includes Aparicio's vision of the Virgin Mary with Joseph surrounded by angels. Also includes a view outside of palm trees, a bed made out of woven rope on the floor, and a chair with a sword and cloak on it.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: Contraé el Bto. Aparizio el Matrimonio en el Conv[en]to Curato de S[a]n Fran[cis]co de Tacuva
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio marries a native American woman in a ceremony held in the convent church of San Francisco de Tacuba. He places a ring on her finger while the priest watches. The ceremony is observed by other people. On the wall hangs a painting which shows the marriage of Mary and Joseph presided over by a rabbi. Above the scene is a view of Aparicio sleeping on a mat on the floor of the bedroom while his wife sleeps in a bed. Includes a crucifix and lamp.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Aparacio married the native woman to help her and her family, but resolved to never consummate the marriage.Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Duerme el Bto. Aparizio en tierra, y su Esposa en la Cama Nupzial, a fin de conservar la Castidad
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio holding rosary beads and a key sleeps on the ground outside of a locked dwelling or nuptial bedroom while his wife sleeps inside. In this way they preserve their chastity. Includes scenes of Aparacio and his wife traveling by sea in a boat with oars and a sail. They come ashore and are welcomed at a house. Also includes a sleeping dog, shoes, lamp, crucifix, and bed.

Image_title: Produzen quexas contra el Bto. Aparizio sus Suegros, por que conserbava su Virginidad en el Matrimonio
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio holding rosary beads defends himself against his father and mother-in-law. They ask why he is sleeping on a mat and not in the bed with their daughter. He points to a grape vine with many grapes on it outside the window. Includes chair and sword.

Image_title: Muere al año la Esposa del Bto. Aparizio, y la manda enterrar con toda Pompa en el dicho Conv[en]to de Tacuva
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio accompanies the body of his wife to the convent church at Tacuba. Her head is encircled by flowers and she holds a cross. Image_title: Cassa secunda vez el Bto. Aparizio, y con la misma intencion, con otra Niña tierna, y bien educada

Image_title: Sigue durmiendo en tierra el Bto. Aparizio, y separado desu Esposa, por el mismo fin ia dicho
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio holding rosary beads and a key sleeps on the ground outside of a locked dwelling or nuptial bedroom while his second wife sleeps inside. In this way they preserve their chastity. Includes scenes of Aparacio and his wife traveling by sea in a boat with oars and a sail. They come ashore and are welcomed at a house. Also includes a sleeping dog, shoes, lamp, cross, a bird or heron, and bed.

At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Enferma el Bto. Aparizio, declara dejar Virgen a su Esposa, y la instituie su heredera
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio lies on his sickbed making his will in the event of his death. His weeping wife stands nearby while he talks to lawyers and men who show him casks of money. Here he declares he is a virgin and makes provisions for his wife to be his heir. Also includes dog and cat, sacks of gold, crucifix, religious paintings, notebook, and quill.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: Caese de un Arbol esta segunda Esposa del Bto. Aparizio, y a esta despracia se sigue su muerte al año poco menos de Casados
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio runs to his wife who lies dead under a tree which she had been climbing. Includes female servant, the tree branch which broke, a ladder, courtyard of the house, horse, pots of flowers, well with a bucket, pulley, and rope. In the background a man rides a horse.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Perdona el Bto. Aparizio â una Vuida muchas deudas, que le devia su Marido, y rasga las escrituras
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio tears a contract or paper in half while a poor widow kneels in front of him. The death of her husband has left her with many debts which Aparicio pays. In the background is a scene of the widow's husband's death and a scene of Aparicio presenting bags of money or gold to the widow and her children. Includes candlestick, table, stool, quill, bed, and dwelling.

Image_title: Enferma gravemt[en]te. el Bto. Aparizio, y deja todos sus bienes al Conv[en]to de Escapuzalco
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio lies on a mat on the floor and gestures towards a convent in front of which two monks converse. A man or scribe writes on a piece of paper with a quill. Also includes table, bust or sculpture on a plinth, sword, table with scissors, comb, and perfume bottle. A bedroom with a bed is shown through a door. Includes a dog holding a torch in its mouth.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Sebastián de Aparicio wished to join a Dominican convent at Atzcapotzalco after the death of his second wife, but his confessor advised against it, because he was already so old and well established in the community. The dog with a torch in its mouth symbolizes the Dominican order [from a play on words with Domicanes or Dominus canis]. Instead Aparacio gave money to the convent and the Mexican Indians who were helped by the Dominicans.Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Apareze en el Campo, y de noche el Demonio al Bto. en figura de Toro, y le venze, y obliga a huir corrido, y abergonzado
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio holds an enraged bull by the horns. In the distance two monks greet someone riding a horse over a bridge. Another monk stands at the door of a convent. Includes a horse, cloak, hat, staff, fortified settlement, dwelling, cross on a column, and churches.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli

Image_title: Hallandose una noche el Bto. Aparizio en el Campo cansado, y melancolico, los Angeles le confortan, y dan Musica
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio rests exhausted and melancholy underneath a carriage or car. An angel comes to him and plays a musical instrument or lute. In the background rain pours down at night and the angel with the lute shines a light onto a dangerous gorge for a monk on the opposite bank.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Pierde el Bto. Aparizio el camino en una noche obscura, y los Angeles selo enseñan, y le dan luz, y Musica
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio sits beside a carriage or cart and oxen at night while angels play their musical instruments or lutes and dance with lit tapers or torches. Includes a church, pipes or horn, violin, cymbal, and rosary.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Ora en Monte el Bto. Aparizio, conjura las tempestades, y no le mojan las Aguas.
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio kneels beside a tree on a mountain top in a rainstorm. He is accompanied by an ox. In the background he holds up a cross to the lightning. Although he has conjured up the storm, he remains dry.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Los Angeles en figura de Indios, asisten al Bto. Aparizio, y le cargan la limosna en un Mulo
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio is assisted by two angels in the guise of native Americans who help him load goods to be given away on a mule. In the background a monk blesses a man who kneels in front of him. A person looks out from a door. Also includes a settlement, cross on a grave [?], shovel, and dwelling.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli

Image_title: Desprecia el Bto. Aparizio las Esteras, que el Demonio le ofrecia para cubrir sus limosnas en tiempo de aguas
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio rejects mats offered by a demon or devil to cover the goods he carries in a carriage or cart for the poor. A lightning storm rages and ruins the mats carried by a mule. Includes oxen and staff.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: Pierde el Bto. Aparizio su Manto, Aparezesele Sn. Diego de Alcala, y le manifesta donde esta
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio meets with Saint Didacus of Alcala [San Diego de Alcala]. In the background a saint blesses people and a cloak in a doorway and a man shows a cloak to people in a house. Includes a cross, rosaries, and dwelling.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastian de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order as a lay brother or tertiary and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.Saint Didacus of Alcala (1400-1463), a Franciscan, was not canonized a saint until 1588 or around the time Aparicio is here represented.

Image_title: Aparezesele Sn. Diego al Beato Aparizio, y cambian sus Rosarios.
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio sits before Saint Didacus of Alcala [San Diego de Alcala] and exchanges a rosary with him. In the background the saint kneels before a woman with his rosary beads. A woman on a balcony looks down on Saint Didacus and Aparicio.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

He was beatified in 1787.Saint Didacus of Alcala (1400-1463), a Franciscan, was not canonized a saint until 1588 or around the time Aparicio is here represented.

Image_title: Un Caminante devoto del Bto. Aparizio, le vio una noche elevado de la tierra, sobre un Collado
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio is elevated in the air while a traveler on horseback observes him. Aparacio flies through the air at night over a cattle path. Includes a night sky with the moon and stars, rosary, carriage or cart, oxen, and horse.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: Sacanle los Angeles al Bto. Aparizio sus Carretas da una Barranca profunda, y se las ponen en caminollano
Description: Angels appear to Sebastian de Aparicio to help him get his carriage or cart and oxen out of a deep ravine. An angel flies his carriage through the clouds and onto a road.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: Caminando el Bto. Aparizio con el exe quebrado de una Carreta, Sn. Fran[cis]co. sostiene la rueda para que no caiga
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio repairs a wheel which has fallen off an ox carriage or cart with the assistance of Saint Francis. Saint Francis puts the wheel on the loaded cart while holding it up. Includes dwelling and a cross on a hill [grave].
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: Despues de haber tomado el Bto. Aparizio una cruel disciplina, un Caminante vio correrle la sangre
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio speaks with a traveler as he drives an oxcart or carriage toward a settlement. Aparicio uses his flail to discipline himself and the traveler sees him covered in blood and directs him toward a settlement. Includes ox, horse, blood flowing down Aparicio's leg, church, and fortifications.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: Salta una rueda, y cae en tierra una Carreta cargada de leña, y el Bto. Aparizio solo, la sostiene, y acomoda
Description: Sebastian de Aparicio repairs a cart carrying a load of wood which has had a wheel come off. He holds the weight of the carriage on his shoulder. Another traveler waves at him. Includes staff and tools.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: En una noche obscura caio el Bto. Aparizio a Cavallo en un Rio, y con el auxilio de los Angeles salio sin desgracia.
Description: An angel assists Sebastian de Aparicio from the river on a dark night. The angel carries a lit candle and Aparicio holds a rosary. In the background a man holds a lit candle which is being blown out by the wind. A horse swims in the river. Includes dwelling.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico

Image_title: [Catafalque of Charles III]
Image_publisher: Imprenta Real de los Niños Expósitos
Description: Catafalque of Charles III. Decorative elements include skeleton with a bow and arrow, candelabras, royal coat of arms of Spain. Allegorical figures representing faith (holding a cross), magnanimity (holding a compass), strength (holding a column), and fertility (holding a baby) are on the first tier. Figures stand on the second tier representing a native American (with feathered headdress) and a European (with a crown). Figure at the top stands on a hemisphere.
Source_creator: Rico, Juan, sacerdote de la Congregacion del Oratorio
Source_Title: Reales exequias, que por el fallecimiento del señor don Carlos III, rey de España y de las Indias
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta Real de los Niños Expósitos
notes: Charles III, Bourbon king of Spain, died in 1788. A catafalque, an elaborate funerary structure, was erected in the cathedral at Lima to commemorate his death.

Image_title: Patagonian Warbler, from Falklands Islands. Latham's Synopsis. Vol. 4. P. 434. No. 26.
Description: Bird [warbler?] perched on a tree stump.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world; but more particularly to the north-west coast of America: performed in 1785, 1786, 1787, and 1788, in the King George and Queen Charlotte, Captains Portlock and Dixon. ...
Source_publisher: Geo. Goulding, Haydn's head, no. 6, James Street, Covent Garden.
notes: Text describes the bird as nine inches long and colored grey, brown, and white.Beresford was supercargo on the Queen Charlotte, the ship of which Dixon was captain. Dixon edited Beresford's letters and added the maps and the navigational and natural history information. The goal of the voyage was to establish a fur trade along the northwest coast for King George's Sound Company in which Dixon was a partner.Draughtsman is probably William Lewin, active 1764-1782, died ca. 1795. Engraver may be Peter Mazell, active 1761-1797.

Image_title: Plan of the Harbour of Monte-Video, on the North Shore of the River la Plata, surveyed in the Year 1789
Description: Plan of the harbor of Montevideo. Geographical, topographical, and military features are given, as well as a scale, soundings, and locations of fortifications.
Source_Title: [cover title] Manuscript Maps for the South American Campaigns of 1806-7
notes: Between March 1806 and January 1808, the British launched several assaults against Spanish fortifications in Buenos Aires and Montevideo. Sir Home Popham, British naval commander at the Cape of Good Hope, launched these attacks (without official authorization) to bring free trade to the region of the Rio de la Plata and thus reconcile the local population to British rule. His plan backfired and, instead, the British expedition sparked local resistance to the British, as well as a popular uprising against Spanish authority in the area. Spanish claim to power was undermined by the apparent unwillingness of the Spanish Viceroy to defend Buenos Aires against the British and by the success of local efforts to defend the city. These events stimulated a revolt which led to independence from Spain in 1810. This item is included in a collection of manuscript maps hinged in a folio album titled, Manuscript Maps for the South American Campaigns of 1806-7.
References: Grainger, J. D., ed. Royal Navy in the River Plate, 1806-1807
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: El Illmo. Y Rmo. Señor D. Fr. Josef Antonio de S. Alberto Carmelita Descalzo Obispo del Tucuman y al presente Arzobispo de Charcas.
Description: Portrait of Josef Antonio de San Alberto. Includes miter, crozier, patriarchal cross, globe, quills, inkwell, bundles of papers, books, coat of arms, crown, and laurel wreaths.
Source_creator: Catholic Church. Diocese of Córdoba (Argentina). Bishop (1780-1784 : José Antonio de San Alberto)
Source_Title: Coleccion de instrucciones pastorales, que en diferentes ocasiones, y con varios motivos publicó para edificacion de los fieles...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta Real
notes: Josef Antonio de San Alberto was bishop of Tucuman and archbishop of Charcas.

Image_title: N. S. De Guadalupe De Mexico. ...
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe with starry cloak, crescent moon, crown, and angel.
Source_Title: Manifiesto satisfactorio anunciado en la Gazeta de Mexico (Tom. I. Núm. 53.) Opusculo Guadalupano ...
Source_publisher: Impreso con licencia de los Superiores, por D. Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.

Image_title: Esta Lamina es solo para representar el viage, ò hilo, de la costura de los dos paños del Ayáte Guadalupano, como hoy existe 1787.
Description: A sketch of the image of the Virgin of Guadalupe. The original image was made on ayate cloth.
Source_Title: Manifiesto satisfactorio anunciado en la Gazeta de Mexico (Tom. I. Núm. 53.) Opusculo Guadalupano ...
Source_publisher: Impreso con licencia de los Superiores, por D. Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: Ayate is a cloth woven from fiber of an agave plant. The image refers the viewer to Francisco Hernandez, Historia de Plantos, book 3, chapter 43, about how the thread from the variety of plant shown here is preferred over the maguey plant. The image also includes the particular dash which resembled an 8 that Miguel Cabrera saw on the image of Our Lady of Guadalupe.Miguel Mateo Maldonado y Cabrera (1695-1768) was an indigenous Zapotec painter, the greatest painter in all of New Spain. His book, Maravilla americana, published in 1756 studied the icon of Our Lady of Guadalupe. He made three copies of the original image.This plate has another impression from the same plate on the verso.
SubjectHeadings3: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico--Guadalupe Hidalgo

Image_title: Recoto Sebasticen de Aparicio.
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio kneels in front of a cart. Includes a tree with a hat hanging on it, cross, rosary, a settlement, bridge, and an overturned cup with a flower growing out of it.
Source_Title: Novena del portentoso confesor de Jesu-Christo el B. Sebastian de Aparicio ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de D. Pedro de la Rosa
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: B. Sebastian de Aparicio
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio kneels in front of a cart, He holds a rosary in his hand. Also includes a tree, an ox, and an overturned cup with a flower growing out of it.
Source_Title: Novena del portentoso confesor de Jesu-Christo el B. Sebastian de Aparicio ...
Source_publisher: por su original en la oficina de los Herederos del Lic. don Joseph de Jauregui

Image_title: N.S. De Guadalupe de Mexico.
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe standing on a crescent moon with crown, starry cloak, and angel.
Source_Title: Pensil americano florido en el rigor del invierno, la imágen de María santísima de Guadalupe.
Source_publisher: Por D. Mariano de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it filled with out-of-season roses.

Image_title: Iczotl. Palma Sylvestre, de que se sacó la materia del Ayáte de la Tilma de Juan Diego
Description: Woody plant from which the ayate for Juan Diego's tilma was made.
Source_Title: Manifiesto satisfactorio anunciado en la Gazeta de Mexico (Tom. I. Núm. 53.) Opusculo Guadalupano ...
Source_publisher: Impreso con licencia de los Superiores, por D. Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: Ayate is a cloth woven from fiber of an agave plant. The image refers the viewer to Francisco Hernandez, Historia de Plantos, book 3, chapter 43, about how the thread from the variety of plant shown here is preferred over the maguey plant. The image also includes the particular dash which resembled an 8 that Miguel Cabrera saw on the image of Our Lady of Guadalupe.Miguel Mateo Maldonado y Cabrera (1695-1768) was an indigenous Zapotec painter, the greatest painter in all of New Spain. His book, Maravilla americana, published in 1756 studied the icon of Our Lady of Guadalupe. He made three copies of the original image.

Image_title: Verd. Efigie del Ve. Siervo de Dios P. Fr. Pedro Urraca ...
Description: Portrait of Pedro Urraca, member of the Mercedarian Order. He wears the shield of his order, holds a heart with a cross on it [sacred heart] and a chained book. He points to a triangle with three stars surrounded by angels.
Source_Title: El Job de la ley de gracia, retratado en la admirable vida del siervo de Dios venerable padre fray Pedro Urraca, del real, y militar orden de Nuestra Señora de la Merced ... del la ciudad de Quito ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la viuda de d. Pedro Marin
notes: Urraca was born in Spain and was brought to Quito in present-day Ecuador by his brother. He was ordained as a priest in Lima in 1610 and he died there in 1657. The triangle in the portrait refers to a miraculous appearance of three stars in this configuration when Urraca was nine years old.

Image_title: Dn. Bartolome de Mesa, Teniente d[e] Milicias, Comerciante Almazenero, y Comisario d[e] las funciones d[e] la nacion Yndica.
Description: Portrait of Bartolome de Mesa in military attire.
Source_creator: Terralla y Landa, Esteban de, fl. 1790
Source_Title: El sol en el medio dia: Año feliz, y jubilo particular con que la nacion Indica de esta muy noble ciudad de Lima solemnisó la exaltacion al trono ... Don Carlos IV ...
Source_publisher: Impreso en la Casa Real de Niños Expósitos
notes: This may be Bartolomé Massa who was an Italian entrepreneur and composer of sacred and lyric music who lived and worked in Lima beginning in 1765. He died in Lima in either 1796 or 1799.

Image_title: M. Sma. S. de Guadalupe de Mexico
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe with roses, starry cloak, crescent moon, and angel shown on a piece of cloth.
Source_creator: Campo y Rivas, Manuel del, ca. 1755-1830
Source_Title: Compendio histórico de la fundacion, progresos, y estado actual de la ciudad de Cartago en la provincia de Popayán en el Nuevo Reyno de Granada ...
Source_publisher: En la Oficina de Don Mariano Valdés Tellez Giron
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, with an image of the Virgin on it.The engraver may be Francisco Aguera Bustamente (1779-1820) who worked in Mexico.
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2007. Formerly owned by Maury A. Bromsen

Image_title: La Milagrosissima Ymagen de Nra Sra del Rosar[i]o de Chiquinquira
Description: Image of Our Lady of the Rosary of Chiquinquirá flanked by two men, one a monk holding the Christ Child, the other Moses [?] holding a book and a pole. At the bottom of the image is the scene of Maria Cárdenas discovering the miraculous plank of wood.
Source_creator: Campo y Rivas, Manuel del, ca. 1755-1830
Source_Title: Compendio histórico de la fundacion, progresos, y estado actual de la ciudad de Cartago en la provincia de Popayán en el Nuevo Reyno de Granada ...
Source_publisher: En la Oficina de Don Mariano Valdés Tellez Giron
notes: In 1709 Maria Cárdenas, a washerwoman of Maracaibo in the state of Zulia, Venezuela, (where the town is also called La Chinita) discovered a slab of wood with an image of the Virgin Mary and the Christ Child on it.
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2007. Formerly owned by Maury A. Bromsen
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Venezuela

Image_title: Plan Del curso d[e] los Rios Huallaga. y Vcayali. y de la pampa del Sacramento.
Image_publisher: la Sociedad de Amantes del Pais de Lima
Description: Map of part of northeastern Peru with the Marañon River at the top, the Ucayali River at right, the Huallaga River in the center and Lima at lower left. Map is dedicated to Charles IV [Carlos IV] of Spain. Key at lower left indicates towns populated by Christians, converts, and the unconverted, symbols defining the territory occupied by the converted and paths through the mountains. Cartographic elements include scale, degrees of latitude and longitude, names of rivers, mountains, lakes, settlements, and regions. Also includes native American man holding bow and arrows and wearing feathered headdress, and a woman and child holding birds.
Source_Title: Mercurio peruano de historia, literatura, y noticias publicas que da à luz la Sociedad academica de amantes de Lima.
Source_publisher: En la imprenta real de los Niños Huérfanos...
notes: Between 1789 and 1790 Father Manuel Sobreviela travelled along the Huallaga River and created a map of the area around the Huallaga and Ucayali Rivers. Sobreviela was made Guardian of the Colegio de Ocapa in 1786.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Die ehrwürdige Jungfrau Mariana von Jesu ... durch den Tod ihr Vaterland Quito ...
Description: Mariana de Jesús Paredes y Flores holds a lily. She prays to Jesus during the earthquake of Quito. A city topples down in the background. Jesus with flames surrounding his head holds lightning bolts [?] in his hand.
Source_Title: [Vita della venerabile Marianna di Gesù. German] Leben der Ehrwürdigen Jungfrau Marianna von Jesu de Paredes und Flores, von Quito in Amerika ...
Source_publisher: Bey Nicolaus Doll
notes: Mariana de Jesus de Paredes y Flores, called the White Lily of Quito, offered herself to God in expiation for the sins of others following an earthquake and subsequent epidemic that afflicted the city of Quito in 1645. When the epidemic began to abate, she was stricken and died on May 26th.
SubjectHeadings2: Paredes y Flores, Mariana de Jesus de, Saint, 1618-1645

Source_Title: Elogio historico de Maria santisima de Guadalupe de Mexico ...
Source_publisher: por los Herederos del Lic. D. Joseph de Jauregui, calle de Santo Domingo y esquina de Tacuba
