Image_title: [Title page]
Description: A Spanish soldier speaks with a woman holding a child in Peru. Includes a dwelling and altar [?]
Source_Title: Die Spanier in Peru: oder Rollas Tod. Ein romantisches Trauerspiel in fünf Akten
Source_publisher: bey Paul Gotthelf Kummer
notes: This play was soon adapted by the Irish playwright, Richard Brinsley Sheridan, as Pizarro in 1799 and became a success in England.

Image_title: Vista de la Plaza de Mexico, nuevamente adornada para la estatua equestre de nuestro augusto monarca reynante Carlos IV ...
Description: View of the plaza (Zócalo) of Mexico City, Mexico, featuring the newly built equestrian statue of the Spanish king, Carlos IV, erected by Miguel la Gruqa, marques de Branciforte, in honor of the marriage of the king to Maria Luisa de Borbon. Includes church or cathedral, dwellings, gate, men, native Mexicans [?], royal Spanish coat of arms surrounded by the chain of the Order of the Golden Fleece, and fountains.
notes: Manuel Tolsa (1757-1816), a Spanish sculptor and architect, created the bronze statue of Charles IV (known as El Caballito), the design of the Palacio de Mineria, as well as oversaw the completion of the Metropolitan Cathedral. One of the oldest and largest churches in the western hemisphere, the Cathedral of the Zócalo, begun in 1525, is built on part of the old Aztec temple precinct and was finished in its present state in 1813.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Entra Hernan Cortés triunfante en Tlascala.
Description: Hernán Cortés rides on horseback into a settlement. He is accompanied by his soldiers, a woman holding a steaming bowl, and welcomed by native Americans offering food and playing on musical instruments such as a trumpet or horn. More people watch from balconies.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo II
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). Cortés and his men fought with the Otomí troups of Tlaxcala and, after a prolonged conflict, eventually triumphed. Following the defeat, the Tlaxcalan leaders decided to welcome Cortés to their territory in the hopes that the Spanish could defeat their bitter foes, the Aztecs under Moctezuma. Doña Marina or Malinche was the mother of Cortés's child and interpreter for the Spanish.The artist of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Visita Cortés à Motezuma en su Palacio.
Description: Hernán Cortés is greeted by Moctezuma in his palace. Moctezuma stands with his native American subjects, wearing feathered headdresses and places his hand on Cortés's shoulder. Includes a reception hall with rich wall hangings, bench, and plumed hat.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo III
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). Moctezuma welcomed Cortés and his men into his court hoping to discover their weaknesses.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).
SubjectHeadings3: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Acepta Cortés el mando de la Armada
Description: Hernán Cortés accepts command of the fleet to go to Mexico from Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar in the port of Santiago de Cuba. Includes soldiers, ships, boats, fortifications, cargo and swords.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo I
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). Diego Velázquez, first Adelantado (Governor-General) of Cuba, initially supported Cortés's expedition to Mexico, but alarmed by the riches and power Cortés was accruing, ordered Pánfilo de Narváez to arrest him. Cortés defeated Narvaez's troops. The artist of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Batalla de Tabasco
Description: The battle of Tabasco. Spanish soldiers fight against native American soldiers. Includes horses, shields, swords, and war clubs.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo I
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). He first landed in the Yucatan and proceeded to Tabasco where he won a battle against the natives. He received 20 indigenous women from the losers; one of these women was Doña Marina or Malinche who became the mother of his child and was a valuable interpreter - she spoke both Nahuatl and Maya.The artist of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Renuncia Cortés el titulo de General que le dio Velazqz. y el Pueblo le vuelve a elegir.
Description: Hernán Cortés holds a baton and addresses a man who sits at a table with other men. Includes the royal coat of arms of Spain, paper, inkwells, and swords.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo II
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). He organized an independent government and renounced the authority of Diego Velázquez by annointing himself captain general.The artist of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Manda Cortés dar al traves con las naves
Description: Hernán Cortés supervises the unloading of cargo from ships. In the background ships lie scuttled or sinking in harbor. Includes anchor, barrels, cannon, ropes, and flag.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo II
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). He landed in Vera Cruz where he scuttled or sank his ships to prevent his men from retreating.The artist of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Concede Hernan Cortés la paz que le pide el Senado de Tlascala.
Description: Hernán Cortés receives a delegation of native Americans wearing feathered headdresses. A woman speaks to Cortés who sits on an elevated platform or dais surrounded by soldiers.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo II
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). Cortés and his men fought with the Otomí troups of Tlaxcala and, after a prolonged conflict, eventually triumphed. Following the defeat, the Tlaxcalan leaders decided to welcome Cortés to their territory in the hopes that the Spanish could defeat their bitter foes, the Aztecs under Moctezuma. Doña Marina or Malinche was the mother of Cortés's child and interpreter for the Spanish.The artist of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Manda Cortes poner grillos á Motezuma mientras se ajusticia á un General de su Imperio.
Description: Hernán Cortés has Moctezuma put in leg irons. He stands with his company while Moctezuma raises his hands in protest. Includes native American attendants in feathered headdresses and garments in the imperial reception hall.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo III
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). Cortés took Moctezuma as a hostage in his own palace in 1519.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).
SubjectHeadings3: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Congregados Motezuma y los nobles mexicanos declaran á Carlos V. por legitimo sucesor de su Imperio.
Description: Moctezuma and his nobles declare the sovereignty of Charles V. Hernán Cortés sits in a chair watching Moctezuma who points toward a table with an [Aztec] crown, scepter, and shield on it. Also includes native Americans in feathered headdresses and garments, a box of treasure and gold, a censer or thurible, a desk with a man writing at it, paper, ink pot, and royal coat of arms of Spain.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo III
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). Cortés took Moctezuma as a hostage in his own palace in 1519 and forced him to swear alligiance to Charles V.stoned by his own people.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).
SubjectHeadings3: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Derrota del exercito de Narbaez, y prision de este.
Description: Capture of Pánfilo de Narváez at night by Hernán Cortés and his soldiers. Includes the bound prisoner, torches, scene of warfare, cannons, fortifications, flags, shields, and swords.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo III
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: In 1520, Diego Velázquez sent an expedition, lead by Pánfilo de Narváez, to overturn Hernán Cortés. Although greatly outnumbered, Cortés and his men took Narváez prisoner and convinced Narváez's men to join them. stoned by his own people.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: [Allegory of Spanish conquest of Mexico]
Description: Allegorical representation of the Spanish monarchy as a crowned woman giving a book to a native American woman wearing a feathered headdress. Behind her stands a woman representing the Catholic Church with a cross, a dove, and a book. Cherubs or angels support a portrait of Hernán Cortés. Other women representing industry (with a beehive and bees) and plenty (with a cornucopia of fruit) stand beside the crowned woman. Also includes the royal coat of arms of Ferdinand VII, scepter, and laurel wreath.
Source_Title: México conquistada. Poema heroyco
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta Real, por D. Pedro Julian Pereyra, impresor de cámara de S.M.
notes: The author, a courtier, priest, and writer, here defends the Spanish conquest of Mexico. He was tutor to the heir-apparent, who was later Ferdinand VII. The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Luis Paret y Alcázar (1746-1799).

Image_title: Geometrical Details of the Monuments of Easter Island
Description: Fig. 1. Plan of a Stone Hut. Fig 2. 1st Section of the Stone Hut taken in the line DD. Fig. 3. 2d Section of the Stone Hut taken in line XX, Fig. 4. Elevatin of the Stone Hut. Fig. 5. Plan of a large Hut. Fig. 6 Frame of the large Hut. Fig. 7. Section of the large Hut taken in line FF. Fig. 8. Plan of a Morai [moai] or Burying Place. Fig. 9. Height of the Morai [moai]. Section of the Morai [moai] taken in the line MM. Image placed horizontally on page.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788
Source_Title: [Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde. English] A voyage round the world in the years 1785, 1786, 1787, and 1788
Source_publisher: Printed by A. Hamilton, for G.G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row; J. Edwards, Pall-Mall; and T. Payne, Mews-gate, Castle-Street.
notes: The French decided to mount a scientific and exploration voyage to rival that of Captain James Cook. Two ships, the Boussole and the Astrolabe, under La P�rouse's command left France in August 1785. They spent the summer of 1786 off the coasts of Alaska looking for a northwest passage then sailed down the west coast of North America in August and September 1786. In September they crossed the Pacific Ocean to Asia. They first sailed north and then south to Australia which they reached in January 1788. In mid-March both ships were wrecked on a coral reef near the island of Vanikoro with all hands lost. Thirty years later remains were found, and islanders reported that survivors had built a boat and headed out to sea, but none were ever heard from again. La P�rouse sent letters back to Europe from Manila, Macao, and Australia; this is how the voyage is known. In October 1787 he had also sent a Russian-speaking officer, Jean Baptiste Barth�lemy, Baron de Lesseps (1766-1834) overland from Kamchatka with documents, charts, and journals. De Lesseps traveled through Siberia to St. Petersburg and then to Paris, arriving late in 1788. In May 1791, when it seemed clear that La P�rouse would not return, the revolutionary government commissioned former army officer Louis Antoine Milet-Mureau (1756-1825) to edit a book from these materials, which was published in Paris in four volumes with an atlas in 1797. A second French edition was required the following year, and English translations appeared in 1798, 1799, 1801, and 1807; German and Dutch editions were published between 1799 and 1804.

Image_title: View of Cavite in the Bay of Manilla
Description: View of the town of Cavite in the bay of Manila includes outrigger boats. Also includes a volcano, church nets, and ships. Image shown horizontally on page.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788
Source_Title: [Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde. English] A voyage round the world in the years 1785, 1786, 1787, and 1788
Source_publisher: Printed by A. Hamilton, for G.G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row; J. Edwards, Pall-Mall; and T. Payne, Mews-gate, Castle-Street.
notes: De Vancy was the official artist of the La Perouse expedition, on which he disappeared, perhaps in Vanikoro. The French decided to mount a scientific and exploration voyage to rival that of Captain James Cook. Two ships, the Boussole and the Astrolabe, under La Perouse's command left France in August 1785. They spent the summer of 1786 off the coasts of Alaska looking for a northwest passage then sailed down the west coast of North America in August and September 1786. In September they crossed the Pacific Ocean to Asia. They first sailed north and then south to Australia which they reached in January 1788. In mid-March both ships were wrecked on a coral reef near the island of Vanikoro with all hands lost. Thirty years later remains were found, and islanders reported that survivors had built a boat and headed out to sea, but none were ever heard from again. La Perouse sent letters back to Europe from Manila, Macao, and Australia; this is how the voyage is known. In October 1787 he had also sent a Russian-speaking officer, Jean Baptiste Barthélemy, Baron de Lesseps (1766-1834) overland from Kamchatka with documents, charts, and journals. De Lesseps traveled through Siberia to St. Petersburg and then to Paris, arriving late in 1788. In May 1791, when it seemed clear that La Pérouse would not return, the revolutionary government commissioned former army officer Louis Antoine Milet-Mureau (1756-1825) to edit a book from these materials, which was published in Paris in four volumes with an atlas in 1797. A second French edition was required the following year, and English translations appeared in 1798, 1799, 1801, and 1807; German and Dutch editions were published between 1799 and 1804.

Image_title: Physeter, or Spermaceti Whale. Drawn by Scale, from one killed on the Coast of Mexico, August 1793. and hoisted in on Deck.
Description: Sperm whale showing the way it should be butchered. Includes a scale. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text.
Source_Title: A voyage to the South Atlantic and round Cape Horn into the Pacific Ocean, for the purpose of extending the spermaceti whale fisheries ...
Source_publisher: printed for the author, by W. Bennett. Sold by A. Arrowsmith; Stockdale; Edgerton; Elmsly; and White
notes: Colnett had accompanied Captain James Cook on his third voyage. This narrative records the voyage to the South Atlantic to open it to sperm whale hunting.

Image_title: Amaryllis formosissima.
Description: Amaryllis formosissima, Aztec lily, Jacobean lily, St. James's lily, or orchid lily showing only the flower and stem.
Source_Title: The botanic garden. A poem, in two parts. Part I. Containing the economy of vegetation. Part II. The loves of the plants. With philosophical notes
Source_publisher: Printed by T. & J. Swords, printers to the faculty of physic of Columbia College, no. 99 Pearl-Street.
notes: Amaryllis formosissima is synonymous with Sprekelia formosissima and is native to Mexico and Guatemala.Attributed to Erasmus Darwin in the Dictionary of national biography. Darwin's goal was to popularize and promote the sexual or reproductive basis of Linnaeus' system of classification.

Image_title: Fucus natans, vernaculé Sargazo.
Image_publisher: Widow and son of Petro Marin
Description: Gulfweed, seaweed, or Sargassum natans or Sargassum bacciferum, showing stem, leaves, flowers, seed pods and detail of pistil and stamen. Items in the image are numbered and lettered for identification in preceding text.
Source_Title: Hippolyti Ruiz, Regiae Academiae Med. Matrit. Socii, et Peruvianae Expedit. Botanici Primarii, De vera fuci natantis fructificatione. Commentarius
Source_publisher: Apud viduam et filium Petri Marin
notes: The Sargasso Sea is named after the Spanish word for seaweed, saragazo.Eager to showcase the pharmacological importance of South American plants, the Spanish crown sponsored several botanical surveys of the New World. Ruiz was the director of the survey of Chile and Peru and published a number of successful scientific publications.Francisco de Suria was a Spanish engraver.

Image_title: Male Liane of Chili. Called by the Inhabitants Guilboqua.
Description: Male plant of a kind of vine found in Chile. Includes details of all parts of the flower.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788

Image_title: Larger View of the Female Liane of Chili.
Description: Larger view of the female plant of a kind of vine found in Chile. Includes details of all parts of the flower and fruit.

Image_title: The Presidio of Monterrey.
Creator2_role: Sketch taken on the Spot by
Image_publisher: R. Edwards, J. Edwards, & G. Robinson
Description: View of the presedio or mission of Monterey. Includes view of fortification, domestic animals such as horse, tent, boat, and dwellings.
Source_Title: A voyage of discovery to the North Pacific Ocean, and round the world ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for G. G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row; and J. Edwards, Pall-Mall
notes: Vancouver visited present-day California on his way from the northwest of North America to the Sandwich Islands or Hawaii. Vancouver explored the coast of present-day British Columbia, proving that there was no Northwest Passage at that latitude, and was instrumental in negotiations with the Spanish on possession of Nootka. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: A Remarkable Mountain near the River of Monterrey.
Creator2_role: Sketch taken on the Spot by
Image_publisher: R. Edwards, J. Edwards, & G. Robinson
Description: View of a mountain near the Monterey River. Includes a man riding on a horse led by another man.
Source_Title: A voyage of discovery to the North Pacific Ocean, and round the world ... Vol. III
Source_publisher: Printed for G. G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row; and J. Edwards, Pall-Mall

Image_title: The Village of Almandral in the Bay of Valparaiso with a distant View of the Andes.
Creator2_role: Sketch taken on the Spot by
Image_publisher: R. Edwards, J. Edwards, & G. Robinson
Description: View of the settlement at Valparaiso, Chile. Includes dwellings, ships, and boats.
Source_Title: A voyage of discovery to the North Pacific Ocean, and round the world ... Vol. III
Source_publisher: Printed for G. G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row; and J. Edwards, Pall-Mall
notes: Vancouver explored the coast of present-day British Columbia, proving that there was no Northwest Passage at that latitude, and was instrumental in negotiations with the Spanish on possession of Nootka. The Almendral section of Valparaiso is where the Chilean national congress presently meets. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The Mission of St. Carlos, near Monterrey.
Creator2_role: Sketch taken on the Spot by
Image_publisher: R. Edwards, J. Edwards, & G. Robinson
Description: View of the mission of San Carlos Borromeo de Carmelo. Includes dwellings, bells, graveyard, palisade with cattle, horse, ladders, church, crucifixes or crosses, and group of people [native Americans?] slaughtering an animal.
Source_Title: A voyage of discovery to the North Pacific Ocean, and round the world ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for G. G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row; and J. Edwards, Pall-Mall
notes: San Carlos Borromeo de Carmelo, the second of the 21 missions of California, was founded by Father Serra in 1770 on the site of a presidio chapel in Monterey, about 115 miles south of San Francisco, and served as the ecclesiastical capital of California, as well as the administrative headquarters for Father Serra. Vancouver explored the coast of present-day British Columbia, proving that there was no Northwest Passage at that latitude, and was instrumental in negotiations with the Spanish on possession of Nootka. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Dress of the Inhabitants of Conception.
Description: Men and women dressed in high fashion stand before a bay or harbor in Concepcion, in present-day Chile. Also includes a dwelling, ships, and ponchos. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Inhabitants and Monuments of Easter Island.
Description: European men sit with native Easter Islanders. Include some moai. One woman looks at herself in a mirror. Others look at books or papers a man is holding. Also includes feathered headdresses. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Dress of the Inhabitants of Conception.
Description: Men and women dressed in high fashion stand before a bay or harbor in Concepcion, in present-day Chile. Also includes a dwelling, ships, and ponchos. Image placed horizontally on page.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788
Source_Title: [Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde. English] A voyage round the world in the years 1785, 1786, 1787, and 1788
Source_publisher: Printed by A. Hamilton, for G.G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row; J. Edwards, Pall-Mall; and T. Payne, Mews-gate, Castle-Street.
notes: De Vancy was the official artist of the La Perouse expedition, on which he disappeared, perhaps in Vanikoro. The French decided to mount a scientific and exploration voyage to rival that of Captain James Cook. Two ships, the Boussole and the Astrolabe, under La Perouse's command left France in August 1785. They spent the summer of 1786 off the coasts of Alaska looking for a northwest passage then sailed down the west coast of North America in August and September 1786. In September they crossed the Pacific Ocean to Asia. They first sailed north and then south to Australia which they reached in January 1788. In mid-March both ships were wrecked on a coral reef near the island of Vanikoro with all hands lost. Thirty years later remains were found, and islanders reported that survivors had built a boat and headed out to sea, but none were ever heard from again. La Perouse sent letters back to Europe from Manila, Macao, and Australia; this is how the voyage is known. In October 1787 he had also sent a Russian-speaking officer, Jean Baptiste Barthélemy, Baron de Lesseps (1766-1834) overland from Kamchatka with documents, charts, and journals. De Lesseps traveled through Siberia to St. Petersburg and then to Paris, arriving late in 1788. In May 1791, when it seemed clear that La Pérouse would not return, the revolutionary government commissioned former army officer Louis Antoine Milet-Mureau (1756-1825) to edit a book from these materials, which was published in Paris in four volumes with an atlas in 1797. A second French edition was required the following year, and English translations appeared in 1798, 1799, 1801, and 1807; German and Dutch editions were published between 1799 and 1804.

Image_title: [top] Parao, a passage boat of Manilla. [bottom] Sarambeau, a fishing raft of Manilla
Description: [top] Boat or parao of Manila, Philippines. [bottom] Fishing raft of Manila. Includes nets, men walking out on a bowsprit or outrigger, and ships.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788

Image_title: [top] Canoe of Tchotka. [bottom] Canoe of Easter Island.
Description: [top] Boat or canoe of Tchotka. [bottom] Canoe of Easter Island. Includes native Americans wearing a wicker or basket hat and feathered [?] headdress. Also includes outrigger.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788

Image_title: Dress of the inhabitants of Manilla.
Description: View of women and a man dressed in a style common to Manila in the Philippines.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788
Source_Title: [Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde. English] A voyage round the world in the years 1785, 1786, 1787, and 1788

Image_title: D. Antonio de Solis
Description: Portrait of Antonio de Solís y Ribadeneyra, author of this book, wearing spectacles or pince nez. Includes quills and ink pot, books, laurel wreath and trumpet or horn.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo I
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Antonio de Solís, secretary of state and private secretary to Philip IV, was chronicler of the Indies and published this classic work first in 1684.

Image_title: Hernan Cortés.
Description: Portrait of Hernán Cortés. Includes helmet, baton, sword, and laurel wreath.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo I
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II).

Image_title: Pasa muestra el exercito de los Españoles.
Description: Man on horseback wearing armor enters a town or settlement. Crowds of soldiers welcome him. Includes cannon, swabs, cannon balls, guns or muskets, swords, flag, and fortifications.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo IV
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Text discusses Hernan Cortés's defeat of Xicotencal at Tlaxcala.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Vese Cortes en evidente peligro de perderse.
Description: Soldier with shield and sword fights native American soldiers who wield war clubs. Includes bodies on the ground, horse, and dwellings.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo V
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Text discusses Hernan Cortés and his apparent defeat at Quauhnahuac [Quatlabaca]. Instead, helped by a Tlascalan, the Spanish discovered an entry into the settlement and conquered it.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Sale Cortes á recibir á Guatimozin que se le traian prisionero.
Description: Hernán Cortés receives the native American leader, Guatimozin, before he makes him his prisoner.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo V
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Guatimozin or Cuauhtémoc/Cuauhtemotzin was a nephew of Moctezuma II and was the last Aztec emperor. On August 13, 1521, on his way to ask for reinforcements from the lakeshore villages, he was captured by Cortés's officer, Holguin. Guatimozin then surrendered to Cortés and was kept as a hostage by him until Cortés decided to hang him on February 26, 1525. Cortés held his feet to a fire to extract information about the riches of the Aztec.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Asaltan los Mexicanos el quartel, y son rechazados.
Description: Scene of warfare as Mexicans or native Americans attack Spanish soldiers. Includes feathered headdresses and garments, swords, shields, bows, guns or muskets, and fortifications.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo IV
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Text describes the events of the Noche Triste, July 1, 1520, when Hernán Cortés' conquest of the Aztec was nearly halted at Tenochtitlan, and Cortés himself barely escaped. Cortés sent Diego de Ordaz with the Spanish's best resources to fight against the Aztec but the overwhelming number of Aztec soldiers meant their victory. In the end only a small proportion of Spanish escaped.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Pelease de noche en la calzada de Mexico, y se consigue la retirada.
Description: Scene of warfare as Mexicans or native Americans attack Spanish soldiers. They fight on a causeway to Mexico City or Tenochtitlán in the night. Includes feathered headdresses and garments, horse, shields, fortifications, guns or muskets firing, and swords.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo IV
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: The Spanish managed a narrow escape from Tenochtitlán across a causeway while they were being attacked from the rear. The event, known as Noche Triste (June 30 to July 1, 1520) resulted in Hernan Cortes loosing much of the treasure which he had looted.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Batalla de Otumba en que venció Cortes todo el poder mexicano, y ganó el Estandarte.
Description: The battle of Otumba or a scene of warfare as Mexicans or native Americans fight Spanish soldiers. A man on horseback stabs a Mexican ruler or king who is carried on a litter and who holds a standard surmounted by feathers. Includes feathered headdresses and garments, horses, shields, and swords.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo IV
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Hernan Cortés lost 870 men at the battle of Otumba in 1520, and his army fled to Tlaxcala to obtain reinforcements. Encountering a legion of Aztec soldiers sent by Cuitlahuac, Moctezuma's brother and successor, the Spanish decisively won the battle.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Levantase una fortaleza con el nombre de Segura de la Frontera.
Description: Native Americans build a fort. Includes men carrying stones, carving or chiseling stone blocks, using pulleys, and using a scaffolding of wooden poles to build walls. Also includes hammers, mallets, or chisels, compass, baskets, and feathered garments.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de México, poblacion y progresos de la América septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... tomo IV
Source_publisher: Por Cano
notes: Hernan Cortés won a decisive battle over Tepeyacac with no Spanish deaths. Tepeyacac pledged himself and his troops to the Spanish, and Cortes founded and fortified a fort at Segura de la Frontera to solidify his position.The painter of the work from which this engraving was made is probably Antonio Rodríguez (1765-1823).

Image_title: Krameria triandra
Image_publisher: Widow and son of Petro Marin
Description: Ratanya plant, also known as Krameria root, Peruvian rhatany, red rhatany, and rhatany root, showing entire plant including roots, stems, leaves, flowers, seed pods and detail of pistil and stamens. Items in the image are numbered for identification in preceding text.
Source_Title: Disertacion sobre la raiz de la ratánhia, específico singular contra los fluxos de sangre ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la viuda e hijo de Marín
notes: The root of the ratanya plant is used medicinally. Eager to showcase the pharmacological importance of South American plants, the Spanish crown sponsored several botanical surveys of the New World. Ruiz was the director of the survey of Chile and Peru and published a number of successful scientific publications.

Image_title: The manner in which the Natives of Paraguay, (Spanish South America) catch their Bullocks - for the purpose of Killing them.
Description: Native Americans or gauchos lasso bulls from horseback. Includes pen full of cattle.
Source_Title: A visible display of divine providence; or, The journal of a captured missionary, designated to the Southern Pacific Ocean, in the second voyage of the ship Duff, ... captured by Le Grand Buonaparte, ...
Source_publisher: Printed by T. Gillet, Salisbury-Square, for, and sold by the author, no. 100, Whitehorse-Street, Ratcliffe-Cross; Ogle, Turnstile; Button and Symmonds, Paternoster-Row, London; and by all booksellers and newscarriers in the three kingdoms.
notes: The location may or may not be present-day Paraguay.The ship Duff had previously taken part in the first mission to the South Pacific during which voyage the Gambier Islands were discovered. On its second voyage, with Gregory, his wife and four children aboard, it was captured by the ship Le Grand Buonaparte off Cape Frio in 1799. Cape Frio or Cabo Frio is in the present-day Rio de Janeiro state of Brazil. After leaving Montevideo, the missionaries were captured by the Portuguese.Image placed horizontally on page.Plates at end of book are misbound.Cf. 05764-3 for a later use of this image.

Image_title: View of a Carataa as drawn in Paraguay Spanish South America
Description: Closed oxcart with second driver on horseback. Includes two crosses by the roadside.
Source_Title: A visible display of divine providence; or, The journal of a captured missionary, designated to the Southern Pacific Ocean, in the second voyage of the ship Duff, ... captured by Le Grand Buonaparte, ...
Source_publisher: Printed by T. Gillet, Salisbury-Square, for, and sold by the author, no. 100, Whitehorse-Street, Ratcliffe-Cross; Ogle, Turnstile; Button and Symmonds, Paternoster-Row, London; and by all booksellers and newscarriers in the three kingdoms.
notes: This is the cart that conveyed the Gregory's luggage from their first, insalubrious, house to the second. It was in the second house that Mrs. Gregory gave birth to a child. The ship Duff had previously taken part in the first mission to the South Pacific during which voyage the Gambier Islands were discovered. On its second voyage, with Gregory, his wife and four children aboard, it was captured by the ship Le Grand Buonaparte off Cape Frio in 1799. Cape Frio or Cabo Frio is in the present-day Rio de Janeiro state of Brazil. After leaving Montevideo, the missionaries were captured by the Portuguese.The location may or may not be present-day Paraguay.Image placed horizontally on page.Plates at end of book are misbound.Cf. 05764-4 for a later use of this image.

Image_title: [Our Lady of Guadalupe]
Image_publisher: José Mariano de Zúñiga y Ontiveros
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe with starry cloak, crescent moon, crown, flowers, and angel.
Source_Title: Salutacion á María Santísima de Guadalupe, practica devota para venerarla en su santuario, quando se le hace la visita ...
Source_publisher: Por D. Mariano de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico--Guadalupe Hidalgo

Image_title: a. Cinchona angustifolia. b. Gonzalagunia dependens.
Description: Cinchona tree showing branch, leaves, and flowers. Includes details of flowers and seeds. Parts of seeds and flowers of Gonzalagunia dependens are illustrated at the bottom of image. Items in the image are lettered and numbered for identification in text.
Source_Title: Suplemento á la Quinologia, en el qual se aumentan las especies de quina nuevamente descubiertas en el Perú por don Juan Tafalla
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la viuda e hijo de Marín
notes: Cinchona or quinine bark was first documented for its curative effects on malaria in 1638 when the countess of Cinchon, wife of a Peruvian viceroy, was supposed to have been cured of a malarial type fever. Cinchona, one of forty species of trees, was not botanically classified until 1737. Until the seeds were stolen in 1865 and successfully planted in the Dutch East Indies, the tropical forests of northwestern South America were the sole sources of this valuable medicine.Scientific name: Cinchona officinalis.Gonzalagunia is a genus of plant in family Rubiaceae.

Image_title: Plano y vista interior del Panteon erigido en el Convento de N.P.S. Fran[cis]co de Lima por su actual Guardian el R.P. Fr. Antonio Diaz año de 1803.
Description: Plan of the graveyard or mausoleum for the Convent of San Francisco in Lima. Includes at bottom a view of the inside of the mausoleum. Includes crosses, chapel, ossuary, compass rose, location of various burial sites.
Source_Title: Discurso sobre el panteon que está construyendo en el Convento Grande de San Francisco de esta capital el R.P. guardian fray Antonio Diaz
Source_publisher: En la Real Imprenta de Niños Espósitos
notes: The church of San Francisco in Lima was completed in 1774 and is noted for its neoclassical architecture. Catacombs below the monastery contain an ossuary.
SubjectHeadings2: Panteón del Convento de San Francisco (Lima, Peru)

Image_title: [People of ancient Mexico]
Description: People of Tenochtitlan or ancient Mexico, including laborers, a nobleman, a noble lady, a soldier, and a priest or shaman. Includes a hoe or cultivating tool, a basket, a feather fan, shield, sword, and chalice or cup.
Source_Title: Sermon panegirico de la gloriosa aparicion de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, que en el dia 12 de diciembre de 1801 ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de doña Maria Fernandez Jauregui, calle de Stô. Domingo

Image_title: Juegos Mexicanos
Description: Method of dancing among native Mexicans. Men dance while standing on each other's shoulders and while standing on a log. Other men balance on a log which a third man keeps aloft by lying on his back and holding the log with his feet.
Source_Title: Sermon panegirico de la gloriosa aparicion de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, que en el dia 12 de diciembre de 1801 ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de doña Maria Fernandez Jauregui, calle de Stô. Domingo
notes: Text describes the dancing of the natives of Mexico. Some danced on each other's shoulders, others balanced on logs held up by other men.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of Mexico--Social life and customs

Image_title: Templo mayor de Mexico.
Description: The sacrificial temple [the Templo Mayor] at Tenochtitlan. Includes the square the temple is in, dwellings, and the settlement or city outside its gates.
Source_Title: Sermon panegirico de la gloriosa aparicion de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, que en el dia 12 de diciembre de 1801 ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de doña Maria Fernandez Jauregui, calle de Stô. Domingo
notes: The major Aztec temple at Tenochtitlan [Mexico City] was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc (the god of rain), the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli (the god of the sun and war).

Image_title: Sacrificio ordinario.
Description: Human sacrifice. A priest or shaman removes a beating heart from the victim who is held down by other men. Includes a feathered headdress and decorated tilmas or cloaks.
Source_Title: Sermon panegirico de la gloriosa aparicion de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, que en el dia 12 de diciembre de 1801 ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de doña Maria Fernandez Jauregui, calle de Stô. Domingo
notes: The offering of the victim's heart to the gods satisfied the Aztec belief that the sun would rise again nourished by the hearts of men.

Image_title: Sacrificio Gladiatorio.
Description: Scene of sacrifice and gladiatorial fighting among native Mexicans. One man's foot is tied to a large stone while another man wearing a feathered headdress fights him. Includes settlement or city, dwellings, shield, swords, and spectators.
Source_Title: Sermon panegirico de la gloriosa aparicion de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, que en el dia 12 de diciembre de 1801 ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de doña Maria Fernandez Jauregui, calle de Stô. Domingo
notes: This sacrificial rite was celebrated on the festival of tlacaxipehualiztli in honor of Xipe Tótec. Xipe Tótec, "our flayed lord," was the god of agriculture, death, rebirth, and the seasons. At his festival in the spring, men were tethered to an altar stone, or temalacatl. Once defeated, the victim was flayed and his skin worn by priests. A description of this festival is given in the Codex Durán

Image_title: Nra. Sra. de la Pobreza. Que se venera en la Yglesa. del Conveto. de Sn. Franco. de Cartago ...
Description: Image of Our Lady of Poverty wearing a crown and holding a crowned Christ Child. She stands on a crescent moon and is surrounded by angels who drop roses or flowers and hold rosaries.
Source_creator: Campo y Rivas, Manuel del, ca. 1755-1830
Source_Title: Compendio histórico de la fundacion, progresos, y estado actual de la ciudad de Cartago en la provincia de Popayán en el Nuevo Reyno de Granada ...
Source_publisher: En la Oficina de Don Mariano Valdés Tellez Giron
notes: The image of Our Lady of Poverty was venerated in the convent of San Francisco in Cartago, Colombia.
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2007. Formerly owned by Maury A. Bromsen
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Colombia

Image_title: Dei Parenti. Mariae. Septemtrionalis. Americae. In. Guadalupana. Imagine. ... Joannis. Antonii. Bruno. ...
Image_publisher: Apud Marianum Zunnigam & Ontiverium, ad viam Spiritus Sancti.
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe with roses, starry cloak, and angel made for Juan Antonio Bruno and printed on silk to be carried in a religious procession.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it filled with out-of-season roses.

Image_title: Plano Geografico que demuestra la antigua cituacion de Mexico sus Lagunas y Poblaciones inmediatas, en tienpo de la Gentilidad
Description: Plan of Tenochtitlan [Mexico City] as it was before the Spanish invasion. Includes location of settlements around the lakes of Chalco and Tezcuco [Texcoco]. Also includes location of the chinampas and bridges. Cartographic elements include compass rose and scale.
Source_Title: Sermon panegirico de la gloriosa aparicion de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, que en el dia 12 de diciembre de 1801 ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de doña Maria Fernandez Jauregui, calle de Stô. Domingo
notes: The Aztecs created artificial islands called chinampas which were made by piling earth from the bottom of Lake Texcoco onto rafts made of weeds. After a while, the roots of the plants and trees grew down to the lake bottom, creating new farmland.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: El Señor de Santa Teresa.
Image_publisher: José Mariano de Zúñiga y Ontiveros
Description: Image of Christ Crucified [Cristo renovado] on an altar with four vases[?]. Includes the legend, "INRI" above the cross.
Source_Title: Ofrecimiento de las cinco llagas, que á expensas de un devoto se reimprimen para el mayor culto del Smô. Christo milagrosamente renovado, que se venera en la iglesia del convento de religiosas de Santa Teresa la Antigua
Source_publisher: por don Mariano de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: Known variously as the Señor de Santa Teresa, the Cristo Renovado de Ixmiquilpan, the Cristo de El Cardonal, or simply the Cristo Renovado, this image shows the nearly life-size crucifix that was removed to Mexico City in 1623 from the small mining community of Mapethé just north of El Cardonal in the western hills of modern Hidalgo State. INRI is an acronym of the Latin inscription which translates to English as "Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews.

Image_title: [Pyramid at Papantla]

Image_title: [Temple at Xochicalco]

Image_title: [Temple of the Feathered Serpent, Xochicalco]

Source_Title: Due antichi monumenti di architettura messicana ...
Source_publisher: Presso il Salomoni
notes: A Mexican Jesuit who left Mexico to go to Italy when the Jesuits were expelled in 1767, Pedro José Marquez wrote in Italian on architecture and fine arts. The ruins of Xochicalco had first been brought to European attention by José Antonio de Alzate y Ramírez in 1791. Xochicalco means "in the House of Flowers" in the Nahuatl language. Quetzalcoatl, the Aztec god, was known as the Feathered Serpent.

Image_title: [Monument to those killed during the defense of Buenos Aires]
Description: Monument [catafalque] to those killed during the defense of Buenos Aires during the English invasions of 1808. Includes allegorical figures, candelabras, urns with smoke coming out of them, skull, flags, military matériel such as cannon balls, shields, swords, armor, and spears. Also includes a coat of arms with a crown and three clasped hands.
Source_Title: Oracion funebre que en las solemnes exequias celebradas en la Iglesia del Espiritu Santo de la Puebla a devocion y expensas de los hijos y oriundos de Vizcaya y de Navarra, por todos los que murieron en la gloriosa defensa de Buenos-Ayres ...
Source_publisher: En la oficina de Arizpe
notes: Between March 1806 and January 1808, the British launched several assaults against Spanish fortifications in Buenos Aires and Montevideo. Sir Home Popham, British naval commander at the Cape of Good Hope, launched these attacks (without official authorization) to bring free trade to the region of the Rio de la Plata and thus reconcile the local population to British rule. His plan backfired and, instead, the British expedition sparked local resistance to the British, as well as a popular uprising against Spanish authority in the area. Spanish claim to power was undermined by the apparent unwillingness of the Spanish Viceroy to defend Buenos Aires against the British and by the success of local efforts to defend the city. These events stimulated a revolt which led to independence from Spain in 1810.

Image_title: 1. Patagon. 3. Autruche. 2. Patagone.
Description: A native American man, woman, and children from Patagonia stand next to a rhea, here identified as an ostrich. Includes tattoos, a boleadora, and arrows. Items are numbered for identification in key below the image.
Source_Title: Collection abrégée des voyages anciens et modernes autour du monde; avec des extraits des autres voyageurs les plus célèbres et les plus récents ... Tome second
Source_publisher: De l'imprimerie de F. Dufart, père
notes: This image illustrates the voyage of Sir Francis Drake.Boleadoras were tools used by indigenous peoples of the Argentinean Pampas to hunt. Boleadoras consisted of two stones bound by a leather cord which were thrown and then used to lasso an animal. Compiled by François Bancarel, this is a collection of voyages, notably of the Pacific.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Patagonia (Argentina and Chile)

The woman holds a basket of flowers or fruit and carries her child on her back. Items are numbered for identification in key below the image.
Source_Title: Collection abrégée des voyages anciens et modernes autour du monde; avec des extraits des autres voyageurs les plus célèbres et les plus récents ... Tome second
Source_publisher: De l'imprimerie de F. Dufart, père
notes: This image illustrates the voyage of Sir Francis Drake.A fierce tribe of indigenous people who live in present-day Bolivia, the Mojos [Moxos] resisted Christianity until the late seventeenth century.Compiled by François Bancarel, this is a collection of voyages, notably of the Pacific. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Plan of the Harbour of Sn. Carlos or St. Charles, situated on the North part of the Island of Chiloe.
Image_publisher: W. Faden, Geographer to His Majesty ...
Description: Map and chart of the harbor of San Carlos or Saint Charles on the island of Chiloe (Isla Grande de Chiloé) off the coast of Chile. Cartographic elements include compass rose, soundings, locations of shoals, military installations, topographical details, and scale.
notes: Spain claimed the island in 1567, and a settlement was founded at Castro in 1567, later the seat of a Jesuit mission and capital of the province until the founding of Ancud in 1768. In 1784 Chiloé Island was made a direct dependency of the colonial viceroyalty of Peru, while continental Chile was a captaincy-general within the viceroyalty. In December 1817 the island became the last stronghold of Spanish loyalists (together with Valdivia) fleeing from the Chilean mainland. A Chilean expedition led by Thomas Cochrane, 10th Earl of Dundonald failed to conquer it. On 15 January 1826, after another unsuccessful attempt in 1824, the Spanish forces surrendered to a military expedition led by Ramon Freire, and the island was fully incorporated into the independent republic of Chile, although Spain did not recognize it until 1844. In atlas with binder's title Charts, West Indies & North & South America - 1789-1808.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Habitants de la Terre de Feu.

notes: This image illustrates the voyage of Jacques l'Hermite.The indigenous inhabitants of Tierra del Fuego were known as Fuegians. They belonged to several tribes including the Ona (Selk'nam), Haush (Manek'enk), Yahgan (Yámana), and Alacaluf (Kawésqar) and are now considered extinct.Compiled by François Bancarel, this is a collection of voyages, notably of the Pacific. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Sketch of the Country from Reduction to Buenos Ayres, shewing the movements of B: Genl. Beresford, when he Captured that place June 1806. ... by Capt: Donnelly
Description: Chart of Buenos Aires showing the attack of the British under General William Beresford on June 26, 1806. Geographical, topographical, and military features are given, as well as a scale, soundings, and details of military campaign. Decorative elements include ships. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at bottom.
Source_Title: [cover title] Manuscript Maps for the South American Campaigns of 1806-7
notes: Between March 1806 and January 1808, the British launched several assaults against Spanish fortifications in Buenos Aires and Montevideo. Sir Home Popham, British naval commander at the Cape of Good Hope, launched these attacks (without official authorization) to bring free trade to the region of the Rio de la Plata and thus reconcile the local population to British rule. His plan backfired and, instead, the British expedition sparked local resistance to the British, as well as a popular uprising against Spanish authority in the area. Spanish claim to power was undermined by the apparent unwillingness of the Spanish Viceroy to defend Buenos Aires against the British and by the success of local efforts to defend the city. These events stimulated a revolt which led to independence from Spain in 1810. This item is included in a collection of manuscript maps hinged in a folio album titled, Manuscript Maps for the South American Campaigns of 1806-7.
References: Grainger, J. D., ed. Royal Navy in the River Plate, 1806-1807

Image_title: [Allegorical union of Spain and Guatemala]
Description: Two worlds [?] clasp hands under a crown. They rest on a lion [Europe?] and an alligator [the New World?]. Includes a settlement with church in the background, and an eye within a triangle [eye of Providence or the all-seeing eye] shines over the figures.
Source_Title: Et que rey ninguno, que no hobiesse poder de facer cort sin conseio de los ricos homes naturales del regno ...
Source_publisher: Apud Beteta
notes: The eye of Providence, often shown within a triangle, represents the eye of God watching humanity.

Image_title: [Apparitions of victory in the sky]
Description: Three cloud formations in the shape of palms in the sky in Zitácuaro and in Cuautla.
Source_Title: Sermon que en el aniversario solemne de Gracias a María Santísima de los remedios ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de Arizpe
notes: Medina places this image before p. 249, an addendum (presumably written after the 1811 publication date of this book) which describes how an apparition of palms of victory appeared in the sky before Spanish victories during the wars of Mexican independence. Rebels in Zitácuaro had attempted to establish an independent government and were attacked by royalist forces under General Felix Maria Calleja. After winning the battle in Zitácuaro at the beginning of January 1812, Calleja marched on to Cuautla. The battle of Cuautla ended in May 1812 with Calleja claiming victory, but with his forces badly weakened.This image was engraved from a sketch done by Diego Miguel Bringas, emmissary from the Colegio Apotolico de la Santa Cruz de Queretaro. One shape appeared two days before the battle in Zitácuaro, the other one day before the same battle. The third shape appeared in Cuautla. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: N. S. de la O.
Description: Image of the pregnant Virgin on a pedestal. Includes flower, angels, crown, and halo.
Source_Title: Origen, progresos y actual estado del contrato espiritual o Congregacion de seglares de nuestra Señora de la O, fundada en la Iglesia principal de San Pedro y San Pablo, que en esta ciudad de Lima, capital del Reyno del Perú, ocupan los RR. PP. del Oratorio de San Felipe Neri ...
Source_publisher: Siendo asistente mayor tesorero D. José Antonio de Errea. Por D. Bernardino Ruiz
notes: The Congregación de la O was founded in Lima, Jan. 4, 1632. This image of the pregnant Mary is in a chapel of the Jesuit church of San Pedro y San Pablo in Lima, Peru. The chapel is named after the Magnificat, an antiphon sung on the 8 days preceding the Nativity, which begins with the Latin word, "O."
SubjectHeadings2: Congregación de Seglares de Nuestra Señora de la O (Lima, Peru)

Image_title: Azteck hieroglyphical MS. in the Vatican Library.
Description: Two men wrestle before a figure of an Aztec goddess who sits before a snake. Six glyphs (including those for monkey, dog, and rabbit) are found at the top of the scene.
Source_Title: [Vues des Cordillères et monumens des peuples indigènes de l'Amérique. English] Researches, concerning the institutions & monuments of the ancient inhabitants of America ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, J. Murray & H. Colburn
notes: The text describes the goddess, Cihuacoatl, also called Quilaztli or Tonacacihua. She was considered the mother of the human race. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: A Lawsuit in Hieroglyphics.
Description: An Aztec lawsuit over ownership of a farm. A plan of the farm is shown with complainants, one native American and Spaniards (wearing beards and hats), who defend their positions. Spanish judges are shown with laws placed before them. Glyphs identify each complainant. A ruler sits on a reed throne.
Source_Title: [Vues des Cordillères et monumens des peuples indigènes de l'Amérique. English] Researches, concerning the institutions & monuments of the ancient inhabitants of America ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, J. Murray & H. Colburn
notes: The text explains how the complainants would present their cases to the judge of the district. The king might also sit in judgment on the case. This hieroglyphical description of the dispute served to record what had happened during the case, because the sentence was not immediatedly pronounced. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Statue of an Azteck Priestess.
Description: Front and back view of a statue of an Aztec priestess with an elaborate headdress.
Source_Title: [Vues des Cordillères et monumens des peuples indigènes de l'Amérique. English] Researches, concerning the institutions & monuments of the ancient inhabitants of America ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, J. Murray & H. Colburn
notes: This may be either a representation of the Aztec corn goddess Xilonen, or a priestess impersonating her. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: View of Cotopaxi in present-day Ecuador.
Source_Title: [Vues des Cordillères et monumens des peuples indigènes de l'Amérique. English] Researches, concerning the institutions & monuments of the ancient inhabitants of America ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, J. Murray & H. Colburn
notes: Cotopaxi is a stratovolcano which has erupted 50 times since 1738.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Simon Bolivar.
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: This engraving is not included in Boulton, although he cites a variant work (00-138), and is not recorded in any institutional collection.

Image_title: [View of Buenos Aires]
Description: View of Buenos Aires in present-day Argentina. Includes bay, churches, dwellings, carriage, two men, and a horse.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Pampa Indians]
Description: Pampa Indians sit and stand in from of a store which has stirrups and riding crops or whips on display. Includes jaguar skins and feathers.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: The Pampa Indians or Querandíes no longer exist as a group. They became intermixed with Mapuche. Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi.

Image_title: [Recova in Buenos Aires]
Description: View of the marketplace or recoba on the Plaza de Mayo in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Includes horse, carriages or carts, merchants selling birds, soldiers with guns or muskets, and men and women conversing.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: Text describes the marketplace and cabildo which also served as prison in Buenos Aires. Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Guachos of Tucaman]
Description: Native American men sit and cook meat over a fire beside carts. Includes a view of Buenos Aires [?] in the background. Also includes ax, knife, grill, and ponchos.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore

Image_title: Bolivar.
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.

Image_title: La portent[os]a Ymag[e]n del Sr. del Ensino, que se venera en su Santua[ario] á estramur[os] de la Villa de Aguas Calient[es]
Description: Image of a dark Christ Crucified [Cristo renovado] on an altar with stylized flowers. Includes the legend, "INRI" above the cross and flowing blood.
Source_Title: Novena del Señor del Ensino, que se venera en la Villa de Aguas Calientes
Source_publisher: Impresa en el Armadillo por Alexo Infante
notes: Between 1773 and 1796, a church was built in Aguascalientes, Mexico, and dedicated to El Señor del Encino, a Black Christ which appeared in the area when lightning struck a tree.

Image_title: Attack by a Tiger.
Image_publisher: Black, Young & Young, Tavistock St. Covent Garden
Description: European man tries to club a tiger [jaguar?] with his gun or musket. Another European and some native Americans rush to his aid. Includes campfires and packs or luggage.
Source_Title: Journal of an expedition 1400 miles up the Orinoco and 300 up the Arauca; ..
Source_publisher: For Black, Young and Young, Foreign Booksellers, Tavistock Street, Covent Garden.
notes: The author remarks that both tigers [jaguars ?] and crocodiles or alligators are very plentiful in this area of the Arauca River. He had gone away from camp in hopes of shooting fowl when he was confronted with what he describes as a small tiger.Advertisement states that the author wished his name to be concealed, because he was critical of the people and government of Venezuela. His journey "in support of the South American Patriots" began in late 1817.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Angostura.
Image_publisher: Black, Young & Young, Tavistock St. Covent Garden
Description: View of the port of Angostura, present-day Ciudad Bolívar, in Venezuela. Includes dwellings, church, ships, and boats.
Source_Title: Journal of an expedition 1400 miles up the Orinoco and 300 up the Arauca; ..
Source_publisher: For Black, Young and Young, Foreign Booksellers, Tavistock Street, Covent Garden.
notes: Angostura [Ciudad Bolívar] is on the Orinoco River and was originally called Santo Tomé de Guayana de Angostura del Orinoco. It was the headquarters for the revolutionary government during its war for independence from Spain. In 1819, the Congress of Angostura declared Simón Bolívar president of Venezuela.Advertisement states that the author wished his name to be concealed, because he was critical of the people and government of Venezuela. His journey "in support of the South American Patriots" began in late 1817.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Old Guyana.
Image_publisher: Black, Young & Young, Tavistock St. Covent Garden
Description: View of the town of Old Guyana on the Orinoco River. Includes dwellings and two fortifications.
Source_Title: Journal of an expedition 1400 miles up the Orinoco and 300 up the Arauca; ..
Source_publisher: For Black, Young and Young, Foreign Booksellers, Tavistock Street, Covent Garden.
notes: Text states that the village consisted of about fifty houses, and the author notes the poverty and illness prevalent there.Advertisement states that the author wished his name to be concealed, because he was critical of the people and government of Venezuela. His journey "in support of the South American Patriots" began in late 1817Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Bocas del Inferno. - Whirlpool on the Orinoco.
Image_publisher: Black, Young & Young, Tavistock St. Covent Garden
Description: View of a series of whirlpools and a waterfall in the Orinoco River. Four men on a mountain path use a rope to drag a boat away from the falls and against the current.
Source_Title: Journal of an expedition 1400 miles up the Orinoco and 300 up the Arauca; ..
Source_publisher: For Black, Young and Young, Foreign Booksellers, Tavistock Street, Covent Garden.
notes: Text notes the difficulty of navigating this stretch of river not far from Las Piedras, a town recently destroyed by the Royalists.Advertisement states that the author wished his name to be concealed, because he was critical of the people and government of Venezuela. His journey "in support of the South American Patriots" began in late 1817.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings1: Orinoco River (Venezuela and Colombia)--Description and travel

Image_title: Caycara.
Image_publisher: Black, Young & Young, Tavistock St. Covent Garden
Description: View of a town on a river. Includes dwellings and boats.
Source_Title: Journal of an expedition 1400 miles up the Orinoco and 300 up the Arauca; ..
Source_publisher: For Black, Young and Young, Foreign Booksellers, Tavistock Street, Covent Garden.
notes: Text states that Caycara (or Caicara) on the Orinoco River had been a considerable town but now consisted of only four or five huts, two of which were made of bullock skins. The Patriots had destroyed it when it was last held by the Spaniards. Alexander von Humboldt had also visited this site.Advertisement states that the author wished his name to be concealed, because he was critical of the people and government of Venezuela. His journey "in support of the South American Patriots" began in late 1817.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Banks of the Orinoco.
Image_publisher: Black, Young & Young, Tavistock St. Covent Garden
Description: Bank of the Orinoco River with large piles of rocks arranged in pyramidal forms. Includes boat.
Source_Title: Journal of an expedition 1400 miles up the Orinoco and 300 up the Arauca; ..
Source_publisher: For Black, Young and Young, Foreign Booksellers, Tavistock Street, Covent Garden.
notes: Text states that near Las Piedras boulders were piled up to an inestimable height. The author could not imagine how or why they came to be there.Advertisement states that the author wished his name to be concealed, because he was critical of the people and government of Venezuela. His journey "in support of the South American Patriots" began in late 1817.Image placed horizontally on page.

Source_Title: Journal of an expedition 1400 miles up the Orinoco and 300 up the Arauca; ..

Image_title: [Simón Bolívar]
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: This anonymous work is in the style of José Gil de Castro, the Lima artist who painted Bolívar in 1825. Bolivar is reputed to have deemed Gil de Castro to have painted the most lifelike representation of himself. An engraved copy of this painting was done by James B. Longacre in Philadelphia, 1826, thus confirming that this painting was completed before that date.
References: Boulton, A. El Rostro de Bolívar, p. 101, item 84

Image_title: Mexican Indians going to Market
Description: Elderly native American man and woman carry goods to market. The woman has something wrapped in her shawl; the man has a kind of crate strapped to his back.
Source_Title: Six Months' Residence and Travels in Mexico; ...
Source_publisher: John Murray, Albemarle Street
notes: William Bullock (1775-1840) was a jeweler and goldsmith from Sheffield, England who founded a museum in London to display his collection of objects. Bullock traveled to Mexico City in 1823 and in 1824 held an exhibit of ancient Mexican artifacts he had acquired. Plates based on author's drawings.

Image_title: Ancient Mexican Sculpture. Plate 2.
Description: View of three Mexican sculptures, 1) Xochipilli , 2) Xiuhcoatl, and 3) a headless eagle.
Source_Title: Six months' residence and travels in Mexico ...
Source_publisher: John Murray, Albemarle Street
notes: William Bullock's collection is now at the British Museum, and Xochipilli "Flower Prince" (the Aztec god of music and dance), and the Fire Serpent or Xiuhcoatl are positively identified as being in the collection there. The eagle was the symbol of Tenochtitlan or Mexico City. William Bullock (1775-1840) was a jeweler and goldsmith from Sheffield, England, who founded a museum in London to display his collection of objects. Bullock traveled to Mexico City in 1823; in 1824 he held an exhibit of ancient Mexican artifacts he had acquired. Plates based on author's drawings. The engraver may be John Clark, an English engraver active from 1775 to 1825. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Pyramid of the Sun, or of San de Teotihuacan.
Description: View of the pyramid of the sun at Teotihuacán. Includes other pyramids.
Source_Title: Six months' residence and travels in Mexico ...
Source_publisher: John Murray, Albemarle Street
notes: It is not known who built the pyramids of Teotihuacán, but they were at the center of learning and culture for over one thousand years before they were abandoned abruptly around 700 AD. William Bullock (1775-1840) was a jeweler and goldsmith from Sheffield, England, who founded a museum in London to display his collection of objects. Bullock traveled to Mexico City in 1823; in 1824 he held an exhibit of ancient Mexican artifacts he had acquired. Plates based on author's drawings. The engraver may be John Clark, an English engraver active from 1775 to 1825. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Ancient Mexican Sculpture. Plate 1.
Description: View of three Mexican sculptures of an Aztec god and two goddesses, 1) Chalchiuhtlicue, 2) Quetzalcoatl, and 3) Chicomecóatl.
Source_Title: Six months' residence and travels in Mexico ...
Source_publisher: John Murray, Albemarle Street
notes: William Bullock's collection is now at the British Museum, and Chalchiuhtlicue, "She of the jade skirt" (goddess of waters and of birth), and Quetzalcoatl, "feathered serpent (god of creation)," are positively identified as being in the collection there. This statue was also illustrated in Edward King, viscount Kingsborough, Antiquities of Mexico, London, 1830, plate 1 and 2 (01967-1 and 01967-2). Chicomecóatl, "Seven snakes" (goddess of maize and plenty), wears a distinctive headdress. Bullock (1775-1840) was a jeweler and goldsmith from Sheffield, England, who founded a museum in London to display his collection of objects. Bullock traveled to Mexico City in 1823; in 1824 he held an exhibit of ancient Mexican artifacts he had acquired. Plates based on author's drawings. The engraver may be John Clark, an English engraver active from 1775 to 1825. Image placed horizontally on page.

Source_publisher: John Murray, Albemarle Street
notes: Popocatepetl, whose name means smoking mountain, is the second highest volcano, and one of the most active, in Mexico. Image_title: A su libertador Simon Bolivar.
Description: Front of medal showing a profile portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: The Constituent Congress of Peru voted on February 12, 1825, to have a medal struck in its Lima mint to honor Simón Bolívar for his services at the victory of the Battle of Ayacucho, December 9, 1824. Only 259 recorded copies were made of this gold medal and many do not survive to this day. The only other copy of this medal located in a public institution is in the Museo Bolivariano, Caracas. This medal was accompanied by a diploma (signed in full by Simón Bolívar, as Libertador Presidente de la República de Colombia), presented to Lieutenant José Antonio Espina, at La Paz, September 4, 1825, also in the Bromsen collection at the John Carter Brown Library.
References: Barroso Alfaro, M. La Medalla del Busto del Libertador, p. 28; cf. Urdaneta Braschi, E. Bolívar en la Numismática Conmemorativa y en las Condecoraciones, p. 21-26
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 16
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: Brig Jane, and Cutter Beaufoy, in Indian Cove, Terra del Fuego.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: Native American Fuegians [Indians] in boats approach two European ships in a bay. The larger of the ships seems to begin to sink.
Source_Title: A voyage towards the South Pole, performed in the years 1822-24. Containing ... a visit to Tierra del Fuego, with a particular account of the inhabitants ...
Source_publisher: Printed for Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green, Paternoster-Row
notes: Weddell made his voyages as captain of the Jane (a refitted American ship) in search of new sealing grounds. His 1822-24 voyage was his third to the Antarctic area. He was accompanied by the ship Beaufoy commanded by Matthew Brisbane. Since seals were scarce, both ships sailed farther south in hopes of finding better grounds. In an unusually ice-free year, they reached latitude 74o 15' S, a feat not repeated until 1967.Repeatedly running up against ice had made repairs to the Jane necessary, and this was the first coast at which an examination of the ship could be made.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings1: Tierra del Fuego (Argentina and Chile)--Description and travel

Source_Title: Narrative of a visit to Brazil, Chile, Peru, and the Sandwich Islands, during the years 1821 and 1822. ...
