Image_title: Females of Lima.
Image_publisher: Pub'd. by Charles Knight, Pall Mall East
Description: Two Peruvian women of European descent wearing dresses. One wears a dress covered with lace; another wears a top hat and a short cloak.
Source_Title: Narrative of a visit to Brazil, Chile, Peru, and the Sandwich Islands, during the years 1821 and 1822. ...
Source_publisher: printed for Charles Knight, Pall Mall East
notes: Text explains that the woman on the right is pulling back a manto from her face, an article of dress that usually concealed the face. She also wears a Banda Patriotica in order to honor the newly-established Patriot Government. Women who dress like this are known as tapadas. The woman on the left is wearing evening clothes.

Image_title: Precipitous Descent of a Cordillera of the Andes in the Province of Choco.
Description: View of a mountainside with a European man, a chair, a small trunk, and two native Americans.
Source_Title: Journal of a residence and travels in Colombia during the years 1823 and 1824, ... Vol. 2.
Source_publisher: Printed for Henry Colburn, New Burlington Street.
notes: Text describes the author's descent down part of a mountain being carried on the back of a native American servant on the way to Las Juntas, Colombia. The author faced the 2,000-foot drop while his bearer searched for footholds. Cochrane (b. 1796) served in the Napoleonic wars. After leaving the Navy he went to Colombia in hopes of mining copper and lowering the number of deaths in the pearl fisheries. He was perhaps the first to describe native Americans' use of the secretions from frog skin as a poison. When mining proved impracticable, he returned to Britain where he claimed to be a wandering Spanish minstrel, calling himself Jean de Vega. In 1830 he took out a patent in France on a machine for spinning cashmere and built a mill in Glasgow for spinning that wool which was new to Europe.These volumes are preceded by a dedication to Simón Bolívar.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: "Then come the unsteady step, the tottering pace;"
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: In a forest, a native American woman walks behind a child as he walks toward a seated native American man who stretches out his arms toward the child. Includes hut or dwelling.
Source_Title: A tale of Paraguay.
Source_publisher: Printed for Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green, Paternoster-Row
notes: The poem explains that this is a native American family [the mother named Monnema, the father Quiara, the son Yeruti, and a daughter about to be born, Mooma].Southey wrote this poem as an illustration of his ideas of an ideal moral state as it could exist, perhaps only, away from "civilization" or society. It also refers to the missionary work of the Catholic Church among the Guarani and Abipones in Paraguay, especially the Jesuit reductions. Southey claims to have based his story on the Austrian Jesuit Martin Dobrizhoffer's Historia de Abiponibus, equestri bellicosaque Paraquariae natione, ... (Vienna, 1784) which had been translated by Sara Coleridge and published in 1822.The engraver was probably Charles Heath (1785-1848) or his atelier. He was particularly known for his engraving of illustrations for books by Sir Walter Scott.

Image_title: "Like one entranced, beholding him, she stood;"
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: In a forest, a native American woman expresses surprise as she is approached by a monk carrying a crucifix. Includes hut or dwelling.
Source_Title: A tale of Paraguay.
Source_publisher: Printed for Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green, Paternoster-Row
notes: The poem explains that this is Mooma being discovered by the Jesuit missionary, Dobrizhoffer.Southey wrote this poem as an illustration of his ideas of an ideal moral state as it could exist, perhaps only, away from "civilization" or society. It also refers to the missionary work of the Catholic Church among the Guarani and Abipones in Paraguay, especially the Jesuit reductions. Southey claims to have based his story on the Austrian Jesuit Martin Dobrizhoffer's Historia de Abiponibus, equestri bellicosaque Paraquariae natione, ... (Vienna, 1784) which had been translated by Sara Coleridge and published in 1822.The engraver was probably Charles Heath (1785-1848) or his atelier. He was particularly known for his engraving of illustrations for books by Sir Walter Scott.

Image_title: The Author in the Travelling Costume of the Country.
Description: Portrait of Captain Charles Stuart Cochrane in British military attire and a striped poncho leaning against a donkey. Includes sword and straw hat.
Source_Title: Journal of a residence and travels in Colombia during the years 1823 and 1824, ... Vol. 1.
Source_publisher: Printed for Henry Colburn, New Burlington Street.
notes: Cochrane (b. 1796) served in the Napoleonic wars. After leaving the Navy he went to Colombia in hopes of mining copper and lowering the number of deaths in the pearl fisheries. He was perhaps the first to describe native Americans' use of the secretions from frog skin as a poison. When mining proved impracticable, he returned to Britain where he claimed to be a wandering Spanish minstrel, calling himself Jean de Vega. In 1830 he took out a patent in France on a machine for spinning cashmere and built a mill in Glasgow for spinning that wool which was new to Europe.These volumes are preceded by a dedication to Simón Bolívar.Artist may be Richard Cooper II, 1740-after 1814.

Image_title: Simon Bolivar. Chef Suprême de la République de Vénézuéla et de la nouvelle Granade
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: This work is derived from the engraving of M. N. Bate, London, 1819. Bate based his work on a drawing in the possession of William Walton and exhibited it at the Royal Academy, London, in 1821. This lithograph is not included in Boulton and is not recorded in any institutional collection.
References: Cf. Boulton, A. El Rostro de Bolívar; Wallter, F. G. Biographisch Woorenboek von Noord Nederlandsche Graveurs, p. 195
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 18
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: Bolivar Hommage au héros, des jeunes Républiques d'Amérique.
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: Possibly removed from a book published during Bolívar's lifetime. This engraving is not included in Boulton and is not recorded in any institutional collection.
References: Cf. Boulton, A. El Rostro de Bolívar, p. 98, item 57
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 21
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: Simon Bolivar.
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: This engraving is derived from the engraving by M. N. Bate, London, 1819. Boulton cites a similar pose, also published by Robins, dated March 1, 1823.
References: Cf. Boulton, A. El Rostro de Bolívar, p. 90; Hunnisett, B. An Illustrated Dictionary of British Steel Engravers, p. 69

Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: View of the pass from Quindio, in the province of Popayan, & cargueros (or carriers) who travel it.
Description: Native American porters or carriers (also called peons) ascend a mountain. One porter carries a pack on his back, another carries a man seated in a chair on his back. Includes parasol and staff.
Source_Title: Travels through the interior provinces of Columbia ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: John Murray, Albemarle Street

Image_title: Cottages and natives at hacienda of Mondomo.
Description: Native American families and their settlement near the hacienda of Mondomo. Includes feathered headdress, hammock, man breaking sticks for a cook fire, natives carrying loads, cacti, sword, lances, and black or mulatto man and woman in European dress.
Source_Title: Travels through the interior provinces of Columbia ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: John Murray, Albemarle Street
notes: Text describes an estate which had been plundered by the Spanish because the owner was a staunch patriot. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Lancers of the plains of Apuré, attacking Spanish troops.
Description: Soldiers on horseback attack European soldiers on horseback. Includes scene of warfare, lances or spears, and swords.
Source_Title: Travels through the interior provinces of Columbia ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: John Murray, Albemarle Street
notes: The plains of Apuré are located in present-day Venezuela and Colombia. These lancers, or the “bravos de Apuré,” were critical in securing Simón Bolívar’s victory at Carabobo. The “llaneros,” or the Venezuelan and Colombian cavalry that fought in this battle and others, were largely pardo (or mulatto) and “zambo” (of African and native descent). Information on the "llaneros" comes from Professor Caitlin Annette Fitz. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Bas reliefs de Palenqué.
Image_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16
Description: Two bas reliefs of Palenque. [left] A native American man in elaborate costume and headdress and holding some kind of instrument stands over a kneeling native American man with clasped hands. Includes platform on which both men stand and border of stylized flowers. (see also #06080-5). [right] Two native American men standing on a platform face one another while holding a vine-like object that functions as a symbol. Includes human heads (see also #06080-9). Image is shown horizontally.
Source_Title: Recherches sur les antiquités de l'Amérique septentrionale ... (Ouvrage extrait du 2e volume des Mémoires de ladite société)
Source_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16.
notes: Palenque is a Classic Maya site most vital in the 7th century A.D. Its bas reliefs were first drawn by Europeans in 1822.

Image_title: Bas reliefs de Palenqué.
Image_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16
Description: Two bas reliefs of Palenque. [left] Native American man sits on a pillow on a throne supported by two jaguar forelegs and heads. Includes elaborate headdress and Maya glyph (see also #06080-12). [right] Native American noble or king stands holding two ceremonial objects while wearing elaborate headdress and costume. Two native American men sit cross-legged on either side of him (see also #06080-11). Image is shown horizontally.
Source_Title: Recherches sur les antiquités de l'Amérique septentrionale ... (Ouvrage extrait du 2e volume des Mémoires de ladite société)
Source_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16.
notes: Palenque is a Classic Maya site most vital in the 7th century A.D. Its bas reliefs were first drawn by Europeans in 1822.

Image_title: Bas reliefs de Palenqué.
Image_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16
Description: Two bas reliefs of Palenque. [left] Native American in elaborate costume and headdress stands holding symbolic object. Includes glyphs. (see also #06080-7). [right] A native American male figure in elaborate costume, which includes a headdress partly comprised of a bird's head, stands smoking. He is surrounded by symbols (see also #06080-10). Image is shown horizontally.
Source_Title: Recherches sur les antiquités de l'Amérique septentrionale ... (Ouvrage extrait du 2e volume des Mémoires de ladite société)
Source_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16.
notes: Palenque is a Classic Maya site most vital in the 7th century A.D. Its bas reliefs were first drawn by Europeans in 1822.

Image_title: Bas reliefs de Palenqué
Image_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16
Description: Two bas reliefs of Palenque. [left] A native American man pierces the hand of another seated native American man with an axe. Both wear elaborate headdresses. They stand on a platform (see also #06080-4). [right] A native American man in elaborate headdress and costume grasps the hair of a seated native American man while also gesturing with an instrument. Includes glyphs, platform, human head, and skull (see also #06080-6). Image is shown horizontally.
Source_Title: Recherches sur les antiquités de l'Amérique septentrionale ... (Ouvrage extrait du 2e volume des Mémoires de ladite société)
Source_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16.
notes: Palenque is a Classic Maya site most vital in the 7th century A.D. Its bas reliefs were first drawn by Europeans in 1822.

Image_title: Bas relief de Palenqué; le milieu est occupé par une croix.
Image_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16
Description: Bas relief of Palenque. Two native American men face one another across a "cross." A bird perches on top of the "cross," and the figure on the right holds what appears to be a baby. Includes elaborate costumes and headdresses as well as glyphs (see also #06080-8). Image is shown horizontally.
Source_Title: Recherches sur les antiquités de l'Amérique septentrionale ... (Ouvrage extrait du 2e volume des Mémoires de ladite société)
Source_publisher: Everat, imprimeur-libraire, rue du Cadran, no 16.
notes: Palenque is a Classic Maya site most vital in the 7th century A.D. Its bas reliefs were first drawn by Europeans in 1822. This image shows the accession of Chan-Bahlum or K'inich Kan Bahlam II--ruler of the Maya city-state of Palenque.

Image_title: [Emperors of Peru and Mongols]
Image_publisher: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown and Green
Description: Portrait medallions of two rulers of the Incas. Each holds an ax or hatchet and wears a feathered crown. They are Huasca Inca, XIII, and Atahuallpa, XIV, last Inca. Below the Incas are a medallion relating to the Mongol or Mughal empire showing a lion and sun, portraits of Timur Bec and Jahanghir, an animal rendered in bricks, and two sides of a Roman (?) coin showing Janus and an animal with a tree.
Source_Title: Historical researches on the conquest of Peru, Mexico, Bogota, Natchez, and Talomeco, in the thirteenth century by the Mongols, ...
Source_publisher: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown and Green.
notes: The portraits are of the Inca rulers of Peru, Huascar and Atahualpa or Atabaliba. Atahualpa was the last independent Inca ruler.Text notes the similarities between Inca and Mongol dress and their mutual veneration for the lion and sun. Ranking identifies the coin as from the reign of Cunobeline, king of the Trinobantes, whose capital was near Colchester, England. He suggests that the animal is a tapir.The Mughal emperor Jahangir reigned from 1605 to 27. Timur Bec is Ti-mu-r bin Taraghay Barlas or Tamerlane (1336  February 1405).Cf. Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, London, 1726 (#07324d-1) and Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, Madrid, 1615 (#10772-3).

Image_title: Emperors of Peru.
Image_publisher: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown and Green
Description: Portrait medallions of the first six rulers of the Incas. Each holds an ax or hatchet and wears a feathered crown. They are Manco Capac, First Inca; Sinchi Roca, II; Lloque Yupanqui, III; Mayta Capac, IV; Capac Yupanqui, V; and Inca Roca, VI.
Source_Title: Historical researches on the conquest of Peru, Mexico, Bogota, Natchez, and Talomeco, in the thirteenth century by the Mongols, ...
Source_publisher: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown and Green.
notes: The portraits are of the Inca rulers of Peru. In order of reign they are Manco Capac, Sinchi Roco, Lloque Yupanqui, Maita Capac, Capac Yupanqui, and Inca Roco.Cf. Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, London, 1726 (#07324d-1) and Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, Madrid, 1615 (#10772-3).

Image_title: Emperors of Peru.
Image_publisher: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown and Green
Description: Portrait medallions of six rulers of the Incas. Each holds an ax or hatchet and wears a feathered crown. They are Yahuar Huacac, VII; Vira Cocha, VIII; Pacha Cutec, IX; Yupanqui, X; Tupac Yupanqui, XI; and Huayna Capac, XII.
Source_Title: Historical researches on the conquest of Peru, Mexico, Bogota, Natchez, and Talomeco, in the thirteenth century by the Mongols, ...
Source_publisher: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown and Green.
notes: The portraits are of the Inca rulers of Peru. In order of reign they are Yahuar Huacac, Inca Viracocha, Pachacuti Inca, Yupanqui, Topa Inca Yupanqui, and Huayna Capac.Cf. Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, London, 1726 (#07324d-1) and Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, Madrid, 1615 (#10772-3).

Image_title: Simón Bolívar. Libertador de Colombia y del Peru; y Fundador de Bolivia ...
Image_publisher: Mr. Turner, 50 Warren Street, Fitzroy Square
Description: Full length portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire. Military elements include sword and spurs. In the background, two soldiers converse.
notes: This engraving is derived from a painting of Bolívar done in Lima by José Gil de Castro. Bolívar is reputed to have deemed Gil de Castro to have painted the most lifelike representation of himself. It is this image that M. N. Bate used for his widely-copied engraving of Bolívar. This engraving is not included in Boulton and is not recorded in any institutional collection.
References: Boulton, A. El Rostro de Bolívar, p. 107, item 109; http://www.puc.cl/faba/ARTE/AUTORES/GildeCastro.html; http://www.artnet.com/library/01/0148/T014827.asp (Feb. 2004)
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Mrs. DeCoursey Fales, Jr.

Image_title: Bolivar.
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: This engraving is not included in Boulton, although he cites two similar works, and is not recorded in any institutional collection.
References: Cf. Boulton, A. El Rostro de Bolívar, p. 97-98, item 57, 59
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 22
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: [Armed man of Tucumán, Argentina]
Description: Man in the attire of a militia active in Tucumán, Argentina. Includes gun, sword, and plumed hat.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol I.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: Tucumán is a province in northwestern Argentina. It acquired importance as the mid-point in transporting gold and silver from Peru to Buenos Aires. Its government was unstable after independence.Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.

Image_title: [Man of Tucumán, Argentina or gaucho]

Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol I.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: Tucumán is a province in northwestern Argentina. It acquired importance as the mid-point in transporting gold and silver from Peru to Buenos Aires. Text describes the behavior of gauchos of Tucumán.Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.

Image_title: [Ruined church in Trancas, Argentina]

Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol I.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: Trancas is a town in the province of Tucumán, Argentina, north of San Miguel de Tucumán. Text explains that there had been a strong earthquake three weeks before, and that it had destroyed the town, including the church depicted here.Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.

Image_title: Setting out from Tarija.

Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street

Image_title: [Pottery and wooden vessels]
Description: Two vessels, the one on the left made of wood and the one on the right of pottery, probably made by the Moche people. The wooden one is decorated with bird motifs; the pottery one is a drinking vessel in two parts in humanoid form.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: Text notes the presence of ruins near Ancacato. There is a town of Ancacato northwest of Potosí, Bolivia.Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Night Scene in the Curate's House.
Description: A room full of European and native American men and women standing, sitting, or lying on the floor. In the center are two monks or priests, one of whom holds a rosary while the other holds a crucifix. Includes dogs, rugs, jug, and candle.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: Text notes that these people have gathered at a curate's house to sleep after a festival. The half-clothed young women are in costumes meant to symbolize America. The author refers to the women as Cholas, a term used to describe people of mixed mestizo and native American ancestry.Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Scene in the Carnival at Potosi.
Description: Men, women, and children dance and cavort on a large plain in front of a range of mountains. Includes horses, flags, dogs, musical instruments such as violin, guitar, flute, and drum, and military exercises.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [The author and a gaucho]
Description: The author, wearing a rolled up poncho and a large hat, lights his cigar from that of a gaucho.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.

Image_title: How to mount on horseback in Peru.
Description: A woman mounts a horse from the rear by using a knot in the horse's tail as a stirrup. She is helped by a man already mounted on the horse.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: Text describes how accomplished the women of Tarija, Bolivia were as riders. Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.

Image_title: A Peruvian Indian, bargaining with a cloth merchant of Cochabamba
Description: Two native Americans bargain for cloth.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street

Image_title: [View of a mountain]
Description: View of a mountain range with a pass. Includes group of tents and mounted people.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: This is probably Illimani, a mountain 21,004 feet high just south of La Paz, Bolivia.Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Scene near San Lucas.
Description: View of a mountain range with men and donkeys traveling on paths. Includes view down into the town of San Lucas in present-day Bolivia.
Source_Title: Travel in various parts of Peru, including a year's residence in Potosi, ... Vol II.
Source_publisher: Henry Colburn and Richard Bentley, New Burlington Street
notes: San Lucas is southeast of Potosí.Temple made his trip as secretary of the Potosi Mining Association and left London in 1825. He sailed to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and then made his way to Potosí by land.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Simón Bolívar]
Description: Profile portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: Possibly a proof before lettering. This engraving is not included in Boulton and is not recorded in any institutional collection. Perhaps a lithograph.
References: Cf. Boulton, A. El Rostro de Bolívar, p. 97-98
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 23
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: Plan d'un ancien lavage d'or des Incas ou Quichuas Situé sur le sommet de la montagne dite Fuerte del Inca près du village de Samaypata, province de valle grande, Département de Santa Cruz de la Sierra (Bolivia)
Description: Plan of a gold washing site on the summit of a mountain called Fuerte del Inca, near the village of Samaypata, department of Santa Cruz de la Sierra, Bolivia. Also includes a topographical and profile view of the mountains surrounding the site and scales. Items in the image are lettered and numbered for identification in other volumes.
Source_Title: [Voyage dans l'Amérique méridionale] Voyage dans l'Amérique méridionale (le Brésil, ... l'Uruguay, la République argentine, la Patagonie, la république du Chili, la république de Bolivia, la république du Pérou) ... Tome troisième
Source_publisher: Chez P. Bertrand, éditeur ... ; Chez Veuve. LeVrault ...
notes: Originally issued in 90 fascicles between 1834 and 1847; typically bound in 7 to 11 volumes.Benard was a leading lithography firm in Paris in the mid-nineteenth century.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Bolivar.
Image_publisher: chez Chaillou, editeur, rue St. Honor��, No. 140
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: Based on a miniature that was painted by Antonio Meucci in 1830 and shows Bolívar in the final stages of tuberculosis. This print is not included in Boulton and is not recorded in any institutional collection.
References: Cf. Boulton, A. El Rostro de Bolívar, p. 70
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 32
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: Recivelo Motezuma en hombros de Reyes, y ofrecele dones
Description: Moctezuma (Montezuma) II is carried on a golden litter by his Aztec subjects. Decorative elements include crowns, feathered garments, canopy, armor, ornaments including quetzal plume fans, and jaguar skin attire.
notes: Moctezuma II (reigned 1502-1520), the ninth Aztec emperor, whose surname was Xocoyotzin or bitter lord (or the youngest), was the son of Axayácatl and great grandson of Moctezuma I. He surrendered to the Spanish in 1520. This painting was owned by William H. Prescott, his daughter, and grandson and was never publicly exhibited until given to the John Carter Brown Library in 2000. The frontispiece of Prescott's History of the Conquest of Peru, vol. II, New York, 1843, depicts Moctezuma alone in royal attire.
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 2
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.
SubjectHeadings1: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Mapa de la suntuosa Biblioteca del insigne Seminario Palafoxiano de la Puebla de los Angeles, erigida a beneficio comun Año de 1771.
Description: A gentleman and members of the clergy admire and work in a library. Includes bookcases, desk, Classical altarpiece containing symbolic elements such as the Lamb of God, the Virgin Mary as the seat of wisdom holding the Christ Child, and the dove of the Holy Spirit. Also includes portrait of a winged Saint Thomas Aquinas holding a quill and a book.
notes: The library depicted, now called the Biblioteca Palafoxiana, is in Puebla, Mexico, and was founded as part of a seminary by Juan de Palafox y Mendoza in 1648. Palafox donated his own book collection to the library, and in the eighteenth century (probably around 1773) Bishop Francisco Fabián y Fuero donated his personal library, the bookcases, and altarpiece that are still in situ. This is the only library from the Colonial period surviving in the Americas.

Image_title: [Antonio José de Sucre]
Description: Portrait of Antonio José de Sucre in military attire.
notes: This painting was sold directly to the U.S. minister plenipotentiary in Quito in 1892. The portrait is based on a circular miniature made in Quito in 1828 by José Sáez, an Ecuadorian artist. Sucre was instrumental in Bolivia's declaration of independence in 1825 and he was elected president for life of Bolivia in 1826, a position which he held for only two years. The great grandfather of Salas was Antonio Salas, a personal friend of Bolívar and one of the few who painted him from life in 1822, 1824, 1826, and 1829.
References: Boulton, A. Miranda, Bolívar y Sucre, p. 71-72; Boulton, A. Iconografía del Gran Mariscal de Ayacucho, p. 100; Arocha, M. Iconografía Ecuatoreana del Libertador, p. 87-126
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 14
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: [Simón Bolívar]
Description: Portrait of Simón Bolívar in military attire.
notes: This painting was sold directly to the U.S. minister plenipotentiary in Quito in 1892. The portrait is based on an 1824 print by Kepper. Boulton states that the lithograph was based in part on the copper engraving of M. N. Bate made in London in 1819. The great grandfather of Salas was Antonio Salas, a personal friend of Bolívar and one of the few who painted him from life in 1822, 1824, 1826, and 1829.
References: Boulton, A. Le Rostro de Bolívar, p. 97, item 57, 98; Arocha, M. Iconografía Ecuatoreana del Libertador, p. 87-126; www.bolivar.ula.ve/cgi-win/be_alex.exe?Acceso=T011900000379/0&Nombrebd=BOLIVAR (Jan. 2004)
References_exhibitions: John Carter Brown Library, Portraits of the Liberator Simón Bolívar, no. 13
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2000. Gift of Maury A. Bromsen.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: An armed Spanish ship. Military aspects include group of armed Spaniards and armed native Americans.
Source_Title: Ein Auszug ettlicher Sendbrieff dem aller durchleüchtigisten grossmechtgiste[n] Fürsten und Herren Herren Carl römischen un hyspanische[n] König [etc.] vnserm gnedigen hern durch ire verordent Hauptleut, von wegen einer newgefunde[nen] Inseln, der selbe[n] Gelegenheit vun jnwoner sitten un[d] Gewonheite[n] inhaltend vor Kurtzuerschinen Tagen zugesandt.
Source_publisher: Fryderichen Peypus
notes: Imprint from colophon.
SubjectHeadings1: First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Scene of worship and human sacrifice. At right, two men and two women stand with a spirit or demon. At bottom, a ship with the banner of the Spanish crown and armed men approaches a city. Built environment includes dwellings, temple, altar, idol, and boats.
Source_Title: Newe Zeittung. Von dem Lande. Das die Sponier funden haben ym 1521. iare genant Jucatan ...
notes: The artist has interpreted written accounts of Hernán Cortés' discoveries in the Yucatan and Mexico, giving his depiction a medieval European appearance.
References: Wagner, H.R. "Three accounts of the expedition of Fernando Cortes, printed in Germany," Hispanic American Historical Review, May 1929; John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1929. p. 8-9

Image_title: [View of Tenochtitlán]
Description: View of fortified city surrounded by water with men standing before its bridges. Built environment includes dwellings, fortifications, boats, and outlying settlements.
Source_Title: Newe Zeittung. Von dem Lande. Das die Sponier funden haben ym 1521. iare genant Jucatan ...
notes: This is the first published view of the Aztec capital of Tenochtitlán, as it was supposed to have looked before its destruction by Hernán Cortés and its rebuilding as Mexico City. The artist has interpreted written accounts of the "city in a lake" with its causeways linking the city and surrounding land, giving it a distinctly medieval European appearance.
References: Wagner, H.R. "Three accounts of the expedition of Fernando Cortes, printed in Germany," Hispanic American Historical Review, May 1929; John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1929, p. 8-9
References_exhibitions: Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Fig. 14
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: The title of the book is surrounded by a decorative border containing floral motifs and grotesque heads. The double eagle is depicted on a shield in the lower center, flanked by two [gryphons?].
Source_Title: Ein schöne newe Zeytung so Kayserlich Mayestet ausz India yetz nemlich zukommen seind
Source_publisher: Melchior Ramminger
notes: This book contains a brief account of Columbus' voyage, Spanish conquest of Mexico, and Magellan's circumnavigation of the world.

Image_title: [Map of Temixtitan and map of the Gulf of Mexico]
Image_publisher: Per Bernardino de Viano de Lexona Vercellese. Ad instantia de Baptista de Pederzani Brixiani
Description: Map of a city identified as Temixtitan [actually Tenochtitlan, present-day Mexico City]. Built environment includes a sacrificial temple [the Templo Mayor], causeways, buildings, dwelling and gardens of Montezema. A map of the Gulf of Mexico is given.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a. Italian] La preclara narratione di Ferdinando Cortese della Nuoua Hispagna del Mare Oceano, al sacratissimo, [&] inuictissimo Carlo di romani imperatore sempre augusto Re Dhispagna, [&] cio che siegue, nella [n]no del Signore
Source_publisher: Per Bernardino de Viano de Lexona Vercellese. Ad instantia de Baptista de Pederzani Brixiani
notes: Cortés first published his second letter in Nuremberg, 1524. The above edition was published in Venice later in the same year. The Nuremberg edition map of the Gulf of Mexico is the first printed map to portray the outline of the Caribbean basin (and the first to mention Florida); it is also the first printed depiction of an American city.
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, Fig. 6.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Map of Tenochtitlán and the Gulf of Mexico]
Description: Map of a city identified as Temixtitan [actually Tenochtitlán, present-day Mexico City]. Built environment includes a sacrificial temple [the Templo Mayor], causeways, buildings, dwelling and gardens of Montezema [Moctezuma]. A map of the Gulf of Mexico is given. Also includes flag with Hapsburg double-headed eagle, scale, boats or canoes, and outlying settlements.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a] Praeclara Ferdina[n]di. Cortesii de noua maris oceani Hyspania narratio sacratissimo. ac inuictissimo Carolo Romanoru[m] Imperatori semper Augusto, Hyspaniaru[m], [etc] Regi Anno Domini. M.D.XX. transmitta ...
Source_publisher: Per Fridericum Peypus
notes: This map is the first printed map to portray the outline of the Caribbean basin (and the first to mention Florida); it is also the first printed depiction of an American city. This woodcut has been attributed to Albrecht Dürer; it shows the city before its destruction by the Spanish in 1521 and includes the principal temples of the Aztecs, the main square (or Zócalo), the causeways which connected the city with the mainland, and the wicker dam which regulated the water of the Lake of Mexico.See also another version of the same map published in the same year in Venice (0236-2).
References: Danforth. S. Encountering the New World, Fig. 16
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [La manera o como los indos enciende lumbre]
Description: Fire stick.
Source_creator: Fernández de Oviedo y Valdés, Gonzalo, 1478-1557
Source_Title: [Sumario de la natural y general istoria de las Indias] Ouiedo Dela natural hystoria delas Indias
Source_publisher: se imprimio a costas del autor Gonçalo Fernandez de Ouiedo alias e Valdes. Por industria de maestre Remon de Petras
notes: Text describes a native American stick used to make fire.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Spanish priest and soldiers meet the Incan ruler Atahualpa and his retinue. Atahualpa is carried on a litter and holds a bar of gold [?]. Includes fortified castle on hill, canopy or parasol, bows, angels, Virgin Mary on a crescent moon, papal and royal Hapsburg coat of arms.
Source_Title: [Verdadera relacion de la conquista del Peru] Uerdadera relacion de la conquista del Peru
Source_publisher: impressa en casa de Bartholome Perez
notes: This image shows the capture of Atahualpa by Francisco Pizarro at Cajamarca, Peru. Atahualpa, in a desperate attempt to buy his freedom, offered Pizarro a room of gold. The ransom was in vain; Pizarro had the Incan king executed as soon as the ransom was collected.
References_exhibitions: Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Fig. 61; Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writings, Item 23

Image_title: [Tobacco pipes]
Description: Tobacco pipes.
Source_creator: Fernández de Oviedo y Valdés, Gonzalo, 1478-1557
Source_Title: [Historia general y natural de las Indias. 1a parte] La historia general delas Indias
Source_publisher: Enla emprenta de Iuam Cromberger, el postrero dia del mes de setiembre
notes: This book is the first known European account to mention how tobacco was smoked by the natives.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Enla emprenta de Iuam Cromberger, el postrero dia del mes de setiembre
Description: Coat of arms of the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V (Charles I of Spain) held by a double-headed eagle and surrounded by the chain of the Order of the Golden Fleece. Decorative elements include border with grape vines,grotesques, floral motifs, globe topped by cross, and a man on horseback holding a sword who tramples the figures of conquered people.

Image_title: [Dugout canoe and adz]

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Scene of warfare. Two groups of armed men face each other. Military aspects include fortified city, tents, horses, shields, and lances.
Source_Title: [Verdadera relacion dela conquista del Peru ] Conquista del Peru. Verdadera relacion dela conquista del Peru [y] provincia del Cuzco llamada la Nueva Castilla
Source_publisher: Por Ivan de Iunta

Image_title: La istoria de las Indias
Description: Verso of title page. Text surrounded by ornate border with allegorical figures (including four women at the corners with various attributes). At top of the border, a woman sits on a beast holding a cross and the beast's tail with two fauns. Text begins, "La istoria de las Indias ... "
Source_Title: [Historia de las Indias] Primera y segunda parte dela historia general de las Indias: con todo el descubrimiento y cosas notables que han acaecido dende que se ganaron ata el año de 1551
Source_publisher: A costa de Miguel Capila mercader de libros vezino de Caragoçca

Image_title: [Title page]

Source_Title: [Historia de las Indias] Primera y segunda parte de la historia general de las Indias: con todo el descubrimiento y cosas notables que han acaecido dende que se ganaron ata el año de 1551
Source_publisher: A costa de Miguel Capila mercader de libros vezino de Caragoçca

Image_title: [Buffalo]
Description: Buffalo.
Source_Title: [Historia de las Indias] Primera y segunda parte de la historia general de las Indias: con todo el descubrimiento y cosas notables que han acaecido dende que se ganaron ata el año de 1551
Source_publisher: A costa de Miguel Capila mercader de libros vezino de Caragoçca

Image_title: [Building of cities in South America]
Description: Masons chisel and build a wall supervised by a man riding a horse. Includes dwellings.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bellero ala enseña del Salmon
notes: Text here refers to the building of cities in Peru, but this is a generic image of masons probably intended to represent native American workers. The same woodcut is used many times in this book to illustrate the building of other towns.

Image_title: [Native Americans talk to devil]
Description: Men talk to a devil or idol.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bellero ala enseña del Salmon
notes: Text here refers to the the religious practices of the native Americans of Anzerma in present-day Colombia.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: [View of a city]
Description: Men stand before steps to a building. Includes a beggar, statue, and dwellings.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bellero ala enseña del Salmon
notes: Text here refers to the richness of the city of Tombebamba near present-day Cuenca, Ecuador. The presence of a beggar in the illustration is included to impress the viewer because only rich cities have beggars. Tombebamba was a major Inca town before the Spaniards conquered it. Before the Incas, it was inhabited by the Cañaris and served as a major administration center.

Image_title: Cuzco
Description: Inca ruler gestures toward a settlement in the background. A bearded man in European dress stands next to him. Includes church and dwellings.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bellero ala enseña del Salmon
notes: Text here refers to the founding of Cuzco by the Inca. Here an Inca ruler, possibly Manco Capac (adorned with the royal fringe [llautu] or crown), gestures toward Cuzco to Francisco Pizarro.

Image_title: [Native American sacrifice]
Description: Native American sacrifices another by cutting out his heart in front of an idol or devil with wings. Also includes two men hanging from ropes and two idols [harpies?] in front of the altar.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bellero ala enseña del Salmon
notes: Text describes the religious sacrifices practiced by the natives of Peru.

Image_title: [Native American king receives two Spaniards]
Description: Orejone [i.e., big-eared Inca ruler or native American king] with two men.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bellero ala enseña del Salmon
notes: The ruler may symbolize Manco Capac, adorned with the royal fringe [llautu] or crown.

Image_title: [Del Rio de Apurima: y del valle de Xaquixaguana ... hasta llegar ala ciudad del Cuzco]
Description: Incan ruler gesturing toward Cuzco to Francisco Pizarro.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin Nucio
notes: The ruler may symbolize Manco Capac, adorned with the royal fringe [llautu] or crown. Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [Building of the city of Saint Sebastian and Antioch]
Description: Masons chisel and build a wall supervised by a man holding a baton. Includes winch, hammer, and stool.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bellero ala enseña del Salmon
notes: Text here refers to the city of San Pedro de Uraba (Antioquia, Colombia), but this is a generic image of masons probably intended to represent native American workers. The same woodcut is used many times in book to illustrate the building of other towns. Image title taken from chapter title. This illustration, reprinted within the volume, represents the building efforts of the Spanish in Peru.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [De los ritos y sacrificios que estos Indios tienen: y quan grandes carniceros son de comer carne humana]
Description: Human sacrifice. Native American plunges a knife into another's chest. Two bodies hang, a statute of an idol or devil on a pillar stands at left.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru
Source_publisher: En casa de Martin Nucio
notes: Image title taken from chapter title.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Fig. 48

Image_title: [Six fruits]
Description: Six different fruits. They are probably: 1) coca?, 2) jobo or hog plum (Spondias mombin), 3) jagua or genipap, or marmalade box (Génipa americana L.), 4) mamey or mamey apple, mamma apple, or mamee tree (Mammea americana L.), 5) guayaba or guava (Psidium guajava L.), and 6) perhaps a kind of guanábana.
Source_Title: [Historia de las Indias]
Source_publisher: en casa de Miguel de Capila mercader de libros
notes: López de Gómara never visited America.

Image_title: Cerro de Potosi
Description: Town and mountain of Potosí. Includes a view of the churches, dwellings, and town square (with decapitated head on a pike) of the settlement. Also includes river and paths up the mountain along with an indication of the different veins of silver.
Source_Title: [La chronica de Peru. Part 1] Chronica del Peru ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bellero ala enseña del Salmon
notes: The mines at Potosí in Peru were discovered by Diego Hualca in 1544. The silver mines there were among the richest in the world.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Coat of arms of the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V (Charles I of Spain) held by a double-headed (Hapsburg) eagle and surrounded by the chain of the Order of the Golden Fleece.
Source_creator: Núñez Cabeza de Vaca, Alvar, 16th cent.
Source_Title: [Relación y comentarios] La relacion y comentarios del gouernador Aluar Nuñez Cabeça de Vaca, de lo acaescido en las dos jornadas que hizo a las Indias
Source_publisher: Francisco Fernandez de Cordoua

Image_title: [Temple at Temistitan or Mexico City]
Description: Temple or pyramid with two towers.
Source_Title: [Navigazioni e viaggi. Volume 3] Terzo volume delle Navigationi et viaggi nel quale si contengono le nauigationi al Mondo Nuouo
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia de Giunti
notes: The major temple at Mexico City, called Tenochtitlan by Aztecs (also called Temistitan by Europeans in the sixteenth century), was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc (the god of rain), the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli (the god of the sun and war). The wood blocks used to create this edition of Ramusio's Navigationi et viaggi were destroyed in a fire in 1557. Later editions used illustrations which seem similar but were made from new wood blocks.

Image_title: [Native Americans mining]
Description: Native Americans search for gold in a stream. Human activity includes mining, hoeing, and panning.
Source_Title: [Navigazioni e viaggi. Volume 3] Terzo volume delle navigationi et viaggi
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia de Giunti
notes: This illustration was derived from that in Gonzalo Fernandez de Oviedo y Valdés, Historia general delas Indias, first published, Seville, 1535. The wood blocks used to create this edition of Ramusio's Navigationi et viaggi were destroyed in a fire in 1557. Later editions were made from new wood blocks.

Image_title: Il Cuscho citta principale della provincia del Peru
Description: A bird's eye view of Cuzco, Peru. Built environment includes walls, temple (showing Atabalipa [or Atahualpa], the last independent Incan ruler, being carried on a litter), and dwellings.
Source_Title: [Navigazioni e viaggi. Volume 3] Terzo volume delle navigationi et viaggi
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia de Giunti
notes: The wood blocks used to create the first edition of Ramusio's Navigationi et viaggi were destroyed in a fire in 1557. This edition's woodcuts were new.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Animal]
Image_publisher: heritiers de Maurice de la Porte
Description: "Su" from Patagonia.
Source_Title: [Les singularitez de la France Antarctique] Les singularitez de la France Antarctique autrement nommée Amerique
Source_publisher: Chez les heritiers de Maurice de la Porte, au Clos Bruneau, à l'ensiegne S. Claude
notes: Text describes an animal hunted for its fur by the native Americans, which lived by rivers, put its young on it back when threatened, and had a terrible cry. The same woodcut is used in Thevet's Cosmographie universelle (leaf 1002 recto) to illustrate a "succarath" (a ground sloth or puma?). Thevet, a Franciscan monk , traveled to Brazil with Nicolas Durand, chevalier de Villegagnon, stayed only ten weeks, and wrote Les singularitez from his own observations and those of others.

Image_title: Alberi che producono le zucche, del che gl'Indiani generalmente se ne seruano de' uasi.
Description: Native Americans with baskets on their backs walk underneath the trees that produce calabashes.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: The calabash tree, Crescentia cujete, produces large spherical fruit used by native Americans as vases. Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Modo di ballare.
Description: Method of dancing. Native Americans dance while others beat drum, prepare and serve beverages.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: Publication information from colophon.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Social life and customs

Image_title: Come gli Indiani viuono sopro gli Arbori.
Description: How the native Americans live in trees. Spanish soldiers chop down a tree with a dwelling while the inhabitants drop stones on them. Includes hatchets or axes.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: Natives of the Orinoco River in present-day Venezuela and Colombia lived in houses built on high rocks or in trees during the rainy season . Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Il modo di pescare, & nauigare nel mare di Mezzo giorno.
Description: Native American method of fishing and navigation in the Pacific Ocean.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: Text describes native Americans fishing off the coast of Ecuador. Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Come gl'Indiani del Peru adorano il Sole, & lo tengono per il suo principal Iddio.
Description: Native Americans of Peru pray to the sun which they worship as their principal idol. Includes temple or pyramid.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: Publication information from colophon.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Il modo che tengono gli orefici nel lauorare, & fondere l'oro, & l'argento.
Description: Native American method of working gold and silver. Two men blow through a reed over a hearth or foundry. Another man pounds the metal with a stone to fashion it. Includes a dwelling.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: Text describes the Inca goldsmithing around Cuzco in present-day Peru. Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Indiana marauigliosa in Cumana
Description: Native American woman with a ring through her nose presents a basket of fruit to European gentlemen who sit at a table eating. Includes tattoo.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: Benzoni describes a strange old woman who had a large wooden ring in her nose and heavy earrings. She brought a basket of fruit and claimed to be the wife of a local cacique or chief in Cumana, present-day Venezuela. Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Modo di dormire nel Golfo di Paria, & altri moti luoghi.
Description: Native American methods of sleeping near the Gulf of Paria, present-day Venezuela. Includes hammocks under shelters and a campfire.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Come gli Indiani colauano l'oro in bocca a gli Spagnuoli, e dell'habito che lor portano in diuersi lochi di terra Ferma.
Description: Native Americans melt gold ore and pour molten gold into the throats of Spaniards. In background is a scene of cannibalism. Native Americans butcher and roast limbs over a grill. Also includes dwellings, hearth and men blowing on a fire.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: In retribution for European greed, native Americans are shown obliging the invader's craving for gold by pouring molten metal down their throats. Text describes the Spanish under the leadership of the governor of Panama, Pedrarios Davila, raiding the coast for gold. Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Indiani della Spagnuola per non seruire a i Christiani, si andauano a impiccare alli boschi.
Description: Native Americans commit suicide. Includes death from stabbing by knives and spears, from jumping off high places, hanging, and beating. Mothers and fathers kill their own children.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: Text describes Spanish rule after the death of Christopher Columbus on Hispaniola and tells of native Americans commiting suicide rather than serving Christians. Includes description of mothers using the juice of a herb to abort their babies. Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Casa benissimamente coperta nella prouincia di Suere.
Description: Native American dwelling by a river.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: This house is described as being shaped like an egg and encircled with reeds. Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: Albero che produce il cacauate, & come gl'Indiani di due legni cauano fuoco.
Description: Native American drills wood to make a fire. A big tree shades a cacauatl or cocoa tree; cacao beans dry in the background.
Source_Title: La historia del mondo nuovo
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco Rampazetto
notes: This is the first published picture of a cocoa or cacahuatl tree. It is described as flourishing only in shady locations. Publication information from colophon.

Image_title: [Settlement and ship]
Description: View of a settlement and ship.
Source_Title: Obra nueuamente compuesta, en la qual se cue[n]ta, la felice victoria que Dios por su infinita bondad y misericordia, fue seruido de dar, al ... Pedro Melendez .. contra Iuan Ribao ...
Source_publisher: En casa de Hernando Diaz impressor de libros, a la Calle de la Sierpe
notes: This book is an account in verse of the destruction of the French Huguenot colony of Fort Caroline under Jean Ribaut by Pedro Menéndez de Avilés in Florida. It is the only contemporary printed record of the Spanish/French conflicts from the Spanish point of view. The pamphlet also served as a promotional tract for a Spanish colony that Menéndez de Avilés was trying to establish in Florida as a buffer against French and English incursions.Publication information taken from colophon.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Figure of a woman holding a branch in her right hand and a torch pointed toward the ground in her left. The figure is enclosed in strapwork.
Source_Title: Historie del S.D. Fernando Colombo; nelle quali s 'ha particolare, & vera relatione della vita, & de' fatti dell' Ammiraglio D. Chritoforo Colombo, suo padre
Source_publisher: Appresso Francesco de' Franceschi Sanese
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, Fig. 33.

Image_title: [Comme les esclaves fouillent & font fondre la mine]
Description: Slaves excavate and smelt ore from a mine. Supervised by a European man with a club, the workers are shown mining ore with hoes or adzes, carrying ore in baskets to smelt, and tending the forge. Includes dwellings, wood, and buckets.
Source_Title: La cosmographie vniuerselle ... Tome seconde
Source_publisher: chez Pierre L'Huillier, rue Sainct Iaques, à l'Oliuier
notes: The text describes the mountain at Potosí, incorrectly giving its location as an island next to Cuba. Thevet, a Franciscan monk, traveled to Brazil with Nicolas Durand, chevalier de Villegagnon. He stayed only ten weeks, returning to France in 1556, and wrote Les singularitez de la France Antarctique from his own observations and those of others. As a result of the popularity of Les singularitez, Thevet received the position of cosmographer to the French court and wrote this book, an account of the known world. Title is from marginal gloss.

Image_title: [Portrait du Hogà poi[sson] mo[n]strueux.]
Description: A large, hairy fish with fins, ears, and "mustaches."
Source_Title: La cosmographie vniuerselle ...
Source_publisher: chez Pierre L'Huillier, rue Sainct Iaques, à l'Oliuier
notes: Image title from marginal gloss. Text describes the "fish" as being as large as a seal, giving birth to live young, changing color, eating leaves and large fish, having many teeth, and being very vicious. It lived in the lake on which Mexico City was built. It may have been a kind of seal or sea lion.

Image_title: [Figure du Maroli oyseau de proye fort estrange.]
Description: Bird with hooked beak perched on a branch with a snake in its beak and another snake under its claw. Long "ears" hang down to its throat.
Source_Title: La cosmographie vniuerselle ...
Source_publisher: chez Pierre L'Huillier, rue Sainct Iaques, à l'Oliuier
notes: Image title from marginal gloss. Text states that the bird is found near the "Cap de Cotoche" on the Yucatan peninsula.

Image_title: [Descripcion de la Audiencia de la Nueva España.]
Description: Map of the audiencia of Mexico including the Yucatan peninsula and part of Guatemala and Honduras.
Source_Title: Demarcacion y diuision de las Yndias
notes: The maps in this manuscript (a summary of a larger work by the author, a prominent sixteenth-century Spanish cartographer) of the various colonial Spanish tribunals were copied and expanded by Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas in his Historia general, Madrid, 1601. This manuscript postdates a copy in the Biblioteca national in Madrid (which was made after 1570), but predates the publication of Herrera's book. Image title taken from the verso of the map.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1936, p. 10-13

Image_title: [left] Mexico, Regia & Celebris Hispaniae Novae Civitas. [right] Cusco, Regni Peru In Novo orbe Caput.
Description: Bird's-eye views of Mexico City and Cuzco. The view of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán includes causeways, dikes, the central plaza with temples and the statue of an idol, people boating, outlying settlements around Lake Texcoco, and three native Americans in
Source_Title: Civitates orbis terrarum
Source_publisher: Apud Aegidium Radeum
notes: This is the first example of a systematic atlas of cities and was meant to complement Ortelius's Theatrum Orbis Terrarum. Georg Braun was a priest and geographer. Although neither print is signed, the engravers are known to be Frans Hogenberg (1538-1590)
References: Braun, Georg, Civitates orbis terrarum, 1572-1618... With an introduction by R. A. Skelton, Amsterdam, 1965.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Aztec calendar]
Description: Aztec calandar with Christian calendar.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religious rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Ad sensus aptat coelestia dona magister, Aridaq eloquij pectora fonte rigat.
Description: Missionary instructs native Americans by making use of graphic depictions of the Passion. A monk holds an hourglass on the steps of the pulpit.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religous rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico. Image placed horizontally on page. Diego Valades, fl. 1580, is probably the image creator.

Image_title: [Mexicans saved and fallen]
Description: At top, native Americans (wearing tilmas or indigenous clothes) are suspended from two trees while a devil tries to pull one down with a chain. Each tree has a representation of a crucified man [Christ?] on it. At bottom, native Americans kill martyrs with bows and arrows, stones, knives, and spears.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religious rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico. Image placed horizontally on page. Diego Valades, fl. 1580, is probably the image creator.

Image_title: [Syllabary with elements of Nahuatl pictograms combined with European letters]
Description: Set of pictographs which includes Aztec or Nahuatl symbols, such as native American figures or Mexicans, bird in a tree, symbol for house, and the Aztec god, Huitzilopochtli (with serpent and shield), eagle, and others.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religious rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico.

Image_title: [Model by which native Americans are taught their catechism]
Description: Native Americans are taught their catechism in a courtyard of a convent or monastery. Includes monks or brothers teaching native Americans by use of symbols, words, and pictures. Monks carry a church, with a symbol of the Holy Spirit in the entry and God the Father in clouds above it, on their shoulders. They teach about the creation of the world, Catholic doctrine, instruct for marriage and writing, take care of the sick, read aloud, perform baptism, burial, and marriage services, hear confessions, and give communion and last rites.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religious rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico.

Image_title: Tipus sacrificiorum que in maniter indi faciebant in novo indiarum orbe precipue in Mexico
Description: Aztec sacrifice scene in temple surrounded by daily life in ancient Mexico. Priests under a dome offer the victim's heart to an idol while other priests attend. At left, the bodies are tossed down the stairs and burned on a pyre. Before the sacrificial place dancers celebrate, and around the temple women prepare tortillas and cook, a burial ceremony takes place, men fish with seine net, men paddle canoes and rafts, one made out of balsa, people collect fruit and carry water, and people make astronomical observations. Built environment includes dwellings and towns. Botanical elements include identified plants and trees, including maize, pineapple, and cacti.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religious rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico. Image placed horizontally on page.
References_exhibitions: Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Fig. 15

Image_title: [Missionary instructs native Americans]
Description: A missionary or priest instructs native Americans who sit in a circle around him. Cultural artifacts include bows, quivers, and arrows.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religious rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico. Diego Valades, fl. 1580, is probably the image creator.

Image_title: [Missionary brings Christianity to native Americans]
Description: A missionary or priest and his retinue with luggage meet a band of native Americans with shield, spears, and bows and arrows. The missionary's group carries a chalice, censer, crucifixes, staffs,and boxes. Two women and their children kneel down before them. Also includes an open fire in a pit. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text below.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religious rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico.

Image_title: [Idolatrous speech among native Americans]
Description: Set of pictographs illustrates the dangers and consequences of idolatrous speech. The two engraving are ruled over by Satan who is enthroned at the top of the images and attended by devils who offer him delicacies, including humans. Sinners receive punishments in their body and soul, devils torture native Americans or Mexicans, people are shackled to the desires of the devil. On the left engraving, blasphemous speech is shown as "speech scrolls" and angels hover near some of the speakers attempting to keep them from using that language. At the bottom of the image are souls burning in hell.
Source_Title: Rhetorica christiana ad concionandi, et orandi usum accommodata ...
Source_publisher: Apud Petrumiccobum Potrutium
notes: This book, a manual of instructions for missionaries to Mexico that described indigenous religious rites and customs, was the first book by a Mexican to be published in Europe. The author gives a firsthand account of the evangelization of Mexico. Many thanks to Amara Solari who described the importance of this illustration.

Image_title: Of the notable things that Guaynacava caused to be done in Peru.
Description: Guaynacana, a native American king or chief, supervises workers or stone masons who build stone walls. Includes windlass, chisels, mallets, dividers, staff, and fortifications.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimento y conquisto de la provincia del Perù. English] The discoverie and conqvest of the prouinces of Peru
Source_publisher: By Richard Ihones
notes: Text describes the emperor, Guaynacava, who was responsible for the building of the mountain highways which revolutionized communication in the Inca empire. He also caused houses, known as tambos, to be built along the road for travelers or messengers. Guaynacava is more commonly known as Huayna Capac.

Image_title: [Llamas]
Description: Llamas.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimento y conquisto de la provincia del Perù. English] The discoverie and conqvest of the prouinces of Peru
Source_publisher: By Richard Ihones

Image_title: Iasminum Mexicanum.
Description: Flowering plant with tubular flowers. Includes tuberous root and detail of bud.
Source_Title: Caroli Clusii Atreb. aliquot notæ in Garciæ aromatum historiam. eiusdem descriptiones nonnullarum stirpium, & aliarum exoticarum rerum, qu[a]e à ... Francisco Drake ...
Source_publisher: Ex officina Christophori Plantini
notes: This plant is probably Mirabilis jalapa, the marvel of Peru or four o'clock. Charles De L'écluse, or Lescluse, born in Arras, then part of the Southern Netherlands, developed new garden cultures and cultivated plants, such as the tulip, potato, and chestnut, from other parts of the world. He was the director of the Holy Roman emperor's garden in Vienna (157387) and from 1593 was chair of botany at the University of Leiden, where his cultivation of tulips in the botanic garden began the Dutch tulip bulb industry. This book is comprised of notes on a botanical work (1563) by Garcia da Orta, a Portuguese physician who lived in Goa, India, and published several works about native herbs and spices. It also includes Clusius's notes about plants observed by Sir Francis Drake, on the western coast of America during his circumnavigation of the world (1577-1580). In the dedication Clusius describes his visit to Drake. Among the plants described are cocoa and "Winter's bark," a medicinal bark named for Captain William Winter, who sailing with Drake while passing through the Straits of Magellan in 1578, used the bark to cure scurvy among his crew.

Image_title: Cacao.
Description: Fruits or pods of the cacao tree. One is shown broken open.
Source_Title: Caroli Clusii Atreb. aliquot notæ in Garciæ aromatum historiam. eiusdem descriptiones nonnullarum stirpium, & aliarum exoticarum rerum, qu[a]e à ... Francisco Drake ...
Source_publisher: Ex officina Christophori Plantini
notes: This is probably Theobroma cacao sphaerocarpum, the South American species that has smooth as opposed to ridged fruits. The plant is now believed to be native to the Amazon River basin. Charles De L'écluse, or Lescluse, born in Arras, then part of the Southern Netherlands, developed new garden cultures and cultivated plants, such as the tulip, potato, and chestnut, from other parts of the world. He was the director of the Holy Roman emperor's garden in Vienna (157387) and from 1593 was chair of botany at the University of Leiden, where his cultivation of tulips in the botanic garden began the Dutch tulip bulb industry. This book is comprised of notes on a botanical work (1563) by Garcia da Orta, a Portuguese physician who lived in Goa, India, and published several works about native herbs and spices. It also includes Clusius's notes about plants observed by Sir Francis Drake, on the western coast of America during his circumnavigation of the world (1577-1580). In the dedication Clusius describes his visit to Drake. Among the plants described are cocoa and "Winter's bark," a medicinal bark named for Captain William Winter, who sailing with Drake while passing through the Straits of Magellan in 1578, used the bark to cure scurvy among his crew.

Image_title: Winteranus Cortex.
Description: Bark of the tree commonly known as Winter's bark.
Source_Title: Caroli Clusii Atreb. aliquot notæ in Garciæ aromatum historiam. eiusdem descriptiones nonnullarum stirpium, & aliarum exoticarum rerum, qu[a]e à ... Francisco Drake ...
Source_publisher: Ex officina Christophori Plantini
notes: This tree, Drimys winteri Forster, is native to southern South America. Charles De L'écluse, or Lescluse, born in Arras, then part of the Southern Netherlands, developed new garden cultures and cultivated plants, such as the tulip, potato, and chestnut, from other parts of the world. He was the director of the Holy Roman emperor's garden in Vienna (157387) and from 1593 was chair of botany at the University of Leiden, where his cultivation of tulips in the botanic garden began the Dutch tulip bulb industry. This book is comprised of notes on a botanical work (1563) by Garcia da Orta, a Portuguese physician who lived in Goa, India, and published several works about native herbs and spices. It also includes Clusius's notes about plants observed by Sir Francis Drake, on the western coast of America during his circumnavigation of the world (1577-1580). In the dedication Clusius describes his visit to Drake. Among the plants described are cocoa and "Winter's bark," a medicinal bark named for Captain William Winter, who sailing with Drake while passing through the Straits of Magellan in 1578, used the bark to cure scurvy among his crew.

Image_title: Drakena Radix.
Description: Roots of the Drakena plant.
Source_Title: Caroli Clusii Atreb. aliquot notæ in Garciæ aromatum historiam. eiusdem descriptiones nonnullarum stirpium, & aliarum exoticarum rerum, qu[a]e à ... Francisco Drake ...
Source_publisher: Ex officina Christophori Plantini
notes: Native to South America, this is probably Dorstenia drakena also known as contrayerva due to its ability to cure snake bite. Charles De L'écluse, or Lescluse, born in Arras, then part of the Southern Netherlands, developed new garden cultures and cultivated plants, such as the tulip, potato, and chestnut, from other parts of the world. He was the director of the Holy Roman emperor's garden in Vienna (157387) and from 1593 was chair of botany at the University of Leiden, where his cultivation of tulips in the botanic garden began the Dutch tulip bulb industry. This book is comprised of notes on a botanical work (1563) by Garcia da Orta, a Portuguese physician who lived in Goa, India, and published several works about native herbs and spices. It also includes Clusius's notes about plants observed by Sir Francis Drake, on the western coast of America during his circumnavigation of the world (1577-1580). In the dedication Clusius describes his visit to Drake. Among the plants described are cocoa and "Winter's bark," a medicinal bark named for Captain William Winter, who sailing with Drake while passing through the Straits of Magellan in 1578, used the bark to cure scurvy among his crew.

Image_title: Civitas Carthagena in Indiae occidentalis continente sita, portu commodissimo ad mercaturam inter Hispaniam et Peru exercendam
Description: Plan of the city of Cartagena in present-day Colombia. Decorative cartouche contains a phoenix. Decorative elements include lizard or iguana, ships, sea monster, flying fish, animals, compass rose with an armillary sphere, and soldiers. Items in image are lettered but no key is present.
notes: In 1585, Sir Francis Drake led a flottila of ships to the West Indies. The English fleet captured Santo Domingo on Hispaniola, Cartagena, Colombia, and St. Augustine, Florida. This map is one of four illustrating Drake's conquests presumably made by Baptista Boazio and published in Leiden. Baptista Boazio was an Italian artist resident in London who is well known for his manuscript maps, although no known engraved work with his full name on it exists. The signature on the "Drake map," or "The Famouse West Indian voyadge," of 1589 with its signature, "Baptista B.," is the only example of his [partial] name on an engraved work.
References: Cf. Burden, P.D. Mapping of North America, 65
SubjectArea3: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Civitas S. Dominici sita in Hispaniola Indica Angliae magnitudine sere oequatis, ipsa vrbs elagantor ab Hispanis extruca, et omnibus circumuicinis insulis iura dat
Description: A bird's eye view of Santo Domingo and the surrounding countryside. Built envrionment includes cathedral at center, churches, dwellings. Decorative elements include ships, turtles, fish, coat of arms, and an alligator in the sea. Military aspects include cannons, formations drilling, ships in harbor, scenes of warfare. Letters to a key (not provided on image) are given.
Source_Title: [Summarie and true discourse of Sir Frances Drakes' West Indian voyage. Latin.] Expeditio Francisci Draki equitis Angli in Indias Occidentales A.M. D. LXXXV
Source_publisher: Apud Fr. Raphelengium
notes: Sir Francis Drake captured the supposedly impregnable city of Santo Domingo in 1585.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Portrait of Hern?n Cort?s with his coat of arms]
Description: Portrait of Hern?n Cort?s with his coat of arms. Also includes facing poem.
Source_Title: Primera parte de Cortes Valoroso, y Mexicana`
Source_publisher: En casa de Pedro Madrigal
notes: Cort?s was awarded his coat of arms by Emperor Charles V.

Image_title: S. Augustini pars est terrae Florida ...
Description: Bird's-eye view of Saint Augustine, Florida, including harbor and scene of naval warfare. Includes compass rose, ships, some topographical details, cannons, battalions marching, boats, and large fish or dolphin. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: A summarie and true discourse of Sir Francis Drakes VVest Indian voyage
Source_publisher: by Richard Field, dwelling in the Blacke-Friars by Ludgate
notes: This view, one of four illustrating Drake's conquests, shows Sir Francis Drake's sack of Saint Augustine on May 28 and 29, 1586. It is the first known printed representation of a European settlement in North America. It also includes an illustration of a dolphin or dorado fish likely copied from a drawing of John White (and is the first White drawing to be published). The map was perhaps engraved by Baptista Boazio, an Italian artist resident in London well known for his manuscript maps, although no known engraved work with his full name on it exists. The signature on the "Drake map," or "The Famouse West Indian voyadge," of 1589 with its signature, "Baptista B.," is the only example of his [partial] name on an engraved work.
References: http://www.loc.gov/rr/rarebook/catalog/drake/drake-6-caribraid.html (Sept. 2004); Kraus, H.P. Drake, p. 21; Cumming, W.P. Discovery of North America, 187
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Portrait of Alonso de Ercilla y Zúñiga]
Description: Portrait of Alonso de Ercilla y Zúñiga.
Source_Title: [Araucana] Primera, segunda, y tercera partes de la Araucana
Source_publisher: En casa de Pedro Madrigal

Image_title: Armadillo
Description: Armadillo.
Source_Title: [Primera y segunda y tercera partes de la historia medicinal. Latin] Orbe de latorum, quorum in medicina vsus est, historia; ...
Source_publisher: Ex officina Platiniana, Apud Viduam, & Ioannem Moretum
notes: Image is placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Ad Praefectum Erreram seruntur munera ab uxore Reguli Provinciae Cumanae.
