Image_title: Americaner in Peru.
Description: Native American man from Peru wearing feathered headdress and ornaments and holding a war club.
Source_Title: Der newen summarische Welt Historia: vnnd Beschreibung aller Königreiche vnd Fürstenthumb auff Erden ... Von der Newen Welt
Source_publisher: durch Wolffgang Ketzeln
notes: This copy of Fabronius contains two books bound together. This image is in the second book which is is bound with the author's Newe Summarische Welt-Historia, Schmalkalden, 1614.
References_exhibitions: Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Item 63

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with four portrait medallions--Blasco Nuñez Vela; Cristóbal Vaca de Castro, governor of Peru; Pedro de Valdivia, governor of Chile; Hernando de Soto. Includes scenes of battle against fortified positions. Six vignettes show the battle between the forces of Chile and Vaca de Castro; the battle of Santiago de Chile; the battle of Quilacura in Chile; the battle at Mauvila, the fort and chief city of the Gulf Indians (present-day Mobile) who, led by their chief, Tuscaloosa (here Tlascaluza) were conquered by Hernando de Soto; and Hernando de Soto's retreat to Florida. Includes fortifications, cannons, horse, dogs, and ships.In the center is the Spanish royal coat of arms (of Castile and Leon).
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellano en las Islas y tierra firme del mar oceano ... Decada setima
Source_publisher: Por Iuan de la Cuesta
notes: The four men were involved in the wars in Peru, Chile, and southeastern North America during the middle of the sixteenth century.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with four portrait medallions--Pedro de la Gasca, Gabriel de Rojas, Diogo Centeno, General Pedro Alonso de Hinojosa. Includes scenes of battle in Pocona, Panama, Guarina (or Huarina), Chuquinga (Peru), and Xaquixaguana (Jaquijaguana, Chile). Includes fortifications, cannons, horse, dogs, and ships.In the center is the Spanish royal coat of arms (of Castile and Leon).
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellano en las Islas y tierra firme del mar oceano ... Decada octava
Source_publisher: Por Iuan de la Cuesta
notes: The four men were involved in the civil wars in Peru during the middle of the sixteenth century. Sent from Panama to Peru, the conquistadors aided in the restoration of authority to Spain.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with thirteen portrait medallions of native Americans or Peruvian Inca rulers--Guascar Terzeno ynca, Guiaynacapac Duodezimo ynga, Topaynga yupangui Undecimo ynga, Pachaiuti yupangui Decimo ynga, Vrco noueno ynga, Viracocha Octauo ynga, Aiarmango Capac I Rey Del Cuzco, Cinchiaroca Segundo ynga, Lloquiyupangui Terzero Ynga, Maytacapac Quarto ynga, Yngaroca Sesto ynga, Yaguaroco Sesto ynga, and Yaguarfuacac Yupangui Setimo ynga. Cultural artifacts include headdresses, helmets, septres, and ceremonial garments. In the center is the Spanish royal coat of arms (of Castile and Leon) and the coat of arms of the president of the Council of the Indies, Luis de Velasco, marques de Salinas.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellano en las Islas y tierra firme del mar oceano ... Decada quinta
Source_publisher: Por Iuan de la Cuesta
notes: The portraits are of the Inca rulers of Peru. In order of reign they are Manco Capac, Sinchi Roco, Lloque Yupanqui, Maita Capac, Capac Yupanqui, Capac Yupanqui, Inca Roco, Yahuar Huacac, Inca Viracocha, Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui, Topa Inca Yupanqui, Huayna Capac, Huascar, and Atahualpa. Luis de Velasco (1534-1617), son of Luis de Velasco (d.1564), second viceroy of New Spain, was (like his father) viceroy of New Spain (1590-1595, 1607-1611) and of Peru (1595-1604). He became president of the Council of the Indies in 1611.
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writings about the New World, Fig. 25

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page with four portrait medallions--Alonso de Alvarado, Gonzalo Jimenez de Quesada, Rodrigo Orgonez, and Sebastian de Belalcazar [or Benalcazar], and six vignettes showing the battles of Salinas, Abancay, Benalcazar, and at Cuzco. Also shows the prison of Atahualpa, Inca king of Peru, and the treaty between Almagro and Alvarado. Includes native Americans and scenes of warfare, cannons, fortifications, dwellings, and horses. In the center is the Spanish royal coat of arms (of Castile and Leon).
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: Historia general de los hechos de los Castellano en las Islas y tierra firme del mar oceano ... Decada sesta
Source_publisher: Por Iuan de la Cuesta
notes: The portraits are of conquistadors of Peru. The Spanish under the leadership of Francisco Pizarro conquered the Inca territory by 1533 when the Inca leader Atahualpa was executed, although the last of the Incas, Tupac Amaru, was not executed until 1571. In the process the Spanish also set off a series of internecine wars among the conquerors. Belalcazar first led the Spanish into Ecuador. Once there he and Alvarado fought against Diego de Almagro at the battle of Salinas near Cuzco. Orgonez took part in the battle of Abancay in which he captured Alvarado. Quesada founded New Granada.

Image_title: Inhabitantes flurij.[?] Rio de la plata
Description: Two native Americans. One offers the other a boleadora.
Source_Title: Iournael oft daghelijcz-register van de voyagie na Rio de Plata
Source_publisher: By Michiel Colijn, Boeck-vercooper op't vvater by de Oude-brugge int Huyt-boeck
notes: Boleadoras were tools used by indigenous peoples of the Argentinian Pampas to hunt. A boleadora consisted of two stones bound by a leather cord which were thrown and then used to trip an animal. The gauchos, or cowboys, of Argentina later would refine this tool and make it their own.
References_exhibitions: Klooster, W. Dutch in the Americas, Fig. 1.2

Image_title: [Dutch musketeers fire on a native vessel shortly after navigating the Strait of Magellan in 1616]
Description: Dutch in a boat fire upon a native American outrigger with a musket or gun. Native Americans guide the sailboat with rudders or paddles, one tends a cook fire, three sailors have fallen into the water. In the background is a ship.
Source_Title: [Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse] Iournal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse
Source_publisher: By Willem Jansz, op't water inde Sonnewyser
notes: Text describes Schouten's voyage around the coast of Peru and Chile. Since the author is unknown, this journal is generally attributed to Schouten.
References_exhibitions: Cf. Klooster, W. Dutch in the Americas, Fig. 1.6

Image_title: Les habitans de la Moche
Description: Native Americans of Isla Mocha. Cultural artifacts include axe or hatchet and spear.
Source_Title: [Beschryvinghe van de voyagie om den geheelen werelt cloot] Beschrijvinge vande voyagie om den geheelen werelt-kloot
Source_publisher: By Michiel Colijn, boeckverkooper op't vvater, aen de Koorn-Marckt, in't Huys-Boek
notes: Olivier van Noort was the first Dutchman to circumnavigate the world. He reached Isla Mocha near present-day Concepción, Chile, in March 1600.

Image_title: La moche in Chili
Description: Native American settlement with cultivated fields, dwellings, and llamas[?] on Isla Mocha. Europeans land in long boats on shore.
Source_Title: [Beschryvinghe van de voyagie om den geheelen werelt cloot] Beschrijvinge vande voyagie om den geheelen werelt-kloot
Source_publisher: By Michiel Colijn, boeckverkooper op't vvater, aen de Koorn-Marckt, in't Huys-Boek
notes: Olivier van Noort was the first Dutchman to circumnavigate the world. He reached Isla Mocha near present-day Concepción, Chile, in March 1600.Engraver's name taken from map of Strait of Magellan in this same book.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Fretum Magllanicu[s]
Description: Map of the Strait of Magellan showing the course taken by Olivier van Noort's three ships from November 1599 to February 1600. Cartographic elements include detailed depictions of the mouth of the Rio de la Plata, Puerto Deseado, and the southern coastline of Chile, degrees of latitude, scales, and compass roses. Includes a penguin and ships.
Source_Title: [Beschryvinghe van de voyagie om den geheelen werelt cloot] Beschrijvinge vande voyagie om den geheelen werelt-kloot
Source_publisher: By Michiel Colijn, boeckverkooper op't vvater, aen de Koorn-Marckt, in't Huys-Boek
notes: Olivier van Noort was the first Dutchman to circumnavigate the world.Part of right side of plate seems not to have been printed.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Quomodo Americus Vesputius in Pariam, modò Americam dictam pervenerit, acquale hominum genus ibidem offenderit.
Description: Amerigo Vespucci and soldiers meet native Americans who offer them women. In the background a sick man lies in a hammock while others dance around him. Also includes scene of burial. Platters of food are ready to be buried with the corpse. Also includes ship and dwellings.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 10. Latin] Americae pars decima: Qua continentur, I. Duae navigationes Dn. Americi Vesputii ... II. Solida narratio de moderno provinciae Virginiae statu ... III. Vera descriptio Novae Angliae ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: Text describes how in the region of Paria, present-day Venezuela, people danced around a sick person and then left him alone for four days with food and water to recover or die. If the sick person died, he was buried with food for their journey into the next world. This work was published by Johann Theodor de Bry and contains three parts. The first part includes two letters of Amerigo Vespucci describing his voyages to America in 1497 and 1499. The second is derived from Ralph Hamor, A true discours of the present state of Virginia, London, 1615. The third part is derived from Captain John Smith, A description of New England, London, 1616. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 10. Latin. Imprint information from colophon.
SubjectHeadings1: First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners

Image_title: Quibus remediis contra morbos utantur Indiani.
Description: Native Americans place a sick man in a stream, then chase him with whips around a fire, let his blood, and put him in a hammock. Includes dwellings. On the interior of a dwelling hang human limbs (scene of cannibalism).
Source_Title: [America. Pt 10. Latin] Americae pars decima: Qua continentur, I. Duae navigationes Dn. Americi Vesputii ... II. Solida narratio de moderno provinciae Virginiae statu ... III. Vera descriptio Novae Angliae ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: Text describes how in the region of Paria a person with a fever was placed in a cold stream for two hours, chased around a fire until dried, and then put to rest. This work was published by Johann Theodor de Bry and contains three parts. The first part includes two letters of Amerigo Vespucci describing his voyages to America in 1497 and 1499. The second is derived from Ralph Hamor, A true discours of the present state of Virginia, London, 1615. The third part is derived from Captain John Smith, A description of New England, London, 1616. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 10. Latin. Imprint information from colophon.

Image_title: Quomodo Indiani Hispanis per foeminas dolos struxerint, atque hinc velitaris pugna coortasit.
Description: Native American women in canoes meet Spanish soldiers in boats. In the background from a settlement made of dwellings built on water, native American soldiers attack Spaniards who shoot at them with guns or muskets.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 10. Latin] Americae pars decima: Qua continentur, I. Duae navigationes Dn. Americi Vesputii ... II. Solida narratio de moderno provinciae Virginiae statu ... III. Vera descriptio Novae Angliae ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: Text describes how the Spanish explorers discovered villages built upon the waters of a lake, Lago de Maracaibo, linked by bridges and reminding them of Venice (from which the name Venezuela comes). When the natives saw the Spanish coming they paddled in canoes with young women to offer them to the visitors. At a signal from older women, the young women jumped from the canoes and the men began shooting arrows at the Spanish. This work was published by Johann Theodor de Bry and contains three parts. The first part includes two letters of Amerigo Vespucci describing his voyages to America in 1497 and 1499. The second is derived from Ralph Hamor, A true discours of the present state of Virginia, London, 1615. The third part is derived from Captain John Smith, A description of New England, London, 1616. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 10. Latin. Imprint information from colophon.
SubjectHeadings1: First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners

Image_title: Quomodo Hispani alio quodam in loco excepti fuerint, ubi incolae serpentibus vescuntur.
Description: Spanish soldiers approach bound serpents or dragons. In the background, the creatures are grilled and native American women are being offered to the Spanish. Also includes scene of dancing and of first encounter with native Americans with natives fleeing into the woods.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 10. Latin] Americae pars decima: Qua continentur, I. Duae navigationes Dn. Americi Vesputii ... II. Solida narratio de moderno provinciae Virginiae statu ... III. Vera descriptio Novae Angliae ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1499-1500, the Spanish, under Alonso de Ojeda and including Amerigo Vespucci, were reputed to have landed on the shore of Cabo de la Vela in present-day Colombia. Many natives fled into the woods when they landed. The Spanish followed them and came upon a settlement where many strange animals described as being horrible snakes with feet and wings (iguanas) were held and being prepared for a meal. The natives were very hospitable, even offering their women. This work was published by Johann Theodor de Bry and contains three parts. The first part includes two letters of Amerigo Vespucci describing his voyages to America in 1497 and 1499. The second is derived from Ralph Hamor, A true discours of the present state of Virginia, London, 1615. The third part is derived from Captain John Smith, A description of New England, London, 1616. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 10. Latin. Imprint information from colophon.
SubjectHeadings1: First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners

Image_title: Abbildung dess hafens der Statt S. Jacob, Valparisa genannt.
Description: View of the settlement of present-day Valparaiso, Chile. Includes burning ship, ships, scene of naval warfare, marching battalions, compass rose, and a native American man and woman with feathered headdress and spear. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. German] Historische Beschreibung der wunderbarlichen Reyse
Source_publisher: Durch Paull Jacobi
notes: Text describes Valparaiso as being the harbor of the town of San Jago, perhaps Santiago, 80 miles from Valparaiso. Spilbergen and his men arrived on June 12, 1615. In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Valparaiso was founded by Juan de Saavedra in 1536. This work is taken from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. German.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Abbildung der Schlacht mit den Spaniern bey Nacht gehalten.
Description: Battle by night. Includes noctural naval warfare, ship sinking, and cannons. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. German] Historische Beschreibung der wunderbarlichen Reyse
Source_publisher: Durch Paull Jacobi
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Spilbergen and his men were pursued by the commander general of the Spanish fleet, Don Rodrigo de Mendoza, and engaged battle off of the coast of Lima, Peru. This work is taken from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.

Image_title: Fürbildung der andern Schlacht so mit den Spaniern bey Tage gehalten.
Description: Battle by day. Includes daytime or diurnal naval warfare, ship sinking, men swimming in the water, and cannons. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. German] Historische Beschreibung der wunderbarlichen Reyse
Source_publisher: Durch Paull Jacobi
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Spilbergen and his men were pursued by the commander general of the Spanish fleet, Don Rodrigo de Mendoza, and engaged battle off of the coast of Lima, Peru. The Dutch were victorious. This work is taken from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. German.

Image_title: Abbildung dess Hafen Caliou de Lima.
Description: View of Callao de Lima, in present-day Peru, showing the Spanish fleet surrounded by the Dutch ships. Built environment includes dwellings and church. Includes scenes of warfare and naval battle. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. German] Historische Beschreibung der wunderbarlichen Reyse
Source_publisher: Durch Paull Jacobi
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. This work is taken from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. German.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Descriptio freti Le Maire à Guilhelmo Schouten Hornano inventi & lustrati.
Description: Map or chart of Estrecho de Le Maire and Cape Horn at the tip of South America showing the voyage of Willem Corneliszoon Schouten around Cape Horn. Cartographic elements include compass rose, rhumb lines, and degrees of latitude.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: Schouten's discovery of the way round Cape Horn, named after the town of Hoorn from which he came, in 1615 was kept secret by the Dutch until the middle of 1618, making this map one of the earliest to show his journey. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: XIII. Delineatio civitatis et portus Aquapolque.
Description: View of the harbor of Acapulco de Juárez, Mexico, showing the welcome given by the inhabitants to Europeans. Includes fish, ships, boats, dwelling, church, fortifications (present-day Fort San Diego), and domestic animals such as donkeys, cattle, and sheep. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Spilbergen and his men arrived in Acapulco in October 1615 and exchanged the numerous Spanish prisoners they had for provisions. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Delineatio portus San-Iago, Selagues et Nativida.
Description: View of the harbors of Santiago and Barra de Navidad, Mexico. Includes scene of warfare and naval warfare, battalions fighting, guns or muskets, compass roses, ships, boats, and a large image of a captured fish. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Spilbergen and his men arrived in Santiago, Mexico, in October 1615. The two bays of Santiago and Salagua face the neck of land on which the present-day town of Manzanillo is located. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea3: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Delineatio portus Quintero.
Description: View of the harbor of Quintero, Chile. Includes scene of naval warfare, marching battalions, compass rose, native American man, woman, and child, hoe, horses, ships, boats, casks, and dwelling. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Spilbergen and his men arrived on June 13, 1615, and erected a crescent or half-moon enclosure to protect the men who were collecting water for their ships. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Delineatio stationis Guarmensis.
Description: View of the harbor of Guarme, present-day Huarmey, Peru. Includes scene of warfare, fortifications, boats, ships, church, men fishing with net, casks, battalions marching, and compass rose. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. The Dutch had gone ashore at Guarme to replenish their stocks of water and had sent a force of men to the town to find food. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Peyta oppidum ab Hollandis expugnatum.
Description: View of the harbor of Paita, in present-day Peru. Includes scene of warfare, boats, ships, church, battalions marching, hill with crosses or crucifixes on it, and compass rose. In foreground two men with a large bird paddle a balsa raft. Also includes another balsa raft with sails. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Spilbergen and his men arrived off Paita on August 8, 1615. Text describes a large bird [condor], two yards high and three yards wide, captured at the island of Lobos de Tierra, near Lambayeque. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: America Meridionalis
Description: Map of South America. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude, scales, and some topographical details. Decorative elements include ships, sea monsters, native American holding bow and arrow, native Americans in canoe with fire. Decorative cartouche includes women holding navigational tools such as dividers, globe, and armillary sphere. Decorative inset shows a plan of Cuzco, Peru.
notes: This map was published in Mercator's Atlas, Amsterdam, 1619, and is here held separately.
References: Keoman, I.C. Atlantes Neerlandici, II, 330, no. 315 (Me26A)
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Tijpus Freti Magellanici; quod Georgius Spilbergius cum classe lustravit.
Description: Plan of the Strait of Magellan with south at the top. Includes European men with muskets or guns greeting native Americans, penguin, scenes of hunting and warfare, spears, bow and arrow, drinking vessel, birds, dwellings, ships, fruit tree, compass rose, and some topographical details. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjacent text.
Source_Title: Oost ende West-Indische spiegel: der 2. leste navigatien, ghedaen inden jaerem 1614. 15. 16. 17. ende 18. daer in vertoont woort
Source_publisher: By Nicolaes van Geelkerchen
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Six heavily-armed ships and about 700 men left the Netherlands to circumnavigate the world.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: la Mocha
Description: View of Isla Mocha with two native Americans and llama [?] in foreground. Includes dwellings, meeting of inhabitants with Europeans, ships, and sheep. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjacent text.
Source_Title: Oost ende West-Indische spiegel: der 2. leste navigatien, ghedaen inden jaerem 1614. 15. 16. 17. ende 18. daer in vertoont woort
Source_publisher: By Nicolaes van Geelkerchen
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Six heavily-armed ships and about 700 men left the Netherlands on a voyage to circumnavigate the world; one ship deserted before the Strait was passed. After successfully passing through the Strait of Magellan, the ships first stopped at Isla Mocha.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Aquapolgue
Description: View of Acapulco de Juárez showing the welcome given by the inhabitants to Europeans. Includes fish, ships, boats, dwelling, church, fortifications (present-day Fort San Diego), and sheep. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjacent text.
Source_Title: Oost ende West-Indische spiegel: der 2. leste navigatien, ghedaen inden jaerem 1614. 15. 16. 17. ende 18. daer in vertoont woort
Source_publisher: By Nicolaes van Geelkerchen
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Six heavily-armed ships and about 700 men left the Netherlands on a voyage to circumnavigate the world; one ship deserted before the Strait was passed. The Dutch were surprisingly given a friendly welcome and supplies by the inhabitants of Acapulco. The fleet then sailed west to the Moluccas which it reached in March 1616.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Caljou de Lima.
Description: View of Callao de Lima showing the Spanish fleet surrounded by the Dutch ships. Built environment includes dwellings and church, Includes scens of warfare and naval battle. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjacent text.
Source_Title: Oost ende West-Indische spiegel: der 2. leste navigatien, ghedaen inden jaerem 1614. 15. 16. 17. ende 18. daer in vertoont woort
Source_publisher: By Nicolaes van Geelkerchen
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Six heavily-armed ships and about 700 men left the Netherlands on a voyage to circumnavigate the world; one ship deserted before the Strait was passed. The Dutch were surprisingly given a friendly welcome and supplies by the inhabitants of Acapulco. The fleet then sailed west to the Moluccas which it reached in March 1616.On July 17, 1615, the Dutch ships, which had fewer armed soldiers but twice as many big guns, overcame the defending Spanish fleet, the armadilla, which consisted of two crown galleons supported by five conscripted merchant ships.Callao, the port city of Lima, was destroyed by the great earthquake of 1749.
References: Spilbergen, J. van East and West India Mirror, Hakluyt Society, 2nd ser., no. 18
References_exhibitions: Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Item 125
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Delineatio insulae Lannocha.
Description: View of Isla Mocha, present-day Chile, with two native Americans and llama in foreground. Includes dwellings, meeting of inhabitants with Europeans, ships, market, and sheep. Includes a concert on the beach with musical instruments and scene of trading. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. After successfully passing through the Strait of Magellan, the ships first stopped at Isla Mocha on April 24, 1615. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings2: First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners

Image_title: [Map of the Le Maire Strait]
Description: Plan of the Estrecho de Le Maire, including Tierra del Fuego and part of the Strait of Magellan. Also includes compass rose, ships, degrees of latitude, and route of Willem Corneliszoon Schouten and Jacques Le Maire's voyage around Cape Horn.
Source_Title: [Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse. Spanish] Relacion diaria. del viage de Iacobo de Mayre, y Guillelmo Cornelio Schouten, en que descubrieron nueuo estrecho y passage del Mar del Norte al Mar del Sur ...
Source_publisher: Por Bernardino de Guzman
notes: Le Maire and Schouten were searching for a way to the East Indies which did not include sailing through the Strait of Magellan or the Cape of Good Hope--routes granted only to the East India Company.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Delineatio freti Magellanici.
Description: Plan of the Strait of Magellan with south at the top. Includes European men with muskets or guns greeting native Americans, penguin, scenes of hunting and warfare, spears, bow and arrow, drinking vessel, birds, dwellings, ships, fruit tree, compass rose, and some topographical details. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. Six heavily-armed ships and about 700 men left the Netherlands to circumnavigate the world. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Delineatio insulae San. Mariae.
Description: View of the island of Santa Maria off of the coast of Punta Lavapié, Chile. Includes settlements burning, ships and boats in harbor, scene of warfare, and compass rose. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. After stopping at Isla Mocha, Spilbergen landed at Santa Maria on May 29, 1615, and the Spaniards invited the Dutch to dinner. Suspecting a trap the Dutch withdrew from the island after scattered skirmishes. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Delineatio insulae Conceptionis.
Description: View of the settlement of present-day Talcahuano, Chile, in Concepción Bay. Also includes Punta de Bio Bio, San Pedro, San Vincent, and the island of Quiriquina. Includes a native American man, woman, and child, ships in harbor, settlement burning, church, dwellings, compass rose, and horses. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text at bottom.
Source_Title: [America. Pt 11. Latin] Americae pars undecima: seu Descriptio admirandi itineris ... qua ratione in Meridionali plaga freti Magellanici novum hactenusque icognitum in mare Australe transitum patefecerit ...
Source_publisher: Typis Hieronymi Galleri. Hieronymus Galler
notes: Concepción, first founded on the site of present-day Penco, was moved inland to its current site in 1754. Spilbergen and his men landed at Concepcíon on June 3, 1615. In 1614 the Dutch East India Company and the States-General commissioned Joris van Spilbergen to sail to the Moluccas via the Strait of Magellan. This work is translated from Willem Corneliszoon Schouten, Journal ofte beschryvinghe van de wonderlicke reyse, Frankfurt a. M., 1619. The appendix is translated from Joris van Spilbergen, Oost en West-Indische spiegel, Leiden, 1619. Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 11. Latin.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Spaniards torture native Americans] Figuere Num. 15.
Description: Spaniard stands over native American who is tied to two tree trunks while another tends a fire at the feet of the man. A man is hanged from a tree. Details include dwellings.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel

Image_title: [Soldiers chase native Americans into a pit]
Description: Spaniards drive native Americans out of their dwellings into a pit filled with stakes. The natives are impaled on the stakes. Spaniards on horseback are visible in the background. Includes settlement and swords.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: Text discusses the treatment of Indians in Guatemala.This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598, and is here reversed. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Scene of cannibalism]
Description: Native Americans butcher human corpses. Natives buy and eat human body parts. A child's body is cooked over a fire. Natives are forced to carry an anchor and a cannon for the Spanish. Includes scene of cannibalism, swords, boat, ship, and butcher shop.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: Text discusses the treatment of Indians in Guatemala where the Spanish let Indians kill and eat their enemies, thus feeding their native armies and killing other natives.This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598, and is here reversed. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Scene of torture]
Description: A native American is tied to a chair and his feet are placed in stocks. Armed Spaniards stand around him while a boy pours a liquid over the victim's feet which are over a fire. Includes dog on a chain, pike, crossbow, fortifications, and scene of torture.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: Text discusses the treatment of the chief or cacique of Michoacán, Mexico.This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598, and is here reversed. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Spaniards drive native Americans on forced march]
Description: European soldiers lead native American men, women, and children on a forced march. Includes guns or muskets, swords, dwellings burning, and natives being stabbed. One soldiers raises a club to beat a man, woman, and her child.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: Text discusses a Spanish commander in Jalisco, Mexico, who captured many native Americans and drove them away from their lands, laying waste to their towns.This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598, and is here reversed. See also Theodor de Bry, America, Pt. 4, plate 4. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Execution of Atahualpa]
Description: Atabalipa [Atahualpa] who is chained to his chair is garroted or executed in a room with Spanish soldiers and blacks [slaves]. Includes spears, gun or musket, headdress, pole and rope used to strangle the Inca king, and scene of warfare. In the background, Atabalipa is shown on his litter holding a scepter. He throws down a book that a monk gives him.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: The Spanish were uneasy about an uprising by natives as long as Atahualpa remained alive. In 1533, on a trumped-up charge of conspiracy, the Inca king was found guilty and sentenced to death by strangulation. The execution was performed by black slaves under orders from the Spanish. This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598, and is here reversed. See also Theodor de Bry, America, Pt. 6, plate 11. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Spaniards mutilate native Americans]
Description: Spaniards cut off noses, hands, and gauge out eyes of native Americans. In the background, Spaniards force natives down a steep hill, and dogs attack escaping natives. Includes hatchets or axes, swords, and dwellings.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598.One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Spaniards punish native Americans]
Description: Spaniards punish native Americans by whipping one man who is tied to a stake with flails and by pouring hot wax and metal on the back of another. Also includes scenes of mining and agriculture. Also includes a winch, pickax, hoe, and dwellings.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: Text discusses the punishment of caciques or native American rulers in Cuba.This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598.One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Scene of torture]
Description: Spaniards torture a native American by holding his feet to a fire. Other men bring out even more gold and precious objects. In the background, Spaniards kill women. Includes guns or muskets, swords, bows, and arrows.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: Text discusses how in the year 1514, a villainous governor, probably Pedro Arias d'Avila, governor of Panama, had a cacique tortured who had already given the governor gold and precious objects. Under torture the cacique revealed the location of even more gold. This governor would also attack mountain retreats of the natives and kill all the men, but capture the women. When other native men would arrive to rescue the women, they in turn were killed. This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598, and is here reversed. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Scene of torture]
Description: Spaniards torture native Americans by burning them at stakes. Includes men bringing wood to feed the fire. In the background other natives are forced into a dwelling which is burning.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: Text discusses the slaughter of five or six thousand natives in Cholula, Mexico. The verse here compares the Spaniard's behavior to that of Nero who sang while Rome burned.This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Men bring treasure to European soldiers]
Description: Native Americans bring tribute to Spaniards. In the background, a ruler or emperor is carried on a litter from a walled city.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: The image of the emperor is that of the Inca, Atahualpa [Atabaliba], who was carried by his subjects to meet Pizarro, although here the text refers to Mexico. This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: [Soldiers chase native Americans from room]
Description: European soldiers chase native Americans wearing feathered headdresses and garments from room while ruler or emperor sits on throne.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spiegel der Spaensche tyrannye, ghescheit in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Ghedruckt by Ian Evertss Cloppenburg, op 't Watertegen over de Koor-Beurs in vergulden Bÿbel
notes: Text discusses how the Spanish attacked the nobles in the court of Moctezuma [Montezuma] who were dancing the mitote for their imprisoned emperor. The Spanish left no one alive.This image is derived from author's Narratio regionum ..., Frankfurt a. M., 1598. One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.
SubjectHeadings3: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Opuntia sine ficus Indiqua Minor.
Description: Opuntia or prickly pear cactus in flower.
Source_Title: Histoire des plantes, nouuellement trouuées en l'Isle Virgine, & autres lieux, lesquelles ont esté prises & cultiuées au iarden de Monsieur Robin arboriste du Roy. Non encore veuës n'y imprimées par cy deuant.
Source_publisher: Chez Guillaume Macé au mont S Hilaire, a l'enseigne de la pyramide.
notes: This cactus is Opuntia ficus-indica. Text notes that it is the host plant for the cochineal insect.Some contend that this description of Virginia plants is by the French botanist, Jean Robin (1550-1629), the most famous botanist of his time. The book appeared with its own title in 1620 in L'Histoire des plantes by Geoffroy Linocier (itself an adaptation of Historia Plantarum by Du Pinet). Jean Robin established one of the most beautiful gardens in Paris between the Louvre and St. Germain l'Auxerrois. There he naturalized many plants, some of them raised from seeds gathered in Virginia.Antoine du Pinet (d. 1584) condensed the work of the botanist P. A. Mattioli to produce one of the earliest pocket herbals. Each plant is illustrated in woodcut and described briefly.

Image_title: Narcissus Indicus rubro flore.
Description: Jacobean, St. James, or Aztec lily.
Source_Title: Histoire des plantes, nouuellement trouuées en l'Isle Virgine, & autres lieux, lesquelles ont esté prises & cultiuées au iarden de Monsieur Robin arboriste du Roy. Non encore veuës n'y imprimées par cy deuant.
Source_publisher: Chez Guillaume Macé au mont S Hilaire, a l'enseigne de la pyramide.
notes: This lily is probably Sprekelia or Jacobean lily, also known as the Aztec lily. It is native to Mexico.Some contend that this description of Virginia plants is by the French botanist, Jean Robin (1550-1629), the most famous botanist of his time. The book appeared with its own title in 1620 in L'Histoire des plantes by Geoffroy Linocier (itself an adaptation of Historia Plantarum by Du Pinet). Jean Robin established one of the most beautiful gardens in Paris between the Louvre and St. Germain l'Auxerrois. There he naturalized many plants, some of them raised from seeds gathered in Virginia.Antoine du Pinet (d. 1584) condensed the work of the botanist P. A. Mattioli to produce one of the earliest pocket herbals. Each plant is illustrated in woodcut and described briefly.

Image_title: [View of Cuzco with royal carriage]
Description: Spanish priests and soldiers take the Inca ruler [Atahualpa] and his retinue in a carriage drawn by llamas to the settlement of Cuzco in background. The ruler carries a symbol of the sun. Also includes horses, cross or crucifix, gun or muskets, war clubs, feathered headdresses and garments, flag, litter carried by horses, and fortifications.
Source_Title: Nova typis transacta navigatio ...
notes: This image shows the capture of Atahualpa or Atabalipa by Francisco Pizarro at Cajamarca, Peru. Atahualpa, in a desperate attempt to buy his freedom, offered Pizarro a room of gold. The ransom was in vain; Pizarro had the Inca king executed as soon as the ransom was collected. Wolfgang Kilian (1581-1662), an Augsburg printmaker, is presumed to be the artist for all the images in this book not obviously derived from the Petits Voyages and Grands Voyages of Theodor de Bry. Honorius Philoponus is a pseudonym, probably for Caspar Plautius to whom this book is dedicated. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Native Americans ride a manatee]
Description: Observed by Europeans, native Americans ride on a sea monster or manatee while in the background others capture another sea creature and turtle.
Source_Title: Nova typis transacta navigatio ...
notes: First mentioned by Pietro Martire d'Anghiera, De orbe novo (book 1, cap. 8), the manatee derived its name from the Spanish word for hands (manos). This manatee is an anecdotal interpretation of López de Gómara's description of an animal which would let boys and men ride on its back. Wolfgang Kilian (1581-1662), an Augsburg printmaker, is presumed to be the artist for all the images in this book not obviously derived from the Petits Voyages and Grands Voyages of Theodor de Bry. Honorius Philoponus is a pseudonym, probably for Caspar Plautius to whom this book is dedicated. Image placed horizontally on page.
References: Moffitt, J. F. & S. Sebastián, O Brave New People, p. 245-246

Image_title: [Native Americans receive Spaniards]
Description: Native American chieftain, or cacique, surrounded by his retinue receives a bishop (in galero with crozier and mitre). In the background is a village with native Americans standing on the walls. Other elements include feathered headdresses and garments, ornaments of bird feathers, muskets, spears, dwellings, and ceremonial clubs.
Source_Title: Nova typis transacta navigatio
notes: Text refers to Peru. Wolfgang Kilian (1581-1662), an Augsburg printmaker, is presumed to be the artist for all the images in this book not obviously derived from the Petits Voyages and Grands Voyages of Theodor de Bry. Honorius Philoponus is a pseudonym, probably for Caspar Plautius to whom this book is dedicated. Image placed horizontally on page.
References: Cf. Moffitt, J. F. & S. Sebastián. O Brave New People, p. 236-247

Image_title: [Puerto Deseado]
Description: Plan of Puerto Deseado in present-day Argentina. Includes scenes of hunting and burial. Men kill and butcher sea lion and seal, dig up the bones from a graveyard, and carry water back to a ship. Cartographic elements include compass rose. Also includes axes, skeletons, casks, rheas, penguins, and llamas. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at bottom.
Source_Title: Spieghel der Australische navigatie, door den ... zee-heldt, Iacob Le Maire ...
Source_publisher: By Michael Colijn, boeck-vercooper op't water by de oude brugh, in't huys-boeck.
notes: The Dutch reached Puerto Deseado on the estuary of the Rio Deseado in December 1615 where they ran aground. While refitting and preparing for the next leg of the voyage, one of the ships, the Hoorn, was accidentally set on fire while her weed-fouled hull was being scorched clean and was destroyed (letter F on the map). The Dutch found what they thought was a giant's grave or a native Patagonian grave. Puerto Deseado was named by the English circumnavigator, Thomas Cavendish or Candish, in 1586 after his ship, Desire. This journal (based on Le Maire's logbook) of the voyage of Jacob Le Maire and Willem Schouten was the first true publication of the expedition. Issued as a part of Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, Nieuwe werelt, anders ghenaempt West-Indien, Amsterdam, 1622.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Portrait of Jacob Le Maire]
Description: Portrait of Jacob Le Maire holding a map of the Estrecho de (Strait of) Le Maire and with the [Le Maire] coat of arms.
Source_Title: Spieghel der Australische navigatie, door den ... zee-heldt, Iacob Le Maire ...
Source_publisher: By Michael Colijn, boeck-vercooper op't water by de oude brugh, in't huys-boeck.
notes: Jacob Le Maire was chosen by his father, Isaac Le Maire, to command a ship to discover a passage to the South Seas that did not include the Strait of Magellan, a route controlled by the Dutch East India Company (VOC). This journal (based on Le Maire's logbook) of the voyage of Jacob Le Maire and Willem Schouten was the first true publication of the expedition. Issued as a part of Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, Nieuwe werelt, anders ghenaempt West-Indien, Amsterdam, 1622.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Apud Michaelem Cohinium Bibliopolam, ad insigne Libri Domestici
Description: Engraved title page with illustrations of six Aztec gods--the gods of death, water, gluttony, wind, wine, as well as the chief god, Hoitzili pochtli [i.e., Huitzilopochtli]. Also included are the king of Mexico (Acamapich, seventh child of Montezuma) and a temple. Decorative elements include Spanish royal coat of arms (of Castile and Leon), native Americans in boats, and map of the western hemisphere in a cartouche.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Descripción de las India Occidentalis. Latin] Novus Orbis, sive Descriptio Indiae occidentalis
Source_publisher: Apud Michaelem Cohinium Bibliopolam, ad insigne Libri Domestici
notes: First map to delineate California as an island.
References: Burden, P.D. Mapping of North America, 195
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, Fig. 12
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Descripçion del destricto del audiençia de Nueva Espana
Description: Map of Central America, including the Yucatan peninsula, present-day Mexico, Honduras, and Guatemala. Cartographic elements include locations of rivers and settlements.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Descripción de las India Occidentalis. Latin] Novus Orbis, sive Descriptio Indiae occidentalis
Source_publisher: Apud Michaelem Cohinium Bibliopolam, ad insigne Libri Domestici
notes: The maps in this book were copied from the manuscript maps of Juan López de Velasco and expanded by Herrera y Tordesillas. Cf. 17000-4.
References: Burden, P.D. Mapping of North America, 196

Image_title: Descripcion del destricto del audiencia de la Nueva Galicia
Description: Map of part of Central America, including present-day Mexico (states of Aguascalientes, Colima, and Jalisco, and parts of the neighboring states of Durango, Guanajuato, Michoacán, Nayarit, and Zacatecas). Cartographic elements include some topographical details, and locations of rivers, mountains, and settlements.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
