Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Scientific name: Procyon lotor.

Image_title: [top] Simivs Zambvs. [bottom] Levncvlvs titi.
Description: Monkeys. [bottom] Titi monkey.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: [bottom] Scientific name: Callicebus spp.

Image_title: [top] Sagouin. [middle] Gercopithecus sagouin clusii. [bottom] Cercopithecus barbatus clusii.
Description: Tamarins and marmosets.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: The family name, Cercopithecus, refers to an old world family of long-tailed primates; here the monkeys are probably tamarins or marmosets of the Callithricidae family and genus, Saquinus or Callithrix family.

Image_title: Taurus quivirensis.
Description: Buffalo or bison.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Scientific name: Bison bison.

Image_title: Su.
Description: Su or succarath.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Text describes an animal from Patagonia hunted for its fur by the native Americans, which lived by rivers, put its young on it back when threatened, and had a terrible cry. The same animal is illustrated in André Thevet's Cosmographie universelle and Les singularitez de la France Antarctique. Thought to be perhaps a giant sloth (mylodon or magatherium).

Image_title: Anser magellanicus.
Description: Great auk or magellanic penguin.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: This animal has been identified as a great auk, a flightless bird which lived in Newfoundland and other islands off the coast of Canada, Norway, Scotland and Iceland, but which is now extinct. The name, penquin, was originally applied to the great auk and afterward applied to birds of the Spheniscidae family which are of no relation to the great auk.

Image_title: Xochitenacatl.
Description: Toucan or emerald toucanet.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Scientific name of the emerald toucanet: Aulachorynchus prasinus.

Image_title: Altera xochitenacatl.
Description: Toucan or emerald toucanet.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Text descibes this toucan as another variety having a yellow top and black bottom to its beak. Probably another emerald toucanet. Scientific name of the emerald toucanet: Aulachorynchus prasinus.

Image_title: Mergus americanus.
Description: American merganser or common North American diving duck.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Scientific name: Mergus merganser americanus.

Image_title: [top] Psittacus elegans. [bottom] Psittacus minimus.
Description: Parrots.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Psittacus usually refers to the African grey parrot. Here the text describes a psittacus from Brazil.

Image_title: Ourissia sive tominejo.
Description: Hummingbird.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Native only to the Americas, hummingbirds were first identified by Oviedo in 1525 who speculated that they were perhaps a cross between an insect and a bird. Text also cites Andre Thevet, Singularitez de la France antarctique (and his description of the hummingbird which he called gonambuch) and Joseph Acosta, Historie naturalis. Hummingbirds are in the Trochilidae family.

Image_title: Manati phocae genus.
Description: Manatee.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Scientific name: Trichechus manatus.

Image_title: Reversus sive gaicanus.
Description: Eel.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Text discusses Christopher Columbus' sighting of eels, as well as Francisco Herando's description of them. Scientific name: Anguilla rostrata.

Image_title: Domina serpentum, sive teuhtlacocauhqui.
Description: Western diamondback rattlesnake.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Scientific name: Crotalus atrox.

Image_title: Iguana.
Description: Iguana.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Scientific name: Iguana iguana.

Image_title: Mater formicarum, sive tzicatlinan.
Description: Snake that delights in anthills.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Probably a coral snake. The Nahuatl name is tzicanântli, or "Mother of ants," because it lives at the bottom of ant hills.

Image_title: Manucodiata.
Description: Bird of paradise.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: The bird of paradise, a bird without feet which can never land on earth, is here shown with long plumage. Specimens of this bird sent to Europe seldom had the legs and feet attached, giving Europeans the idea that they flew continuously.

Image_title: [top] Manucodiata altera. [bottom] Rex avium paradisearum clusii.
Description: Two birds of paradise.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: The bird of paradise, a bird without feet which can never land on earth, is here shown with long plumage. Specimens of this bird sent to Europe seldom had the legs and feet attached, giving Europeans the idea that they flew continuously.

Image_title: Acaltetepon, seu monoxilus mucronatus.
Description: Mexican beaded lizard.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: The Mexican beaded lizard, along with the Gila Monster, are the only lizards known to be venomous. Scientific name: Heloderma horridum.

Image_title: Atatapalacatl.
Description: Aquatic plant.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Atatapalacatl means aquatic plant in Nahuatl.

Image_title: Ayotli.
Description: A winter squash or calabash plant.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: The Nahuatl word, "ayotl," means tortoise and may refer to the turtle-like shape of the pumpkin or squash. The image of the plant appears to be based on a verbal description.

Image_title: Guayaci ramulus.
Description: Branch of guaiacum or lignum-vitae tree.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Guaiacum, also known as Lignum vitae, received much attention during the sixteenth century as a cure for syphillis and other diseases.

Image_title: [top] Petum latifolium. [bottom] Petum angustifolium.
Description: Tobacco plants.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: The Brazilians called tobacco, "petum." The plant at the top is the large-leaved tobacco; the plant at the bottom is the narrow-leaved tobacco.

Image_title: Molle.
Description: Branch of the Brazilian or Peruvian peppertree.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Identified in the text as molle of Peru, but also known by other names such as Jesuit's balsam, aroeira, mastic tree, and aguaribay. The oil from the tree is often used medicinally by indigenous peoples of South America. Scientific name: Schinus molle.

Image_title: Tvna, Sive Nopalli Saxis Innascens
Description: Cactus.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Prickly pear (opuntia).
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Fig. 23

Image_title: Armadillo siue Aiatochtli; Armadillo Clvsii; Armadillo Genvs Altervm Clvsii
Description: Armadillos.
Source_Title: Ioannis Evsebii Nierembergii Madritensis ex Societate Iesu ... Historia natvrae, maxime peregrinae, libris XVI. distincta
Source_publisher: ex officina Plantiniana Balthasaris Moreti
notes: Three different kinds of armadillo are depicted, a hairy armadillo, a nine-banded(?) armadillo, and a three-banded armadillo,
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Fig. 21

Image_title: Nova Hispania et Nova Galicia
Description: Map of New Spain or Mexico. Decorative elements include the Spanish royal coat of arms, armadillos, ships. Geographical elements include names of native American and European settlements, a scale, lines of longitude and latitude, locations of churches and monasteries.
Source_Title: Tweede deel van 't Tooneel des aerdriicx, ofte Nieuwe atlas
Source_publisher: Apud Guiljelmum et Iohannem Blaeu
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Spaniards hang a woman and feed children to dogs]
Description: Spaniards hang a native American woman and feed children to dogs. A priest baptizes a child.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spieghel der Spaense tyrannye geschiet in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt by Evert Kloppenburg, op't Water tegen over de Koren Beurs inde Vergulden Bÿbel
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writings about the New World, Fig. 24.

Image_title: [Spanish massacre native Americans]
Description: Spaniards massacre native Americans. Some native Americans carry spoils of war. A village burns in the distance. Military aspects include swords, clubs, helmets, and spears.
Source_Title: [Brevissima relacion. Dutch] Den spieghel der Spaense tyrannye geschiet in West-Indien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt by Evert Kloppenburg, op't Water tegen over de Koren Beurs inde Vergulden Bÿbel

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Augustinians preaching and baptising native Americans in Peru. At top is an image of Saint Augustine of Hippo holding a heart pierced by an arrow, the annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary, and a monk holding a hemisphere labeled, "Peru."
Source_Title: [Crónica moralizada. Tomo I] Cronica moralizade del orden de San Augustin en el Peru
Source_publisher: Por Pedro Lacavalleria, en la calle de la Libreria
notes: The Augustininan symbol is a heart pierced by an arrow, often in flames. Erasmus Quellin II (1607-1678), a Flemish Baroque artist, probably painted the picture from which Pieter de Jode the Younger (1606-after 1674), Flemish engraver and publisher, engraved this title page.
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, Fig. 31

Image_title: Martirio Del bendito Pe. Fray Diego Ortiz En Vilcabamba
Description: Martyrdom of Fray Diego Ortiz in Vilcapampa. In the background are scenes of his trials at the hands of native Americans.
Source_Title: [Crónica moralizada. Tomo I] Cronica moralizade del orden de San Augustin en el Peru
Source_publisher: Por Pedro Lacavalleria, en la calle de la Libreria
notes: Ortiz, born in Spain in 1532, was a missionary to the Incas in Cuzco, Peru, until his martyrdom in 1571. Vilcapampa, or Vilcabamba, "the lost city of the Incas," from which the Inca led a rebellion against the Spanish until 1572, is probably Espíritu Pampa, an Inca city excavated in 1964. It has also been thought to be Machu Picchu.
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, Fig. 32

Image_title: [Virgin Mary]
Description: The Virgin Mary is shown standing on a cactus and surmounted by the papal crown and keys. Includes angels and double-headed eagle and wings.
Source_Title: Zodiaco regio, templo politico. Al excellentissimo señor don Diego Lopez Pacheco Gabrera, y Bobadilla Marques de Villena, y Mora
Source_publisher: Impresso con licencia, en la Imprenta de Francisco Robledo,
notes: Poem possibly by Estaban Aquilar or Mathias de Bocanega? Perhaps meant to represent the Virgin of Guadalupe, the figure shown in the image combines elements of European rule [the papal crown and keys and the double-headed Hapsburg eagle] and elements of indigenous legend [the eagle may represent the eagle which led the Aztecs to their home in Tenochtitlan].
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: De Seyndinghe nae de Nieuwe wereldt.
Description: The pillars of Hercules with "plus oultre" on them stand before an ocean and within scrollwork.
Source_Title: Af-beeldinghe van d'eerste eeuwe der societeyt Jesu
Source_publisher: Inde Plantiinsche durckeriie
notes: The pillars of Hercules refer to the promontories that flank the entrance to the Strait of Gilbraltar and were used on the royal coat of arms of Spain of Charles V and others. This book, an emblem book edited by Jean Bollandus, the Jesuit Provincial for Flanders and translated from Latin by Laurentius Uwens, was illustrated with emblems by Abraham van Diepenbeek (1596-1675), a follower of Rubens.
References: Shirley, R.W. Mapping the world (4th ed.) 352; http://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/rk097dw1744

Image_title: [Fruits]

Source_publisher: Chez Bonaventure & Abraham Elseviers, imprimeurs ordinaires de l'Université
notes: Text discusses the Indian fig or tuna fruit (possibly the prickly pear, Opuntia) which are either white or red and grow on a cactus.

Image_title: [Seed pods]
Description: Seed pods, possibly vanilla seed pods.
Source_Title: [Beschrijvinghe van West-Indien. French] L'histoire du nouveau monde ...
Source_publisher: Chez Bonaventure & Abraham Elseviers, imprimeurs ordinaires de l'Université
notes: Text discusses the decoctions of vanilla beans steeped in herbs and other herbs which were used medicinally by the Aztecs.
References: Bruman, H. "The culture history of Mexican vanilla," Hispanic American Historical Review, 1948, p. 360-376 (May 2007)

Image_title: [Nuts]
Description: Nuts.

notes: Text discusses nuts of the huitzpacotl, an Aztec word, which is used as a purge and as an emetic.
References: Grant Loomis, C. "Some Mexican lore prior to 1670," California Folklore Quarterly, 1944, p. 95-101 (May 2007)

Image_title: [Cocoa nuts]
Description: Cocoa beans.
Source_Title: [Beschrijvinghe van West-Indien. French] L'histoire du nouveau monde ...
Source_publisher: Chez Bonaventure & Abraham Elseviers, imprimeurs ordinaires de l'Université
notes: Text discusses the discovery of cacao in New Spain and Guatemala.

Image_title: [Cocoa pods and leaves]
Description: Cocoa pods and leaves on a branch.
Source_Title: [Beschrijvinghe van West-Indien. French] L'histoire du nouveau monde ...
Source_publisher: Chez Bonaventure & Abraham Elseviers, imprimeurs ordinaires de l'Université

Image_title: [Plant with leaves]
Description: Plant with leaves, possibly indigo plant.
Source_Title: [Beschrijvinghe van West-Indien. French] L'histoire du nouveau monde ...
Source_publisher: Chez Bonaventure & Abraham Elseviers, imprimeurs ordinaires de l'Université
notes: Text discusses the colors derived from this plant. Indigofera is a large genus of about 700 species of flowering plants belonging to the family Fabaceae.

Image_title: [Guava]
Description: Guava fruit with leaves on a branch.
Source_Title: [Beschrijvinghe van West-Indien. French] L'histoire du nouveau monde ...
Source_publisher: Chez Bonaventure & Abraham Elseviers, imprimeurs ordinaires de l'Université
notes: Text discusses the guava trees found in Mexico. Guava belong to the genus Myrtaceae.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Representation of the Virgin standing on crescent moon and a hemispere with Peru on it. She is flanked by two figures representing Faith (holding a cross) and Grace (with a dove holding a branch). At the bottom is a figure of a colla [?] (an Inca princess) or ñustra ( an Inca noblewoman) facing a devil or idol. Decorative elements include coat of arms of the Augustinian order (with sacred heart in flames pierced by arrows). Also included is a view of a lake (Lake Titicaca?).
Source_Title: Santuario de N.Señora de Copacabana en el Peru. Poema Sacro.
Source_publisher: Por Luis de Lyra
notes: Our Lady of Copacabana, the patron saint of Bolivia, is dressed as an Inca princess. She was made by a native Inca, Francisco Tito Yupanqui, descendant of Huayna Capac Inca and was enthroned in Copacabana on the shore of Lake Titicaca in 1583. Valverde was a prior and provincial vicar of the Augustinian order in Cuzco and Lima convents.

Image_title: St. Francisco de Campeche.
Description: View of the harbor at San Francisco de Campeche, now known as Campeche, Mexico. Includes a scene of naval warfare, government buildings, dwellings, cathedral, churches, monastery, ships, people on shore, and boats. Includes an inset map of the Yucatan and Gulf of Honduras; cartographic elements include sea banks or shoals, some topographical detail, location of Trugillo [Truxillo, Trujillo], Campeche, and Cuba. Items in the image are identified in key at bottom.
Source_Title: Historie ofte Iaerlijck verhael van de verrichtinghen der Geoctroyeerde West-Indische Compagnie, zedert haer begin, tot het eynde van 't jaer sesthien-hondert ses-en-dertich ...
Source_publisher: by Bonaventuer ende Abraham Elsevier
notes: Campeche, founded on the site of a Mayan village, was one of three ports that had a monopoly of trade on the Yucatán peninsula in the eighteenth century.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: S. Franco. de Borja ...
Description: Portrait of Saint Francisco Borgia [Francisco de Borja y Aragon] kneeling before an altar. Includes the IHS symbol of the Jesuits with three nails below, crucifix, skull wearing a crown or miter, instruments of self-mortification such as scourge or flails, chains, crown of thorns. Also includes coat of arms of Borja y Aragon, crowns, galeros, open books, and hands covered in armor or mail holding military materièl such as arrows, spears, tent.
Source_Title: Vida del santo padre, y gran siervo de Dios el B. Francisco de Borja, tercero general de la Compañia de Iesus ...
Source_publisher: Por Maria de Quiñones
notes: Borja was the third commissary-general of the Jesuits and given charge of the Jesuit missions in the East and West Indies. Under his leadership, the Society established its missions in Florida, New Spain and Peru.

Image_title: Trugillo
Description: View of the harbor at Trugillo [Trujillo or Truxillo], present-day Honduras. Includes ships, signal tower, dwellings, fortifications, cross, and people on the beach. Items in the image are numbered for identification in key at bottom of image. Of interest is the identification of individual ships, giving their names.
Source_Title: Historie ofte Iaerlijck verhael van de verrichtinghen der Geoctroyeerde West-Indische Compagnie, zedert haer begin, tot het eynde van 't jaer sesthien-hondert ses-en-dertich ...
Source_publisher: by Bonaventuer ende Abraham Elsevier
notes: Trujillo, a pirate stronghold, was destroyed several times between 1633 and 1797, and abandoned by the Spanish after it was deemed indefensible during the eighteenth century.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: D. Franco. de Quiñones Martin Gartia Ones y Loyola Pedro de Viscarra
Description: Three soldiers, or Spanish conquistadors, on horseback, identified as Francisco de Quiñónez, Martín García Oñez de Loyola, and Pedro de Viscarra de la Barrera. Includes military matériel such as armor, sword, and helmets. One man holds a baton.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Quiñónez was governor of Chile from 1599 to 1600, García Oñez de Loyola was governor from 1592 to 1598, and Viscarra de la Barrera was governor for a few months in 1592 and then for a few months from December 1598 to May 1599.

Image_title: D. Martin de Muxica del habito de santiago
Description: A soldier on horseback brandishes a baton. Includes a fallen soldier at his feet holding a broken sword and scene of warfare. Includes military matériel such as armor, sword, and helmets.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Martín de Mujica y Buitrón, a Spanish conquistador, was governor of Chile from 1646 to 1649.

Image_title: Pedro de Valdivia Franco de Villagra Gmo. Alderete Adelantado
Description: Three soldiers, or Spanish conquistadors, on horseback, identified as Pedro de Valdivia, Francisco de Villagra, and Gerónimo de Alderete. Includes military matériel such as shield and helmets.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Valdivia, Villagra, and Adelantado were Spanish conquistadors who waged war against the native Americans of Chile or the Mapache and Araucanians. Valdivia and Villagra also served as governors of Chile. Alderete was appointed governor but did not survive to assume the position.

Image_title: Alonso Garcia Ramon Alonso de Rivera Dr. Luis Merlo de la Fuente
Description: Three soldiers, or Spanish conquistadors, on horseback, identified as Alonso Garcia de Ramón, Alonso de Ribera de Pareja, and Luis Merlo de la Fuente Ruiz de Beteta. Includes military matériel such as shield, sword, and helmets.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Ramon, Rivera, and Merlo de la Fuente were Spanish conquistadors who waged war against the native Americans of Chile or the Mapache and Araucanians.

Image_title: D. Luis Fernandez de Cordova Marques de Baydes D. Franco. Laso della Vega
Description: Three soldiers, or Spanish conquistadors, on horseback, identified as Luis Fernandez de Cordova y Arce, the marqués de Baides, and Francisco Laso de la Vega. Includes military matériel such as shield, armor, and helmets.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Laso de la Vega was governor of Chile from 1629 to 1639. Luis de Cordova was appointed governor of Chile in 1625 by his uncle, Diego Fernandez de Cordova, who was viceroy of Mexico and Peru, and he served as governor until 1629. Francisco López de Zúñiga, marqués de Baides, governor of Chile from 1639 to 1646, was responsible for the Treaty of Quillín which established the territory between the Mapuches and the Spanish at the Río Biobío in Chile and which briefly established peace after the Araucanian Wars.

Image_title: Juan Xaraquemada D Lope de Ulloa Fernando Talaverano
Description: Three soldiers, or Spanish conquistadors, on horseback, identified as Juan Jaraquemada, Lope de Ulloa y Lemos, and Fernando Talaverano Gallegos. Includes military matériel such as shield, armor, and helmets.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Jaraquemada was governor of Chile from 1611 to 1612. Lope de Ulloa y Lemos was governor from 1618 to 1620, and Talaverano Gallegos was governor from 1671-1618.

Image_title: D. Franco Dalua D. Pedro Sorez de Ulloa D. D. Xpobal de la Cerda
Description: Three soldiers, or Spanish conquistadors, on horseback, identified as Francisco de Alava y Nureña, Pedro Osores de Ulloa, and Cristóbal de la Cerda y Sotomayor. Includes military matériel such as sword, armor, and helmets. One man holds a baton.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Cerda y Sotomayor was governor of Chile from 1620 to 1621, Osores de Ulloa was governor from 1621 to 1624, and Alava y Nureña was governor from 1624 to 1625.

Image_title: D. Garcia Hurtado de Mca. Marquis de Canete Pedro de Villagra Ro de Quiroga adelantado
Description: Three soldiers, or Spanish conquistadors, on horseback, identified as García Hurtado de Mendoza y Manríquez, Pedo de Villagra y Martínez, and Rodrigo de Quiroga López de Ulloa. Includes military matériel such as armor and helmets.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Hurtado de Mendoza y Manríquez was governor of Chile from 1557 to 1561, Villagra y Martínez was governor from 1563 to 1565, and Quiroga López de Ulloa was twice governor from 1565 to 1567 and from 1575 to 1580.

Image_title: Mariscal Martin Ruiz de Gamboa D. Melchoir Bravo de Sardvia [sic] D. Alo. Sotomior Marq. de Villahermosa
Description: Three soldiers, or Spanish conquistadors, on horseback, identified as Martín Ruiz de Gamboa de Berriz, Melchoir Bravo de Saravia Sotomayor, and Alonso de Sotomayor de Valmediano. Includes military matériel such as armor, sword, and helmets. One man holds a baton.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Ruiz de Gamboa de Berriz was governor of Chile from 1580 to 1583, Bravo de Saravia Sotomayor was governor from 1568 to 1575, and Sotomayor de Valmediano was governor from 1583 to 1592.

Image_title: Sic trans ferunt indi domus suas cum exvno in, alium locum transeunt
Description: Native Americans transfer a dwelling from one location to another.
Source_Title: Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y de las missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesvs
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo

Image_title: [left] ita saltant et canunt ind [right] Modi ludendi indorum Ludus quechucague
Description: [left] Native Americans dance around a pole. [right] Two native Americans games, one using a top, the other a Quechua game of dice.
Source_Title: Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y de las missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesvs

Image_title: Moduo ludendi indorum vocatur ala chueca
Description: Native Americans play chueca, a game similar to field hockey.

Image_title: La imperial imagen d. N.S[enor]a. delas Nieves obradora de milagros en la tierra i en el mar ...
Description: Our Lady of the Snows holding the Christ child stands before the city of Concepción, Chile. She holds a chain which guides a ship into port during a storm. Includes various miracles attribued to her, a geyser, and birds raining down from heaven. Also includes settlement, dwellings, fortifications, and anchor.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y delas missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesus
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: The image of Nuestra Señora de las Nieves is associated with the founding in 1552 of La Imperial in Mapuche territory by Pedro de Valdivia. La Imperial was abandoned by the Spanish in 1600 but they took with them the image of Our Lady of the Snows and placed it in the cathedral in Concepcion. She was the patroness of sailors of the dangerous waters off the shores of Chile.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: Indi prodigijs Montis igniuomi, Amnis arborem, mostrum que trahentis, Aquilarum iterum tantum Visarum, exercitus Hispani in aere de suo Victoris, paci conciliantur et Fidei in Chile
Description: Native Americans led by their god or idol are vanquished by a heavenly host which includes soldiers led by a man on a horse wielding a sword. Hail falls from heaven and lava flows from a volcano. In the distance large birds roost on the roofs of a settlement. The idol has a human face with the body of a bird and a snake's tail. Includes bows, scene of warfare, and fortifications.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y delas missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesus
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Text describes the miraculous victory of the Spanish over the Araucanians in 1640.

Image_title: Adelantado Geronimo de Alderete
Description: Portrait of Geronimo de Alderete wearing armor and holding a baton and helmet. In the background, men set siege to fortifications. Men raise ladders, other men run from a cask of dynamite which explodes against a gate.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y delas missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesus
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Alderete was active during the war against the Araucanians and was named governor of Chile after the death of Pedro de Valdivia. However, he died of yellow fever in Panama before assuming the position of governor.

Image_title: Cap Christobal de Escobar Villarroel
Description: Portrait of Captain Christobal de Escobar Villarroel wearing armor and holding a baton. In the background is a scene of warfare.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y delas missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesus
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo

Image_title: Vera Efigies cuiusdam Arboris, quoe in hunc modum et figura[m] crucis, et Crucifixi creuisse inventa est in Regno Chilensi in America, ubi in valle Limache colitur magna populi devotione ab anno d[omi]ni 1634
Description: Tree found in the district of Limache, Chile, which has a figure of Christ crucified on it.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y delas missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesus
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Text relates the miraculous appearance of the figure of Christ on a tree. The image was venerated until the church in Renca (to which it was transferred) burned in 1729.

Image_title: [top] sic implicant indi tauros et equos proijcientes ad extrema funis ligatos globos [bottom] Sic euitat struthio canis insequetis ictum
Description: [top] Native American hunts cattle or buffalo with a boleadora. [bottom] Dog hunts a long-tailed bird.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y delas missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesus
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Boleadoras were tools used by indigenous peoples of the Argentinian Pampas to hunt. A boleadora consisted of two stones bound by a leather cord which were thrown and then used to trip an animal. The gauchos, or cowboys, of Argentina later would refine this tool and make it their own.

Image_title: Vera efigies alterius, quae in rupis cavitate in modum capellae concameratae, non ab opifice aliquo delineata ...
Description: Virgin Mary with her child, Jesus, stands in a grotto or cave. Two native Americans [Araucanians] worship her.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, y delas missiones, y ministerios que exercita en el la Compañia de Iesus
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: This image is said to be a true copy of an effigy which was miraculously found in a cliff in Chile.

Image_title: [Sijnde een Kameel-Schaep, nevens een Chilees met sijn Vrouw.]
Description: Male and female Chilean native Americans encounter European men. Includes bow and arrow, feathered headdress, European ship, and llama.
Source_Title: Journael ende historis verhael van de reyse gedaen by oosten de straet le Maire, naer de custen van Chili, onder het beleyt van den Heer Generael Hendrick Brouwer, inden jare 1643 ...
Source_publisher: gedruckt by Broer Jansz, woonende op de Nieu-zijds Achter-burghwal, inde Silvere kan.
notes: Text notes that the Spanish were the first to name these people. The encounter took place in May 1643 in southern Chile near Fort Castro or Calbuco.In 1642 the VOC (Dutch East India Company) and the WIC (West India Company) sent a fleet under Hendrik Brouwer to Chile to conquer the city of Valdivia and to take the Spanish gold mines. In 1643 Brouwer conquered the island of Chiloe and the city Valdivia, making him military governor beginning in May 1643. Brouwer died on August 7, 1643, and the vice-general Elias Herckmans took control.Image title from following page.

Image_title: [Sijnde den grooten Inwijck, ofte Chilesche binne-landtsche Zee.]

Source_Title: Journael ende historis verhael van de reyse gedaen by oosten de straet le Maire, naer de custen van Chili, onder het beleyt van den Heer Generael Hendrick Brouwer, inden jare 1643 ...
Source_publisher: gedruckt by Broer Jansz, woonende op de Nieu-zijds Achter-burghwal, inde Silvere kan.
notes: In 1642 the VOC (Dutch East India Company) and the WIC (West India Company) sent a fleet under Hendrik Brouwer to Chile to conquer the city of Valdivia and to take the Spanish gold mines. In 1643 Brouwer conquered the island of Chiloe and the city of Valdivia, making him military governor beginning in May 1643. Brouwer died on August 7, 1643, and vice-general Elias Herckmans took control.Image title from following page.

Image_title: Archipielago de Chiloe.
Description: Map of the archipelago that includes Chiloé Island or Isla Grande de Chiloé off the coast of Chile. Built environment includes church.
Source_Title: [Historica relacion de reyno de Chile] Historica relacion del reyno de Chile
Source_publisher: Por Francisco Cavallo
notes: Image seems to be taken from both a view from above and a view looking head on at the coast. Spain claimed the island in 1567, and a settlement was founded at Castro in 1567, later the seat of a Jesuit mission and capital of the province until the founding of Ancud in 1768. In 1784 Chiloé Island was made a direct dependency of the colonial viceroyalty of Peru, while continental Chile was a captaincy-general within the viceroyalty. In December 1817 the island became the last stronghold of Spanish loyalists (together with Valdivia) fleeing from the Chilean mainland. A Chilean expedition led by Thomas Cochrane, 10th Earl of Dundonald failed to conquer it. On 15 January 1826, after another unsuccessful attempt in 1824, the Spanish forces surrendered to a military expedition led by Ramon Freire, and the island was fully incorporated into the independent republic of Chile, although Spain did not recognize it until 1844.

Image_title: [Homoyoca Dio del Mexico]
Description: Homoyoca [Ometeotl?] is shown on a maize or corn decorated litter. Native American god or deity holds a plume of quetzal feathers in one hand and wears a feathered headdress.
Source_Title: [Imagini de i dei de gli antichi ] Imagini delli Dei de gl'antichi ...
Source_publisher: presso il Tomasini.
notes: The highest level of the Aztec pantheon was occupied by Ometeotl [Ometecutli-Omeciuatl] who combined both male and female and dominated the genesis of things. Brotherston identifies an image from Codex Rios [Rios f. 1v, 'Genesis'] as the Lord of our Flesh, Tonacatecutli [Ometecutli], who with his partner, Tonacatciuatl [Omecihuatl], is associated with the beginning of time and the beginning of the year. The image from the Codex Rios (also known as Vaticanus A) also includes the crown.Image dimensions also includes printing ornaments.Image title taken from text.

Image_title: [Miquitlantecatle o Tzitzimitl]
Description: Miquitlantecatl [Mictlantecuhtli] is shown seated on a throne and holding a basket and bunch of flowers. He wears a feathered headdress and a bone or snake on his chest.
Source_Title: [Imagini de i dei de gli antichi ] Imagini delli Dei de gl'antichi ...
Source_publisher: presso il Tomasini.
notes: According to the text, Mictlantecuhtli, "Lord of Mictlan" [or lord of the underworld or the dead], was also known as Tzitzimitl. Tzitzimitl was a celestial demon goddess.Image dimensions also includes printing ornaments.Image title taken from text.

Image_title: [De Chilensium indigenarum Statura, & habitu corporis, atque Vestitu.]
Description: Native Americans from Chile. Cultural artifacts include staff, poncho, vessels, and spurs.
Source_Title: Historia naturalis Brasiliae
Source_publisher: Franciscum Hackium & Lud. Elzevirium
notes: Image title taken from chapter heading.

Image_title: Apariçion De la imagen de nuestra Sa. D. guadalupe de Mexico
Description: A man wearing a cloak with an image of Our Lady of Guadalupe on it stands before a cleric who kneels before him. At the man's bare feet are scattered roses, as well as a hat and staff.
Source_creator: Lasso de la Vega, Luis, 17th cent.
Source_Title: Huei Tlamahuiçoltica omonexiti in ilhvicac tlatóca çihvapilli Santa Maria Totlaçonantzin Gualalupe
Source_publisher: en la Imprenta de Iuan Ruyz
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it filled with out-of-season roses. This book, written in Nahuatl by the vicar of the chapel of Guadalupe, is the second known retelling of the Guadalupe story. The first was written in 1648 by Lasso de la Vega's friend, the priest, Miguel Sanchez. According to Medina, this account was probably written by a native Mexican, Antonio Valeriano, and edited, with a preface by Lasso de la Vega.

Image_title: Armas de la ciudad de Mexico
Description: Coat of arms of Mexico City. Includes crown, lions, gate, or fortifications.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Still used as the arms of the Distrito Federal, Mexico City, this coat of arms is described as being on a blue shield (representing the lake upon which Mexico City was founded) with a golden castle in the middle, lions rampant on either side of the castle, and with ten cactus leaves bordering the shield.

Image_title: Armas de la muy noble y muy leal ciudad de Yucatan
Description: Coat of arms of Mérida, in the present-day state of Yucatan, Mexico. Includes fortress or fortification and rampant lion. Also includes crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Still used as the coat of arms of Mérida, the lions, castle, and crown represent the power and authority held by Charles V .

Image_title: Armas de la ciudad de Guaxaca.
Description: Coat of arms of Oaxaca. Includes Virgin Mary on a crescent moon surrounded by adoring angels. Also includes crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: First known as Hua-xyacac [Nahuatl], the Spanish settlement, raised to the category of royal city by decree of Charles V and named Antequera de Guaxaca in 1532, is now known as Oaxaca.

Image_title: Armas de la ciudad de Nicaragua.
Description: Coat of arms of Nicaragua. Includes a lion rampant with his paw on a ball. Also includes a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Presently used as the coat of arms of Managua, the capital of Nicaragua. Managua was founded in 1819 and given the name of Leal Villa de Santiago de Managua and made the capital in 1852.

Image_title: Armas de la ciudad de Durango.
Description: Coat of arms of Durango, Neuva Vizcaya. Includes a man sitting in a chair holding a quill with an angel in the background. Also includes a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Nueva Vizcaya was the first province of northern Mexico (New Spain) to be explored and settled by the Spanish.

Image_title: Armas de la ciudad de Venezuela.
Description: Coat of arms of a city in Venezuela showing a female saint instructing a child in reading. Includes crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: This may be Saint Ann instructing the young Virgin Mary. The text discusses the cathedral of the church of Venezuela being dedicated to Saint Ann.

Image_title: Armas de la ciudad de la Puebla de los Angeles
Description: Coat of arms of Puebla. Includes fortifications with five towers, river, angels, crown, and Latin motto.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Puebla, in the Mexican state of Puebla, was also known as Puebla de los Angeles, and Puebla de Zaragoza. Still used as the arms of the city, the coat of arms is a green shield with a five-tower fortress in gold; two angels hold the fortress. The "K" and "V" in the angel's hands stand for Karolus V (Charles V). Below the fortress is a blue river. The text translates to "God command his angels take care of you in all your paths."

Image_title: [Episcopal arms of the diocese of Michoacán]
Description: Episcopal coat of arms of Michoacán. Includes lions rampant with galero and six fiocchi on either side of shield.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: This coat of arms is also used by González Dávila in his map of Michoacán, in volume 2 of this work, cf. 0432-1.

Image_title: [Coat of arms of San Pedro and San Pablo]
Description: Coat of arms of San Pedro and San Pablo, Michoacán. Includes church on top of a mountain with three mountains in front of it and an image of a church. Also includes a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera

Image_title: [Coat of arms of Michoacán]
Description: Coat of arms of Michoacán. Includes three kings holding scepters surmounted by a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Used as the colonial arms of Michoacán, until it was forbidden by the republicans, this coat of arms is now used by the capital city of Michoacán, Morelia.

Image_title: [Coat of arms of Antigua Guatemala]
Description: Coat of arms of Antigua Guatemala. Includes a saint on horseback holding a flag and wielding a sword against fallen soldiers, three volcanoes (one erupting), scallop shells, and a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Used as the coat of arms of Guatemala, these arms were of La Antigua Guatemala, capital of Guatemala until 1773 when it was largely destroyed by an earthquake. The volcanoes surrounding the town of Antiqua are Acatenango, Agua, and Fuego. The saint on horseback is James of Compostela, also known as Santiago, patron saint of Guatemala, Spain, conquistadors, and the Spanish army.

Image_title: [Episcopal arms of the archdiocese of Antigua Guatemala]
Description: Episcopal coat of arms of the archdiocese of Guatemala. Includes shield with galero and nine fiocchi on either side.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera

Image_title: [Coat of arms of Guadalajara]
Description: Coat of arms of Guadalaxara [Guadalajara], in the present-day state of Jalisco, Mexico. Includes two lions rampant with their claws sunk into the trunk of a tree. The shield is surmounted by a closed knight's helm or helmet, a crusader's cross, and a flag.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Guadalajara was granted a coat of arms by Charles V by royal writ issued on November 8, 1539.

Image_title: Armas de la ciudad de Chiapa.
Description: Coat of arms of Chiapa, in the present-day state of Chiapas, Mexico. Includes two lions rampant with their claws sunk into a fortress or fortification and into a palm tree. They are separated by a river. Also includes a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ...Tomo primero
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: The coat of arms of Chiapa was initially the emblem of Ciudad Real founded in 1535 by the Spanish and is now known as San Cristóbal de las Casas. The lions, castle, and crown represent the power and authority held by Charles V .

Image_title: [Arms of the city of Lima]
Description: Coat of arms of the city of Lima showing the double-headed Hapsburg eagle, a crown, the pillars of Hercules with "Plus Ultra" on them, three crowns, and a star with a tail in the center.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: The coat of arms of Lima, or Cuidad de los Reyes [City of the Kings], still includes the three crowns, star, and eagles of its colonial days.

Image_title: [Arms of the viceroyalty of New Granada]
Description: Coat of arms of the viceroyalty of New Granada, present-day Colombia and Venezuela. Includes an eagle holding a seeded pomegranate in its talons. The shield is surrounded by pomegranates. Includes crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: The coat of arms of the viceroyalty of New Granada incorporates the pomegranate taken from the coat of arms of Granada.

Image_title: [Eclessiastical arms of the city of La Plata]
Description: Ecclesiastical coat of arms of the city of Sucre [La Plata], present-day Bolivia. Includes a tree flanked by two pillars [pillars of Hercules] and two mountains or hills with crosses on them. Also includes fortifications with lions rampant and a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: Sucre was founded as Ciudad de la Plata de la Nueva Toledo in 1538.

Image_title: [Arms of the city of Quito]
Description: Coat of arms of the city of Quito, Peru. Includes castle or fortifications with two eagles or birds clasping a crusader's cross on the main tower. Also includes a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera

Image_title: [Arms of the church of Panama]
Description: Coat of arms of the church of Panama. Includes three ships, a yoke, and a bundle of arrows surrounded by rampant lions and fortifications. Also includes a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera

Image_title: [Arms of Cartagena]
Description: Coat of arms of Cartagena, present-day Venezuela. Includes two lions rampant flanking a cross. Also includes a crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: This coat of arms is the colonial arms of Cartagena and was first used in 1574.

Image_title: [Arms of the city of Trujillo]
Description: Coat of arms of the city of Trujillo [Truxillo], Peru. Includes an eagle, a crown, two pillars surmounted by crowns [pillars of Hercules], crossed branches, fruit, and the letter "K."
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: por Diego de la Carrera
notes: This coat of arms is still used as the Trujillo's arms. One of the first cities founded by Spanish conquerors, it was named in honor of Francisco Pizarro's birthplace in Spain, and its arms were granted by Charles I in 1537 (signified by the letter "K")

Image_title: De Apoyomatli, seu Phatzisiranda Cypero Americano.
Description: A tall, grass-like plant with its roots or tubers.
Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: Scientific name: Cyperus articulatus, also known as jointed flatsedge. The plant was included in Diderot's Encyclopedie. One of its uses was as an aphrodisiac. It has a hollow stem.Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.
References: Jan G. R. Elferink, "Aphrodisiac Use in Pre-Columbian Aztec and Inca Cultures," Journal of the History of Sexuality, vol. 9, No. 1-2, January/April, 2000, p. 28.

Image_title: De Hoitziloxitl Anethina, seu arbore refinam manante.
Description: Balsam of Peru or Hoitziloxitl tree.
Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: Scientific name: Myroxylon balsamum. The resin of this plant is used for incense and in medicinal preparations. It is also known as balsam of Peru, because it was shipped to Spain from Peru.Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.

Image_title: De Tlilxochitl seu flore nigro Araco Aromatico.
Description: Tlilxochitl or vanilla plant showing its leaves and beans.
Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: The vanilla plant is an orchid that grows as a vine and is native to Mexico. The Nahuatl name tlilxochitl means black flower (referring to the pod). The Totonaca paid tribute to the Aztecs in the form of vanilla beans. Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.

In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.

Image_title: De Tomahuactlacopatli Aristolochia Mexicana.

The harlequin dutchman's pipe is native to Central America.Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.

Image_title: [Cacaua Quahuitl]
Description: Small cacao tree with its roots and seed pods.
Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: Scientific name: Theobroma cacao. It is native to South America, and its seeds are used to make cocoa and chocolate. Its name comes from the Nahuatl word cacahuatl.Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: [American landscape]
Description: View of a coastline with a river or stream leading to the sea. Includes trees, vines, plants, European man, ships, settlement, buffalo [bison], iguana or lizard, bird, and fish [?] on land.
Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.

Image_title: [De Xochinacaztli, seu Flore auriculae.]
Description: Branch of the Xochinacaztli or ear flower plant.

Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: Scientific name: Cymbopetalum penduliflorum, known in Spanish as orejuela. This plant was used by the Mexicans to flavor chocolate drinks. The plant is native to Guatemala.Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.

Image_title: [left] Acocotlis; [right] Acocotlis alia Icon.
Description: Two double-flowered dahlia plants with their tubers and details of their leaves.
Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: Author describes these dahlias as coming from Cuernavaca and Tepoztlan in present-day Morelos, Mexico. The Nahuatl name translates literally as water cane or water pipe. Paul D. Sorensen (see citation below) believes that these double-flowered dahlias may be Dahlia pinnata, D. coccinea, or D. brevis. The dahlia is native to Mexico and is its national flower. Its stems were used for pipes.Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him.

Hern?ndez linked each plant with one or more of the humors of the body. Image title from chapter title.

Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: It has not been possible to identify the Tepehoila plant. Ahoaton may be a member of the buckthorn family, Rhamnus serrata, also known as Karwinskia humboltiana. Hern?ndez was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him. Hern?ndez linked each plant with one or more of the humors of the body. Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: [De Olcacatzan Pahuatlanica China Mexicana.]
Description: Olcacatzan pahuatlanica plant with its root, leaves, flowers, and fruit. Includes detail of leaf.
Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: Olcacatzan is one of the species of Smilax, commonly known as sarsaparilla and as China root. True China root is native to China and Japan, but forms of American Smilax were substituted for it. Many different species exist and are widely spread throughout the Americas. Smilax aritstolochiaefolia is native to Mexico. Hern?ndez describes three different kinds. It was an important plant, because it was believed to treat many illnesses including venereal disease. Hern?ndez was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him. Hern?ndez linked each plant with one or more of the humors of the body. Image title from chapter title.

Image_title: [top] [De Tlalchinol Xochitl. Venerea Medcina II.] [bottom] [ De Tlallantlacuacuitlapilli, seu Cauda parui Tlacuatzin. Michuacanica Diuretica.]
Description: [top] Tlalchinol plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers. Includes detail of flowers. [bottom left and right] Two kinds of Tlallantlacuacuitlapilli (or Tlallantlacua cuitlapilli) plant with their roots and leaves. Each includes a detail of its leaf.
Source_Title: Nova plantarum, animalium et mineralium mexicanorum historia ...
Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: [top] Tlalchinol is a region of Mexico east of Querétaro and north of Mexico City. The plant is thus called simply "flower from Tlalchinol." [bottom] Tlallantlacua is a region of Mexico east of Mexico City. Cuitlapilli translates literally as "tailwing." Tlalantlacacuitlapilli translates as purgative root of Michoacán. Hernández identifies four varieties of this plant. It may be Michoacán root and as such, any one of the genus Ipomoea such as I. purga, I. orizabensis, I. stans Cav., I. jalapa, I. batatas, or I. simulans. Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him. Hernández linked each plant with one or more of the humors of the body. Image title from chapter title.

Source_publisher: Sumptibus Blasij Deuersini, & Zanobij Masotti Bibliopolarum. Typis Vitalis Mascardi
notes: Tlallantlacua is a region of Mexico east of Mexico City. Cuitlapilli translates literally as "tailwing." Hernández identifies four varieties of this plant. Hernández was an expert on medicinal botany who became personal physician to King Philip II of Spain. In 1571 he left for Mexico and the Philippines where he collected specimens for seven years. Three indigenous artists accompanied him. Hernández linked each plant with one or more of the humors of the body.

Source_Title: Verdadera relasion del modo conque se instituyo de nuebo la deuosion del santissimo rosario, en la insigne y noble ciudad de Santiago de Guatemala ...
Source_publisher: por Benedictos Guasco
notes: Text discusses the 1651 earthquake in Guatemala during a celebration of the Virgin Mary. Publication statement from colophon.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Guatemala

Image_title: [Dutch ships at Puerto Deseado]
Description: Three ships enter the harbor at Puerto Deseado. On land various parties engage in battle, set up a blacksmithing operation, and carry a box upon their shoulders. Also includes canoes, boats, bellows, bows, arrows, rheas, ships running aground, scene of warfare, and anvils.
Source_Title: Wonderlijcke voyagie, by de Hollanders ghedaen, door de Strate Magalanes, ende voorts den gantschen kloot des aerdtbodems om, met vier schepent ...
Source_publisher: By Lucas de Vries, boeck-verkooper in de snippe-vlucht
notes: Olivier van Noort was the first Dutchman to circumnavigate the world. He reported that when his men went ashore at Puerto Deseado in present-day Argentina, they found many native American graves.Between 1598 and 1601, Olivier van Noort led four Dutch ships sponsored by Dutch merchants on a voyage through the Straits of Magellan. Their purpose was to harass the Spanish with whom they were at war, to create commerce, and, if possible, to circumnavigate the globe. An abridgment of author's Beschryvinghe van de voyagie om den geheelen werelt cloot, Rotterdam, 1601.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [La Mocha, Chile]
Description: Native American settlement with cultivated fields, dwellings, and llamas[?] on Isla Mocha. Europeans land in long boats on shore.
Source_Title: Wonderlijcke voyagie, by de Hollanders ghedaen, door de Strate Magalanes, ende voorts den gantschen kloot des aerdtbodems om, met vier schepent ...
Source_publisher: By Lucas de Vries, boeck-verkooper in de snippe-vlucht
notes: Olivier van Noort was the first Dutchman to circumnavigate the world. He reached Isla Mocha near present-day Concepción, Chile, in March 1600.Between 1598 and 1601, Olivier van Noort led four Dutch ships sponsored by Dutch merchants on a voyage through the Straits of Magellan. Their purpose was to harass the Spanish with whom they were at war, to create commerce, and, if possible, to circumnavigate the globe. An abridgment of author's Beschryvinghe van de voyagie om den geheelen werelt cloot, Rotterdam, 1601.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Athabalipa, Peruviae Imperator.
Description: Portrait of Atabalipa wearing feathered headdress and ornaments.
Source_Title: Het vorstelyck treur-toonneel, of Open onder-gangh der grooten
Source_publisher: By Nicolaes van Ravensteyn, op S. Anthonis Marckt
notes: Atabalipa [Atahualpa] was the last independent Inca ruler in Peru. He was captured by the Spanish and executed in 1533, despite his paying a vast ransom for his life.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page showing native Americans. Includes feathered headdress and garment, tattoos, penguins, bows, and arrows.
Source_Title: Wonderlijcke voyagie, by de Hollanders ghedaen, door de Strate Magalanes, ende voorts den gantschen kloot des aerdtbodems om, met vier schepent ...
Source_publisher: By Lucas de Vries, boeck-verkooper in de snippe-vlucht
notes: An abridgment of author's Beschryvinghe van de voyagie om den geheelen werelt cloot, Rotterdam, 1601. The French edition of the author's book, Description du penible voyage, Amsterdam, 1602, identifies the three native Americans as from the Strait of Magellan, from the island of Capul (in the Philippine Islands), and from New Spain.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page which includes images of Father Martin de Jesus, dressed in Franciscan habit, and Don Beltran Nuno de Guzman, in armor with swords. Also shown are native Americans with feathered headdresses and bows and arrows, a king enthroned with scepter and orb, and a cross with two arms nailed to it.
Source_Title: Libro segundo, Dia chronica miscelanea, en que se tr�ta de la conquista espiritual y temporal d[e] la sancta prouincia
notes: Martin de Jesus was probably Friar Martin de la Coruna, one of the "twelve apostles of Mexico," Franciscans who landed with Hernan Cortes at La Paz in 1535 and unsuccessfully attempted to establish missions in Mexico. The author of this work was part of another later, and also unsuccessful, effort by the Franciscans to establish missions in lower California. Nuno Beltran de Guzman was governor of Panuco and Neuva Galacia; he was eventually jailed for his cruelty to native Mexicans.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page which includes images of Father Martin de Jesus, dressed in Franciscan habit, and Don Beltran Nuno de Guzman, in armor with swords. Also shown are native Americans with feathered headdresses and bows and arrows, a king enthroned with scepter and orb, and a cross with two arms nailed to it.
Source_Title: Libro segundo, Dia chronica miscelanea, en que se trâta de la conquista espiritual y temporal d[e] la sancta prouincia
notes: Martin de Jesus was probably Friar Martin de la Coruña, one of the "twelve apostles of Mexico," Franciscans who landed with Hernán Cortés at La Paz in 1535 and unsuccessfully attempted to establish missions in Mexico. The author of this work was part of another later, and also unsuccessful, effort by the Franciscans to establish missions in lower California. Nuño Beltran de Guzman was governor of Panuco and Neuva Galacia; he was eventually jailed for his cruelty to native Mexicans.

Image_title: [Native American]
Description: Native American man holding a spear.
Source_Title: Anthropometamorphosis: man transform'd: or, The artificiall changling historically presented ... fashioning and altering their bodies from the mould intended by nature ...
Source_publisher: Printed by William Hunt
notes: Text describes how Vasco Nuñez de Balboa [Vaschus] discovered the brother of the king of Quarequas or "Quarequan" (probably in Panama) dressed as a woman. Balboa set the dogs on him for the crime of sodomy and had him killed. Bulwer, a pioneer in the education of the deaf, writes here about cosmetic alterations of the human body and makes comparisons between contemporary fashions and those of savage and exotic people.

Image_title: Obispado de Mechovacan en los Reynos de la Nueva España ...
Image_publisher: Por Diego Diaz de la Carrera
Description: Map shows the boundaries of the diocese of Michoacán (Mexico). Geographical elements include towns, rivers, and lakes. Cartographic elements include compass rose and scale. Decorative elements include ships, the coat of arms of a bishop (with galero and six fiocchi on either side of shield); title of the image is given in a cartouche surmounted by a shield and crown.
Source_Title: Teatro eclesiastico de la primitiva iglesia de las Indias occidentales, vidas de svs arzobispos, y obispos
Source_publisher: Por Diego Diaz de la Carrera, Impressor del Reyno
notes: Engraver may be Joan van Noort (b. ca. 1620, act. 1645-75).
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: A youth and a native American in feathered headdress and garment flank a woman holding a crucifix. Includes bow and quiver of arrows.
Source_Title: Vita del servo di Dio D. Torivio Alfonso Mogrovejo ...
Source_publisher: Per Nicolangelo Tinassi
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726.

Image_title: Venerab Dei servus D. Turibius Alphonsus Mogrovejus Hispanus, Archiep. Limensis, Peruvianae gentis ...
Description: Portrait of Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo, an archbishop who kneels in prayer before an altar and painting of the Virgin Mary who holds the Christ child. Includes crucifix, candles, bishop's miter, stole, processional cross, and staff or crozier.
Source_Title: Vita del servo di Dio D. Torivio Alfonso Mogrovejo ...
Source_publisher: Per Nicolangelo Tinassi
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Thomas Ratcliffe and Edward Mottershed for Tho. Newberry
Description: Added engraved title page with personifications of the four quarters of the globe: Europe as a crowned woman leading a horse, Asia with an elephant and orb surmounted by a cross [globus cruciger], Africa with a lion and sun, and America holding vessels and standing next to a camel-like animal [a llama?]. Also includes palm trees, elephant, rhinoceros, globe, swags of fruit, and architectural volutes.
Source_Title: A mirrour or looking-glasse both for saints, and sinners, ...Whereunto are added A geographical description of all the countries in the known world ...
Source_publisher: Printed by Thomas. Ratcliffe. and Edward. Motttershed. for Tho. Newberry, and are to be sold at his shop at the Three Golden Lyons, in Corn-hill hear the Royall-Exchauge sic.
notes: This added engraved title page precedes a part of the book whose title is A geographicall [sic] description of all the known countries in the known vvorld ... which has the imprint: London, printed for R.I[bbotson]. for Thomas Newberry, at the Three Lions in Cornhill, over against the Conduit. M DC LVII.

Image_title: [Native Americans worship the sun and idols, and feast on human limbs]
Description: In three scenes native Americans worship the sun, idols, and feast on human flesh (scene of cannibalism). Includes temple, volcano, dwelling, bones, hammock, scene of warfare with butchery of captured enemy, scene of feasting with grilling of human limbs, bones, turtle, lizard or iguana, and monkey.
Source_Title: [Neu-augirte Welt-Beschreibung. Dutch] De nieuwe bereysde wereldt
Source_publisher: by Iohannes Tongerloo
notes: Text describes the natives of Mexico and the Yucatan.

Image_title: [Accounts of tribute to Aztec rulers]
Image_publisher: Chez André Cramoisy, ruë de la vieille Bouclerie, au Sacrifice d'Abraham
Description: Aztec pictographs showing tribute paid by various villages to Aztec rulers.
Source_Title: Relations de divers voyages curieux ... Premiere partie
Source_publisher: De l'Imprimerie de Iacques Langlois, Imprimeur ordinaire du Roy ...
notes: This image was issued in Thevenot's Relations de divers voyages curieux, Paris, 1672-74 (a compilation of many separately printed items) as part of Thomas Gage's Histoire de l'empire Mexicain representée par figures. Gage translated his work from a version used in Samuel Purchas's Purchas his pilgrimes, London, 1625. Purchas's source was the ms. 'Codex Mendoza.' Image publication information from half title of Gage's work within Thévenot's Relations. Translation of pictographs follows in French. Gage, a Dominican friar, traveled to Mexico and Guatemala in 1625 to 1637.

Image_title: [Aztec methods of raising children]
Image_publisher: Chez André Cramoisy, ruë de la vieille Bouclerie, au Sacrifice d'Abraham
Description: Aztec pictographs showing how Aztec fathers and mothers raise their sons and daughters. The top two scenes show a father teaching his son to fish [left] and a mother teaching a daughter to spin cotton [right]. The following scenes show parents threatening, punishing (with cactus spikes) and beating their children.
Source_Title: Relations de divers voyages curieux ... Premiere partie
Source_publisher: De l'Imprimerie de Iacques Langlois, Imprimeur ordinaire du Roy ...
notes: This image was issued in Thevenot's Relations de divers voyages curieux, Paris, 1672-74 (a compilation of many separately printed items) as part of Thomas Gage's Histoire de l'empire Mexicain representée par figures. Gage translated his work from a version used in Samuel Purchas's Purchas his pilgrimes, London, 1625. Purchas's source was the ms. 'Codex Mendoza.' Image publication information from half title of Gage's work within Thévenot's Relations. Translation of pictographs follows in French. Gage, a Dominican friar, traveled to Mexico and Guatemala in 1625 to 1637.

Image_title: [Aztec methods of raising children]
Image_publisher: Chez André Cramoisy, ruë de la vieille Bouclerie, au Sacrifice d'Abraham
Description: Aztec pictographs showing how Aztec fathers and mothers raise their sons and daughters. The top four scenes show parents punishing their children with exposure and smoke from fire.The following scenes show parents teaching children how to canoe, make tortillas [galettes], fish, and weave woolen cloth.
Source_Title: Relations de divers voyages curieux ... Premiere partie
Source_publisher: De l'Imprimerie de Iacques Langlois, Imprimeur ordinaire du Roy ...
notes: This image was issued in Thevenot's Relations de divers voyages curieux, Paris, 1672-74 (a compilation of many separately printed items) as part of Thomas Gage's Histoire de l'empire Mexicain representée par figures. Image publication information from half title of Gage's work within Thévenot's Relations. Translation of pictographs follows in French. Gage, a Dominican friar, traveled to Mexico and Guatemala in 1625 to 1637.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Chez André Cramoisy, ruë de la vieille Bouclerie, au Sacrifice d'Abraham
Description: Aztec pictographs show the emperor in building with subjects below. Letters refer to unknown key.
Source_Title: Relations de divers voyages curieux ... Premiere partie
Source_publisher: De l'Imprimerie de Iacques Langlois, Imprimeur ordinaire du Roy ...

Image_title: [Saint Francisco Xavier standing on the Philippines]
Description: Saint Francisco Xavier holding a crucifix stands on the main island of the Philippines with other islands around him. Includes ships with priests and a crab holding a crucifix.
Source_Title: Labor euangelica, ministerios apostolicos de los obreros de la Compañia de Iesus, fundacion, y progressos de su prouincia en las Islas Filipinas ... Parte primera
Source_publisher: por Ioseph Fernandez de Buendia
notes: Saint Francisco Xavier has been called the first apostle of the Philippines because he was thought to have landed on Mindanao, although it has never been absolutely proved he ever landed in the Philippines. The second part, by Father Pedro Murillo Velarde, was published in Manila, 1749 as: Historia de la provincia de Philipinas de la Compañia de Jesus. Segunda parte. Some copies have a folded plate representing the martyrdom of five Jesuit fathers. Other copies contain a map of the Philippines and coast of China, and a plate representing S. Francisco Xavier upon the water. The John Carter Brown Library copy contains the latter.

Image_title: [Back of a statue of an Aztec god or goddess]
Description: Back of a statue of an Aztec god or goddess, perhaps Coatlicue [?].
Source_Title: [De open-deure tot het verbogen heydendom. German] Abraham Rogers Offne Thür zu dem verborgenen Heydenthum
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben
notes: The illustrator for Rogerius' book uses the same images found on Antonio Herrera y Tordesillas, Novus Orbis, sive Descriptio Indiae occidentalis, Amsterdam 1622. On this title page are illustrations of six Aztec gods--the gods of death, water, gluttony, wind, wine, as well as the chief god, Hoitzili pochtli [i.e., Huitzilopochtli]. Also included are the king of Mexico (Acamapich, seventh child of Montezuma) and a temple. Coatlicue was the Aztec goddess who gave birth to the moon, stars, and Huitzilopochtli, the god of the sun and war.

Description: Front of a statue of an Aztec god or goddess, perhaps Coatlicue [?].
Source_Title: [De open-deure tot het verbogen heydendom. German] Abraham Rogers Offne Thür zu dem verborgenen Heydenthum
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben

Description: [top] The Mexican god of excess or gluttony. [bottom] Acamapich or Acamapichtli, first ruler of the Mexica of Tenochtitlan, and founder of the Aztec imperial dynasty.
Source_Title: [De open-deure tot het verbogen heydendom. German] Abraham Rogers Offne Thür zu dem verborgenen Heydenthum

Description: [top] The Mexican god, Huitzilopochtli, the chief god. [bottom] The Mexican god of wind, Quetzalcoatl.
Source_Title: [De open-deure tot het verbogen heydendom. German] Abraham Rogers Offne Thür zu dem verborgenen Heydenthum

Image_title: [Pagan temple]
Description: Pagan temple with an idol or devil under the dome.
Source_Title: [De open-deure tot het verbogen heydendom. German] Abraham Rogers Offne Thür zu dem verborgenen Heydenthum
Source_publisher: In Verlegung, Johann Andreas Endters, und Wolffgang dess jüng. seel. Erben
notes: The illustrator for Rogerius' book uses the same images found on Antonio Herrera y Tordesillas, Novus Orbis, sive Descriptio Indiae occidentalis, Amsterdam 1622. On this title page are illustrations of six Aztec gods--the gods of death, water, gluttony, wind, wine, as well as the chief god, Hoitzili pochtli [i.e., Huitzilopochtli]. Also included are the king of Mexico (Acamapich, seventh child of Montezuma) and a temple. Text describes temples in Peru.

Image_title: Sponsa Jesu Christi Rosa a Sa. Maria e tertio Ordine S.P. Dominici, strenua S. Catarinae Senensis imitatrix. nata Limae in Regno Peruano, 1586. mense Aprili, denata ibidem 1617. mense Augo.
Description: St. Rose of Lima wearing a crown of thorns and holding a picture of an infant surrounded by roses. Also includes a coat of arms.
Source_Title: [Vita mirabilis et mors pretiosa venerabilis Sororis Rosae de S. Maria Limensis. Spanish] Vida admirable, y muerte preciosa, de la venerable madre soror Rosa de Santa Maria peruana ...
Source_publisher: Por Geronimo Vilagrasa, Impressor del Santo Tribunal, y de la ciudad, junto al molino de Rovella
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first saint canonized who was born in the Americas, joined the secular order of the Dominicans and was devoted to St. Catherine of Siena.

Image_title: Paysage de la Province de Bemarin au Royaume d'Apalache
Description: View of part of the mythical kingdom of "Apalache." Built environment includes a church, palace, temple of the sun. Decorative elements include French royal coat of arms. Items in the image are lettered for identification in a key below.
Source_Title: Histoire naturelle et morale des iles Antilles de l'Amerique
Source_publisher: Chez Arnout Leers
notes: Depicts Melilot, the mythical capital of Apalache. This idealized view was meant to encourage Protestant settlement in America.
