According to Rochefort, Apalache, supposedly located in present-day Florida or Georgia, was the home of European Protestants who had been driven from their Virginia colony. Text describes religious practices that are illustrated. This may be the first printed illustration of a North American utopian city.
References_exhibitions: Cf. Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Fig. 43; Danforth, S. View of America, item 22
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: El Ve. Pe. Po. Claver Catalan de la Compa. de Jesus ...
Description: Portrait of the Jesuit, Pedro Claver. He holds a crucifix and stands before two blacks [slaves]. He is surrounded by insects, probably mosquitos.
Source_Title: Apostolica, y penitente vida de el V.P. Pedro Claver, de la Compañia de Iesus. Sacada principalmente de informaciones juridicas hechas ante el Ordinario de la ciudad de Cartagena de Indias
Source_publisher: Por Diego Dormer
notes: Claver, known as the patron saint of the slaves, baptized and cared for the slaves in Cartagena, present-day Colombia, working especially amongst the lepers and during a smallpox epidemic.

Image_title: [Catafalque of Philip IV]
Description: Catafalque erected in the cathedral of Mexico City to commemorate the death of Philip IV of Spain. Includes the funerary structure in the interior of a church. Also includes figures representing the king, angels holding candles or tapers, allegorical figures holding the sun, an orb, and baton. At the base of the catafalque are scenes from Philip IV's life including the appearances of the Virgin Mary on a crescent moon, a battle scene, a scene with a skeleton, and a representation of the pillars of Hercules flanked by a queen and king. The plinth rests on a platform made of eagles and cactus.
Source_Title: Llanto del Occidente en el ocaso del mas claro sol de las Españas y noticia breve de la deseada ultima dedicacion del Templo Metropolitano de Mexico ...
Source_publisher: Por la Viuda de Bernardo Calderon
notes: A catafalque, an elaborate funerary structure, was erected in the cathedral of Mexico City on the death of Philip IV. The statue of Philip IV is shown with four statues of King Solomon, as a symbol of the perfect monarch. In the lower part of the catafalque royal insignia appear surrounded by statues of great rulers (Constantine, Charlemagne, Alexander), god and heroes of Antiquity (Theseus, Jason, Prometheus, Janus), and four female figures representing Spain. The catafalque is crowned with an image of Faith, who carries a cross in one hand and a chalice and host in the other. This engraving is one of the earliest American copperplate prints known.
References: Cañeque, A. The king's living image, p. 130

Image_title: B. Rosa de S. Maria Tertii ord: Praed: altera catharina senensis Nata Limae, 1586 20 April: ob. ib 1617. 24 Aug.
Description: Portrait of Saint Rose of Lima holding a bouquet of roses with the Christ Child sitting in them. Includes crown of thorns, flowers, sacred heart, star, and crowns.
Source_Title: [Compendium admirabilis vitae Rosae de S. Maria Limanae] Rosa de S. Maria Virgo Limensis è Tertio Ordine de SS. P. Dominici ...
Source_publisher: typis Simonis Utzschneider
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first canonized saint born in the Americas, joined the secular order of the Dominicans and was devoted to Saint Catherine of Siena. This book is also attributed to Leonhard Hansen.

Image_title: [Mining in Peru]
Image_publisher: Christoph Gerhard, for widow and heirs of Paul Fürst
Description: Method by which native Americans mined precious metals from the mountain. Men climb up and down a ladder carrying ore from the mines. Other men hold lights, carry the ore in a basket, and use pickaxes to extract the ore.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Guineischer und americanischer Blumen-Pusch ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung Paul Fürstens, Kunst- und Buchh. seel: Wittib und Erben. Gedruckt daselbst bey Christoph Gerhard
notes: Text describes the silver mines in Peru. Deriving his material from facts and anecdotes related in other books, Francisci was a prolific and popular writer. The illustrations in his books were copied from other illustrations, mostly from Theodor de Bry. See Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, part 3, plate 3.

Image_title: [Founding of Mexico City]
Image_publisher: Christoph Gerhard, for widow and heirs of Paul Fürst
Description: Founding of Tenochtitlán or Mexico City. An eagle devours a bird while perched on a tree. Native Mexicans bow down before the eagle.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Guineischer und americanischer Blumen-Pusch ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung Paul Fürstens, Kunst- und Buchh. seel: Wittib und Erben. Gedruckt daselbst bey Christoph Gerhard
notes: Text describes the founding of Mexico City. The Aztecs or Mexica, guided by the prophecies of Huitzilopochtli (the god of the sun and war), ended their migration by building Tenochtitlán, on an island in a lake where an eagle held a snake perched on a flowering nopal cactus. Deriving his material from facts and anecdotes related in other books, Francisci was a prolific and popular writer. The illustrations in his books were copied from other illustrations, mostly from Theodor de Bry. See Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, pt. 3, plate 12.

Image_title: [Founding of Mexico City]
Image_publisher: Christoph Gerhard, for widow and heirs of Paul Fürst
Description: Founding of Tenochtitlán or Mexico City. Native American men pole floating gardens on a raft. The raft supports maize, squash, birds, and flowers.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Guineischer und americanischer Blumen-Pusch ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung Paul Fürstens, Kunst- und Buchh. seel: Wittib und Erben. Gedruckt daselbst bey Christoph Gerhard
notes: Text describes the founding of Mexico City. The Aztecs or Mexica, guided by the prophecies of Huitzilopochtli (the god of the sun and war), ended their migration by building Tenochtitlán, on an island in a lake where an eagle held a snake perched on a flowering nopal cactus. The Aztecs created artificial islands called chinampas which were made by piling earth from the bottom of Lake Texcoco onto rafts made of weeds. After a while, the roots of the plants and trees grew down to the lake bottom, creating new farmland. Deriving his material from facts and anecdotes related in other books, Francisci was a prolific and popular writer. The illustrations in his books were copied from other illustrations, mostly from Theodor de Bry. See Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, pt. 3, plate 12. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Our Lady of Guadalupe appears to Juan Diego]
Description: In the background Our Lady of Guadalupe appears to a man. In the foreground kneels a man with an image of the Virgin on his cloak. Includes cacti on the hill.
Source_Title: Veridicum admodum anagramma, epigramma obsequiosum, unaque cum acrostichide Virgilio centunculus rigorosis. In laudem purissimae immaculataeque conceptionis sanctissimae Virginis Dei-genitricis Mariae ...
Source_publisher: Ex Typographia Vidue Bernardi Calderon
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it, which was filled with out-of-season roses.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: Nra Sra de Guadalupe apparescida en Mexico.
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe standing on a crescent moon with starry cloak and angel.
Source_Title: Veridicum admodum anagramma, epigramma obsequiosum, unaque cum acrostichide Virgilio centunculus rigorosis. In laudem purissimae immaculataeque conceptionis sanctissimae Virginis Dei-genitricis Mariae ...
Source_publisher: Ex Typographia Vidue Bernardi Calderon
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Crocodile]
Image_publisher: Christoph Gerhard, for widow and heirs of Paul Fürst
Description: Two native Americans shove a pole into the mouth of a crocodile or alligator.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Guineischer und americanischer Blumen-Pusch
Source_publisher: In Verlegung Paul Fürstens, Kunst- und Buchh. seel: Wittib und Erben. Gedruckt daselbst bey Christoph Gerhard
notes: The text describes the animal as a crocodile that lives in Florida. A similar image depicting the same activity can be found in DeBry, Pt. 2, plate 26. Image placed horizontally on page.
References_exhibitions: Landis, D.C. Literature of the Encounter, no. 58, fig. VI.4

Image_title: [Snakes]
Image_publisher: Christoph Gerhard, for widow and heirs of Paul Fürst
Description: Snakes.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Guineischer und americanischer Blumen-Pusch ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung Paul Fürstens, Kunst- und Buchh. seel: Wittib und Erben. Gedruckt daselbst bey Christoph Gerhard
notes: Text describes a cobra de veado (or boa constrictor) from Brazil, a water snake, and a tzicatlinan or Mexican ant-mother snake (Probably a coral snake. The Nahuatl name is tzicanântli, or "Mother of ants," because it lives at the bottom of ant hills). Deriving his material from facts and anecdotes related in other books, Francisci was a prolific and popular writer. The illustrations in his books were copied from other illustrations, mostly from Theodor de Bry. For an illustration of a tzicatlinan, see Juan Eusebio Nieremberg, Historia natvrae, Antwerp, 1635, p. 272.

Image_title: [Rattlesnake]
Image_publisher: Christoph Gerhard, for widow and heirs of Paul Fürst
Description: Rattlesnake.
Source_Title: Erasmi Francisci Guineischer und americanischer Blumen-Pusch ...
Source_publisher: In Verlegung Paul Fürstens, Kunst- und Buchh. seel: Wittib und Erben. Gedruckt daselbst bey Christoph Gerhard
notes: Text describes a rattlesnake. Scientific name: Crotalus atrox. Deriving his material from facts and anecdotes related in other books, Francisci was a prolific and popular writer. The illustrations in his books were copied from other illustrations, mostly from Theodor de Bry. For an illustration of a rattlesnake, see Juan Eusebio Nieremberg, Historia natvrae, Antwerp, 1635, p. 268.

Image_title: ... Doctoris D. Augustini Sarmiento de los Salbadores [sic]
Description: Portrait of Augustin Sarmiento de los Salvadores in an interior room or his study. Includes table or desk with books, quill, inkwell, royal coat of arms, statue of the Virgin Mary with crown, window with trellis and grape vine.
Source_Title: Clarin de la aurora y excelencias de la purissima reyna de los angeles Maria santissima señora nuestra ...
Source_publisher: Por Joseph de Contreras
notes: Agustin Sarmiento de los Salvadores was the priest or rector of the church of San Sebastian in Lima, Peru, and visitor general of New Spain. The coat of arms is probably the author's coat of arms; the Sarmiento coat of arms includes "bezantes de oro" (bezants or gold circles). The vines in the window may symbolize a sarment (twig of a vine).

Image_title: [Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo]
Description: Portrait of Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo, an archbishop who confirms Rosa of Lima [?], who kneels before him. Includes other acolytes, altar boy, and worshipers, as well as bishop's miter, staff or crozier, processional cross, coats of arms of the diocese and city of Lima.
Source_Title: Mirabilis vita, et mirabiliora acta Dei venerii servi Toribii Alfonsi Mogrobesi Limani Archipraesolis ...
Source_publisher: Typis Nicolai Angeli Tinassi
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726.

Image_title: [Warfare between the Spanish and native Americans]
Description: Scene of warfare between Spanish or European soldiers and native Americans wearing feathered headdresses. Includes dogs, guns or muskets, spears, war clubs, bows, and arrows.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the warfare between the Spanish under Francisco Vazquez de Coronado who was twice defeated by stone-wielding natives before he was able to conquer the territory of the kingdom of Tontonteac, one of the mythical seven cities.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of North America--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: [Aztec idol or god]
Description: Mexican idol or god holding a smoking mirror in one hand and a shield with arrows in the other. Wearing a feathered headdress and ornaments, the idol is seated before a curtain decorated with skulls and bones. Native Americans kneel before the figure.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Tezcatlipoca, or "Smoking Mirror," was an omnipresent and omnipotent god, the god of the night sky and memory in the Aztec pantheon.

Image_title: [Native Americans process cocoa]
Description: Native Americans process cocoa by harvesting cacao pods from trees in forest. Men roast the cocoa over a fire, grind it, stir it in a pot, and make into cakes. Includes ornaments and feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the process by which the native Americans of New Spain or Mexico harvest and process cocoa (scientific name: Theobroma cacao).

Image_title: [Native American falls from high pole]
Description: Native American or Mexican falls from a high pole onto the ground on which wounded soldiers lie. Other native soldiers kill each other. Includes scene of warfare.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes Ezhuahuacatl, cousin or brother of Moctezuma, who was offered the chance to become the ruler of the Chalco, but instead danced on a pole and threw flowers and himself off of it to his death to save his people from being slaves of the Chalco. The people of Chalco, so enraged by his actions, slew all the other Mexicans there present.

Image_title: Portus Acapulco
Description: View of the harbor at Acapulco. Includes native Americans carrying goods and Europeans entering a settlement with dwellings, churches, fortifications, and ships. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at lower left.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: The fort of San Diego was built by the Spanish in 1614 at Acacuplco, Mexico, to defend the town against pirate attacks.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Native Americans of Chile]
Description: Native Americans. Includes men, women, and child, baskets, club, and vessel.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the native Americans of Chile.

Image_title: [Temple in the Yucatan]
Description: Temple with an image of a man assaulted by beasts (an armadillo, a llama [?], a goat, and a stag or deer [?]) from all sides. Next to the image of the man is a statue of a snake eating a stone lion. Bodies are thrown off of the platform onto the ground below. Within the building, fires burn and other men slay or execute victims. Native American soldiers with bows and spears stand in front of the building. Includes scenes of sacrifice.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses Campeche in the Yucatan discovered by Fernandez and Morantes. The temple is described as being a theater of marble with huge figures carved on the top. People were executed daily, and their bodies thrown down on the ground below.The first documented Spanish exploration of the mainland west of the Caribbean area was led by three conquistadors from Cuba, Francisco Fernandez de Córdoba, Lopez Ochoa Cayzedo, and Cristobal Morantes.

Image_title: [Native American flayed by a priest]
Description: Native American priest removes the skin of a man surrounded by native American soldiers. In the background is a scene of warfare or duel. Includes knife, spears, feathered headdresses, shield, and sword.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the practices of the natives of Panuco who celebrated a festival called the Flaying of slaves. The priest would choose a slave who then was allowed to fight for his life with one of his feet tied to a round stone.This sacrificial rite was celebrated on the festival of tlacaxipehualiztli in honor of Xipe Tótec. Xipe Tótec, "our flayed lord," was the god of agriculture, death, rebirth, and the seasons. At his festival in the spring, men were sacrificed by being tied to an altar stone, called the temalacatl.

Image_title: St. Francisco de Campeche
Description: View of the harbor at San Francisco de Campeche. Includes a scene of naval warfare, government buildings, dwellings, cathedral, churches, monastery, ships, and boats. Of interest is a boat's bottom being cleaned or tarred. Items in the image are identified in key at bottom.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Campeche, founded on the site of a Mayan village, was one of three ports that had a monopoly of trade on the Yucatán peninsula in the eighteenth century. A method of careening a ship, shown here, used an enormous floating dock with a set of capstans which pulled the hull onto one side.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Native American funeral service]
Description: Native American priest dances by the funeral pyre of a nobleman while another priest kills slaves [?] with an ax to put them on the pyre. Includes shovel, feathered headdresses, and spears.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the practices of native Mexicans who would offer up goods and presents, as well as slaves, household priest, and servants on a nobleman's funeral pyre.

Image_title: [Native Americans of Peru]
Description: Native Americans of Peru. One nobleman stands on a platform while people of lower status sit before him. In the background the funerary practices of the Peruvians are shown. The dead man is carried seated on a litter while a man puts a liquid in the corpse's mouth. Two women are buried alive beside him. Others bring food in baskets. Includes shovels, feathered headdresses, war club, bows, and arrows.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the funerary practices of the Peruvians. The dead man's nearest relation puts chica, a liquor, in the corpse's mouth and two of the dead man's favorite concubines were buried alive beside him. All this was done so that the deceased might have all he needed in the next world.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: [Religious practices of the native Americans of Peru]
Description: Religious practices of the native Americans of Peru. Priests sacrifice animals on a bonfire, throw rocks with serpents or snakes and animals painted on them, and eviscerate animals.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the religious practices of the Peruvians. Animals were sacrificed differently depending on their color. Animals were killed as an example of how gods killed their enemies.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: [Religious practices of the native Americans of Peru]
Description: Religious practices of the native Americans of Peru. Priests wearing feathered headdresses and collars carry torches at night while others bathe and drink out of cans. In the background are llamas and goats.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the Inca religious feast of Huarqui during which the people beat each other with torches in the night before the moon rises. They sacrifice sheep, bathe, and are drunk for four days.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Vera effigies Venerab. Servi Dei P. F. Francisci Solani Indiarum Concionatoris Apostolici Ord. Min. Provinciae Andalusiae in Hispania, qui Limae obijt die 14. Julij Anno 1610 aetatis suce 61
Description: Francisco Solano, a Franciscan brother, baptizes native Americans and holds a crucifix in his hand. Includes scene of his being shipwrecked in the background. Also includes feathered headdresses and quiver of arrows.
Source_Title: Triumphus charitatis, siue De vita, virtutibus et miraculis venerabilis serui Dei P. Fr. Francisci Solani ...
Source_publisher: Typis Michaelis Herculis
notes: A missionary in Peru and Paraguay, Saint Francisco Solano [Solanus] arrived in Peru in 1589 and was known for his ability to speak numerous native American dialects. He was censor of the convents of his order in Tucuman and Paraguay and was later elected guardian of the Franiscan convent in Lima, Peru.

Image_title: Uiztlipuztli idolum Mexicanorum.
Description: Native American worship before Huitzilopochtli, a Mexican idol or statue, in the interior of a temple. The idol, shown as a devil with wings, a face on his stomach, and cloven hooves, stands on an altar decorated with military matériel such as spears, shields, and feathered headdresses. In one hand he holds a pole, in the other a shield with five feathers on it. Also includes animal headdresses and men worshipping before the idol.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Huitzilopochtli or Huitziláihuitl, an Aztec god symbolized by the hummingbird, was the god of the sun and war. Text describes the statue as being seated on a litter painted blue with serpents' heads at the end of the poles. The statue held a serpent in one hand and a shield with five feathers on it in the other. Its head was crowned with feathers.

Image_title: Nova Mexico.
Description: Bird's-eye view of Mexico City after the Spanish conquest from the shore of a lake. Built environment includes churches, walls, fountains, and dwellings. Also includes domestic animals, dogs, horses, fields outside of the city walls and black or native American men farming, boating on a canal or river, hauling goods on an ox-drawn cart, and carrying loads on their backs. Items in image are lettered for identification in a key below.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Derived from a view in an unpublished atlas by Johannes Vingboons in 1628, this image was probably copied from a map of Juan Gomez de Trasmonte, supervisor for the construction of the drainage system of Mexico City in 1628. That map may have been brought to the Netherlands by Adrian Boot, the Belgian engineer responsible for designing the project.
References: Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.23; Lombardo de Ruiz, S. Atlas histórico de la ciudad de México, lamina 125
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Manioc mill]
Description: Manioc mill in operation. Slaves bring tuber, grind and press manioc. Also includes illustrations of manioc or cassava plants.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discribes the processing of manioc by the native Americans of Panama. Roots are grated and milled to a pulp; the pulp is pressed to extract the poisonous juice.

Image_title: [Natural bridge in Peru]
Description: Native Americans stand before a natural bridge and waterfall in Peru. Includes feathered headdresses, decorated tunic, and basket.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs

Image_title: [Opossum]
Description: An opossum [?] and her babies hunted by European soldiers.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes a remarkable animal found by Vincent Pinzon in his exporation of the Gulf of Paria, in present-day Venezuela, that resembled a fox in the front, a monkey in the back, whose feet resembled human feet, and had ears like an owl. It carried its babies in a sack under its belly.

Image_title: [Sacrifice Island]
Description: Native Americans sacrifice other natives. A man falls into a trough. Includes a lion, statues of gods or idols, fires, feathered headdresses and garments, knives, and bones or skeletons.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the Island of Sacrifice in the province of Tabasco, Mexico, where a great lion made of stone has fresh blood poured on it. The blood is collected in a stone trough which has a statue of a man next to it. The sacrifice victims have their hearts given to the idols, but their bodies are left unburied.

Image_title: [Native Americans kneel before European soldiers]
Description: Native Americans kneel before European soldiers while volcanos erupt in background. Stones hail down on the men who run away from the eruption. Includes guns or muskets, flags, feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the Spaniards under Hernán Cortés who climbed the double-spired mountain Popocatepeque [Popocatepetl]. The mountain shook and stones hailed down on the men as they ran from the volcano. The natives admired the Spaniards' courage in attempting to climb the volcano.

Image_title: Vetis Mexico
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing the various islands, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city. Also includes men on horseback, domestic animals, boats, churches, dwellings, wicker dams, and main square. In the foreground, native Americans carry goods to the city. Includes horses, cattle, oxcarts, and parasols. Items in the image are lettered for identification in table at upper left.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: The city is probably shown as the artist imagined Tenochtitlán was before Europeans arrived, but with European-type houses and churches and men on horseback or herding sheep. It is based on the woodcut view of Tenochtitlán in Hernán Cortés, Carta, Nuremberg, 1524.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Huitzilopochtli]
Description: Interior of a temple with an idol which has horns and faces on its chest. Also includes torches and lamps. Includes a scene of sacrifice, bones or skeleton, knife, and European soldiers.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the idol, Huitzilopochtli, an Aztec or Mexican deity, whose head touched the arched ceiling of the high temple. Near him stand various images made of meal and kneaded with men's blood. While Cortes and Montezuma [Moctezuma] were viewing the temple, two Spaniards rushed suddenly into one of the cells lit with many torches with walls covered in human blood.

Image_title: [Scene of warfare in Peru]
Description: Scene of warfare with slain native American soldiers. European soldiers attack the men carrying a litter. Includes feathered headdresses, battalions fighting, spears, and guns or muskets.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the encounter between Atahualpa [Atabalipa] and Francisco Pizzaro. A monk named Vicente de Valverde confronted Atahualpa with a crucifix and a breviary. When Atahualpa asked how the Spanish knew what the teachings of God were, Valverde said the book spoke of them. The king took the book, turned the pages, said it did not speak of anything, and threw it on the ground. At this point, Pizarro and his men charged into the crowds which panicked and were slaughtered. Atahualpa was thrown from his litter which was overturned even though as soon as one bearer was killed another took his place until the Inca king was surrounded by piles of dead subjects. Atahualpa was then taken prisoner.

Image_title: [Native Americans bring food and treasure]
Description: Native Americans bring animals such as cattle or oxen, sheep, and goats. A woman plays tambourines. A man leads the bull she rides and another carries a box. Also includes feathered headdress, bows, and spears.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the Dutch explorer, Olivier van Noort, and his arrival along the coast of Chile and Isla Mocha where the inhabitants brought out their women who plied the Dutch with alcohol or liquor.

Image_title: Pagus Hispanorum in Florida
Description: View of Saint Augustine and the Castillo de San Marcos in Florida. Includes fortifications, ships, black men [slaves?] cooking, native Americans with feathered headdresses, veiled European woman protected by a parasol, dog, boats, dwellings, and church.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the Spanish colony at Saint Augustine, Florida.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Native American family group]
Description: Native American man offers [an oyster with pearl?] to woman and child in a hammock. Decorative elements include food such as fish and vegetables, a club, baskets, hooks, and arrow.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes Pedro Alonzo Nigno's discovery of a native American tribe near the Gulf of Paria (between present-day Trinidad and Venezuela). This island was abundant with pearl oysters.
References_exhibitions: Klooster, W. Dutch in the Americas, Fig. 4.5

Image_title: [Death of the Indian king's brother]
Description: Spaniard sets dogs on native American in a bedroom. A group of Europeans stand with guns and flags. One reaches into a bag of gold. In the background is a scene of warfare.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes Vasco Nuñez de Balboa's punishment of sodomy. Balboa had entered a castle of the territory "Quarequan," (probably in Panama) where he found the king's brother dressed as a woman. Balboa set the dogs on him and had him killed. Among the slain were several black slaves.

Image_title: [Dutch explorers are crowned by native Americans]
Description: Dutchmen are entertained by native Americans who place feather headdresses on their heads. In the background, native Americans welcome and bow to Europeans. Decorative elements include birds, men playing a fanfare on long horns, open-sided dwelling, and spears.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes inhabitants of one of the islands in the Strait of Magellan who welcomed Willem Schouten and Jacques le Maire.
References_exhibitions: Klooster, W. Dutch in the Americas, Fig. 1.7

Image_title: Potosi
Description: The mountain in which the silver mines of Potosí are located. At the left is a windmill in which native American workers process silver. Decorative elements include a chapel at the top of the mountain, dwellings, churches, windmills, wooden cart, feathered headdresses, horses.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: The mines at Potosí were discovered by Diego Hualca in 1544. The silver mines there were among the richest in the world.
References_exhibitions: Klooster, W. Dutch in the Americas, Fig. 4.7
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Animals of Guatemala]
Description: Animals of Guatemala including three snakes, one identified as "Mater lamicarumclus," and one a feathered serpent. Includes a baboon identified as a "papio" and a sloth [?].
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: The snake at right is possibly the same as that identified by Nieremberg as "Mater formicarum, sive tzicatlinan," a coral snake. The snake in the middle resembles the so-called "feathered serpent" of the Aztec or Mexican people. The snake at left is a rattlesnake, Teuthlacokauhqui or voogdesse der stangen. Scientific name of the baboon is Papio ursinus. The animal identified as Papio 2 resembles Nieremberg's three-toed sloth.

Image_title: Porto Rico
Description: View of San Juan, in present-day Puerto Rico, showing harbor, dwellings, fortifications, ships, and boats.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Truxillo
Description: View of Trujillo, in present-day Honduras. Includes ships, boats, dwellings, fortifications, and a signal tower [?]. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at bottom left.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Trujillo, a pirate stronghold, was destroyed several times between 1633 and 1797, and abandoned by the Spanish after it was deemed indefensible during the eighteenth century.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Cartagena
Description: View of the harbor at Cartagena, in present-day Colombia. Includes ships, boats, dwellings, fortifications, churches, and chain across the mouth of the harbor.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: In the late sixteenth century, Cartagena was attacked by both English (Drake, Hawkins) and French (Cote, Baal) pirates/privateers. The Spanish crown responded to these threats in the seventeenth century by building very extensive fortifications. Its defenses were still strong enough in 1741 to withstand the siege made by the English Admiral Edward Vernon.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Guarme
Description: View of the fortifications at Guarme, or present-day Huarmey, Peru. Includes men landing goods and barrels from boats and a settlement with a church in a distance.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses Joris van Spilbergen's fleet landing at Guarme to replenish his food stores, but the natives fled with all their goods and hid in the mountains, so that he found very little besides a decayed fort.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Callao de Lima
Description: View of Callao, in the harbor of Lima in present-day Peru. Includes ships, boats, dwellings, fortifications, churches, scene of naval warfare, and ships on fire. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at top left.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the sacking of Callao by Sir Francis Drake in 1578.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Peru
Description: Map of Peru showing the coastline on the Pacific Ocean. Cartographic elements include locations of settlements and rivers, degrees of latitude, compass rose, scales, and some topographical details. Decorative cartouche includes armadillo, llama, cornucopia, basket, war club, snake eating fruit, pineapple, and native Americans with feathered headdress and shield. Also includes ships, scene of naval warfare, sea monster or whale, mythological figures or sea god, and mermaids.
Source_Title: [De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld. English] America: being an accurate description of the Nevv VVorld ...
Source_publisher: Printed by Tho. Johnson for the author, and are to be had at his house in White Fryers
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Cusco
Description: Bird's eye view of Cuzco in present-day Peru. Native Americans cross a bridge in foreground of a walled city or settlement. Includes a large temple on a pyramid, fortifications, dwellings, idols or statues, and ruins or tombs in the background hills.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the Angoyaca bridge over the Xauxa River and the ruins of ancient structures by the Vinaque River. The great temple in Cuzco is described as being the Temple Curicanche or Koricancha, dedicated to the sun, sumptuously decorated and covered in thick plates of gold and silver.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Native American garments]
Description: Native Americans are shown wearing feathered headdresses and collars. They also wear arm and leg ornaments. Includes bows, arrows, and dwelling.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the costume of the Mexicans or Aztecs. It also describes the practice of making a holy ointment made out of tobacco, various insects, and seeds.

Image_title: [Native Americans of Peru]
Description: Native Americans of Peru are shown wearing their various costumes. Includes bows, arrows, feathered headpieces, and leg ornaments.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes the costume of the Peruvians. They are all said to wear similar long shirts over which were put a cotton cloak. Different territories are represented by different head ornaments.

Image_title: [Native Americans of Brazil]
Description: Duel or fist fight between two native Americans. Includes crowds watching in the background, feathered headdresses and ornaments, and dwellings.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text discusses the hand combat between native Americans of Brazil.

Image_title: [Native American shoots an arrow]
Description: Native American man who stands next to two men wearing feathered (?) garments or cloaks shoots an arrow at deer or stags. Also includes feathered headdess, spear, and bow.
Source_Title: De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America
Source_publisher: By Jacob Meurs Boek-verkooper en Plaet-snyder, op de Kaisars-graf, schuin over de wester-markt, in de stad Meurs
notes: Text describes how the ordinary Indians or Mexicans dress very simply with only a cloth to cover themselves, but that the native nobility dress in costly apparel, including strings of pearls, a hat from which hang down two scarves, and a multicolored cotton coat, covering a vest, which hangs to their knees.

Image_title: Muteczuma Rex ultimus Mexicanorum
Description: Portrait of Moctezuma, last king of the Mexica or Aztecs. Includes feathered headdress, garments, collar, eagle, and shield. Includes jewelry and spear.
Source_Title: [Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld. English] America: being the latest, and most accurate description of the Nevv VVorld containing the original of the inhabitants, and the remarkable voyages thither. The conquest of the vast empires of Mexico and Peru, and other large provinces and territories, with the several European plantations in those parts. Also their cities, fortresses, towns, temples, mountains, and rivers. Their habits, customs, manners, and religions. Their plants, beasts, birds, and serpents
Source_publisher: printed by the author, and are to be had at his house in White Fryers
notes: Moctezuma II (or Montezuma II, reigned 1502-1520), the ninth Aztec emperor, whose surname was Xocoyotzin or bitter lord (or the youngest), was the son of Axayácatl and great grandson of Moctezuma I. He surrendered to the Spanish in 1520.
SubjectHeadings1: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page showing Rose of Lima surrounded with roses and holding the image of a child with an allegorical figure of the Christian church as a woman holding a crucifix, book, chalice, and host. Also shown is a native American woman with bird, feathered headdress and garments.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans.

Image_title: Severa in corpus
Description: Rose of Lima is shown kneeling in a room flagellating herself before a crucifix on a shelf. Also includes a skull, hourglass, book, image of the Virgin and Child, and the saint's bed made of sticks and rocks. Rose is half-clothed, with a chain around her waist, and wearing a metal-spiked crown.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans.

Image_title: Seraphicis ardoribus colliquescens.
Description: Rose of Lima, in Dominican habit, speaks with an angel or seraph. Includes garden and church in distance.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. In 1602, she entered a Dominican convent and took the veil.

Image_title: In solitudine operosa.
Description: Rose of Lima, in Dominican habit, reads a book and contemplates in a rough hut or grotto. Includes a rose bush and bird.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. In 1602, she entered a Dominican convent and took the veil. She lived as a recluse in a hut built in the family garden.

Image_title: Cibi et somni parca.
Description: Rose of Lima, in Dominican habit, in a rough hut or grotto kneels before a spring from which she fills a bowl. Includes a bird, cross, open book, rosary, and paper knife.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. In 1602, she entered a Dominican convent and took the veil. She lived as a recluse in a hut built in the family garden.

Image_title: Demonum victrix.
Description: Rose of Lima, in Dominican habit, is attacked by a savage dog or a demon. Includes a shelf with books, a crucifix, and a skull.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. In 1602, she entered a Dominican convent and took the veil.

Image_title: In coelis gloriosa.
Description: Rose of Lima, in Dominican habit, lies on her deathbed surrounded by nuns and priests. In the background, she is seen rising to heaven represented by a pyramid, and kneeling before the Blessed Virgin. Includes candles, crucifix, and log bed.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. In 1602, she entered a Dominican convent and took the veil. She died on August 25, 1617, at the age of 31.
SubjectHeadings2: Rose, of Lima, Saint, 1586-1617--Death and burial

Image_title: E sepulcro opifera.
Description: Rose of Lima's corpse is carried on a pallet by monks/priests to a church. People kneel beside the path taken by the funeral procession. Includes crosses and a bishop with miter and crozier.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. In 1602, she entered a Dominican convent and took the veil. She died on August 25, 1617, at the age of 31, and was buried at the Dominican convent in Lima.
SubjectHeadings1: Rose, of Lima, Saint, 1586-1617--Death and burial

Image_title: Habitu religiosa.
Description: Rose of Lima kneels before a priest who gives her religious garments. Includes an altar, candlesticks, and an altar boy or monk.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans.

Image_title: Christo desponsa.
Description: Rose of Lima kneels before a statue of the Virgin Mary and Child. The Virgin is surrounded by a rosary and stands upon a crescent moon.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans.

Image_title: Ab infantia gratiosa.
Description: Rose of Lima as a baby lies in a wicker cradle surrounded by adoring women. Includes a view outside with trees.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. As an infant, her face was seen to be transformed into a mystical rose.

Image_title: Casta ex voto
Description: Rose of Lima holding shears and a hank of hair kneels before a vision of the Christ Child who holds an orb in his hand and stands on angels. Also includes a parrot or bird.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. After reading the life of Saint Catherine, she determined to take that saint as a model and cut off her hair.

Image_title: Constans in proposito.
Description: Rose of Lima pulls away from a gentleman and a woman who attempt to take her hand.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. She determined to take a vow of chastity, opposing her parents who wished her to marry.

Image_title: Iesu familiaris.
Description: Rose of Lima works needlework on her lap with the symbol, IHS, on it. She holds a needle and thread while looking at the Christ Child who reads from a book. Includes pillow, baskets [with laundry or mending] and crucifix on a shelf.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. She was known for her fine embroidery and lacemaking. IHS, a monogram of the name of Jesus Christ, was adopted by Saint Ignatius of Loyola as the seal of the Society of Jesus or the Jesuits.

Image_title: Coelesit sponso comitata.
Description: Rose of Lima holds the hand of Jesus Christ.
Source_Title: Vita et historia S. Rosae a S. Maria quae nata Limae in regno Peruano 1586, obiit 1617 aetatis suae 31.
notes: Rose of Lima, patron saint of the Americas and first American-born saint, joined the secular order of the Dominicans. In 1602, she entered a Dominican convent and took the veil. She is here shown symbolically marrying Christ in her eighteenth year.

Image_title: [Dwarf wearing a hat]
Description: Man wears a hat which comes down to his knees.
Source_Title: JDMBMD Vorstellung etlicher Kunst- und Naturalien-Kammern, in America und Asia
Source_publisher: gedruckt durch Joachim Reuman, Acad. Buchdr.
notes: Text discusses a carving on the palace wall of Montezuma [Moctezuma]. It was said to represent a dwarf wearing a hat, but the person was so small that the hat came all the way down to his hips. The court of Moctezuma included deformed people.

Image_title: [Fray Luis Cervela and ship]
Description: Fray Luis de Cervela, a Franciscan monk, stands on a ship. Includes twelve stars, candles, a checkered design on the sail with letters, human eyes, and a lead weight.
Source_Title: Templo de N. grande patriarca San Francisco de la provincia de los doze apostoles de le Peru en la Ciudad de los Reyes
notes: Text describes the twelve stars as representing the twelve Franciscan monks who went to Lima. The eyes are said to represent vigilance. The letters within the checked squares read, "ISULUSI," an anagram of "Luis." The letters' "Ser," represent Cervela's last name. Cervela was the builder of the church and monastery of San Francisco in Lima, Peru, as well as its general commissary or comisario general from 1669 to1674.
References: Camilloni, H.R. "Architectural Principles ... San Francisco, Lima," Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians, vol. 28, no. 4, p. 235-253

Image_title: P. Rochus Gonzalez à S. Cruce Paragvariensis Indus et P. Alphonsus Rodriguez Hispanus Soc. Iesu crudelissimè ab Idololatris Paraqvariensibus pro Christo necati. 15 Novemb. A. 1628.
Description: Fathers Rocque González and Alphonso Rodriguez martyred by Paraguayan native Americans. Cultural artifacts include a church in flames, an overturned chalice and paten, cross, hatchet, and club.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: González, a Paragyan-born Jesuit who understood Guaraní, established Jesuit missions in Paraguay among the nomadic Guarani. Rodriquez, also a Paraguayan, was canonized in 1988. The author, Mathias Tanner (1630-1692), from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University. The engraver may be Melchoir Küsel (1626-1683) or his brother, Matthäus Küsel (1629-1681), members of a German family of engravers.

Image_title: P. Petrus Martinez Hispan. S.I. odio Fidei Christianae occisus à Barbaris Americanis in Insula Florida Ao. 1566.z 8 Septembris
Description: Native American wearing feathered garments and holding a war club stands over the body of a martyr, monk, or priest. In the background are two dwellings.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Father Pedro Martinez was among a small contingent of Jesuits sent to the mission called Nombre de Dios in Saint Augustine, Florida. Fearful Indians clubbed him to death on Fort George Island in 1566.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Gundisalvus de Tapia S. I. illustri stemmate in Hispania natus, pro Fide Christi necatus in Mexico. Ao. 1594. 10 Iulij
Description: Native American stands over a priest or monk with a hatchet or ax. A war club lies on the fallen man's head and one of his arms has been chopped off. Includes a rough shelter or dwelling.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Gonzalo de Tapia, a Spanish Jesuit who established a mission in Michoacán, Mexico, was martyred by one of his Tarascan converts, a cacique or chief named Nacaveva, in 1594.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Antonius Lopez Hispanus Soc: Iesu veneno sublatus ab Indis odio Fidei in Peruvia A. 1596.
Description: Priest or monk stands before an altar with a broken idol. He holds a chalice with a phoenix [?] in it and a crucifix.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Text discusses the Jesuits who reached Peru in 1567 and proceeded to proselytize among the Indians, destroying native artifacts in their efforts to destroy idolatry.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Michael de Urrea Hispanus Soc: Iesu. ex odio Fidei à Barbaris necatus in Peruvia A. 1597. 28 Aug.
Description: Priest or monk kneels before a cross made of tree trunks lashed together. A native American man holds an ax over his head. Includes dwellings.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Michael de Urrea was martyred by the cacique, Vici Torapo, in Peru in 1597.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Raphaël Ferrer Hispanus Soc: Iesu, odio Fidei Christianae submersus à Barbaris in America. A. 1611. Mense Martio
Description: Priest or monk holding a cross flies under a bridge. Three native American men with a spear and a war club and wearing feathered garments stand on the bridge above the river.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Ferrer, a Catalonian Spaniard, supposedly escaped from his native American pursurers by flying under a bridge near Quito, Peru.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Martinus de Aranda Valdivia, P. Horatius de Vecchi, Didacus de Montalvan Soc: Iesu, pro Christo crudeliter interfecti in Chile 14. Decem: A 1612
Description: Three priests or monks are martyred by spears, by being beheaded, and by a war club.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Martin de Aranda Valdivia, Horacio Vecchi, and Diego de Montalvan, under the leadership of Father Luis de Valdivia, were martyred by native Americans in Elicura, Chile, during the seventy-year war between the Spanish and the Araucanians. The native leader, Anganamun, incited his followers to kill the Jesuits because they claimed his marriages to his three wives, since the wives had become Christian, were void. See the image at Alonso de Ovalle, Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, Rome, 1646 (0875-5).The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Ferdinandus de Tovar Hispanus, Soc: Iesu, à Barbaris Americanis odio Fidei interemtus, in nova Hispania Ao. 1616. 16 Nov:
Description: Priest or monk is stabbed by a native American with a spear. His body is also pierced by arrows. Includes a cross, rosary, and dwellings.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Hernando de Tovar was martyred in Culiacan, Mexico, during the armed uprising of the Tepehuanes in 1616.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Bernardus de Cisneros, P. Didacus de Orosco, P. Ioannes de Valle, P. Ludovicus de Alabes Hispani, Soc: Iesu, à Barbaris Americanis occisi fidei in nova Hispania Ao. 1616. 18 Novemb:
Description: Priests or monks lie martyred outside a church. A priest holding a painting of the Virgin Mary and Child kneels beside the church while a native American wearing feathered headdress and garment stands over the slain men with an ax. Includes cross, crucifix, reliquary [?], altar, and palm tree.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Diego de Orozco, Bernardo de Cisneros, Juan del Valle, and Luís de Alavés were martyred in northwestern Mexico during the armed uprising of the Tepehuanes in 1616.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Ioannes de Fonte, P. Hieronymus de Moranta Hispani, Soc: Iesu, odio fidei à Barbaris Americanis interfecti in nova Hispania Ao. 1616. 19. Novembris.
Description: Priests or monks stand pierced by arrows. A war club is held over each of their heads.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Juan Fonte and Jerónimo de Moranta were martyred in Mexico during the armed uprising of the Tepehuanes in 1616.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Ferdinandus Santaren Hispanus, Soc: Iesu, Religionis causâ ab Indis Americanis occisus. in nova Hispania A. 1616. 20 Novembris
Description: Priest or monk is martyred by a native American who beats him on his head with a war club. Includes rosary, harbor, ship, bow, and arrows.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Hernando de Santaren, a Jesuit monk who worked to convert the Acaxees, was martyred in Mexico during the Tepehuán rebellion of 1616 to 1617. The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Ioannes del Castillio illustri sanguine Hispana Soc: Iesu, Fidei odio ab Idololatris in Paraquaria crudelissimâ per faxa et spinas raptatione necatus 17. Novemb. A. 1628.
Description: Priest or monk is martyred by being dragged through spiny cacti or thorn bushes and a rocky landscape by native Americans [?].
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Juan de Castillo was one of three Jesuit missionaries martyred at the missions in Paraguay. Left at the mission of Iyuí by the fathers Roque Gonzalez and Alonso Rodriquez, he was stoned to death and his body was dragged into the woods.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Bernardus Reus Hispanus Soc: Iesu, evulso corde telis Confixus ab Idololatris in Peru. 17 Iulij. A. 1629
Description: Priest or monk is martyred by having his heart cut out by a native American with a knife clenched in his mouth. Also includes arrows.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Bernardo Reus, a Spanish Jesuit, was martyred in Peru in 1629.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Iulius Pasqualis Italus, et P. Emmanuel Martinez illustri Prosapiâ Lusit: Soc: Iesu, sagittis confixi ab Idololatris in America apud Varohios 1. Februarij A. 1632
Description: Two priests or monks are shot in the back with arrows by two native Americans.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Julius Pasqualis [Julio Pascual], an Italian Jesuit, arrived in Mexico in 1624 and was instrumental in mediating between the Chinipas, Temoris, Varohios, and Guazapares and the Spanish soldiers, thus preventing a local war. He and Manuel Martinez were martyred by natives they attempted to save.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Christophorus de Mendoza Soc: Iesu. clarissimo apud Hispanos genere ortus in Peruvia, crudelissimè ab Idololatris pro Christo necatus in Paraquaria Ibiae 25 Aprilis A. 1635.
Description: Priest or monk nailed to a cross is dragged by two native Americans. Another man with an ax or hatchet prepares to kill the crucified man.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Cristoforo de Mendoza, a man of noble birth from Peru, was martyred in Paraguay in 1635. He, along with his fellow Jesuits, ran the mission of Jesus-Maria among the Guarani and Mamelucos (mixed European-native race).The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Petrus de Espinosa, Soc: Iesu, illustrissimis Natalibus Hispanus, necatus ab Idololatris odio Nominis Iesu, in Paraquaria 3. Iulij. A. 1637.
Description: Priest or monk kneels before a vision of the Virgin Mary and Child while a native American prepares to kill him with an ax or hatchet.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Pedro de Espinosa was martyred in Paraguay in 1637. He, along with his fellow Jesuits, ran the mission in Tayaoba, but was killed when the natives, Guapalaches, hacked his body apart and left it for the wild animals to eat.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Didacus de Alfaro, in America Laxamae illustri Sanguine natus, Soc: Iesu, in obsequio Pastoralis animarum curae ab infidelibus caesus in Paraquaria. A. 1639. die 17 Ianuarij
Description: Priest or monk kneels before a native American who shoots him with a gun or musket. In the background is a scene of warfare.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Diego de Alfaro was martyred in Paraguay in 1637 during the conflicts with the Mamelucos (mixed European-native race). He had been left in charge of the three remaining Jesuit missions on the Uruguay and Parana rivers.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Gaspar Osorius de Valderavano Hispanus, et P. Antonius Riparius Italus Soc: Iesu crudeliter ab Idololatris pro Christo occisi in Paraquaria apud Ciacos. A. 1639. 1 Aprilis.
Description: Priest or monk is martyred by being struck by a war club by a native American before a dwelling. He calls out, "Jesus Maria." In the background another priest has his heart ripped out by two native Americans.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Gaspar Osorio de Valderavano [Valderrábano], a Spanish Jesuit, and Antonio Ripario, an Italian, were two of the first Jesuits martyred by the Chiriguano Indians in the district of Chaco. They were part of the mission at Jujuí under the leadership of Sebastián de Alarcón.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Petrus Romerus Hispanus et Matthaeus Fernandez Indus Soc: Iesu, crudeliter ab Idololatris in Paraquaria apud Itatines occisi, zz. Martij. A. 1645.
Description: Priest or monk kneeling in prayer is martyred by being struck with a war club by a native American. Another priest lies on the ground and calls out, "Jesus Maria," while a native holds a knife.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Pedro Romero, Mateo Fernandez, and Justo Vanfurk (superior of the mission at Itatín) attempted to proselytize the area of Chaco Boreal (part of the Grand Chaco) across the Paraguay River from Itatín. Romero and Fernandez founded the mission of Santa Bárbara, but were killed in 1645.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: P. Cornelius Beudin Belga Soc: Iesu, crudeliter ab Idololatris Indis raptatus., et pro Christo strangulatus. apud Taraumarenses in America. A. 1650. 4. Junij
Description: Two native Americans drag a strangled priest or monk towards a cross made of a tree trunk with a board lashed to it. In the background are pagodas.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Corneille Beudin [Cornelio Godínez], a Belgian or Flemish Jesuit missionary, was strangled by the Tarahumara Indians in Mexico.The author, Mathias Tanner from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University.

Image_title: Neustra S. de guadalupe aparesida en mex[i]co
Description: Our Lady of Guadalupe appears to a man who wears her image on his cloak. In the background is a scene of the apparition. Details include cacti on the hill, church, and roses.
Source_Title: Felicidad de Mexico en el principio, y milagroso origen, que tubo el Santuario de la Virgen Maria N. Señora de Guadalupe
Source_publisher: Por la Viuda de Bernardo Calderon
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, filled with out-of-season roses to the bishop. The cloak was imprinted with the image of theVirgin. This portrait of the Virgin is the nineteenth known to have been printed in Mexico.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Item 20, Fig. 27

Image_title: P. Iacobus Basile, Italus Soc. Iesu ab isololartris pro fide truncatus, et è Cruce suspensus, apud Papigochos Indas in America A 1652 mense Martio
Description: Father Jacob Basile beheaded by the "Papigochos" (perhaps Pápago) Indians. His body is on a cross with one arm upraised, his head at his feet. In the background are dwellings.
Source_Title: Societas Jesu usque ad sanguinis et vitae profusionem militans in Europea, Africa, Asia, et America
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis Carolo-Ferdinandeae, in Collegio Societatis Jesu ad S. Clementem per Joannem Nicolaum Hampel Factorem
notes: Text describes Basile's life in Mexico, the Jesuit mission at Sinaloa, and the Tarahumares. The author, Mathias Tanner (1630-1692), from Pilsen, Bohemia, entered the Society of Jesus in 1646, spent most of his life in Prague, and became rector of the Colegio and Imperial University. The engraver may be Melchoir Küsel (1626-1683) or his brother, Matthäus Küsel (1629-1681), members of a German family of engravers.

Image_title: Ecclesia Celeberrimi Co[n]v[en]t[us], S. Franci[si] d[e] Lima ...
Description: Bird's-eye view of the Franciscan church and convent or monastery of San Francisco in Lima, Peru. Includes a representation of Fray Antonio de Somoza with a bird, well, cloisters, chapels, infirmary, and steeples. Items in the image are identified in a key at middle right.
Source_Title: Templo de N. grande patriarca San Francisco de la provincia de los doze apostoles de le Peru en la Ciudad de los Reyes
notes: Finished in 1674, the church of San Francisco was one of the few buildings in Lima to withstand the 1746 earthquake. This illustration is the only known one from the colonial period to show the entire edifice. Antonio de Somoza was the Franciscan Commissary General of the Indies and an Inquisition examiner.
References: Camilloni, H.R. "Architectural Principles ... San Francisco, Lima," Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians, vol. 28, no. 4, p. 235-253
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Item 43, Fig. 61
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Basilica Celeberrimi Conventus, Sti. Francisci Auspiciis S. Ludovici Episcopi Dicata; Erecta studio et cura Rmi. Ps. F. Ludovici Zerbela Australis Americae Commissarii Generalis Anno 1673.
Description: View of the Franciscan church and convent of San Francisco in Lima, Peru. Includes a view of the courtyard and entrances to the church and monastery, coat of arms, and compass.
Source_Title: Templo de N. grande patriarca San Francisco de la provincia de los doze apostoles de le Peru en la Ciudad de los Reyes
notes: Finished in 1674, the church of San Francisco was one of the few buildings in Lima to withstand the 1746 earthquake; its adjoining monastery also survived. Luis de Cervela was the builder of the church and monastery of San Francisco in Lima, Peru, as well as its general commissary from 1669 to 1674. The architect of much of the buildings of San Francisco, until his death in 1668, was Constantino Vasconcelos. Image placed horizontally on page.
References: Camilloni, H.R. "Architectural Principles ... San Francisco, Lima," Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians, vol. 28, no. 4, p. 235-253
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Rmo. P.F. Ludovico Zerbela Australis Americe Seraphici Ordinis Commissario Generali huius Claustralis Topiarii Auctori
Description: View of the main cloister of the monastery of San Francisco, Lima, Peru. Includes fountains and topiary.
Source_Title: Templo de N. grande patriarca San Francisco de la provincia de los doze apostoles de le Peru en la Ciudad de los Reyes
notes: Text describes some of the landscaping details of the garden and attributes its design to Capitan Sebastian de Cubas. Luis de Cervela was the builder of the church and monastery of San Francisco in Lima, Peru, as well as its general commissary from 1669 to 1674. The architect of the main cloister of the monastery was Constantino Vasconcelos. Image placed horizontally on page.
References: Camilloni, H.R. "Architectural Principles ... San Francisco, Lima," Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians, vol. 28, no. 4, p. 235-253
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Vera effigies Venerab: Servi Dei B. Francisci Solani ...
Description: Saint Francis Solanus, a Franciscan brother, baptizes native Americans and holds a crucifix in his hand. Includes scene of his being shipwrecked in the background. Also includes feathered headdresses and garments, discarded bow and arrow, and bishop's miter.
Source_Title: [Vida, virtudes, y milagros del nuevo apostol del Peru. German] Leben, Tugenden, unnd Wunderwerck dess Apostels von Peru ...
Source_publisher: Getruckt und verlegt durch Johann Jäcklin Churfl. Hoffbuechtrucker
