notes: A missionary in Peru and Paraguay, Solanus arrived in Peru in 1589 and was known for his ability to speak numerous native American dialects. He was censor of the convents of his order in Tucuman and Paraguay and was later elected guardian of the Franiscan convent in Lima, Peru.

Image_title: Ferdinand Cortez A Spaniard.
Description: Portrait of Hernán Cortés wearing armor and carrying a sword.
Source_Title: [Vrais pourtraits et vies des hommes illustres. English] Prosopographia: or, Some select pourtraitures and lives of ancient and modern illustrious personages ...
Source_publisher: Printed by John Hayes, for William Lee, at the Turks Head in Fleetstreet, over against Fetter Lane, London
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II).

Image_title: [Pirates raid Puerto Principe]
Description: The pirate, Captain Henry Morgan, captures and sacks the town of Puerto Principe. Military aspects include guns, spears, swords, and scene of warfare. Built environment includes dwelling and an arch.
Source_Title: [Amerikaanse zeerovers] De Americaensche zee-roovers ...
Source_publisher: By Jan ten Hoorn, Boeckverkoper ober 't oude Heeren Logement
notes: Henry Morgan was a notorious pirate who captured numerous Spanish ships, as well as the towns of Puerto Principe (present-day Camaguey, Cuba), Portobelo (in Panama) and Maracaibo (in Venezuela). In 1674, after being granted a pardon by Charles II of England, Morgan was knighted and appointed Lieutenant-Governor of Jamaica.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Brief van den Spaenschen Generael Don Alonzo del Campo Spinoce, aen Morgan Admirael van de Rovers.]
Description: Scene of naval warfare and an attack by pirates on a town. Built environment includes ships, boats, and fortifications.
Source_Title: [Amerikaanse zeerovers] De Americaensche zee-roovers ...
Source_publisher: By Jan ten Hoorn, Boeckverkoper ober 't oude Heeren Logement
notes: On May 1, 1669, Captain Henry Morgan sailed a ship purposely set alight into the flagship of the Spanish admiral in the harbor of the town of Maracaibo in present-day Venezuela causing it to sink. Another ship was scuttled by the Spaniards to keep it from being taken by Morgan's men. A third Spanish ship was captured by the pirates. The Spanish fleet was commanded by Admiral Alonso del Campo y Espinosa. Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: Reskontre van de Spanÿaerden tegens de Roovers voor de stadt Panama, Nevens het Verbranden en Ruÿneren van de selve stadt.
Description: Attack on a city in Panama. At top the town is engulfed in flames. At bottom is a scene of warfare. Built environment includes dwellings, church and ships. Military aspects include guns or muskets, lances or spears, horses, and swords.
Source_Title: [Amerikaanse zeerovers] De Americaensche zee-roovers ...
Source_publisher: By Jan ten Hoorn, Boeckverkoper ober 't oude Heeren Logement
notes: Henry Morgan attacked the town of Portobelo on the northern coast of the Isthmus of Panama in June 1666. In a daring attack he took the town, held its citizens for ransom and repelled the Spanish troops who came to the aid of the town from the city of Panama.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Mira historia de imagine B. Virginis in Regno Chilense visa.]
Description: Image of the Virgin Mary and Christ child found in a grotto or cave in Chile.
Source_Title: [Mundus subterraneous] Athanasii Kircheri e Soc. Jesu Mundus subterraneous, in XII libros digestus ... Tomus II
Source_publisher: Apud Joannem Janssonium à Waesberge & filios
notes: Kircher, a Jesuit polymath, in this chapter on stones describes the miraculous discovery of a statue found in a hidden cliff or grotto in Chile. He attributes the story of the statue's discovery to Alfonso d'Ovalle. (Cf. 0875-20).Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [Mining in Peru]
Description: Mining in Peru. Includes miners, one holding a torch, climbing a double ladder from a mine in a mountain. The miners wear packs on their backs to carry the ore.
Source_Title: [Mundus subterraneous] Athanasii Kircheri e Soc. Jesu Mundus subterraneous, in XII libros digestus ... Tomus II
Source_publisher: Apud Joannem Janssonium à Waesberge & filios
notes: Kircher, a Jesuit polymath, in this chapter on mining discusses how the silver mines, specifically in Potosí, Peru (present-day Bolivia), are worked.

Image_title: El Sieruo de Dios fr. Gonçalo Diaz de Amarante del Rl. y Militry. Orden de Na. Sa. de la Merced. Ron. et d[e] Cautos. murio en 27 d[e] Enero de 1618
Description: A monk holding keys and carrying a basket filled with bread [?] over his arm looks at a vision of the Virgin Mary wearing a crown and surrounded by angels. Before him native Americans with feathered headdresses pray.
Source_Title: Vida del servio de Dios V. P. Fray Gonzalo Diaz de Amarante ...
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Gonçalez de Reyes
notes: Gonzalo Diaz de Amarante was born in Portugal, but traveled to Peru where he became a Mercedarian religious. In 1675, the apostolic process of making him a saint was initiated.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: [Life of Gonzalo Diaz de Amarante]
Description: A monk kneels before a vision of the Virgin Mary wearing a crown and surrounded by angels. Before him stands a basket filled with bread [?]. Surrounding the Classical aedicule are scenes from his life including scene of him feeding the religious in the convent and feeding the poor of Lima. Also includes ship, devil or demon, coat of arms, deathbed, burial, and fire scene.
Source_Title: Vida del servio de Dios V. P. Fray Gonzalo Diaz de Amarante ...
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Gonçalez de Reyes
notes: Gonzalo Diaz de Amarante was born in Portugal, but traveled to Peru where he became a Mercedarian religious. In 1675, the apostolic process of making him a saint was initiated.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Virgin Mary [Nuestra Senora de los Remedios] holding the Christ Child. Includes hanging votaries of head, heart, leg, and arm, hanging lanterns, scepter, crowns, and candlesticks.
Source_Title: Acordes rendimientos, afectos numerosos, que continuando su devocion ...
Source_publisher: Por la Viuda de Bernardo Calderon
notes: This image represents a statue of the Virgin Mary or Our Lady of Remedies. Said to have been brought to New Spain by one of the Spanish conquistadors, the statue was kept in Tlacopan and was brought to Mexico City to provide relief from drought.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Morgan resolveett om de Stadt Porto Ville aen te tasten, rust sijn Vloot toe, en verovert de Stadt met weynigh macht.]
Description: Porto-Bello under seige by pirates. Scenes of warfare with pirates using swords, guns, and spears.
Source_Title: [Amerikaanse zeerovers] De Americaensche zee-roovers.
Source_publisher: By Jan ten Hoorn, Boeckverkoper ober 't oude Heeren Logement
notes: Captain Henry Morgan attacked and plundered the city of Portobelo [in Panama] through which the riches of the Spanish Indies passed. The seige might have failed, but Morgan had his men take ladders and climb over the walls into the fortifications. Image title taken from chapter title.
References_exhibitions: Klooster, W. Dutch in the Americas, Fig. 6.11

Image_title: Afbeeldingh van de stadt en t' Landtschap, van Panama
Description: Plan of the coast of Panama showing some topographical details, location of rivers and settlements, compass rose, and ships.
Source_Title: [Amerikaanse zeerovers] De Americaensche zee-roovers ...
Source_publisher: By Jan ten Hoorn, Boeckverkoper ober 't oude Heeren Logement
notes: Captain Henry Morgan attacked the town of Panama in January 1671. In a daring attack, he took the town which burned during the seige.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Afbeeldingh van de stadt en t' Landtschap, van Marcaibo
Description: Plan of the harbor of Maracaibo showing some topographical details, location of settlements, rivers, and sea banks or shoals, compass rose, and ships.
Source_Title: [Amerikaanse zeerovers] De Americaensche zee-roovers ...
Source_publisher: By Jan ten Hoorn, Boeckverkoper ober 't oude Heeren Logement
notes: On May 1, 1669, Captain Henry Morgan sailed a ship purposely set alight into the flagship of the Spanish admiral in the harbor of the town of Maracaibo in present-day Venezuela causing it to sink. Another ship was scuttled by the Spaniards to keep it from being taken by Morgan's men. A third Spanish ship was captured by the pirates.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Elv. P. Bartholome Castaño dela Compañia de JHS ...
Description: Portrait of Bartholomé [Bartolomé] Castaño holding a book.
Source_Title: Breve noticia de la vida exemplar y dichosa muerte del venerable padre Bartholomé Castaño de la Compañia de Jesus ...
Source_publisher: por Juan de Ribera, en el Pedradillo
notes: Castaño was a Jesuit missionary among the Opatas in Sinaloa, Mexico.

Image_title: Signum magnum apparvit in coelo mulier amicta sole et luna sub pedibus eius
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe standing on a crescent moon with crown, starry cloak, and angel.
Source_Title: Centonicum virgilianum monimentum mirabilis apparitionis purissimae virginis Marieae de Guadalupe extramuros civitatis Mexicanae
Source_publisher: Apud Viduam Bernardi Calderon
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Cruelities of the pirates in Panama]
Description: Men torture and kill in a settlement by the sea. Includes man having molten liquid poured down his throat, another bound before a fire, another man on a rack being burned, another being quartered, another hanging from a pole. Also includes ships, battalions of soldiers marching toward the men, church, and dwellings.
Source_Title: [Zeldzaame en gedenkwaardige zee- en land-reizen] Eduward Meltons, Engelsch edelmans, zeldzaame en gedenkwaardige zee- en land-reizen
Source_publisher: By Jan ten Hoorn, Boeckverkoper ober 't oude Heeren Logement
notes: Text discusses the cruelities of the pirates in Panama. This account of the West Indies is in part taken from Alexandre Olivier Exquemelin's De Americaensche Zee-Roovers, Amsterdam, 1678. A compilation of accounts from various sources, attributed by Tiele to Godofridus van Broekhuizen; Melton is considered a pseudonym.

Image_title: Diseño de la fachada del conuento de nuestra Sa. del Rosario de Predicadores de Lima

Image_title: [Kidney stone, weesle headed armadillo, skulls of a hippopotamus and a baby-roussa or wild Mexican musk-hog, and wild boar tusk]
Description: Kidney stone, a nine-banded armadillo, skulls of a hippopotamus and wild pig or peccary or Mexican musk-hog, and a wild boar tusk.

Source_publisher: Printed by W. Rawlins, for the author
notes: The Mexican musk-hog, Mexicanus moschiferus, is the collared peccary, pecari tajacu. Image title taken from image labels.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: The Virgin Mary stands on a cactus surrounded by angels and superimposed on a Hapsburg double-headed eagle. The eagle is surmounted by the papal crown and keys.
Source_Title: Villancicos, que se cantaron en la Santa Iglesia Metropolitana de Mexico: en honor de Maria Santissima Madre de Dios. En su Assumpcion triumphante ...
Source_publisher: Por la Viuda de Bernardo Calderon
notes: The eagle perched on a cactus was a sign to the wandering Mexica or Aztec tribe of the site where they were to build their city of Tenochtitlan, now Mexico City.Publication information taken from colophon.

Image_title: B. T. in Archiepiscopum Limae consecratiir.
Description: Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo is consecrated an archbishop. Includes a man kneeling before a seated archbishop who places a miter on the kneeling man's head. Also includes a crozier.
Source_Title: Breve teatro de las acciones mas notables de la vida del bienaventurado Toriibio arçobispo de Lima ...
Source_publisher: Por el Tinasi Ympr. Cam. impresor cameral
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726. Mogrovejo was appointed as the archbishop of Lima before he had even been ordained a priest. After receiving papal dispensation he was ordained as a priest in Grenada and recieved episcopal consecration in Seville in 1578. He left for Peru in September 1580. This book shows scenes from his life.

Image_title: B. T. a jumento in flumen decusso parcunt Crocodili
Description: Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo riding a mule or donkey falls into a river filled with alligators or crocodiles.
Source_Title: Breve teatro de las acciones mas notables de la vida del bienaventurado Toriibio arçobispo de Lima ...
Source_publisher: Por el Tinasi Ympr. Cam. impresor cameral
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726. Mogrovejo left for Peru in September 1580. Here he is shown having fallen into alligator-infested waters on the trip between Panama to Portobelo [Porto belo or Porto Bello]. This book shows scenes from his life.

Image_title: B. T. Limam humiliter ingreditur.
Description: Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo walks through a crowded city street blessing beggars and ordinary people who kneel before him. Includes other priests and attendants, parasol, and galero [hat].
Source_Title: Breve teatro de las acciones mas notables de la vida del bienaventurado Toriibio arçobispo de Lima ...
Source_publisher: Por el Tinasi Ympr. Cam. impresor cameral
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726. Mogrovejo left for Peru in September 1580. When he arrived in Lima, he found the church in a spiritual decline; Peru had been without an archbishop for six years. This book shows scenes from his life.

Image_title: Vida Exemplae Muerte preciosa del Venerable Hermano Pedro de S. Joseph Betancur Fundador de la Compa[ñ]a Bethleemitica [sic] en las Indais Occidentales.
Description: Saint Rodrigo with a knife through his head and a Spanish king, on either side of a monument, look up at the Holy Family encircled by angels. On the monument is the portrait of a woman. Seated at the foot of the monument is a native American with feathered headdress and a bow and arrow. Also includes crown, orb, sword, chain of the Order of the Golden Fleece, pile of coins, palm branch, and trumpet.
Source_Title: Vida admirable y muerte preciosa del venerable hermano Pedro de S. Joseph Betancur fundador de la Compañia Bethlemitica en las Yndias Occidentales
Source_publisher: Por Nicolas Angel Tinassi Ympresor Camer.
notes: Pedro de San José de Betancourt founded the hospitaler Bethlehemites or Belemites and worked for the poor in Guatemala. He became the first Guatemalan saint in 2002. The woman in the center of the monument is the Queen Regent of Spain, Maria Ana de Austria, who ruled as the monarch for her son, Charles II, after her husband, Philip IV died. Her son, the last of the Hapsburg family and mentally handicapped, was was only 4 years old when his father died; the crown at the foot of his mother's portrait represents his monarchy. In 1672 Betancourt's successor, Brother Roderick of the Cross, obtained the confirmation of a hospital in Lima from the king of Spain and also the confirmation of the Bethlehemites from Pope Clement X. Saint Roderick, Brother Roderick's patron saint, was martyred by the Moors in ninth-century Spain. The scene of the nativity at the top of the image represents the symbol of the Bethlehemites; it is included in any images or buildings related to the order. Betancourt is credited with introducing the custom of the "posada" in Guatemala (also practiced in Mexico). On Christmas Eve, groups recreate the procession of Mary and Joseph, looking for shelter and hospitality among neighbors and friends.
Commentary: Information on the iconography of this image was provided by Coralia Anchisi de Rodriguez of the Popul Vuh Museum at the Universidad Francisco Marroquín. She identified Queen Maria Ana de Austria, Charles II, and the coat of arms of the Bethlehemite Order.

Image_title: Verdadero Retrato del Venerable Hermano Pedro de S. Joseph Betancur, Fundador de la Compañia Bethleemitica en las Indias Occidentales.
Description: Barefoot monk kneels before the image the Virgin Mary on an altar or reredos. His cloak has a badge with the Holy Family on it.
Source_Title: Vida admirable y muerte preciosa del venerable hermano Pedro de S. Joseph Betancur fundador de la Compañia Bethlemitica en las Yndias Occidentales
Source_publisher: Por Nicolas Angel Tinassi Ympresor Camer.
notes: Pedro de San José de Betancourt founded the hospitaler Bethlehemites or Belemites and worked for the poor in Guatemala; he was devoted to the Virgin Mary. He became the first Guatemalan saint in 2002. This engraving represents an apparition of the Virgin to Pedro de Betancourt in the chapel of "El Calvario" in Antigua, Guatemala. The Virgin is accompanied by Saint Joseph and Saint Francis of Assisi. Most of the representations of this apparition were confiscated by the Bishop Andres de la Navas because Betancourt is shown wearing the clothes of the order of the Bethlehemites and not those of the Franciscans to which he belonged. The scene of the nativity on Betancourt's cloak is the symbol of the Bethlehemites; it is included in any images or buildings related to the order. Betancourt is credited with introducing the custom of the "posada" in Guatemala (also practiced in Mexico). On Christmas Eve, groups recreate the procession of Mary and Joseph, looking for shelter and hospitality among neighbors and friends.
Commentary: Information on the iconography of this image was provided by Coralia Anchisi de Rodriguez of the Popol Vuh Museum at the Universidad Francisco Marroquín. She provided the information about the chapel, identification of the saints in the painting being venerated by Betancourt, as well as details about the suppression of images of Betancourt as a Bethlehemite.

Image_title: The Spanish Armada destroyed by Captaine Morgan
Description: Scene of naval warfare. Built environment includes ships, boats, dwellings, church, and fortifications. In the foreground men in a boat pull others from the sea.
Source_Title: [Americannse zeerovers. English] Bucaniers of America: or, A true account of the most remarkable assaults committed of late years upon the coasts of the West-Indies
Source_publisher: Printed for William Crooke, at the Green Dragon without Temple-bar
notes: On May 1, 1669, Captain Henry Morgan sailed a ship purposely set alight into the flagship of the Spanish admiral in the harbor of the town of Maracaibo in present-day Venezuela causing it to sink. Another ship was scuttled by the Spaniards to keep it from being taken by Morgan's men. A third Spanish ship was captured by the pirates. The Spanish fleet was commanded by Admiral Alonso del Campo y Espinosa. Part I of the Bucaniers of America was written by Alexandre Olivier Exquemelin.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The Battel Between the Spaniards and the pyrats or Buccaniers before the citty of Panama.
Description: Attack on a city in Panama. At top the town is engulfed in flames. At bottom is a scene of warfare. Built environment includes dwellings, church, fortifications, and ships. Military aspects include guns or muskets, lances or spears, horses, and swords.
Source_Title: [Americannse zeerovers. English] Bucaniers of America: or, A true account of the most remarkable assaults committed of late years upon the coasts of the West-Indies
Source_publisher: Printed for William Crooke, at the Green Dragon without Temple-bar
notes: Henry Morgan attacked the town of Panama in January 1671. In a daring attack, he captured the town which burned during the seige. Part I of the Bucaniers of America was written by Alexandre Olivier Exquemelin.
References: Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.11, p. 81
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Title page showing two allegorical figures representing Spain and New Spain supporting a portrait of Charles II of Spain. Decorative elements include a crown over two hemsipheres, a phoenix and an eagle, feathered headdress.
Source_Title: Historia de la conqvista de Mexico
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de Bernardo de Villa-Diego, Impressor de su Magestad
notes: Charles II was the last of the Hapsburgs to rule Spain. An example of the degenerative effect of inbreeding of the Hapsburgs, he died without issue and was mentally and physically handicapped.
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, Fig. 9

Image_title: Beatus Turribius Archiepiscopus Limanus
Description: Portrait of Toribio Alfonso de Mogrovejo supported by angels ascending to heaven. Includes miter, cross, laurel wreath, and cloak.
Source_Title: Concilia Limana, constitvtiones synodales, et alia vtilia monumenta: qvibvs Beatvs Toribivs archiepisc. Limanvs ecclesias Peruani imperij mirificè illustrauit ...
Source_publisher: Ex typographia I. Vannaccij
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He died in 1606 and was canonized in 1726.

Image_title: The Bay of Panama and Gulf of Ballona
Description: Map of the bay of Panama and the gulf of Ballona (also known as the gulf of Vallona or Saint Michael).
Source_Title: Bucaniers of America. The second volume. Containing the dangerous voyage and bold attempts of Captain Bartholomew Sharp ...
Source_publisher: Printed for William Crooke, at the Green Dragon without Temple-bar
notes: This map was originally made by William Hack, a London map and chart maker, from a collection of Spanish charts captured by the English privateer, Captain Bartholomew Sharpe, when his ship, Trinity, seized the Spanish ship, Rosario, off the coast of Ecuador in 1681. Among the booty seized was a derrotero, or a volume of manuscript charts of the coast with detailed sailing directions, captured as it was about to be thrown overboard. Hack copied this work for the British crown and called it the South Sea Wagoner. Hack never published his atlas (it was thought to be too important to grant access to the information in it), although several manuscript copies were made and sold by Hack.Here a version was published as part of Sharpe's account of his journey.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Montagne de Potosi
Description: Mine at Potosí. Details include chapel at top, settlement, churches and dwellings at the bottom. Also seen are paths up the mountain and the river running through the town.
Source_Title: Description de l'univers, contenant les differents systemes du monde, les cartes generales & particulieres de la geographie ancienne & moderne ... Tome cinquième
Source_publisher: Chez Jean David Zunner
notes: The mines at Potosí were discovered by Diego Hualca in 1544. The silver mines there were among the richest in the world. Cf. 03390-1 and 01631-7.

Image_title: Patagons
Description: Native American man and woman from Patagonia. Includes feathered headdresses and garment, arrow, and bow.
Source_Title: Description de l'univers, contenant les differents systemes du monde, les cartes generales & particulieres de la geographie ancienne & moderne ... Tome cinquième
Source_publisher: Chez Jean David Zunner
notes: As early the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Patagonia (Argentina and Chile)

Image_title: P[eup]les. du Chili
Description: Native American man and woman from Chile. Includes a settlement in the background with dwellings and farming.
Source_Title: Description de l'univers, contenant les differents systemes du monde, les cartes generales & particulieres de la geographie ancienne & moderne ... Tome cinquième
Source_publisher: Chez Jean David Zunner
notes: Image derived from images of Isla Mocha in Olivier van Noort, Beschrijvinge vande voyagie om den geheelen werelt-kloot, Amsterdam, 1618. Cf. 04820-2 and 04820-4.

Image_title: Atabalipa frere de Guascar Inca ou Empereur du Perou
Description: Portrait of Atahualpa or Atabalipa, a native American ruler, holding a spear. Includes feathered headdress, arrow, eagle, and ornaments [gorget].
Source_Title: Description de l'univers, contenant les differents systemes du monde, les cartes generales & particulieres de la geographie ancienne & moderne ... Tome cinquième
Source_publisher: Chez Jean David Zunner
notes: Atabalipa [Atahualpa] was the last independent Inca ruler in Peru. He was captured by the Spanish and executed in 1533 despite having paid a vast ransom for his life. He took leadership from his half-brother, Inti Cusi Huallpa Huáscar, during a civil war.

Image_title: P[eup]les. du Perou
Description: Native Americans of Peru. Includes war club and feathered headdress.
Source_Title: Description de l'univers, contenant les differents systemes du monde, les cartes generales & particulieres de la geographie ancienne & moderne ... Tome cinquième
Source_publisher: Chez Jean David Zunner
notes: Image of the Peruvians derived from Theodor de Bry, America, part 6.

Image_title: Royaume des Amazons
Description: Native American women from the Amazon River flank a map showing the Amazon River and its tributaries. Includes bow, arrow, and spear.
Source_Title: Description de l'univers, contenant les differents systemes du monde, les cartes generales & particulieres de la geographie ancienne & moderne ... Tome cinquième
Source_publisher: Chez Jean David Zunner

Image_title: Verdadero Retrato del V. P. Fr. Sebastian de Aparicio ...
Description: Man in Franciscan garments stands in a mountainous landscape before oxen teams. Includes an overturned ewer or vessel, staff, and ox carts.
Source_Title: Virtudes, y milagros en vida, y muerte del V.P. fr. Sebastian de Aparicio ... de la provincia del Santo Evangelio de Mexico, en la Nueva España ...
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: [Cinchona tree]
Description: Cinchona [chinchona] tree showing roots, trunk, leaves, and flowers.
Source_Title: Febris china chinae expugnata, seu Illustrium aliquot virorum opuscula, quae veram tradunt methodum, febres china chinae curandid ...
Source_publisher: Typis Bernardini Pomatelli
notes: Cinchona or quinine bark was first documented for its curative effects on malaria in 1638 when the countess of Cinchon, wife of a Peruvian viceroy, was supposed to have been cured of a malarial type fever. Cinchona, one of forty species of trees, was not botanically classified until 1737. Until the seeds were stolen in 1865 and successfully planted in the Dutch East Indies, the tropical forests of northwestern South America were the sole sources of this valuable medicine. Scientific name: Cinchona officinalis.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: A bishop with miter and crosier is flanked by two native Americans who kneel before him. On his left is a woman [Rose of Lima?] with an angel placing a wreath of roses on her head, on the right is a monk [Francis Solano?] holding a crucifix who baptizes various kneeling native Americans by pouring water from a vessel. Another vignette shows a man asleep who holds a rosary in his hand while an angel offers him another rosary. Also includes various coats of arms (including the Spanish royal coat of arms [Spanish Hapsburg coat of arms] and the papal coat of arms), angels, the Holy Spirit or Dove, and architectural features.
Source_Title: La estrella de Lima convertida en sol sobre svs tres coronas el B. Toribio Alfonso Mogrobexo ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Baptista Verdussen
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Portrait medallions of native American rulers and battle scenes. Decorative elements include seven medallions of indigenous rulers or caciques (Sacuan, Sugamuxi, Nemeguene, Vbaqui, Saquesazippa, Thysquesuca, and Guatabita), and four battle scenes (the battles of Choconta, las Bueltas, Portachuelo, and Voqueron), and two coats of arms--the Spanish royal coat of arms and [Vincente Gonçaga?] coat of arms.
Source_Title: Historia general de la conqvistas del nvevo reyno de Granada
Source_publisher: Juan Baptista Verdussen Tomás de Haro?
notes: New Granada was located in northern South America and at various times included present-day Panama, Venezula, Ecuador, and Colombia. Engraver is probably Joseph Mulder (1659/60 - aft. 1718).
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writing about the New World, 35.

Image_title: Suspice coelumet numera stellas.
Description: Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe with roses, starry cloak, and angel.
Source_Title: La estrella del norte de Mexico
Source_publisher: por Doña Maria de Benavides, Viuda de Juan de Ribera en el Empedradillo
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Bishop Zumárraga accepted the vision when Juan Diego presented his cloak, or tilma, filled with out-of-season roses to the bishop.

Image_title: [Indian of Peru]
Description: Native American man wearing a headdress with feathers and feather leg ornaments stands before a dwelling.
Source_Title: Thesaurus exoticorum. Oder eine mit aussländischen Raritäten und Geschichten wohlversehene Schatz-Kammer fürstellend die asiatische, africanische und americanische Nationes ...
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und Verlegt durch Thomas von Wiering Buchdrucker und Formschneider; sind auch zu bekommen in Franckfurth bey Zacharias Herteln
notes: This image is derived from Arnoldus Montanus, De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld, Amsterdam, 1671 (cf. 01631-90). A prolific writer (mostly of novels), Happel here describes a variety of exotic peoples at the border of Europe. His principal focus is on Islamic peoples, but he does include indigenous peoples of the Americas.

Image_title: Athabaliba ultimus Rex Peruanorum
Description: Portrait of Atahualpa or Atabalipa, the last Inca ruler. Includes feathered headdress, arrow, eagle, and ornaments [gorget].
Source_Title: Thesaurus exoticorum. Oder eine mit aussländischen Raritäten und Geschichten wohlversehene Schatz-Kammer fürstellend die asiatische, africanische und americanische Nationes ...
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und Verlegt durch Thomas von Wiering Buchdrucker und Formschneider; sind auch zu bekommen in Franckfurth bey Zacharias Herteln
notes: A prolific writer (mostly of novels), Happel here describes a variety of exotic peoples at the border of Europe. His principal focus is on Islamic peoples, but he does include indigenous peoples of the Americas.

Image_title: [Indians of Chile]
Description: Native American man and woman. Includes war club and dwellings.
Source_Title: Thesaurus exoticorum. Oder eine mit aussländischen Raritäten und Geschichten wohlversehene Schatz-Kammer fürstellend die asiatische, africanische und americanische Nationes ...
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und Verlegt durch Thomas von Wiering Buchdrucker und Formschneider; sind auch zu bekommen in Franckfurth bey Zacharias Herteln
notes: This image is derived from Arnoldus Montanus, De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld, Amsterdam, 1671 (cf. 01631-96). A prolific writer (mostly of novels), Happel here describes a variety of exotic peoples at the border of Europe. His principal focus is on Islamic peoples, but he does include indigenous peoples of the Americas.

Image_title: [Indian of Paraguay]
Description: Native American man holding a bow and arrow. Includes skin garment and quiver of arrows.
Source_Title: Thesaurus exoticorum. Oder eine mit aussländischen Raritäten und Geschichten wohlversehene Schatz-Kammer fürstellend die asiatische, africanische und americanische Nationes ...
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und Verlegt durch Thomas von Wiering Buchdrucker und Formschneider; sind auch zu bekommen in Franckfurth bey Zacharias Herteln
notes: A prolific writer (mostly of novels), Happel here describes a variety of exotic peoples at the border of Europe. His principal focus is on Islamic peoples, but he does include indigenous peoples of the Americas.

Image_title: [Indian of Mexico]
Description: Native American man with feathered headdress and ornaments. Includes bow and arrow.
Source_Title: Thesaurus exoticorum. Oder eine mit aussländischen Raritäten und Geschichten wohlversehene Schatz-Kammer fürstellend die asiatische, africanische und americanische Nationes ...
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und Verlegt durch Thomas von Wiering Buchdrucker und Formschneider; sind auch zu bekommen in Franckfurth bey Zacharias Herteln
notes: A prolific writer (mostly of novels), Happel here describes a variety of exotic peoples at the border of Europe. His principal focus is on Islamic peoples, but he does include indigenous peoples of the Americas.

Image_title: [Huitzilopochtli, Aztec idol or god]
Description: Huitzilopochtli, an idol or god shown as a devil with wings, a face on his stomach, and cloven hooves, stands on an altar decorated with military matériel such as spears, shields, and feathered headdresses. In one hand he holds a pole, in the other a shield with five feathers on it.
Source_Title: Thesaurus exoticorum. Oder eine mit aussländischen Raritäten und Geschichten wohlversehene Schatz-Kammer fürstellend die asiatische, africanische und americanische Nationes ...
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und Verlegt durch Thomas von Wiering Buchdrucker und Formschneider; sind auch zu bekommen in Franckfurth bey Zacharias Herteln
notes: Huitzilopochtli or Huitziláihuitl, an Aztec god symbolized by the hummingbird, was the god of the sun and war. Text describes the statue as being seated on a litter painted blue with serpents' heads at the end of the poles. The statue held a serpent in one hand and a shield with five feathers on it in the other. Its head was crowned with feathers. This image is derived from Arnoldus Montanus, De Nieuwe en onbekende Weereld, Amsterdam, 1671 (cf. 01631-16). A prolific writer (mostly of novels), Happel here describes a variety of exotic peoples at the border of Europe. His principal focus is on Islamic peoples, but he does include indigenous peoples of the Americas.

Image_title: Beatus Turribius Archiepiscopus Limanus.
Description: Portrait of Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo, an archbishop who confirms a child [?], Rosa of Lima [?], kneeling before him. Includes other acolytes, altar boy, and worshipers, as well as miter, processional cross, and bishop's staff or crozier.
Source_Title: La estrella de Lima convertida en sol sobre svs tres coronas el B. Toribio Alfonso Mogrobexo ...
Source_publisher: Por Juan Baptista Verdussen
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726.This image is derived Cipriano de Herrera, Mirabilis vita ... Toribii Alfonsi Mogrovesi ..., Rome, 1670.

Image_title: [Europeans arrive in America]
Image_publisher: la veuve d'Edme Martin, Jean Boudot, & Estienne Martin
Description: A group of European men, disembarked from their ships, stands near a group of native Americans. Includes feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_Title: Histoire du monde, ... Tome cinquième.
Source_publisher: Chez la veuve d'Edme Martin, Jean Boudot, & Estienne Martin, ruë S. Jacques, au Soleil d'or.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: [View of Mexico City]
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing the various islands, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city. Also includes soldiers on horseback (perhaps invading Spaniards?). Items in the image are lettered for identification in table at bottom.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: The city is depicted as the artist imagined Tenochtitlan was before (or as ?) Europeans arrived, with European-type houses and churches.
References: Cf. Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.25, p. 92-93
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: La ville de Mexique
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing the various islands, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city. Also includes men on horseback , domestic animals, boats, churches, dwellings, wicker dams, and main square. Items in the image are lettered for identification in table at bottom.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: The city is probably depicted as the artist imagined Tenochtitlan was before Europeans arrived, with European-type houses and churches and men on horseback or herding sheep. The image is derived from Carol Allard, Orbis habitabilis oppida et vestitas, Amsterdam 1681, who in turn derived his view from the Hernán Cortés map-view of Tenochtitlán.
References: Cf. Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.24, p. 92-93
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Hernán Cortés captures Moctezuma]
Description: Spanish soldier directs a boy to put manacles on a native American chief or ruler. Includes armor, chains, feathered headdress and garments, throne, and baton.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Text describes the capture of Montezuma or Moctezuma II by Hernán Cortés.

Image_title: Bataille dans la Vallée d'Ottumba
Description: View of the battle of Otumba. Includes columns or battalions of soldiers and scene of warfare. Items are lettered for identification in key at bottom of image.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: The battle of Otumba occurred as Hernán Cortés was retreating from Tenochtitlán followed by hunger, disease, and pursuing Aztec warriors. Cort�s' army fled to Tlaxcala to obtain reinforcements. Encountering a legion of Aztec soldiers sent by Cuitlahuac, Moctezuma's brother and successor, the Spanish decisively won the battle.

Image_title: Le grand Temple de Mexique
Description: Bird's-eye view of the main temple [the Templo mayor] of Mexico City. The temple is encircled by a wall with serpents or snakes carved on it and two sanctuaries on the top before which priests sacrifice a victim. A body is tossed down the stairs. Dancers celebrate before the temple within the wall. In foreground is a skull rack or tzompantli and native Americans with bows and arrows wearing feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: The great temple at Tenochtitlan was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc, the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli. Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. Tlaloc, the god of rain and agriculture, was of pre-Aztec, or Toltec, origin. A coatepantli or wall made of sculpted serpents often surrounds Aztec temples. The tzompantli would hold the skulls of sacrificial victims.

Image_title: Danses apellees Mitoles
Description: Method of dancing among native Mexicans. Men dance while standing on each other's shoulders and while balancing on a rope. Also includes a man being ferried across a river. Includes European ship, musical instruments such as drums, feathered headdresses and garments, and bows and arrows.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Mitotes were ceremonies involving chanting and drinking usually held after a hunt or as part of a funeral.This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9, 3rd part, plate 11, which describes the dances of the Mexicans. The image of how Mexicans cross rivers is from the same Theodor de Bry, Pt. 9, 3rd part, plate 2.

Image_title: Combat des Brigantins de Cortez contre les canots des Mexiquains.
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán in Lake Texcoco with European ships firing guns and native American boats or canoes.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Text relates the reconquest of Tenochtitlán or Mexico City. Cortés had built brigantines, really barges, that could carry men, guns, and horses; these were carried to and launched at Iztapalapa, a town that guarded one of the major causeways providing access to Tenochtitl�n. Eventually, the defenders of Tenochtitl�n were starved out by the effectiveness of the brigantines in preventing food or water from entering the city.

Image_title: Retraite de Guatimozin pris par Holguin.
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán in Lake Texcoco with European ships firing guns and native American boats or canoes, scene of naval warfare.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Text relates the reconquest of Tenochtitlán or Mexico City. Guatimozin or Cuauhtámoc/Cuauhtemo tzin was a nephew of Moctezuma II and was the last Aztec emperor. On August 13, 1521, on his way to ask for reinforcements from the lakeshore villages, he was captured by Cortés's officer, Holguin. Guatimozin then surrendered to Cortés and was kept as a hostage by him until Cortés decided to hang him on February 26, 1525. Cortés held his feet to a fire to extract information about the riches of the Aztec.

Image_title: L'Idole Uiztzilipuztli
Description: Scene of worship and human sacrifice at a native American or Mexican temple. The victim's heart is cut out before an idol or statue by a priest with a knife. The priest's assistants hold the victim by all four limbs. Includes feathered headdress, statues of men in feathered headdresses and garments, and an alcove holding the idol who holds snakes, arrows, and a feathered shield.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. The offering of the victim's heart to the gods satisfied the Aztec belief that the sun would rise again nourished by the hearts of men. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9, plate 8.

Image_title: Vaisseaux de Cortez desagrées et échouez par ses ordres
Description: Ships scuttled in a rocky harbor. Built environment includes an encampment of tents, dwellings, and a settlement.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: On April 21, 1519, Hernán Cortés landed near the site of Veracruz on a mission to establish a colony in Mexico. In order to prevent his men from retreating, he had the ships sunk. The painter of this image may be Jan Karel Donatus van Beecq, 1638-1722. In 1691 Fouard engraved a series of plates after van Beecq's designs (only this one is signed by the two men) for this book.
References: Bryan, M. Bryan's Dictionary of Painters and Engravers

Image_title: Isle de cuba Port St. Jacques.
Description: European ships sail from a harbor or port. One ship flies a flag reading "In hoc signo Vinces."
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Hernán Cortés was selected to lead the Spanish fleet to Mexico by the governor of Cuba, Diego Velázquez. Juan de Grijalva had explored Mexico's coast, but Cortés would explore and conquer its interior. He was accompanied by Diego de Ordaz, Francisco de Morla, and Bernard Diaz del Castillo.

Image_title: Riviere de Panuco autrement Rio de Canoas
Description: European ships fire guns at native Americans in boats.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne
Source_publisher: Chez Robert Pepie, ruë Saint Jacques, à l'Image S. Basile, au dessus de la Fontaine S. Severin
notes: Juan de Grijalva sailed from Santiago de Cuba in April 1518 to explore the shores of Mexico. He sailed along the northern coast of Cuba, landing at Bahía de la Ascensión on the Yucatan. He then traveled north along the Mexican coast, reaching his most northerly point at Rio Pánuco. There the Spanish ships were attacked by native Americans in canoes.
References: Cf. Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.24, p. 92-93

Image_title: Vaisseaux de Cortez desagrées et échouez par ses ordres
Description: Ships scuttled in a rocky harbor. Built environment includes an encampment of tents, dwellings, and a settlement.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. French] Histoire de la conquête du Mexique ou de la Nouvelle Espagne. Par Fernand Cortez.
Source_publisher: Chez Adrian Moetjens, Marchand Libraire pres la Cour à la Librarie Françoise
notes: On April 21, 1519, Hernán Cortés (1485-1547) landed near the site of Veracruz on a mission to establish a colony in Mexico. In order to prevent his men from retreating, he had the ships sunk.

Image_title: La idolatria de los Indios de Naçion Aruacos, que habita en las Sierras de S. Martha; destruida, por un Religiosso Del Orden de S. Augustin de la Prouincia de Lima el ano de [16]91 ...
Description: Two native Americans worship in a temple before an altar with religious objects. Holding war clubs and trumpets, they offer European military equipment such as a drum and armor.
Source_Title: Llanto sagrado de la America Meridional ...
Source_publisher: por Marcos Antonio Pandulso Malatesta
notes: This book relates the visit of the Augustinian missionary to the Sierra Nevada de Santa Martha in Colombia in 1691 and the subsequent destruction of many native American temples and idols.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: [Native Americans offer gifts to Thomas Gage]
Description: Native Americans and a European present offerings to a monk. Includes their offerings of bowl, animal skin, sugar canes, and a frog or toad whose blood is collected in a vessel. In the background a volcano erupts, and a llama carries a burden up a hill. Also includes a battle between a lion and a bear, as well as a feathered headdress and garment.
Source_Title: [English-American his travail by sea and land. German] Neue merckwürdige Reise-Beschreibung nach Neu Spanien ...
Source_publisher: Verlegts Johann Herbordt Kloss Buchhändl.
notes: Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, reported that the Pokoman Maya of Guatemala added poisonous toads to their fermented ritual drink called chicha to give it a special potency. The skin glands of the cane toad, Bufo marinus, contains bufotenine, a psychotropic drug.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Three Jesuit priests kneel in clouds surrounded by angels above kneeling native Americans in feathered headdresses. Also includes skulls and inset map of part of North and South America with California, Mexico, Cuba, Peru, and Cartagena labeled.
Source_Title: Historia de la provincia de la Campañia de Jesus de Nueva-España ... Tomo primero
Source_publisher: Por Juan Joseph Guillena Carrascoso
notes: Florencia was appointed procurator for the Jesuit province of Mexico, managed the provinces of his order in the Indies from Madrid, Seville, and Rome, but returned to Mexico in 1680. He wrote only the first volume of the Historia; the work was finished by Francisco Javier Alegre.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Map of Patagonia and Tierra del Fuego]
Description: Detailed map of Patagonia in Argentina and Chile and of Tierra del Fuego. Cartographic elements include compass rose, scale, lines of latitude and longitude, soundings, indications of sea banks or shoals, topographical and geographical details with their names. Cartouche includes angels holding palm branches and coat of arms with knight's helmet and a camel's head issuing from a ducal coronet. Includes commentary on character of land and people.
Source_Title: An account of several late voyages & discoveries to the south and north. Towards the Streights of Magellan, the South Seas, the vast tracts of land beyond Hollandia Nova, &c. Also towards Nova Zembla, Greenland or Spitsberg, Groynland or Engrondland, &c.
Source_publisher: Printed for Sam. Smith and Benj. Walford, printers to the Royal Society, at the Prince's Arms in S. Paul's Churchyard
notes: Commissioined by Charles II, Sir John Narbrough (or Narborough) left Deptford on November 26, 1669 and reached the Pacific Ocean on November 15, 1670. His ship, the Sweepstakes, was separated from its companion, the Batchelour Pink, and believed lost. He sailed up the Chilean coast as far as Valdivia, but was denied entry to that port by the Spanish.Probably originally published in Seller's Atlas Maritimus, or a Book of Charts, 1675, and in various editions until 1710. Seller dedicated his map, A Chart of the Sea Coast of Brazil ... to Narbrough. This map is dedicated by its publishers to Samuel Pepys.Engraver is probably John Sturt, 1658-1730.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Guatimala
Description: Volcanic eruption in Guatemala. Built environment includes view of town dwellings. Human activity includes ox carts driven by native Americans. Also includes waterfalls.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne, ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, Marchand Libraire dans le Beurs-straat.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Memorias Tiernas, Dispertador Afectuoso, ...
Description: The author [?] or monk [priest] kneels before the Virgin Mary who sits with a sword thrust through her heart. He wears an image of the Virgin around his neck and has before him the instruments of the Passion, pincers, sponge, shallow bowl, a hammer with bent nails, a crown of thorns, and a book or bible. Behind the Virgin is a cross with the letters, INRI, and in the background is a settlement with a church or mission.
Source_Title: Memorias tiernas, dispertador afectuoso, y devociones practicas con los dolores de la Santissima Virgen
Source_publisher: Por Henrico y Cornelio Verdussen
notes: The author was prefect of the Franciscan Congregation of the Colegio de San Pedro and San Pablo, Michoacan, Mexico. Here he writes of the sorrows of the Virgin Mary. INRI is an acronym of the Latin inscription which translates to English as "Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews."
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Portrait of Sebastián de Aparicio]
Description: A native American woman with a feathered headdress holding a book kneels before a portrait of Sebastián de Aparicio. Aparicio is flanked by angels, one with the [Pignatelli] coat of arms [family arms of Pope Innocent XII], the other with the royal Spanish coat of arms. Also includes another image of Sebastián de Aparicio emerging from a lily holding a rosary. He is surrounded by his symbols of an ox and oxcart. Also includes the symbol of Mexico, an eagle holding a snake in its beak resting on a cactus, papal keys and crown, a settlement with churches, ship, crown, horse, cornucopia, and armadillo [?].
Source_Title: Opusculum vitae, virtutum, et miraculorum ven. serui Dei Fr. Sebastiani ab Apparitio ordinis min. de obseruantia laici professi prouinciae mexicanae ...
Source_publisher: Ex Officina Reverendae Camerae Apostolicae
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787. The eagle perched on a cactus was a sign to the wandering Mexica or Aztec tribe of the site where they were to build their city of Tenochtitlan, now Mexico City.

Image_title: [right] Peruanische Stechwinde. Salsaparilla.
Description: [right] Branch, roots, leaves, and flowers of the sarsaparilla plant.
Source_Title: Theatrum botanicum, das ist: Neu vollkommenes Kräuter-Buch, worinnen allerhand Erdgewächse der Bäumen, Stauden und Kraütern, welche in allen vier Theilen der Welt, sonderlich aber in Europa herfür kommen ...
Source_publisher: gedruckt und verlegt durch Jacob Bertsche
notes: Monardes records that sarsaparilla was brought to Seville from New Spain around 1536-1545. John Gerard, about the close of the 16th century, noted that it was imported into England from Peru in large quantities. The best-known medicinal form was known as Jamaica sarsaparilla. This plant is part of the genus Smilax which is indigenous to Central America, Mexico, and Peru.Authorship according to British Museum (Natural History): This is based on Verzascha's edition of Pier Andrea Mattioli's "De Plantis Epitome utilissima..." from Verona, 1586, but so much altered and extended as practically to constitute a new work. Illustrated with about 1200 annotated woodcuts in the text by Gesner/ Camerarius (Iochino Camerario) originally used by Mattioli. Gesner had been preparing material for a massive historia plantarum but died before finishing the task. Camerarius acquired the material, utilized the woodcuts and supplemented them with his own designs. The woodcuts are remarkable in their scientific detail especially in the enlarged depictions of floral structure, seeds, and fruit. First appearing in 1586, these woodcuts became a convention in scientific botanical illustration. Zwinger was professor of physics and botany at Basel.

Image_title: [right] Indianische Zaunruben oder Mechoacana. Mechoacana.
Description: [right] Vine, leaves, and tuber of a kind of convolvulus.
Source_Title: Theatrum botanicum, das ist: Neu vollkommenes Kräuter-Buch, worinnen allerhand Erdgewächse der Bäumen, Stauden und Kraütern, welche in allen vier Theilen der Welt, sonderlich aber in Europa herfür kommen ...
Source_publisher: gedruckt und verlegt durch Jacob Bertsche
notes: This plant, a type of convolvulus, may be one known as Ipomoea jalapa, Bryonia mechoacana nigricans, Convolvulus mechoacana, or Ipomoea purga. The last is a well-known cathartic drug found in Vera Cruz, Mexico.Authorship according to British Museum (Natural History): This is based on Verzascha's edition of Pier Andrea Mattioli's "De Plantis Epitome utilissima..." from Verona, 1586, but so much altered and extended as practically to constitute a new work. Description: Cinchona tree or bush in flower.
Source_Title: Theatrum botanicum, das ist: Neu vollkommenes Kräuter-Buch, worinnen allerhand Erdgewächse der Bäumen, Stauden und Kraütern, welche in allen vier Theilen der Welt, sonderlich aber in Europa herfür kommen ...

Image_title: Indianische feigen. Ficus Indica.
Description: Opuntia cactus cut into its constituent parts which are lettered for identification in key at left.
Source_Title: Theatrum botanicum, das ist: Neu vollkommenes Kräuter-Buch, worinnen allerhand Erdgewächse der Bäumen, Stauden und Kraütern, welche in allen vier Theilen der Welt, sonderlich aber in Europa herfür kommen ...

Image_title: [Patagonians]
Description: A native American man and woman huddle in the cold. The man wears a fur cloak. In the background a native American woman warms herself at a fire within a semi-circular enclosure. Includes boats, dog, and penguin.
Source_Title: Relation d'un voyage fait en 1695. 1696. & 1697 ...
Source_publisher: dans l'Isle du Palais, sur le Quay de l'Horloge, à la Sphere Royale et chez Michel Brunet, dans la grande salle du Palais, au Mercure galant
notes: The expedition first came into contact with the native American Patagonians in February of 1696 near Port Famine. Now called Puerto del Hambre, this was one of the settlements along the Strait of Magellan established by the Spanish. In spite of many reports of giants living in the area, Froger found nothing unusual about these people.Admiral de Gennes had two purposes in this voyage supported by Louis XIV -- to create trouble for Spain and to take booty. Six ships sailed ostensibly to establish a colony at the Strait of Magellan. They stopped on the African coast where they raided a fort, taking slaves and goods that were then sold by one of the ships in the Antilles. The other ships continued on to Rio de Janeiro and down the South American coast to the Strait of Magellan, but they had to turn back due to a shortage of food. They returned to La Rochelle in April 1697. Cf. 09519-4 & 03701-4.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Patagonia (Argentina and Chile)

Image_title: Capivard ou cochon d'Eau au Pied d'un Bananier

Source_Title: Relation d'un voyage fait en 1695. 1696. & 1697
Source_publisher: dans l'Isle du Palais, sur le Quay de l'Horloge, à la Sphere Royale et chez Michel Brunet, dans la grande salle du Palais, au Mercure galant

Image_title: The Straight of Magellan
Image_publisher: M. Gillyflower ... W. Freeman ... M. Wotton ...
Description: Map of the southern tip of South America with Tierra del Fuego. Cartographic elements include names of topographical features, soundings, scale, and compass rose.
Source_Title: [Relation d'un voyage fait en 1695, 1696, & 1697. English] A relation of a voyage made in the years 1695, 1696, 1697. on the coasts of Africa, streights of Magellan, Brasil, Cayenna, and the Antilles, by a squadron of French men of war, under the command of M. de Gennes.
Source_publisher: Printed for M. Gillyflower in Westminster Hall; W. Freeman, M. Wotton in Fleet-Street; J. Walthoe in the Temple; and R. Parker in Cornhill.
notes: The ships reached Patagonia or Tierra del Fuego in late winter of 1696.Admiral de Gennes had two purposes in this voyage supported by Louis XIV -- to create trouble for Spain and to take booty. Six ships sailed ostensibly to establish a colony at the Strait of Magellan. They stopped on the African coast where they raided a fort, taking slaves and goods that were then sold by one of the ships in the Antilles. The other ships continued on to Rio de Janeiro and down the South American coast to the Strait of Magellan, but they had to turn back due to a shortage of food. They returned to La Rochelle in April 1697.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The French Bay with the Mouth of the River Gennes in the Straight of Magellan
Image_publisher: M. Gillyflower ... W. Freeman ... M. Wotton ...
Description: Map of part of the Strait of Magellan at French Bay showing the entrance to the Gennes River.
Source_Title: [Relation d'un voyage fait en 1695, 1696, & 1697. English] A relation of a voyage made in the years 1695, 1696, 1697. on the coasts of Africa, streights of Magellan, Brasil, Cayenna, and the Antilles, by a squadron of French men of war, under the command of M. de Gennes.
Source_publisher: Printed for M. Gillyflower in Westminster Hall; W. Freeman, M. Wotton in Fleet-Street; J. Walthoe in the Temple; and R. Parker in Cornhill.
notes: The river was named after the leader of the expedition, Count Julien de Gennes, 1652-1704. It is near Punta Arenas, Chile and is south of Port Famine. The expedition reached this area in March of 1696. No river by that name is known today.Admiral de Gennes had two purposes in this voyage supported by Louis XIV -- to create trouble for Spain and to take booty. Six ships sailed ostensibly to establish a colony at the Strait of Magellan. They stopped on the African coast where they raided a fort, taking slaves and goods that were then sold by one of the ships in the Antilles. The other ships continued on to Rio de Janeiro and down the South American coast to the Strait of Magellan, but they had to turn back due to a shortage of food. They returned to La Rochelle in April 1697.
