Image_title: [Mercury processing and llamas]
Description: Two llamas stand before works for processing mercury. Included are a grinding wheel, drying floor, washing basins, and drying ovens.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. Dutch] Reis-Beschryving door de Zuid-Zee langs de Kusten van Chili, Peru en Brazil
Source_publisher: By R. en G. Wetstein
notes: In 1563, mercury was discovered in Huancavelica in Peru and was used as an amalgamate for silver mining there.This image derived from Frézier, Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily et du Perou, Paris, 1716.

Image_title: Aardbezie uit Chile afgetekent volgens hare naturelyke grootheit.
Description: Strawberry plant showing fruit and leaves. Also includes an illustration of the mountain flax or Nancolahui.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. Dutch] Reis-Beschryving door de Zuid-Zee langs de Kusten van Chili, Peru en Brazil
Source_publisher: By R. en G. Wetstein
notes: Frézier was a French royal military engineer under contract to the Spanish government. He introduced one of the ancestors of the modern strawberry to France, where it was known as the "fraise du Chili."This image derived from Frézier, Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily et du Perou, Paris, 1716.

Image_title: [Fish and sea animals]
Description: Various fish, sea horse, and a crustacean or lobster. Includes a barracuda [?], a swordfish seen from the bottom and from the side, a seahorse, a pejegallo or elephant fish.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. Dutch] Reis-Beschryving door de Zuid-Zee langs de Kusten van Chili, Peru en Brazil
Source_publisher: By R. en G. Wetstein
notes: Elephantfish or Callorhinchus callorynchus.This image derived from Frézier, Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily et du Perou, Paris, 1716.

Image_title: [Santolina and cytifus plants]
Description: Branches, leaves, and flowers of two plants. Includes details of flowers.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. Dutch] Reis-Beschryving door de Zuid-Zee langs de Kusten van Chili, Peru en Brazil
Source_publisher: By R. en G. Wetstein
notes: This plant is identified as called by the Indians, "culen" (Otholobium glandulosum). Text states that the cytisus (alvaquilla or, in Indian, culen) plant was used to cure sores, smells like sweet basil, and has white shading to violet flowers (Otholobium glandulosum). The santolina (Quinchamalium chilense) is native to Chile.This image derived from Frézier, Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily et du Perou, Paris, 1716.

Image_title: Plan van de Stadt Santiago Hoofdstadt van Chili, ...
Description: Plan of the city of Santiago, Chile, showing locations of churches, religious orders, and municipal places and structures. Items are numbered and lettered for identification in a key within the image. Includes inset of a view of the mountain of Saint Lucie. Also includes compass rose and scale. Decorative cartouche includes allegorical figure of justice with scales and sword and man with long pipe and head of cattle.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. Dutch] Reis-Beschryving door de Zuid-Zee langs de Kusten van Chili, Peru en Brazil
Source_publisher: By R. en G. Wetstein
notes: This image derived from Frézier, Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily et du Perou, Paris, 1716.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Tialoc, Idolo della Pioggia
Description: Tlaloc is shown holding an obsidian knife, shield, and wearing a feather headdress.
Source_Title: Giro del mondo
Source_publisher: Presso Sebastiano Coletti
notes: Tlaloc, the Aztec god of rain, presided over the third era of the Mexica. His attributes include rimmed eyes, a crown of heron feathers, and a "netted" cloud dress.
References: Cañizares-Esguerra, J. How to write the history of the New World, fig. 5.1; http://titan.glo.be/~kg000407/tlalocvn.htm (May 2004)

Image_title: [Robinson Crusoe]
Description: Robinson Crusoe wearing fur clothes and holding two guns or muskets. Includes hat, sword, palisade, and ship.
Source_Title: [Robinson Crusoe. Part I] The life and strange surprizing adventures of Robinson Crusoe ...
Source_publisher: Printed for W. Taylor at the Ship in Pater-Noster-Row
notes: The story of Robinson Crusoe was based on the story of Alexander Selkirk who went to sea in 1704 with William Dampier and was put ashore on Juan Fernandez Island off of the coast of Chile where he survived until he was rescued in 1709 by Woodes Rogers.

Image_title: Rivier d'or avec des esclaves.
Description: Slaves mine for gold in a river. Includes men panning for gold, spreading gold ore out on shore to dry, and pouring it into bottles.
Source_Title: Voyage de Marseille a Lima, et dans les autres lieux des Indes occidentales
Source_publisher: Chez Jean-Baptiste Coignard, Imprimeur & Libraire ordinaire du Roy, ruë S. Jacques
notes: Text describes a river of gold found in Panama. Preface is signed: Durrett.

Image_title: Voyage de Thomas Gage Tome. I.
Description: A monk holding a book stands before native Americans who offer him riches in the form of coins, rolls of tobacco, food, and jewels. Includes soldiers, parasol, bow, feathered headdresses, and spears.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell. The engraver was probably Pierre Aveline, 1656-1722.

Image_title: Surpris des Indiens de la Guardeloupe.
Description: Europeans run on a beach while being attacked by native Americans in the woods. Ships in the harbor fire cannons on shore. Includes scene of warfare.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: Text describes the attempt by zealous Jesuits in Gage's party to forcibly abduct a mulatto, his wife, and children from Guadeloupe to convert them to Christianity. The Jesuit plan was discovered by the natives who attacked men wearing black coats (whom they took to be Jesuits). Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.

Image_title: Mexique
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing the various islands, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city. Also includes men on horseback, domestic animals, boats, churches, dwellings, wicker dams, and main square.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: The city is shown as the artist imagined Tenochtitlán before Europeans arrived, but with European-type houses and churches and men on horseback or herding sheep. The image is derived from Carol Allard, Orbis habitabilis oppida et vestitas, Amsterdam 1681, who in turn derived his view from the Hernán Cortés map-view of Tenochtitlán. Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.
References: Cf. Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.24, p. 92-93
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Aztec temple]
Description: Aztec sacrifice scene in temple. Priests cuts out a victim's heart to give to an idol at the top of a pyramid while other priests attend. A body is tossed down the stairs. Before the sacrificial place dancers celebrate. A wall covered with serpents or snakes surrounds the pyramid. Native Americans with feathered headdresses and garments stand outside the temple compound. Includes bows, statues, and domed structures on top of pyramid. In the foreground is a structure with a staircase, perhaps a skull rack.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: The major temple at Tenochtitlán or Mexico City was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc (the god of rain), the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli (the god of the sun and war). A coatepantli or wall with serpents carved on it often surrounded Aztec temples. The tzompantli held the skulls of sacrificial victims. Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.

Image_title: [Interior of an Aztec temple]
Description: Native Americans worship before an idol in the interior of a temple. The idol, with wings and wearing a feather headdress, has a face on his stomach and goat legs with cloven hooves. It stands on an altar decorated with feathers. In one hand, he holds a flaming torch, in the other, a shield with feathers on it and a branch. Also includes men worshipping before the idol and above the idol, representations of Aztec gods.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: The idol is identified in the text as Tlumacaztli (perhaps Huitzilopochtli?). Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell. Aveline was one of a large family of 17th- and 18th-century printmakers.

Image_title: Attaque du Palais
Description: Native Americans and European soldiers attack a building. Includes swords, guns or muskets, rocks, scene of warfare or riot.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: The text describes the conflict between Diego Carrillo, marqués de Gélvez, viceroy of New Spain, and Juan Pérez de la Cerna, archbishop of New Spain, which escalated into riots causing the burning of the viceroy's palace and the prison adjoining in 1624. Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.

Image_title: Voyage de Thomas Gage. Tome. II.
Description: European soldiers are greeted by native Americans. Includes ship, boat, and swords.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.

Image_title: [Celebration scene]
Description: Native Americans dance and celebrate a festival. Includes a man being pulled across a river in a basket, bows, ship, men walking on a tightrope, hammock, and feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: Text describes the celebrations of the Indians of Guatemala. The chief dance is called toncontin and the main instruments are drums or tepanahuaztli. Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of Central America--Social life and customs

Image_title: Sauterelles.
Description: Men walk through a field devasted by locusts or grasshoppers. In the foreground, a field lies in waste and trees are bare of leaves. Includes a pack mule.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: Text describes a plague of locusts or grasshoppers which covered the road causing traveling mules to startle and which destroyed crops of indigo and sugar cane. The magistrate ordered the native Americans to go out into the fields and make noise to frighten the insects away. Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.

Image_title: L'Enterrement du Roy de la Méxique.
Description: Native Americans carry a casket of a Mexican king on a litter through a town or settlement at night. Men carry torches and blow musical instruments such as drums, horns, or trumpets. Includes feathered headdresses, dwellings, and flags.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of Mexico--Funeral customs and rites

Image_title: Foire de Porto Bello
Description: Market day or fair in Portobello, Panama. Includes native Americans unloading goods from boats, men weighting and selling goods, dwellings, casks, chest, market stalls, settlement, fleet of ships being saluted from fortifications, carts, and donkeys.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: Author describes how the prices of goods and number of people increase as soon as the Spanish fleet arrived in Portobello. Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.

Image_title: Mines de Potosi
Description: Miners underground with pick axes, laterns, ladders, and shovels.
Source_Title: Voyage de Marseille a Lima, et dans les autres lieux des Indes occidentales
Source_publisher: Chez Jean-Baptiste Coignard, Imprimeur & Libraire ordinaire du Roy, ruë S. Jacques
notes: The mines at Potosí were discovered by Diego Hualca in 1544. The silver mines there were among the richest in the world. Preface is signed: Durrett.

Image_title: Carthagene
Description: View of Cartagena, present-day Colombia. Includes ships, fortifications, churches, and chain across harbor mouth.
Source_Title: [New survey of the West Indies. French] Nouvelle relation, contenant les Voyages de Thomas Gage dans la Nouvelle Espagne ...
Source_publisher: Chez Paul Marret, dans le Beurs-straat, proche le Dam à la Renommée
notes: Thomas Gage, an English Dominican friar, returned to England after several decades in Spanish America, became a Protestant and a principal advisor to Oliver Cromwell.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plan de Lima
Description: Plan of the city of Lima.
Source_Title: Voyage de Marseille a Lima, et dans les autres lieux des Indes occidentales
Source_publisher: Chez Jean-Baptiste Coignard, Imprimeur & Libraire ordinaire du Roy, ruë S. Jacques
notes: Preface is signed: Durrett.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Patagonian giant]
Description: Native American Patagonian giant. Cultural artifacts include basket and staff.
Source_Title: Shijûni-koku Jinbutsu zusetsu
Source_publisher: Ibaragi Tazaemon
notes: This image is in a book, one of the first Japanese pictorial ethnographies, which has a description of people from each of the 42 barbarian countries outside of Japan. Published in two editions in 1720, this one-volume Kyoto edition is extremely scarce.
References: Boxer, C.R. Jan Compagnie in Japan, 1600-1850, p.17-18

Image_title: Mine
Description: View of a mine. Men descend a ladder made of a tree trunk to reach the ore. Items in the image are numbered for identification in adjacent text.
Source_Title: Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales, contenant ce qu'il y a vû de plus remarquable pendant son séjour depuis 1666 ...
Source_publisher: Chez André Cailleau, Place de Sorbonne, au coin de la ruë des Maçons, à Saint-André
notes: Text describes the workers as native Americans who use pickaxes to remove ore and who carry the ore up in sacks on their backs. The ore is either gold from Chile or silver from Peru. No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author has been questioned. This book was later reprinted under titles: Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Mériodionale, Amsterdam, 1738, and Relations des voyages de François Coreal, Brussels, 1736.

Image_title: [Presidio de N.S. de Loreto en la Bahia del Espiritu Santo de la Provincia de Texas, Nuevo Reyno de Philipinas]
Description: Plan of a presidio or fortification in Texas. Includes the mission of Spiritu Santo on the San Gabriel River. Decorative elements include ship, trees, bull, turkey, and deer or stag.
Source_Title: Derrotero de la expedicion en la provincia de los Texas, nuevo reyno de Philipinas
Source_publisher: Juan Francisco de Ortega Bonilla
notes: Image title taken from verso of plan. The marquis de San Miguel de Aguayo, don Jospeh de Azlor y Virto de Vera, was appointed governor of the provinces of Coahuila and Texas in 1719. When he left Texas, the province was indelibly Spanish, had ten missions, four presidios, and over 300 Spaniards. He had effectively eradicated French hopes to claims in Texas. Juan Antonio de la Peña, a Franciscan friar and chaplain, was the chronicler of the Aguayo expedition.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1928, p. 23-24; Wagner, H.R. Spanish Southwest, 86
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Presidio de N.S. del Pilar de los Adays, en la Fro[n]tera de los Texas ...]
Description: Plan of a presidio or fortification in Texas. Includes named bastions with cannons situated on three of the fort's six corners and scale. Includes an arroyo or creek, trees, unknown animal, and deer or stags.
Source_Title: Derrotero de la expedicion en la provincia de los Texas, nuevo reyno de Philipinas
Source_publisher: Juan Francisco de Ortega Bonilla
notes: Image title taken from verso of plan.The marquis de San Miguel de Aguayo, don Jospeh de Azlor y Virto de Vera, was appointed governor of the provinces of Coahuila and Texas in 1719. When he left Texas, the province was indelibly Spanish, had ten missions, four presidios, and over 300 Spaniards. He had effectively eradicated French hopes to claims in Texas. Juan Antonio de la Peña, a Franciscan friar and chaplain, was the chronicler of the Aguayo expedition.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1928, p. 23-24; Wagner, H.R. Spanish Southwest, 86
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Plan del presidio de San Antonio de Bejar, de la Provincia de Texas ...]
Description: Plan of a presidio or fortification in Texas. Includes named bastions with cannons situated on four of the fort's four corners and scale. Includes two rivers (the Rio San Pedro and the Rio de San Antonio), trees, grape vines, turkey or bird, buzzard or vulture [?] in tree, fox, and deer or stags. Also includes bridges.
Source_Title: Derrotero de la expedicion en la provincia de los Texas, nuevo reyno de Philipinas
Source_publisher: Juan Francisco de Ortega Bonilla
notes: Image title taken from verso of plan.The presidio of San Antonio de Bexar, present-day San Antonio, was at the center of Spanish defense of western Texas and was founded in 1718. The marquis de San Miguel de Aguayo, don Jospeh de Azlor y Virto de Vera, was appointed governor of the provinces of Coahuila and Texas in 1719. When he left Texas, the province was indelibly Spanish, had ten missions, four presidios, and over 300 Spaniards. He had effectively eradicated French hopes to claims in Texas. Juan Antonio de la Peña, a Franciscan friar and chaplain, was the chronicler of the Aguayo expedition.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1928, p. 23-24; Wagner, H.R. Spanish Southwest, 86
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Plan del Presidio de N.S. de los Dolores, junto à la Mission de nuestra Señora de la Concepcion, que està en el centro del Pays de los Texas ...]
Description: Plan of a presidio or fortification in Texas. Includes named bastions situated on two of the fort's four corners, compass rose, and scale. Includes an arroyo or creek, trees, birds, and deer or stags.
Source_Title: Derrotero de la expedicion en la provincia de los Texas, nuevo reyno de Philipinas
Source_publisher: Juan Francisco de Ortega Bonilla
notes: Image title taken from verso of plan.The marquis de San Miguel de Aguayo, don Jospeh de Azlor y Virto de Vera, was appointed governor of the provinces of Coahuila and Texas in 1719. When he left Texas, the province was indelibly Spanish, had ten missions, four presidios, and over 300 Spaniards. He had effectively eradicated French hopes to claims in Texas. Juan Antonio de la Peña, a Franciscan friar and chaplain, was the chronicler of the Aguayo expedition.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1928, p. 23-24; Wagner, H.R. Spanish Southwest, 86
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: La ville de Mexique
Description: Bird's-eye view of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán, showing the various islands, outlying villages, and causeways or bridges which linked the city to the mainland. Also includes men on horseback, domestic animals, boats, dwellings, wicker dams, fortifcations, and main square.
Source_Title: Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales, contenant ce qu'il y a vû de plus remarquable pendant son séjour depuis 1666 ...
Source_publisher: Chez André Cailleau, Place de Sorbonne, au coin de la ruë des Maçons, à Saint-André
notes: No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author has been questioned. This book was later reprinted under titles: Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Mériodionale, Amsterdam, 1738, and Relations des voyages de François Coreal, Brussels, 1736.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plan de la ville du Callao.
Description: Plan of Callao, Peru, including a profile view of the settlement. Also includes compass rose, churches, dwellings, and military matériel such as cannon, drums, trumpets, shields, and flags.
Source_Title: Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales, contenant ce qu'il y a vû de plus remarquable pendant son séjour depuis 1666 ...
Source_publisher: Chez André Cailleau, Place de Sorbonne, au coin de la ruë des Maçons, à Saint-André
notes: No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author has been questioned. This book was later reprinted under titles: Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Mériodionale, Amsterdam, 1738, and Relations des voyages de François Coreal, Brussels, 1736.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [La Planche XV. [sic] pag. 344. Initiation finale d'un Devin Caraïbe.]
Description: Initiation of a Carib religious leader. A native American dwelling with three hammocks is surmounted by an idol or devil with wings. Built environment includes dwellings.
Source_Title: Moeurs des sauvages ameriquains, comparées aux moeurs des premiers temps ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez Saugrain l'aîné, Quay des Augustins ... Charles Estienne Hochereau, à l'entrée du Quay des Augustins
notes: Text describes how hammocks are provided for the initiate, his teacher, and the spirit. After making an offering at an altar, the spirit appears with a great noise in the middle of the night causing the other villagers to come out of their dwellings. Image title taken from "Explication des planches et figures," in preface.

Image_title: [La Planche XIV. est distribuée en deux sujets. page. 302. Le premier représente les épreuves d'un Capitaine chez les Caraïbes, & le second celles d'un Chef ou Capitaine, expliquées à la pag. 297. & suiv.]
Description: Initiation rites of native American Caribs. At top, a man is flogged with whips, has a drink poured on him through a sieve, while others make more whips. At bottom, the initiate is attacked by men with bows and arrows. Cultural artifacts include dwellings and a hammock.
Source_Title: Moeurs des sauvages ameriquains, comparées aux moeurs des premiers temps ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez Saugrain l'aîné, Quay des Augustins ... Charles Estienne Hochereau, à l'entrée du Quay des Augustins
notes: Image title taken from "Explication des planches et figures," in preface.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Social life and customs

Image_title: [Cortés greets native American noble in Mexico]
Image_publisher: T. Woodward ... J. Hooker ... J. Peele
Description: Hernán Cortés and a native American noble greet each other in a Mexican city. Cortés' men ride horses while the native American is carried in a chair. Inhabitants of the city observe the scene from every window and balcony.
Source_Title: [Historia de la conquista de Mexico. English] ... Done into English ... By Thomas Townsend Esq;
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Woodward at the Half-Moon, and J. Hooker at the Flower-de-Luce, both against St. Dunstan's Church, in Fleet-Street; and J. Peele at Locke's-Head in Pater-Noster-Row.
notes: Artist is probably Jacobus Schijnvoet, fl. 1704-1733.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of Mexico--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: [Native Americans attack ships in harbor]
Description: Native Americans attack European ships from canoes. Native American women jump on and from the ship. Includes circular dwellings built on poles in a lake, anchor, pows, and arrows.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: Text relates Alonso de Ojeda's arrival in Venezuela where the natives lived in houses built on the lake. When the natives saw the Spanish coming they paddled in canoes with young women to offer them to the visitors. At a signal from older women, the young women jumped from the canoes and the men began shooting arrows at the Spanish.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: The Manner of Hunting on ye Continent of America
Description: Native American men hunt wild pigs pr peccaries. Includes nets and spears.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: Text describes men hunting swine in Panama by driving them into large nets and spearing them.

Image_title: Vitzilipuztli, the Principal Idol of the Mexicans.
Description: Religious rites of native Americans. Priests flagellate themselves with rope, pierce their feet with nails, and offer incense to an idol who holds arrows in one hand and a religious object or shield with five feathers on it in the other. Also includes skulls and bones.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: Priests (tlamacazqui or keepers of the gods) of Mexico would flagellate themselves, pierce their feet with thorns, or beat each other with stones to atone for the sins of the common people. They would play musical instruments such as horns, use incense, and wash their idol in blood. Here the god referred to is Huitzilopochtli whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left" and who was the Aztec god of the sun and war. A turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. This work is derived from Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, plate 7.

Image_title: The Great Charnel House in ye City of Mexico
Description: Aztec or Mexican cemetery with human skulls placed in tiers in a circular wall and piled in two columns or towers.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: Text describes the cemetery as a sort of theater with towers and walls made out of skulls and lime. Aztec temples used tzompantli or skull racks to hold the skulls of sacrificial victims.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of Mexico--Social life and customs

Image_title: Synopsi De la Historia General de la Sta. Cathedral Iglesia Metropolitana de Lima Primada del Reyno del Peru
Image_publisher: Imprenta de la Calle de Palacio
Description: Vignettes of the archbishops of Peru surround title and image of Francisco Pizarro presenting a brick to King Charles V. Behind him stand native Americans representing Peruvians [?]. Built environment includes dwellings.
Source_creator: Cueva Ponce de Léon, Alonso de la, 1684-1754
Source_Title: Carta suplicatoria alos illustrissimos y r. senornes arçobispoos, y obispos, de los Reynos del Perù, Tierra-firme y Chile
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de la Calle de Palacio
notes: The brick may symbolize the building of the cathedral of Lima. The first stone of the cathedral of Lima was laid by Francisco Pizarro in January 1535.

Image_title: The manner of propagating, gathering & curing ye Grana or Cochineel, done by an Indian in the Bishoprick of Guaxaca in the Kingdom of Mexico in America
Image_publisher: Printed by B.M. for the author
Description: Stages in the commercial production of cochineal dye. Prickly pears (opuntia) host plant of the cochineal (a scale insect) are grown in a field. Human activity includes farming, cooking tortillas, production of dye. Social interactions consist of a cacique, "gentleman Indian descendant of the family of Montezuma," instructing a native American worker. Items in the image are lettered for identification in a key below.
Source_Title: A voyage to the islands Madera, Barbados, Nieves. S. Christophers and Jamaica: with the natural history of the herbs and trees, four-footed beasts, fishes, birds, insects, reptiles, &c. of the last of those islands
Source_publisher: Printed by B.M. for the author
notes: The engraver is probably Michiel van der Gucht, 1660-1725.
References_exhibitions: Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Item 43

Image_title: [left] Asteroides Conysae folio flore luteo. [right] Anisillo, vulgò Mouchu.
Description: [left] The Asteroides conysae folio plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers. [right] Anisillo vulgò plant with its leaf and flower. Includes details of flowers.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Feuillée states that the Asteroides conysae (perhaps a member of the genus Conyza) was found on the coast of Peru. The Anisillo plant may be a member of the genus Tagetes that includes marigolds and is native to Mexico and South America. Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725

Image_title: [left] Bermudiana bulbosa, flore reflexo caeruleo, vulgò Illum. [right] Barba Jovis triphilla, flore ex albo et caeruleo vario, vulgò Culen.
Description: [left] The Bermudiana bulbosa plant with its bulb, leaves, and flowers. [right] The Barba jovis triphilla plant with its leaves and flowers.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Feuillée states that the Bermudiana bulbosa plant was found in Chile and that its bulb was eaten in soups. Barba jovis triphilla or culen is probably Otholobium glandulosum, native to Peru, Chile, and Bolivia. It is a member of the bean family. Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725

Image_title: [left] Bermudiana Narcisso Leucoii flore, vulgò Thekel-Thekel. [right] Bidens trifolia Americana Leucanthemi flore Inst R. herb.
Description: [left] Bermudiana Narcisso leucoii plant with its roots, leaves, flowers, and seed. [right] Bidens trifolia Americana leucanthemi plant with its roots, leaves, flowers, and seed heads.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Both of these specimens were gathered in Chile. Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725

Image_title: [left] Chala Origani folio [right] Blitum Spica rubra, vulgô Taios
Description: [left] Chala origani folio plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers. [right] Blitum spica rubra plant with its roots, leaves, and grains.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Blitum spica rubra is probably Amaranthus spinosus, a plant native to tropical America that is eaten like spinach. Feuillée states that it came from the gardens of Peru. It has not been possible to identify Chala origani folio, but Feuillée collected the specimen in Chile. Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725

Image_title: [left] Boigue Cinnamomifera, Oliva fructu [right] Boldu arbor Olivifera.
Description: [left] Boigue cinnamomifera, oliva fructu plant with its roots, leaves, and flowers. [right] Boldu arbor olivifera with its roots, leaves, and flowers.
Source_Title: [Journal des observations physiques, mathématiques et botaniques. Selections] Histoire des plantes medecinales qui sont le plus en usage aux royaumes de l'Amerique meridionale, du Perou & du Chily, composée sur les lieux par ordre du Roy, dans les années 1709. 1710. & 1711.
Source_publisher: rue S. Jacques, chez Pierre Giffart
notes: Slightly later eighteeenth-century botanists describe Boigue cinnamomifera, oliva fructu as the same as Winter's bark, Drimys winteri. It grows in Chile and Argentina and was used in the treatment of scurvy. Boldu arbor olivifera may be Drimys andina, a small tree native to Chile. Feuillée, a member of the order of Minims, worked with Jacques Cassini as a hydrographer and later made trips using his knowledge of currents, astronomy, and botany to the Caribbean, Peru, and Chile. Detached copy from v. 2 and [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques, Paris, 1714-1725. Imprint for this part taken from the title page of vol. [3] of the author's Journal des observations physiques, mathematiques et botaniques. Paris, 1725
References: Lamarck, J.B.P.A. De Monet De & Poiret, J.L.M. Encyclopédie méthodique botanique, tome 2 (Paris, 1786) p. 331; http://www.chileflora.com/Florachilena/FloraEnglish/HighResPages/EH0183.htm (Oct. 2008)

Image_title: The Great Temple of Mexico
Description: Bird's-eye view of the main temple [the Templo mayor] of Tenochtitlán or present-day Mexico City. The temple is encircled by a wall with serpents or snakes carved on it, and there are two sanctuaries on the top before which two priests stand. Includes view of the settlement with dwellings and fortifications, as well as a view of the lake beyond it.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: The great temple at Tenochtitlan was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc, the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli. Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. Tlaloc, the god of rain and agriculture, was of pre-Aztec, or Toltec, origin. A coatepantli or wall made of sculpted serpents often surrounds Aztec temples. The tzompantli would hold the skulls of sacrificial victims. This image is similar to the one printed in Antonio de Solís, Histoire de la conquête du Mexique, Paris, 1691.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: An Indian of ye Island of Chiloe in pursuit of a Bull
Image_publisher: J. Senex, W. and J. Innys, J. Osborn and T. Longman
Description: Native American of Chiloe off of the coast of Chile holding a rope or lariat chasing a bull. Includes checkered leggings, hat, and poncho.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world by the way of the great South Sea ...
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Senex, ... W. and J. Innys, ... and J. Osborn and T. Longman ...
notes: Text describes the poncho of the Chiloean, the hat (called a montera), and leggings (called poulaines) or a sort of knit buskin. The engraver may be John Pine (1690-1756), chief engraver of seals and compiler of an eighteenth-century survey of London. Between 1718 and 1722, George Shelvocke completed the last of the English buccaneer circumnavigations. His account has achieved a place in literary history for its story of the unlucky albatross, immortalized by Samuel Taylor Coleridge in his Rime of the Ancient Mariner.

Image_title: An Indian of ye Southermost parts of California as Returning from Fishing & another on his Barklog
Image_publisher: J. Senex, W. and J. Innys, J. Osborn and T. Longman
Description: Native American of southern California holding a fish on his shoulder and a barbed harpoon with rope in his hand. In the background another native kneels on a raft made of logs. Each man wears a band around his head with two tufts of hawk's feathers in it.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world by the way of the great South Sea ...
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Senex, ... W. and J. Innys, ... and J. Osborn and T. Longman ...
notes: The engraver may be John Pine (1690-1756), chief engraver of seals and compiler of an eighteenth-century survey of London. Between 1718 and 1722, George Shelvocke completed the last of the English buccaneer circumnavigations. His account has achieved a place in literary history for its story of the unlucky albatross, immortalized by Smauel Taylor Coleridge in his Rime of the Ancient Mariner.

Image_title: Two Californian Women, the one in a Birds; Skin the other in that of a Deer.
Image_publisher: J. Senex, W. and J. Innys, J. Osborn and T. Longman
Description: Native American women of California, one wears a bird skin cape and the other a deer cape. Includes bow and arrows.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world by the way of the great South Sea ...
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Senex, ... W. and J. Innys, ... and J. Osborn and T. Longman ...
notes: The engraver may be John Pine (1690-1756), chief engraver of seals and compiler of an eighteenth-century survey of London. Between 1718 and 1722, George Shelvocke completed the last of the English buccaneer circumnavigations. His account has achieved a place in literary history for its story of the unlucky albatross, immortalized by Smauel Taylor Coleridge in his Rime of the Ancient Mariner.

Image_title: 1 The Mexicans on their March to seek a Place to settle. 2. the Silver water. 3. The Tuna Tree with the Eagle ...
Description: Founding of Tenochtitlán or Mexico City. An eagle devours a bird while perched on a tree beside a river. Native Mexicans bow down before the eagle. Other men pole floating gardens on a raft down the river. The raft contains maize, squash, birds, and flowers. Others carry an idol to the riverbank and build a dwelling.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. III
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: Text describes the founding of Tenochtitlán. The Aztecs or Mexica, guided by the prophecies of Huitzilopochtli (the god of the sun and war), ended their migration by building Tenochtitlán, on an island in a lake where an eagle held a snake perched on a flowering nopal cactus. The Aztecs created artificial islands called chinampas which were made by piling earth from the bottom of Lake Texcoco onto rafts made of weeds. After a while, the roots of the plants and trees grew down to the lake bottom, creating new farmland. This image was derived from Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, 3rd part, plate 12.

Image_title: Several sorts of Mexican Dances
Description: Method of dancing among native Mexicans. Men dance while standing on each other's shoulders and while walking on a rope. Includes musical instruments such as drums, bows, arrows, feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. III
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: Text describes Aztec dances called mitotes danced by native rope dancers. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9, 3rd part, plate 11, which describes the dances of the Mexicans.

Image_title: The Sheep of Peru, The manner of their Carrying Burthens, & of appeasing them, when they grow sullen
Description: Method by which ore was transported by llamas. Native Americans herd llamas carrying packs. In the background is an encampment and a man shooting at a llama on a hill.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. IV
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: The llama was used for the transport of silver ore in Peru. When overburdened the animals would sit down, and nothing would make the animal get up again. If they ran away, they had to be shot to recover the ore they were carrying. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, plate 4.

Image_title: The Manner of Interring the Grandees of Peru
Description: Native Americans bury a chief or king with food, golden vessels, and jewelry. Includes feathered garments and settlement with fortifications.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. V
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: Text describes the funerals of Inca kings as being ceremonies of great splendor. The native Americans would decorate the body with gold and silver and bury it with many fine ornaments. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 6, plate 26.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Funeral customs and rites

Image_title: The posture of a Sea Lion wn. Suddenly rouz'd or disturb'd a Lioness asleep by him & a Seal, in a moveing posture
Image_publisher: J. Senex, W. and J. Innys, J. Osborn and T. Longman
Description: A group of sea lions and seals on shore with their mates and young.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world by the way of the great South Sea ...
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Senex, ... W. and J. Innys, ... and J. Osborn and T. Longman ...
notes: These animals were observed around the Juan Fernández Islands off the coast of Chile. A species of fur seal native to the area is now endangered; even Shelvocke noted how few remained after his men had slaughtered many during their calving season.The engraver may be John Pine (1690-1756), chief engraver of seals and compiler of an eighteenth-century survey of London.Between 1718 and 1722, George Shelvocke completed the last of the English buccaneer circumnavigations. His account has achieved a place in literary history for its story of the unlucky albatross, immortalized by Samuel Taylor Coleridge in his Rime of the Ancient Mariner.

Image_title: Mission Bey den Moschen durch die Iesuiter von Peru Gestifft.
Image_publisher: Heirs of Phillip, Martin & Johann Veith
Description: Map of the Jesuit Moxo [Mojo] missions in Peru between the Beni and Mamoré rivers. Cartographic elements include degrees of latitude and longitude, compass rose, some topographical details, and location of settlements, missions, and forts.
Source_Title: Allerhand so lehr- als geist-reiche Brief Schrifften und Reis Beschreibungen, welche von denen Missionariis der Gesellschafft Jesu aus beyden Indien un andern ... Ländern ... Erster Bund
Source_publisher: In Verlag Philipp, Martin, und Joh. Veith seel. Erben Buchhändlern
notes: This map accompanies Cyprian Baraza's account of his mission among the Moxo Indians. Baraza lived among the Moxo for 27 years before he was martyred in 1702 by the Baures, a tribe living to the east of the Moxos. For an illustration of Cyprian Baraza's martyrdom, cf. 99-129.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The Thirteen Yngas or Sovereigns that Reign'd Successively in Peru before the Arrival of the Spaniards
Description: Thirteen portrait medallions of native Americans or Peruvian Inca rulers--Aiarmango Capac first King of Cuzco, Cinchiaroca second Ynga, Lloquiyupangui third Ynga, Maytacapac fourth Ynga, Capacyupangui fifth Ynga, Yngaroca Sixth Ynga, Yaguarguacac yupangui Seventh Ynga, Viracocha Eighth Ynga, Vrco Ninth Ynga, Pachaiuti yupangui Tenth Ynga, Topaynga yupangui Eleventh Ynga, Guaynacapac Twelfth Ynga, Guascar Thirteenth Ynga. Cultural artifacts include headdresses, helmets, scepters, and ceremonial garments.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. IV
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row
notes: The portraits are of the Inca rulers of Peru. In order of reign they are Manco Capac, Sinchi Roco, Lloque Yupanqui, Maita Capac, Capac Yupanqui, Capac Yupanqui, Inca Roco, Yahuar Huacac, Inca Viracocha, Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui, Topa Inca Yupanqui, Huayna Capac, Huascar, and Atahualpa. These images are derived from the title page of Antonio Herrera y Tordesillas, Historia general de los hechos de los Castellano en las Islas y tierra firme del mar oceano ... Decada quinta, Madrid, 1615.

Image_title: The five most famous men in Peru and Chile
Description: Portrait medallions of Francisco Pizarro, Diego de Almagro, Pedro de Alvarado, Pedro de la Gasca, and Pedro de Valdivia.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos. English] The general history of the vast continent and islands of America, commonly call'd the West-Indies ... Vol. V
Source_publisher: Printed for Jer. Batley at the Dove in Pater-noster-row

Image_title: Das Silber Bergwerck Potosi in Peru.
Description: Mining in Peru. Includes miners, one holding a torch, climbing a double ladder from a mine in a mountain. The miners wear packs on their backs to carry the ore.
Source_Title: Magnalia Dei in locis subterraneis oder Unterirdische Schatz-Cammer aller Königreiche und Länder ...
notes: This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, part 9 [part 3], plate 3, where the text describes the mines at Potosí, in present-day Bolivia, the richest silver mines in the Americas. It describes how the natives worked about a hundred and fifty fathoms below the ground and carried the ore out by a series of double-sided ladders made from ox-hide and poles. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: El Vi-reÿ Blasco Nunuez Vela.
Description: Portrait of Blasco Nunez Vela holding a baton and wearing armor blazoned with the cross of the Order of Santiago. The decorative border includes anchors, musical instruments such as trumpets and drums, navigational instruments such as compasses and globes, flags, fish, angels holding treasure such as gold and pearls, the royal Spanish coat of arms, shields, pikes, and swords.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Blasco Núñez Vela replaced Vaca de Castro as the viceroy of Peru in 1544 and served briefly and violently. His rule was so harsh, and the feeling among the people of Lima over his stabbing of their procurator was so resentful, he decided to transfer his offices to Trujillo, three hundred miles to the north. Gonzalo Pizarro, the last of the four Pizarro brothers, led a revolt against the governor, stormed his palace, and took him prisoner in 1546.

Image_title: Prision del Viréy Blasco Nuñez Vela
Description: Blasco Nunez Vela is captured by Spanish soldiers. Includes scene of interior of room, chair, and view (through a window) of a prisoner being taken into a dwelling. Also includes spears and swords.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Blasco Núñez Vela replaced Vaca de Castro as the viceroy of Peru in 1544 and served briefly and violently until he was captured in 1546 by Gonzalo Pizarro. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 6, plate 18.

Image_title: Tabla geographica del reyno de Chile
Description: Map of the coastline of Chile. Cartographic elements include sea banks or shoals, compass rose, location of rivers and settlements. Decorative elements include lion, llamas or guanacos, parrot, penguin [?], rheas, armadillo, sea monsters, mermaid, ships, native American with a tail, a Patagonian giant, stag or deer chased by a dog, volcanoes, native Americans with bows and arrows, hunting birds, and settlements.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: This image is derived from the map in Alonso de Ovalle, Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, Rome, 1646.
SubjectArea3: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: El Inga Atahualpa ultimo Rey del Peru.
Description: Portrait of Atahualpa [or Atabalipa] holding an arrow and wearing a feathered headdress. The portrait is surrounded by a decorative frame which includes Atahualpa adorned with jewelry and carrying a scepter or symbol of the sun. He is being carried on a litter by native Americans. Includes scenes of mining by native Americans. Also includes musical instruments such as drum, pipes, and trumpet, swords, scene of warfare, baskets, winches, hoes, shovels, bows, arrows, ships, and boat.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Atabalipa [Atahualpa] was the last independent Inca ruler in Peru. He was captured by the Spanish and executed in 1533 despite his paying a vast ransom for his life. The decorative frame is derived from the title page of Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 6.

Image_title: Carneros del Perú, que dizen llamas, múÿ Provechosos, ÿ su naturaleza.
Description: Method by which ore was transported by llamas. Native Americans herd llamas carrying packs. In the background is an encampment where animals and men rest. Also includes a man shooting at a llama on a hill.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: The llama was used for the transport of ore in Peru. When overburdened the animals would sit down, and nothing would make the animal get up again. If they ran away, they had to be shot to recover the ore they were carrying. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, plate 4. Members of the Bouttats family were engravers active in Antwerp in the late seventeenth century.

Image_title: El apostol Santiago favorece á Los Castellanos, ÿ persigue á los Indios
Description: Scene of warfare between native Americans and Spanish soldiers at Cajamarca, Peru. In the center vignette, Saint James the Greater leads the Spanish on a horse in the heavens while below him Spaniards kill native Americans. The decorative border contains another scene of warfare, as well as feathered headdresses, shields, war clubs, bows, arrows. Surmounted by angels of fame holding laurel wreaths and musical instruments such as trumpets. Also includes dogs, ship, dwelling, guns or muskets, and axes.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Both scenes of warfare are derived from illustrations in Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 6. The scene in the middle is derived from Plate 12, which shows the Spanish taking over Cuzco after the execution of Atahualpa in 1533. The scene at the bottom is derived from Plate 13, which shows the Inca attempt to retake Cuzco under the leadership of Atahualpa's brother, Manco. James of Compostelo, also known as Santiago, patron saint of Spain, conquistadors, and the Spanish army, is shown with his attributes of a pilgrim's hat ornamented with cockle [scallop] shells.

Image_title: El Adelantado Don Diego de Almagro fue preso, ÿ por orden de Hernando Pizarro hecho su processo, sentenciado á muerte, ÿ justiciado
Description: Scenes from the end of the life of Diego de Almagro. He is detained on a street, tried, garroted. His associate is carried to the place of execution and beheaded. Includes dwellings, swords, ax, and native Americans who watch the execution.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Almagro returned to Cuzco from Chile where he had been searching for further wealth. His arrival in Cuzco upset the power balance and created two factions, those who followed Pizarro and those who followed Almagro. Their disagreement culminated in a battle just outside of Cuzco, known as Las Salinas; Almagro was garrotted and his captain, Rodrigo Orgóñez, was beheaded. The image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 6, plate 14. The Bouttats family were engravers active in Antwerp in the late seventeenth century.

Image_title: El Idolo Viztzilipuztli.
Description: Scene of worship and human sacrifice at a native American or Mexican temple. The victim's heart is cut out before an idol or statue by a priest with a knife. The priest's assistants hold the victim by all four limbs. Includes feathered headdress, statues of men in feathered headdresses and garments, and an alcove holding the idol who holds snakes, arrows, and a feathered shield.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. The offering of the victim's heart to the gods satisfied the Aztec belief that the sun would rise again nourished by the hearts of men. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9, plate 8.

Image_title: El Capitan Juan de Grijalva de Cuellar.
Description: Portrait of Juan Grijalva of Cuellar, Spain. The decorative border includes allegorical figures, one wreathed in a laurel wreath who holds a musical instrument, a lyre [Apollo?], the other wearing armor next to whom stands an owl [Athena]. At the bottom o
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Nephew of Diego Velásquez de Cuéllar, Grijalva explored the Yucatan. He traveled into the interior of Mexico where he heard of the wealth of Moctezuma, but he had been asked by his uncle not to claim the new lands he explored. When his uncle discovered th

Image_title: Como Los Indios solemnizavan sus fiestas con atambores, vozinas ÿ Caracoles.
Description: Native Americans worship before a many-headed god or idol and other idols in a temple. They offer gold and jewels and play music with musical instruments including drums. Also includes feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: This image is derived from plate 24 in Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 4, which describes the feast days of native Americans in Hispaniola. The cacique or chief would lead his people by beating a drum to the worship of their idol, a strange hydra-like creat

Image_title: [Tenochtitlan or Mexico City and environs]
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing the various islands, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city in the lake to the land. Also includes men on horseback, domestic animals, boats, churches, dwellings, wicker dams, and main square.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: The city is probably shown as the artist imagined Tenochtitlán was before Europeans arrived, but with European-type houses and churches and men on horseback or herding sheep. The image is derived from Carol Allard, Orbis habitabilis oppida et vestitas, A

Image_title: Motezuma ultimo Rey de los Mexicanos.
Description: Portrait of Moctezuma II, the last emperor of the Mexica or Aztecs. He is shown with feathered headdress, garments, and shield and is holding a spear. In the background are dwellings and temples. The decorative border shows a native American ruler or chie
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Moctezuma II (or Montezuma II, reigned 1502-1520), the ninth Aztec emperor, whose surname was Xocoyotzin or bitter lord (or the youngest), was the son of Axayácatl and great grandson of Moctezuma I. He surrendered to the Spanish in 1520. The decorative b
SubjectHeadings1: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Concierto entre Francisco Pizarro, Diego de Almagro, ÿ Harnando de Luque para hazer el descubrimiento del Sur à Levante ÿ sale francisco Pizarro para descubrir.
Description: Francisco Pizarro, Diego de Almagro, and the priest, Hernando de Luque, negotiate a contract while men load cargo onto boats and ships. Includes dwelling, casks, swords, and stores.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Pizarro, Almagro, and Hernando de Luque entered an agreement in 1522 to share out the riches they hoped to find in Peru. As a result of Pizarro's explorations at the San Juan River (between present-day Nicaragua and Costa Rica) and the Gulf of Guayquil (E

Image_title: Capitulacion del Reÿ con Francisco Pizarro ÿ Mercedes que se hizo à Hernando de Luque, ÿ al Capitan Diego de Almagro, ÿ sus Compañeros.
Description: Francisco Pizarro presents his case to the King of Spain. Men sit in council in the royal court around the king and hear Pizarro's case. Includes scribe with pen and inkwell, tapestries, casks, boats, and ship being loaded with spoils.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Pizarro was granted a royal agreement on July 26, 1529 which made him governor of Peru or all the territory up to 200 leagues south of Guayaquil in present-day Ecuador. His colleague, Diego de Almagro was made commander of Tumbes, and the priest, Hernando

Image_title: Tesóro del templo de Pachiacama, que Hernando Pizarro llevó con Sigo a Chaliquichiama.
Description: Spanish soldiers on horseback supervise native Americans who bring gold and silver vessels and statues to the temple of Pachiacama [Pachacamac]. Includes vessels, animals such as a lobster, alligator, turtle, eagle, trays, and chests made out of precious
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Image_title: Batalla ÿ Vitoria de Gabriel de Rojas con los Indios de Mango cerca del Cusco.
Description: Spanish soldiers, some on horseback, fight against native Americans before a fortified town. Includes guns or muskets, drums, swords, spears, fortifications, and scene of warfare.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Image_title: Batalla de Chupas muÿ sangrienta de Vaca de Castro, ÿ Don Diego de Almagro, la vitoria se declara por Vaca de Castro.
Description: Spanish soldiers fight each other. Includes scene of warfare, swords, cannons, and guns or muskets.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros

Image_title: El Secreto de la mina de Potosi se descubre à Villarroel, ÿ la cantidad de plata, que se sacava en los primeros tiempos
Description: Method by which native Americans mined precious metals from the mountain. Men climb up and down a rope ladder carrying ore from the mines. Other men hold candles or lights and use pickaxes to extract the ore. In the background, men herd llamas and take th
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros

Image_title: El Almirante Christoval Colon descubre las Islas Margarita ÿ de Cubagúa, adonde an cogido muchas perlas.
Description: Native Americans from the Isla de Margarita dive and collect pearl oysters from boats or canoes. On an island in the background, a group of native Americans trade pearls with Europeans. Built environment includes settlement with dwellings and ships.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Christopher Columbus discovered Isla de Margarita on his third trip to the Americas. He described how a native American tribe near the Gulf of Paria and the island of Cubagua (between present-day Trinidad and Venezuela) collected pearl oysters. Pearls wer

Image_title: Lope de Olano mandò, que se hiziesse una Caravéla de las tablas de las naos que se aviàn hecho pendaços.
Description: Shipbuilding in Veragua. Men saw planks and construct a ship. In the background, a shipwrecked vessel lies on shore, men build dwellings and sow fields. Includes boat building tools such as adzes, axes, pitch cooking over a fire, cross-saw, pliers, mallet
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros

Image_title: Indios, que tenían sus casas sobre arboles, por las lagunas ÿ pantanos.
Description: Native Americans in trees drop stones, shoot with arrows, and pour water on Spanish soldiers who attack from the ground. One man chops at a tree trunk while two others hold boards over his head to protect him from the onslaught above. At right, Spaniards
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: The Urabá natives of the Atrato River built their houses in trees because the land was so swampy. The Spanish heard that they had gold and silver and tried to get them down. The Indians threw down stones, spears, and boiling water to prevent the Spaniards

Image_title: Basco Nuñes de Balboa mandò echar à los perros al hermano del Casique ÿ otros presos, del pecado nefando inficionados.
Description: European soldiers watch as dogs tear apart native Americans. Includes guns or muskets, swords, dwelling, and bird.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: While crossing the Isthmus of Panama in 1513, Vasco Nuñez de Balboa came across native Americans from the province of Quarenca, dressed as women, commiting acts of sodomy. As punishment, Balboa had the men thrown to the dogs. This image is derived from pl

Image_title: El Adelantado Iuan Ponce Descubridor de la Florida.
Description: Portrait of Juan Ponce de Leon wearing a plumed hat. A ship sails in the background. The decorative border includes a scene of warfare, native Americans fighting Spanish soldiers, feathered headdresses, shields, war clubs, bows, arrows. Surmounted by ange
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Known for his search for the Fountain of Youth, Ponce de Leon was the first European to land in Florida. He also founded the first settlement in Puerto Rico and discovered the Gulf Stream.

Image_title: El Adelantado Basco Nuñes de xeres que descubrio la mar del Sur.
Description: Portrait of Vasco Núñez de Balboa wearing armor and holding a sword. The decorative border shows a native American ruler or chief, adorned with jewelry and carrying a scepter or symbol of the sun, being carried on a litter by native Americans. Includes sc
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: The first European to see the Pacific Ocean or South Sea, Balboa was executed for treason by Pedro Arias Dávila (usually called Pedrarias), governor of Darién. The decorative border is derived from the title page of Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 6, which

Image_title: Hernando de Magallanes, Cavallero Portugués, descubridar del Estrecho de su nombre.
Description: Portrait of Ferdinand Magellan holding dividers and a globe. Also includes a chart, ship, and depiction of the Strait of Magellan [?] with crosses or graves [?]. The decorative border includes anchors, musical instruments such as trumpets and drums, navig
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Fernão de Magalhães, or Magellan, discovered the strait named after him in 1520.

Image_title: El Adelantado Don Diego Velasques de Cuellar Aútor del descrubrimiento de nueva España.
Description: Portrait of Diego Velasquez de Cuellar. The decorative border shows a native American ruler or chief, adorned with jewelry and carrying a scepter or symbol of the sun, being carried on a litter by native Americans. Includes scenes of mining by native Amer
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Velásquez de Cuéllar was the first governor of Cuba from 1511 to 1524. The decorative border is derived from the title page of Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 6, which shows Atahualpa [or Atabalipa] being carried on a litter by native Americans.

Image_title: Danças llamadas Mitotes.
Description: Method of dancing among native Mexicans. Men dance while standing on each other's shoulders and while walking on a rope. Also includes a man being ferried across a river. Includes musical instruments such as drums, feathered headdresses and garments, and
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Image_title: Artificio grande de los Plateros Indios.
Description: Native Americans mold gold. Goldsmiths or silversmiths tend a fire and blow on the flames of the hearth or foundry. At right, a man unmolds a statue. Includes baskets, feathered garments, and dwellings.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Image_title: [Hernán Cortés captures Moctezuma]
Description: Spanish soldier directs a boy to put manacles on a native American chief or ruler. Includes armor, chains, feathered headdress and garments, throne, and baton.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Image_title: Batalla en el valle de Otumba
Description: View of the battle of Otumba. Includes columns or battalions of soldiers and scene of warfare. Items in the image are identified in key at bottom.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo primo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: The battle of Otumba occurred as Hernán Cortés was retreating from Tenochtitlan followed by hunger, disease, and pursuing Aztec warriors. Cortés army fled to Tlaxcala to obtain reinforcements. Encountering a legion of Aztec soldiers sent by Cuitlahuac, Mo

Image_title: Los Indios acometen à Los Religiosos ÿ otros ÿ ponen fuego à la casa ò atarazana.
Description: Native Americans kill European monks and soldiers using war clubs, bows, and arrows. Includes dwellings, guns or muskets, and ships.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Some monks left Cubagua to proselytize among the native Americans near Cumana, present-day Venezuela. The native Americans, however, tired of Spanish interference, massacred many monks and Spanish traders. Some of the Spaniards managed to escape and went to Hispaniola where they reported the massacre to Bartholomew Columbus, who was governor of that island. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 4, plate 16.

Image_title: La Villa de Mexico.
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing the various islands, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city. Also includes men on horseback, domestic animals, boats, churches, dwellings, wicker dams, and main square.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: The city is probably shown as the artist imagined Tenochtitlan was before Europeans arrived, but with European-type houses and churches and men on horseback or herding sheep. The image is derived from Carol Allard, Orbis habitabilis oppida et vestitas, Amsterdam 1681, who in turn derived his view from the Hernán Cortés map-view of Tenochtitlán. Image placed horizontally on page.
References: Cf. Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.24, p. 92-93

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: A youth and a native American in feathered headdress and garment flank a woman holding a crucifix. Includes bow, quiver of arrows, and coats of arms (one of the city of Lima).
Source_Title: Toribio Alfonso Mogrovesio il santo arcivescovo di Lima compendio di vita ...
Source_publisher: Appresso Gio. Maria Salvioni
notes: This image is derived from the added engraved title page in Cipriano de Herrera, Mirabilis vita ... venerii servi Toribii Alfonsi Mogrobesi Limani Archipraesolis ..., Rome, 1656.

Image_title: Quasi Pater in Filio complacet.
Description: Portrait of Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo, an archbishop who kneels in prayer before an altar. Above the altar is a painting of the Virgin Mary who holds the Christ child and presents a rosary to a saint with a halo. Includes richly-embroidered altar cloth, crucifix, candles, painting of a bishop supported by angels, and a scene of people traveling to church.
Source_Title: Toribio Alfonso Mogrovesio il santo arcivescovo di Lima compendio di vita ...
Source_publisher: Appresso Gio. Maria Salvioni
notes: Appointed archbishop of Lima in 1580, Toribio Alfonso Mogrovejo traveled Peru on foot baptizing and confirming the natives, among them Rosa of Lima, Francisco Solano [Solanus], and Martin Porrés. He was canonized in 1726.

Image_title: Navios de Cortés desagregados y echados à pique por orden fuya

Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Image_title: El Adelantado Hernando de Soto.

Image_title: Pedro de Valdibia Governador de Chile.
Description: Portrait of Pedro de Valdivia wearing armor and holding a baton. The decorative border contains feathered headdresses, bows, arrows, suits of armor, cannon, flags, two native American men (one kneeling, the other bound by rope at the wrist), and a woman r
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Valdivia became the governor of Chile in 1549 and defended the colony against native American uprisings. He founded the city of Concepción and several towns, but was killed by the Araucanians south of the Río Biobío.

Image_title: Gabriel de Rojas General de la Artilleria.

Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
