notes: Rojas, a Spanish soldier, came to South America in 1514 with Pedrarias Davila. He assisted Francisco Pizarro in the defense of Cuzco, during the siege by Manco Inca Yupanqui and in the civil wars between the factions of Pizarro and Almagro. He was appoint

Image_title: Il Maese de Campo xtoval de olid de Ubeda
Description: Portrait of Christoval de Olid dressed in armor with a helmet. Decorative elements include angels and eagles.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo segundo
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Olid, one of the conquistadors of Mexico under Hernán Cortés's command, was named "Maese de Campo" by Cortes in 1520. After successfully conquering Michoacán, Olid was sent to plant a colony in Honduras in 1524. He was eventually beheaded for attempting to set up his own government there.

Image_title: El Capitan Diego de Ordas del Reÿno de Leon

Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

notes: Ordaz, a Spanish adventurer, served under Hernán Cortés, obtained a grant of the country near the bay of Venezuela, and explored Oaxaca and the Orinoco River. The Bouttats family were engravers active in Antwerp in the late seventeenth century.

Image_title: El Mariscal Alonso de Alvarado
Description: Portrait of Alonso de Alvarado. The decorative border includes allegorical figures, one wearing a laurel wreath and holding a musical instrument, a lyre [Apollo?], the other wearing armor next to whom stands an owl [Athena]. At the bottom of the image an
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Image_title: El Mariscal Rodrigo Orgoñes.
Description: Portrait of Rodrigo Orgóñez. The decorative border includes allegorical figures holding flaming torches, snakes, trumpet or musical instrument. Also includes suit of armor, arrows, war clubs, and shields.

Image_title: El Licenciado Vaca de Castro Governador del Pèru.
Description: Portrait of Cristóbal Vaca de Castro holding a baton. The decorative border includes allegorical figures such as a woman holding a book and leaning on a globe and flanked by angels. Includes a man dressed in armor and woman holding holding a caduceus. At
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

notes: Vaca de Castro was chosen by Charles V to restore order between the Pizarro and Almagro factions in Peru. Hearing of the assassination of Francisco Pizarro on his arrival in Peru in 1541, he assumed the governorship. He was succeeded by the first viceroy

Image_title: El Licenciado Pedro de la Gasca
Description: Portrait of Pedro de la Gasca wearing a biretta and clerical clothes. The decorative border includes allegorical figures such as a woman holding a book and leaning on a globe and flanked by angels. Includes a man dressed in armor and woman holding holding
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Gasca, a Spanish bishop and royal commissioner, led an army to Peru to unseat Gonzalo de Pizarro who was attempting to have himself crowned king of Peru. Gasca arranged for the two armies to meet in the valley of Sacsahuana on April 9, 1548, but most of t

Image_title: El Capitan Diego Centeno.
Description: Portrait of Diego Centeno wearing armor. The decorative border includes angels and eagles holding laurel branches.
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Centeno, a Spanish soldier, came to Peru with Francisco Pizarro. He distinguished himself at the battle of Chupas, allied with Vaca de Castro against Almagro, but later challenged Gonzalo Pizarro for possession of Peru and was routed at Huarinas in 1547.

Image_title: El General Pedro Alfosso de Hinojosa Cavallero de Truxillo
Description: Portrait of Pedro de Hinojosa wearing armor. The decorative border includes angels seated on fish or dolphins who offer treasure, pearls and gold. Also includes musical instruments such as drums and trumpets or horns, anchors, swords, shields, stern of a
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625
Source_Title: [Historia general de los hechos de los castellanos] Historia general de las Indias Ocidentales ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: Por Juan Bautista Verdussen, Mercader de Libros
notes: Hinojosa, a Spanish soldier, came to Peru with Hernando Pizarro and became lieutenant-governor of Cuzco. He fought with Pizarro in the battle of Salinas, where Almagro was defeated. He sided with Vaca de Castro against Almagro's son and took part in the b

Image_title: Don Hernando Cortes Marquez de Valle, natural de Medellin
Description: Portrait of Hernán Cortés. The decorative border includes allegorical figures including a woman with many breasts [Diana or Artemis?], one holding a snake [Minerva or Athena?], one holding a caduceus, and two chained men [captives or slaves?]. Also includ
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II). The Bouttats family were engravers active in Antwerp in the late seventeenth century.

Image_title: Gonzalo de Sandoval de Medellin, Capitan Valeroso.
Description: Portrait of Gonzalo de Sandoval wearing armor with plumed helmet. The decorative border includes allegorical figures including a woman with many breasts [Diana or Artemis?], one holding a snake [Minerva or Athena?], one holding a caduceus, and two chained
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

notes: Gonzalo de Sandoval of Medellin, a Spanish conquistador, was the youngest of Hernán Cortés's lieutenants and returned with Cortés to Spain, but died soon after landing there. The Bouttats family were engravers active in Antwerp in the late seventeenth cen

Image_title: Don Bartholmeo Colon L. Adelantado.
Description: Portrait of Bartholomew Columbus. The decorative border contains allegorical figures with a flaming sword, figure with snakes for hair (symbol of envy), angels playing musical instruments such as trumpets (angels of fame), armor, shields, maces, flags, ar
Source_creator: Herrera y Tordesillas, Antonio de, d. 1625

Image_title: El Ve. Siervo de Dios el illmo. y exmo. Sr. D. Iuan de Palafox y Me[n]doza Obispo dela Puebla delos Angeles ...
Description: Portrait of Juan Palafox y Mendoza kneeling before an altar on which is a crucifix, book, and inkwell. He kneels next to a bookcase with tears running down his face. Two angels hold a bishop's crozier and mitre along with the seal showing the crucifix and bearing Palafox y Mendoza's motto. Also includes the coat of arms of Palafox y Mendoza [?].
Source_Title: Puntos que el señor don Juan Palafox y Mendoza .. dexa encargados, y encomendados â las almas de su cargo, al tiempo de partirse de estas provincias, â los reynos de España, año de 1649
Source_publisher: Por Joseph Bernardo de Hogal. En la Calle Nueva
notes: Appointed "visitator general" of Mexico in 1639, he served as the bishop of Puebla of Los Angeles, a position he held until 1649. The process of Palafox y Mendoza's canonization was begun in 1726, but a final decision was suspended in 1777.

Image_title: [Cochineal]
Description: Cochineal, showing views under a microscope of the details of the insect. Includes views of the engorged cochineal from the top, bottom, and side with a detail of a leg.
Source_Title: Natuerlyke historie van de couchenille ... Histoire naturelle de la cochenille ...
Source_publisher: By Hermanus Uytwerf, boekverkooper
notes: Text discusses the discoveries made by Nicolas Hartsoeker and Nicolas Lemery on the insects found in America.

Image_title: Vro. Rro. de Sor Maria Ines delos Dolores Muger insigne entodo genero de Virtudes ...
Description: Portrait of Sor Maria Ines de los Dolores holding a medallion and a rosary. At the upper right is the Jesuit symbol IHS.
Source_Title: Espejo crystalino de paciencia, y viva imagen de Christo crucificado
Source_publisher: Imprenta Real
notes: Sor Maria Ines de los Dolores was a nun at the convent of San Lorenzo in Mexico City.

Image_title: [Interior of a convent]
Image_publisher: Heirs of the Widow of Miguel de Rivera Calderone
Description: Interior of a domed room. Includes candlesticks [?].
Source_Title: Mano religiosa de fray José Cillero en la obra de la sacristía y altares del Convento Franciscano de Toluca, que ideó, hizo y dedicó el día 8 de diciembre de 1729
Source_publisher: en la Imprenta Real de el Superior Govierno, de los herederos de la Viuda de Miguel de Rivera Calderon; en el Empedradillo
notes: This book describes the architecture of the Convento Franciscano de la Asumpción in Toluca de Lerdo, Mexico. Here the text discusses the sacristy. Sylverio, a Mexican engraver, claimed to have made at least 1245 numbered engravings between 1721 and 1763.

Image_title: [Verdadero Retrato de nuestra Señora de Tepepan.]
Description: Our Lady of Tepepan stands holding the Christ Child and a scepter. She wears a crown, as does her child. She is supported by a Franciscan monk.
Source_Title: Aurora alegre del dichoso dia de la Gracia Maria Santissima Digna Madre de Dios ...
Source_publisher: Por Joseph Bernardo de Hogal, ministro, e impressor del Real Tribunal de la Santa Cruzada
notes: The statue of the Virgin of Tepepan was a copy of Our Lady of Remedies. The original statue was commissioned by Pedro de Gante. Tepepan is an area now on the outskirts of Mexico City. This book was based on sor María de Jesús de Agreda, Mystica ciudad de Dios and Vida de la Virgin Madre de Dios. Title on page under image.
References: Weckman, L. The medieval heritage of Mexico, p. 283

Image_title: [Holy figure with papal symbols, eagles, and cactus]
Image_publisher: Heirs of the Widow of Francisco Rodriguez Lupercio
Description: A figure [the Virgin Mary?] stands above two eagles [?], snakes (held in the eagles' talons), and a cactus. Two angels holding keys hold back a curtain. Above the figure is a papal crown.
Source_Title: Doctrina christiana en lengua chinanteca, añadida la explicacion de los principales mysterios de la fee ...
Source_publisher: Por los herederos de la viuda de Francisco Rodriguez Lupercio, en la puente de Palacio
notes: Perhaps meant to represent the Virgin of Guadalupe, the figure shown in the image combines elements of European rule [the papal crown and keys and the double-headed Hapsburg eagle] and elements of indigenous legend [the eagle may represent the eagle which led the Aztecs to their home in Tenochtitlan].
SubjectHeadings3: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles--Mexico

Image_title: [Guava or guayacan (?), cactus (?), and a man ]
Description: Two trees, a guava or guayacan[?] and cactus, and a man.
Source_Title: [Historia de la Indias. Turkish] [Tarih-i Hind-i garbi]
Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes three trees; two are illustrated here. Ninety percent of the information in this book is from López de Gómara's Historia de las Indias and was probably translated and adapted by Emir Mehmet ibn Emir Hasan el-Suudi [?] in 1580. This is the first illustrated book ever to be produced on an Ottoman printing press.
References: Goodrich, T.D. Sixteenth Century Ottoman Americana, Ph.D. diss., 1968, picture #14, pp. 184-187, 540.

Image_title: [Sloth and opossum]
Description: Hunting with bow and arrow. A man shoots an arrow into a tree while an opossum sneaks up on a hen house where a rooster paces. A sloth stands on the limb of a tree.
Source_Title: [Historia de la Indias. Turkish] [Tarih-i Hind-i garbi]
Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes the opossum as catching chickens at night and drinking their blood. The sloth is described as having a long neck and small round head. Ninety percent of the information in this book is from López de Gómara's Historia de las Indias and was probably translated and adapted by Emir Mehmet ibn Emir Hasan el-Suudi [?] in 1580. This is the first illustrated book ever to be produced on an Ottoman printing press.
References: Goodrich, T.D. Sixteenth Century Ottoman Americana, Ph.D. diss., 1968, picture # 12, p. 173-180, 528-529.

Image_title: [Jaguar, ant-eater, and armadillo]
Description: Hunter with bow and arrow hunts a jaguar. Also includes an ant-eater and armadillo.
Source_Title: [Historia de la Indias. Turkish] [Tarih-i Hind-i garbi]
Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes the jaguar as a predacious animal like a tiger. The ant-eater is described as a kind of bear with no tail. The armadillo is described being like a horse with a pack-saddle. Ninety percent of the information in this book is from López de Gómara's Historia de las Indias and was probably translated and adapted by Emir Mehmet ibn Emir Hasan el-Suudi [?] in 1580. This is the first illustrated book ever to be produced on an Ottoman printing press.
References: Goodrich, T.D. Sixteenth Century Ottoman Americana, Ph.D. diss., 1968, picture #11, p. 171-174, 523-527.

Image_title: [Potosi, its mountain, and its river]
Description: Two men in European attire bow to a king. In the background is a walled town with a river beside it and a mountain behind it.
Source_Title: [Historia de la Indias. Turkish] [Tarih-i Hind-i garbi]
Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes the city of Potosí, the mountain from which the silver is mined (Cerro Rico), and the River of Silver which flows through it. Ninety percent of the information in this book is from López de Gómara's Historia de las Indias and was probably translated and adapted by Emir Mehmet ibn Emir Hasan el-Suudi [?] in 1580. This is the first illustrated book ever to be produced on an Ottoman printing press.
References: Goodrich, T.D. Sixteenth Century Ottoman Americana, Ph.D. diss., 1968, picture #10, p. 164-170, 498-500.

Image_title: [Men hunt mermen.]
Description: Two naked native Americans hunt two mermen.
Source_Title: [Historia de la Indias. Turkish] [Tarih-i Hind-i garbi]
Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes the island of Cobagua (present-day Cubagua, Venezuela, in the Gulf of Paria) where the inhabitants live off of the pearl oyster and where there is a fish with the upper body of a man [manatee?]. This was the first book on the New World published east of Italy and the first illustrated book to be produced on an Ottoman printing press. 90% of the information in this book is from López de Gómara's Historia de las Indias, and was probably translated and adapted by Emir Mehmet ibn Emir Hasan el-Suudi [?] in 1580.
References: Goodrich, T.D. Sixteenth Century Ottoman Americana, PhD diss., 1968, picture # 5, 139-143, 376

Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes the soursop tree with fruit the size of a melon and the mammee tree which produces pear-like fruit. Ninety percent of the information in this book is from López de Gómara's Historia de las Indias and was probably translated and adapted by Emir Mehmet ibn Emir Hasan el-Suudi [?] in 1580. This is the first illustrated book ever to be produced on an Ottoman printing press.
References: Goodrich, T.D. Sixteenth Century Ottoman Americana, Ph.D. diss., 1968, picture #13, p. 181-183, 537.

Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes buffalo as having horns and a hump like a camel. The sheep is described as having large horns and soft hair. Ninety percent of the information in this book is from López de Gómara's Historia de las Indias and was probably translated and adapted by Emir Mehmet ibn Emir Hasan el-Suudi [?] in 1580. This is the first illustrated book ever to be produced on an Ottoman printing press.
References: Goodrich, T.D. Sixteenth Century Ottoman Americana, Ph.D. diss., 1968, picture #9, p. 158-163, 458-459.

Image_title: [Armadillo, pelican, and two ducks]
Description: Armadillo, pelican, and two Muscovy ducks.
Source_Title: [Historia de la Indias. Turkish] [Tarih-i Hind-i garbi]
Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes the armadillo as being the size of a cat and whose head and beak are like a duck; on its back is a robe of bone which it can either close or open. The ducks are described as being geese with black bodies and white wings. The pelican is described as being able to swallow three boys in one gulp. Ninety percent of the information in this book is from López de Gómara's Historia de las Indias, and was probably translated and adapted by Emir Mehmet ibn Emir Hasan el-Suudi [?] in 1580. This is the first illustrated book ever to be produced on an Ottoman printing press.

Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press
notes: Text describes tapirs as looking like a mule with long snouts like the trunks of the elephant. Source_Title: [Historia de la Indias. Turkish] [Tarih-i Hind-i garbi]
Source_publisher: Ibrahim Mutafarrika, at the Imperial Press

Image_title: La Ve. Me. Maria de Iesus de Agreda. Predicando a los Chichimecos del Nuebo-mexico
Description: A nun holding a crucifix preaches to native Americans who wear feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_Title: Tanto que se sacó de una carta ...
Source_publisher: por Joseph Bernardo de Hogal ...
notes: This book relates the story of the miraculous spiritual transportation of the Venerable Mother Maria de Jesus de Agreda (1602-1665) from her own Franciscan convent in Spain to the native people of present-day New Mexico. She reported that she had a memory of some five hundred spiritual visits in the six-year period preceding 1628 during which time she converted the whole Indian population to Christianity without physically leaving Spain. Publication information taken from colophon.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1936, p. 8-9; Wagner, H.R. Spanish Southwest, no. 92

Image_title: Bateau que les Indiens appellent Balzes
Description: A native American woman paddles a balsa raft. Parts of the raft are lettered and numbered for identification in the text.
Source_Title: [Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales] Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Meridionale, contenant diverses observations remarquables touchant le Perou, la Guiane, le Bresil, &c. traduits de l'espagnol & de l'anglois. Tome second.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: Balsa rafts were known to Europeans since 1527 when first seen by Pizarro's pilot.Cf. 03093-13 for Feuillée's earlier version; this image is a re-engraved copy.No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author is frequently questioned. Coreal may be a pseudonym for the real traveler who visited the West Indies, Florida, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, and Peru.

Image_title: Llama, & Vigognes
Description: A llama and a vicuña stand in a landscape.
Source_Title: [Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales] Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Meridionale, contenant diverses observations remarquables touchant le Perou, la Guiane, le Bresil, &c. traduits de l'espagnol & de l'anglois. Tome second.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: The vicuña is Vicugna vicugna, and the llama is Lama glama.No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author is frequently questioned. Coreal may be a pseudonym for the real traveler who visited the West Indies, Florida, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, and Peru.

Image_title: Arica
Description: View of Arica, Chile. Includes convents, dwellings, fortifications, ships, and sugar factory. Items are lettered for identification in the text.
Source_Title: [Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales] Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Meridionale, contenant diverses observations remarquables touchant le Perou, la Guiane, le Bresil, &c. traduits de l'espagnol & de l'anglois. Tome second.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: At the right is a high hill known as the Morro de Arica. Arica was a part of Peru until 1880. Text notes the unhealthy air and smell of the place, as well as the tendency for earthquakes to occur. No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author is frequently questioned. Coreal may be a pseudonym for the real traveler who visited the West Indies, Florida, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, and Peru.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Cartagene Avec ses Ports, et ses Forts.
Description: Map or plan of the city of Cartagena and chart of Cartagena Bay. Cartographic elements include soundings, shoals, compass rose, scale, topographical details, names and locations of churches, forts, and bodies of water.
Source_Title: [Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales] Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Meridionale, contenant diverses observations remarquables touchant le Perou, la Guiane, le Bresil, &c. traduits de l'espagnol & de l'anglois. Tome premier.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: The body of water labeled Lac de Cartagene is actually Cartagena Bay and is south of the city.Cartagena was founded in 1533 by Pedro de Heredia and was one of only two ports under Spanish control in the New World allowed to engage in the slave trade. (The other was Veracruz, Mexico.) In the late sixteenth century, Cartagena was attacked by both English (Drake, Hawkins) and French (Cote, Baal) pirates/privateers. The Spanish crown responded to these threats in the seventeenth century by building very extensive fortifications so that only late in the 1600s did buccaneers successfully attack the city. Its defenses were still strong enough in 1741 to withstand the siege made by the English Admiral Edward Vernon.No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author is frequently questioned. Coreal may be a pseudonym for the real traveler who visited the West Indies, Florida, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, and Peru.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Lima
Description: Plan of the city of Lima, Peru. Cartographic element includes scale. Includes arms of the colonial city of Lima assigned by Queen Juana I and King Carlos I.
Source_Title: [Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales] Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Meridionale, contenant diverses observations remarquables touchant le Perou, la Guiane, le Bresil, &c. traduits de l'espagnol & de l'anglois. Tome second.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: Lima was founded by Francisco Pizarro in 1535.Cf. 09226-8 for Frézier's earlier version of this plan.No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author is frequently questioned. Coreal may be a pseudonym for the real traveler who visited the West Indies, Florida, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, and Peru.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: La V. Madre Sor Maria de Iesus de Agreda
Description: Portrait of a nun writing in a book with quill and ink. Behind her stands a statue of the Virgin Mary standing on a crescent moon, her head encircled by stars.
Source_creator: Castorena y Ursúa, Juan Ignacio de, 1668-1733
Source_Title: Escuela mystica de Maria Santissima en la mystica ciudad de Dios ... a su amantissima sierva la venerable Madre maria de Jesus de Agreda ...
Source_publisher: Por Joseph Bernardo de Hogal, Ministro, ê Impressor de la Santa Cruzada
notes: Sor Maria de Jesus de Agreda wrote the work, The city of God, a history of the Virgin Mary. She also reported that she had a memory of over five hundred spiritual visits to the various tribes of the American southwest during which time she converted the whole Indian population to Christianity without physically leaving Spain. The engraver may be Francisco Sylverio de Sotomayor, Mexican engraver, who claimed to have made at least 1245 numbered engravings between 1721 and 1763.
References: Mathes, M. Ilustracion en Mexico colonial, p. 121; www.analesiie.unam.mx/pdf/78_221-234.pdf (Feb. 2006)
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles
SubjectHeadings2: María de Jesús, de Agreda, sor, 1602-1665

Image_title: [Inca and Indians of Peru]
Description: Inca and his queen with a child holding a parasol are flanked by a native American man and woman who offer gifts. Built environment includes native dwellings. Artifacts include a type of stove and three drinking vessels. Includes lettered key for identification.
Source_Title: Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily et du Perou, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713 & 1714
Source_publisher: Chez Nyon, ... Didot, ... Quillau ...
notes: Key states that the Inca and Coia [queen] were drawn after a picture made by the Indians of Cuzco. The stove is used to cook a herb. Engraver was probably Nicolas Guérard (son of Nicolas Guérard, ca. 1648-1719) who was active at the beginning of the eighteenth century.

Image_title: [The Virgin of Patrocinio with the four founders of Zacatecas]
Description: Four conquistadors or Spanish founders of Zacatecas in armor hold a medallion (with PLS II on it for Philip II of Spain) and stand before a hill with an image of Nuestra Señora del Patrocinio de Zacatecas in an aureole flanked by her symbols of the sun and the moon. Decorative elements include bows and arrows and a banner displaying the motto "Labor Vincit Omnia."
Source_creator: Rivera Bernárdez, José de, conde de Santiago de la Laguna, -1743
Source_Title: Descripcion breve de la muy noble, y leal ciudad de Zacatecas. Su situacion, que la engrandece; signos, que la señorean; planeta, que la domína; vezinos, que la ilustran; minas, que la enriquecen; gastos, que la mayorizan; y lo demás memorable, con algunas noticias del iman de los corazones, Christo Señor Nuestro, en su admirable, portentosa imagen, y algunos de sus maravillosos prodigios
Source_publisher: Por Joseph Bernardo de Hogal, Ministro, è Impresso del ... todo esta Nueva-España
notes: Silver was discovered in Zacatecas, Mexico, by the city's founders, Juan de Tolosa, Baltazar Temiño de Bañuelos, Diego de Ibarra, and Cristóbal de Oñate in 1546. By 1710 the mines at Zacatecas produced more sliver than the mines at Potosí. In 1585 it was made a city named for its patron saint, the Virgin of Patrocinio, by Philip II.
References_exhibitions: Danforth, S. Encountering the New World, Item 37

Image_title: Description, Situation & Vue de la ville de Mexique ...
Description: Views of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán, the grand Aztec temple, as well as illustrations of the dance called mitoles and worship before the altar of Huitzilopochtli. Includes a scene of sacrifice with priest and pyramid. Also includes map of Mexico or New Spain and plan of Mexico City.
Source_Title: Atlas historique, ou nouvelle introduction a l'histoire ... Tome VI. Qui comprend l'Afrique & l'Amerique ...
Source_publisher: Chez Zacharie Chatelain
notes: Huitzilopochtli or Huitziláihuitl, an Aztec god symbolized by the hummingbird, was the god of the sun and war. The descriptions and illustrations are taken from Theodor de Bry, America. Pt 9.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: V. R. dela V. VIrgen Mariana de [Jesus], nombrada la Azuçena de Quito, illustre en santidad.
Image_publisher: Heirs of the Widow of Miguel de Rivera Calderone
Description: Portrait of Mariana de Jesus of Quito holding a lily with a skull and whip or scourge for flagellation. Also includes the Jesuit symbol for Jesus, as well as an eye within a triangle.
Source_Title: La azucena de Quito, que brotò en el florido campo de la iglesia en las Indias Occidentales, la venerable virgen, Mariana de Jesus, Flores, y Paredes ...
Source_publisher: en la Imprenta Real de el Superior Govierno, de los herederos de la Viuda de Miguel de Rivera Calderon; en el Empedradillo
notes: A symbol later used by the Freemasons, the eye within a triangle represents the All-seeing eye of God or Providence.The engraver may be Francisco Sylverio [Silverio] de Sotomayor, 1699-ca. 1763, who claimed to have made at least 1245 numbered engravings between 1721 and 1763.
SubjectHeadings1: Paredes y Flores, Mariana de Jesús, Saint, 1618-1645

Image_title: Abbildung der ersten wie auch der Paraquaischen Kirche.
Description: A child in the midst of wild beasts such as lions, sheep, bears, and tapir [?]. In the background a priest holding a cross leads native Americans dressed in feathered headresses and garments toward a church.
Source_Title: [Relacion historial de las misiones de los Indios que se llaman Chiquitos. German] Neuer Welt-Bot, mit sich bringend eine wahrhaffte Historie einiger von denen Patribus der Gesellschafft Jesu in Paraquaria neu-bekehrten Völcker
Source_publisher: verlegts Paul Straub, Buchhändler auf dem Peters-Freyd-Hof, dem goldnen Vässlein gegen über
notes: In 1608, the Jesuits were granted the right to establish missions or "reducciones" in Paraguay. The "reducciones" owned and worked land in common, had free public services for the poor, schools, hospitals, established birth control, suppressed the death penalty, and protected native Americans from slavery.
References_exhibitions: Landis, D.C. Literature of the encounter, No. 20

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Press of Mother Maria de Agreda
Description: Saint Francis Solanus, a Franciscan brother, stands on an orb upheld by native Americans with feathered headdresses and garments, bows and arrows. He holds a violin and book in one hand and a crucifix and lilies in the other. In the background are representations of Paraguay, Tucuman, and Lima. Includes dwellings, churches, and fortifications.
Source_Title: El sol, y año feliz del Peru San Francisco Solano, apotol, y patron universal de dicho reyno
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de la Causa de la V. M. de Agreda
notes: A missionary in Peru and Paraguay, Solanus arrived in Peru in 1589. Known for his ability to speak numerous native American dialects, he was censor of the convents of his order in Tucuman and Paraguay and was later elected guardian of the Franiscan convent in Lima, Peru.

Image_title: V. R. d[e]l V. P. Dn. Pedro de Arellano, y Sossa ...
Description: Portrait of Pedro de Arellano y Sosa, an Oratorian, holding a rosary and a biretta which rests on a book.
Source_creator: Eguiara y Eguren, Juan José de, 1696-1763
Source_Title: Vida del venerable padre Don Pedro de Arellano, y Sossa, sacerdote, y primer preposito de la Congregacion del Oratorio de Mexico
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta real del superior gobierno y del nuevo rezado, de Doña Maria de Rivera en la Empedradillo
notes: Arellano y Sosa was a confessor of Sor Juana Inéz de la Cruz.Sylverio, a Mexican engraver, claimed to have made at least 1245 numbered engravings between 1721 and 1763.

Image_title: Capt. Hen Morgan before Panama w[hic]h. he took from the Spaniards.
Description: Portrait of Captain Henry Morgan standing before a battle scene and fortifications. Morgan holds a gun or musket and has two pistols and a sword.
Source_Title: [General history of the robberies and murders of the most notorious pyrates] A general history of the lives and adventures of the most famous highwaymen, murderers, street-robbers, &c. ... By Captain Charles Johnson
Source_publisher: Printed for and sold by Olive Payne, at Horace's-Head, in Round-Court in the Strand, over against York-Buildings
notes: Henry Morgan was a notorious pirate who captured numerous Spanish ships, as well as the town of Portobelo in Panama. In 1674, after being granted a pardon by Charles II of England, Morgan was knighted and appointed Lieutenant-Governor of Jamaica. This work is often attributed to Defoe based on textual relationship to works of Defoe's proven authorship together with supporting external evidence. It also has also been attributed to Charles Johnson.

Image_title: Vitzliputsli
Description: A statue of Huitzilopochtli, holding a serpent or rattlesnake in one hand and a shield and four arrows in the other, sits on a litter and wears a hummingbird mask or helmet with feathered crown.
Source_Title: Modern history: or, The present state of all nations ... Vol. XXVIII. Being the first volume of America ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the Author: And sold by J. Roberts, in Warwick-Lane; and the Booksellers in Town and Country
notes: Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. The engraver is perhaps William Stephens.

Image_title: The Indians Marching on a Visit or to a Feast
Description: A native American king or chief with his wife, children, and attendants. Includes dwelling, feathered headdresses, bows, arrows, baskets, hammock, nose ring, ornaments, knife, and necklaces. Items are numbered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: Modern history: or, The present state of all nations ... Vol. XXVIII. Being the first volume of America ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the Author: And sold by J. Roberts, in Warwick-Lane; and the Booksellers in Town and Country
notes: The text describes people in Veraguas, Panama, especially their clothing and ornaments. The ornaments are so heavy that women carry some of them in baskets. Some of the ornaments lie in the foreground and include men's and women's nose rings and other ornaments. This image is taken from Lionel Wafer's image of the same name where he describes the Cuna people of present-day Panama. In his New voyage and description of the isthmus of America, London, 1699, Wafer identified the chief or cacique of the Cuna named Lacenta, and said he was his friend and protector.

Image_title: [Members of the Oratorio congregation in Mexico City]
Description: A priest [Saint Philip Neri?] wearing a biretta and holding a flower stands on clouds, flanked by angels. Below him is a group of priests [Oratorians] who carry a book, birettas, and rosary. One angel throws flowers down on the priests while holding a rosary, the other holds a sacred heart and a book.
Source_Title: Memorias historicas de la congregacion de el Oratorio de la ciudad de Mexico ... fondo el esclarecido patriarch San Phelipe Neri ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta real de superior govierno, y del Nuevo Rezado de Doña Maria de Ribera
notes: Saint Philip Neri (Filippo de Neri), also known as Apostle of Rome, was the founder of a society of secular priests called the Congregation of the Oratory. The Mexico City Oratory was founded around 1660.

Image_title: Desolation des Peruviens pendant l'eclipse de lune.
Description: Native Americans cry out in dismay during a lunar eclipse. Men beat dogs with ropes and sticks. Includes musical instruments such as tambourine drums and mallets. Also includes fortifications of a city and dwellings.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Clemence de LYnca Mayta Capac en faveur des Collas:
Description: Native American king or chief grants clemency to his noble subjects. Native Americans with feathered headdresses and with ropes around their hands and necks are given their freedom by their leader. Includes encampment, dwellings, fortifications on a mountain, and spears.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: The Colla people were conquered by the Inca in the fifteenth century.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Le Temple du Soleil.
Description: Native Americans dance before a Sun Temple. Also shows natives worshipping the sun.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: This image is derived from the title page of Garsilasso de la Vega, Le commentaire royal, ov L'histoire des Yncas, Paris, 1633.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Maniere dont les Yncas marioient les Princes du Sang.
Description: Native American marriage or wedding ceremony between two members of Inca nobility. In the background are dwellings and fortifications of a city. Also includes feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: The artist may be Bernard Picart, 1673-1733, a French painter, draughtsman, and engraver, who also worked in the Netherlands.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Marriage customs and rites

Image_title: Le premier Ynca Manco Capac et la Reine Coya Mama Oello Huaco son Epouse tous deux Enfans du Soleil rassemblent les Sauvages et batissent la Ville capitale de Cuzco.
Description: Native Americans bow down before the Inca king and queen. In the background, others build the Inca capital, Cuzco. Cultural artifacts include feathered headdresses, earrings, bow and arrow, dwellings, and club.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: Manco Capac, with his sister Mama-Ocllo, known as children of the Sun, were revered as the progenitors of Inca civilization. The last Inca emperor was also named Manco Capac and crowned as a puppet king by Francisco Pizarro. He escaped, however, and led the last stand of the Inca against the Spanish.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Cruautés exercées par Atahuallpa a l'egard de son frere Huasar et de tous les yncas du sang Roial. Liv. IX.
Description: The Inca king, Atahualpa, enthroned under a tent, points towards a man, Huascar, who is being brought forward by other native Americans. Cultural artifacts include war clubs, axes, spears, and feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: Shortly before the arrival of Francisco Pizarro in 1532, the Incan king, Atahualpa invaded the kingdom given to his brother, Huascar, whom he defeated and imprisoned.

Image_title: [Viracocha]
Description: Native American Inca ruler or king holding two spears and wearing earrings.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: Viracocha, according to Inca beliefs, was the creator of the world and was often shown with a stave in each hand. He also created the eight brethren to rule the world, two of whom, Manco Capac and Mama Ocello, founded the Inca civilization. An Inca ruler was named Viracocha, as well. This image is derived from the title page of Garsilasso de la Vega, Le commentaire royal, ov L'histoire des Yncas, Paris, 1633.

Image_title: [Coya Mama Ocllo, mother of Huayna Capac]
Description: Native American Inca ruler or queen holding fabric [?] and a pole.
Source_Title: Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Depuis le premier Ynca Manco Capac ... jusqu'a Atahualpa dernier Ynca: ... Tome Premier
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: Coya Mama Ocllo [Oello] was with her husband/brother, Manco Capac, the founder of Inca civilization and taught women the art of weaving and spinning. This image is derived from the title page of Garsilasso de la Vega, Le commentaire royal, ov L'histoire des Yncas, Paris, 1633.

Image_title: V. R. de el V. P. F. Antonio Margìl de Jesus, Predr. Apost. Guard. y Fundador de los tres Colegios ...
Description: Portrait of Antonio Margil de Jesus, a barefoot monk in patched habit, holding a crucifx before praying native Americans. Includes feathered headdresses, bows, and arrows.
Source_Title: El peregrino septentrional atlante: Delineado en la exemplarissima vida del venerable padre Fr. Antonio Margil de Jesus ...
Source_publisher: por Joseph Bernardo de Hogal ...
notes: Antonio Margil de Jesus converted many native Americans from Texas, Mexico, and Central America. He founded two colleges in Guatemala and Mexico and is associated with the rebirth of the Franciscan apostolate in Mexico, and later Guatemala, Panama, and most of South America.The engraver may be Joaquín Sotomayor.
References: Mathes, M. Ilustracion en Mexico colonial, 8A, p. 122; www.analesiie.unam.mx/pdf/78_221-234.pdf (Feb. 2006)

Image_title: Environs du Lac de Mexique
Description: Simplified map of the valley of Mexico with Mexico City or Tenochtitlán, its lake, and surrounding settlements. Includes causeways and aquaduct. Cartographic elements include topographical details, cardinal points, and names of settlements.
Source_Title: [Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales] Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Meridionale, contenant diverses observations remarquables touchant le Perou, la Guiane, le Bresil, &c. traduits de l'espagnol & de l'anglois. Tome premier.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author is frequently questioned. Coreal may be a pseudonym for the real traveler who visited the West Indies, Florida, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, and Peru.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Baye et Forts de Porto Belo
Description: Map and chart of the Darien peninsula and bay of Portobelo in present-day Panama. Cartographic elements include topographical details, soundings, shoals, compass rose, and locations of forts.
Source_Title: [Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales] Recueil de voyages dans l'Amerique Meridionale, contenant diverses observations remarquables touchant le Perou, la Guiane, le Bresil, &c. traduits de l'espagnol & de l'anglois. Tome premier.
Source_publisher: Chez Jean Frederic Bernard
notes: Portobelo, also known as Puerto Bello and Porto Belo, was important as a port on the itinerary of the Spanish silver fleets. It was plundered by the pirate, Henry Morgan, in 1668, and it was taken by the British admiral, Edward Vernon, in the War of Jenkins' Ear in 1739. Darien was the site of an ill-fated Scottish settlement in the 1690s.No Spanish original of Coreal's voyages is known, and the identity of the author is frequently questioned. Coreal may be a pseudonym for the real traveler who visited the West Indies, Florida, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, and Peru.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: La V. Virgen Juana de Jesus Hija de la Noble Ciudad de Quito ...
Description: Portrait of Sor Juana de Jesus, a Franciscan nun and native of Quito, Ecuador, who holds the Christ Child in her arms. The nun kneels before an altar with a crucifx, a lily, book, and whip. Under her feet are two devils and an orb. The Virgin Mary resting on clouds and surrounded by angels surveys the scene.
Source_creator: Santa Maria, Francisco Xavier Antonio de, padre
Source_Title: Vida prodigiosa de la venerable virgen Juana de Jesus de la Tercera Orden de Penitencia de Nuestro Seraphico Padre San Francisco ...
Source_publisher: En la calle del tigre; por Francisco Sobrino y Bados

Image_title: Puerto del Principe, Taken, & Sackt.
Image_publisher: D. Midwinter ... ; T. Woodward ... ; C. Bathurst ... ; and A. Ward
Description: Men attack the town or settlement of Puerto Principe using guns or muskets. Also includes dwellings and church.
Source_Title: [Americaanse zeerovers. English] The history of the bucaniers of America ...
Source_publisher: printed for D. Midwinter ... ; T. Woodward ... ; C. Bathurst ... ; and A. Ward ...
notes: Henry Morgan was a notorious pirate who captured numerous Spanish ships, as well as the towns of Puerto Principe (present-day Camaguey, Cuba), Portobelo (in Panama) and Maracaibo (in Venezuela). In 1674, after being granted a pardon by Charles II of England, Morgan was knighted and appointed Lieutenant-Governor of Jamaica. A translation of Alexander Olivier Exquemelin's 'De Americaanse zeerovers', first published in 1678.

Image_title: A Map of ye Country and City of Panama
Image_publisher: D. Midwinter ... ; T. Woodward ... ; C. Bathurst ... ; and A. Ward
Description: Map of the isthmus of Panama with north at the bottom. Cartographic details include compass rose, topographical details, locations of settlements and churches or missions, and plan of Panama City. Also includes armed men marching, ships, and armed men disembarking in boats.
Source_Title: [Americaanse zeerovers. English] The history of the bucaniers of America ... In two volumes
Source_publisher: printed for D. Midwinter ... ; T. Woodward ... ; C. Bathurst ... ; and A. Ward ...
notes: A translation of Alexander Olivier Exquemelin's 'De Americaanse zeerovers', first published in 1678.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The great Temple of Mexico.
Description: Bird's-eye view of the main temple [Templo mayor] of Mexico City (Tenochtitlán). The temple precinct is defined by a wall with serpents or snakes carved on it. Before two sanctuaries on the top of the temple, priests sacrifice a victim. A body is tossed down the stairs. Dancers celebrate in front of the temple within the wall. In foreground is probably a skull rack or tzompantli and native Americans with bows and arrows wearing feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_Title: The American traveller; being a new historical collection carefully compiled from original memoirs in several languages, ... containing a compleat account of that part of the world, now called the West Indies, from its discovery by Columbus to the present time. ...
Source_publisher: J. Fuller at the Dove in Creed-Lane
notes: Huitzilopochtli (god of war and the sun) and Tlaloc (god of rain) both had temples at the top of this structure.For similar images earlier than this one, cf. 01564-4 (1720) and especially 07639-3 (1723). For similar images later than this one, cf. 04878-39 (1752) and especially 05741-8 (1769) and 34575-5 (1778).Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Spanish Gratitude. Cortes orders Motezuma [sic] to be Fetter'd.
Description: Hernán Cortés, dressed in armor and holding a baton, directs another European to bind the hands of Montezuma (or Moctezuma) dressed in feathered headdress and garments.
Source_Title: The American traveller; being a new historical collection carefully compiled from original memoirs in several languages, ... containing a compleat account of that part of the world, now called the West Indies, from its discovery by Columbus to the present time. ...
Source_publisher: J. Fuller at the Dove in Creed-Lane
notes: Cortés probably arrested Montezuma (or Moctezuma) in order to prevent an Aztec uprising and perhaps in response to the deaths of several Spaniards at Almeria.
SubjectHeadings2: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, ca. 1480-1520

Image_title: Guayaquil.
Description: Chart of Guayaquil, Ecuador, and its harbor. Cartographic elements include soundings, compass rose, location of dwellings and rivers. Decorative elements include ships, alligator, and snake. Items in the image are identified in key at bottom.
Source_Title: Compendio historico de la provincia, partidos, ciudades, astilleros, rios, y puerto de Guayaquil ...
Source_publisher: Por Manuel Fernandez, impressor de la reverenda Camara Apostolica ...
notes: Image creator is probably the Spanish printmaker Pablo Minguet, active 1737-78.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [View of Lake Tezcuco (i. e. Lake Texcoco)]
Description: View of Lake Tezcuco [i. e. Lake Texcoco] with causeways, aquaduct, and surrounding towns. An army of men, some on horseback, enter the area of Tezcuco at the lower left. Elements labelled for identification in key at lower left of image.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de Mexico, poblacion, y progressos de la America Septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España. ...
Source_publisher: A Costa de Marcos-Miguel Bousquet Y Compañia
notes: Area depicted is now included in present-day Mexico City. In the early 1400s Tezcuco, Mexico, and Tlacopan formed a powerful league that grew by conquest. By the time of the Spanish invasion, Tezcuco was under the control of Tenochtitlan, but was still powerful. Lake Texcoco (as it is now known) once covered much of the ground now occupied by Mexico City. Cuyioacan (or Coyoacan) may be where Hernán Cortés lived. Suchimilco (or Xochimilco) was the site of a famous battle won by Cortés.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Francis Lolonois
Image_publisher: D. Midwinter ... ; T. Woodward ... ; C. Bathurst ... ; and A. Ward
Description: Portrait of François Lolonois.
Source_Title: [Americaanse zeerovers. English] The history of the bucaniers of America ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: printed for D. Midwinter ... ; T. Woodward ... ; C. Bathurst ... ; and A. Ward ...
notes: Jean David Nau, known as François L'Ollonais, was from Sables-d'Olonne in the Vendée, France, and had his base of operations at Tortuga. He captured and plundered the cities of Maracaibo and Gibraltar in 1666 and Puerto de Cavallo and San Pedro in May 1667, as well as numerous Spanish vessels. He was killed in Nicaragua by native Americans there. A translation of Alexander Olivier Exquemelin's 'De Americaanse zeerovers', first published in 1678.

Image_title: Hernan Cortes.
Description: Portrait of Hernán Cortés in armor and feathered hat carrying a baton. He is placed in front of a landscape that includes a sailboat and rowboat. Below his portrait are trophies of war including a cannon, cannonball (?), chain shot, halberd, armor, and flag.
Source_Title: The American traveller; being a new historical collection carefully compiled from original memoirs in several languages, ... containing a compleat account of that part of the world, now called the West Indies, from its discovery by Columbus to the present time. ...
Source_publisher: J. Fuller at the Dove in Creed-Lane
notes: Chain shot was used to tear the rigging and sails of an enemy ship so that it could not manoeuver.

Image_title: Capt. Henry Morgan before Panama.
Description: Portrait of Captain Henry Morgan before the fortifications of Panama. Military elements include ship, scene of naval warfare, sword, gun or musket, and boat.
Source_Title: [General history of the robberies and murders of the most notorious pyrates] A history of the lives and exploits of the most remarkable pirates, highwaymen, murderers, street-robbers, & c. ...
Source_publisher: Printed and sold by T. Aris, near the Swan, in the High-Street
notes: Henry Morgan was a notorious pirate who captured numerous Spanish ships, as well as the town of Portobelo in Panama. In 1674, after being granted a pardon by Charles II of England, Morgan was knighted and appointed Lieutenant-Governor of Jamaica. This work is often attributed to Defoe based on textual relationship to works of Defoe's proven authorship together with supporting external evidence.
References_exhibitions: Hattendorf, J.B. Boundless Deep, Fig. 6.23

Image_title: Vo. Ro. del V. Pe. Fy. Antonio Margìl de Jesus, Predicador Apostolico, Franciscano. aclamado por Apostol de Guatemala, en las Indias.
Description: Portrait of Antonio Margil de Jesus, a barefoot monk in patched habit, holding a crucifx before praying native Americans. Includes feathered headdresses, bows, and arrows.
Source_Title: El peregrino septentrional atlante: Delineado en la exemplarissima vida del venerable padre Fr. Antonio Margil de Jesus ...
Source_publisher: Por Joseph Thomas Lucas ... Vendese en casa de Salvador Faulì ...
notes: Antonio Margil de Jesus converted many native Americans from Texas, Mexico, and Central America. He founded two colleges in Guatemala and Mexico and is associated with the rebirth of the Franciscan apostolate in Mexico, and later Guatemala, Panama, and most of South America.

Image_title: [Native American and raft]
Description: Native American paddling a raft in Peru. Also includes a front view of the boat, a diagram of the animal skin bladders and balsa rods which make up the raft and the manner in which it was put together, a penguin, a seal or walrus on land. Also includes inset diagram of raft and method of lashing it together. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. German] Hrn. Frezier, Königl. französis. Ingenieurs, Reise nach der Süd-See, und denen Küsten von Chili, Peru und Brasilien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und verlegt bey seel. Thomas von Wierings Erben, im güldnen ABC.
notes: This image is derived from Frézier, Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chily ..., Paris, 1716.

Image_title: [Dress of the women of Peru]
Description: Dress or costume of women of Peru. Three Spanish women prepare and consume a drink made from a herb called a Paraguayan herb (maté?). Different items of clothing, a chupon, fatdellin, montera, and gregorillo are shown, as well as a silver wicker table and teapot or vessels. Items are lettered for identification in the key below the image. Also includes pictures on the wall and grill over the window.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. German] Hrn. Frezier, Königl. französis. Ingenieurs, Reise nach der Süd-See, und denen Küsten von Chili, Peru und Brasilien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und verlegt bey seel. Thomas von Wierings Erben, im güldnen ABC.
notes: Text discusses dress, dwellings, manners, and morals of the Spaniards in Peru.This image was derived from Frézier, Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily ..., Paris, 1716.

Image_title: [Inca and Indians of Peru]
Description: Inca and his queen with a child holding a parasol are flanked by a native American man and woman who offer gifts. Built environment includes native dwellings. Artifacts include a type of stove and three drinking vessels. Includes lettered key for identification. Also includes mantilla and ornaments.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. German] Hrn. Frezier, Königl. französis. Ingenieurs, Reise nach der Süd-See, und denen Küsten von Chili, Peru und Brasilien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und verlegt bey seel. Thomas von Wierings Erben, im güldnen ABC.
notes: Key states that the Inca and Coia [queen] were drawn from a picture made by the Indians of Cuzco.The stove is used to cook a herb.This image was derived from Frézier, Relation du voyage de la mer du sud aux côtes du Chily ..., Paris, 1716.

Image_title: [Fish and sea animals]
Description: Various fish, sea horse, and a crustacean or lobster. Includes a barracuda [?], a swordfish seen from the bottom and from the side, a seahorse, and a pejegallo or elephant fish.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. German] Hrn. Frezier, Königl. französis. Ingenieurs, Reise nach der Süd-See, und denen Küsten von Chili, Peru und Brasilien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und verlegt bey seel. Thomas von Wierings Erben, im güldnen ABC.
notes: Elephantfish or Callorhinchus callorynchus.

Image_title: [top] Prospect von Penco. [bottom] Grund: Riss der Stadt Penco beleg: auf der Küste von Chil: 30 45 gr: Südl:
Description: [top] View of the settlement of Penco, Chile. Includes dwellings, bridge, and church. [bottom] Plan of Penco. Cartographic elements include some topographical details and location of rivers.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. German] Hrn. Frezier, Königl. französis. Ingenieurs, Reise nach der Süd-See, und denen Küsten von Chili, Peru und Brasilien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und verlegt bey seel. Thomas von Wierings Erben, im güldnen ABC.
notes: Penco is located in the former location of Concepcion, the capital of the Bio-Bio province of Chile. After earthquakes and tsunamis in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries destroyed the city, Concepcion was moved to its present site. Those who remained in that location formed the town of Penco.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Die Rheed Valparaisso mit den benachbarten Cüsten Unterm 32 Gr. 55 min. Süder-Breite.
Description: Plan of Valparaiso, Chile, with an inset plan of the settlement showing location of fortifications, streets, and church square. Also includes profile of mountains around Valpariso and profile of the fort. Cartographic elements include compass rose, some topographical details, scale, and locations of rivers.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. German] Hrn. Frezier, Königl. französis. Ingenieurs, Reise nach der Süd-See, und denen Küsten von Chili, Peru und Brasilien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und verlegt bey seel. Thomas von Wierings Erben, im güldnen ABC.
notes: Presently Chile's most important seaport, Valparaiso did not become a major habor until after the country's independence from Spain.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Grund Riss der Stadt und Vestung Callao auf der Cüste von Peru.
Description: Plan of Callao, Peru, showing location of fortifications, streets, and churches. Also includes a profile of the towers and bastion, a diagram of the surveying technique, and a view of Callao. Includes cannons, military matériel, and scale.
Source_Title: [Relation du voyage de la mer du Sud aux côtes du Chili, du Pérou, et du Brésil, fait pendant les années 1712, 1713, & 1714. German] Hrn. Frezier, Königl. französis. Ingenieurs, Reise nach der Süd-See, und denen Küsten von Chili, Peru und Brasilien
Source_publisher: Gedruckt und verlegt bey seel. Thomas von Wierings Erben, im güldnen ABC.
notes: This plan was also printed in Francisco Coreal, Voyages de François Coreal aux Indes Occidentales, Paris, 1722.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Vuë d'une Place preparée pour une Course de Taureaux, en la Ville de Cuenca au Perou ...
Description: Riot at a bullring in Cuenca, Peru. Jean Semiergues defends himself with a sword and pistol or gun against a mob. Includes priests or monks, spectators in the galleries, and scene of fighting. Also includes churches, dwellings, and the bulls destined for the bull fight in the background. Items in the image are numbered and lettered for identification in keys at bottom.
Source_Title: Lettre a Madame *** sur l'emeute populaire excitée en la ville de Cuenca au Perou, le 29. d'Août 1739 ...
Source_publisher: Veuve Pissot
notes: This book tells the fate of the surgeon of La Condamine's scientific expedition, Jean Semiergues, who was killed by a mob in a bullring on August 29, 1639, after defending a woman, Manuele de Quesada, who had been jilted by her fiancé. La Condamine, explorer, physicist, and advocate of smallpox innoculation, went to South America in 1735 to measure a meridian that would establish the flattening of the Earth toward its poles.

Image_title: [Title page]
Image_publisher: Por la Viuda de Joseph Bernardo de Hogal
Description: View of Mexico City during a plague. Our Lady of Guadalupe with angels comes to the aid of clergy and faithful during the epidemic of 1737.
Source_Title: Escudo de armas de Mexico: Celestial proteccion de esta nobilissima ciudad, de la Nueva-España ... Maria Santisssima, en su potentos imagen del Mexicano Guadalupe
Source_publisher: Por la Viuda de D. Joseph Bernardo de Hogal, impressora del Real, y Apostolico Tribunal de la Santa Cruzada, en todo este Reyno
notes: José Ibarra (1688-1756), a Mexican artist of religious subjects, probably painted the original from which this engraving was made.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: A Calash much used at Lima & all over Peru
Description: A calash or carriage drawn by a horse. A black man rides the horse. Includes whip.
Source_Title: [Individual, y verdadera relacion de la extrema ruyna que padeciò la Ciudad de los Reyes Lima. English] A true and particular relation of the dreadful earthquakes which happen'd at Lima ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Osborne in Grey's Inn
notes: A calash is a four-seater carriage with a hood, often two-wheeled.

Image_title: A Creole-Lady in her Dress within Doors
Description: A creole woman of Lima wearing an elaborate dress with ruffled petticoat inside a house. A black boy [slave?] hands her a letter. Includes dog, bird, chair, painting, and mirrors.
Source_Title: [Individual, y verdadera relacion de la extrema ruyna que padeciò la Ciudad de los Reyes Lima. English] A true and particular relation of the dreadful earthquakes which happen'd at Lima ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Osborne in Grey's Inn
notes: Text describes the faldellin, or short hoop petticoat, worn by women of Lima.

Image_title: A Creole-Lady veiled, going to Church.
Description: A creole woman of Lima wearing an elaborate dress with ruffled petticoat goes to church attended by two black women [slaves?].
Source_Title: [Individual, y verdadera relacion de la extrema ruyna que padeciò la Ciudad de los Reyes Lima. English] A true and particular relation of the dreadful earthquakes which happen'd at Lima ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Osborne in Grey's Inn

Image_title: A Creole Don & Donna in their Dress, when abroad at Night.
Description: A creole man and woman of Lima dressed to go out at night. Includes shawls, hats, and ruffled petticoat.
Source_Title: [Individual, y verdadera relacion de la extrema ruyna que padeciò la Ciudad de los Reyes Lima. English] A true and particular relation of the dreadful earthquakes which happen'd at Lima ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Osborne in Grey's Inn

Image_title: A Mulatta-Woman in her Dress by day.
Description: A mulatto or black woman wearing an elaborate dress with ruffled petticoat and sleeves stands outside a church [?] in a town square. Includes a man standing beside her.
Source_Title: [Individual, y verdadera relacion de la extrema ruyna que padeciò la Ciudad de los Reyes Lima. English] A true and particular relation of the dreadful earthquakes which happen'd at Lima ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Osborne in Grey's Inn

Image_title: [Native American houses and transportation]
Description: A litter carried by two llamas [?] passes through a settlement in Peru. A native American [?] riding a horse accompanies the litter. Built environment includes dwellings. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at bottom.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional ... Segunda parte, Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: An account of the expedition sent by the French Académie Royale des Sciences in 1735 to measure a degree of the meridian at the equator.

Image_title: [Animals of Peru]
Description: Various animals of South America. Pelican, seals, and a bull are shown. A Chilean is shown in his poncho and another native American is lassoing the bull. Also included are plants which are being harvested and a spear. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional ... Segunda parte, Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: This image is from an account of the expedition sent by the Académie Royale des Sciences in 1735 to measure a degree of the meridian at the equator.

Image_title: [Costumes, animals, and modes of transportation of Peru]
Creator2_role: Tallador extrao. d[e] las Rs. Cs. d[e] Monda. la abrio.
Description: Men and women of Peru in a landscape with animals. Includes woman of Lima in riding dress, a woman in house-keeping dress, a Spaniard in Peruvian dress, a mulatto woman, a black servant, and a mulatto woman riding a horse. Animals include llama, vicuña, and huanaco or guanaco. Also includes people being driven in a calash or two-wheeled carriage and a building. Items are lettered for identification in key at upper right of image.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional ... Segunda parte, Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: A calash is a four-seater carriage with a hood, often two-wheeled, used in Lima. Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian.

Image_title: Demostracion de la Montaña de Sn. Antonio, con la de los precipicios y Viesgo de su Camino.
Description: Man on horseback is seen traveling a narrow mountain path with the help of a guide. Includes stream.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo primero
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian.

Image_title: [Women of Peru and methods of crossing rivers]
Description: Women of Peru including native American, mestiza, and Spanish women. Includes a rope bridge, a horse being pulled across the river on a harness, and a man suspended in a hammock who is being pulled across the gorge. Also includes various dwellings.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo primero
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian.

Image_title: [Plants, animals, and people of Peru]
Description: Plants and people of Peru including trees, plants, insects, crustaceans, birds, and reptiles. Items such as the manzanillo tree, banana and cocoa palm, zapote tree, guanabana or guanbana (soursop) tree, guayabas (guava) tree, papaya tree, snakes, scorpion, snails, bird [swift?], toucan, pineapples, dwelling, black or native American pushing a wheelbarrow, woman carrying a basket on her head, and woman identified as a mulatto.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo primero
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian. Items in the image lettered for identification in key below.

Image_title: [Houses and animals of Peru and Ecuador]
Description: Native American dwellings and boats, canoes, or pirogues are shown. Also includes animals such as an armadillo and alligator or cayman, plants such as cacao tree and cacao shrub (vijahua), (sugar?) canes, and matapalo or strangler fig tree, and sura (or houses of the Rio Guayas). Also includes hammock and man fishing using a balsa log for a boat.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo primero
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: The strangler fig, Ficus destruens, begins life as a epiphyte in the branches of a host tree. It sends out roots that root in the soil beneath the host and begin to grow around the trunk of the host tree which eventually dies. Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian. Items in the image lettered for identification in key below.

Image_title: [Methods of slaughtering cattle in Chile]
Creator2_role: Tallador extrao. d[e] las Rs. Cs. d[e] Monda. la abrio.
Description: Manner of capturing and slaughtering beasts in Chile. Includes a quarry or shell midden, a man killing an animal with a hatchet, a man with a cow tied to a tree, a man riding after a cow, a horse descending a hill, a pajaro niño or penguin, sea wolves or
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Segunda parte, Tomo tercero.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin

Image_title: Balsa de Guayaquil dibujada con sus proporciones.
Description: A balsa raft with a shelter and native Americans on it. Parts of the raft are lettered for identification in key within cartouche.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo primero.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: An account of the expedition sent by the French Académie Royale des Sciences in 1735 to measure a degree of the meridian at the equator. The participants included the Frenchmen, La Condamine, Godin, and Bouguer, and the Spaniards, Ulloa and Juan y Santaci

Image_title: [Natural phenomena]
Description: Various natural phenomena including (fig. 1) an eruption of the volcano, Cotopaxi, (fig. 2) a whole triple rainbow or fogbow in Pambamarca, in present-day Ecuador, (fig. 3) a series of reflections from the moon projected on the tops of a mountain, perhaps lunar fogbows or dewbows. Also includes tent and observation tripod.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo segundo.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: These mysterious phenomena, described in great detail by Ulloa, have been analyzed by optical specialists. Ulloa is credited with the first observation of a white rainbow or fogbow (also known as a "circle of Ulloa" in his honor). Fig. 3, a more mysterious observation (seen by Ulloa on the plain of Turubambaat in April 1738 and by George Juan on the mountain of Quinoa-Loma in May 1739), presented as a series of colorless arcs intersecting at one point and seen by the light of the moon. This phenomenon may be an inner lunar fog-bow accompanied by a primary reflected lunar fog-bow.Cotopaxi eruption of 1743 was observed by Ulloa.
References: Wilk, S.R. "Antonio de Ulloa's mystery," Optics & Photonics News, April 2004, p. 16-19

Image_title: [Native American artifacts from the grave mounds of ancient Peruvians or Inca.]
Description: Native American or Inca artifacts, including ax heads, pectorals, earthenware vessels, mirrors, ornaments, tupus (or large pins for fastening clothing), earrings, and tweezers for pulling out facial hair, other funerary artifacts, and depiction of the grave mound. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key above.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo segundo.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: A huaca, in Quechua, is either an object that represents something revered or the specific locale or shrine, which is venerated and holy, and can be a burial chamber of a mummified ancestor.

Image_title: [Native American dwellings and religious places.]
Description: Native American or Inca religious buildings and dwellings. Includes the ruins of a native American temple in Cayambe, huacas or mounds, a fortified site or pucaras, and the contemporary town of Cayambe. Includes church and fortifications. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key above.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo segundo.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: A huaca, in Quechua, is either an object that represents something revered or the specific locale or shrine, which is venerated and holy, and can be a burial chamber of a mummified ancestor.Cayambe is the highest and coldest point on the equator. Cayambe is both a volcano, long thought to be extinct, and an inhabited place.

Image_title: [View of native American palace near a mountain and river.]
Description: View of a ruined native American or Inca palace near a mountain named Panecillo and a river in a ravine in the alpine plain of Cotopaxi. Also includes dwellings. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key above.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo segundo.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: Panecillo hill outside of the present-day city of Quito, Ecuador, was used by native peoples as a place to worship the sun.

Image_title: Plano del Palacio, y Fortaleza delos Reyes Yngas, que en parte existe, y se halla cerca del Pueblo de Cañar...
Description: Plan of a ruined native American or Inca palace near Cañar, in the province of Quito, Ecuador. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key above.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo segundo.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: The most important archeological site of the Inca in Ecuador, Ingapirca was built as a religious site and as an inn for Incan couriers. It was later fortified under the Cañaris of Huayna Capac and used as a resting place for the emperor, as well as a temple.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Vista y perspectiva de la Fortaleza y Palacio que los Reyes Yngas tenian en el Territorio de Cañar cuias Paredes se Conservan.
Description: Bird's-eye view of a native American or Inca palace near Cañar, in the province of Quito, Ecuador. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key in previous plate.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo segundo.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: The most important archeological site of the Inca in Ecuador, Ingapirca was built as a religious site and as an inn for Incan couriers. It was later fortified under the Cañaris of Huayna Capac and used as a resting place for the emperor, as well as a temple.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The burning of the Town of Payta on the Coast of Santa Fee in the South Sea
Description: View of the sacking of the town of Paita in present-day Peru. Includes scene of a town burning, sunken ships, ships, and a church. Items in the image are lettered and identified in key at bottom.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world, in the years MDCCXL, I, II, III, IV. By George Anson ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the Author; By John and Paul Knapton, in Ludgate-Street
notes: George Anson, first baron Anson, a commodore in the British Royal Navy, set sail on a circumnavigation in 1740. Anson's orders were to raid Spanish possessions along the South American coast and to disrupt their trade. Anson made a successful attack on Paita in November 1741.

Image_title: A View of the Commodores Tent at the Island of Juan Fernandes.
Description: A European man holding a walking stick walks toward three tents set in a clearing in the woods. Includes a goat [?], a dog, and other men.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world, in the years MDCCXL, I, II, III, IV. By George Anson ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the Author; By John and Paul Knapton, in Ludgate-Street
notes: The archipelago of Juan Fernández islands of the coast of Chile are known primarily for being the home of the marooned sailor Alexander Selkirk who had been on William Dampier's expedition. In 1704, having doubts about the seaworthiness of the ship he was on, Selkirk asked to be left on Juan Fernandez Island, also known as Mas a Tierra, but now known as Isla Robinson Crusoe. His story is said to have inspired Defoe to write Robinson Crusoe. George Anson, first baron Anson, a commodore in the British Royal Navy, set sail on a circumnavigation in 1740. Anson's orders were to raid Spanish possessions along the South American coast and to disrupt their trade.

Image_title: [Mount Capiro with tamandua and battle between mulatto and tiger]
Description: Landscape with view of Mount Capiro [Capira?] in present-day Panama. In the foreground are a tamandua and a mulatto fighting with a so-called tiger. Items are lettered for identification in key at bottom of image.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Primera parte, Tomo primero.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: An account of the expedition sent by the French Académie Royale des Sciences in 1735 to measure a degree of the meridian at the equator. The participants included the Frenchmen, La Condamine, Godin, and Bouguer, and the Spaniards, Ulloa and Juan y Santaci

Image_title: [River scene with boat and various birds]

Image_title: A Sea=Lion and Lioness.
Description: Sea lion, male and female, lie on a beach with seashells.
Source_Title: A voyage round the world, in the years MDCCXL, I, II, III, IV. By George Anson ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the Author; By John and Paul Knapton, in Ludgate-Street
notes: These animals were observed around the Juan Fernández islands off the coast of Chile, perhaps the South American, southern or Patagonian sea lion (scientific name:Otaria flavescens). The archipelago of Juan Fernández Islands of the coast of Chile are known primarily for being the home of the marooned sailor Alexander Selkirk who had been on William Dampier's expedition. In 1704, having doubts about the seaworthiness of the ship he was on, Selkirk asked to be left on Juan Fernandez Island, also known as Mas a Tierra, but now known as Isla Robinson Crusoe. His story is said to have inspired Defoe to write Robinson Crusoe. George Anson, first baron Anson, a commodore in the British Royal Navy, set sail on a circumnavigation in 1740.
