Image_title: Monte Vidio
Description: Plan of Montevideo in present-day Uruguay, a small fortified colony on the Rio de la Plata. Built environment includes fortifications, church, well, and dwellings. Also includes ship, pile of rocks, and compass rose. Items in the image are lettered and numbered for identification in text following the plan.
Source_Title: Relacaõ do sitio, que o governador de Buenos Aires D. Miguel de Salcedo poz no anno de 1735 à praca da nova colonia do Sacramento, sendo governador da mesma praca Antonio Pedro de Vasconcellos
Source_publisher: Na officina de Francisco Luiz Ameno, impres. da Congregacaõ Camer. da S. Igreja de Lisboa
notes: The Spanish first built a fort on the site of Montevideo in 1726 to resist Portuguese expansion at Colonia del Sacramento on the Rio de la Plata. Identification of artist and engraver from Moraes.
References: R. B. de Moraes. Bibliographia braziliana, 1983, 2:812.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Planta da Cidade de Buènus Ayres
Description: View of Buenos Aires, in present-day Argentina. Built environment includes fortifications, dwellings, towers, ships, and churches. Items in the image are lettered and numbered for identification in text following the plan.
Source_Title: Relacaõ do sitio, que o governador de Buenos Aires D. Miguel de Salcedo poz no anno de 1735 à praca da nova colonia do Sacramento, sendo governador da mesma praca Antonio Pedro de Vasconcellos
Source_publisher: Na officina de Francisco Luiz Ameno, impres. da Congregacaõ Camer. da S. Igreja de Lisboa
notes: The Portuguese established the Sacramento colony (in existence from 1680 to 1828), now Colonia del Sacramento, on the east bank of the Rio de la Plata in present-day Uruguay, across from the Spanish town of Buenos Aires. Identification of artist and engraver from Moraes.
References: Moraes, R.B. de. Bibliog. brasiliana (1983 ed.) p. 812
References_exhibitions: Schaeffer, D. Portuguese exploration, p. 52
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plan of the Town of Callao as it was before the Earthquake in 1746
Description: Plan of the town of Callao as it was before the earthquake of 1746. Includes profile of the town, as well as profile of the bastion or wall construction. Decorative cartouche includes military matériel such as cannons, shields, and musical instruments such as trumpets. Also includes scale and compass rose. Items in the image are lettered and numbered for identification in key at right.
Source_Title: [Individual, y verdadera relacion de la extrema ruyna que padeciò la Ciudad de los Reyes Lima. English] A true and particular relation of the dreadful earthquakes which happen'd at Lima ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Osborne in Grey's Inn
notes: Founded in 1537 and the harbor for Lima, Callao was completely destroyed in 1746 by the earthquake which damaged much of Lima.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plano scenographico, dela ciud[a]d. delos Reyes, ò Lima capital delos Reynos del Perú ...
Description: Plan of Lima, Peru, showing fortifications of the city, buildings, dwellings, gardens, churches, monasteries, and squares. Also includes scales. Items in the image are numbered for identification in key at top right.
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional ... Segunda parte, Tomo tercero
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: Lima was extensively rebuilt with wide streets, plazas, and elaborate churches after the devastating earthquake of 1746. Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: El Puerto de el Callao, en el Mar Pacyfyco, que el sur: ...
Description: Map of the port of Callao, Peru, and its bay. Cartographic elements include compass rose, topographical details, soundings, scales, and names of geographical features. Items are lettered for identification in key at right within image. Letter H represents
Source_Title: Relacion historica del viage a la America meridional ... Segunda parte, Tomo tercero.
Source_publisher: Por Antonio Marin
notes: Callao was and is the largest port in Peru. Founded in 1537, it was the main port for Spanish commerce in the Pacific, handling exports from Peru, Bolivia, and Argentina. In 1746, a tsunami caused by an earthquake destroyed it.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Quipus of 40 master words]
Description: A series of knotted ropes (or quipu) of forty master words.
Source_creator: Sansevero, Raimondo di Sangro, principe di, 1710-1770
Source_Title: Lettera apologetica dell'esercitato accademico della crusca contenente la difesa del libro intitolato lettere d'una Peruana per rispetto alla supposizione de' Quipu
notes: In this book, Raimondo di Sangro defends Françoise d'Issembourg d'Happoncourt Graffigny, Lettres d'une peruvienne, published anonymously, Paris, 1747. His book is the earliest full study of quipus, although he erroneously believed that quipus were a writing system.
References: Cañizares-Esguerra, J. How to write the history of the New World, p. 115-118, plate I
References_exhibitions: Hough, S.J. Italians and the creation of America, 66
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Source_creator: Sansevero, Raimondo di Sangro, principe di, 1710-1770
Source_Title: Lettera apologetica dell'esercitato accademico della crusca contenente la difesa del libro intitolato lettere d'una Peruana per rispetto alla supposizione de' Quipu
notes: In this book, Raimondo di Sangro defends Françoise d'Issembourg d'Happoncourt Graffigny, Lettres d'une peruvienne, published anonymously, Paris, 1747. His book is the earliest full study of quipus, although he erroneously believed that quipus were a writing system. The coloring on this plate is achieved through hand coloring and the author's invention, a letterpress coloring process.
References: Cañizares-Esguerra, J. How to write the history of the New World, plate 2, p. 115-118
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Description: A man in a room observes the sky through a telescope. Another man measures the time by observing a wall clock. Through an open door, which a boy opens, a volcano is erupting.
Source_Title: Mesure des trois premiers degrés du méridien dans l'hémisphere austral ...
Source_publisher: de l'Imprimerie royale
notes: In 1735 La Condamine led a scientific expedition to Quito to measure the location of the equator in order to determine the form of the earth. Discovering that tall mountains deflected the pendulum used in triangulation, he fairly accurately measured the meridian in Ecuador.

Image_title: Vue de la Place de l'Ile de Juan Fernandes ou le Commandeur avoit sa Tente.
Description: View of the encampment of Commodore George Anson on Juan Fernandez Island. Includes tents, dog, and goat.
Source_Title: [Voyage round the world. French] Voyage autour du monde, fait dans les années MDCCXL, I, II, III, IV. Par Georges Anson
Source_publisher: Chez Arkstée & Merkus
notes: Anson's circumnavigation was beset by difficulties. Only one ship out of six finished the voyage. By the time his fleet reached Juan Fernandez Island, the only sanctuary available for the English ship along the Spanish controlled western coast of South America, two thirds of his crew had perished. Piercy Brett, lieutenant on The Centurion, was responsible for the drawings which became part of the narrative of the journey. This image is derived from his sketches and earlier editions of Walter's book.

Image_title: Incendie de la Ville de Paita, sur la Côte du Perou dans la Mer du Sud.
Description: View of the town of Paita, Peru, in flames after an attack by a squadron of ships. Includes ships, some sunk, settlement, dwellings, church, flags, and boat. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: [Voyage round the world. French] Voyage autour du monde, fait dans les années MDCCXL, I, II, III, IV. Par Georges Anson
Source_publisher: Chez Arkstée & Merkus
notes: Anson's circumnavigation was beset by difficulties. Only one ship out of six finished the voyage. By the time his fleet reached Juan Fernandez Island, the only sanctuary available for the English ship along the Spanish controlled western coast of South America, two thirds of his crew had perished. Anson's orders were to raid Spanish possessions along the South American coast and disrupt their trade. He succeeded in sacking Paita in November 1741.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Observationibus astronom Regiae Paris Scientiar Academiae Promontorium Palmar Equatori subjacere compertum est
Description: A man engraves title into a rock while in background men canoe to shore where scientific instruments, a quadrant which is nailed into the ground and a pendulum protected under a shelter, are located.
Source_Title: Journal du voyage fait par ordre du Roi, a l'equateur servant d'introduction historique a la Mesure des trois premiers degrés du Méridien
Source_publisher: de l'Imprimerie royale
notes: La Condamine was one of three scientists sent by the Académie Royale des Sciences to Peru in 1735 to measure the length of a degree of meridian at the equator. The three soon separated and made independent measurements, finishing in 1743. His research was used to prove that the earth flattens toward its poles. This book was the first scientific account of the Amazon River. Engraver is probably Pierre Etienne Moitte, 1722-1780.

Image_title: Plan Profil et Elevation des deux Pyramides ...
Description: Plan, profile, and elevation drawings of two pyramids erected in the Yarouqui plain, near Quito, Peru (present-day Ecuador).
Source_Title: Journal du voyage fait par ordre du Roi, a l'equateur servant d'introduction historique a la Mesure des trois premiers degrés du Méridien
Source_publisher: de l'Imprimerie royale
notes: La Condamine was one of three scientists sent by the Académie Royale des Sciences to Peru in 1735 to measure the length of a degree of meridian at the equator. The three soon separated and made independent measurements, finishing in 1743. La Condamine's research was used to prove that the earth flattens toward its poles. This book was the first scientific account of the Amazon River.

Image_title: [Astronomical calculations]
Description: A man makes a reading using a quadrant or surveying instrument with an altazimuth mount before a tent in a mountainous landscape. Two men climb a mountain in the background. Includes volcanoes.
Source_Title: Mesure des trois premiers degrés du méridien dans l'hémisphere austral, tirée des observations de Mrs. de l'Académie royale des sciences, envoyés par le roi sous l'́Équateur
Source_publisher: de l'Imprimerie royale
notes: In 1735 La Condamine led a scientific expedition to Quito to measure the location of the equator in order to determine the form of the earth. Discovering that tall mountains deflected the pendulum used in triangulation, he fairly accurately measured the meridian in Ecuador.

Image_title: Karte von den triangeln der Mittags Linie zu Quito ...
Description: Map showing the triangulations made to measure a degree of the meridian on the equator. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude, a scale, some topographical details, and locations of rivers and settlements.
Source_Title: Reisen nach Peru, Acadien und Egypten ...
Source_publisher: Verlegts Abram Vandenhoeks seel. Wittwe
notes: This book is a translation of three books by different authors. The first part contains the first part of Pierre Bouguer, La figure de la terre, Paris, 1749, which contains an account of Bouguer's scientific mission to Peru (actually, present-day Ecuador) which he took with Charles Marie de La Condamine to measure a degree of the meridian near the equator.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Profile and topographical view of the land near Quito]
Description: Profile and topographical view of the the Cordiller mountain range near Quito, present-day Ecuador. Includes volcanos, scale, and letters which identify mountain peaks in text. Also shows elevation.
Source_Title: Reisen nach Peru, Acadien und Egypten
Source_publisher: Verlegts Abram Vandenhoeks seel. Wittwe
notes: This book is a translation of three books by different authors. The first part contains the first part of Pierre Bouguer, La figure de la terre, Paris, 1749, which contains an account of Bouguer's scientific mission to Peru (actually, present-day Ecuador) which he took with Charles Marie de La Condamine to measure a degree of the meridian near the equator.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plan d'une Baye de la Côte du Chili découverte par un des Vaisseaux d'Avituaillement de l"Escadre de Mr. Anson, en 1741.
Description: Plan of a bay in Chile with a detail of an island called Inchin by the native Americans. Cartographic elements include profiles of the coast, soundings, sea banks or shoals, compass rose, and scale.
Source_Title: [Voyage round the world. French] Voyage autour du monde, fait dans les années MDCCXL, I, II, III, IV. Par Georges Anson
Source_publisher: Chez Arkstée & Merkus
notes: Anson's circumnavigation was beset by difficulties. Only one ship out of six finished the voyage. By the time his fleet reached Juan Fernandez Island, the only sanctuary available for the English ship along the Spanish controlled western coast of South America, two thirds of his crew had perished.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Vue de la Base mesurée dans la plaine d'Yarouqui pres de Quito ... sous un arc qui comprend 180. degrez de l'horison ...
Description: View of the Yaroqui plain including factory, dwellings, churches, and mountains. Items in the image are identified in key below. Includes location of mountains such as Cotopaxi, Pithintcha, and others, as well as the pyramids of Carabourou and Oyambaro.
Source_Title: Journal du voyage fait par ordre du Roi, a l'equateur servant d'introduction historique a la Mesure des trois premiers degrés du Méridien
Source_publisher: de l'Imprimerie royale
notes: La Condamine was one of three scientists sent by the Académie Royale des Sciences to Peru, or present-day Ecuador, in 1735 to measure the length of a degree of meridian at the equator. The three soon separated and made independent measurements, finishing in 1743. His research was used to prove that the earth flattens toward its poles. This book was the first scientific account of the Amazon River.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plan de Quito Capitale de la Province de même nom dans le Royaume de Pérou ...
Creator1_role: Levé au pas ... Ingr. du Roy
Description: Plan of Quito, Peru (present-day Ecuador). Cartographic elements include the meridian line drawn through the tower of the church of Mercy [La Merced], location of Pitchincha volcano, some topographical details, and a scale. Decorative cartouche includes Peruvians, cactus, and pineapples. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at right.
Source_Title: Journal du voyage fait par ordre du Roi, a l'equateur servant d'introduction historique a la Mesure des trois premiers degrés du Méridien
Source_publisher: de l'Imprimerie royale
notes: La Condamine was one of three scientists sent by the Académie Royale des Sciences to Peru in 1735 to measure the length of a degree of meridian at the equator. The three soon separated and made independent measurements, finishing in 1743. La Condamine's research was used to prove that the earth flattens toward its poles. Jean-Louis Morainville was the engineer who accompanied La Condamine on his expedition. He disappeared in the Amazon in 1744. This book was the first scientific account of the Amazon River.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Man on raft and native Americans]
Description: A European man carrying a sword travels down a river on a raft while native Americans run alongside the river. In the background native Americans dip large ladles into the river. Includes dwellings.
Source_Title: Des See-Capitains Franz Urban Bawiers Merckwürdige Reisen und Begebenheiten seine Kriegsdienste zu Lande Seefahrten nach Ost- und Westindien ...
Source_publisher: verlegts Georg Peter Monath
notes: This event seems to have happened after the author had been dropped off in Panama. He also mentions having been in Darien. He is shown here having lived with the natives for a while and built a raft. This may be an imaginary voyage.

Image_title: [Bawiers greets a hermit praying in front of a cross]
Description: A group of European men carrying guns or muskets approaches a man kneeling in front of a cross.
Source_Title: Des See-Capitains Franz Urban Bawiers Merckwürdige Reisen und Begebenheiten seine Kriegsdienste zu Lande Seefahrten nach Ost- und Westindien ...
Source_publisher: verlegts Georg Peter Monath
notes: After having looted the Chilean city of Arica (the port from which the silver mined at Potosí was shipped) with some freebooters, Bawiers discovered a hermit praying. Text states that Bawiers greeted him in Spanish and was taken to his hut which contained a crucifix, a book, and a skull. This may be an imaginary voyage.

Image_title: Das alte Mexico.
Description: Bird's-eye view of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing the various islands, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city. Also includes men on horseback, domestic animals, boats, churches, dwellings, wicker dams, and main square.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: The city is probably shown as the artist imagined Tenochtitlán was before Europeans arrived, but with European-type houses and churches. Cuyioacan (or Coyoacan) may be where Hernán Cortés lived. Suchimilco (or Xochimilco) was the site of a famous battle won by Cortés. The image is derived from Carol Allard, Orbis habitabilis oppida et vestitas, Amsterdam 1681, who in turn derived his view from the Hernán Cortés map-view of Tenochtitlán. This image is similar to the one printed in Antonio de Solís, Histoire de la conquête du Mexique, Paris, 1691, following p. 272. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Tänze Mitotes.
Description: Method of dancing among native Mexicans. Men dance while standing on each other's shoulders and while walking on a rope. Also includes a man being ferried across a river. Includes musical instruments such as drums, feathered headdresses and garments, and bows and arrows.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9, 3rd part, plate 11, which describes the dances of the Mexicans. The image of how Mexicans cross rivers is from the same Theodor de Bry, Pt. 9, 3rd part, plate 2. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.

Image_title: Der grosse Tempel in Mexico.
Description: Bird's-eye view of the main temple [the Templo mayor] of Mexico City. The temple is encircled by a wall with serpents or snakes carved on it and two sanctuaries on the top before which priests sacrifice a victim. A body is tossed down the stairs. Dancers celebrate before the temple within the wall. In foreground are a skull rack or tzompantli and native Americans with bows and arrows wearing feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: The great temple at Tenochtitlán was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc, the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli. Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. Tlaloc, the god of rain and agriculture, was of pre-Aztec, or Toltec, origin. A coatepantli or wall made of sculpted serpents often surrounds Aztec temples. The tzompantli would hold the skulls of sacrificial victims. This image is similar to the one printed in Antonio de Solís, Histoire de la conquête du Mexique, Paris, 1691. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.

Image_title: Götzenbild Viztzilipuztli.
Description: Scene of worship and human sacrifice at a native American or Mexican temple. The victim's heart is cut out before an idol or statue by a priest with a knife. The priest's assistants hold the victim by all four limbs. Includes feathered headdress, statues of men in feathered headdresses and garments, and an alcove holding the idol who holds a shield with arrows and a snake.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: The great temple at Tenochtitlán was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc, the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli. Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. Tlaloc, the god of rain and agriculture, was of pre-Aztec, or Toltec, origin. This image is similar to the one printed in Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, Historia general, Antwerp, 1728, which, in turn, is derived from Plate 8 of Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.

Image_title: Der Sonnen Tempel.
Description: Sun temple of the Incas. Native Americans are shown processing to the temple, dancing, and worshipping the sun.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: This image is derived from the title page of Garsilasso de la Vega, Le commentaire royal, ov L'histoire des Yncas, Paris, 1633. This image is similar to the one printed in Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas, Historia general, Antwerp, 1728, which, in turn, is derived from Plate 8 of Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Art der Yncas die Prinzen vom Geblüt zu verheiraten.
Description: Native American marriage or wedding ceremony between two members of Inca nobility. In the background are dwellings and fortifications of a city. Also includes feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: This image is derived from Garsilasso de la Vega, Histoire des Incas, Amsterdam, 1737. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Marriage customs and rites

Image_title: Verschiedene Arten von Schmuck, deren sich die Indianer in ihren Tänzen bedienen.
Description: Native American artifacts include headdresses, belts, collars, a camiza or stole, and a cuÿu or apron.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.

Image_title: Feÿerlicher Umgang zu Ehren der Götter auf der Insel Hispaniola.
Description: Native Americans dance and worship before a many-headed idol in a temple or dwelling. Includes feathered headdresses and garments, offerings of baskets of food, man playing musical instrument or drum, and winged devils.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: This image is derived from plate 24 in Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 4, which describes the feast days of native Americans in Hispaniola. The cacique or chief would lead his people by beating a drum to the worship of their idol, a strange hydra-like creature with several heads. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.

Image_title: Gebrauche der Yncas wenn sie die Prinzen vom Geblüt zu Rittern schlagen.
Description: Native American ceremony for initiation into nobility. The Inca king, enthroned in a Western (Classical) architectural setting, pierces the earlobe of one of his subjects. Other prospective "princes" await their turns and have sandals fitted on their feet. Decorative elements include statues in niches with reliefs of native birds, beasts, and insects.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: The image is derived from Garcilaso de la Vega, Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Amsterdam, 1737. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Der erste Ynca Manco Capac, und die Königin Mama Oello Huaco versamlen die Wilden und legen den Grund zur Hauptstadt Cuzco
Description: Native Americans bow down before the Inca king and queen. In the background, others build the Inca capital, Cuzco. Cultural artifacts include feathered headdresses, earrings, bow and arrow, dwellings, and club.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: Manco Capac, with his sister Mama-Ocllo (Oello), known as children of the Sun, were revered as the progenitors of Inca civilization. The last Inca emperor was also named Manco Capac and crowned as a puppet king by Francisco Pizarro. The engraver may be Johann David Schleuen who flourished from 1740-1774. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: 1. Mulatresse à Cheval . 2. Caléche à la maniere de Lima. 3. Vicogne ... 4. Huanaco ... 5. Llama
Description: Mulatto rides a horse. In the background a caleche or carriage is shown with two people being carried while another rides the mule or horse that pulls it. In the foreground are a vicuña, huanaco [guanaco], and llama.
Source_Title: [Relación histórica del viage a la America meridional. French] Voyage historique de l'Amerique meridionale ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez Arkstée & Merkus
notes: The calash used in Lima, Peru, was a four-seater carriage with a hood, often two-wheeled. This image is derived from Ulloa, Relación histórica, Madrid, 1748. Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian.

Image_title: 1. Femme de Lima en Habit de Ville. B. En Habit de Ménage. C. Espangnol vétu comme on l'est au Perou. D. Mulatresse. E. Negre Domestique.
Description: Men and women of Lima, Peru. Includes a black domestic servant and mulatto woman, as well as an
Source_Title: [Relación histórica del viage a la America meridional. French] Voyage historique de l'Amerique meridionale ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez Arkstée & Merkus
notes: This image is derived from Ulloa, Relación histórica, Madrid, 1748. Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian.

Image_title: Gegend von Mexico.
Description: Bird's-eye view of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing Lake Texcoco, the various islands and settlements, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city. Also includes churches and dwellings. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at bottom.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: The city is probably shown as the artist imagined Tenochtitlán was before Europeans arrived, but with European-type houses and churches. Cuyioacan (or Coyoacan) may be where Hernán Cortés lived. Suchimilco (or Xochimilco) was the site of a famous battle won by Cortés. This image is similar to the one printed in Antonio de Solís, Histoire de la conquête du Mexique, Paris, 1691, following p. 272. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Die Hauptstadt Cüzco aus dem Dapper zu den Zeiten der Yncas
Description: A bird's-eye view of Cuzco in present-day Peru. Built environment includes walls, temple (with three statues in front of the wall), and dwellings. Includes tombs or towers on hill, fortifications, and bridge.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: The image is derived from Giovanni Battista Ramusio, Terzo volume delle Navigationi et viaggi, Venice, 1556. The towers may be chullpas, monuments built by the Collas as burial chambers. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plan du Palais et Citadelle des Rois Incas ... Vue du Palais et Citadelle que les Rois Incas avoient près du Village de Cañar et dont on voit encore les Murs.
Description: Plan and bird's-eye view of the palace and citadel of the Inca kings near the village of Cañar [Cannar] in Peru. Items in the image are lettered for identification in a key at upper and lower left.
Source_Title: [Relación histórica del viage a la America meridional. French] Voyage historique de l'Amerique meridionale ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez Arkstée & Merkus
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Ynca Viracocha und Seine Gemahlin.
Description: Two native Americans. Includes spears, feathered headdresses, and ornaments.
Source_Title: Algemeine Geschichte de Länder und Völker von America. Zweiter Theil. Nebst einer Vorrede Siegmund Jacob Baumgartens ...
Source_publisher: bey Johann Justinus Gebauer
notes: Viracocha, according to Inca beliefs, was the creator of the world and was often shown with a stave in each hand. He also created the eight brethren to rule the world, two of whom, Manco Cpac and Mama Ocello, founded the Inca civilization. An Inca ruler was named Viracocha as well. This image is derived from the title page of Garsilasso de la Vega, Le commentaire royal, ov L'histoire des Yncas, Paris, 1633. Compiled and translated from several sources by Johann Friedrich Schröter, with a preface by Siegmund Jakob Baumgarten. Schröter was secretary to the Privy Council of Magdeburg and had served for some years as a missionary in Canada.

Image_title: 1. Espagnole de Quito 2. Indienne de distinction. 3. Barbier Indien. 4. Métive de Quito. 5. Paysan Indien. 6. Indienne du Commun.
Description: Spanish woman of Quito, a high-class Indian woman, mestizia of Quito, and ordinary native Americans.
Source_Title: [Relación histórica del viage a la America meridional. French] Voyage historique de l'Amerique meridionale ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez Arkstée & Merkus
notes: This image is derived from Ulloa, Relación histórica, Madrid, 1748. Ulloa, Spanish general, explorer, astronomer, colonial administrator, and first Spanish governor of Louisiana, went to Peru as part of the French scientific expedition led by Pierre Bouguer which aimed to measure an arc of the meridian. Engraver may be Jan Punt, Dutch painter, printmaker, actor, 1711-1779.

Image_title: Retrato del V. P. Juan Bautista Zappa de la Compañia de Jeusus, que traxo de Italia la Santa Imagen de Na. Sra. de Loreto â la Ciudad de Mexico.
Description: Portrait of Giovanni Battista Zappa wearing a birreta and holding a statue of Our Lady of Loreto.
Source_Title: Vida y virtudes del V. P. Juan Bautista Zappa de la Compañia de Jesus
Source_publisher: Por Pablo Nadal Impressor, en la calle de la Canùda
notes: Zappa, an Italian and Jesuit missionary in Mexico, brought a statue of Our Lady of Loreto, as well as precise measurements of the house at Loreto said to be the house in which the Virgin Mary received the angel Gabriel, from Italy in 1675. He supervised the construction of the Loreto chapel at Tepotzotlán which began in 1678.
References: Mathes, M. Ilustracion en Mexico colonial, 9A; http://www.jesuit.org/sections/sub.asp?SECTION_ID=194&SUBSECTION_ID=558&PARENT_ID=489 (Feb. 2006)
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: Cimetierre des Sacrifices.
Description: Aztec or Mexican cemetery (tzompantli) for sacrificial victims. Human skulls are placed on tiers or piled in niches in walls. Native Americans converse or place skulls on tiers.
Source_Title: Histoire générale des voyages, ou nouvelle collection de toutes les relations de voyages par mer et par terre ... Tome douzieme
Source_publisher: Chez Didot, Libraire, Quai des Augustins, à la Bible d'or
notes: Text describes the cemetary as a sort of theater with towers and walls made out of skulls and lime. Aztec temples used tzompantli to hold the skulls of sacrificial victims. Image is placed horizontally on the page.

Image_title: Philip Quarll & Beaufidell
Image_publisher: J. Wren, ... J. Jefferies, ... and J. Fuller
Description: Bearded man carrying wood is followed by a monkey also carrying wood. Includes dwellings, hatchet or ax, and deer or stags.
Source_Title: The hermit: or The unparallel'd sufferings and surprising adventures of Mr. Philip Quarll
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Wren, ... J. Jefferies, ... and J. Fuller
notes: Forming part of a literary genre known as a "Robinsonade," this book was widely read during the eighteenth century. Quarll was marooned on an unknown island, said to be off of the coast of Mexico, and adopted a monkey as a companion. The book is also attributed to Alexander Bicknell.

Image_title: 1. Zapota ou Sapotier 2. Sapotille. 3. Cacaotier. 4. Cacao.
Description: Branch, fruit, flower, and cross-section of fruit of the sapote tree and branch, cross section of fruit, and fruit of the cocao. Items are numbered for identification in key at top of image.
Source_Title: [Histoire générale des voyages] Histoire générale des voyages, ou nouvelle collection de toutes les relations de voyages par mer et par terre ... Tome douzieme
Source_publisher: Chez Didot, Libraire, Quai des Augustins, à la Bible d'or
notes: Black and white sapote (zapote in Spanish) trees are discussed on pp. 604-605 of the text. White sapote is Casimiroa edulis, and black sapote, actually related to the persimmon, is Diospyros digna. Text discusses the value and uses of the plants.

Image_title: 1. Vanille 2. Mamey
Description: Branch, fruit, flower, seeds, and cross-section of fruit of the mamey apple tree and branch, flowers, and pods of the vanilla orchid. Items are numbered for identification in key at top of image.
Source_Title: [Histoire générale des voyages] Histoire générale des voyages, ou nouvelle collection de toutes les relations de voyages par mer et par terre ... Tome douzieme
Source_publisher: Chez Didot, Libraire, Quai des Augustins, à la Bible d'or
notes: The vanilla orchid, native to South and Central America, was first brought to the attention of Europeans by Hernán Cortés who saw it at the Aztec court where it was called tlilxochitl. Due to the difficulty of its pollination, it was not successfully cultivated until the nineteenth century. The mamey apple is Mammea americana.

Image_title: 1. Aguacate Avorat ou Persea 2. Granadille Fleur de la Passion
Description: Branch, fruit, flowers, and seed or pit of the avocado with branch and flower of the passion flower. Items are numbered for identification in key at top of image.
Source_Title: [Histoire générale des voyages] Histoire générale des voyages, ou nouvelle collection de toutes les relations de voyages par mer et par terre ... Tome douzieme
Source_publisher: Chez Didot, Libraire, Quai des Augustins, à la Bible d'or

Image_title: Oeconomie Mexiquaine.
Description: Aztec or Nahuatl glyphs or picture writing represents the education of a young native American Aztec man and the marriage of a young native American Aztec woman. Items in the image are lettered for explanation in footnote in text.
Source_Title: [Histoire générale des voyages] Histoire générale des voyages, ou nouvelle collection de toutes les relations de voyages par mer et par terre ... Tome douzieme
Source_publisher: Chez Didot, Libraire, Quai des Augustins, à la Bible d'or
notes: Footnote explains that the upper part of the image represents the choice a father must make between general education or preparation for the priesthood for his son. The bottom part of the image represents the marriage of a young woman to a man in a ceremony involving tying their robes together, burning incense, and eating food.
SubjectHeadings4: Indians of Mexico--Marriage customs and rites
SubjectHeadings5: Indians of Mexico--Social life and customs

Image_title: [Large-leaf'd Portlandia.]
Description: Flower and leaves of the portlandia plant with details of the cup, filaments, germen, fruit, and seeds.
Source_Title: The civil and natural history of Jamaica. ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the author; and sold by T. Osborne, and J. Shipton, in Gray's-Inn.
notes: This plant is now known as Portlandia grandiflora L., a member of the Rubiaceae family. It was named for the Duchess of Portland who had a great interest in botany. Image title from p 164.In the plates the letter (a) indicates the empalement or cup; (b) the flower; (c) the filaments with their antherae; (d) the style and stigma; and (e), (f), and (g) the germen, fruit and seeds.Browne was an Irish medical doctor who settled in Jamaica in 1746. There he collected 1200 species of plants, 400 more than Sloane. He retired to Ireland in 1771.
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 1963; former collections of William Charles de Meuron, Earl Fitzwiliam; Charles William de Meuron, Earl Fitzwilliam; Mary, Marchioness of Rockingham.

Image_title: V. R. de la Milagrosa Ymagen de Na. Sa. de Sn. Juan de los Lagos
Description: Image of the Virgin of San Juan of the Lakes. Includes crescent moon, crown, and halo.
Source_Title: Origen de los dos celebres santuarios de la Nueva Galicia obispado de Guadalaxara en la America Septentrional ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la Bibliotheca Mexicana.
notes: The town of San Juan de los Lagos is located in the eastern part of the state of Jalisco in west central Mexico. In 1542, the Spanish priest, Father Miguel de Bologna, brought an image of the Virgin of the Immaculate Conception to the village. In 1632, a daughter of Indian parents fell gravely ill but was saved by praying to the Virgin. Construction began on the present church in 1732.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles
SubjectHeadings2: Santuario de Nuestra Señora de San Juan (Guadalajara, Mexico)

Image_title: Milagrosa Imagen de Na. Sa. de Tzapopan
Description: Image of Our Lady of Tzapopan [Zapopán] on an altar. Includes vases of flowers, candles, crown, halo, and draperies.
Source_Title: Origen de los dos celebres santuarios de la Nueva Galicia obispado de Guadalaxara en la America Septentrional ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la Bibliotheca Mexicana.
notes: The Virgin of Zapopán is said to have interceded between the Spanish and the native population during the European conquest of Mexico. In 1689, a basilica dedicated to her was begun by the Franciscans in the state of Jalisco, México. It is considered the third most important pilgrimage center in the country.
SubjectHeadings1: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: [Cross of Tepique]
Description: Image of a cross on the ground, formed from grass, with an image of feet marked in stone. Includes a settlement with church and dwellings, mountainous landscape, scale, and compass. Items in image are lettered for explanation in key at bottom.
Source_Title: Origen de los dos celebres santuarios de la Nueva Galicia obispado de Guadalaxara en la America Septentrional ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la Bibliotheca Mexicana.
notes: The sacred Cross of Tepique is a cross formed in the soil in the plains of Jalisco, Mexico. Said to be on the spot where a wooden cross decayed and fell, the grass grows green in this shape. A stone nearby has footprints alleged to be those of a disciple of Saint Thomas.
References: Clavigero, F. S., transl. by C. Cullen, History of Mexico, p. 250-251

Image_title: [Symbol of Mexico]
Image_publisher: Heirs of the Widow of Joseph Bernardo de Hogal
Description: Symbol of Mexico with an eagle holding a snake sitting on a cactus. Over the eagle's head is a star and a crown.
Source_Title: Resguardo contra el olvido, en el breve compendio de la vida admirable, y virtudes heroycas del Illmo. Sr. Dr. D. Alonso de Cuevas Davalos ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de los Herederos de la Viuda de D. Joseph Bernardo de Hogal.
notes: Juan Alonso de Cuevas Dávalos was first elected bishop of Oaxaca in 1657. Eventually he became archbishop of Mexico from 1664 to 1665. The eagle perched on a cactus was a sign to the wandering Mexica or Aztec tribe of the site where they were to build their city of Tenochtitlan, now Mexico City. It remains a symbol of Mexico.
Provenance_Donor: Originally owned by the Convento de San Antonio de la Puebla, Mexico.

Image_title: La M. Iosepha Petra Iuana Nepomucena de Sr. S. Miguel. Religiosa professa de velo negro en el Convento de Dominicas de N. Sa. de la Salud de Patzquaro ...
Description: Portrait of Josepha Petra wearing Dominican habit, a rosary, and holding a book. Includes a pot of flowers [lilies?] on balcony railing.
Source_creator: Ponce de León, José Antonio Eugenio
Source_Title: Carta, que escribe a las religiosas dominicas de N. Sra. de la Salud de la ciudad de Patzquaro ...
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta de la Bibliotheca mexicana, enfrente de San Augustin
notes: Josepha Petra Juana Nepomucena de San Miguel was a novice in the Dominican convent of Nuestra Señora de la Salud in Pátzcuaro, the province of Michoacán, Mexico, who died at age sixteen.
SubjectHeadings1: Josepha Petra, Juana Nepomucena de San Miguel

Source_publisher: en Casa de Antonio Sanz Plazuela de la Calle de la Paz

Image_title: Parte Occidental de la Costa Patagomica [sic]
Description: Map of part of the coast of Chile showing the location of the shipwreck of HMS Wager, near the island of Guayaneco, now Isla Wager, and the island of Chiloe. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude, sea banks or shoals, and compass rose. Items in the image are lettered for identification in key at bottom right.
notes: The wreck of the HMS Wager off the coast of Chile in 1741 led to numerous Spanish attempts to salvage the ship and make contact with native Americans who, being expert divers, could assist them.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: V. P. Juan Antonio de Oviedo, Americano, de la Compañia de Jesus, murio de edad de 87 años.
Image_publisher: Imprenta del Real, y Mas-Antiguo de S. Ildefonso
Description: Portrait of Juan Antonio de Oviedo, holding a book and biretta and surrounded with volumes of books.
Source_Title: Vida examplar, y virtudes heroicas del venerable padre Juan Antonio de Oviedo, de la Compañia de Jesus
Source_publisher: en la Imprenta del Real, y Mas-Antiguo de S. Ildefonso
notes: A native-born American, Oviedo taught philosophy in Mexico and theology in Guatemala, was procurator at Rome and Madrid, visitor of Manila, rector of Mexico, and twice provincial of the Jesuits of Mexico. He was also a prolific writer on religious and theological subjects, both in Spanish and Latin.Cabrera was a Mexican painter.
References: Mathes, M. Ilustracion en Mexico colonial, 9B

Image_title: 1 Amsaleira; 2 Amsale; 3 Ananseira ell Ananas; 4 Anoneira; 5 Anona
Description: Three kinds of fruit: 1) and 2) the amsaleira, 3) the pineapple plant with its fruit, 4) and 5) the Anoneira shown whole with its leaves and cut open.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Anoneira's scientific name is Annona cherimola Mill. It was originally found in Colombia, Bolivia, and Ecuador. It is also known as cherimoya. Pineapple's scientific name is Ananas comosus; it is probably native to Brazil or Paraguay.Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon.Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely.

Image_title: 1. Caramdeira 2. Carambes. 3. Taranja 4. Caramboleira 5. Caramboles 6. Cocstraet 7. Cocos
Description: 1. Branch and leaves some tropical trees including the cocoanut and the starfruit or carambola.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: The camradiera is described as being a low tree with lots of spines and with leaves like the orange tree. The carambola or starfruit is the fruit of Averrhoa carambola, a species of tree native to the Far East. Scientific name for the cocoanut: Cocos nucifera. Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: 1. Figueira ell. Bananes Indianske Troe 2. Bananes 3. Jangomeira. 4. Jangomas 5. Brindeira 6. Brindons
Description: 1 & 2. Banana palms or trees. 3. Tropical fruit tree. 4. Flacourtia jangomas, Indian plum, coffee plum [?]. 5. & 6. Other trees.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Scientific name of banana: Musa. Scientific name of the Indian plum: Flacourtia jangomas Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely. Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: 1. Jamboyera 2. Jamboya 3. Jambo 4. Dets aabne Blomster 5. Dets voxende Frugt 6. Jamoleira 7. Jambolon aaben
Description: Varieties of the jamboleira, jambolon, or jamboyera tree. Includes fruit, leaves, flowers, and seeds.
Source_Title: [Collection of voyages and travels. Danish] Almindelig Historie over Reiser til Lands og Vands; ... Europa, Asia, Afrika og Amerika ... Sextende Deel.
Source_publisher: Lars Nielsen Svare
notes: Perhaps Jabuticaba described as being like a lemon tree. Scientific name: Plinia cauliflora Translation of Collection of voyages and travels ... The third edition, London, 1744-1746, edited by Awnsham and John Churchill and Thomas Osborne. Publisher from colophon. Part of this plate also appears in the Abbé Prevost's Histoire generale des voyages, 4th ed., Paris, 1755. Said to be by Schely. Engraver may be Jean Haas.

Image_title: Balza in tutte le sue proporzioni
Description: Raft and boats of the native Americans of Peru. Includes a raft with sail, shelter and cookfire, as well as balsa boats. Also includes a penguin and fox [?].
Source_Title: Il gazzettiere Americano ... Volume primo
Source_publisher: Per Marco Coltellini all' Insegna della Verità
notes: This encyclopedia was translated from an English edition and was the first comprehensive geographical dictionary of America in Italian. The image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, plate 2.

Image_title: A Donna di Lima in abito da Città B In abito domestico C Vestitura degli Spagnuoli nel Perù D Mulatta E Moro di servizio
Description: Two women of Lima, one wearing outdoor dress and the other wearing a domestic dress, speak to a gentleman. Also includes two black or mulatto servants or slaves. Items in the image are identified in title.
Source_Title: Il gazzettiere Americano ... Volume secondo
Source_publisher: Per Marco Coltellini all' Insegna della Verità
notes: This encyclopedia was translated from an English edition and was the first comprehensive geographical dictionary of America in Italian.

Image_title: 1. Ponte di Liana, ò Bejuco. 2. Tarabita per gl'Animali. 3. Tarabita per gl'Uomini.
Description: Suspension rope bridges of Peru, one made of twine or vines crossing a ravine or river, one to transport animals, and the third to convey people. Includes dwellings, horse, and native Americans crossing the river.
Source_Title: Il gazzettiere Americano ... Volume terzo
Source_publisher: Per Marco Coltellini all' Insegna della Verità
notes: See also Antonio de Ulloa, Relacion historica del viage a la American meridional, Madrid, 1748, plate 13, vol. 1, pt. 1. This encyclopedia was translated from an English edition and was the first comprehensive geographical dictionary of America in Italian.

Image_title: Penguino dell' America settentrionale
Description: Penguin with detail of feather and head profile.
Source_Title: Il gazzettiere Americano ... Volume terzo
Source_publisher: Per Marco Coltellini all' Insegna della Verità
notes: Perhaps the Humboldt penguin which is native to Peru and Chile. Scientific name: Spheniscus Humboldti. This encyclopedia was translated from an English edition and was the first comprehensive geographical dictionary of America in Italian.

Image_title: Il re degli zopiloti ò sia degli avoltoi
Description: Vulture or buzzard with skeletons of its prey about its feet.
Source_Title: Il gazzettiere Americano ... Volume primo
Source_publisher: Per Marco Coltellini all' Insegna della Verità
notes: Text describes the vultures of the area around Acapulco; this is perhaps the turkey vulture or Cathartes aura. This encyclopedia was translated from an English edition and was the first comprehensive geographical dictionary of America in Italian.

Image_title: Tucano ò sia pica del Brasile
Description: Toucan on the branch of a tree.
Source_Title: Il gazzettiere Americano ... Volume primo
Source_publisher: Per Marco Coltellini all' Insegna della Verità
notes: Text describes a toucan with a red body and white throat. Scientific name: Ramphastos tucanus. This encyclopedia was translated from an English edition and was the first comprehensive geographical dictionary of America in Italian.

Image_title: Cours de l'Orenoque Depuis ses sources jusqu'à la Mer Avec les Rivieres qui s'y déchargent
Description: Map of the Orinoco River in present-day Venezuela. Cartographic elements include tributaries of the Orinoco, sand banks, some topographical details, location of settlements, scale, and compass rose.

The top is a map of the mouth of the Orinoco to the fort and town of St. Thomas and the bottom a map of the principal arm of the Orinoco to the same St. Thomas. Cartographic elements include tributaries of the Orinoco, soundings, sand banks, some topographical details, location of settlements and forts, scale, and compass rose.

Image_title: Piano Scenografico della Città dei Re, ò sia di Lima Capitale del Regno del Perù tal quale era prima che fosse distrutta dall' ultimo Terremoto.
Description: Plan of Lima, Peru, showing the city as rebuilt after the earthquake of 1746. Cartographic elements include scale and some topographical details. Includes fortifications. Items in the image are lettered for identification in a key above.
notes: Lima was extensively rebuilt with wide streets, plazas, and elaborate churches after the devastating earthquake of 1746. This plan was included in Gazzettiere Americano, Livorno, 1763, and is here held separately. Publication information from that serial.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: V. R. dela V. M. Sor Sebastiana Iosepha dela SSma Trínídad Religiosa de velo negro en el Convento. de S. Iuan dela Penitencia de Mxco. ...
Image_publisher: en la Imprenta de la Bibliotheca Mexicana
Description: Sister Sebastiana Josepha prays before an image of the infant Christ.
Source_Title: Vida admirable, y penitente de la V.M. Sor Sebastiana Josepha de la SS.Trinidad, ...
Source_publisher: en la Imprenta de la Bibliotheca mexicana, en el Puente del Espiritu Santo.
notes: The convent of San Juan de la Penitencia was founded in 1598 by nuns from the convent of Santa Clara in a community of indigenous peoples in Mexico City. It was founded for women of Spanish descent.

Image_title: [Title page]
Description: Patagonian family of giants being given bread by a sailor.
Source_Title: Bickerstaff's Boston Almanack, For the year of our Lord 1768 ...
Source_publisher: Printed by Mein and Fleeming, and to be sold by John Mein at the London Book-Store, North-side of King-Street
notes: Text following the title page is entitled, "A faithful and compleat account of the Giants called Patagonians lately discovered in South-America by the Hon. Commodore Byron." As early the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America. In 1766, when Commodore John Byron returned to London after circumnavigating the world, word had already leaked out that the crew had discovered nine-foot tall Patagonian giants. Almanack is attributed to Benjamin West.

Image_title: [Coast of southern Chile]
Description: Profile maps of the coast of southern Chile. Decorative element includes ship.
Source_Title: Viage al Estrecho de Magallanes
Source_publisher: En la Imprenta Real de la Gazeta
notes: Sarmiento de Gamboa was the cosmographer of a Spanish expedition launched from Peru to explore the southern Chilean coast from the Pacific Ocean to the Atlantic and to look for possible sites of settlement that would repel English incursion into the area, an important gateway to the South Pacific. The author's maps, drawn as part of his report on the mission in 1580, remained in manuscript until 1768 when the report was published in Madrid. It was used extensively by all Spanish expeditions during the eighteenth century.
References_exhibitions: Delgado-Gomez, A. Spanish Historical Writings about the New World, Fig. 22
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: El Yllmo. Exmo. y Venerable Siervo de Dios Dn. Juan de Palafox, Obis[p]o. de la Puebla de los Ange[le]s. ...
Description: Portrait of Juan de Palafox y Mendoza holding a book and quill. Includes a bookcase, bishop's miter, ring, pontifical hat with six tassels, pectoral cross, crozier, and lilies.
Source_Title: Carta del venerable siervo de Dios D. Juan de Palafox y Mendoza ...
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de D. Gabriel Ramirez, se hallara en las librerias de Ulloa
notes: Appointed "visitator general" of Mexico in 1639, Palafox y Mendoza served as the bishop of Puebla of Los Angeles, a position he held until 1649. The process of his canonization was begun in 1726, but a final decision was suspended in 1777.

Image_title: [Patagonian giant family]
Description: Native American man, woman, and child trade with European. Also includes horse, dog, ship, belts being traded. The giant man carries a boleadora.
Source_Title: Journal historique d'un voyage fait aux iles Malouïnes en 1763 & 1764 ... Tome II
Source_publisher: Chez Etienne de Bourdeaux, Libraire du Roy & de la Cour
notes: In 1766, Commodore John Byron returned to London after circumnavigating the world. Word soon leaked out that the crew had discovered nine-foot tall Patagonian giants. Earlier explorers had also reported a race of giants in Patagonia. As early the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America. Boleadoras were tools used by indigenous peoples of the Argentinian Pampas to hunt. A boleadora consisted of two stones bound by a leather cord which were thrown and then used to trip an animal. The gauchos, or cowboys, of Argentina later would refine this tool and make it their own.

Image_title: Ein Matrose bietet einer Patagonischen frau ein Stück Zwieback für ihr kind an.
Description: Patagonian family of giants being given bread by a sailor.
Source_Title: [Voyage round the world in His Majesty's ship The Dolphin. German] John Byrons, obersten Befehlshaber über ein englishches Geschwader, Reise um die Welt, in den Jahren 1764 und 1765
Source_publisher: bey Johann Benedict Mezler
notes: In 1766, Commodore John Byron, grandfather of the poet Byron, returned to London on his ship, the Dolphin, after circumnavigating the world. Word soon leaked out that the crew had discovered nine foot tall Patagonian giants. Earlier explorers had also reported a race of giants in Patagonia. As early the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America.

Image_title: [Towns pay tribute to Montezuma]
Description: Pictographs representing towns that were conquered by, and that paid tribute to, the Aztecs. Their names appear in both Nahuatl and Spanish.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a-4a] Historia de la Nueva-España, ... aumentada con otros documentos, y notas, por el ilustrissimo señor don Francisco Antonio Lorenzana, ...
Source_publisher: en la imprenta del Superior Gobierno, del Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal en la Calle de Tiburcio
notes: One of the 31 facsimile plates illustrating a Mexican codex reproduced in Francisco Antonio de Lorenzana's Historia de la Nueva-España (Mexico, 1770). The Historia brought together historical documents relating to the civil and religious history of Mexico. The name glyph of Tenochtitlan was a cactus issuing from a stone.

Image_title: [Aztec Tribute List]
Image_publisher: Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal
Description: A list of kinds of tribute paid to the Aztecs. Includes cloth or clothing, warriors' costumes, shields, measures of beans. Includes symbols for the towns paying. A cherub blows a trumpet and carries three books. Hanging from the trumpet is a cloth depicting an ecclesiastical coat of arms.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a-4a] Historia de la Nueva-España, ... aumentada con otros documentos, y notas, por el ilustrissimo señor don Francisco Antonio Lorenzana, ...
Source_publisher: en la imprenta del Superior Gobierno, del Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal en la Calle de Tiburcio
notes: One of the 31 facsimile plates illustrating a Mexican codex reproduced in Francisco Antonio de Lorenzana's Historia de la Nueva-España (Mexico, 1770). The Historia brought together historical documents relating to the civil and religious history of Mexico.

Image_title: [Aztec Tribute List]
Image_publisher: Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal
Description: A list of kinds of tribute paid to the Aztecs. Includes cloth or clothing dyed in various colors, warriors' costumes, shields, measures of beans. Includes symbols for the towns paying the tribute along the bottom and right of the image.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a-4a] Historia de la Nueva-España, ... aumentada con otros documentos, y notas, por el ilustrissimo señor don Francisco Antonio Lorenzana, ...
Source_publisher: en la imprenta del Superior Gobierno, del Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal en la Calle de Tiburcio
notes: Part of Francisco Antonio de Lorenzana's Historia de la Nueva-España (Mexico, 1770) which brought together historical documents relating to the civil and religious history of Mexico.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Item 26, fig. 40.

Image_title: [Los Meses de el Año Mexicano...]
Image_publisher: Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal
Description: A diagram of the lunar months of the Aztec calendar. Each month consists of 20 days. Each month is given its symbol, Nahuatl name, and Spanish description. At the center of the circular diagram is the moon. Below the diagram is a landscape including the city of Tula with two figures moving away from Tula and toward an eagle eating a snake while perched on a cactus. A [native American?] female half reclines on a globe and holds a scepter [?]. Next to her are a quiver of arrows and a crowned shield depicting an eagle and a Mexican temple [?].
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a-4a] Historia de la Nueva-España, ... aumentada con otros documentos, y notas, por el ilustrissimo señor don Francisco Antonio Lorenzana, ...
Source_publisher: en la imprenta del Superior Gobierno, del Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal en la Calle de Tiburcio
notes: Part of Francisco Antonio de Lorenzana's Historia de la Nueva-España (Mexico, 1770) which brought together historical documents relating to the civil and religious history of Mexico. Image title taken from explanation at bottom. Also called the Veytia calendar wheel. Tula is a city near Mexico City. The eagle perched on a cactus was a sign to the wandering Mexica tribe of the site where they were to build their city of Tenochtitlan, now Mexico City.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Item 26, fig. 39.

Image_title: [Aztec Tribute List]
Image_publisher: Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal
Description: Pictographs representing kinds of tribute paid to the Aztecs including feathers of different colors, alabaster columns, strings of fine stones, packages of cacao, birds, gourd cups, pots for heating water, hides of the "tiger," and yerba or herb.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a-4a] Historia de la Nueva-España, ... aumentada con otros documentos, y notas, por el ilustrissimo señor don Francisco Antonio Lorenzana, ...
Source_publisher: en la imprenta del Superior Gobierno, del Br. D. Joseph Antonio de Hogal en la Calle de Tiburcio
notes: One of the 31 facsimile plates illustrating a Mexican codex included in Francisco Antonio de Lorenzana's Historia de la Nueva-España (Mexico, 1770). The Historia brought together historical documents relating to the civil and religious history of Mexico.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Item 26, fig. 41.

Image_title: Magellaner
Description: Native American or Patagonian of the Strait of Magellan. Cultural artifacts include feathered headdress and garment, bow and arrow.
Source_Title: Nach dem jezigen Staat eingerichtete Bilder-Geographie, darinnen von den vier Haupttheilen des Erdbodens Europa, Asia, Afrika und Amerika Nachricht gegeben
Source_publisher: Zu finden bey Christoph Riegels seel. Wittib
notes: The plates for this work were largely based on Neu-eroffnetes Amphi-Theatrum ..., Erfurt, 1723.

Image_title: Paragayer
Description: Native American from Paraguay or the region around Rio de la Plata. Cultural artifact includes hatchet. Also includes scene of cannibalism.
Source_Title: Nach dem jezigen Staat eingerichtete Bilder-Geographie, darinnen von den vier Haupttheilen des Erdbodens Europa, Asia, Afrika und Amerika Nachricht gegeben
Source_publisher: Zu finden bey Christoph Riegels seel. Wittib
notes: The plates for this work were largely based on Neu-eroffnetes Amphi-Theatrum ..., Erfurt, 1723.

Image_title: Attabaliba
Description: Portrait of Atabalipa [Atahualpa], a native American ruler, holding a spear. Cultural artifacts include ornaments, and feathered headdress and garments.
Source_Title: Nach dem jezigen Staat eingerichtete Bilder-Geographie, darinnen von den vier Haupttheilen des Erdbodens Europa, Asia, Afrika und Amerika Nachricht gegeben
Source_publisher: Zu finden bey Christoph Riegels seel. Wittib
notes: Atabalipa was the last independent Incan ruler in Peru. He was captured by the Spanish and executed in 1533 despite his paying a vast ransom for his life. The plates for this work were largely based on Neu-eroffnetes Amphi-Theatrum ..., Erfurt, 1723.

Image_title: Motezuma
Description: Portrait of Moctezuma (Montezuma), a native American or Aztec ruler of Mexico, holding a sceptre. Cultural artifacts include ornaments and a crown.
Source_Title: Nach dem jezigen Staat eingerichtete Bilder-Geographie, darinnen von den vier Haupttheilen des Erdbodens Europa, Asia, Afrika und Amerika Nachricht gegeben
Source_publisher: Zu finden bey Christoph Riegels seel. Wittib
notes: This is probably Moctezuma II (reigned 1502-1520), the ninth Aztec emperor, whose surname was Xocoyotzin or bitter lord (or the youngest), was the son of Axayácatl and great grandson of Moctezuma I. He surrendered to the Spanish in 1520. The plates for this work were largely based on Neu-eroffnetes Amphi-Theatrum ..., Erfurt, 1723.

Image_title: An Indian of Montevideo.
Description: A native American man wears a cloak decorated in geometric patterns and made of deer skin.
Source_Title: [Journal historique d'un voyage fait aux iles Malouïnes. English] The history of a voyage to the Malouine (or Falkland) Islands ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Jefferys, in the Strand
notes: This voyage was undertaken by Louis de Bougainville at his own expense to found a French colony in the islands (named by him in honor of French seamen from St. Malo), presently known as the Falkland Islands [or Islas Malvinas]. The Spanish objected to the colony and the French later surrendered the land to Spain. Pernety, who traveled with the expedition, was a Benedictine monk.

Description: Spaniard wearing poncho and hat and holding a walking stick. Includes a veiled woman in the background.
Source_Title: [Journal historique d'un voyage fait aux iles Malouïnes. English] The history of a voyage to the Malouine (or Falkland) Islands ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Jefferys, in the Strand

The Spanish objected to the colony and the French later surrendered the land to Spain. Pernety, who traveled with the expedition, was a Benedictine monk.

Image_title: [Sea lions, shells, crab, and plants]
