Image_title: [top] A view of Fort St. Louis at Acarron Bay. [bottom] Plan of Acarron Bay Situated at the East Point of the Malouine Islands.
Description: [top] Bird's eye view of Acarron Bay, present-day Berkeley Sound and Port Louis, in the Falkland Islands, including dwellings, fortifications, ships, group of men and herd of domestic animals. [bottom] Plan of Acarron Bay includes soundings, scale, and some topographical details.
Source_Title: [Journal historique d'un voyage fait aux iles Malouïnes. English] The history of a voyage to the Malouine (or Falkland) Islands ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Jefferys, in the Strand
notes: This voyage was undertaken by Louis de Bougainville at his own expense to found a French colony in the islands (named by him in honor of French seamen from St. Malo), presently known as the Falkland Islands [or Islas Malvinas]. Fort St. Louis was the French colony's first settlement. The Spanish objected to the colony and the French later surrendered the land to Spain. Pernety, who traveled with the expedition, was a Benedictine monk.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [top] A view of the Town of St. Philip of Monte Video. [bottom] Plan of the Town of St. Philip of Monte Video
Description: View and plan of the town of San Felipe y Santiago de Montevideo or present-day Montevideo. Includes fortifications, church, monastery, and ships. Cartographic elements include scale, compass rose, and some topographical details. Items in the image lettered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: [Journal historique d'un voyage fait aux iles Malouïnes. English] The history of a voyage to the Malouine (or Falkland) Islands ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Jefferys, in the Strand
notes: Montevideo was a garrison town built by Bruno Mauricio de Zabal, governor of Buenos Aires, to repel Portuguese advances from Brazil in the eighteenth century. Image placed horizontally on page. This voyage was undertaken by Louis de Bougainville at his own expense to found a French colony in the islands (named by him in honor of French seamen from St. Malo), presently known as the Falkland Islands [or Islas Malvinas]. The Spanish objected to the colony and the French later surrendered the land to Spain. Pernety, who traveled with the expedition, was a Benedictine monk.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The Patagonians.
Description: Patagonian family of giants trading with a European gentleman. Cultural artifacts include a boleadora or sling, feathered headdress, and geometrically-patterned clothing. Also includes a dog, horse, and ships.
Source_Title: [Journal historique d'un voyage fait aux iles Malouïnes. English] The history of a voyage to the Malouine (or Falkland) Islands ...
Source_publisher: Printed for T. Jefferys, in the Strand
notes: Pernety does not mention the size of the Patagonians in his description of the inhabitants, although as early the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America. In 1766, when Commodore John Byron returned to London after circumnavigating the world, word had already leaked out that the crew had discovered nine-foot tall Patagonian giants. Pernety mentions seeing Byron's fleet, but not his giants. Boleadoras were tools made of two stones bound by a leather cord and used by indigenous peoples of the Argentinian Pampas to hunt. This voyage was undertaken by Louis de Bougainville at his own expense to found a French colony in the islands (named by him in honor of French seamen from St. Malo), presently known as the Falkland Islands [or Islas Malvinas]. The Spanish objected to the colony and the French later surrendered the land to Spain. Pernety, who traveled with the expedition, was a Benedictine monk.

Image_title: [top] [View of the desert of Cotopaxi.] [bottom left] [View of a torrent and the manner of passing it.] [bottom right] [Works of the ancient Indians, found in their tombs.]
Description: [top] View of the volcano Cotopaxi, erupting and showing (a) the phenomenon of rainbows or mirages around the head of people. Also includes a (b) lunar rainbow observed by Don George Juan, and (c) the mountain of Cotopaxi at the time of the eruption in 1743. [bottom left] View of a rope bridge called bejucos, a bridge for transporting horses called a tarabita, and one for people. [bottom right] Native American artifacts found in graves, including (a) a tomb, (b) a plan of the tomb, (c) a gold idol, (d, e, f, g) hatchets, mirrors, jars, tupus (or large pins for fastening clothing), earrings, and tweezers (l) for pulling out facial hair. Also includes horse, dwellings, and tent. Items in the image are lettered for identification in Explanation at beginning of volume one.
Source_Title: [Relación histórica del viage a la America meridional. English] A voyage to South America ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Printed for Lockyer Davis, in Holborn; Printer to the Royal Society
notes: These mysterious phenomena, described in great detail by Ulloa, have been analyzed by optical specialists. Ulloa is credited with the first observation of (fig. a) a white rainbow or fogbow (also known as a "circle of Ulloa" in his honor). Fig. b, a more mysterious observation, presented as a series of colorless arcs intersecting at one point and seen by the light of the moon. This phenomenon may be an inner lunar fog-bow accompanied by a primary reflected lunar fog-bow. This image is derived from the images in Ulloa, Relación histórica, Madrid, 1748. Information about the image taken from the Explanation of plates found at the beginning of volume one. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: [top] [Temple of the ancient Indians near the village of Cayambe ....] [middle] [View of the ruins of a palace of the Yncas, called Callo ...] [bottom left] [The balza.] [bottom right] [View of a palace and citadel of the Yncas, near the village of Canar.]
Description: [top] (a) View of a native American temple in the province of Quito in present-day Ecuador, including tombs (b), fortifications (c), and the village of Cayambe (d). [middle] View of the ruins of an Inca palace called Callo, near the town of Latacunga, also in Quito province. Various parts of the palace are described, as well as a mountain (K) called Panacillo, which served as a watchtower when the king was in residence, and a river (L) which had its source in the desert of Cotopaxi. [bottom left]. A balsa raft with the various parts identified, including the cook fire. [bottom right] View of an Inca palace and fortifications near Canar, including the rivers which surround the citadel. Also includes dwellings and church. Items in the image are lettered for identification in Explanation at beginning of volume one.
Source_Title: [Relación histórica del viage a la America meridional. English] A voyage to South America ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Printed for Lockyer Davis, in Holborn; Printer to the Royal Society
notes: Information about the image taken from the Explanation of plates found at the beginning of volume one. The ruins of Ingapirca, in present-day Ecuador, still stand in the province of Cañar. The Temple of the Sun was used by the Cañari and Inca cultures mainly for ceremonies and rituals, and was elliptical in shape. The ruins consist of a cemetery, solar observatories, roads, storage areas, priests' chambers, and a native square. Balsa rafts were known to Europeans since 1527 when first seen by Pizarro's pilot. Ulloa was the first to study how the rafts actually operated. The text notes that they were capable of deep sea navigation, 80 to 100 feet long, 20 to 26 feet wide, and able to carry 20 to 25 tons of cargo. The native Americans and mulattos moved their entire families onto them in the rainy season when they were cut off from their small farms. From the rafts they fished and subsisted on preserved meats and grains. Ulloa discovered how the rafts were able to tack by shifting the sails and be steered by means of guares. Images for this image are derived from Ulloa, Relacion historica, Madrid, 1748. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [top] Plan of Lima [middle] The Port of Callao [bottom left] [Modes of transportation in Peru] [bottom right] [Inhabitants of Lima]
Description: [top] Plan of Lima. [middle] Plan of the port of Callao. [bottom left]. Modes of transportation in Peru. Includes llamas, a calash or carriage used in Lima, and a mestizo woman on horse or mule back. [bottom right] Various inhabitants of Lima, including a Spaniard in Peruvian dress, a lady in riding dress, a mulatto woman and a negro servant. Cartographic elements include compass rose, scales, and some topographical details. Items in the image are lettered for identification at bottom of page.
Source_Title: [Relación histórica del viage a la America meridional. English] A voyage to South America ... Vol. II
Source_publisher: Printed for Lockyer Davis, in Holborn; Printer to the Royal Society
notes: Image placed horizontally on page. The images for this image are derived from Ulloa, Relacíon histórica, Madrid, 1748.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Fish, cocoons, rock formation]
Description: A fish, two views of a butterfly's cocoon, and a faceted rock formation. Items are numbered and lettered for explanation in the text.
Source_Title: [Voyage en Californie pour l'observation du passage de Vénus sur le disque du soleil] Voyage en Californie ...
Source_publisher: Chez Charles-Antoine Jombert, Libraire du Roi pour l'Artillerie & le Génie, rue Dauphine, à l'Image Notre-Dame.
notes: Text describes the cocoon as belonging to the butterfly, Mariposa plateada, the fish as 1 to 1.5 inches long, and the rocks as protruding three feet from the ground, faceted, and black. The rock is found in Pachuca (Hidalgo province, Mexico) near the silver mines discovered in 1534.Chappe's journal concludes on p. 39, because shortly after his arrival at the mission of San Joseph, he died of an epidemic disease. His companions then simply fulfilled their mission of taking observations of the transit of Venus. Items depicted are described in a letter from Don Joseph Antoine de Alzate y Ramyrez to the Académie Royale des Sciences and sent to the Académie with Chappe's papers. Alzate was a priest born in Mexico who studied astronomy, physics, metallurgy, and antiquities. He was a corresponding member of the French Academy of Sciences. Some time after the papers arrived, a trunk containing these specimens also arrived at the Académie. Alzate gathered his specimens from the area around Mexico City.

Image_title: [Cascalotte, Ahuehuete, Huisiache, Chia]
Description: Flowers, seeds, and branch of the Cascalote tree, Huisache shrub, Montezuma cypress, and chia plant. Items are numbered and lettered for identification and discussion in the text.
Source_Title: [Voyage en Californie pour l'observation du passage de Vénus sur le disque du soleil] Voyage en Californie ...
Source_publisher: Chez Charles-Antoine Jombert, Libraire du Roi pour l'Artillerie & le Génie, rue Dauphine, à l'Image Notre-Dame.
notes: Cascalotte (Cascalote in English) is Caesalpinia cacalaco, noted for its usefulness in making an excellent black dye (figs. 1-4). Huisiache (Huisache in English) is Acacia smallii also used for the creation of black dye, especially for ink (figs. 5-7). The ahuehuete tree is Taxodium mucronatum or Montezuma Cypress, one of which is claimed to be the tree with the largest trunk in North America (figs. 8-10). Chia is salvia hispanica used as a medicine, food, and for its oil which can be mixed with pigments (figs. 11-12).Chappe's journal concludes on p. 39, because shortly after his arrival at the mission of San Joseph, he died of an epidemic disease. His companions then simply fulfilled their mission of taking observations of the transit of Venus. Items depicted are described in a letter from Don Joseph Antoine de Alzate y Ramyrez to the Académie Royale des Sciences and sent to the Académie with Chappe's papers. Alzate was a priest born in Mexico who studied astronomy, physics, metallurgy, and antiquities. He was a corresponding member of the French Academy of Sciences. Some time after the papers arrived, a trunk containing these specimens also arrived at the Académie. Alzate gathered his specimens from the area around Mexico City.Image title taken from accompanying text.

Image_title: [top] Plan of the Harbour and Town of Porto Bello [bottom] Plan of the City of Quito
Description: Plan of the harbor and town of Porto Bello in present-day Panama and a plan of the city of Quito in present-day Ecuador. Also includes at bottom, illustrations of people of Quito, a Spanish lady of Quito, a native American woman of high rank, an Indian barber, a mestizo, an Indian peasant and a common Indian woman with a child. Cartographic elements include compass rose, scale, indications of shoals or sea banks, and some topographical details. Items are numbered for identification in key at bottom.
Source_Title: [Relación histórica del viage a la America meridional. English] A voyage to South America ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Printed for Lockyer Davis, in Holborn; Printer to the Royal Society
notes: The images for this image are derived from Ulloa, Relacíon histórica, Madrid, 1748. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Commodore Byron Conversing with a Patagonian Woman.
Description: European man gives jewelry to a Patagonian or native American giant and her son.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the third
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: In 1766, Commodore John Byron returned to London after circumnavigating the world. Word soon leaked out that the crew had discovered nine-foot tall Patagonian giants. Earlier explorers had also reported a race of giants in Patagonia. As early as the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry.

Image_title: View of a Town in the Island of Terra del Fuego.
Description: View of a native American settlement in Tierra del Fuego. Woman dressed in furs holds a basket while others sit around a fire in one of the open-sided grass-roofed dwellings in the settlement.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the third
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Social life and customs

Image_title: The Wolf Fox of Faulklands Islands.
Description: Falkland Islands wolf or warrah.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the third
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: The Falkland Island wolf (Dusicyon australis) is now extinct. Killed by Europeans to protect the cattle and sheep that they introduced to the islands, the last known Falkland wolf was killed in 1876. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Cavendish plunders & burns Paita.
Description: European soldiers carry goods from a burning town down to a ship in the harbor. Includes swords, shields, boxes or casks, churches, and sacks.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the first
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text describes the voyage of Thomas Cavendish or Candish, the second Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, and the subsequent sack of the town of Paita by his men in May 1586. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Cavendishes Crew in Great distress at Port desire, Set up a Forge & repair their shatterd Vessels.
Description: European sailors work at a forge, make rope, saw wood, and carry provisions. Includes ship, boat, hammers, fire, and ax or hatchets.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the first
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text describes the voyage of Thomas Cavendish or Candish, the second Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, and his discovery of Puerto Deseado in present-day Argentina, where he landed to effect repairs to his ship and which he named after his ship. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Dampier's Comrades seizing the Oxen & Mules laden with Flour, Cheese &c. at a Farm House.
Description: European men take flour, cheese, mules, and oxen in front of a dwelling. Includes guns or muskets and sacks.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the first
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text describes the voyage of William Dampier and his discovery of an abandoned native American village near Acapulco where they purchased goods from a mulatto woman. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Cowley & his Men taking in Provisions at the Island of Iuan Fernandez.
Description: European men load up provisions into casks, butcher goats and birds, row casks in boats to ships in harbor. Also includes men chopping wood.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the first
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text describes the circumnavigation of William Ambrosia Cowley, sailing as master of a buccaneer ship in a fleet which included William Dampier, and the refitting of his ship on Juan Fernandez Island. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Alexander Selkirk Makes his Cats and Kids dance before Captn. Cook and his Company.
Description: Man dressed in furs instructs his cats and goats to dance before European men. Includes dwelling.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the second
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Daniel Defoe's story of Robinson Crusoe was based on the story of Alexander Selkirk who went to sea in 1704 with William Dampier and was put ashore on Juan Fernandez Island off of the coast of Chile where he survived until he was rescued in 1709 by Woodes Rogers. This image illustrates Captain Edward Cooke's account of the ship that rescued Selkirk. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Mr. Hatley & his Small Crew Cruelly Whip'd by ye. Savage Indians but are Saved by a Priest.
Description: Men are whipped at posts by native Americans. Two natives with feathered headdresses observe while a priest rushes toward the men. Includes dwelling.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the second
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Simon Hatley and a small crew were lost in the Galapagos Islands. Left for dead by Captain Edward Cooke, they surrendered to the enemy, a mixed group of Indians and mulattos who beat them. A priest who was respected by the natives saved the Englishmen's lives. Later Hatley was rescued and served as a captain under Shelvocke in his voyage around the world from 1719 to 1720. Hatley's shooting of a black albatross during that voyage inspired Coleridge's poem, Rime of the Ancient Mariner. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Histoire de la conquete du Perou
Description: Native American ruler is pulled down from his litter by European soldiers. Includes a priest holding up a cross, men mining, gathering fruit, and drawing water from a well. Also includes ships, bows, swords, and scene of killing or warfare.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Atahualpa [or Atabalipa], the last independent Incan ruler in Peru, was carried into Cajamarca, in present-day Peru, accompanied by about 15,000 soldiers. A monk confronted Atahualpa with a crucifix and a breviary. When Atahualpa asked how the Spanish kne

Image_title: [Comment Don Pédro d'Alvarado passa au Pérou, & ce qui lui arriva.]
Description: European soldiers run before an erupting volcano. Includes guns or muskets and spears.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Text describes the conquistador, Pedro de Alvarado, and his men passing by a volcano which erupted near Quito in present-day Ecuador. Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [Les peines & les fatigues qu'eurent à supporter Dom Diegue d'Almagro & ses gens, dans la découverte du Chili.]
Description: European soldiers trek through a mountainous landscape. One man lies down in foreground. Includes horses.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Text describes the conquistador, Diego de Almagro, leading the first European exploration of Chile. Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [Fernand Pizarre retourne au Pérou. Les dépêches & les ordres qu'il y apporte. Les Indiens se soulevent.]
Description: Native Americans attack European soldiers. Includes scene of warfare, bows, arrows, and gun or musket.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Text describes the uprising by the Inca after the execution of Atahualpa (or Atabaliba). Atahualpa's brother, Manco Capac, led a long siege to reoccupy the Inca capital of Cuzco. Francisco Pizarro sent an army of 500 men, under the command of Diego de Alm

Image_title: [Des Cérémonies religieuse & des Sacrifices des Indiens du Pérou.]
Description: Native American priest sacrifices or eviscerates a victim before an idol. Includes man sitting on a high platform, man playing a tambourine, mace, axe, vessels, and arrows.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Text describes how the Indians of Peru would sacrifice men and animals to their gods. The priest would read the entrails to fortell the future. Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [Les Peuples qui habitent sous la ligne Equinoxiale ... ]
Description: Native American man and woman who live beneath the equator. Cultural artifacts include jewelry and basket.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: [Des veines de poix qu'on trouve au Cap de Sainte Helene, & des Géans qui habiterent autrefois en ce lieu-là.]
Description: Men and women flee from an angel throwing fire or lightening bolts. Includes bones or skulls.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: The seams of pitch found at Santa Elena, Ecuador, inspired the native American legend of a race of giants who were punished for sodomy. An angel consumed the giants with fire using a sharp, bright sword, leaving only a few bones and skulls. Captain Juan d

Image_title: [Methods of crossing rivers in Peru]
Description: Methods of crossing rivers in Peru. Native American pushes a European who rests on a raft made of logs or gourds across a river. A family sits at its meal and watches the raft. In the background a man is taken across a river by canoe.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Theodor de Bry's America, Part 9, plate 2, also shows the methods by which the Indians of Peru crossed rivers. The text describes the raft being made of gourds.

Image_title: [Method of hunting among the Indians of the mountains of Peru.]
Description: Method of hunting among the native Americans of the mountains of Peru. The people link arms and herd the game into a net. Includes birds, lion, and dogs.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Text describes how the Indians of Peru captured game, herds of sheep and deer, by using 4 or 5 thousand people who made a huge circle, enclosing a large area of land. By moving closer and closer together, they trapped their prey. Birds, surprised by the n

Image_title: Spanish treatment at Carthagena.
Description: Two Spanish gentlemen beat a chained man with a cat-o-nine tails or whips in Cartagena, present-day Colombia. Other chained men carry hods or shovels. In the background are ships and boats in a harbor with fortifications.
Source_Title: The royal American magazine, or Universal repository of instruction and amusement. For July, 1774
Source_publisher: Printed by and sold at Greenleaf's Printing-Office in Hanover-street ...
notes: The plate accompanies an article on the barbarity of the Spaniards taken from the writing of Bartholomé de las Casas. Revere copied the plate from the London Magazine, Dec. 1771, vol. 40, p. 610. Image is placed horizontally on page. This issue was the first brought out by Joseph Greenleaf, having taken over publication of the magazine by Isaiah Thomas. The magazine was produced from January 1774 until April 1775 when the war put an end to publication.
References: Brigham, C.S. Paul Revere's engravings, p. 87
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: A Sea Lion when suddenly disturbed a Lioness asleep by him & a seal in a moveing posture
Description: Male and female elephant seals.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the second
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Scientific name: Mirounga leonina. The elephant seal is found in the southern part of South America. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Cayman or alligator]
Description: Cayman, crocodile, or alligator.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: This animal is identified in the text as a cayman and is said to resemble the crocodiles found in Egypt.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Chinchona plant]
Description: Chichona plant or quinine bark showing branches, leaves, flowers, and buds. Also includes a child [?] climbing a stalk of the plant which has crosspieces tied to it to act as a ladder. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text.
Source_Title: [Cortex Peruvianus. Italian] La china poemetto
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia degli Eredi Avondo
notes: This book contains a poem on Peruvian bark (Chinchona pubescens Vahl.) Dates of imprint inferred from publisher's introduction (p. 4).

Image_title: [Chinchona plant]
Description: Chichona plant or quinine bark showing branches, leaves, flowers, and buds. Also includes a child [?] climbing a stalk of the plant which has crosspieces tied to it to act as a ladder. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text.
Source_Title: [Cortex Peruvianus. Italian] La china poemetto
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia degli Eredi Avondo
notes: This book contains a poem on Peruvian bark (Chinchona pubescens Vahl.) Dates of imprint inferred from publisher's introduction (p. 4).

Image_title: [Sea snakes or sea kraits]
Description: Sea snakes or sea kraits, showing their rudder-like tails.
Source_Title: Natuurkundige beschryving eener uitmuntende verzameling van zeldsaame gedierten
Source_publisher: J. B. Elwe
notes: These snakes, one of which may be a Pelamis platurus or yellow-bellied sea snake, were included in a pamplet with the title, "Beschryving van twee verschillende en voor als nog zeer weinig bekende Platstaart Slangen, zynde de bruin-rug uit Mexico,"Amsterdam, 1774. The yellow-bellied sea snake can be found on both sides of the Pacific and is amphibious, laying its eggs on land. Arnout Vosmaer was director of the menageries founded in 1756 when the widow of William IV bought Vosmaer's collection. Many rare species were imported from places like Borneo, the Philippines, Surinam, South-Africa and Japan. Between 1766 and 1778 Vosmaer wrote separate pamphlets describing each rare animal. Each description was accompanied by a handcoloured print, usually made by Simon Fokke. Altogether 31 parts were published with 33 engravings. Image information taken from title page of each pamphlet.

Image_title: A View of the Lawn where Commodore Anson pitch'd his Tent at Juan Fernandes.
Description: View of camp site on Juan Fernandez Island. Includes men sitting beside a stream and waterfall, tent, dog, and ships in harbor.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the second
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Text describes the lawn where Commodore George Anson pitched his tent on Juan Fernandez Island. By the time Anson's fleet reached Juan Fernandez Island, the only sanctuary available for the English ship along the Spanish controlled western coast of South America, two thirds of his crew had perished. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Llamas.]
Description: Native Americans put packs on llamas. Includes fortifications.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Text identifies the animals as the sheep of Peru.

Image_title: [On fait mourir Atabaliba, parce qu'on l'accusoit d'avoir voulu faire massacrer tous les Chrétiens. Dom Diegue d'Almagro va pour la second fois au Pérou.]
Description: Native American ruler wearing chains is garroted or executed in a room with Spanish soldiers and [slaves]. Includes pole and rope used to strangle the Inca king.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: The Spanish were uneasy about an uprising by natives as long as Atahualpa (or Atabalipa) remained alive. In 1533, on a trumped-up charge of conspiracy, the Inca king was found guilty and sentenced to death by strangulation. The execution was performed by

Image_title: [De la Nature & des qualités du Pays sur les montagnes du Pérou; & des Indiens & Chrétiens qui y habitent.]
Description: Native American man and woman from the mountains of Peru. Includes bow and ships in the distance.
Source_Title: [Historia del descubrimiento y conquisto de la provincia del Peru. French] Histoire de la découverte et de la conquête du Perou ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Par la compagnie des libraires
notes: Image title taken from chapter title.

Image_title: Entrevue du Commodore Byron avec les Patagons.
Description: Commodore Byron and his men disembark from ships and meet native Americans or Patagonians. Includes boats, guns or muskets, and horses.
Source_Title: [Account of the voyages undertaken by the order of the present Majesty. French] Voyages autour du monde ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: Chez E. van Harrevelt, D.J. Changuion; Chez Henry Beman, Bennet et Hake
notes: In 1766, Commodore John Byron returned to London after circumnavigating the world. Word soon leaked out that the crew had discovered nine-foot tall Patagonian giants. Earlier explorers had also reported a race of giants in Patagonia. As early the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America.The engraver was also known as Robert Delaunay.

Image_title: Vue des indiens de la Terre de Feu dans leurs huttes.
Description: Native American family group sits in a dwelling around a cook fire. Two boys bring fish to the group. Includes basket and harpoon or spear.
Source_Title: [Account of the voyages undertaken by the order of the present Majesty. French] Voyages autour du monde ... Tome second
Source_publisher: Chez E. van Harrevelt, D.J. Changuion; Chez Henry Beman, Bennet et Hake
notes: This image illustrates an account of Captain Cook's expedition through the Strait of Le Maire which separates Staten Island from the island of Tierra del Fuego. He anchored at the Bay of Good Success on January 16, 1769.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Social life and customs

Image_title: [Atahualpa carried on a litter]
Description: The Inca king, Atahualpa or Atabalipa, is carried on a litter by native American soldiers. A monk or priest walks in front of the litter holding a crucifix. In the background is a temple [?]. Includes feathered headdress, bows, open book, cannon, shields,
Source_Title: Histoire philosophique et politique des établissemens et du commerce des Européens dans les deux Indes ... Tome deuxieme
Source_publisher: Chez les libraires associés
notes: Atabalipa, the last independent Incan ruler in Peru, was carried into Cajamarca, in present-day Peru, accompanied by about 15,000 soldiers. A monk named Valverde, confronted Atahualpa with a crucifix and a breviary. When Atahualpa asked how the Spanish kn

Image_title: Plan de la Vera=Cruz Avec les Isles de St. Jean du Luz ...
Description: Map of the city of Veracruz and the fortress of San Juan de Ulúa (here called St. Jean du Luz). Cartographic elements include compass rose, scale, locations of customs house, governor's palace, and fortress. Also includes ships.
Source_Title: Histoire des aventuriers flibustiers qui se sont signalés dans les Indes; contenant ce qu'ils y ont fait de remarquable, avec la vie, les mœurs & les coutumes des boucaniers, & les habitans de St. Domingue & de la Tortue ...
Source_publisher: par la Compagnie.
notes: Hernán Cortés founded Veracruz in 1519; it was the port where the silver from Mexican mines was loaded onto the Spanish treasure fleet. The fortress in the harbor is San Juan de Ulúa. In 1683, 600 men under the command of the pirates, Laurens de Graff and Michel de Grammont, looted and terrorized the city of 5,000 inhabitants.Vols. 1-2, by Alexandre Olivier Exquemelin, are a translation by de Frontignières of: Piratas de la America. Cologne, 1681, itself a translation of: De Americaensche zee-roovers. Amsterdam, 1678. French translation originally published Paris, 1686.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plan de la Ville de Cartagene ...
Description: Map of the city of Cartagena and surrounding area including the bay. Elements in the image are lettered for identification in key within the image. Includes ships and fortifications. Cartographic elements include scale, compass rose, and soundings.
Source_Title: Histoire des aventuriers flibustiers qui se sont signalés dans les Indes; contenant ce qu'ils y ont fait de remarquable, avec la vie, les mœurs & les coutumes des boucaniers, & les habitans de St. Domingue & de la Tortue ...
Source_publisher: par la Compagnie.
notes: Cartagena in present-day Colombia was founded in 1533 by Pedro de Heredia. It is one of the most heavily fortified ports due to the fact that it was so often attacked by pirates and privateers. In 1697 the French buccaneer Jean Du Casse (or Ducasse) led pirates, and Jean Bernard Desjeans, Baron de Pointis, led soldiers on a successful attack of the city. The soldiers who had collected all the loot refused to share it with the pirates, so the pirates sacked the city again.Vols. 1-2, by Alexandre Olivier Exquemelin, are a translation by de Frontignières of: Piratas de la America. Cologne, 1681, itself a translation of: De Americaensche zee-roovers. Amsterdam, 1678. French translation originally published Paris, 1686.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Rto. de la hermosissima Imagen de N.S. Crusificado, y milagrosamente renovado; q. se venera en el Cto. antiguo de Sras. Carmelitas descalzas de Mexico.
Description: Image of Christ Crucified [Cristo renovado], with four vases of stylized flowers.
Source_Title: Exaltacion de la divina misericordia en la milagrosa renovacion de la soberana imagen de Christo Sr. Nro. crucificado ...
Source_publisher: en la Imprena del Lic. D. Joseoph de Jauregui, Calle de san Bernardo
notes: The book tells the history of the statue of Christ Crucified to which many miracles were attributed. This statue was first created in 1545 in the town of Izmiquilpa. In the seventeenth century, it was moved to the Convent of San José of the Discalced Carmelite Women in Mexico City.
SubjectHeadings2: Convento de San José (Mexico City, Mexico)

Image_title: Tavola. 1. Givoco il Quechucague
Image_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
Description: Two native American children sit playing a Quechua game before a branch of culèn and a Chilean pine and palm tree.
Source_Title: Compendio della storia geografica, naturale, e civile del regno del Chile
Source_publisher: Nella stamperìa di S. Tommaso d'Aquino
notes: This work was published anonymously. The plants illustrated here figure predominantly in Mapuche Indian medicine. Culen, Psoralea glandulosa, commonly known as culen scurt pea and Jesuit's tea, was a common medicinal herb of the Mapuche. The Chilean palm, Jubaea chilensis, is commonly known as Chilean wine palm or coquito palm. The pine tree, Araucaria araucana, commonly known as monkeypuzzle tree or, in Spanish, as pehuén, was prized by the Mapuche who used its seeds as a staple food. They also used the tree as a center for their ceremonies.

Image_title: Nuovo Messico
Description: Bird's-eye view of Mexico City. Built environment includes churches, walls, fountains, and dwellings. Also includes domestic animals, dogs, horses, fields outside of the city walls and black or native American men farming, boating on a canal or river, hauling goods on an ox-drawn cart, and carrying loads on their backs.
Source_Title: Atlante dell'America contenente le migliori carte geographiche ...
Source_publisher: Presso Gio. Tommaso Masi e comp.
notes: Derived from a view in an unpublished atlas by Johannes Vingboons in 1628, this image was probably copied from a map of Juan Gomez de Trasmonte, supervisor for the construction of the drainage system of Mexico City in 1628. This post-conquest map may have been brought to the Netherlands by Adrian Boot, the Belgian engineer responsible for designing the project. This image is derived from Il gazzettiere Americano, vol. 2, Livorno, 1763, which in turn is derived from Arnoldus Montanus, De nieuwe en onbekende Weereld: of Beschryving van America, Amsterdam, 1671.
References: Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.23; Lombardo de Ruiz, S. Atlas histórico de la ciudad de México, lamina 125
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Pianta di Cusco nel tempo della Conquista che ne fecero gli Spagnoli
Description: Plan of Cuzco, Peru, before the conquest by the Spaniards. Includes town walls and the castle or central temple.
Source_Title: Atlante dell'America contenente le migliori carte geographiche ...
Source_publisher: Presso Gio. Tommaso Masi e comp.
notes: This image is also in ll gazzettiere Americano, vol. 1, Livorno, 1763.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Veduta della Citta, e della Montagna del Potosi
Description: View of Potosí, including its mountain. Includes a chapel at the top of the mountain, dwellings, churches, windmills, wooden cart, palm trees, and horses.
Source_Title: Atlante dell'America contenente le migliori carte geographiche ...
Source_publisher: Presso Gio. Tommaso Masi e comp.
notes: First discovered by the Spanish in 1547, Potosí was illustrated in Pedro de Cieza de León, Parte primera de la chronica del Peru, Seville, 1553. This view is derived from Arnoldus Montanus, De nieuwe en onbekende Weereld, Amsterdam, 1671.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Amor Increatus in Creaturas effusus
Description: Jesus Christ on a cross [Christ Crucified] is shown with blood flowing from his hands and side. Around the crucifix stand men and women praying. At least one of the people may be native American [?].
Source_Title: Chilidúgu sive Res Chilenses ... Tomus III
Source_publisher: Typis Aschendorfianis sumptibus Bernardi Havestadt
notes: Havestadt, a German Jesuit who had lived in Chile for twenty years, compiled this treatise on the Araucanian Indian language in Germany after the expulsion of the Jesuits from the Spanish colonies.

Image_title: Ses levres tremblerent en prononçant le voeu que son coeur devoit abjurer.
Description: In an Inca temple, three virgins who are to become brides of the sun are revealed by the priest to the king.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism.

Image_title: La famille d'Ataliba...dormoit alors autour de lui.
Description: Three European men enter the cell where Ataliba [Atahualpa] and his family are held prisoner.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism. The Spaniard Requelme visits Atahualpa [Ataliba] and his sleeping family in the room where they are imprisoned to baptize Atahualpa and then have him killed.

Image_title: Arrète! commence par moi: je me défie de ma main, et je veux mourir de la sienne.
Description: Native American man leads a native American woman from a scene of battle between native American and European forces. Includes feathered skirts and headdresses, quivers, and bow and arrows.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism.

Image_title: Cora, desolée et tremblante, étoit tombée à ses genoux.
Description: In a landscape with a building in the distance, a young native American woman kneels at the feet of a young European man.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism. Cora and Alonzo have declared their love, but she fears that her family's lives will be forfeit, because she has broken her vow to be the bride of the sun god.

Image_title: Ô malheureux enfant! qui m'eut dit qu'un jour tu aurois à rougir de ton pere?
Description: Four native Americans, two men and two women, converse in a European-style interior.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism. Atahualpa is reproached by his mother for preferring a "dishonorable" peace to upholding the laws and ideals of his ancestors.

Image_title: Vois, cruel, ce que tu me coutes.
Description: Two noble native Americans argue with the body of another native American between them.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism. Huascar, bound with ropes, and his brother, Atahualpa, argue over the dead body of Atahualpa's son.

Image_title: Ah cruel! dis-nous donc, si tu veux mourir, quel est l'ami que tu nous laisses.
Description: Three European men attend the deathbed of an elderly European man. A native American man and woman approach the bed.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism. The cacique [chief or ruler], Henri, brings a female companion to the sickbed of Las Casas. The woman has lost her child, and milk from her breast will cure the illness of the priest.

Image_title: Kleidung und Lebens Art der Spanier in Süd-America
Description: Clothing and manners of the Spanish in South America. Includes a man playing a guitar, a woman lying on a couch, a child paying with a dog [?], and a woman carrying a basket of flowers. Also includes a sheet of music, tennis racket, and an arrow.
Source_Title: [New system of geography. Book 4 and Appendix. German ] Neue Erdbeschreibung von ganz Amerika ... Sechster Theil
Source_publisher: in der Weygandschen Buchhandlung

Image_title: Ynca Manco Capac Vater Seines Volks.
Description: Native Americans bow down before the Inca king and queen. In the background, others build the Inca capital, Cuzco. Cultural artifacts include feathered headdresses, earrings, bow and arrow, dwellings, and club.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: Manco Capac, with his sister Mama-Ocllo (Oello), known as children of the Sun, were revered as the progenitors of Inca civilization. The last Inca emperor was also named Manco Capac and crowned as a puppet king by Francisco Pizarro. Cf. 02318-2 & 04878-53. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Opfer welches die Floridaner der sonne mit ihrer erst-gebuhrt bringen.
Description: Native American woman weeps before a tree trunk while another woman holds a baby. Other women dance around the woman and baby. A ruler or chief sits on a bench with other men nearby. Includes war clubs.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image is derived from the second part of Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 2, plate 34, and describes how the natives sacrifice their first-born son to their chief in Florida. The mother whose child it is weeps in front of the tree trunk upon which the sacrifice is to occur. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815.
SubjectHeadings3: Indians of North America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Witwen aus Florida die ihre Haare auf das Grab ihrer Maenner streuen
Description: Native American women scatter their cut hair over graves upon which are placed quivers of arrows, bows, spears, and drinking shells. Includes baskets.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image is derived from the second part of Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 2, plate 19, and describes how the widow of a man killed in warfare in Florida cuts her hair and scatters it on the grave of her husband along with his weapons and drinking shells. Widows are forbidden to remarry until their hair grows long enough to cover their shoulders.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of North America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Floridanerinnen die ihre Maenner im Krige verlohren haben und ihre caciquen um Beystand anflehen
Description: Native American women weep and mourn before their chief or cacique who wears a feathered headdress and pectoral or breastplate. Men carry dead or wounded in background. Includes tattoos.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image is derived from the second part of Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 2, plate 18, describes the widows of men killed in warfare in Florida who petition the chief for their livelihood and to avenge their husbands. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of North America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Opferung eines gefangenen bey de Antiern
Description: Native Americans torture another by cutting him, collecting his blood, and eating his flesh (scene of cannibalism). Includes a temple in the background in which a skeleton hangs and before which people make an offering. Includes knives, shield, war club, arrows, and post at which the victim is tied.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: Cf. 02318-5. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Der Sonnen-Tempel.
Description: Sun temple of the Incas. Native Americans are shown processing to the temple, dancing, and worshipping the sun. They bring fish, birds, and animals into the temple.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image is derived from the title page of Garsilasso de la Vega, Le commentaire royal, ov L'histoire des Yncas, Paris, 1633.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Rittermachen der Incas
Description: Native American ceremony for initiation into nobility. The Inca king, enthroned in a Western (Classical) architectural setting, pierces the earlobe of one of his subjects. Other prospective nobles await their turns and have sandals fitted on their feet. Decorative elements include statues in niches with reliefs of native birds, beasts, and insects.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image is derived Garsilasso de la Vega, Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Amsterdam, 1737.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Der Yncas verheirathung der Prinzen von geblüte.
Description: Native American marriage or wedding ceremony between two members of Inca nobility. In the background are dwellings and fortifications of a city. Also includes feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image is derived Garsilasso de la Vega, Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Amsterdam, 1737. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Marriage customs and rites
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Bezeigen der Peruaner bey einer Mond finsterniss.
Description: Native Americans or Inca cry out in dismay during a lunar eclipse. Men beat dogs with ropes and sticks. Includes musical instruments such as tambourine, drums, and mallets. Also includes moon, fortifications of a city, and dwellings.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image is derived from Garsilasso de la Vega, Histoire des Yncas rois du Perou, Amsterdam, 1737.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Schlange Göttlich verehrt von den Guaÿacuruern.
Description: Giant snake eats a lion while a man is attacked by beasts with sharp teeth. Includes the bodies of other victims or sacrifices.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image was also used in Arnoldus Montanus, De nieuwe en onbekende Weereld, Amsterdam, 1671 (cf. 01631-57), where it is used to describe a temple in the Yucatan discovered by Francisco Fernandez de Córdoba and Cristobal Morantes. The temple is described as being a theater of marble with huge figures carved on the top. People were daily executed within the bars and their bodies thrown down on the ground below. Here the image describes the sacred snake of the Guayacuru (indigenous peoples of the Chaco?).

Image_title: Opfer welches die Floridaner der Sonne mit einem Hirsche bringen.
Description: How native Americans from Florida offer a stag as part of a religious ceremony. The stag, decorated with garlands or flowers, is impaled on a pole.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: This image is derived from the second part of Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 2, plate 35, and describes how the natives in Florida annually at the end of winter take the skin of the largest stag they have been able to capture, stuff it, and place it so that its head faces the rising sun.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of North America--Rites and ceremonies

Image_title: Mappa Geographica exhibens Provincias, Oppida, Sacella &c quae Mensibus Novembri ac Decembri anni 1751 et ... anni 1752 peragravit ad Indorum Chilensium terras ...
Description: Map showing the provinces, missions, towns, and shrines of the Jesuits in Chile between November 1751 and March 1752. Cartographic elements include location of rivers, compass rose, scale, some topographical details, and degrees of latitude and longitude. Decorative elements include animals such as cattle, horse, goats, sheep, llama, and a rhea. Also includes native American towns. Decorative cartouche includes a Jesuit monk [Havestadt?] holding a biretta and wearing a crucifix. Also includes altar with a picture of the Virgin and child.
Source_Title: Chilidúgu sive Res Chilenses ... Tomus III
Source_publisher: Typis Aschendorfianis sumptibus Bernardi Havestadt
notes: Havestadt, a German Jesuit who had lived in Chile for twenty years, compiled this treatise on the Araucanian Indian language in Germany after the expulsion of the Jesuits from the Spanish colonies.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Que fais tu! ne sommes-nous pas Freres? n'es-tu pas mon égal?
Description: A cacique or native American chief or ruler, a monk, and a European man in an interior. Includes feathered headdress and quiver of arrows.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism. Text explains that Las Casas has convinced the Cacique that man's better [Christian] nature requires magnanimity and kindness. The Cacique releases Gonsalve, the son of Governor Davila, because he is touched by Las Casas' argument. It is the Cacique who speaks the caption when the freed young man falls at his feet in gratitude.

Image_title: Daigne agréer cette douce compagne. elle est sensible[;] elle t'aimera.
Description: Native American woman presents young native American woman to a seated European man with a cacique [chief or ruler], standing beside him. Two other native American women stand behind the one being presented.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism. A young native American woman is presented as a possible companion for Alonzo, one of Pizarro's men.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Social life and customs

Image_title: Ah! laiße moi, et sauve Telasco.
Description: Two native American men pull a woman into a boat while another rows. Another native American swims toward the boat.
Source_Title: Les Incas, ou, La destruction de l'empire du Pérou
Source_publisher: chez Henry-Louis Broenner
notes: Marmontel, better known for his libretti, wrote Les Incas... as a philosophical romance meant to attack fanaticism. Text explains that the native American Orozimbo rescued his sister and his friend from drowning after the boat in which they were sailing sank.

Image_title: Vitzliputzli, vornehmster Götze der Mexicaner.
Description: Scene of worship and human sacrifice at a native American or Mexican temple. The victim's heart is cut out before an idol or statue by a priest with a knife. The priest's assistants hold the victim by all four limbs. Includes feathered headdresses, statue of a winged and cloven-hoofed god in feathered headdress and garments who holds snakes and a shield.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America ... Zweyter Theil
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. The offering of the victim's heart to the gods derived from the Aztec belief that the sun would rise again nourished by the hearts of men. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9, plate 8. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815.

Image_title: Begraebnis-platz der opfer
Description: Aztec or Mexican cemetery (tzompantli) for sacrificial victims. Human skulls are placed in tiers or piled in niches in walls. Native Americans converse or place skulls in tiers.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America ... Zweyter Theil
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: Text describes the cemetery as a sort of theater with towers and walls made out of skulls and lime. Aztec temples used tzompantli to hold the skulls of sacrificial victims. This image is derived from l'abbé Prévost, Histoire générale des voyages, Paris, 1759. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of Mexico--Funeral customs and rites

Image_title: Zeitvertreib des kaisers nach der tafel
Description: Native Americans or Mexicans dance before the emperor or king. Includes feathered headdresses, garments, and fans, musical instruments or drums, and throne.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America ... Zweyter Theil
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: Text describes the eating habits of Montezuma (Moctezuma) and how he was entertained after dining by dances and poems set to music. This image is derived from l'abbé Prévost, Histoire générale des voyages, Paris, 1759.

Image_title: Tänze Mitoles
Description: Method of dancing among native Mexicans. Men dance while standing on each other's shoulders and while walking on a rope. Also includes a man being ferried across a river, feathered headdresses and garments, ship, spears, and musical instruments such as drums.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America ... Zweyter Theil
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: Mitotes were ceremonies involving chanting and drinking usually held after a hunt or as part of a funeral. This image is derived from Theodor de Bry's America, Pt. 9, 3rd part, plate 11, which describes the dances of the Mexicans. The image of how Mexicans cross rivers is from the same Theodor de Bry, Pt. 9, 3rd part, plate 2. Cf. 06381-6, 04878-38.

Image_title: Chronologisches rad der Mexicaner.
Description: Aztec solar circular calendar. Divided into four divisions of time, the reed (acatl), the rabbit (tochtli), the house (calli), and the flint (tecpatl), the symbols for the eighteen months, and the phases of the moon.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America ... Zweyter Theil
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: The Aztecs used two calendars to compute the days of the year. The first (or solar) calendar (xiuhpohualli) consisted of 365 days, divided into eighteen "months" of twenty units each, plus an additional period of five unlucky days at the end of the year. The second calendar was called the tonalpohualli or "day count." Its cycle was made up of 260 days, combinations of 13 numbers and twenty symbols. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815. Image derived from Awnsham and John Churchill, editors, A collection of voyages and travels, London, 1704.

Image_title: Bilder=Schrifft der Mexicaner
Description: Aztec pictographs showing tribute paid by various villages to Aztec rulers. Items in the image are lettered for identification in text [not located].
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America ... Zweyter Theil
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe

Image_title: A Woman of Lima in full dress, a D[on]a: behind her in undress; a Spaniard drest as they are in Peru, and a Mulatto and Negro Servant.
Description: Two women of Lima, one wearing outdoor dress and the other wearing a domestic dress, speak to a gentleman. Also includes two black servants or slaves.
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: Text describes the richness of the dress in Lima. The image is derived from vol. 2 of II gazzettiere Americano, Livorno, 1763.

Image_title: Marina and other Indian Girls, presented to Cortez, & his Companions at Tabasco.
Description: Native American girls or women are presented to Hernán Cortés and his men. Includes women examining trade goods, combs, mirrors, and scissors, and women dancing around a hammock. Also includes ships, dwellings, and swords.
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: Doña Marina or Malinche (in Nahuatl, Malintzin) served as Cortés's translator, negotiator, and cultural mediator from 1519 to 1526. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of Mexico--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: The Public Entry of Cortez & his Companions, into Mexico.
Description: Hernán Cortés and a native American noble greet each other in a Mexican city. Cortés's men ride horses while the native American is carried in a chair and attended by his retinue.
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of Mexico--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: A View of the City of Mexico.
Description: View of Mexico City or Tenochtitlán showing the various islands, aqueduct, and causeways or bridges which linked the city. Also includes men on horseback, domestic animals, boats, churches, dwellings, wicker dams, and main square.
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: The city is probably shown as the artist imagined Tenochtitlan was before Europeans arrived, but with European-type houses and churches and men on horseback or herding sheep. The image is derived from Carol Allard, Orbis habitabilis oppida et vestitas, Amsterdam 1681, who in turn derived his view from the Hernán Cortés map-view of Tenochtitlán. Image placed horizontally on page.
References: Cf. Kagan, R.L. Urban Images of the Hispanic World, Fig. 4.24, p. 92-93
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: A View of the Great Temple of Mexico.
Description: Bird's-eye view of the main temple [the Templo mayor] of Mexico City. The temple is encircled by a wall with serpents or snakes carved on it and two sanctuaries on the top before which priests sacrifice a victim. A body is tossed down the stairs. Dancers celebrate before the temple within the wall. In foreground is a skull rack or tzompantli and native Americans with bows and arrows wearing feathered headdresses and garments.
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: The great temple at Tenochtitlan was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc, the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli. Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. Tlaloc, the god of rain and agriculture, was of pre-Aztec, or Toltec, origin. A coatepantli or wall made of sculpted serpents often surrounds Aztec temples. The tzompantli would hold the skulls of sacrificial victims. This image is similar to the one printed in Antonio de Solís, Histoire de la conquête du Mexique, Paris, 1691. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The Temple of the Sun.
Description: Interior of a temple dedicated to the sun. Includes native Americans worshipping before an image of the sun. The walls are decorated with paintings of trees and animals such as a monkey and lion.
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: Text describes the religion of the Inca.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Batses, or Jangades of the Peruvians.
Description: Raft and boats of the native Americans of Peru. Includes a raft with sail, shelter and cookfire, as well as balsa boats. Also includes a penguin and fox [?].
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: The image of Peruvian boats is derived from Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, plate 2.

Image_title: Tezcaltliputca, the Mexican God of Pennance and Remission of Sins.
Description: Religious rites of native Americans. Priests flagellate themselves with rope, pierce their feet with nails, and offer incense to an idol holding arrows in one hand and a religious object in the other. Also includes skulls and bones.
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: Priests (tlamacazqui or keepers of the gods) of Mexico would flagellate themselves, pierce their feet with thorns, or beat each other with stones to atone for the sins of the common people. They would play musical instruments such as horns, use incense, and wash their idol in blood. Here the god is referred to as Tezcaltlipoca (usually Tezcatlipoca) or "Smoking Mirror" (the Toltec god of the night sky and memory) whose symbols include a flaming mirror and arrows. This work is derived from Theodor de Bry's America. Pt. 9, plate 7, but there the god is referred to as Huitzilopochtli (the god of the sun and war). Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Grosser tempel in Mexico
Description: Bird's-eye view of the main temple [the Templo mayor] of Tenochtitlán [Mexico City]. The temple is encircled by a wall with serpents or snakes carved on it and has two sanctuaries. In foreground is a skull rack or tzompantli. Includes view of the surrounding town with gardens, dwellings, fortifications, and distant lake.
Source_Title: Sitten und Meinungen der Wilden in America ... Zweyter Theil
Source_publisher: bey Johann Gottlieb Garbe
notes: The great temple at Tenochtitlan was surmounted by two sanctuaries--the one on the left dedicated to Tlaloc, the one on the right to Huitzilopochtli. Huitzilopochtli, whose name means "Blue hummingbird on the left," was the Aztec god of the sun and war. The turquoise or fire serpent (xiuhcoatl) was his mystical weapon. Tlaloc, the god of rain and agriculture, was of pre-Aztec, or Toltec, origin. A coatepantli or wall made of sculpted serpents often surrounds Aztec temples. The tzompantli would hold the skulls of sacrificial victims. This image is similar to the one printed in Antonio de Solís, Histoire de la conquête du Mexique, Paris, 1691. The engraver may be Johann Michael Zell, 1740-1815.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: View of the Palace and Citadel which the Inca Kings had near the Village of Canar, the Walls of which are still remaining.
Description: Bird's-eye view of the palace and citadel of the Inca kings in Cañar [Cannar].
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: The ruins of Ingapirca, in present-day Ecuador, still stand in the province of Cañar. The Temple of the Sun was used by the Cañari and Inca cultures mainly for ceremonies and rituals, and was elliptical in shape. The ruins consist of a cemetery, solar observatories, roads, storage areas, priests' chambers, and a native square. Image is derived from Antonio de Ulloa, Voyage historique de l'Amerique meridionale, Amsterdam & Leipzig, 1752.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Inhabitants of the Straights of Magellan, commonly called Patagonians.
Description: Native Americans stand before boats and a shelter or dwelling.
Source_Title: The history of America, from its discovery by Columbus ... Volume I.
Source_publisher: Printed for Fielding and Walker, no. 20, Pater-noster-Row
notes: Text refutes the idea that the Patagonians are a giant race.

Image_title: Bartolammeo Di Las-Casas Vescovo di Chiappa
Description: Portrait of Bartolomé de las Casas wearing a biretta and pectoral cross. Includes bishop's mitre, book, and crosier.
Source_Title: [History of America. Books 1-8. Italian] Storia di America del dottore Guglielmo Robertson tradotta dall' originale inglese dall' abate Antonio Pillori fiorentino Tomo II.
Source_publisher: Presso Giovanni Gatti
notes: Bartolomé is the author of Brevísima Relacion de la Destruycion de las Indias (Seville, 1552) in which he accuses the Spanish of abusing the aboriginal population. He became bishop of Chiapas, in Southern Mexico.Four volumes bound in two.

Image_title: Ferdinando Cortes Cavato da un Originale fatto innanzi ch'ei si portasse alla conquista del Messico
Description: Portrait of Hernán Cortés holding a baton and wearing armor. Includes spears, pike, animals, and horn (musical instrument).
Source_Title: [History of America. Books 1-8. Italian] Storia di America del dottore Guglielmo Robertson tradotta dall' originale inglese dall' abate Antonio Pillori fiorentino Tomo III.
Source_publisher: Presso Giovanni Gatti
notes: Four volumes bound in two.

Image_title: Francesco Pizzarro Conquistatore del Perú.
Description: Portrait of Francisco Pizarro holding a baton and wearing armor.
Source_Title: [History of America. Books 1-8. Italian] Storia di America del dottore Guglielmo Robertson tradotta dall' originale inglese dall' abate Antonio Pillori fiorentino Tomo IV.
Source_publisher: Presso Giovanni Gatti
notes: Four volumes bound in two.

Image_title: The Muskitoe Indians Plundering the Town of Cheriqui and Burning a Spanish Priest
Description: Native Americans dance around a man bound on a pole in a fire. Includes fortifications on fire, scene of looting (a man throws a bundle out of the steeple of a church), dwellings, bows, and arrows.
Source_Title: [Unfortunate Englishmen] The unfortunate Englishmen; or, A faithful narrative of the distresses and adventures of John Cockburn, and five other English mariners
Source_publisher: Printed, and sold by all the booksellers, in town and country
notes: Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Caralteri numerali, e figure simboliche.
Description: Aztec numbers and symbols. Symbols "translated" into Italian in lettered key within image.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: [top] Strumenti musicali. [bottom] Forma del Ballo grande. Pianta del giuoco del Pallone.
Description: [top] Musical instruments and native Mexicans playing them. [botttom] Plan of the court used for playing an Aztec ball game. The musical instruments are numbered for identification at the bottom of the image and are two drums called huehuetl and teponaztli and a rattle or maraca called ajacaxtli.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
notes: Aztecs believed that music was a gift brought to earth by the gods. The drums were venerated as spiritual beings sent from the court of the sun by Tezcatlipoca, the god of the night sky and memory, and Quetzalcoatl, the wind god. The huehuetl, from the Nahuatl word for ancient, is an upright wooden drum. The teponaztli is a wooden drum played on its side. Clavigero, a native of Veracruz, Mexico, wrote this four-volume study of pre-conquest Mexico based on themes laid down by Lorenzo Boturini Benaducci.
References_exhibitions: Hough, S.J. Italians and the creation of America, 71
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: Figure significanti i nomi de' Re messicani.
Description: Symbols of Aztec emperors. Items in the image are numbered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: Figure di Città
Description: Symbols of Aztec cities. Includes the cactus, calendar, and fish. Items in the image are numbered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
References: Cañizares-Esguerra, J. How to write the history of the New World, p. 242
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: Modo di fare il pane
Description: Method of making bread. Native America women are shown husking, grinding, shaping, and cooking tortillas. Items in the image are numbered for identification in key below.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: Abiti Messicani.
Description: Costumes of native Americans or Mexicans, a peasant man and woman, a nobleman and noblewoman, a soldier, and a priest. Includes basket, axe or hatchet, feather fan, cloak, tilma, shield, war club, bow and arrows, and a chalice.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: Giuoco de Volatori.
Description: Flying dance of the Mexicas or Aztecs. Includes native Americans with feathered headdresses climbing a pole and another descending from the pole on ropes at the ends of which captive birds fly. At the top another man stands holding a flag. Here the birds are tethered to the cords.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
notes: An ancient ritual, the Sun Dance was performed for the god of fertility, Xipe Totec, to ensure success in harvest. The four (symbolic of the four cardinal directions) dancers or voladores would climb a high pole to which they were tethered by cords. The fifth dancer (or caporal) acted as priest and musician and invoked the god's protection. The dancers would fly around the pole like birds and descend headfirst to ground. Initially suppressed after the conquest, the dance was considered an interesting game by the Spanish.
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: Geschenken van Montezuma aan Cortes.
Description: Native Americans or Mexicans present an image of a sun and moon to Hernán Cortés, a European soldier in armor. Includes feathered headdresses and garments, spears, and bows.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a-4a. Dutch] Brieven van Ferdinand Cortes, aan Keiser Karel V. wegens de verovering van Mexico Eerste deel
Source_publisher: By Yntema en Tieboel.
notes: Cortés conquered Mexico in the years 1519 to 1521 and defeated the Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II (Montezuma II).
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of Mexico--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: Ontmoeting van Cortes met Montezuma.
Description: Native Americans or Mexicans approach Hernán Cortés, a European soldier in armor. Includes Moctezuma under a feathered parasol with attendants, chest, llama [?], settlement, and feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: [Cartas. Carta 2a-4a. Dutch] Brieven van Ferdinand Cortes, aan Keiser Karel V. wegens de verovering van Mexico Eerste deel
Source_publisher: By Yntema en Tieboel.
