Image_title: Veduta di un Campo Indiano
Description: Native Americans of the Orinoco River valley cultivate plants. Botanical elements include pineapple, manioc or cassava and its tubers, banana palms, and the yupa, curupa, ñopo, or curuba tree. Cultural artifacts include hoe and spade. Items in the image are numbered for identification in text.
Source_Title: Saggio di storia americana o Sia storia naturale, civile, e sacra de regni, e delle provincie spagnuole di terra-ferma nell'America meridionale ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: Per Luigi Perego erede Salvioni stampator Vaticano nella Sapienza
notes: The yupa plant is the source of the hallucinogenic drug made from the seeds of various species of piptadenias and used by many indigenous tribes in South America and the Caribbean. The ground seeds are inhaled as a powder using a bifurcated tube into the nostrils.
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)

Image_title: Lavoro dell'Olio di Tartaruga
Description: Native Americans extract oil from tortoise eggs. Eggs are crushed in a tub with a pestle, cooked over an open fire, and then ladled into calabashes or gourds. Also includes turtles or tortoises.
Source_Title: Saggio di storia americana o Sia storia naturale, civile, e sacra de regni, e delle provincie spagnuole di terra-ferma nell'America meridionale ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: Per Luigi Perego erede Salvioni stampator Vaticano nella Sapienza
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)

Image_title: Veduta di una Ranceria
Description: Native Americans in an agricultural scene. Man in European dress speaks to native Americans who start a fire with a fire drill. Another man butchers an animal (perhaps a manatee?). Built environment includes canoes, paddles, and dwelling. Also includes an alligator, hammocks, and cooking pot.
Source_Title: Saggio di storia americana o Sia storia naturale, civile, e sacra de regni, e delle provincie spagnuole di terra-ferma nell'America meridionale ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: Per Luigi Perego erede Salvioni stampator Vaticano nella Sapienza

Image_title: 1. Coatzontecoxochitl. 2. Xiloxochitl. 3. Iolloxochitl. 4 Occloxochitl. 5. Macpalxochitl. 6 Nopalxochquetzalli. 7 Tlalcacahuatl. 8 Tliltzapotl. 9 Chajotli.
Description: Nine flowers of Mexico.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
notes: 1. Coatzontecoxochitl (or flower with the viper's head, Scientific name: Stanhopea hernandezii. 2. Xiloxochitl translates as "corn-silk flower." 2. Xiloxochitl (flower from a tree: red-silk cotton tree or clavellina). 3. Iolloxochitl (or Yoloxochitl "heart-flower" or magnolia. Scientific name: Talauma mexicana (DC.) G. Don.). 4, Occloxochitl ([tiger lily (Tigridia pavonia)] bulb and flower). 5. Macpalxochiltl flower from a tree: devil's hand tree. Scientific name: Chiranthodendron pentadactylon). 6. Nopalxochquetzalli (prickly pear of Mexico. Scientific name: Opuntia). 7 Tlalcacahuatl. (seedpod from a legume or peanut. Scientific name: Arachis hypogaea). 8 Tliltzapotl (fruit and branch of a tree, Zapota negro, black sapote, or Diospyros Tlilzapotl. Scientific name: Diospyros nigra). 9 Chajotli (or, perhaps chayote, although the chayote does not have a prickly husk. Scientific name: Sechium edule). Clavigero, a native of Veracruz, Mexico, wrote this four-volume study of pre-conquest Mexico based on themes laid down by Lorenzo Boturini Benaducci
References_exhibitions: Hough, S.J. Italians and the creation of America, 71
Provenance_Donor: Acquired before 1870 by John Carter Brown.

Image_title: 1. Tigre Messna. 2. Tlacocelotl. 3. Itzcuintepotzotli. 4. Istrice Messno. 5. Re de' Zopiloti. 6. Axolotl. 7. Occhione. 8. Tepajaxin. 9. Anfisbena Messna. 10. 11. Temolin.
Description: Nine animals and insects of Mexico.
Source_Title: Storia antica del Messico cavata da' migliori storici spagnuoli, e da' manoscritti, e dalle pitture antiche degl' Indiani ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Gregorio Biasini all' Insegna di Pallade
notes: 2. Tlalcojotl (or Tlalcoyoto or badger?). 3. Itzcuintapolzotli, or hunch-backed dog, 4. Istrice Messno or Huitztlacuatzin, hedge-hog or porcupine of Mexico 5. Re de' Zopito or buzzard (raven or king of the zipilotes) 6. axolotl (or great water lizard). 7. Occhione or limpet. 8. Terpjaxin or other reptile (horned lizard?). 9. amphisbaena (two-headed snake). and 10 & 11. Stag beetle. Clavigero, a native of Veracruz, Mexico, wrote this four-volume study of pre-conquest Mexico based on themes laid down by Lorenzo Boturini Benaducci.
References_exhibitions: Hough, S.J. Italians and the creation of America, 71

Image_title: [Apparatus for extracting fetuses]
Description: A surgical instrument comprised of a small chamber attached by a tube to a suction device.
Source_Title: El zelo sacerdotal para con los niños nonacidos.
Source_publisher: Imprenta de los Niños Expositos
notes: A member of the Order of the Buena Muerte and known for his interest in botany, González Laguna advocated the post-mortem removal of fetuses from the wombs of deceased women in order to carry out the baptism of those unborn children. His determination to do so was sparked by events during the Tupac Katari Rebellion of 1780-1781.

Image_title: Indiani dell' alto Orinoco
Description: Native Americans roast human limbs over a grill. Includes scene of cannibalism.
Source_Title: Saggio di storia americana o Sia storia naturale, civile, e sacra de regni, e delle provincie spagnuole di terra-ferma nell'America meridionale ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Luigi Perego erede Salvioni stampator Vaticano nella Sapienza
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)

Image_title: Modo di fare il Pane chiamato Casave
Description: Native American women process cassava or manioc. Three women pound the manioc, one sits on a limb which extracts liquid from woven sack, another grates the tubers into a tub. The cakes of expressed manioc are baked over a fire. Also includes dwellings, grill, and mortar and pestles.
Source_Title: Saggio di storia americana o Sia storia naturale, civile, e sacra de regni, e delle provincie spagnuole di terra-ferma nell'America meridionale ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Luigi Perego erede Salvioni stampator Vaticano nella Sapienza
notes: To process manioc the roots were grated and pounded into a pulp which was put into long cylinders made of woven plant fibers. Each tube was hung with a heavy weight at the bottom, which compressed the pulp and expressed the poisonous juice. The pulp could then be removed, washed and roasted, rendering it safe to eat.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)

Image_title: Armi degli Orinochesi
Description: Native Americans prepare to go to war. Includes soldiers with bows and arrows, women and children weeping and lamenting their departure, dwellings, and a man playing a musical instrument [drum]. Items in the image are numbered.
Source_Title: Saggio di storia americana o Sia storia naturale, civile, e sacra de regni, e delle provincie spagnuole di terra-ferma nell'America meridionale ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Luigi Perego erede Salvioni stampator Vaticano nella Sapienza
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)

Image_title: Indiani del basso Orinoco
Description: Native Americans distribute goods from box. Cultural artifacts include necklaces, knife, mirrors, scissors, bracelets, and anklets. Includes dwelling. Items in the image are numbered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Saggio di storia americana o Sia storia naturale, civile, e sacra de regni, e delle provincie spagnuole di terra-ferma nell'America meridionale ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Per Luigi Perego erede Salvioni stampator Vaticano nella Sapienza
notes: Text identifies the native Americans as Caribs.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)

Image_title: Trapetum commune.
Description: Sugar cane mill or press driven by mules. Blacks [slaves] drive mules and insert sugar canes into grinding wheels. Items in the image are lettered in poem for identification.
Source_Title: Rusticatio mexicana
Source_publisher: Ex Typographia S. Thomae Aquinatis
notes: Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Trapetum aquarium.
Description: Sugar cane mill or press driven by water. Black worker [slave] inserts sugar canes into grinding wheels. Items in the image are lettered in poem for identification.
Source_Title: Rusticatio mexicana
Source_publisher: Ex Typographia S. Thomae Aquinatis
notes: Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Volantum ludus.
Description: Flying dance of the Mexicas or Aztecs. Includes native Americans dressed with feathers climbing a pole and flying around it held by ropes. A man seated on the top of the pole plays a drum.
Source_Title: Rusticatio mexicana
Source_publisher: Ex Typographia S. Thomae Aquinatis
notes: An ancient ritual, the Sun Dance was performed for the god of fertility, Xipe Totec, to ensure success in harvest. The four (symbolic of the four cardinal directions) dancers or voladores would climb a high pole to which they were tethered by cords. The fifth dancer or caporal acted as priest and musician and invoked the god's protection. The dancers would fly around the pole like birds and descend headfirst to ground. Initially suppressed after the conquest, the dance was considered an interesting game by the Spanish.

Image_title: Envia Cortés Embaxadores à la Republica de Tlascala, y su Senado los admite.
Description: Four native American ambassadors sent from Hernán Cortés to Tlascala [Tlaxcala?] present themselves to the Tlascalans.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de Mexico, poblacion y progresos de la America Septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España. ...
Source_publisher: En La Imprenta De D. Antonio De Sancha, ... Se hallará en su Librería en la Aduana vieja.
notes: Cortés initially fought the Tlascalans, defeated them, and then allied with them. Printmaker may be Juan Moreno Tejada, active 1780-1805.

Image_title: Pelêa Cortes con los Indios de Tabasco, y consigue de ellos una completa victoria
Description: Scene of warfare with Spanish soldiers fighting native Americans dressed in feathered headdresses and garments. Includes horses, swords, clubs, guns or muskets, cannon, and shields.
Source_Title: Historia de la conquista de Mexico, poblacion y progresos de la America Septentrional, conocida por el nombre de Nueva España ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: En La Imprenta De D. Antonio De Sancha, ... Se hallará en su Librería en la Aduana vieja.
notes: Cortes and his army landed at Champoton in Tabasco and quickly vanquished the native Americans there with their superior military power. The natives gave the conquerors goods and a native interpreter named Doña Malintzin or Marina.

Image_title: Monsieur de Bougainville Crossing the River St: Lucia in a Canoe drawn by Horses
Description: Louis Antoine de Bougainville, naked, drives two horses pulling his canoe across a river.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the fourth
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Bougainville served as aide-de-camp to the French General Montcalm in Canada from 1759 to 1761, assisted in negotiating the Treaty of Paris, and then established a French colony on the Falkland Islands in 1764. After the French gave up the colony to the Spanish, he led the expedition of the first French circumnavigation from 1766 to 1769. Text here describes how Bougainville transported men over the particularly swift Saint Lucia River in present-day Uruguay by using horses and a long canoe which has one side higher than the other. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Monsieur Bougainville Hoisting the French Colours on a small Rock near Cape Forward in the Streights of Magellan.
Description: Louis Antoine de Bougainville stands with men on a rock holding a French flag. Also includes ships and boat.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the fourth
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Bougainville served as aide-de-camp to the French General Montcalm in Canada from 1759 to 1761, assisted in negotiating the Treaty of Paris, and then established a French colony on the Falkland Islands in 1764. After the French gave up the colony to the Spanish, he led the expedition of the first French circumnavigation from 1766 to 1769. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings2: Magellan, Strait of (Chile and Argentina)--Description and travel

Image_title: A Prospective View of the great Cascade in Cascade Bay.
Description: View of a waterfall or cascade with a ship.
Source_Title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the fourth
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Bougainville served as aide-de-camp to the French General Montcalm in Canada from 1759 to 1761, assisted in negotiating the Treaty of Paris, and then established a French colony on the Falkland Islands in 1764. After the French gave up the colony to the Spanish, he led the expedition of the first French circumnavigation from 1766 to 1769. Text describes the anchoring of Bougainville's ship in Bahia Cascada, in the Strait of Magellan. Volumes 1 and 2 (and perhaps vols. 3 and 4) of this series were edited by David Henry. Image placed horizontally on page. Engraver is probably John June, active 1740-1770.

Image_title: Hi jam terga fugae, jam pugnae pectora praebent.
Description: Two native Americans mounted on horses ride down a road. Includes feathered headdresses and spears.
Source_Title: Historia de Abiponibus equestri, bellicosaque Paraquarieae natione ... [Volume 1]
Source_publisher: Typis Josephi Nobilis. de Kurzbek Caes. Reg. Aul. Tipog. et Bibliop.
notes: Dobrizhoffer, a German Jesuit, was sent to Paraguay in 1749 where he lived among the Guarani and Abipone people until the Jesuits were expelled from Spanish possessions in 1767. This book is an account of the Abipones, an equestrian tribe which is now extinct.

Image_title: [top] Palometa [middle] Raya [bottom] Armado
Description: Fish, including a piranha, ray, and an armado or armored catfish.
Source_Title: Historia de Abiponibus equestri, bellicosaque Paraquarieae natione ... [Volume 1]
Source_publisher: Typis Josephi Nobilis. de Kurzbek Caes. Reg. Aul. Tipog. et Bibliop.
notes: The palometa is probably a red-bellied piranha (Pygocentrus nattereri). The armado is an armored catfish (Pterodoras granulosus) found in the Paraná River. Dobrizhoffer, a German Jesuit, was sent to Paraguay in 1749 where he lived among the Guarani and Abipone people until the Jesuits were expelled from Spanish possessions in 1767. This book is an account of the Abipones, an equestrian tribe which is now extinct.

Source_Title: Historia de Abiponibus equestri, bellicosaque Paraquarieae natione ... Pars secunda.
Source_publisher: Typis Josephi Nobilis. de Kurzbek Caes. Reg. Aul. Tipog. et Bibliop.
notes: Rattlesnake, probably a Chaco rattlesnake (Crotalus durissus terrificus). Dobrizhoffer, a German Jesuit, was sent to Paraguay in 1749 where he lived among the Guarani and Abipone people until the Jesuits were expelled from Spanish possessions in 1767. This book is an account of the Abipones, an equestrian tribe which is now extinct.

Image_title: [top] Foglie, e frutto della Patata. [bottom] Frutto solo della Patata.
Description: [top] Potato plant including leaves, roots, and tubers. [bottom] Potato.
Source_Title: Memorie sopra il meraviglioso frutto Americano chiamato volgarmente patat ossia pomo di terra ...
Source_publisher: Nella stamperia di S. Michele, per il Giunchi
notes: Originating in the Andean mountain regions of South America, potatoes have been cultivated for at least 4,000 years. Europeans first discovered them in the early sixteenth century. Scientific name: Solanum tuberosum.

Image_title: Mappa regionis Taruma & Mbaè Verà
Description: Map of the Chaco region of Paraguay. Cartographic elements include locations of native American settlements, rivers and streams. Includes a native American with feathered headdress and bow accompanied by a monkey [?].
Source_Title: Historia de Abiponibus equestri, bellicosaque Paraquarieae natione ... [Volume 1]
Source_publisher: Typis Josephi Nobilis. de Kurzbek Caes. Reg. Aul. Tipog. et Bibliop.
notes: Dobrizhoffer, a German Jesuit, was sent to Paraguay in 1749 where he lived among the Guarani and Abipone people until the Jesuits were expelled from Spanish possessions in 1767. This book is an account of the Abipones, an equestrian tribe which is now extinct.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Mappa Paraquariae
Description: Map of Paraguay showing the Rio de la Plata. Cartographic elements includes degrees of latitude and longitude, compass rose, locations of missions, rivers, and streams, notable mountains including Potosí, shoals or sea banks, and lakes (collas iuli, Lake Titicaca?). Also includes royal coat of arms of Spain.
Source_Title: Historia de Abiponibus equestri, bellicosaque Paraquarieae natione ... Pars secunda.
Source_publisher: Typis Josephi Nobilis. de Kurzbek Caes. Reg. Aul. Tipog. et Bibliop.
notes: Dobrizhoffer, a German Jesuit, was sent to Paraguay in 1749 where he lived among the Guarani and Abipone people until the Jesuits were expelled from Spanish possessions in 1767. This book is an account of the Abipones, an equestrian tribe which is now extinct.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Abiponum Foeminarum Variae aetatis Effigies
Description: Six portrayals of Abipon women. Includes tattoos, ornamentation, and earrings.
Source_Title: Historia de Abiponibus equestri, bellicosaque Paraquarieae natione ... Pars secunda.
Source_publisher: Typis Josephi Nobilis. de Kurzbek Caes. Reg. Aul. Tipog. et Bibliop.
notes: Dobrizhoffer, a German Jesuit, was sent to Paraguay in 1749 where he lived among the Guarani and Abipone people until the Jesuits were expelled from Spanish possessions in 1767. This book is an account of the Abipones, an equestrian tribe which is now extinct.

Image_title: El Año de 1531. sabado 9. de Diziembre pasando Juan Diego pr la falda del cerro de Tepeiacac ...
Description: Native American stands before a bridge and the vision of Our Lady of Guadalupe. Also includes an angel.
Source_Title: La estrella del norte de Mexico, aparecida al rayar el dia de la luz evangelica en este Nuevo Mundo
Source_publisher: en la imprenta de Lorenzo de San Martin, impresor de la secretaría de estado y del despacho universal de Indias, y de otras varias oficinas de S.M.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, four times on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: El martes siguiente venia à llamar un confesor para su tío Juan Bernardino q[u]e. se estaba muriendo ...
Description: Native American stands before a vision of Our Lady of Guadalupe. Also includes an angel.
Source_Title: La estrella del norte de Mexico, aparecida al rayar el dia de la luz evangelica en este Nuevo Mundo
Source_publisher: en la imprenta de Lorenzo de San Martin, impresor de la secretaría de estado y del despacho universal de Indias, y de otras varias oficinas de S.M.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, four times on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. She appeared to Juan Diego the second time as he was hurrying to find a priest for his sick uncle, Juan Bernardino. Miraculously, the uncle was cured.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: Subio Juan Diego, y siendo Invierno hallo las Flores tomo en su tilma las que pudo, bajo, y las mostró à la Sa. qn. las tomo en sus divinas manos ...
Description: Native American kneels before a vision of Our Lady of Guadalupe. The Virgin of Guadalupe, wearing a starry cloak and supported by an angel, gives him a rose or flower and he holds many roses in his cloak or tilma. Includes a man gathering flowers on a hilltop.
Source_Title: La estrella del norte de Mexico, aparecida al rayar el dia de la luz evangelica en este Nuevo Mundo
Source_publisher: en la imprenta de Lorenzo de San Martin, impresor de la secretaría de estado y del despacho universal de Indias, y de otras varias oficinas de S.M.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, four times on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Juan Diego told Bishop Zumárraga of his vision but the bishop only believed Juan Diego's tale when he presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it filled with out-of-season roses.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: Llegó el dichoso Yndio al Palacio, y aunque con trabajo entró ante el Obispo, le refirio el mensage y al decirle q[u]e. tambien era su voluntad llamarse Santa Maria de Guadalupe ...
Description: A bishop kneels before an image of Our Lady of Guadalupe printed on a tilma or cloak worn by a native American. Another priest stands behind the two.
Source_Title: La estrella del norte de Mexico, aparecida al rayar el dia de la luz evangelica en este Nuevo Mundo
Source_publisher: en la imprenta de Lorenzo de San Martin, impresor de la secretaría de estado y del despacho universal de Indias, y de otras varias oficinas de S.M.
notes: A vision of the Virgin of Guadalupe, with native American features, appeared to Juan Diego, a native American, four times on a hill named Tepeyac near the site of a temple to the Aztec goddess Tonantzin (Mother of the People) in 1531. Juan Diego told Bishop Zumárraga of his vision but the bishop only believed Juan Diego's tale when he presented his cloak, or tilma, with the Virgin's image on it filled with out-of-season roses.
SubjectHeadings2: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint--Apparitions and miracles

Image_title: P. Ignatius Toebast, gebortig van gend, missionaris in d'indiën, vreedelÿk ... op den 15. October 1684.
Description: Portrait of Ignatius Toebast holding a book and rosary.
Source_Title: Wonderbaere reyze na d'uytterste paelen van America ...
Source_publisher: By J. F. Vander Schueren, ... En zyn te koop tot Brugge, By Joseph Bogaert ...
notes: Backer-Sommervogel identifies the portrait as being that of Father Jacques Laynez. Toebast, a Jesuit missionary and procurator of the province of New Granada in present-day Colombia, was martyred by the Indians of the Orinoco region whom he was attempting to convert.

Image_title: [Mining in Chile]
Description: Two black men [slaves?] dig for silver ore in Chile. Includes dwellings in the distance and men using a grinding wheel.
Source_Title: Ueber das Anquicken der gold- und silberhältigen, Erze, Rohsteine, Schwarzkupfer und Hüttenspeise
Source_publisher: Bey Christian Friederich Wappler
notes: Born's treatise on mining includes abridgments of text from Antonio de Ulloa on the use of mercury in silver processing and Giovanni Ignazio Molina on the amalgamation method used with silver and gold ore in Chile, along with other articles on the metals industry and processing of ore in Spanish colonies. This section, "Anquickung der Silber und Golderze in den Bergwerken von Chili", p. 81-83, is a German translation of selections from Molina's "Saggio sulla storia naturale del Chili" printed in Bologna, 1782.

Image_title: V. R. del V. P. F. Junipero Serra ...
Description: Portrait of Fray Junipero Serra, a Franciscan brother, holding a crucifix and a rock. Before him kneel native Americans wearing feathered headdresses and garments, as well as people in European attire. Also includes a skull, torch, chain, and cup or chalice with a snake in it.
Source_Title: Relacion historica de la vida y apostolicas tareas del venerable padre Fray Junipero Serri, y de las misiones que fundó en la California Septentrional, y nuevos establecimientos de Monterey
Source_publisher: por Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: Founder of 21 missions in California, Serra converted over five thousand Indians to Christianity. He was known for his self-mortification in the form of beating himself with chains or a stone and burning his chest with a torch. One of Saint John the Evangelist's attributes is a snake rising from a chalice. While at Ephesus, legend has it that John was given a cup of poisoned wine to drink, but after blessing it the poison departed in the form of a serpent.

Image_title: Mexican Year. Mexican Month.
Image_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson
Description: Two Aztec calendar wheels, one representing a year divided into six sections of three months each with a moon and sun in the center; the other a month divided into twenty sections.
Source_Title: [Storia antica del Messico. English] The history of Mexico ... Vol. I.
Source_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson, No. 25, Pater-noster Row

Image_title: [Nopal cactus leaves]; Mâle de la Cochenille Sylvestre Sur une feuille de Nopal cochenillifere l'insecte et considerablement grossi et tel qui parait au Microscope
Description: At left are two lobes of a nopal cactus with one bud and one yellow flower. To the right is a cactus lobe (leaf) with a cochineal insect on it.
Source_Title: Traité de la culture du nopal, et de l'éducation de la cochenille dans les colonies françaises de l'Amérique; précédé d'un Voyage a Guaxaca, ...
Source_publisher: Chez la veuve Herbault ...; chez Delalain, le jeune ...; chez Bergeret ...
notes: The nopal cactus was very significant as a source of food and medicine. It was also the food of the cochineal insect whose body produced a commercially important red dye.Thiéry de Menonville was sent to America by Louis XVI to obtain the cochineal insect and the plant on which it subsisted.

Image_title: A Femelle de la Cochenille Sylvestre vüe en dessous et grossie Comme au Microscope.B Femelle de la Cochenille Sylvestre vüe en dessus et Grossie Comme au Microscope
Description: At left, the female cochineal insect seen from above and below. At right, three leaves of a cactus with four flowers in various stages of opening.
Source_Title: Traité de la culture du nopal, et de l'éducation de la cochenille dans les colonies françaises de l'Amérique; précédé d'un Voyage a Guaxaca, ...
Source_publisher: Chez la veuve Herbault ...; chez Delalain, le jeune ...; chez Bergeret ...
notes: The cactus is probably a nopal cactus, food of the cochineal insect whose body produces a commercially important red dye. The nopal cactus is very significant as a source of food and medicine. Thiéry de Menonville was sent to America by Louis XVI to obtain the cochineal insect and the plant on which it subsisted.

Image_title: Itzcuintepotzotli / Mexican Porcupine / Tlacocelotl / Mexican Tiger
Image_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson
Description: Four animals: a hunchbacked wild dog, a Mexican porcupine, an ocelot, and a Mexican tiger or jaguar.
Source_Title: [Storia antica del Messico. English] The history of Mexico ... Vol. I.
Source_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson, No. 25, Pater-noster Row
References_exhibitions: Been, A. Animals & authors, Fig. VII: 2 (detail)

Image_title: Chajotli / Tliltzapotl / Tlalcacahuatl / Nopalxochquetzalli
Image_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson
Description: Four fruits or plants: a chayote, a black-seeded sapotilla or zapote, peanuts or "ground cacao," and prickly pear.
Source_Title: [Storia antica del Messico. English] The history of Mexico ... Vol. I.
Source_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson, No. 25, Pater-noster Row
notes: The peanut plant (Arachis hypogaea), often called the groundnut, was named by the Aztecs, tlalcacahuatl or "ground cacao."

Image_title: Jolloxochitl / Coatzontecoxochitl / Xiloxochitl / Oceloxochitl / Macpalxochitl
Image_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson
Description: Five flowers: a flower from a tree (or Jolloxcochitl), an orchid (Stanhopea tigrina), a calliandra (calliandra calothyrsus), a tiger lily (Tigridia pavonia), and a flower from a shrub known as "flor de manita," (Chiranthodendron pentadactylon).
Source_Title: [Storia antica del Messico. English] The history of Mexico ... Vol. I.
Source_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson, No. 25, Pater-noster Row
notes: Text describes the Jolloxcochitl as "flower of the heart" and being from a very large tree.

Image_title: King of the Zopilots / Tepajaxin / Amphisbeoena / Occhione / Axolotl / Temolin
Image_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson
Description: Seven animals and insects: a Mexican buzzard, a toad-like amphibian, a mythical snake with two heads, a sea bream [?], a Mexican salamander, and two beetles [stag beetle?].
Source_Title: [Storia antica del Messico. English] The history of Mexico ... Vol. I.
Source_publisher: G. G. J. and J. Robinson, No. 25, Pater-noster Row

Image_title: Dampier trouve dans l'Isle Fernandes un Moskite qu'on y avoit laissé depuis trois ans
Description: A boat containing European men approaches an island where a native American leaves his hut to greet them.
Source_Title: Collection de tous les voyages faits autour du monde, ... Tome III
Source_publisher: Chez Poinçot, rue de la Harpe, no. 135.
notes: Image is found in the volume relating the 1679-91 voyage of William Dampier. These voyages and travels were edited by Jean-Pierre Berenger. The Moskito are a native American group indigenous to Honduras.Juan Fernandez Island off the coast of Chile is the same one on which Alexander Selkirk (the model for Robinson Crusoe) chose to remain rather than continue with Dampier's party on a ship he considered unsafe.

Image_title: Theobroma Cacao. Linn. Le Cacotier.
Image_publisher: chez l'auteur, ... De Bure, ... la veuve Tilliard...
Description: Cacao plant with pods and pods cut open to show seeds.
Source_Title: Dissertations sur l'utilité, et les bons et mauvais effets du tabac, du café, du cacao et du thé, ornées de quatre planches en taille-douce; ...
Source_publisher: chez l'auteur, rue de la Harpe, no. 109. De Bure, l'ainé, libraire, rue Serpente, et la veuve Tilliard, & fils, libraires, rue de la Harpe.
notes: The cacao plant is the source of chocolate.Plate numbers appear to apply to a different publication.

Image_title: femme Patagonne.
Description: Native American Patagonian woman with child and baby and painted or tattooed skin.
Source_Title: Costumes civils actuels de tous les peuples connus, dessinés d'après nature ...
Source_publisher: Chez Pavard, Editeur, ... Et se trouve Chez Knapen & Fils, ... Bailly, ...Gastey ...
notes: Published in four volumes, this work was probably issued in parts or fascicles, each part with separate paging and accompanied by one to four colored plates. This edition includes the peoples of each continent spread throughout the four volumes in alphabetical sequence. Cf. record # 68-131-12.

Image_title: Entrevue de Biron avec les Patagons.
Description: European soldier greets a native American. Includes native Americans riding horses, tricorn hat, guns or muskets with bayonets, horses, dog, and bow and arrows.
Source_Title: Collection de tous les voyages faits autour du monde, ... Tome II
Source_publisher: Chez Poinçot, rue de la Harpe, no. 135.
notes: Image is found in the volume relating the voyage of Giovanni Francesco Gemelli Carreri, but Biron's (Byron's) voyage is recounted in vol. 5 of this series. These voyages and travels were edited by Jean-Pierre Berenger.John Byron, 1723-1786, was a British vice-admiral and grandfather of George Gordon, Lord Byron. Between 1764 and 1766 he circumnavigated the globe as captain of HMS Dolphin with the stated purpose of exploring unknown lands around the Straits of Magellan. The voyage was significant, because it established Britain's claim to the Falklands or Malouines. Previously, Byron had been shipwrecked on the coast of Patagonia while accompanying Anson on his circumnavigation. Here Byron greets a Patagonian "giant."
SubjectHeadings2: Indians of South America--First contact with Europeans

Image_title: Indien du Méxique.
Description: Native American or Mexican man wearing a skin cloak, hat, and sandals.
Source_Title: Costumes civils actuels de tous les peuples connus, dessinés d'après nature ...
Source_publisher: Chez Pavard, Editeur, ... Et se trouve Chez Knapen & Fils, ... Bailly, ...Gastey ...
notes: The text identifies the skins as faded moose skin (original bien passées). Published in four volumes, this work was probably issued in parts or fascicles, each part with separate paging and accompanied by one to four colored plates. This edition includes the peoples of each continent spread throughout the four volumes in alphabetical sequence.

Image_title: femme de la Californie.
Description: Native American woman from California wearing a fur skin, arm and leg ornaments, and carrying a sack made of netting.
Source_Title: Costumes civils actuels de tous les peuples connus, dessinés d'après nature ...
Source_publisher: Chez Pavard, Editeur, ... Et se trouve Chez Knapen & Fils, ... Bailly, ...Gastey ...
notes: Published in four volumes, this work was probably issued in parts or fascicles, each part with separate paging and accompanied by one to four colored plates. This edition includes the peoples of each continent spread throughout the four volumes in alphabetical sequence. Artist may be Claude-Louis Desrais, 1746-1816. Cf. record # 68-131-6.

Image_title: Embarcase el Bto. Aparizio en Sn. Lucar de Barrameda para la Nueva España
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio embarks from a pier onto a boat. Includes pillars of Hercules, dog, shells, crowns, and ships in a harbor.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Vende el Bto. Aparizio sus Carretas, y consu producto compra una Hazienda de labranza
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio sells his cart business in order to establish a working farm. Includes a scene of farming, farmyard, carts, bag of coins, oxen or bulls, well, dog, dwelling, and horses.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Exercitase el Bto. Aparizio en labrar, y sembrar sus tierras, y instruie alos Indios en estos oficios
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio sows grain in a field with native Americans who also work. Includes scene of farming, tilling or plowing a field with oxen or bulls, donkey, basket, birds, and settlement in the distance.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: El Demonio en figura de Negro, y cargado de horcas, y palas, se te apareze al Bto. y le ofreze su aiuda
Description: Demon in the shape of a black man carrying shovels on his shoulder offers help to Sebastián de Aparicio. Sebastián half rises from his sleeping pallet. Over his head is a scene of harvest in which the demon or devil will help him, as well as a scene with a man refusing a woman demon with the help of his faith (shown by a cross). Also includes hourglass, skull, rosary, haystack, flail, and granary.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli

Image_title: Limpia, y acriva el Bto. Aparizio los granos por sus proprias manos
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio winnows grain with the help of a machine. In the background men plow a field, harvest, and carry the grains to men who beat the grain in a cradle. Includes sacks of gain, baskets, oxen or bulls, and clubs.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Conduze el Bto. Aparizio a sus traxes los granos de sus Cosechas
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio directs the placement of grain sacks into a granary. In the background men sickle in a field of grain, transport the grain in ox-drawn carts, drive horses over the stalks, and throw the grain up in the air to winnow it. Also includes men carrying sacks of grain up a ladder to a granary, shovels, and dwelling.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Ofrezenle al Bto. Aparizio por Esposa una Niña virtuosa de pocos años, y el la acepta
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio is offered the hand of a young girl in marriage and he accepts her. Includes view of settlement, road with carts and traffic, aqueduct, churches, and convent. The young girl wears traditional native costume.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. He married twice, but never consummated the unions. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Entierra el Bto. Aparizio a su segunda Esposa en el Conv[en]to Curato de Sto. Domingo de Escapuzalco
Description: Interior of the church at the convent of Santo Domingo de Escapuzalco during the burial service of the second wife of Sebastián de Aparicio. Includes dog, candlesticks, musicians' gallery, and altars.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. He married twice, but never consummated the unions. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.This interior may be of the church of Santo Domingo, Zacatecas.

Image_title: Aconseja el Bto. Aparizio â una Vuida, que venda un Batan y Obrase, que inquietaban su conciencia
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio speaks to a widow before a textile mill or factory where yarn is being spun and cloth is being woven and prepared. Includes spinning wheels, machinery, looms, water wheels, and a devil or demon.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Llega el Bto. Aparizio alas Indias, va a establecerse en Plueba [Puebla?], y comienza a domar Novillos.
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio trains and tames bulls with native Americans. Includes scene of bull-fighting, yoke, men opening gates, and fences.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico and for his ability to train animals. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Fabrica Carretas el Bto. Aparizio, y con ellas conduze generos desde la antiqua vera Cruz a Mexico.
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio shows a drawing of a cart to men who build carts in Veracruz, Mexico. Includes a scene of construction, carpenters' tools such as ax, dividers, chisels, awl, saw, and plane.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: Pasase el Bto. Aparizio a vivir a Mexico, y pasa consus Carretas por las Platas al Real de Zacatecas
Description: Sebastián de Aparicio hands the driver of a cart a picture of the Virgin and child and gives a coin to a beggar. Includes bulls, horses, pots, oxen train, and settlement in the distance.
Source_Title: Coleccion de estampas que representan los principales pasos, hechos y prodigios del Bto. Frai Sebastian de Aparizio religo. Franciscano de la Provincia del Sto. Evangelio de Mexico
Source_publisher: por el incisor Pedro Bombelli
notes: Born in Spain, Sebastián de Aparicio traveled to Mexico where he made a substantial fortune building roads and the carriages or carts to carry goods on the roads. At age 70, he joined the Franciscan order and was known as the Angel of Mexico. He was beatified in 1787.

Image_title: The Beheading of Balboa.
Description: One man beheads another with an executioner's ax surrounded by an audience of European soldiers. In the background is an encampment and ship. Includes pike, spears, swords, and horses.
Source_Title: The history of South America. Containing the discoveries of Columbus, the conquest of Mexico and Peru, and the other transactions of the Spaniards in the New World by the Rev. Mr. Cooper
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Executed in January 1519 in Panama, Vasco Núñez de Balboa was convicted of rebellion, high treason, and cruelty to Indians under orders from Pedro Arias Dávila (usually called Pedrarias), governor of Darién, a crown colony.

Image_title: Landing of Cortez in Peru.
Description: European soldier on horseback leads a batallion of soldiers. Includes encampment and ships in background. Also includes cannon, boats, swords, and men unloading supplies.
Source_Title: The history of South America. Containing the discoveries of Columbus, the conquest of Mexico and Peru, and the other transactions of the Spaniards in the New World by the Rev. Mr. Cooper
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: The text describes the landing of Hernán Cortés in San Juan de Ulua, the fortress of Veracruz, Mexico. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Pizarro assassinated in his Palace.
Description: Two men in armor assassinate or kill a Spanish gentleman wearing a feathered hat and carrying a sword and shield. A man in armor lies on the floor.
Source_Title: The history of South America. Containing the discoveries of Columbus, the conquest of Mexico and Peru, and the other transactions of the Spaniards in the New World by the Rev. Mr. Cooper
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Pizzaro had his fellow conquistador, Diego de Almagro, executed in 1537 and in retaliation, Almagro's followers captured Pizzaro and killed him on June 26, 1541. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Slaves at Work in the Silver Mines of Peru.
Description: Slaves work in mines using pickaxes to extract ore. Another smelts the ore in a vessel and another slave works a bellows at a foundry; both are supervised by men in European dress. Also includes wheelbarrows and hearth.
Source_Title: The history of South America. Containing the discoveries of Columbus, the conquest of Mexico and Peru, and the other transactions of the Spaniards in the New World by the Rev. Mr. Cooper
Source_publisher: Printed for F. Newbery, the Corner of St. Paul's Church-Yard
notes: Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Le Chanteur Patagon des Isles Falkland.
Description: Patagonian song bird found in the Falkland Islands.
Source_Title: [Voyage round the world. French] Voyage autour du monde; et principalement a la côte nord-ouest de l'Amérique, fait en 1785, 1786, 1787 et 1788 ... Tome second
Source_publisher: Chez Maradan, Libraire, Hôtel de Château-Vieux, rue Saint-André-des-Arcs
notes: Perhaps the Patagonian mockingbird, Mimus patagonicus. A series of letters giving an account of an English expedition to establish the fur trade in northwestern North American, this book provides information on the geography, ethnology, and natural history on the area north of Nootka Sound.

Image_title: Plan Ignografico de la Capilla que se fabrica en honor de Maria Santissima de Guadalupe, para que sirva de Propiciatorio à las prodigios[a]s Aguas del Pozito.
Description: Plan of the chapel of Our Lady of Guadalupe, called El Pocito. Includes scale. Architectural details are identified with letters, explained in keys at sides.
Source_Title: [Gazeta de México (Mexico City, Mexico)] Gazetas de Mexico, compedio de noticias de Nueva Espana que comprehenden los años de 1790, y 1791 ... Tomo quarto
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Don Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros
notes: The archbishop of Mexico City, Alonso Núñez de Haro y Peralta, was instrumental in constructing the chapel, built completely with volunteer labor, over the stream where Juan Diego spoke to the Virgin of Guadalupe. The architect, Francisco Antonio Guerrero y Torres, was known for his contribution to Mexican baroque architecture and the chapel at Pocita is considered his best work.

Image_title: V. R. de la Hermosissima Imagen de N.S. Crucificado milagrosamente Renobada que se venera en el Convento Antiguo de Señoras Carmelitas Descalzas de Mexico.
Description: Image of Christ Crucified [Cristo renovado], on an altar with four monstrances [?].
Source_Title: Exaltacion de la divina misericordia en la milagrosa renovacion de la soberana imagen de Christo señor Nuestro crucificado ...
Source_publisher: en la Oficina de los Herederos del Lic. D. Joseph de Jaurequi, Calle de S. Bernardo
notes: The book tells the history of the statue of Christ Crucified to which many miracles were attributed. This statue was first created in 1545 in the town of Izmiquilpa. In the seventeenth century, it was moved to the Convent of San José of the Discalced Carmelite Women in Mexico City.
SubjectHeadings2: Convento de San José (Mexico City, Mexico)

Image_title: Der Patagonische Quackstärz von den Falkland's Inseln. Latham's Synopsis vol. 4. P. 434. No. 26.
Description: Bird [warbler?] perched on a tree stump.
Source_Title: [Voyage round the world. German] Der Kapitaine Portlock's und Dixon's Reise um die Welt
Source_publisher: bei Christian Friedrich Boss und Sohn
notes: Text describes the bird as nine inches long and colored grey, brown, and white.This book is a series of letters written by William Beresford, a Quaker, who sailed on a ship owned by a group of merchants who formed a company to participate in fur trading on the northwestern North American coast. The company employed two veterans of Captain James Cook's third voyage. Nathaniel Portlock (master's mate aboard the Discovery) was appointed captain of the King George and commander of the expedition. George Dixon (armorer on the Discovery) commanded the smaller Queen Charlotte.

Image_title: Bayle de los Yndias Mapuyes.
Description: Dance of the Maipures, native Americans of the Orinoco River valley. Cultural artifacts include musical instruments such as pipes or trumpets, drums, tambourines, feathered headdress and garments, quivers of arrows, and dwelling.
Source_Title: [Orinoco ilustrado] Historia natural, civil y geografica de las naciones situadas en las riveras del Rio Orinoco ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Carlos Gibert y Tutó
notes: The Maipures were formerly an important group of tribes on the Upper Orinoco River, from above the Meta River to the entrance of the Cassiquiare, in Venezuela and Columbia, who spoke an Arawak dialect. Gumilla, a Jesuit priest who traveled the Orinoco River from 1716 to 1737, first published El Orinoco ilustrado (considered to be the first scientific study of the Orinoco and its peoples) in 1741.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)--Dances

Image_title: Los Medicos del Orinoco llamados Piaches.
Description: Native American methods of curing the sick. One patient lies on a hammock in an open-sided dwelling. The medicine man blows smoke on her, another shakes a rattle. One man inhales smoke through a pipe in each nostril.
Source_Title: [Orinoco ilustrado] Historia natural, civil y geografica de las naciones situadas en las riveras del Rio Orinoco ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Carlos Gibert y Tutó
notes: Gumilla, a Jesuit priest who traveled the Orinoco River from 1716 to 1737, first published El Orinoco ilustrado (considered to be the first scientific study of the Orinoco and its peoples) in 1741.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)--Medicine

Image_title: Trompeta larga
Description: Large trumpet played by native Americans of the Orinoco area.
Source_Title: [Orinoco ilustrado] Historia natural, civil y geografica de las naciones situadas en las riveras del Rio Orinoco ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Carlos Gibert y Tutó
notes: The Maipures, Salivas, and other tribes of the Orinoco River used a sacred earthenware trumpet, called botuto or batuto, at the center of various religious ceremonies.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)--Music

Image_title: [Native Americans and alligator]
Description: Native American holds cornucopia, another shoots arrow at alligator. In background are fortifications. Cultural artifacts include feathered headdress and bow.
Source_Title: [Orinoco ilustrado] Historia natural, civil y geográfica de las naciones situadas en las riveras del Rio Orinoco ... Tomo II

Image_title: [Funerary rites of native Americans of Orinoco]
Description: Funerary rites of native Americans [Salivas?] of Orinoco. The dead man, surrounded by pillars, is attended by a mourner and by dancers. Outside temple or dwelling men play musical instruments such as pipes or trumpets. Cultural artifacts include feathered headdresses, garments, and ornaments and pot.
Source_Title: [Orinoco ilustrado] Historia natural, civil y geografica de las naciones situadas en las riveras del Rio Orinoco ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Carlos Gibert y Tutó
notes: Gumilla, a Jesuit priest who traveled the Orinoco River from 1716 to 1737, first published El Orinoco ilustrado (considered to be the first scientific study of the Orinoco and its peoples) in 1741.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)--Funeral customs and rites

Image_title: [[Native American women grate, drain, grind manioc to make bread]
Description: Native American women grate manioc, drain the grated root in a cylindrical basket, pound and grind root, and in foreground, bake bread. Cultural artifacts include dwelling, mill, and feathered headdress and garments.
Source_Title: [Orinoco ilustrado] Historia natural, civil y geográfica de las naciones situadas en las riveras del Rio Orinoco ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Carlos Gibert y Tutó
notes: Gumilla, a Jesuit priest who traveled the Orinoco River from 1716 to 1737, first published El Orinoco ilustrado (considered to be the first scientific study of the Orinoco and its peoples) in 1741. To process manioc the roots were grated and pounded into a pulp which was put into long cylinders made of woven plant fibers. Each tube was hung with a heavy weight at the bottom, which compressed the pulp and expressed the poisonous juice. The pulp could then be removed, washed and roasted, rendering it safe to eat.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)

notes: A fierce tribe of indigenous people who live in present-day Bolivia, the Mojos [Moxos] resisted Christianity until the late seventeenth century.The capybara (Hydrochoerus hydrochaeris), native to South America, is a semi-aquatic animal and the largest of all rodents.

Image_title: Il Cacao
Description: Cacao showing seed pod, seeds, flower buds, and leaves. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Text describes this plant as being found in Mexico, Honduras, Guatemala, and Nicaragua. Scientific name: Theobroma cacao.

Image_title: La Kina Kina
Description: Cinchona showing seed pod, seeds, parts of flower, and leaves. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Cinchona or quinine bark was first documented for its curative effects on malaria in 1638 when the countess of Cinchon, wife of a Peruvian viceroy, was supposed to have been cured of a malarial type fever. Cinchona, one of forty species of trees, was not botanically classified until 1737. Until the seeds were stolen in 1865 and successfully planted in the Dutch East Indies, the tropical forests of northwestern South America were the sole sources of this valuable medicine. Scientific name: Cinchona officinalis.

Image_title: La Vainiglia
Description: Vanilla orchid showing seed pod, flowers, and leaves. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Text discusses vanilla's discovery by the ancient Mexicans. Scientific name: Vanilla planifolia.

Image_title: Il Campuccio
Description: Part of the logwood tree showing flowers, heart-shaped leaves, legume pods, and branches. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo I
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Logwood (Haematoxylum campechianum) is a species of flowering tree in the legume family, Fabaceae, that is native to southern Mexico and northern Central America. It is named after the town of Campeche, Mexico, and is used as a source of dye.

Image_title: [Aztec glyphs]
Description: Aztec glyphs, perhaps depicting historical events and tribute.
Source_Title: [History of America. Books 1-8. Greek] Istoria [i.e. Historia] tes Amerikes ... [vol. 4]
Source_publisher: En te Hellenike Typographia Georgiou Ventote
notes: Robertson's history is one of the best known and most influential of the eighteenth century. Text of 1777 English edition (cf. 05766-1) discusses previously known Mexican (Aztec) paintings and their publication. Robertson has taken his example from eight paintings in the so-called Codex Mexicanus in the collection of the Imperial Library at Vienna. These paintings may have come originally from King Emmanuel of Portugal before 1533. Robertson identifies the lettered items in the text as targets or darts (AA), temples (BB), a bale of cloth (C), a numerical notation (DDD), and soldiers (EEE).

Image_title: [Mexico]
Description: Native Americans gather around an authority figure (priest or ruler?) standing by a tree. Includes bows and arrows.
Source_Title: [History of America. Books 1-8. Greek] Istoria [i.e. Historia] tes Amerikes ... [vol. 3]
Source_publisher: En te Hellenike Typographia Georgiou Ventote
notes: Robertson's history is one of the best known and most influential of the eighteenth century.

Image_title: [Coatlicue]
Description: Front, back and side view of a statue of Coatlicue, a Mexican deity. The statue's face is comprised of two fanged serpents, her skirt is of interwoven snakes, her necklace is of hands, hearts, and a skull, and her fingers and toes are claws.
Source_Title: Descripcion histórica y cronológica de las dos piedras, que con ocasion del nuevo empedrado que se esta formando en la plaza principal de Mexico
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Don Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros
notes: During the 1780s and 1790s, major archeological discoveries were unearthed during renovations to the square or Zócalo in Mexico City--the Coatlicue statue and the Aztec calendar stone, or the "piedra del sol" which has become a symbol of Mexico. León y Gama's book was the first scholarly description of that discovery and attempted to explain the meaning of the stones, although he contended that this figure was a composite of the hieroglyphic attributes of at least seven Mesoamerican deities, instead of Coatlicue, an Aztec goddess who symbolized earth as creator and destroyer.
References: Royal Academy, London. Aztecs, fig. 9; Cañizares-Esguerra, J. How to write the history of the New World, fig. 5.1, p. 272-280

Image_title: [Aztec calendar stone]
Description: Aztec calendar stone.
Source_Title: Descripcion histórica y cronológica de las dos piedras, que con ocasion del nuevo empedrado que se esta formando en la plaza principal de Mexico
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de Don Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros
notes: During the 1780s and 1790s, major archeological discoveries were unearthed during renovations to the square or Zócalo in Mexico City--the Coatlicue statue and the Aztec calendar stone or the "piedra del sol" which has become the symbol of Mexico. León y Gama's book was the first scholarly description of that discovery and attempted to explain the meaning of the stones. The Aztec calendar "sunstone" is a thirteen-and-a-half foot, basalt relief representation of the Mexica creation myth and not, strictly speaking, a calendar. The face portrayed at the center of the stone is generally interpreted as the sun god, Tonatiuh, symbolizing the Fifth Sun or fifth era of Aztec time. The glyphs on the stone represent a map of the Aztecs' destiny, indicating not only when the world was supposed to have begun, but also when it would end. The square quadrants spaced around Tonatiuh represent the preceding four eras of the Aztecs--jaguar, wind, rain, and water.
References: http://www.artcamp.com.mx/AZ/2.html (May 2004); Cañizares-Esguerra, J. How to write the history of the New World, fig. 5.2, p. 272-280

notes: During the 1780s and 1790s, major archeological discoveries were unearthed during renovations to the square or Zócalo in Mexico City--the Coatlicue statue and the Aztec calendar stone or the "piedra del sol" which has become the symbol of Mexico. León y Gama's book was the first scholarly description of that discovery and attempted to explain the meaning of the stones. The Aztec calendar "sunstone" is a thirteen-and-a-half foot, basalt relief representation of the Mexica creation myth and not strictly speaking a calendar. The face portrayed at the center of the stone is generally interpreted as the sun god, Tonatiuh, symbolizing the Fifth Sun or fifth era of Aztec time. The glyphs on the stone represent a map of the Aztecs' destiny, indicating not only when the world was supposed to have begun, but also when it would end. The square quadrants spaced around Tonatiuh represent the preceding four eras of the Aztecs--jaguar, wind, rain, and water.

Image_title: L'Oriana
Description: Branch of the roucou shrub showing flowers, leaves, and seed pods. Also includes details of seed pod. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Roucou or Achiote (Bixa orellana) is known as annatto and urucu. Annatto, used as a flavoring and dye, is derived from its seeds. A decoction from its leaves is used to stop nausea. Achiote is a shrub or small tree from the tropical region of the American continent.

Image_title: La Batata
Description: Sweet potato plant showing tubers, stem, leaves, and flower. Includes detail of flower and seed. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo III
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Scientific name: Ipomoea batatas (Convolvulaceae). Here the plant is described as coming from South America.

Image_title: Il Cobureiba ossia Albero del Balsamo del Perù
Description: Balsam of Peru showing roots, stem, leaves, seeds, and flower. Includes detail of root and seed. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo III
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Scientific name: Myroxylon balsamum. The resin of this plant is used for incense and in medicinal preparations. It is also known as balsam of Peru, because it was shipped to Spain from Peru. Gaudenzio and Benedetto Bordiga were brothers and engravers in Milan.

Image_title: L'Aloe
Description: Aloe or maguey showing leaves, seeds, and flower. Includes detail of flower. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo III
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Scienfic name: Agave americana. The maguey is also known as a century plant. Gaudenzio and Benedetto Bordiga were brothers and engravers in Milan.

Image_title: Il Nopal ossia pianta della Cocciniglia
Description: Prickly pear or nopal cactus and cactus flowers. Includes detail of cochineal insect seen from top and bottom. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo IV
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: The nopal cactus is significant as a source of food and medicine. It was also the food of the cochineal insect whose body produced a commercially important red dye. Scientific name: Opuntia ficus-indica.

Image_title: Il Corbaril ossia albero della Gomma Anime
Description: Jatobá tree showing branches, leaves, seeds, and legumes. Includes detail of seed. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo IV
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Jatobá or Guapinol (Hymenaea courbaril), is a tree common to the Caribbean, Central, and South America and Brazil. Its seeds are the source of copal, a resin used as incense by the Aztecs. Text relates copal to myrrh. Scientific name: Hymenaea courbaril L.

Image_title: La Calaguala
Description: Polypodium decumanum, also known as samambaia or calaguala, fern showing leaves and rhizome. Item in the image is lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo IV
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Samambaia is a fern that grows in the rainforests of South America, as well as drier tropical forests in Latin America. Its root is used medicinally. Scientific name: Polypodium decumanum.

Image_title: L'Oriana
Description: Branch of the roucou shrub showing flowers, leaves, and seed pods. Also includes details of seed pod. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo II
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Roucou or Achiote (Bixa orellana) is known as annatto and urucu. Annatto, used as a flavoring and dye, is derived from its seeds. A decoction from its leaves is used to stop nausea. Achiote is a shrub or small tree from the tropical region of the American continent.

Image_title: La Batata
Description: Sweet potato plant showing tubers, stem, leaves, and flower. Includes detail of flower and seed. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo III
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Scientific name: Ipomoea batatas (Convolvulaceae). Here the plant is described as coming from South America.

Image_title: Il Cobureiba ossia Albero del Balsamo del Perù
Description: Balsam of Peru showing roots, stem, leaves, seeds, and flower. Includes detail of root and seed. Items in the image are lettered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Storia delle piante forestiere le più importanti nell'uso medico, od economico ... Tomo III
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di Giuseppe Marelli
notes: Scientific name: Myroxylon balsamum. The resin of this plant is used for incense and in medicinal preparations. It is also known as balsam of Peru, because it was shipped to Spain from Peru. Gaudenzio and Benedetto Bordiga were brothers and engravers in Milan.

Image_title: R. de la M.R.M. Maria Ignacia de Azlor, y Echeverz, Fundadora Patrona, y Prelada del Convento de la Sagrada Compañia de Maria S[antisi]ma de la Enseñanza de Mexico
Description: Portrait of Mother María Ignacia de Azlor y Echeverz. Pictorial elements include illustration of Our Lady of the Pillar, desk, pens, inkwells, seal, the brief from Pope Benedict XIV founding the school, and a rosary.
Source_creator: Compañía de María Santísima de la enseñanza de México
Source_Title: Relación histórica de la fundación de este Convento de Nuestra Señora del Pilar, ...
Source_publisher: por Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: Sor Maria Ignacia de Azlor y Echeverz (1715-1767) founded a convent school in Mexico for native American girls in 1753. The school was named for Neustra Señora de Pilar who appeared to St. James in Saragossa, Spain, and gave him a statue of herself on a column.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J.G. Book in the Americas, Item 60
SubjectHeadings1: Azlor y Echeverz, María Ignacia de, 1715-1767

Image_title: M. Bougainville hoisting French Colours on a small Rock, in Maghellan Streights
Image_publisher: Alexr. Hogg at the Kings Arms No. 16 Paternoster Row
Description: Louis Antoine de Bougainville holds a French flag while standing on a rock with other men. Also includes ships and boat.
Source_Title: A new, complete, and universal collection of authentic and entertaining voyages and travels to all the various parts of the world.
Source_publisher: Printed for Alex. Hogg, at the King's-Arms, No. 16, Paternoster-Row; ...
notes: Bougainville served as aide-de-camp to the French General Montcalm in Canada from 1759 to 1761, assisted in negotiating the Treaty of Paris, and then established a French colony on the Falkland Islands in 1764. After the French gave up the colony to the Spanish, he led the expedition of the first French circumnavigation from 1766 to 1769. Cf. An historical account of all the voyages round the world performed by English navigators ... Volume the fourth, London, 1773 (07195a-2).

Image_title: View of a Village in the Bay of Good Success, in the Island of Terra de Fuego.
Description: View of a native American village on Tierra del Fuego in present-day Argentina. Includes dwellings, dog, and Fuegians wearing fur garments.
Source_Title: A journal of a voyage to the South Seas, in his Majesty's ship the Endeavour: ...
Source_publisher: Printed for Charles Dilly, in the Poultry; and James Phillips, in George-Yard, Lombard-Street.
notes: Parkinson was a natural history draughtsman born in Edinburgh who went to England where his talents were recognized by Joseph Banks. In 1768 he accompanied James Cook on the Endeavor's voyage to the South Seas. During this trip, he died at sea of dysentery in January 1771.The artist is probably Alexander Buchan, who was responsible for rendering the landscape views on Cook's voyage. He died during the voyage in 1769.Image placed horizontally on page.Cf. Parkinson, Voyage autour du monde, ... Paris, 1797 [35894-2].

Image_title: Begónia balmisiana.

Image_title: Ágave americano, ó maguéy.
Description: Agave americana or maguey cactus with details of flower, pistil, calyx, and stamen, as well as a fragment of the root. Items in the image are numbered for identification in adjoining text.
Source_Title: Demostracion de las eficaces virtudes neuvamente descubiertas en las raices de dos plantas de Nueva-España, especies e ágave ye de begónias
Source_publisher: En la imprenta de la viuda de D. Joaquin Ibarra
notes: Also known as the century plant, a variety of the agave is used today primarily for the production of tequila, but has also been used for food, writing material, medicine, and as rope or to make shoes. Balmis advocated the use of the roots of agave in the therapeutic treatment of veneral disease and scrofula.

Image_title: Homme de la Californie.
Description: Native American man wearing furs and carrying a spear. Cultural artifacts include ornaments and headdress. Also includes a cactus.
Source_Title: Encyclopédie des voyages ...
Source_publisher: Se trouve chez Deroy, libraire, rue du Cimetière-André no 15 ...
notes: This book is the prospectus for a five volume work with same title. Paris, 1795-1796. Grasset de Saint-Sauveur was born in Montreal, Canada, but spent his life in Europe. He published and illustrated numerous works on the native costumes of many peoples.

Image_title: Homme Patagon.
Description: Native American man wearing leggings and spurs holds a boleadora.
Source_Title: Encyclopédie des voyages ...
Source_publisher: Se trouve chez Deroy, libraire, rue du Cimetière-André no 15 ...
notes: Boleadoras were tools used by indigenous peoples of the Argentinian Pampas to hunt. A boleadora consisted of two stones bound by a leather cord which were thrown and then used to trip an animal. The gauchos, or cowboys, of Argentina later would refine this tool and make it their own. This book is the prospectus for a five volume work with same title. Paris, 1795-1796. Grasset de Saint-Sauveur was born in Montreal, Canada, but spent his life in Europe. He published and illustrated numerous works on the native costumes of many peoples.

Image_title: Cinchona officinalis.
Description: Branch of the quinine or Cinchona officinalis tree. Includes details of flowers and fruit with cross and longitudinal sections of the branch and bark.
Source_Title: A description of the genus Cinchona, comprehending the various species of vegetables from which the Peruvian and other barks of a similar quality are taken. Illustrated by figures of all the species hitherto discovered. ...
Source_publisher: Printed for B. and J. White, at Horace's Head, Fleet-Street.
notes: Cinchona, native to the Andean highlands from Bolivia to Colombia and to parts of Panama and Costa Rica, was named in honor of the countess of Chinchón who, legend says, was cured of a fever in 1638 by a preparation of the bark. There are about 40 species of the tree. The bark is also known as Jesuit's bark and Peruvian bark.Lambert was a British botanist and one of the first members of the Linnaean Society. He is best known for his description of the genus Pinus; the genus Lambertia is named for him. Some of the species of cinchona are described from examples in the herbarium of Sir Joseph Banks. The engraver is probably Inigo Barlow (active 1790).
Provenance_Donor: Former collection of Edward Duke. Acquired in 1944.

notes: This species is now known as Ladenbergia macrocarpa and is native to Panama. Cinchona, native to the Andean highlands from Bolivia to Colombia and to parts of Panama and Costa Rica, was named in honor of the countess of Chinchón who, legend says, was cured of a fever in 1638 by a preparation of the bark. There are about 40 species of the tree. The bark is also known as Jesuit's bark and Peruvian bark.Lambert was a British botanist and one of the first members of the Linnaean Society. Source_Title: A description of the genus Cinchona, comprehending the various species of vegetables from which the Peruvian and other barks of a similar quality are taken. Illustrated by figures of all the species hitherto discovered. ...

Brown found it more efficacious than the Peruvian bark then used in Europe. Image_title: Liane of Chili called by the Natives Guilboqui.
Description: Male and female plants of a kind of vine found in Chile. Includes details of all parts of the flower.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788
Source_Title: [Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde. English] A voyage round the world, in the years 1785, 1786, 1787, and 1788, ... Vol. III.
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Johnson, St. Paul's Churchyard.
notes: The description of this plant was made by Étienne-Pierre Ventenat from a drawing sent by La Martinière.Translation of: Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde; a different translation than that of the London : G.G. & J. Robinson, 1798 edition.The French decided to mount a scientific and exploration voyage to rival that of Captain James Cook. Two ships, the Boussole and the Astrolabe, under La Perouse's command left France in August 1785. They spent the summer of 1786 off the coasts of Alaska looking for a northwest passage then sailed down the west coast of North America in August and September 1786. In September they crossed the Pacific Ocean to Asia. They first sailed north and then south to Australia which they reached in January 1788. In mid-March both ships were wrecked on a coral reef near the island of Vanikoro with all hands lost. Thirty years later remains were found, and islanders reported that survivors had built a boat and headed out to sea, but none were ever heard from again.La Perouse sent letters back to Europe from Manila, Macao, and Australia; this is how the voyage is known. In October 1787 he had also sent a Russian-speaking officer, Jean Baptiste Barthélemy, Baron de Lesseps (1766-1834) overland from Kamchatka with documents, charts, and journals. De Lesseps traveled through Siberia to St. Petersburg and then to Paris, arriving late in 1788. In May 1791, when it seemed clear that La Pérouse would not return, the revolutionary government commissioned former army officer Louis Antoine Milet-Mureau (1756-1825) to edit a book from these materials, which was published in Paris in four volumes with an atlas in 1797. A second French edition was required the following year, and English translations appeared in 1798, 1799, 1801, and 1807; German and Dutch editions were published between 1799 and 1804.

Image_title: La Ville de Valparaiso Sur la Cote du Chili.
Description: View of Valparaiso, Chile. Includes dwellings, domestic animals, fortifications, ships, and boats.
Source_Title: Voyage de découvertes, a l'océan Pacifique du Nord, et autour du monde; dans lequel la côte nord-ouest de l'Amérique a été soigneusement reconnue et exactement relevée ... Tome III.
Source_publisher: de l'Imprimerie de la Republique
notes: Vancouver arrived at Valparaiso, Chile, in March 1795 to repair a broken mainmast; he left in May 1795. Translation by J. N. Demeunier and A. Morellet of A voyage to the North Pacific Ocean and round the world, first printed London, 1798. Image placed horizontally on page.
