Image_title: Dresses of the Inhabitants of La Conception.
Description: Women and men of Concepción, Chile standing near a shore or harbor. Includes upper and lower classes of people. Also includes boats and ships.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788
Source_Title: [Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde. English] A voyage round the world in the years 1785, 1786, 1787, and 1788 ...
Source_publisher: Printed for J. Johnson, St. Paul's Churchyard.
notes: Concepción was founded in 1550 by Pedro de Valdivia. It functioned as a military outpost on the border between Spanish controlled areas (the Viceroyalty of Peru) and areas controlled by the Mapuche (in Spanish, Araucanos). It was from here that the Spanish tried to subdue the Mapuche; and this was the site of the Real Audiencia. La Perouse arrived there in February of 1786.The French decided to mount a scientific and exploration voyage to rival that of Captain James Cook. Two ships, the Boussole and the Astrolabe, under La Perouse's command left France in August 1785. They spent the summer of 1786 off the coasts of Alaska looking for a northwest passage then sailed down the west coast of North America in August and September 1786. In September they crossed the Pacific Ocean to Asia. They first sailed north and then south to Australia which they reached in January 1788. In mid-March both ships were wrecked on a coral reef near the island of Vanikoro with all hands lost. Thirty years later remains were found, and islanders reported that survivors had built a boat and headed out to sea, but none were ever heard from again.La Perouse sent letters back to Europe from Manila, Macao, and Australia; this is how the voyage is known. In October 1787 he had also sent a Russian-speaking officer, Jean Baptiste Barthélemy, Baron de Lesseps (1766-1834) overland from Kamchatka with documents, charts, and journals. De Lesseps traveled through Siberia to St. Petersburg and then to Paris, arriving late in 1788. In May 1791, when it seemed clear that La Pérouse would not return, the revolutionary government commissioned former army officer Louis Antoine Milet-Mureau (1756-1825) to edit a book from these materials, which was published in Paris in four volumes with an atlas in 1797. A second French edition was required the following year, and English translations appeared in 1798, 1799, 1801, and 1807; German and Dutch editions were published between 1799 and 1804.

Image_title: Cacto cochonilheiro
Description: Prickly pear or nopal cactus and cochineal insect. Includes cactus flowers.
Source_Title: [Traité de la culture du nopal et de l'éducation de la conchenille. Portuguese] Memoria sobre a cultura da urumbeba, e sobre a criação da cochonilha extrahida por M. Bertholet das observações feitas em Guaxaca
Source_publisher: Na Officina de Simão Thaddeo Ferreira
notes: Cochineal (Dactytopius confusus) belongs to a group of insects called scales which feeds on the prickly pear or nopal cactus. The Aztecs developed a dye made from the dried insect.

Image_title: The method of mixing Clay for Bricks. The particular manner of Killing Bullocks. And the Female Missionary House appointed by the French for their reception near Monte Video.
Description: Horses tread on clay mixed with water being thrown into their corral by men. A bull is being raised by its hooves by means of a pulley next to a group of penned cattle. Also includes a dwelling or structure.
Source_Title: A visible display of divine providence; or, The journal of a captured missionary, designated to the Southern Pacific Ocean, in the second voyage of the ship Duff, ... captured by Le Grand Buonaparte, ...
Source_publisher: Printed by T. Gillet, Salisbury-Square, for, and sold by the author, no. 100, Whitehorse-Street, Ratcliffe-Cross; Ogle, Turnstile; Button and Symmonds, Paternoster-Row, London; and by all booksellers and newscarriers in the three kingdoms.
notes: Text notes the inexpensive and excellent beef available. The method of killing a bull involved using a pulley and winch to pull its head through a hole in the penfold, then stabbing it between the horns with a dagger. The animal is then lifted onto a sledge to be flayed. Much of the meat was wasted, the animals being mostly used for hides and tallow. The bricks are used for building, but are also burned with bulls heads and bones as a substitute for wood. The building is one outside of Montevideo in which the missionaries were lodged during their stay.The ship Duff had previously taken part in the first mission to the South Pacific during which voyage the Gambier Islands were discovered. On its second voyage, with Gregory, his wife and four children aboard, it was captured by the ship Le Grand Buonaparte off Cape Frio in 1799. Cape Frio or Cabo Frio is in the present-day Rio de Janeiro state of Brazil. After leaving Montevideo, the missionaries were captured by the Portuguese.Image placed horizontally on page.Plates at end of book are misbound.

Image_title: View of the Missionary House in Paraguay, given to the Author by M. Duclous
Description: Hut and dwellings with two black men, woman, and child [slaves?]. Includes scythe and fire for cooking.
Source_Title: A visible display of divine providence; or, The journal of a captured missionary, designated to the Southern Pacific Ocean, in the second voyage of the ship Duff, ... captured by Le Grand Buonaparte, ...
Source_publisher: Printed by T. Gillet, Salisbury-Square, for, and sold by the author, no. 100, Whitehorse-Street, Ratcliffe-Cross; Ogle, Turnstile; Button and Symmonds, Paternoster-Row, London; and by all booksellers and newscarriers in the three kingdoms.
notes: This may be the dwelling in which Mrs. Gregory was delivered of her son Ebenezer. After the delivery, the blacks who lived nearby were very solicitous of her and the child's health. The location may or may not actually be present-day Paraguay.The ship Duff had previously taken part in the first mission to the South Pacific during which voyage the Gambier Islands were discovered. On its second voyage, with Gregory, his wife and four children aboard, it was captured by the ship Le Grand Buonaparte off Cape Frio in 1799. Cape Frio or Cabo Frio is in the present-day Rio de Janeiro state of Brazil. After leaving Montevideo, the missionaries were captured by the Portuguese.Image placed horizontally on page.Plates at end of book are misbound.

Image_title: [Magellan at the helm of his ship]
Description: A soldier wearing armor stands on the deck of a ship. Includes a broken mast, cannons, and flags. Another ship, whose parts are lettered for identification, is included on the right.
Source_Title: Primo viaggio intorno al globo terracqueo, ossia Ragguaglio della navigazione alle Indie Orientali per la via d'occidente fatta dal cavaliere Antonio Pigafetta ...
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di G. Galeazzi
notes: No records from Magellan's journey are extant; our knowledge of his journey comes from the diary of Antonio Pigafetta. This image of Magellan is derived from Jan van der Straet, also known as Joannes [or Johannes] Stradanus, who compiled a series of four prints under the title Americae retectio in 1592, issued in celebration of the centennial of Columbus' discovery of the New World.

Image_title: Kleidung der Einwohner der Stadt Conception.
Description: Women and men of Concepción, Chile. Includes upper and lower classes of people. Also includes boats and ships.
Source_creator: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de, 1741-1788
Source_Title: [Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde. German] La Perousen's Entdeckungsreise in den Jahren 1785, 86 und 88 ... Erster Theil
notes: Concepción was founded in 1550 by Pedro de Valdivia. It functioned as a military outpost on the border between Spanish-controlled areas (the Viceroyalty of Peru) and areas controlled by the Mapuche (in Spanish, Araucanos). La Perouse arrived there in February of 1786.La Pérouse took command of a French government expedition that was to search for the Northwest Passage from the Pacific side and to explore along the coasts of America, China, and Siberia, and in the South Seas. He never returned from this expedition. His two ships were wrecked on a reef near the island of Vanikoro with all hands lost, but La Perouse had sent letters back to Europe from Manila, Macao, and Australia which were edited by former army officer, Louis Antoine Milet-Mureau, and later published.Image placed horizontally on page.For an earlier version of this image, see #09274-2 La Pérouse, [Voyage de La Pérouse autour du monde. English], London, 1799. For a later version, see #69-206-21 Schmidtmeyer, Travels into Chile ... London, 1824.

Image_title: [Indigo]
Description: Varieties of indigo. Fig. 4 is an example of indigofera from New Spain. Fig. 5 is taken from the mainland of America. Includes leaves, roots, seeds, seedling, and flowers. Items in the image are lettered for identification in preceding text.
Source_Title: [Fazendeiro do Brazil] O fazendeiro do Brazil ... Tomo II. Tinturaria. Parte II
Source_publisher: Na Officina de Simão Thaddeo Ferreira
notes: The examples are taken from Piso, Historia natural do Brasil, according to note in text preceding image.A noted botantist, Velloso was appointed director of the press, Arco do Cego, incorporated in 1798 into the royal printing office. Meant to modernize the Portuguese empire, the Arco do Cego published at least 80 works in three years on various topics, including agriculture, navigation, and medicine.

Image_title: Lo Struzzo
Description: Rhea, here identified as an ostrich.
Source_Title: [Sammlung interessanter und durchgängig zwekmässig abgefasster Reisebeschreibungen für die Jugend. Italian.] Raccolta di viaggi interessanti per istruzione, e diletto della gioventù ... Tomo IV
Source_publisher: Presso Antonio Zatta, Qu:m Giac.
notes: This collection of voyages was edited by Johann Heinrich Campe and was published as eight volumes in four. This volume contains an account of the voyage to South American of John Byron, grandfather of the poet Byron.

Image_title: View of the High Mountain the Missionary ship Duff after her Capture and Harbour of Monte Video, Rio de la Plate. - Spanish South America.
Description: View of the harbor of Montevideo. Includes a hill surmounted by a flag and a few structures with a path leading to the summit. Also includes small island and ships.
Source_Title: A visible display of divine providence; or, The journal of a captured missionary, designated to the Southern Pacific Ocean, in the second voyage of the ship Duff, ... captured by Le Grand Buonaparte, ...
Source_publisher: Printed by T. Gillet, Salisbury-Square, for, and sold by the author, no. 100, Whitehorse-Street, Ratcliffe-Cross; Ogle, Turnstile; Button and Symmonds, Paternoster-Row, London; and by all booksellers and newscarriers in the three kingdoms.
notes: Text states that when the author visited it, the harbor contained fifty or sixty ships including the French ships Le Republicain and Le Buonaparte with their prize, the Duff. The ship Duff had previously taken part in the first mission to the South Pacific during which voyage the Gambier Islands were discovered. On its second voyage, with Gregory, his wife and four children aboard, it was captured by the ship Le Grand Buonaparte off Cape Frio in 1799. Cape Frio or Cabo Frio is in the present-day Rio de Janeiro state of Brazil. After leaving Montevideo, the missionaries were captured by the Portuguese.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Patagone, ossia l'uomo di figura gigantesca. Patagon, ou bien l'homme géant.
Description: Patagonian giant, shown wearing animal skins and with cloven hooves. Also includes bow and arrows.
Source_Title: [Sammlung interessanter und durchgängig zwekmässig abgefasster Reisebeschreibungen für die Jugend. Italian.] Raccolta di viaggi interessanti per istruzione, e diletto della gioventù ... Tomo IV
Source_publisher: Presso Antonio Zatta, Qu:m Giac.
notes: As early the 1520s, Antonio Pigafetta had written of giants living in South America. Magellan, with whom Pigafetta sailed, gave the giants the name "Patagons" because of their big feet, thus naming the southern tip of South America. This collection of voyages, edited by Johann Heinrich Campe, contains an account of the voyage to South American of John Byron, grandfather of the poet Byron. His journal published in 1767 includes a chapter on nine-foot tall Patagonian giants. This collection also contains the voyages of Samuel Wallis who anchored off the coast of Patagonia in 1766 and reported that the natives were not giants. Earlier explorers had also reported a race of giants in Patagonia.

Image_title: [Indians of South America]
Description: Native Americans of South America. Includes feathered headdress and ornament, bow, arrow, branch of bananas, and a man playing a musical instrument. Also includes a Patagonian giant who is shown pushing an arrow down his throat. People are lettered for identification.
Source_Title: Primo viaggio intorno al globo terracqueo, ossia Ragguaglio della navigazione alle Indie Orientali per la via d'occidente fatta dal cavaliere Antonio Pigafetta ...
Source_publisher: Nella Stamperia di G. Galeazzi
notes: No records from Magellan's journey are extant; our knowledge of his journey comes from the diary of Antonio Pigafetta. The Patagonians, perhaps Tehuelches, were named for the size of their feet (after patagón, "big feet") which seemed large to the Spanish because of the straw-stuffed buskins or shoes they wore to ward off the cold. The image of the Patagonian is derived from Jan van der Straet's print of Magellan. Straet, also known as Joannes [or Johannes] Stradanus, compiled a series of four prints under the title Americae retectio in 1592, issued in celebration of the centennial of Columbus' discovery of the New World.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Patagonia (Argentina and Chile)

Image_title: [Magellan at the helm of his ship]
Description: A soldier wearing armor stands on the deck of a ship. Includes a broken mast, cannons, and flags. Another ship, whose parts are lettered for identification, is included on the right.
Source_Title: Primo viaggio intorno al globo terracqueo, ossia Ragguaglio della navigazione alle Indie Orientali per la via d'occidente fatta dal cavaliere Antonio Pigafetta ...

Image_title: Nombra la afortunada Mexico por Patron principal al Bienado. Felipe de Jesus á quien le dia la Tuna
Description: Philip of Jesus stands on an eagle eating a snake on a cactus. Two women, one in European attire and the other in native American attire, kneel before him. Also includes angels, cornucopia, shield, settlement or convent, and churches.
Source_Title: Vida de San Felipe de Jesus protomartir del Japon y patron de su patria Mexico
Source_publisher: Calle des Bautisterio de S. Catalina M: n. 3
notes: The eagle perched on a cactus was a sign to the wandering Mexica or Aztec tribe of the site where they were to build their city of Tenochtitlan, now Mexico City.Born in Mexico, Philip of Jesus joined the Franciscans and while sailing for Manila was blown off course into Japan. There he was martyred with six other Franciscans, a Japanese Jesuit, and seventeen Japanese tertiaries.Montes de Oca was an important Mexican engraver, active during the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries; this is considered his finest work.

Image_title: Celebra Regozijada Mexico, la Beatificacion de su Esclarecido hijo el Bienaventurado Felipe de Jesus
Description: Scene of celebration for the beatification of Philip of Jesus in Mexico City. Includes the zucalo or central square, cathedral or church, carriages, fireworks being set off, and religious procession.
Source_Title: Vida de San Felipe de Jesus protomartir del Japon y patron de su patria Mexico
Source_publisher: Calle des Bautisterio de S. Catalina M: n. 3
notes: Born in Mexico, Philip of Jesus joined the Franciscans and while sailing for Manila was blown off course into Japan. There he was martyred with six other Franciscans, a Japanese Jesuit, and seventeen Japanese tertiaries. He was beatified in 1627 and canonized in 1862.Montes de Oca was an important Mexican engraver, active during the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries; this is considered his finest work.

Image_title: Le Chauve
Description: A fruitcrow, perhaps the crimson fruitcrow.
Source_Title: Histoire naturelle d'une partie d'oiseaux nouveaux et rares de l'Amérique et des Indes ... Tome premier
Source_publisher: chez J.E. Gabriel Dufour, libraire, rue de Tournon, no. 1126. Et, à Amsterdam, chez le même libraire. De l'imprimerie de Didot jeune, quai des Augustins, no. 22
notes: This work, of which only one volume was published, discusses birds, the cotingas, of northern South America, specifically of the Guianas. Text identifies the bird as not being a bald jackdaw or rook, as Georges-Louis Leclerc, comte de Buffon, alleged. Scientific name: Haematoderus militaris . Been identifies the artist of this image as Jacques Barraband.
References_exhibitions: Been, A. Animals & Authors, Fig. VI: 4

Image_title: Fuchsia simplicicaulis. Fuchsia apetala.
Description: Two fuchsia plants showing flowers and leaves.
Source_Title: Flora Peruviana, et Chilensis, sive, Descriptiones, et icones plantarum Peruvianarum, et Chilensium ... Tomus III.
Source_publisher: Typis Gabrielis de Sancha
notes: The Spanish government funded the Spanish botanists, Ruiz and José Antonio Pavon, to lead the first botanical expedition into Chile, Peru, and parts of what is present-day Ecuador and Bolivia. Among the many new species first described by them were these fuchsias. Fuchsia simplicicaulis is native to Peru; fuchsia apetala is native to Peru, Ecuador, and Venezuela. Fuchsia apetala was the first fuchsia without corolla to be described and is now considered lost to cultivation.

Image_title: Vista de la Catedral de Lima, despus de la ereccion de sus Torres, y redificaccion general finalizada de año de 1801 ...
Description: View of the cathedral of Lima. Includes archbishop's palace, church of San Francisco, the oratory, fountain, men riding horseback, native Americans conversing, black men fighting [?], a man in a store. Items in the image are identified in a key at the bottom.
Source_Title: Fama postuma del excelentísimo é ilustrisímo señor doctor don Juan Domingo Gonzalez de la Reguera del consejo de Su Magestad: caballero Gran Cruz de la real y distinguida orden española de Carlos III. dignísimo XVI. arzobispo de los reyes
Source_publisher: En la imprenta real de los Niños Huérfanos...
notes: Juan Domingo Gonzalez de la Reguera (1720-1805) was archbishop of Lima.

Image_title: [View of the town of Montevideo, Uruguay, and its fortifications]
Description: View of Montevideo showing fortifications, church or cathedral, dwellings, and harbor with ships.
Source_Title: [cover title] Manuscript Maps for the South American Campaigns of 1806-7
notes: Between March 1806 and January 1808, the British launched several assaults against Spanish fortifications in Buenos Aires and Montevideo. Sir Home Popham, British naval commander at the Cape of Good Hope, launched these attacks (without official authorization) to bring free trade to the region of the Rio de la Plata and thus reconcile the local population to British rule. His plan backfired and, instead, the British expedition sparked local resistance to the British, as well as a popular uprising against Spanish authority in the area. Spanish claim to power was undermined by the apparent unwillingness of the Spanish Viceroy to defend Buenos Aires against the British and by the success of local efforts to defend the city. These events stimulated a revolt which led to independence from Spain in 1810. This item is included in a collection of manuscript maps hinged in a folio album titled, Manuscript Maps for the South American Campaigns of 1806-7.
References: Grainger, J. D., ed. Royal Navy in the River Plate, 1806-1807
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: V. R. de la Hermosissima Imagen de N.S. Crucificado milagrosamente Renobada que se venera en el Convento Antiguo de Señoras Carmelitas Descalzas de Mexico.
Image_publisher: José Mariano de Zúñiga y Ontiveros
Description: Image of Christ Crucified [Cristo renovado] on an altar, with four monstrances [?].
Source_Title: Exaltacion de la divina misericordia en la milagrosa renovacion de la soberana imagen de Christo señor Nuestro crucificado ...
Source_publisher: en la Oficina de D. Mariano de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: The book tells the history of the statue of Christ Crucified to which many miracles were attributed. This statue was first created in 1545 in the town of Izmiquilpa. In the seventeenth century, it was moved to the Convent of San José of the Discalced Carmelite Women in Mexico City.

Image_title: Manco Inca, couronné par Pizarre en 1533; tué, en 1546. par un Espagnol qu'il avait sauvé.
Description: Portrait of Manco Inca [also known as Tupac Hualpa] wearing a cloak, feathered headdress, and earrings and carrying a scepter with an image of the sun on it.
Source_Title: Histoire de la conquête et des révolutions du Pérou, par Alphonse de Beauchamp. Avec portraits. Tome premier.
Source_publisher: Chez Lenormant, Imprimeur-Libraire, rue des Prêtres Saint-Germain-l'Auxerrois, no. 17; Chez Lerouge, Libraire, Cour du Commerce.
notes: With the appointment of Tupac Hualpa as Manco Inca by Pizarro in 1533, genuine indigenous control ended and passed to the Spanish.Two volumes bound together.
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 1992. Formerly owned by Maury A. Bromsen

Image_title: [Classical structure]
Description: A crown is displayed on an classical structure with mythological scenes--Icarus falling, Perseus cutting off a gorgon's head, Hercules and the hydra. Also includes a man giving a book to classical figures and, on the pediment above, women with shields around a plinth with a portrait. The structure [a catafalque] is surmounted by statues which may represent Christian virtues. Includes an anchor, crucifix, mirror [?], and a royal figure being embraced by native Americans wearing feathered headdresses.
Source_Title: Guatemala por Fernando Septimo el dia 12 de diciembre de 1808
notes: Ferdinand VII ascended to the Spanish throne in 1808 after his father's forced abdication. He reigned for a few months before he was made prisoner by Napoleon Bonaparte for five years. In 1813, he was restored to the throne and remained king until 1833.This plate is followed by plates which show details of the catafalque which was erected in Guatemala.

Image_title: La Fidelidad, y, ternura de la M. N. v. M. J. C. de Guatemala erigio este monumento en medio de dolor a suamado soberano el S. D. Fernando. VII ...
Description: Francisco Antonio Fuentes y Gusman gives a history of Guatemala to an angel [Cleo?] writing in the book of Time, a figure who leans on a broken pillar. Includes [Chronos or Father] Time's sythe or sickle and winged hoursglass. A man looks at a many-headed creature with wings. In the background battalions of soldiers march away from fortifications and over a bridge [scene of warfare].
Source_Title: Guatemala por Fernando Septimo el dia 12 de diciembre de 1808
notes: Hercules was said to have vanquished the Lernaean Hydra by following his mentor's advice to conquer by surrendering.Francisco Antonio de Fuentes y Guzman wrote Historia de Guatemala, an important history of the area.Ferdinand VII ascended to the Spanish throne in 1808 after his father's forced abdication. He reigned for a few months before he was made prisoner by Napoleon Bonaparte for five years. In 1813, he was restored to the throne and remained king until 1833. This plate is a detail from the larger engraving of a catafalque erected in Guatemala.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Spanish colonies pledge their loyalty to Ferdinand VII]
Description: Allegorical figure holding a shield representing Guatemala (with volcanoes and soldier on horseback) assists an angel who places human hearts in a fire beneath a portrait of Ferdinand VII . Other figures with shields containing a rampant lion, cactus, feathered headdress, and stream running through a chasm or gorge also bring hearts.
Source_Title: Guatemala por Fernando Septimo el dia 12 de diciembre de 1808
notes: The allegorical figures probably represent Spanish colonies in Central America, such as Guatemala, Mexico, and Panama, owing fealty to Ferdinand VII.Ferdinand VII ascended to the Spanish throne in 1808 after his father's forced abdication. He reigned for a few months before he was made prisoner by Napoleon Bonaparte for five years. In 1813, he was restored to the throne and remained king until 1833. This plate is a detail from the larger engraving of a catafalque erected in Guatemala.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Native Americans embrace a symbol of Spanish monarchy]
Description: Allegorical figures representing North and South America embrace a figure of Spanish monarchy who wears a dress with castles on it and the chain of the Order of the Golden Fleece. Includes a crown, feathered headdresses, bows, cornucopias, and clasped hands.
Source_Title: Guatemala por Fernando Septimo el dia 12 de diciembre de 1808
notes: The allegorical figures probably represent Spanish colonies in Central America, such as Guatemala, Mexico, and Panama, owing fealty to Ferdinand VII.Ferdinand VII ascended to the Spanish throne in 1808 after his father's forced abdication. Image_title: [Royal coat of arms of Ferdinand VII of Spain]
Description: Two native American women and two European women flank the royal coat of arms of Ferdinand VII of Spain surrounded by the collar of the Order of the Golden Fleece. Includes the rising and setting sun, the eye of Providence or all-seeing eye, feathered headdresses, and wings.
Source_Title: Guatemala por Fernando Septimo el dia 12 de diciembre de 1808
notes: The eye of Providence, often shown within a triangle, represents the eye of God watching humanity.Ferdinand VII ascended to the Spanish throne in 1808 after his father's forced abdication. He reigned for a few months before he was made prisoner by Napoleon Bonaparte for five years. In 1813, he was restored to the throne and remained king until 1833. Ferdinand re-established the arms of Carlos III of Spain. This plate is a detail from the larger engraving of a catafalque erected in Guatemala.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Two men carry pillars to royalty]
Description: Two men carry the pillars of Hercules to plant them on new shores where royalty rest upon the shield of Guatemala (with volcanoes and a soldier on horseback). The pillars read, "For Castile and Leon" and "New World discovered by Columbus." An angel holds a tablet representing Ferdinand VII.
Source_Title: Guatemala por Fernando Septimo el dia 12 de diciembre de 1808
notes: Ferdinand VII ascended to the Spanish throne in 1808 after his father's forced abdication. He reigned for a few months before he was made prisoner by Napoleon Bonaparte for five years. In 1813, he was restored to the throne and remained king until 1833. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Guatemala kiche
Description: Native American woman wearing feathered headdress holds a rope of medals with the names of ancient Mayan rulers. Includes bow, arrows, bird [quetzal]. The names on the medals are Acxopil, Hunahpu, Balamkiche, Balanacan, Maucotal, Yquibalan, and Riçab.
Source_Title: Guatemala por Fernando Septimo el dia 12 de diciembre de 1808

Source_Title: Guatemala por Fernando Septimo el dia 12 de diciembre de 1808

notes: Azara, a Spaniard, went to South America in 1781 as one of the commissioners to settle the boundary between the Spanish and Portuguese possessions. He stayed for twenty years. During that time, he became an authority on the natural and political history of Paraguay and the Plata regions with many newly discovered species being named after him. Scientific name: Tamandua tetradactyla. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Le grand Furet D'Az. Mustela Barbara. Lin.
Description: Tayra.
Source_Title: [Viajes por la América Meridional. French] Voyages dans l'Amérique méridionale ... depuis 1781 jusqu'en 1801 ...
Source_publisher: Dentu, imprimeur-libraire, Rue de Pont-de-Lodi, no. 3
notes: Azara, a Spaniard, went to South America in 1781 as one of the commissioners to settle the boundary between the Spanish and Portuguese possessions. He stayed for twenty years. During that time, he became an authority on the natural and political history of Paraguay and the Plata regions with many newly discovered species being named after him. Scientific name: Eira barbara. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Le Rat épineux D'Az.
Description: Spiny rat or casiragua.
Source_Title: [Viajes por la América Meridional. French] Voyages dans l'Amérique méridionale ... depuis 1781 jusqu'en 1801 ...
Source_publisher: Dentu, imprimeur-libraire, Rue de Pont-de-Lodi, no. 3
notes: Azara, a Spaniard, went to South America in 1781 as one of the commissioners to settle the boundary between the Spanish and Portuguese possessions. He stayed for twenty years. During that time, he became an authority on the natural and political history of Paraguay and the Plata regions with many newly discovered species being named after him. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Le Nandu ou Autruche de Magellan.
Description: Rhea or nandu.
Source_Title: [Viajes por la América Meridional. French] Voyages dans l'Amérique méridionale ... depuis 1781 jusqu'en 1801 ...
Source_publisher: Dentu, imprimeur-libraire, Rue de Pont-de-Lodi, no. 3
notes: Azara, a Spaniard, went to South America in 1781 as one of the commissioners to settle the boundary between the Spanish and Portuguese possessions. He stayed for twenty years. During that time, he became an authority on the natural and political history of Paraguay and the Plata regions with many newly discovered species being named after him. The nandu is the smaller of the two flightless rheas found in South America. Scientific name: Pterocnemia pennata.

Image_title: Vue de Buenos-Ayres.

SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Aparicion del Santo Christo de Chalma
Description: Image of Christ Crucified [Cristo renovado] above a toppled and broken statue of a native American wearing feathered headdress. Also includes monks or priests (one with a cross), native Americans kneeling before the statue, devils, and angels.
Source_Title: Relacion historica y moral de la portentosa imagen de N. Sr. Jesucristo crucificado aparecida en una de las cuevas de S. Miguel de Chalma ...
Source_publisher: Impresa en casa de Arizpe
notes: Now the second most visited Christian holy place in Mexico, Chalma originally had a sacred cave with a statue of Ozteotl [Oztoteotl], the Dark Lord of the Cave. In 1539, Fray Nicholás de Perea gave a sermon to the Indians. Three days later the statue was in pieces, replaced by a life-size image of a black Christ Crucified. In 1683, the image was placed in a church especially consecrated for its worship. In the eighteenth century the image was destroyed by fire.

Image_title: Vultur Gryphus Lin.
Description: Andean condor and horned animal skull.
Source_Title: Recueil d'observations de zoologie et d'anatomie comparée ... Premier volume
Source_publisher: Chez F. Schoell, libraire, rue des fossés-Montmartre, No. 14. et chez Gel. Dulfour et Companie. rue des Mathurins-Saint-Jacques, No. 7
References_exhibitions: Been, A. Animals & authors, Fig. VII: 4

Image_title: No. 11. Gymnotus aequilabiatus. No. 1 Gymnotus electricus.
Description: Electric eel. Includes a cross section of the eel. Image placed vertically on the page.
Source_Title: Recueil d'observations de zoologie et d'anatomie comparée ... Premier volume
Source_publisher: Chez F. Schoell, libraire, rue des fossés-Montmartre, No. 14. et chez Gel. Dulfour et Companie. rue des Mathurins-Saint-Jacques, No. 7
notes: Gymnotus is not a true eel but a fish. Humboldt was the first European to note its existence. Scientific name: Electrophorus electricus.
References_exhibitions: Been, A. Animals & authors, Fig. VII: 7

Image_title: Simia Satanas, Hofm.
Description: Monkey eating a fruit.
Source_Title: Recueil d'observations de zoologie et d'anatomie comparée ... Premier volume
Source_publisher: Chez F. Schoell, libraire, rue des fossés-Montmartre, No. 14. et chez Gel. Dulfour et Companie. rue des Mathurins-Saint-Jacques, No. 7
notes: Author's notes give measurements of the animal and identifies the artist as being M. Waitsch [Friedrich Georg Weitsch (1758-1828)?], director of the academy of painting in Berlin (p. 315-316). Weitsch painted Humboldt in 1806; that painting is in the State Museum at Berlin.

Image_title: The execution of ten of Miranda's Officers.
Description: Men in military attire preside over the execution by hanging of at least nine men. Another lies on a platform about to be decapitated. Includes gallows, ladders, and swords.
Source_Title: History of the adventures and sufferings of Moses Smith, during five years of his life; from the beginnning of the year 1806 when he was betrayed into the Miranda expedition ...
Source_publisher: Printed by Thomas Kirk, Main-Street, for the author
notes: The condemned men were ordered to be hanged, decapitated, and then quartered.Smith claimed to have been hoodwinked into joining Francisco de Miranda's expedition to lead Spain's colonies to independence. Miranda's expedition was a failure, but Smith recounted his adventures in this book in an effort to raise money and to seek justice for himself.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: The Schooner three Friends picking up Sherman, Lippincott, and Smith.
Description: Schooner or ship picks up men. A boat with a flag is rowed toward the ship.
Source_Title: History of the adventures and sufferings of Moses Smith, during five years of his life; from the beginnning of the year 1806 when he was betrayed into the Miranda expedition ...
Source_publisher: Printed by Thomas Kirk, Main-Street, for the author
notes: Smith claimed to have been hoodwinked into joining Francisco de Miranda's expedition to lead Spain's colonies to independence. Miranda's expedition was a failure, but Smith recounted his adventures in this book in an effort to raise money and to seek justice for himself. As Smith was attempting to flee from Cartagena, he met a Captain Sanford who agreed to carry Smith and two other Americans, Sherman and Lippincot, by canoe to the schooner, Three Friends, bound for Baltimore. Even though the canoe shipped water, Captain Sanford made the gallant effort to get the three men to the schooner, saving them from bondage.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: A View of the Pyramid of Cholula, near Mexico.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, J. Murray & H. Colburn
Description: View of the pyramid at Cholula with a church on its summit.
Source_Title: [Vues des Cordillères et monumens des peuples indigènes de l'Amérique. English] Researches, concerning the institutions & monuments of the ancient inhabitants of America ... Vol. I
Source_publisher: Published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, J. Murray & H. Colburn
notes: Cholula, an Aztec [or Toltec] city devoted to the worship of Quetzalcoatl, is in present-day Pueblo, Mexico. Many of the pre-Columbian temples and pyramids were destroyed to build churches. The church of Nuestra Senora de los Remedios was built on the largest pyramid, the pyramid of Tipanipa. In the distance is the volcano of Orizaba or Popocatepetl. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: The Kicker Rocks
Description: View of the Kicker Rocks.
Source_Title: A narrative of the Briton's voyage to Pitcairn's island ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the Author by J. W. Marriott, And Published by Law and Whitaker, Ave Maria Lane, London ...
notes: Kicker Rocks is described as being off of Charles Island (presently known as Floreana Island or Santa Maria) in the Galapagos Islands, in present-day Ecuador.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Views of Lima and Callao]
Description: Views of a lady of Lima, a sepulcher or grave for children in Lima, a view of Lima from Callao roads, and a view of Callao. Includes fortifications, ships, dwellings, and funerary structure.
Source_Title: A narrative of the Briton's voyage to Pitcairn's island ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the Author by J. W. Marriott, And Published by Law and Whitaker, Ave Maria Lane, London ...

Image_title: Pongo i Manseriche.
Description: View of a village on the Marañón River. Includes dwellings (one in European style), men poling a raft down the river, and a man in European dress walking with a native American woman who leads a child by the hand and carries a child in a basket on her back.
Source_Title: Jorden och dess invânare, historisk tafla af det adertonde ârhundradets upptäckter om fremmande folkslag och länder; ... Guiana, Peru, Paraguay och Tukuman.
Source_publisher: hos Zacharias Haeggström
notes: The Pongo de Manseriche is a gorge in northwestern Peru through which the Marañón River runs before it reaches the Amazon basin. First discovered by Europeans in 1557, it was used by missionaries of Cuenca and Quito to reach their several convents on the Andean plateau. The Pongo, a native word for treacherous part of a river, is about 5-6 miles long, in places only 80 feet wide, and contains torrents and large whirlpools interspersed with rocks.Zimmermann, a much-honored and prolific polymath, traveled to Lapland, Russia, Sweden, Denmark, England, France, Switzerland, Italy, and in his native Germany. His writings on the Americas, however, are based on extensive reading in other sources such as Raleigh, Merian, Stedman, Fermin, von Rösel, Barrère, La Condamine, Bouguer, Humboldt, Van Berkel, Cabot, Helms, and Dobritzhoffer, among others. Issued as part 7 of Zimmermann's 13-volume travel series as published in Swedish, Stockholm, 1813-1839. A translation of part 6 of Die Erde und ihre Bewohner ... originally published in Leipzig, 1802-1818.Cf. Zimmermann, De aarde en hare bewoners, ... Haarlem, 1819 (03-88-2) for a re-engraved and reversed version of this image.
Provenance_Donor: Former collection of the Villiga Brandkârens Bibliotek.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Basilio Huaylas, en Rese fran Peru
Description: A very large native American man wearing a bicorn hat and carrying a walking stick stands next to a smaller man carrying and/or playing a musical instrument like a portable harp.
Source_Title: Jorden och dess invânare, historisk tafla af det adertonde ârhundradets upptäckter om fremmande folkslag och länder; ... Guiana, Peru, Paraguay och Tukuman.
Source_publisher: hos Zacharias Haeggström
notes: Basilio Huaylas was a "giant" who lived in Peru. He was 7 feet 2 inches tall, weighed 362 pounds, and came from the province of Castro-Virreyna. The arpa indígena, a musical instrument, was used by the mestizo and native Andean population of Peru. It had been brought to South America by Spanish missionaries who encouraged its use.Zimmermann, a much-honored and prolific polymath, traveled to Lapland, Russia, Sweden, Denmark, England, France, Switzerland, Italy, and in his native Germany. His writings on the Americas, however, are based on extensive reading in other sources such as Raleigh, Merian, Stedman, Fermin, von Rösel, Barrère, La Condamine, Bouguer, Humboldt, Van Berkel, Cabot, Helms, and Dobritzhoffer, among others.Issued as part 7 of Zimmermann's 13-volume travel series as published in Swedish, Stockholm, 1813-1839. A translation of part 6 of Die Erde und ihre Bewohner ... originally published in Leipzig, 1802-1818.Cf. Skinner, The present state of Peru ... London, 1805 (05677-2).
Provenance_Donor: Former collection of the Villiga Brandkârens Bibliotek.

A translation of part 6 of Die Erde und ihre Bewohner ... originally published in Leipzig, 1802-1818.Cf. Skinner, The present state of Peru ... London, 1805 (05677-13).

Image_title: Merkwaardige Bruggen in Zuid-Amerika.
Description: Three bridges over a river that flows in a deeply cut channel: one bridge is a foot bridge; two employ a pulley system to transport a horse and a woman in a kind of litter over the river. Includes dwellings
Source_Title: De aarde en hare bewoners, volgens de nieuwste ontdekkingen, ... van landen en volken en van derzelver voortbrengsels en handel, ...

Description: View of a village on the Marañón River. Includes dwellings (one in European style), men poling a raft down the river, and a man in European dress walking with a native American woman who leads a child by the hand and carries a child in a basket on her back.

Image_title: [Native Americans of Patagonia.]
Description: Native Americans of Patagonia wearing skins are shown in mountainous landscape. Includes boats and wooden shelter with fire. Also includes boleadora.
Source_Title: Unterhaltungen über den Menschen ... Erster Theil
Source_publisher: gedruckt auf Kosten des Herausgebers
notes: Boleadoras were tools used by indigenous peoples of the Argentinean Pampas to hunt. Boleadoras consisted of two stones bound by a leather cord which were thrown and then used to lasso an animal. The gauchos, or cowboys, of Argentina later would refine this tool and make it their own.Gottlieb Tobias Wilhelm (1758-1811) was a Bavarian clergyman and naturalist in Augsburg. This book, an encyclopedic overview representing scientific knowledge of the time, included mankind in its delineation of natural history.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Patagonia (Argentina and Chile)

Image_title: [Fig. 132. Burial practices of the natives of Venezuela.]
Description: Native American men wearing feathered headdresses drink the powdered bones of men. In the background a body or corpse is burned on a pyre. Includes bowl, snake [?], drinking vessels, torches, and bowl.
Source_Title: Unterhaltungen über den Menschen ... Dritter Theil
Source_publisher: gedruckt auf Kosten des Herausgebers
notes: The Yanomami of Venezuelan Amazonian forest burn their dead and crush the bones remaining in the funeral pyre into ash powder which they then drink to internalize their ancestors' power.Gottlieb Tobias Wilhelm (1758-1811) was a Bavarian clergyman and naturalist in Augsburg. This book, an encyclopedic overview representing scientific knowledge of the time, included mankind in its delineation of natural history.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Venezuela--Funeral customs and rites

Image_title: [Fig. 133. Burial practices of the natives of Paria.]
Description: Native American men lower a body or corpse into a grave while women mourn around them. Food for the dead man is laid near the grave. In the background, men and women dance around a hammock with a body in it. Also includes dwellings.
Source_Title: Unterhaltungen über den Menschen ... Dritter Theil
Source_publisher: gedruckt auf Kosten des Herausgebers
notes: Image derived from Theodor de Bry, America, pt 10, plate 1, which shows the natives of Paria in present-day Venezuela. The sick were put into hammocks around which people danced all day and if they died, they were buried with food and water to help them on their journey to the next world.Gottlieb Tobias Wilhelm (1758-1811) was a Bavarian clergyman and naturalist in Augsburg. This book, an encyclopedic overview representing scientific knowledge of the time, included mankind in its delineation of natural history.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Venezuela--Funeral customs and rites

Image_title: [Fig. 145. Burial practices of the natives of Peru.]
Description: Native American men lower a body or corpse into a grave while women mourn around them. Food and supplies for the dead man are laid in the grave. Also includes dwellings and feathered garments.
Source_Title: Unterhaltungen über den Menschen ... Dritter Theil
Source_publisher: gedruckt auf Kosten des Herausgebers
notes: Image derived from Theodor de Bry, America, part 6, plate 26, which shows native American burial practices of the Inca chiefs or rulers. The noble was buried with good food to help him along on his way to the next world. Benzoni alledged to have seen the burial of Huayna-Capac in the province near Quito, Peru.Gottlieb Tobias Wilhelm (1758-1811) was a Bavarian clergyman and naturalist in Augsburg. This book, an encyclopedic overview representing scientific knowledge of the time, included mankind in its delineation of natural history.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Peru--Funeral customs and rites

Image_title: [Fig. 147. Burial practices of the natives of the Orinoco River.]
Description: Native American men dig up skeleton from its grave. A woman and child view skeletons hanging in a house. Also includes scenes of men in boats, men collecting fish in nets, and men climbing ladders to tree houses.
Source_Title: Unterhaltungen über den Menschen ... Dritter Theil
Source_publisher: gedruckt auf Kosten des Herausgebers
notes: Image derived from Theodor de Bry, America, part 8, plate 14, which shows how the natives of the Orinoco delta live in tree houses because of the water level. When their chiefs died, they buried the corpse until it had decomposed enough, after which they would dig up the skeleton, adorn it with feathers, and hang it up in their houses.Gottlieb Tobias Wilhelm (1758-1811) was a Bavarian clergyman and naturalist in Augsburg. This book, an encyclopedic overview representing scientific knowledge of the time, included mankind in its delineation of natural history.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectHeadings1: Indians of South America--Orinoco River Valley (Venezuela and Colombia)--Funeral customs and rites

Source_Title: Jorden och dess invânare, historisk tafla af det adertonde ârhundradets upptäckter om fremmande folkslag och länder; ... Guiana, Peru, Paraguay och Tukuman.
Source_publisher: hos Zacharias Haeggström

His writings on the Americas, however, are based on extensive reading in other sources such as Raleigh, Merian, Stedman, Fermin, von Rösel, Barrère, La Condamine, Bouguer, Humboldt, Van Berkel, Cabot, Helms, and Dobritzhoffer, among others.Issued as part 7 of Zimmermann's 13-volume travel series as published in Swedish, Stockholm, 1813-1839. Image_title: Charles-Marie de la Condamine.
Description: Portrait of Charles-Marie de la Condamine.
Source_Title: Jorden och dess invânare, historisk tafla af det adertonde ârhundradets upptäckter om fremmande folkslag och länder; ... Guiana, Peru, Paraguay och Tukuman.
Source_publisher: hos Zacharias Haeggström
notes: La Condamine, explorer, physicist, and advocate of smallpox innoculation, went to South America in 1735 to measure a meridian that would establish the flattening of the Earth toward its poles. In 1743 he made a four-month raft trip down the Amazon River. Issued as part 7 of Zimmermann's 13-volume travel series as published in Swedish, Stockholm, 1813-1839. A translation of part 6 of Die Erde und ihre Bewohner ... originally published in Leipzig, 1802-1818. Cf. Zimmermann, De aarde en hare bewoners, ... Haarlem, 1819 (#03-88-2) for a re-engraved and reversed version of this image.
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 2003. Former collection of the Villiga Brandkârens Bibliotek.

Image_title: [Potosí]
Description: View of the town of Potosí showing the church at the summit and the town at the foot of a mountain. Also includes windmills, palms, and dwellings. Men converse in the foreground.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: The mines at Potosí were discovered by Diego Hualca in 1544. The silver mines there were among the richest in the world. Cf. 03390-1 and 01631-7. Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Indians play chueca]
Description: Native Americans play a game of chueca, a game similar to field hockey. Includes sticks, ball, feathered headdresses. A basket and laundry or clothing hangs on tree.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: The word "chueca" means curved stick in Mapuche and was played as a ritual celebration with prayer, dancing, and feasting. Europeans disapproved of the game; often it was followed by drinking of chincha and drunkenness. This image is derived from Alonso de Ovalle, Historica relacion del reyno de Chile, Rome, 1646. Cf. 0875-3 and 06454-5. Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [South American monkeys]
Description: Various South American monkeys. One holds a peapod, another black monkey holds a fruit. Items in the image are numbered for identification in followinging text. Includes (1) Cappucino dell'Orenoco (capuchin monkey of the Orinoco) (2) Simia Melanocephala (Cacajao or uakari monkey), (3) Seniculus or simia ursina (red howler monkey).
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: The monkeys are derived from illustrations from Alexander von Humboldt. One is probably a Humboldt's woolly monkey (Lagothrix lagothricha). The red howler monkey is Alouatta seniculus. Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Indians passing through the Andes]
Description: Native Americans or cargueroes walk through a valley. A woman is carried in a chair by a porter while she reads a book.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: Text describes the scene as being of the valley of Quindiu near Ibague. Nevado del Quindío is a volcano in the Andes of central Colombia. In the background is the volcanic Tolima mountain and the river is the Combeima. Narrative taken from Alexander von Humboldt's journey. Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Pizarro captures the Inca]
Description: Spanish soldier grasps a native American ruler or king. Includes scene of warfare, horses, monk holding a crucifix, swords, helmets, book, and flag.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: Text describes the incident when a monk named Vicente de Valverde confronted Atahualpa with a crucifix and a breviary. When Atahualpa asked how the Spanish knew what the teachings of God were, Valverde said the book spoke of them. The king took the book, turned the pages, said it did not speak of anything, and threw it on the ground. At this point, Pizarro and his men charged into the crowds which panicked and were slaughtered. Atahualpa was thrown from his litter and taken prisoner.Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Guaicurù Indians]
Description: Native Americans or Guaicurù ford a stream or river. The woman carries a baby on her shoulders and guides two other children. The man carries spears and a dead animal. Includes auriculated ears and lip ornaments.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Guarani Indians]
Description: Native Americans or Guarani address a young woman who points to something. Includes feathered headdresses, skins, bows, and arrows. Also includes a dwelling made of palms.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: Text describes the Guarani Indians and how they are governed by the Jesuits. Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Jesuit Indians of Paraguay]
Description: Native American women spin yarn inside a barn while a man drives cattle or oxen [for plowing]. Another man holds a spear or shovel. Also includes a statue of the Virgin Mary and Christ child.
Source_Title: Il costume antico e moderno ... [Parte seconda]
Source_publisher: Dalla tipografia dell 'editore
notes: Text describes the Guarani Indians and how they are governed by the Jesuits. Series edited by Giulio Ferrario. The title page identifies the illustrator as Giuseppe Erba Odescalchi. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: [Palenque relief. Two roundels.]
Description: (Top) Roundel depicting a snake winding itself around a tree in a landscape. Includes bird. (Bottom) Roundel depicting a nude man wearing only a cap in a landscape and looking into the mouth of a huge animal with the head of the same kind of animal behind him.
Source_Title: Description of the ruins of an ancient city discovered near Palenque in the kingdom of Guatemala, ...
Source_publisher: By Henry Berthoud, No. 65, Regent's Quadrant, Piccadilly; and Suttaby, Evance and Fox, Stationer's Court.
notes: Antonio del Rio, an artillery captain, was sent by the Spanish crown in May of 1786 to verify persistent rumors of the site of an ancient city near Santo Domingo del Palenque and to determine the origins of its inhabitants. He suggested that the people of that city, Palenque, had been Phoenicians. He took with him Ricardo Almendáriz who made 30 drawings of what was found. Although Rio's manuscript, a report to Don Jose Estacheria (Governor and Commandant General of Guatemala), has been preserved in Madrid, Almendáriz's original drawings were just recently rediscovered in a private European collection. The original drawings had been copied and executed as line lithographs for this publication by Jean Frederic Maxmilien de Waldeck.

Image_title: D. F. Bartolomé de las Casas, obispo de Chiapa en America, defensor de la libertad de los Indios.
Description: Portrait of Bartolomé de las Casas wearing clerical attire. He sits at a desk writing with a quill. Also includes bishop's miter, books, and inkwell.
Source_Title: [Works. Spanish] Coleccion de las obras del venerable obispo de Chiapa, Don Bartolomé de las Casas ... Tomo primero
Source_publisher: En casa de Rosa, librero, gran patio del Palacio-Real y calle de Montpensier, no. 5
notes: One of the first to vilify the Spanish as cruel exploiters of the Indians, Bartolomé de las Casas, the bishop of Chiapas, vehemently condemned maltreatment of the Indians. His writings enforced an enduring set of of ideas known as the Black Legend and sanctioned Protestant retaliation against Catholic countries, especially Spain.

Image_title: View of the Port of Black River in the Territory of Poyais.
Description: View of the place where the Black River empties into the Caribbean in Honduras. Includes dwellings, ship, and boats.
Source_Title: Sketch of the Mosquito Shore, including the territory of Poyais, descriptive of the country; with some information as to its production, the best mode of culture, & c. ... chiefly intended for the use of settlers.
Source_publisher: Sold by William Blackwood, Edinburgh; and T. Cadell, Strand, London.
notes: After the Central American states gained their independance from Spain in 1821, they were too weak to assert their control over the Indian tribes. Thus the Mosquito Indians (a group composed of native Americans and escaped slaves) were able to act on their own. They had long preferred the friendship of the British to that of the Spanish, and the British had laid claim to a large part of the Caribbean coast of Central America since the early eighteenth century. On April 29, 1820 a Mosquito king, George Frederick, made a grant of land to Gregor McGregor, a Scottish adventurer who had offered his services to Bolívar and the Spanish-American colonists of Colombia and Venezuela who fought to gain their independence from Spain. The territory was near the Black River and the Poyer Mountains of Honduras. McGregor returned to Scotland in 1820 to induce settlers to buy land in Poyais; he also issued banknotes on his non-existent bank. After the deaths of many settlers and McGregor's realization that no more money would be made from his scheme, he prevailed upon Venezuela to grant him a salary based on his former service. He died in Caracas in 1845. This is a fanciful piece of merchandising, since the area was a deserted, overgrown, unpopulated former settlement. The Black River is also called Rio Tinto, Negro, or also Poyer or Poyas. Image placed horizontally on page.
References: Alfred Hasbrouck, Gregor McGregor and the Colonization of Poyais, between 1820 and 1824, The Hispanic American Historical Review, Vol. 7, No. 4 (Nov., 1927), pp. 438-459
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Zea.
Description: Half-length portrait of Francisco Antonio Zea wearing a fur-collared coat. Includes books, quills, inkwells, curtain, and piece of paper with "Republic of Columbia" printed on it.
Source_Title: Colombia, being a geographical, statistical, agricultural, commercial, and political account of that country, adapted for the general reader, the merchant, and the colonist.
Source_publisher: Published by Baldwin, Cradock, and Joy.
notes: Zea was a Colombian botanist and revolutionary. He was arrested in 1795 for distributing copies of The Declaration of the Rights of Man and was imprisoned in Spain. He returned to South America to help Simón Bolívar and in 1819 was made vice president of Venezuela. He resigned to become president of the Congress of Angostura and was later vice president of Greater Colombia. He wrote a history of Colombia and works on botany. Zea died in Bath, England.Engraver is probably William Thomas Fry, British engraver, 1789-1843.

Source_publisher: Sold by William Blackwood, Edinburgh; and T. Cadell, Strand, London.
notes: After the Central American states gained their independance from Spain in 1821, they were too weak to assert their control over the Indian tribes. Thus the Mosquito Indians (a group composed of native Americans and escaped slaves) were able to act on their own. They had long preferred the friendship of the British to that of the Spanish, and the British had laid claim to a large part of the Caribbean coast of Central America since the early eighteenth century. On April 29, 1820, a Mosquito king, George Frederick, made a grant of land to Gregor McGregor, a Scottish adventurer who had offered his services to Bolívar and the Spanish-American colonists of Colombia and Venezuela who fought to gain their independence from Spain. The territory was near the Black River and the Poyer Mountains of Honduras. McGregor returned to Scotland in 1820 to induce settlers to buy land in Poyais; he also issued banknotes on his non-existent bank. After the deaths of many settlers and McGregor's realization that no more money would be made from his scheme, he prevailed upon Venezuela to grant him a salary based on his former service. He died in Caracas in 1845. The artist may be Simon Jacques Rochard, French miniaturist, 1788-1872.

Image_title: VR del Seño[r] Cristo aparecido en las cuevas de S. Mig[ue]l de Chalma de los R[eligioso]s. Agusti[nos]. de Mejico.
Description: Image of Christ Crucified [Cristo renovado] on an altar with monstrances and candlesticks.
Source_Title: Alabado que en el Real Santuario de Chalma cantan los peregrinos a Nuestro Señor Jesucristo crucificado ...
Source_publisher: Reimpreso en la oficina de Ontiveros
notes: Now the second most visited Christan holy place in Mexico, Chalma originally had a sacred cave with a statue of Ozteotl [Oztoteotl], the Dark Lord of the Cave. In 1539, Fray Nicholás de Perea gave a sermon to the Indians. Three days later the statue was in pieces, replaced by a life-size image of a black Christ Crucified. In 1683, the image was placed in a church especially consecrated for its worship. In the eighteenth century the image was destroyed by fire.

Image_title: Tiger hunt by the Gaouchos, or natives of Paraguay.
Description: A gaucho mounted on a horse is about to lasso a large wild cat, probably a jaguar. The gaucho wears a woolen poncho.
Source_Title: Narrative of a voyage round the world in the Uranie and Physicienne corvettes, commanded by Captain Freycinet, during the years 1817, 1818, 1819, and 1820; ...
Source_publisher: Treuttel and Wurtz, Treuttel, Jun. and Richter, 30, Soho-Square
notes: The letter discussing the lives of the gauchos was written from Montevideo, Uruguay. Gauchos were most often South Americans of Spanish descent or of mixed Spanish and native American blood.In 1817, Arago obtained permission from the French government to sail on the Uranie as draughtsman. That ship was lost in the Malouine or Falkland Islands.Image placed horizontally on page.

notes: This tertulia or social gathering took place at a village called Asiento de Guasco or Santa Rosa. Yerba or erva maté is a drink made from the boiled leaves of a shrub of the holly family. It is often shared and drunk from a gourd with a metal straw.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Silver and Copper Works.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: Workers refine silver and copper. Includes mill with undershot water wheel, furnaces, men treading on ore, and women washing and bagging ore at the end of the process.
Source_Title: Travels into Chile, over the Andes, in the years 1820 and 1821, with some sketches of the productions and agriculture; mines and metallurgy; inhabitants, history, and other features, of America; particularly of Chile, and Arauco.
Source_publisher: Printed by S. McDowall, 95, Leadenhall Street, for the author; and published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, & Green, Paternoster Row.
notes: In the process of refining ore by amalgamation, crushed silver ore was mixed with salt, dung, and mercury, poured out on ox hides, and trodden on until the silver was saturated with mercury. The resulting paste was then heated and washed to remove all earthy matter. The mixture was placed in bags and the mercury squeezed out. Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Exhibition of Antient Mexico at the Egyptian-Hall Piccadilly
Description: View of an exhibition hall of Mexican or Aztec antiquities, including a calendar stone, pillars, statues, and people. Includes statues of Coatlicue.
Source_Title: A description of the unique exhibition, called Ancient Mexico ...
Source_publisher: Printed for the proprietor J. Bullock, Lombard-Street, Fleet-Street
notes: Egyptian Hall was built by William Bullock (1775-1840) in 1812 and was demolished in 1905; in 1824 he showed some of the artifacts he acquired during a trip to Mexico the previous year. The text describes the items found in the exhibition. During the 1780s and 1790s, major archeological discoveries were unearthed during renovations to the square or Zócalo in Mexico City--the Coatlicue statue and the Aztec calendar stone or the "piedra del sol". The Aztec calendar "sunstone" is a thirteen-and-a-half foot, basalt relief representation of the Mexica creation myth and not, strictly speaking, a calendar. Bullock was able to obtain a plaster cast of the stone and brought it to England for his exhbition. Publisher information taken from colophon.
References: http://www.georgianindex.net/Bullocks/Egyptian_Hall.html (Aug. 2005); Bullock, W. Six months' residence ... in Mexico, p. 334-341

notes: The Maipo River is south of Santiago; the Mapocho River divides the city of Santiago in two. Text includes detailed information on building methods, etc.

Source_Title: Travels into Chile, over the Andes, in the years 1820 and 1821, with some sketches of the productions and agriculture; mines and metallurgy; inhabitants, history, and other features, of America; particularly of Chile, and Arauco.
Source_publisher: Printed by S. McDowall, 95, Leadenhall Street, for the author; and published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, & Green, Paternoster Row.
notes: Text notes that this has been the site of volcanic activity, and the two rocky formations show where the earth's crust split open. It is also the site of played out silver mines. The Mendoza River flows from between the mountains into the valley. Uspallata Pass is about 12,500 feet high and is between Mendoza Argentina and Santiago Chile.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Bridge of the Incas.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: View of a natural rock bridge among mountains. Includes stalactites, river, hut, and travelers.
Source_Title: Travels into Chile, over the Andes, in the years 1820 and 1821, with some sketches of the productions and agriculture; mines and metallurgy; inhabitants, history, and other features, of America; particularly of Chile, and Arauco.
Source_publisher: Printed by S. McDowall, 95, Leadenhall Street, for the author; and published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, & Green, Paternoster Row.
notes: Also known as Puente del Inca, this famous bridge is in Argentina between Las Cuevas and Punta de Vacas. The "bridge" has stalactites hanging from it, and the area has hot springs. It spans the Vacas River which later becomes the Mendoza River. Author notes that the image was done from memory, and that its elements were rearranged in order to make the space more comprehensible.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plan of the Post Road between Buenos Ayres and Santiago de Chile.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: Map of the post road between Santiago, Chile, and Buenos Aires (Buenos Ayres), Argentina. Cartographic elements include compass rose, topographical features, names of rivers, lakes, and settlements, statements of degrees of latitude and longitude, location of legendary giants and the pampas.
Source_Title: Travels into Chile, over the Andes, in the years 1820 and 1821, with some sketches of the productions and agriculture; mines and metallurgy; inhabitants, history, and other features, of America; particularly of Chile, and Arauco.
Source_publisher: Printed by S. McDowall, 95, Leadenhall Street, for the author; and published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, & Green, Paternoster Row.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Baths of Cauquenes.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: Night view of the baths at Cauquenes, Chile. Two native Americans smoke and warm themselves by a campfire near a river. A large building and smaller ones surrounding it are found on a hill behind them. Includes mule.
Source_Title: Travels into Chile, over the Andes, in the years 1820 and 1821, with some sketches of the productions and agriculture; mines and metallurgy; inhabitants, history, and other features, of America; particularly of Chile, and Arauco.
Source_publisher: Printed by S. McDowall, 95, Leadenhall Street, for the author; and published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, & Green, Paternoster Row.
notes: Text states that the river is the Caciapoal (or Cahapoal) and that the baths are located in the smaller buildings. The baths are still in use and have been famous since the seventeenth century.James Paroissien was an Englishman of Huguenot ancestry who went to South America in 1806. He was instrumental in the wars of liberation, working closely with José de San Martín and helping to gain recognition and loans for the newly independent Latin American countries in Europe.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: The Mint of Santiago.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: View of a street in Santiago, Chile, with a variety of citizens going about their daily activities. The mint is on the right and its stable is on the left. Includes horses, mule, and mountains.
Source_Title: Travels into Chile, over the Andes, in the years 1820 and 1821, with some sketches of the productions and agriculture; mines and metallurgy; inhabitants, history, and other features, of America; particularly of Chile, and Arauco.
Source_publisher: Printed by S. McDowall, 95, Leadenhall Street, for the author; and published by Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, & Green, Paternoster Row.
notes: Text describes the people as a woman going to mass with her servant, a monk, two Englishmen, a Chilean in his visiting dress, a man and woman each riding richly outfitted horses, and a detachment of the life guards.James Paroissien was an Englishman of Huguenot ancestry who went to South America in 1806. He was instrumental in the wars of liberation, working closely with José de San Martín and helping to gain recognition and loans for the newly independent Latin American countries in Europe.Image placed horizontally on page.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: El General Javier Mina, ...
Description: Portrait of Francisco Javier Mina wearing a military uniform and drawing a sword from its scabbard. Includes cannon and fortification.
Source_Title: [Memoirs of the Mexican Revolution. Spanish] Memorias de la revolucion de Megico, y de la espedicion del general D. Francisco Javier Mina ...
Source_publisher: Las publica R. Ackermann, no. 101, Strand, Londres.
notes: Francisco Javier Mina (1789-1817) was a Spanish lawyer and army officer. He fought the French after Napoleonic forces invaded Spain, but when Ferdinand VII retook the throne, Mina objected to the lack of democracy in Spain. In order to fight the Spanish monarchy, he went to Galveston, Texas, to attack Spanish shipping in the Gulf of Mexico. He then went south to Mexico where he joined the revolutionaries and effected several victories before being defeated and captured. He was executed by firing squad in 1817 in Mexico City.Robinson's eyewitness account of the Mexican revolution is one of first made available in English.

Image_title: Sea Leopard of South Orkney's.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: Spotted seal on an ice floe with two ships in the background.
Source_Title: A voyage towards the South Pole, performed in the years 1822-24. Containing ... a visit to Tierra del Fuego, with a particular account of the inhabitants ...
Source_publisher: Printed for Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green, Paternoster-Row
notes: Weddell made his voyages as captain of the Jane (a refitted American ship) in search of new sealing grounds. His 1822-24 voyage was his third to the Antarctic area. He was accompanied by the ship Beaufoy commanded by Matthew Brisbane. Since seals were scarce, both ships sailed farther south in hopes of finding better grounds. In an unusually ice-free year, they reached latitude 74o 15' S, a feat not repeated until 1967.This animal is either a true leopard seal, Hydrurga leptonyx, or the Weddell seal, Leptonychotes weddellii, which actually has spots. This drawing is of an animal in the collection of the Edinburgh Museum.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Man and Woman of Terra del Fuego.
Image_publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
Description: Male and female native Americans of Tierra del Fuego. Each wears a cloak of skins with the fur side in.
Source_Title: A voyage towards the South Pole, performed in the years 1822-24. Containing ... a visit to Tierra del Fuego, with a particular account of the inhabitants ...
Source_publisher: Printed for Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green, Paternoster-Row
notes: Weddell made his voyages as captain of the Jane (a refitted American ship) in search of new sealing grounds. His 1822-24 voyage was his third to the Antarctic area. He was accompanied by the ship Beaufoy commanded by Matthew Brisbane. Since seals were scarce, both ships sailed farther south in hopes of finding better grounds. In an unusually ice-free year, they reached latitude 74o 15' S, a feat not repeated until 1967.The Fuegians were invited aboard ship and given gifts. Text notes their minimal clothing and the fact that their bodies were covered with a red ochre color. Weddell speculated that some of them may have been partly Spanish. The crews had extensive contact with the natives.Image placed horizontally on page.

Image_title: Mode of conducting Traffic by Carts between Mendosa & Buenos Ayres.

Source_publisher: Printed for Baldwin, Cradock, and Joy

Image_title: Aucas et leurs Toldos à la Bahià blanca, et vue de la sierra de la Ventana.
Description: Native Americans, one using a boleadora, stand with a horse in front of their huts.
Source_Title: [Voyage dans l'Amérique méridionale] Voyage dans l'Amérique méridionale (le Brésil, ... l'Uruguay, la République argentine, la Patagonie, la république du Chili, la république de Bolivia, la république du Pérou) ... Tome troisième

notes: The Aucas are a Pampas native American tribe and should not be confused with the Aucas or Huaorani, an Ecuadorean Amazon tribe. Boleadoras were tools used by indigenous peoples of the Argentinian Pampas to hunt. A boleadora consisted of two stones bound by a leather cord which were thrown and then used to trip an animal. The gauchos, or cowboys, of Argentina later would refine this tool and make it their own. Originally issued in 90 fascicles between 1834 and 1847; typically bound in 7 to 11 volumes. Source_Title: [Voyage dans l'Amérique méridionale] Voyage dans l'Amérique méridionale (le Brésil, ... l'Uruguay, la République argentine, la Patagonie, la république du Chili, la république de Bolivia, la république du Pérou) ... Tome troisième
Source_publisher: Chez P. Bertrand, éditeur ... ; Chez Veuve. LeVrault ...
notes: Probably vases made by the Moche or Mochica Indians of Peru or Bolivia whose impressive pottery is the major indication of the sophistication of their civilization.Originally issued in 90 fascicles between 1834 and 1847; typically bound in 7 to 11 volumes.

Image_title: Indiennes Chagas à Cobija. (Bolivia.)

Image_title: facsimile [Boban Aztec Calendar Wheel]
Description: Symbolic representation of the months and day of the Aztec year with explanatory text in Nahuatl language transcribed into European script. At top left of the interior circle is a depiction of Hernando decor [Hernán Cortés?] wearing a black Spanish hat seated on a blue circle [the Lake of Mexico?], at top right is Don Antonio Pimentel [son of Ixtlilxochitl, an ally of Cortés, and last native king of Tezcuco] seated on a representation of a mountain [the Sierras of Acolhuan]. In the middle is an image of Netzcualcoyotl [the king of Acolhuan], and Itzcohuatl [his ally, the king of Mexico]. Each are enthroned with their symbol in front of them. At bottom, are depictions of the ancient Chichimecas, founders of the Tezcuco empire, or native Americans, who sit before a sacrificial fire which rises to the sun.
Source_Title: Archives de la commission scientifique de Mexique, vol. 3, p. 120-133
notes: The Boban Calendar, named after Eugène Boban, a French archeologist and collector, was brought to general attention in 1866 when Colonel Doutrelaine published a reproduction and explanation of the calendar in Archives de la commission scientifique de Mexique, Paris, 1866-1867, vol. 3, p. 120-133. Because of deterioration, the reproduction made in 1866 shows much greater detail than the original. The names of the months are written in Nahuatl (but with Castilian characters); the months are given different symbols than are usually present on other Aztec calendars. This accession number has been assigned for the purpose of collocation only; the item bears no accession number.
References: Archives de la commission scientifique de Mexique, Paris, 1866-1867, vol. 3, p. 120-133; Robertson, D. Mexican manuscript painting, p. 146-149, fig. 51

Image_title: Panama & Gulf of Vallona
Description: Chart of the Pacific coast of Panama and the Gulf of Vallona, with Captain Bartholomew Sharpe's route down the coast. Cartographic elements include scale, sea banks or shoals, location of rivers and islands, some topographical details, and compass rose.
Source_Title: An accurate description of all the harbours rivers ports islands sands rocks and dangers between the mouth of California and the straits of Lemaire in the south sea of America ...
notes: This map was made by William Hack, a London map and chart maker, from a collection of Spanish charts captured by the English privateer, Captain Bartholomew Sharpe, when his ship, Trinity, seized the Spanish ship, Rosario, off the coast of Ecuador in 1681. Among the booty seized was a derrotero, or a volume of manuscript charts of the coast with detailed sailing directions, captured as it was about to be thrown overboard. Hack copied this work for the British crown and called it the South Sea Wagoner. Hack never published his atlas (it was thought to be too important to grant access to the information in it), he did, however, make a number of copies.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1966, p. 21-25, 45-52
References_exhibitions: Hattendorf, J.B. Boundless Deep, Fig. 5.6
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 1966. Originally in the possession of John Cleveland, secretary of the Admiralty.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Great River of Guayaquil]
Description: Chart of the river of Guayaquil, in present-day Ecuador. Includes the mountains of Pucará from which much gold dust is gathered after rains. Cartographic elements include sea banks or shoals, location of rivers, islands, and a bridge, and some topographical details. Also includes indications of dwellings, churches, and settlements.
Source_Title: An accurate description of all the harbours rivers ports islands sands rocks and dangers between the mouth of California and the straits of Lemaire in the south sea of America ...
notes: This map was made by William Hack, a London map and chart maker, from a collection of Spanish charts captured by the English privateer, Captain Bartholomew Sharpe, when his ship, Trinity, seized the Spanish ship, Rosario, off the coast of Ecuador in 1681. Among the booty seized was a derrotero, or a volume of manuscript charts of the coast with detailed sailing directions, captured as it was about to be thrown overboard. Hack copied this work for the British crown and called it the South Sea Wagoner. Hack never published his atlas (it was thought to be too important to grant access to the information in it), he did, however, make a number of copies.
References: John Carter Brown Library, Annual Report, 1966, p. 21-25, 45-52
Provenance_Donor: Acquired in 1966. Originally in the possession of John Cleveland, secretary of the Admiralty.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Polar projection of Antarctica]
