Image_title: Parte della Nuova Spagna, ò del Mexico doue sono le Prouincie di Guadalaira Xalisco Mecoacan e Mexico
Description: Map of part of Mexico. Cartographic elements include degrees of latitude and longitude, scales, and some topographical details. Decorative cartouche at top includes the gods, Neptune with trident, Mercury with caduceus, and Mars in armor, as well as a globe, books, and two hippocampi (or fish-tailed horses of the sea). Decorative cartouche at bottom includes angels, cannon, drums, horns, and flags.
SubjectArea2: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Cross on hill, dwelling near water]
Description: Cross on a hill and dwelling (perhaps the council house of the pueblo) near water.
notes: This codex, known as the Codex Coyoacán, is from a pueblo called Santa Maria Tetelpan [perhaps no longer extant] in Oaxaca, Mexico. It was written in council and confirms the property borders and rights of the indigenous peoples of the town. This is one of a number of codices known as the Techialoyan codices which record early eighteenth-century native Mexican land ownership history. Though not of the early Conquest era as is stated in the narrative (either 1525 or 1545), it is now considered to be not so much a forgery, as a fairly accurate statement of landholding probably compiled from pre-Columbian or early colonial pictorial documents and oral traditions and created in the period between circa 1700 and 1743.
References: Robertson, D. "Techialoyan manuscripts," Handbook of Middle American Indians, vol. XIV, 253-280

Image_title: [Ancient Mexicans and lake]
Description: Native Americans of ancient Mexico. Cultural artifacts include spears, bow, arrows, sandals, skin garments, and feathered headdresses.
notes: This codex, known as the Codex Coyoacán, is from a pueblo called Santa Maria Tetelpan [perhaps no longer extant] in Oaxaca, Mexico. notes: [At left], the man and woman are identified in text as Don Simon Ilhuitltemoc and Dona Ana Teçoçomoctzin. [At right], the man holding the staff is perhaps Don Miguel, Fiscal of the village. Image_title: [Church with six dwellings and a pine woods]
Description: [At left] church with six dwellings and [at right] a pine woods.
notes: Translation of text, [at left], "Here is situate and named the Pueblo which has as patron Our Lady the Virgin Maria, on the edge and limit of the woodland country." [At right], "The territory of the Sons of the Pueblo which is found in the place called Ycsocalan (the Place of the Pine-woods) consists of 800 mecates linear." This codex, known as the Codex Coyoacán, is from a pueblo called Santa Maria Tetelpan [perhaps no longer extant] in Oaxaca, Mexico. It was written in council and confirms the property borders and rights of the indigenous peoples of the town. Image_title: [Mexican man and woman under a tree and two Mexican men]
Description: [At left] Native American man and woman of ancient Mexico wearing skins and sitting under a tree. The man carries a net and pole and is possibly fishing. [At right]Two noble Mexicans wearing knee-length dress, tunic, and sandals.
notes: Translation of text [at left] "This place bears the name Tlamaya, where the territory belonging to the Sons of the Pueblo consists of 800 mecates linear." [at right], "Sons of the Pueblo, Don Miguel de Santa Maria, Dona Bartholo Chimaltzin." This is one of a number of codices known as the Techialoyan codices which record early eighteenth-century native Mexican land ownership history. Though not of the early Conquest era as is stated in the narrative (either 1525 or 1545), it is now considered to be not so much a forgery, as a fairly accurate statement of landholding probably compiled from pre-Columbian or early colonial pictorial documents and oral traditions and created in the period between circa 1700 and 1743.
References: Robertson, D. "Techialoyan manuscripts," Handbook of Middle American Indians, vol. XIV, 253-280

Image_title: [Two Mexican men]
Description: Two native Americans of ancient Mexico wearing skin garments and sandals and carrying spears, bow, and arrows.
notes: This codex, known as the Codex Coyoacán, is from a pueblo called Santa Maria Tetelpan [perhaps no longer extant] in Oaxaca, Mexico. It was written in council and confirms the property borders and rights of the indigenous peoples of the town. This is one of a number of codices known as the Techialoyan codices which record early eighteenth-century native Mexican land ownership history. Image_title: [Two deer climb a mountain, a Mexican and European discourse]
Description: Two deer climb a mountain covered by trees and thorn bushes. Two men, one Mexican and one European [?], wearing knee-length dress, tunic, and sandals, talk to one another.
notes: Translation of text, "The territory which is found in the place called Huitztla (place of thorn scrub) consists of 800 mecates." This codex, known as the Codex Coyoacán, is from a pueblo called Santa Maria Tetelpan [perhaps no longer extant] in Oaxaca, Mexico. It was written in council and confirms the property borders and rights of the indigenous peoples of the town. This is one of a number of codices known as the Techialoyan codices which record early eighteenth-century native Mexican land ownership history. Though not of the early Conquest era as is stated in the narrative (either 1525 or 1545), it is now considered to be not so much a forgery, as a fairly accurate statement of landholding probably compiled from pre-Columbian or early colonial pictorial documents and oral traditions and created in the period between circa 1700 and 1743.

Image_title: [South polar projection]
Description: Map of south polar projection showing South America from the Tropic of Capricorn. Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude. Includes a scene at upper left of native American warfare and cooking, at lower left a native American woman giving her children birds to eat while men hunt in canoes in background, and at lower right, a native American man and woman standing next to a penguin while another hunts penguin in background.
notes: Scenes in the corners of the map are taken from Dutch explorers accounts. See Barent Jansz. Potgieter, VVijdtloopigh verhael, Amsterdam. 1600.This map is no. [117] in an atlas with binder's title, Atlas 2, and may have been published by Adriaan Braakman at the beginning of the eighteenth century.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Platte Grond van de Stad en Haven van Vera Crux.
Description: Map of the present-day city of Veracruz in the province of Veracruz, Mexico. Cartographic elements include compass rose, scale, locations of shoals or sea banks, soundings, names of islands, and plan of the city of Veracruz and fort of San Juan de Ulúa.
Source_Title: [Concise history of the Spanish America. Dutch] De tegenwoordige staat der volken van het Spaansche ryk in Amerika,
Source_publisher: by Bernardus Mourik, boekverkooper in de Nes.
notes: The city of Veracruz was founded by Hernán Cortés in 1519 when he landed there. It is the port from which the Spanish treasure fleet left for Spain. Starting in 1565, the fortress of San Juan de Ulúa was built on an island in the harbor in order to protect the port from pirates; it was expanded several times.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings3: Castillo de San Juan de Ulúa (Mexico)

Image_title: Platte Grond van de Stad en Haven van Porto Bello.
Description: Map of Portobelo, Panama, with its harbor. Cartographic elements include compass rose, scale, locations of shoals or sea banks, soundings, names of islands, locations of forts, and plan of the city of Portobelo. Includes inset plan of the city. Also includes ships.
Source_Title: [Concise history of the Spanish America. Dutch] De tegenwoordige staat der volken van het Spaansche ryk in Amerika, ...
Source_publisher: by Bernardus Mourik, boekverkooper in de Nes.
notes: Portobelo, also known as Puerto Bello and Porto Belo, was important as a port on the itinerary of the Spanish silver fleets. It was plundered by the pirate, Henry Morgan, in 1668, and it was taken by the British admiral, Edward Vernon, in the War of Jenkins' Ear in 1739.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Platte Grond van de Stad en Haven van Cartagena.
Description: Map of Cartagena, Colombia, with its harbor. Cartographic elements include compass rose, scale, locations of shoals or sea banks, soundings, fortifications, and names of islands. Items are lettered for identification in key at upper left.
Source_Title: [Concise history of the Spanish America. Dutch] De tegenwoordige staat der volken van het Spaansche ryk in Amerika, ...
Source_publisher: by Bernardus Mourik, boekverkooper in de Nes.
notes: Cartagena was founded in 1533 by Pedro de Heredia. This essentially walled city was attacked by pirates many times. Cartagena and Veracruz were the only Spanish cities allowed to trade in slaves. In 1741 the English admiral, Edward Vernon, failed to take the city in spite of his vastly superior forces.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Plano del Puerto de Sn. Carlos Situado en la parte Norte de la Isla de Chiloe ...
Description: Map and chart of the harbor of San Carlos or Saint Charles on the island of Chiloe (Isla Grande de Chiloé) off the coast of Chile. Cartographic elements include compass rose, soundings, locations of shoals, military installations, topographical details, and scale.
notes: Spain claimed the island in 1567, and a settlement was founded at Castro in 1567, later the seat of a Jesuit mission and capital of the province until the founding of Ancud in 1768. In 1784 Chiloé Island was made a direct dependency of the colonial viceroyalty of Peru, while continental Chile was a captaincy-general within the viceroyalty. In December 1817 the island became the last stronghold of Spanish loyalists (together with Valdivia) fleeing from the Chilean mainland. A Chilean expedition led by Thomas Cochrane, 10th Earl of Dundonald failed to conquer it. On 15 January 1826, after another unsuccessful attempt in 1824, the Spanish forces surrendered to a military expedition led by Ramon Freire, and the island was fully incorporated into the independent republic of Chile, although Spain did not recognize it until 1844. In atlas with binder's title Charts of America.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans
SubjectHeadings1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: [Concluye la Memoria sobre la Grana]
Description: Production of cochineal dye. Includes the insects being transferred from a basket into a vessel, being dried over fire and in the sun, and the dye packaged for shipment.
Source_Title: Gazeta de literatura de Mexico: Por D. Joseph Antonio Alzate ... tomo tercero.
Source_publisher: por Felipe de Zúñiga y Ontiveros, calle del Espíritu Santo
notes: Text describes how the cochineal insect, Dactylopius coccus, was used to make carmine dye. Items in the image are lettered for identification in preceding text.Image title taken from text, and the image is placed horizontally on the page. This serial was edited by Alzate y Ramírez, who was also the principle contributer. Volume 3 of this work was paged continuously (except for supplements and no. 43).

Description: Cochineal insects. Includes a woman gathering the insects from a cactus, with details of the insect on a leaf, a section of cactus, secretions extracted from a cocoon, and details of the insect's body.

Image_title: Mapa d[e]l Presidio d[e] San Antonio d[e] Bexar, i sus Misiones d[e]la Provinsia d[e] Texas ...
Description: Map of the presidio of San Antonio de Bexar.
notes: The presidio of San Antonio de Bexar, present-day San Antonio, was at the center of Spanish defense of western Texas and was founded in 1718. Luis Antonio Menchaca was captain of the garrison there and owner of one of the oldest and largest land grants in Texas.
References_exhibitions: Johnson, J. G. Book in the Americas, Fig. 78
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans

Image_title: Provincia Moxos Americ Meri e MS
Description: Map of part of South America including present-day Peru and Bolivia (here identified as Moxitania). Cartographic elements include lines of latitude and longitude, location of settlements, Lake Titicaca, and rivers. Decorative cartouche includes native American with feathered headdress and arrow.
Source_Title: Descriptio Provinciae Moxitarum in regno Peruano ...
Source_publisher: Typis Universitatis
notes: A fierce tribe of indigenous people who live in present-day Bolivia, the Mojos [Moxos] resisted Christianity until the late seventeenth century.
SubjectArea1: Geography, maps, city views and plans
